column2: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Newton N. Minow, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, suggested tonight that TV end "the virtual news blackout" during the prime viewing hours each night.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The index of average wholesale primary market prices rose 0.1 per cent during the week ended last Tuesday, to 118.7 per cent of its 1947-49 base, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Mr. Nixon today termed "false and libelous" Mr. Knight's charge that a Nixon friend had offered Mr. Knight any state job he wanted to stay out of the race for governor.

Mayor Wagner and Harold A. Felix, City Labor Commissioner, have urged the New York Philharmonic to continue its performances at Carnegie Hall during its negotiations with the Philharmonic management on a new contract.

THIRTEEN years ago an Italian boy 8 years old with a mop of curls framing his cherubic face, his short figure clad in a Lord Faunt leroy suit, made his United States debut conducting a professional orchestra in Carnegie Hall. His name was Ferruccio Burco.
Edward R. Dudley, the Borough President of Manhattan, declared yesterday that some tenements on East 101st Street were "not even habitable by human beings."
The market for United States Government securities was stronger in all sectors yesterday than on Thursday, recovering some of the snap of early trading sessions this week.
The Woodward Stakes, a horse race that has taken on the gloss of a major championship despite its relatively short existence, will be contested at Belmont Park today.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 29 (AP) -- The State Commissioner of Conservation took exception here today to a statement by Robert Moses that a measure urging, establishment of wilderness areas in the State Forest Preserve was a "trick bill hashed up by fanatics."

The auction-block manner in which builders and real estate operators who do business with the city were induced to contribute to Mayor Wagner's re-election is a flagrant illustration of the improprieties inherent in our chaotic system of financing Federal, state and municipal campaigns.
Between 1950 and 1960 1,293,508 more white persons moved out of the city than moved in, a study by the City Planning Department showed yesterday.

The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York and six upstate banks cleared the first hurdle yesterday in their path toward formation of a statewide holding company by winning approval for the proposal from the State Banking Board.
Park Department plans to construct a softball field and concrete bleachers in Tompkins Square Park were rejected Thursday night by residents of the area.
Warner Brothers' record offer of more than $5,500,000 for screen rights to "My Fair Lady" may represent a major change in Hollywood's attitude toward the future of large-scale musicals.

As Attorney General of this state Louis Lefkowitz has served with competence, courage and ability, and I am positive that he can bring to New York City's government the competence and ability which it so badly needs.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The Air Force today awarded three contracts totaling $36,500,000 for aiding development of the Dyna-soar, a manned orbital space glider.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 29 -- It is sobering under present circumstances to reflect on tomorrow's anniversary of that bleak occasion twenty-three years ago when France and Britain, then the West's leading military powers, avoided imminent war by bowing to Hitler at Munich.
VALHALLA, N.Y., Sept. 29 -- President Kennedy was asked today to intervene in behalf of on Indian physician who may be sent back to his South African homeland on Oct. 17 because his visa has expired.
Lorraine Hansberry, author of "A Raisin in the Sun," has taken over the direction of "Kicks Co.," the Oscar Brown Jr. musical, which is scheduled to open in Chicago Oct. 7.

City Investigation Commissioner Louis I. Kaplan was questioned for ninety minutes yesterday by two assistants of the State Attorney General about an alleged conspiracy by school contractors to rig bids.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- United States Administration sources expressed concern today over indications that Ghana was inching more and more toward a pro-Soviet position in foreign affairs and a Marxist dictatorship at home.

That other feller which won more pennants than anybody else for the Yankees before they counted up his birthdays and found that even though it was October and he was born in July and had lost the 1960 world series and didn't need the money anyway is coming back to town next season as manager of the New York Mets and you could look it up.

PARIS, Sept. 29 -- French opinion on the Syrian uprising was divided today between a sense of satisfaction over President Gamal Abdel Nasser's difficulties and worry about what impact the insurrection would have on the general Middle Eastern situation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The International Cooperation Administration announced today the award of a $16,400,000 contract to the Radio Corporation of America for a 3,060-mile telecommunications network linking Turkey, Iran and Pakistan.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 29 -- Pickets were posted at the gangways of seventeen idle ships in West Coast port this afternoon.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- A schedule of cross-country hearings on job discrimination because of race, religion and age was announced today by the House Committee on Education and Labor.

Usually upon word of an investigation of its operations, the stock market goes through a few downward adjustments. But in Washington the other day one of the prime movers behind the pending Securities and Exchange Commission inquiry said the investigation would have the opposite effect ultimately.
GREENPORT, L.I., Sept. 29 -- Officials are awaiting word from Albany on whether they must transport a 14-year-old girl by land and water to a private school 9.85 miles from her home.

SAN MATEO, Calif., Sept. 29 (AP) -- Djebonita won the first race at Bay Meadows today and paid $520.80 on a $2 bet to win -- but the daily double paid only $467.20 as Timesaver won the second race at $4.

Brake and switch trouble halted all service on the IRT Lexington Avenue line for twenty-two minutes during the evening rush four yesterday and slowed it for thirty-five minutes more. In all, 30,000 riders were delayed, the Transit Authority said.

First place in the Eastern Division will be at stake today when the New York Titans and Boston Patriots clash in an American Football League game at the Polo Grounds. The kick-off is scheduled for 2 P. M.

WHEN "Sail Away," the first of the new season's big musicals, berths Tuesday night at the Broadhurst, there will be a program line you don't see often these days. It is the crediting of words, music and direction to a single name.

The first detailed port operation plan for use in case of a national disaster -- such as a nuclear attack -- has been drawn up by harbor officials of Long Beach, Calif. Fourteen months of work went into the plan, which was presented last week at the annual convention of the American Association of Port Authorities at Long Beach.

OCALA, Fla. -- Ocala National Forest, the southernmost one in the United States and the oldest one east of the Mississippi, is a vast semi-tropical wilderness of pine and palm, giant springs, air-clear lakes and streams.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Sept. 30 -- Twenty-three years ago a 16-year-old African boy read Booker T. Washington's book, "Up From Slavery," and decided that some day he, too, would build a school. In January he will see his dream realized.
LONDON, Sept. 30 -- Senator J.W. Fulbright said tonight that the West was not "without fault" over the Berlin situation.

BERLIN, Sept. 30 -- A group of twenty-three mayors from the United States presented 300 messages of support to Mayor Willy Brandt today. The messages came from cities, townships and just plain citizens.

As early as 1820, when debate raged as to whether Missouri should be admitted to the Union as a slave or free state. Jefferson Davis called the crisis "a fire-bell in the night," and the figure still applied some forty years later when war came.

RESUMING an exhibit series he started in 1952 and last presented in 1956, Edward Steichen last week offered the fifth in the series, "Diogenes With a Camera V," in the auditorium of the Museum of Modern Art, where it will continue through Nov. 12.
LITTLE ROCK, Sept. 30 -- The Arkansas Legislature, in its second try, has produced a Congressional redistricting plan that apparently will be accepted by political interests over the state.

DAMASCUS, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Premier Kuzbari announced tonight the dismissal of Lieut. Gen. Mohammed el-Jarrah as Syria's chief of intelligence and police. Lieut. Gen, Fateh Bakhr was appointed to the post.

For a crowd of 29,182, which included 19,061 paying customers, guests of the Yankee management and some 9,000 roaming youngsters, it was a pleasant enough afternoon at the Stadium yesterday. It was a barren day, however, for the more serious-minded fans who had clustered in the right wing of the triple-decked grandstand and the right-field bleachers in the hope of catching Roger Maris' sixty-first home run.

GREENLAWN, L.I., Sept. 30 -- Mrs. W.J.S. Borie's black and white English springer spaniel, Ch. Wakefield's Black Knight, from Gwynedd Valley, Pa., became the top dog of the Suffolk County Kennel Club show today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The issue of private ownership of a communications satellite system is bringing to a head a long-standing controversy over who should own the inventions resulting from Government-sponsored research.

LONDON, Sept. 30 -- Senator J.W. Fulbright urged the members of the British Commonwealth today to accept Britain's proposed entry into the European Common Market with "understanding and a sense of history."

Bright, sunny weather last week helped retail sales in the New York area rise above the 1960 level, although the temperature ranged well above normal. Volume for the week ran 6 per cent to 8 per cent above 1960, according to estimates from leading department store officials.

FIFTEEN year ago, when he was a downy veteran of two years in the House and one in the Senate, J.W. Fulbright, the present chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, delivered an address at the University of Chicago on 'The Legislator." in the course of which he pronounced the following indisputable truth: "The first thing, obviously, that every legislator has to do is to get himself elected to office."

The eighty-second annual campaign, with a goal of $3,000,000, of the United Hospital Fund of New York will begin at a dinner at the Plaza Hotel tomorrow night. Six hundred volunteers and representatives of the eighty-two voluntary hospitals aided by the fund will attend.
GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 30 -- Voters in ten Fairfield County towns will go to the polls Monday to choose officials for two-year terms. Ten other towns and cities will hold elections Nov. 7.

KANSAS CITY, Sept. 30 (UPI) -- The Washington Senators assured themselves of at least a tie for ninth place in the American League today by defeating the Kansas City Athletics, 5-4.

CLAUDE LORRAIN'S magnificent landscapes are so steeped in imaginative poetry that one might too easily suspect their foundation in the visual world of being slight or vague. However, his drawings after nature disprove such a conclusion and demonstrate that the generalizing of his paintings was derived directly from actual studies done in the open air.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 30 -- Billy Haughton, the 37-year-old reinsman from near-by Old Brookville, demonstrated tonight that he was out for a banner season at Roosevelt Raceway's fall meeting.

Certainly there is reason to feel this way about our musical life, what with the easy availability of that commodity on records and radio, to say nothing of the deadening wash of sound that follows us in and out of office buildings and grocery stores.

In many cases common household materials are the only supplies required, while a little practice will enable even the neophyte to make highly successful repairs.

Wants me to exchange the duplicate gifts!

LONDON (Science Service) -- Soaking feet in formalin, or formaldehyde solution, has been effective in curing 80 per cent of plantar warts among 646 children surveyed by Dr. C.F.H. Vickers of the Sheffield Royal Infirmary.

MONTEREY, CALIF. WITH its fourth annual concert series, presented last week-end, the Monterey Jazz Festival came into full maturity. During a furry of charges of graft and corruption in the city administration two years ago Mayor Robert F. Wagner won the City Council's approval of a Code of Ethics to govern the conduct of city officials and employes. Among other things it bars the acceptance of "any valuable gift" from any individual or company doing business with the city.

ST. GEORGE'S, Grenada -- A crescent-shaped white sand beach, which with desultory exceptions has been lying uninhabited since Columbus came to Grenada in 1498, is now taking its place as the hub of a new tourist development program on this British West Indies isle.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 30 (AP) -- John M. Schiff's Our Jeep set a track record for a mile and a half on the turf when he won today's $23,700 Ocean City Handicap before a crowd of 21,552.
HACKENSACK, N. J., Sept. 30 -- The long-sought reclamation survey of the Hackensack Meadows by the Army Corps of Engineers, is expected to begin within the next few months.

These two substantial volumes, centennial publications of Mississippi's Department of Archives and History, are intended (as any sensible person should expect) to scent war memories like the blossoms that give the Magnolia State its nickname.

MT. KISCO, N.Y., Sept. 30 -- Pupils in the sixth through the eighth grades in the Fox Lane School District will progress at "their own rate and readiness," as a result of a program developed here during a two-day symposium.
The United States tanker fleet has dropped from second to third place in the tonnage ranking of world oil fleets, according to an annual study published by the Sun Oil Company.
DAMASCUS, Syria, Sept. 30 -- The new Government ordered the deportation of all Egyptians today and announced a move to close "spy centers."

A supper dance in honor of the equestrian jumping teams from Argentina, Canada, Ireland, Mexico and the United States has been arranged by the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals. The event will be Nov. 1 at the Astor.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 30 -- William E. John Jr. sailed Lizbet to a six-length victory in the fourth race of the International Class series for the de Coppet Trophy in the post-season Yacht Racing Association regatta held off Larchmont Yacht Club today.

FOR the beginner or for the busy home owner there are many easy-to-grow perennials that will perform well with little more than a balanced diet and good soil. Before planting this fall, the gardener should have his soil tested and add the amount of organic matter, lime and fertilizer that the test recommendations suggest.

IN your identifying footnote to Charlton Ogburn's review of John Masters "The Road Past Mandalay," you refer to Mr. Ogburn's book "The Marauders" as "an account of the ill-fated Burma campaign of 1944."

TWO gardening courses -- "Plants in Small Greenhouses" and "Planning the Home Grounds" -- will start this week at the New York Botanical Garden, Bronx Park. The courses are designed to aid beginning and advanced gardeners.
GARRISON, N.Y., Sept. 30 -- Boscobel, a restored 1805 Hudson River mansion on a thirty-four-acre site on Route 9D. here, will open tomorrow to the public, by reservation only.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 30 -- St. Vincent's Hospital in Harrison will be the beneficiary of a luncheon and fashion show at the Apawamis Club here Thursday, Nov. 2. This is the annual fete sponsored by the ladies' auxiliary of the hospital.

FOR young composers in the United States, the New York season coming up will be one of the saddest and most discouraging in many a year With the demise of Howard Shanet's "Music In The Making" Series at Cooper Union, opportunities for orchestral performances of their works will be disastrously diminished.
A highway scale developed in West Germany will soon be tested in this country in the continuing effort to find a workable method for weighing trucks in motion.

ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Sept. 30 -- President Moise Tshombe of secessionist Katanga Province said today that he no longer wanted any white mercenaries in his army. He made the statement at a news conference here.
ORONO, Ont., Sept. 30 (AP) -- Peter Ryan won the first Canadian sports car Grand Prix in a Lotus 19 today after being momentarily deprived of the victory by a timer's error.
The slogan "Peace is our profession" of the Strategic Air Command, as reported by Sidney Hyman in "The Men Who Fly the Bomb" (Sept. 17), should not pass unnoticed.

LAKE FOREST, Ill., Sept. 30 -- Lake Forest College's five sororities have lost their national charters in a dispute over the right of national sorority officials to dictate local policy on racial and religious discrimination.
The new Board of Education has quietly eliminated a controversial fixture of the old board -- the position of confidential secretary.

Preliminary trade reports took on a more cheerful aspect here last week after General Motors assembly workers terminated their local walkout and returned to their jobs. Coincidentally, the three-week gasoline price war ended as the week closed with standard grade bouncing up 6 cents the gallon to 28.9 cents.

HANOVER, N.H., Sept. 30 (UPI) -- Dartmouth spotted the University of New Hampshire an early field goal and then ground out a 28-3 victory today. The triumph was Dartmouth's eleventh without a loss in the intra-state series.

Department store sales in the Federal Reserve District for the week ended Sept. 23 showed an increase of 7 per cent. Strong gains were registered in most areas, and the Portland area showed the only decrease. The four-week period ended Sept. 23 showed an increase of 7 per cent, and for the cumulative year an increase of 2 per cent.
IOWA CITY, Sept. 30 (AP) Iowa wasted several scoring opportunities today, but whipped California, 28-7, with a crushing running attack.

HANOVER, N.H., Sept. 30 -- Dartmouth College has received a gift of subantarctic literature and ethnographic material from William E. Clark of Falmouth Foreside, Me., for the college library's Stefansson Collection on Arctic and polar regions.

SEA CLIFF, L.I., Sept. 30 -- Hellcat of Great Britain moved within one race of winning the International Catamaran Challange Trophy today by deefating Wildcat of the United States by 1-minute 17 seconds.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 30 -- The Soviet Union, which has been clamoring for more United Nations jobs for its citizens, has not yet produced the necessary candidates.

PERHAPS the jingle-maker, as a historian, deserves a larger role than we give him in chronicling the great American conflict that was fought for four years with the sword and thus far has been fought a hundred years with the pen.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 30 -- Lehigh struck suddenly for two last-period touchdowns and defeated Harvard, 22-17, at Soldiers Field today.

VIENNA, Sept. 30 -- The fifth general conference of the International Atomic Energy Agency adjourned today to prepare for next week's East-West debate, which will be focused on the election of a new Director General.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- In the history of school desegregation, 1961 may be known as the year when white moderates in major Southern cities discovered their own quiet strength.

MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 30 (AP) -- The outstanding punting of Daryl Krugman and a key interception by Carl Crawford led Missouri to a 6-0 victory over Minnesota today in cold, wet weather that brought snow before the game ended.

WHAT pleases the palate of a first-class chef when, on his jour de repos, he dines in the quiet and peace of his own home? This question was put recently to scattered members of the chef's profession in Manhattan.
SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Sept. 29 -- The Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland is showing signs of recovery from the economic slump that has plagued it for the last two years.
Every state in the union except Alaska has been allocated mileage in the Interstate Highway System. Hawaii had qualified for forty-eight miles, all on its principal island of Oahu.

As far as this reviewer can perceive, with every book Glenn Tucker gets better, and he was awfully good in his earlier volumes on Gettysburg and Winfield Scott Hancock. Mr. Tucker isn't satisfied simply to stitch together the threads of a familiar story-pattern; rather, he probes deeply into personalities, supporting his events with human motivations.
Modern ironmasters are finding new ways to increase output and cut costs in the blast furnace, the towering, $20,000,000 symbol of the steel industry.

Recent news that the works of both Dryden and Pope have lost ground ,to contemporary sources as the literary fountains for quotations to demonstrate the use of words in Webster's Third International Dictionary brings to mind A Dictionary of the English Language produced by Dr. Samuel Johnson in 1755.

The Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association will receive the proceeds of two theatre parties this winter. The first will be at the Dec. 27 evening performance of "Write Me A Murder" at the Belasco Theatre, and the second will be at "Subways Are For Sleeping" on Jan. 9.

GAINESVILLE, Fla., Sept. 30 (AP) -- Roy Bickford, a "wild card" defensive specialist for Florida State, blocked a punt and set up a field goal that heavily favored Florida could barely match today as the state rivals played a 3-3 tie.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, Sept. 30 (AP) -- The leaders of Malaya and Singapore named an eight-man working party today to draw up plans for a merger of the two territories by June, 1963.
CHICAGO, Sept. 30 (AP) -- William Lydon was acquitted today of a charge of evading income taxes on money allegedly paid him during the State Treasury swindle.

Layers of wintry woolens that may be piled up to a mascaraed eye -- this is the muffled look destined to cover the fall fashion front. The stoles, capes and hoods that create this silhouette are as practical as they are chic, appear with everything from a dress or suit to country pants or a narrow coat.

Bosley Crowther's interesting article (Sunday, Sept. 24) reminded me of a fine children's picture that you recommended a few months ago, "Misty." The grandsons that I took to the Normandie to see it voted it the best picture they'd seen in a long time, with no questions from me.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Sept. 30 -- President Kennedy's reference in the United Nations this week to the "smoldering coals of war in Southeast Asia" was considered particularly timely here in view of the strong attacks against population centers in South Vietnam by Communist forces presumed to be based in southern Laos and Cambodia.

In his article, "Moments of Magic on Broadway" (Sept. 17), Ward Morehouse cites as among the most spellbinding performances on the commercial stage in New York that he has seen in the last quarter century or so, a dozen performances by actresses.

Right at the start John M. Gibson, a library research specialist in Raleigh, confesses that he has never quite outgrown his boyhood dislike for William Tecumseh Sherman; he was, Mr. Gibson insist, "unnecessarily cruel" and "used terror as a weapon"; but, though a bit grudgingly, Mr. Gibson can now see a good side to Sherman.

DO the nonaligned nations, especially the numerous nonaligned nations of Africa and Asia, have any weighty role to play in a world where mighty forces confront each other and where each moment seems to increase the risk that they may engage in literally mortal combat?
PARIS, Sept. 30 -- Machinery was established this week for one of the most fateful negotiations in Europe in the post-war period: The negotiations for Britain's entry into the European Common Market.

THERE is one basic fallacy in Archie Carr's review of "Man and Dolphin" by Dr. John C. Lilly. That is that types of intelligence in order to be equal have to be of like nature. Mr. Cart says: "I simply don't believe that a manlike intelligence could ever develop in the water.

Building permits issued in the eighteen largest marketing areas of Illinois during July amounted to $34,189,000. This was 48.3 per cent less than in June and 20.7 per cent below the 1960 level. Only four of the areas, two of which are in the metropolitan area of Chicago, recorded an increase for the month compared with June, while a like number showed a gain over July, 1960.
A 1-yard plunge in the last quarter by Pat Timpone gave Brooklyn Tech a 19-13 victory 2 6vet New Utrecht yesterday in a Public Schools Athletic League game at Boys High field.
EVANSTON, Ill., Sept. 30 (UPI) -- Bill Swindle ran for three touchdowns and flipped a lateral pass for another as Northwestern crushed Boston College, 45 -- 0, today.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 30 -- A bill permitting National Football League teams to pool their television rights in a single contract was signed into law today by President Kennedy.

New York's hotels -- and motels -- are in an era of high prices and changing concepts of luxury. There is a surge of new building and a strong emphasis on built-in parking. There are at least twenty hotels in the city where the minimum rate is $15 or more.
HOPES of a United Nations stamp memorializing its late Secretary General, Dag Hammarskjold, were dimmed last week by opposition from members of various blocs.

The New York Giants will help the Redskins open their new District of Columbia Stadium in Washington today. The game is one of seven scheduled for the third Sunday of the National Football League season.
WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 30 (AP) -- Unbeaten Villanova shook off adversity and made two fierce goal-line stands today for a 20-6 football victory over Holy Cross.

ERNEST Pintoff, the 29-year-old New Yorker, who, since 1958, has headed his own cartoon manufactory, Ernest Pintoff Productions, which has turned out such funny shorts as "The Violinist" and "The Interview," is preparing to start production on his f'.nt feature-length film.
RABAT, Morocco, Sept. 30 -- Moroccans expect the Soviet Union to veto the admission of the Islamic Republic of Mauritania to the United Nations.
The twenty-seventh season of the Avery Lectures will begin on the morning of Oct. 19 at the Central Branch of the Young Women's Christian Association.
A fashion party and tea on Oct. 16 at Brookside, the estate in Rye, N.Y., of Mrs. Ricardo C. Gonzales, will benefit the Youth Consultation Service of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York.

THE age-old injunction, "Know thine enemy," has been respected and practiced with varying success throughout history. It is a counsel of common prudence that applies not merely to war but to all relations between states and especially to that uneasy form of international coexistence called the "cold war," which is increasingly becoming a long-term political duel-to-the-death fought in the shadow of thermonuclear war.

DETROIT, Sept. 30 (AP) -- The Ford Motor Company and the U.A.W. wound up a week of intensive bargaining today and moved into week-end negotiations without any official word on how close they were to a new contract.

THIS is the month the New York theatre season begins rolling in high. Sixteen new productions are scheduled for Broadway, nine for off Broadway. Altogether, some 300 performers, garbed in assorted raiment and placed amid varied settings, will be involved, each engaged in the personal struggle of trying to be someone he or she is not, each seeking to evoke as truthfully as possible the creature of someone else's imagination.

ANY woman who has ever had a frivolous impulse is bound to be delighted with the irrepressible femininity of the heroines in the "Elizabeth" novels. The heroine of B.J. Chute's new book (her first novel since "Greenwillow") is reminiscent of these ladies, though less perceptive and less amusing.

A JOYOUS thing about the retrospective exhibition of Bernard Reder, which opened at the Whitney last week, is that it brings into proper conspicuousness a sculptor who belongs with the thin handful of creative people today (in any art) who can make a vigorous, positive statement that life is worthwhile.

ELEKTRA RECORDS has come up with a novel packaging idea in A Treasure Chest of American Folk Song (EKL-205). In what is called a "bonus pak," two LP's are offered for the price of one ($4.98, or stereo, $5.98).

An official of one of the country's largest voluntary health insurance plans yesterday called for a study to determine the extent of abuses in such programs and what role they may play in raising the costs of medical care.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 30 -- The White House said today that President Kennedy had no plans now to see Andrei A. Gromyko or to send a personal message to Premier Khrushchev next week.

SAYVILLE, L.I., Sept. 30 -- Phil Marriner's Mischief of the Centerport (L.I.) fleet had two second-place finishes today and took the lead in the Atlantic Coast Penguin championship series. The five-race series, staged by the Sayville Yacht Club, ends tomorrow.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Sept. 30 -- The names of the young women who will be presented at the annual Holly Ball at the Scarsdale Golf Cub on Dec. 29 have been announced by the committee planning the event. Mrs. Alexander M. Paterson heads the committee.

" SOMETIMES a man has to be hog wild," Joss Melborne's crippled father tells him as the 12-year-old pours out his plan for driving a hog herd 100 miles overland to the railhead in Prairie City and, if bog prices are right, using the money to put his father back on his feet. Trials aplenty follow in the race against time along the trail -- a hazardous river crossing, thunderstorms and straying hogs.

OTTAWA, Sept. 30 -- Ever since Prime Minister John Diefenbaker told the nation of the need to take protective measures against the possibility of a nuclear attack, Canadians have been wondering what, if anything, they should do about it.
LONDON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Winston Churchill urged an easing of "terror bombing" of German cities toward the end of World War II so the Allies would not find a totally ruined country.
PARIS, Sept. 30 -- Vice President Johnson flew back to Washington today after having received a report here on progress toward an Allied military build-up to meet the Berlin crisis.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- President Kennedy was honored today by the Radio-Television News Directors Association as "the man who has contributed most to the advancement of broadcast news" during the year.

RABAT, Morocco, Sept. 30 -- Royal Moroccan Army troops paraded through the capital and other centers today, marking the withdrawal of the last French air and ground forces and the turnover of French military air schools to the Moroccan Defense Ministry.

TO move from England's Angry Generation to Gabriel Fielding's vanishing Edwardians is to step from a vivid and violent present into a silvered past whose glint has been tarnished by war. The grubby realism of Nottingham is replaced by a Kentish drawing room, ironing boards give way to frayed antimacassars, the frustration of "not being" to the frustration of "having been."

PARIS, Sept. 30 -- Autumn has come to Paris. The leaves are falling, children march to school each morning -- and the wrestling arenas, all nine, are again going full blast. The masked villains are back in town. They appear more hardhearted than ever.

THE situation in this first novel by Kit Reed, a Connecticut and Florida newspaper woman, is a promising one. A beautiful but innocent teenager, who has been reared by a widowed grandmother after having been abandoned by a trampish mother, wins a beauty contest.
WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Sept. 30 -- Scoring twice on pass plays in the first quarter and again in the final period, Hofstra defeated Lycoming, 20 -- 7, today.

RHODES, Greece, Sept. 30 -- After nearly twelve centuries of separation as national churches the main Orthodox churches of the world reaffirmed their unity today and declared that their conference in Rhodes had ended in unanimity.

BELGRADE, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Bobby Fischer of the United States tied Svetozar Gligoric of Yugoslavia for second place after eighteen rounds of the Bled chess tournament tdday. Each had 12 1/2 points. Mikhail Tal of Latvia leads with 13 1/2 points.
NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 30 -- India and the United States finished the first day's play in an interzone final of the Davis Cup tennis matches today tied at 1 -- 1.
" In the Congo, there is no political difference that is unbridgeable, no enemy who cannot become a friend and brother if the circumstances are right, and no friend who may not be an enemy tomorrow."

The arresting collection of pictures of Israel's Lake Hula, taken by Peter Merom and displayed under the title of "The Death of the Lake" (Sept. 10), pays vivid tribute to the energy and resourcefulness of Israel's pioneers in transforming a malarial swamp into a fertile valley.
When Congress adjourned last Wednesday most maritime industry leaders were satisfied with appropriations for harbor and river improvements.
LIMA, Peru, Sept. 22 -- The United States will emphasize its economic partnership with Peru in a 60,000-square-foot exhibition at the Second Pacific International Fair in Lima Oct. 12 to 29.

ONE day recently, when an ad agency photographer was about to take a picture of Roger Marts smoking a Camel, the Yankee slugger held up his hand in protest. "No, no," he said. "Don't shoot from that side. Do it from the other side. My nose is straighter there."
HOW do American composers make a living? At least one is a lobster fisherman. Another has a mail-order stamp business. Still another is a psychiatric social worker.

A LIBERAL society that snuffs out human life in electric chairs should have a system for determining guilt, innocence and mental responsibility as pure and unerring as the death sentence is final. Whether we have such a system in this country is a question explored in "Death and the supreme Court," a fascinating study of justice in America and specifically of the role played in death sentences by the highest tribunal.

Thomas Darson, a pianist last heard here in 1956, gave a recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall, in memory of his teacher, the late Angela Weschler. The program consisted of three works -- Beethoven's early A major Sonata, Chopin's "Funeral March" and Mussorgsky's "Pictures at an Exhibition.''

MRS. ISABELLE MALLET in her review of "A Glimpse or Arcadia" by MacDonald Hastings mentions a legend born in March of 1831, when Big Ben struck twenty times tolling the passing of the silver salmon from the Thames waters.

TANANARIVE, Malagasy Republic, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Explosion and fire wracked the Norwegian Starcarrier at Diego Suarez, Malagasy Republic, last night. Port officials set the toll at twenty-one dead or missing.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Sept. 30 -- The formal induction of John E. Sawyer as the eleventh president of Williams College has been scheduled for 3 P.M. Oct. 8 in Chapin Hall. Mr. Sawyer has been president since July 1, succeeding Dr. James P. Baxter 3d.

Senator Barry Goldwater's arguments in "Goldwater: How to Win the Cold War" (Sept. 17) were thought-provoking. But indeed, he seems to ignore communism's most effective strategy, that of propaganda, the winning of minds.

Present evidence suggests that a new era of bitterness between Syria and Egypt has begun in the wake of the successful revolt in Damascus. On the Syrian side the order has been issued for expulsion of all Egyptians, while crowds have roamed the streets tearing down pictures of Nasser and signs referring to the now very moribund "United Arab Republic."

PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 30 -- The latest public opinion poll in the Philippines by the Princeton Research Council shows Vice President Diosdado Macapagal running ahead of President Carlos P. Garcia in the Presidential campaign.

MEMPHIS, Sept. 30 -- This cultural capital of the Mississippi River delta will soon begin token desegregation at the first-grade level of some of its schools. There have been reports that the start will come next month.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Sept. 30 (UPI) -- The city school board announced yesterday activation of its "selective" desegregation plan.
Ravi Shankar, an Indian virtuoso of the sitar, a gourd-and-teakwood stringed instrument that has evolved over many centuries, will open a coast-to-coast concert tour tomorrow at Town Hall.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Sept. 30 (AP) -- Kermit Jorgensen, a senior quarterback, cranked up touchdown drives of 54 and 72 yards and speedy Charlie Mitchell raced 66 yards to score in the last four minutes for a 20-7 Washington victory over Illinois today.

BOLZANO, Italy, Sept. 30 -- A group of German-speaking leaders of the Alto Adige, or South Tyrol, called today for constructive negotiations with the Italian Government to attain larger regional authority and sternly condemned terrorism.

EVERTON, where Richard Le Gallienne was born, straggles across the summit of the steepest hill in the city of Liverpool. Long dull streets of identical brick boxes, born red and now mellowed to a uniform sooty black, crawl up the slope high above the docks and river.

GREAT FALLS, Mont., Sept. 30 -- Work on the nation's first Minuteman missile complex is well ahead of schedule in this north central Montana area, but could be slowed drastically if the winter is hard.

At least one good, fat, soul-satisfying week-end during the early autumn should be reserved with a high priority for Block Island. This may be a little far for a Friday-to-Monday weekend or even for a Thursday-to-Tuesday extension for Upstate skippers along the Hudson.
GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, Sept. 30 -- The executive of the People's National Congress party decided last night to boycott British Guiana's thirteen-member upper house.

FOREIGN aid, education, health and the national defense were among the topics before the Senate as it struggled toward adjournment last week, but the problems of the nation were of little concern to Otto Preminger.
NEW DELHI, Sept. 30 -- A sweeping reorientation of the Indian educational system was urged today to promote national unity.

DURING April, May and June of this year, more than 800 Brazilian tourists visited the eastern United States as part of a tour program instituted by Varig Airlines of Brazil. The program, called "The Trip of Your Life," attracted the largest group of South Americans ever to visit this country.

TO judge from the two books under review, news correspondents are making good use of their opportunities in Africa. It's no news that those opportunities are plentiful as the continent goes through the torments of growth.
ROME, Sept. 30 -- Pope John XXIII has asked the whole Catholic world to recite the rosary in praying for peace.
CLOSE elections are usually lost -- not won. More often than not, the reasons for defeat are directly related to campaign bloopers that could have been avoided.
Early American cabinetwork from New England, Pennsylvania and other centers of the craft will be auctioned Thursday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.

Sections 25, 27, 29, 31, and 33 in the Yankee Stadium grandstand and the right corner of the bleachers were areas of anxious waiting again yesterday afternoon. The thousands who packed those right-field regions where Roger Maris usually slams his home runs waited in vain, however.
RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 30 -- Virginia opens and dedicates a $500,000 Civil War centennial center here tomorrow.

The battle for the consumer dollar this year has been intensified by the determination of giant merchandising syndicates to increase their volume in the face of a somewhat lackadaisical attitude on the part of the consumer.

In theory, the struggle now dominating, the United Nations is merely over the election of a temporary successor to Dag Hammarskjold. Actually it goes beyond that, for the decision will indicate what kind of a permanent successor can be expected. Indeed, it is possible that an Acting Secretary General would hold office indefinitely.
" Where can I get money or cash a check?"

WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 30 -- A transformation of Grasslands Hospital at Eastview into a medical center for everyone in Westchester County was recommended today by County Executive Edwin G. Michaelian, who also is leader of the dominant Republican organization.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 30 (AP) -- The defiant general who backed Joao Goulart in Brazil's Presidential crisis has been transferred from command of the Third Army in the south of Brazil on orders of Premier Tancredo Neves.

Michigan State University announced a change in admissions procedure last week and assured that it would be the last change at least until September, 1964. A university official explained that since admissions policies have been in constant flux for the past few years, parents have become worried lest plans made today will be obsolete by the time of college applicants.
Two of the nation's largest retail chains took divergent paths last week in the same direction.
LONDON, Sept. 30 (Reuters) -- The Communists were said today to have lost their two-year hold on Britain's powerful electrical Trades Union in balloting for a new Executive Council.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Sept. 30 -- Angelo Dabiero, a 165-pound senior, put the punch in Notre Dame's attack today and sparked the Irish to a 19-6 triumph over Oklahoma.
The nation's business and industry is beginning to face up to the grim possibility of a nuclear war.
Ten West German community and youth leader will arrive here by air tomorrow to begin a tour of seven cities in a study of community life, "civic affairs, citizenship and democratic attitudes."

The extension of the International Coffee Agreement, which was approved last week by the twenty-eight member nations alter more than two weeks of sometimes-heated discussion, left most coffee traders unimpressed.
There is an end to the patience of even the most avid moviegoer. Something should be said editorially about the ragged prints on display in virtually any theatre where revivals are shown.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (UPI) -- The Air Force Systems Command announced today consolidation of all Air Force bioastronautics research and development under a single management.

SEAT belts for automobiles, long a conversation piece with motorists but seldom used, are beginning to come into more general acceptance. And last week Wisconsin became the first state to take the drastic step of ordering the installation of front-seat belts on all 1962 models -- now corning into the market.
The Reynolds Metals Company, the country's second largest producer of aluminum, is expanding its fleet of ocean barges for the carrying of bauxite, the ore that is the basic source of aluminum.
CHICAGO -- A new $6,000,000 hotel was added to this city's list of accommodations last week when the fifteen-story, 300-room Water Tower Inn opened for business on upper Michigan Avenue.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 30 -- Yale finessed its way past Connecticut's Bunyanesque football team today in their season opener at the Bowl. The score was 18-0.
The railroad industry, which has been in a state of ill health for many years because of declining earnings, is showing signs of recovery.
CLEMENTON, N.J., Sept. 30 -- The New York metropolitan golf team regained the Lesley Cup by winning nine of the ten singles matches this afternoon at the Pine Valley Golf Club.

Congratulations on an excellent article by Senator Goldwater. There is quite an impressive difference between this determined man of principle who would rather "follow the world to Kingdom Come" than "consign it to hell under communism" and the pitiful cringing of those who would "rather be Red than dead."

COLORADO, SPRINGS, Colo. -- The Rocky Mountains are so full of Boot Hills and reconstructed ghost towns dotted with gambling halls and the like that many visitors go home wondering if normal people ever came West to live.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 30 (AP) -- The State Conservation Council urged today an extension of the party permit system for deer hunters and the institution of game-management practice within the State Forest Preserve.

TEN-YEAR-OLD Cathy bubbled with self-confidence about filling in as society reporter on the Ferris County Crier during the regular reporter's vacation. Some grown-ups had misgivings, and Editor Stark was plain shocked at finding a little girl on his staff. In the midst of newsgathering, schoolwork and home chores Cathy became a public heroine, to boot -- all heady with glory.

PORT JEFFERSON, L.I., Sept. 30 -- Three persons died and five others, including a parkway policeman, were injured in three separate accidents on Long Island highways last night and early this morning.
SAN FRANCISCO -- A fascinating motor trip from this West Coast metropolis is the one northward to the coastal redwood groves in Humboldt Redwoods State Park, about 250 miles above the Golden Gate.

A hurricane threat together with unseasonably warm weather slowed the sale of fall and winter merchandise, particularly apparel, during the other week. With pre-school buying out of the way, merchants report a lull in seasonal business.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30 -- An experiment in helping mentally retarded persons to help themselves by caring for animals and preparing garden supplies got under way here this week with the opening of Lambs, Inc., a nonprofit pet and garden shop.

ANYONE familiar with English literature of the Eighteen Nineties recalls the name of Richard Le Gallienne as one in the circle whose center was Oscar Wilde, and any admirer of Max Beerbohm's caricatures will remember a drawing of that group in which the young Le Gallienne's great shock of raven hair floats like a thundercloud in back of the other figures.

ONCE again, in her latest specimen of American womanhood, Bessie Breuer (author of several novels including "Memory of Love" and, more recently, "The Actress") has pinned one of her fluttering, wind-driven, lethal creatures to the pages of a book.

THE oustanding Success of this year's Irish Theatre Festival has been "The Voice of Shem." Fittingly, that sublime Dubliner, James Joyce, inspires the excitement, for "The Voice of Shem" is a stage adaptation of his "Finnegan's Wake."
District Attorney Frank D. O'Connor of Queens said yesterday he had never advised City Investigation Commissioner Louis I Kaplan to withhold information relating to a school scandal.
Don Cavalli, a quarterback, and Frank Melos, a halfback, paced the Wagner College eleven to a 34-6 victory over Haverford College yesterday at Grymes Hill, S.I.
GENEVA, Sept. 30 -- W. Averell Harriman, leader of the United States delegation at the fourteen-nation conference here on Laos, announced today his intention to fly to Washington, probably tomorrow.

RHODES, Greece, Sept. 29 -- In small door at the side of the Church of the Annunciation in Rhodes stood a portly young man in the black robes and flat-topped hat of the Orthodox Church. He was fingering the gold cross resting comfortably on his robes and speaking rapidly and affably in Russian to one gentleman rfom Israel, another from Italy and several from Athens.

The index of steel production in the Cleveland-Lorain district advanced 9 points in the week ended Sept. 16 to 123 (1957-59 equals 100). The index was at the highest point since April of last year. Max J. Rubin, president of the Board of Education, served notice last night in his first public address that the board's top administrators must produce results or be replaced.

The new one-story factory biulding at 2114 Arthur Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by EH. R. Builders, Inc., to the 2114 Arthur Avenue Corporation. The buyer immediately -- aged the building to Sam Zakow Co., riggers and movers of machinery.
CAIRO, Oct. 1 -- The problem of recognizing Syria as a separate state again was thrown at the door of the Arab League today.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Steve Myhra kicked a 52-yard field goal on the last play of a wild National Football League game today to enable the Baltimore Colts to defeat the Minnesota Vikings, 34 -- 33.
The Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell yesterday warned against those "timid souls" who were counseling the West to surrender in the Berlin crisis.

" The Classmate" has been added to Broadway's list of great expectations. Starring in it will be Walter Slezak, who kept "The Gazebo" on the boards for 219 performances in his last appearance here. The governments of Latin America were advised yesterday that programs for economic and social development would have "little practical meaning" unless the rapid growth of their city populations was checked.
Richard M. Nixon's announcement that he is running for Governor of California in 1962 and will not be a candidate for President in 1964 is both boon and bane for Nelson A. Rockefeller.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Oct. 1 -- The lost art of the illuminated manuscript book as it developed through centuries will appear in many of its phases tomorrow in the exhibition of a new acquisition by the Lilly Library of Indiana University.

THE baseball experts never learn. They start with strong opinions and then get wafted away by delusions of infallibility. It's a cinch, therefore, that they will talk themselves into picking the Yankees to crush the Cincinnati Reds in the forthcoming world series. The longer they ponder the matter the more convinced they will become that this steamroller job will require the minimum of four games.
Roger Maris yesterday became the first major league player in history to hit more than sixty home runs in a season.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 1 -- For the world as a whole the rate of population growth in 1960-61 outpaced the production of food and other agricultural commodities, the Food and Agriculture Organization reported today.

Genevieve Caulfield recently received from Manila the $10,000 Ramon Magsaysay Award for International Understanding for her autobiography, "The Kingdom Within." The book, which Harper published, is an account of her lifelong work with the blind of Southeast Asia.
A BRILLIANT television account of the rich, vigorous life of the late Ernest Hemingway appeared last night on Channel 4.

A moderately optimistic City Planning Commission made public yesterday a proposed record capital budget of $746,642,713 for the calendar year 1962.
Michael J. Quill called yesterday for the readmission of James R. Hoffa's International Brotherhood of Teamster to the merged labor movement.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The 100-megaton bomb that Premier Khrushchev said is being built by the Soviet Union could be a massive incendiary weapon. It could start fires over an area larger than the State of Vermont.
KEANSBURG, N.J., Oct. 1 -- This Monmouth County community will seek recognition from the state as the area where white men made their first landing in New Jersey.
HONG KONG, Oct. 1 -- The Communist regime in China marked the twelfth year of its rule today. A colorful parade in Peiping celebrated production achievements.

BERLIN, Oct. 1 -- Several thousand Communist policemen, blue-shirted members of the Communist youth organization and militia men worked under a gray sky today to widen the razed area along the barrier that cuts Berlin in two.

One of Japan's leading brokers has come to town with the aim of enticing more dollars into the land of the sen and the yen. He is Genichi Toyama, chairman of the Nikko Securities Company and a former chairman of the Tokyo Stock Exchange. Mr. Toyama also is a master salesman.
CAIRO, Sept. 30 -- Syria's secession from the United Arab Republic this week was a dramatic reaction to the vast economic upheaval inaugurated by President Gamal Abdel Nasser two months ago.

SONS seem less likely to resist following in father's footsteps when they tread the vineyard path. Countless wine businesses have stayed in the same family generation after generation, and the British concern of Williams Humbert is no exception. Since this sherry house was founded in 1877, there have been four generations of Williamses and three of Humberts.

A program variation in the New York Philharmonic concert in Carnegie Hall Saturday night brought the Tchaikovsky Piano Concerto in B flat minor, with Philippe Entremont as soloist. Roussel's Third Symphony and Berlioz's "Cleopatre," with Jennie Tourel as soloist, were repeated from the previous concerts of the week.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 1 -- Master Tara Singh ended tonight his fast in support of Sikh demands for a Punjabi-speaking state.

Daniel Majeske, assistant concertmaster of the Cleveland Orchestra, came to town without most of his colleagues to give a violin recital late yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. This was Mr. Majeske's New York debut. George Silfies, who plays in the clarinet section of the orchestra, accompanied at the piano.
NEWPORT, Oct. 1 -- President Kennedy deferred action today on a Tariff Commission recommendation for an increase in the duty on Wilton and velvet carpets.
LONDON, Oct. 1 (AP) -Somerset Maugham came home today to see London in the and his secretary said the year-old author planned to end his long stay in France to settle again in Britain.
PANAMA, Oct. 1 -- Panama publicly revived today her demands on the United States for improved terms and fully "sovereign" rights in the Panama Canal Zone.

DALLAS, Tex., Oct. 1 -- Leaders of the natural gas industry made it plain here today that there is plenty of gas to meet future demand.

Arthur J. Benline yesterday renewed his demand for the installation of devices to lessen air pollution caused by fumes from auto crankcases.
NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 1 -President Kennedy has been encouraged enough by preliminary Soviet-American talks to wish to meet with Mr. Gromyko.

There were only three polio cases in the city in the first nine months of the year, a Department of Health report showed yesterday. There was one death.

THE scheduled opening later this month of New York City's newest television station -- WUHF on Channel 31 -- was the subject last night of a courteous and generous salute by a sister outlet, WNEW-TV on Channel 5.

The Rev. Dr. Frank A. Mullen of the Young Men's Christian Association said yesterday that young people entering the adult world had failed to find the proper "signposts" to indicate their future courses.

Nominations are being accepted for the twelfth annual Musical Talent In Our Schools series, which will be broadcast next spring by radio station WQXR. As in the past, this series will enable exceptionally talented pianists, violinists and 'cellists in high schools to be heard in radio recitals.

Starting this week, advertising for Schlitz Brewing Company will acquire a sweeping "new look." Instead of depicting the usual scenes of beer-drinking conviviality, the new campaign will be almost starkly simple in format.

If, as it is said, the proof of the pudding is in the eating, then the man who sells both life insurance and mutual funds is here to stay.

Mayor Wagner charged yesterday that "Republican rule in Albany" had resulted in "scandalous short-changing" of the city on state aid. His charge came in what was billed as a "major statement" formally opening Mr. Wagner's drive for re-election Nov. 7.

BIZERTE, Tunisia, Oct. 1 (AP) -- France today began withdrawing her troops that have occupied part of Bizerte since mid-July, when severe fighting broke out between French and Tunisian forces. The operation is expected to be finished Tuesday.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Gerry Perry's 27-yard field goal with five seconds to play highlighted a St. Louis comeback from a 17-point deficit today as the Cardinals beat the Philadelphia Eagles, 30 -- 27, in a National Football League game before 59,399 fans at Franklin Field.
British pound sterling continued to show a strong undertone on active dealings in the foreign exchange market during the past week. Canadian dollar was steady and quiet.

American League pitchers are not alone in their judgment that Roger Eugene Maris is a difficult man to get along with. The Yankee who hit his sixty-first home run of the season yesterday has a demeanor that can be as intimidating as his big bat.

EVERY once in a while an artist of a cultural tradition alien to our own can come across the barriers that divide men and reach us. Ravi Shankar is one of those artists.

SARANAC INN, N.Y., Oct. 2 -- Back in 1812, when muskets rather than missiles were weapons of war, the state of New York enacted a law providing that communities could vote funds to erect public school buildings.
The American Ballet Theatre last night opened a two-week engagement at the Fifty-fourth Street Theatre. It was not good.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (UPI) -- Eugene R. Black, president of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, was accused today of violating the bank's charter by refusing to make loans to Indonesia until that country has settled financial claims by the Netherlands.
Dr. Grayson C. Kirk, president of Columbia University, was named yesterday as chairman of a new Citizens Committee for the Adoption of the New Charter.

THE wives of alcoholics usually spend years trying such home remedies as nagging, scolding, hiding liquor, pouring it down the drain and taking away their husbands' pin money, according to a recent survey conducted by the National Council on Alcoholism.

MANILA, Oct. 2 -- President Carlos Garcia directed Felixberto M. Serrano, Foreign Minister, tonight to demand the immediate recall by Havana of Andres Avino Soler. Charge d'Affaires of the Cuban Embassy here.

The creation of three new managerial posts and the establishment of a new Italian department in its passenger organization were announced here yesterday by Capt. Mario F. Vespa, vice president of Home Lines Agency.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 50 cents a bale off to 40 cents up yesterday. Near October showed the largest loss.

The New York Rangers, who missed the Stanley Cup play-offs the last three seasons, have received a jolt for the coming National Hockey League campaign. Pat Hannigan and Johnny Wilson forwards, will be lost for at least a month, the Rangers learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- The United States will probably recognize the new Syrian regime by the end of the week if the Government of Premier Mamoun al-Kuzbari has fully established its authority, official said today.

ALBANY, Oct. 2 -- The transfer of school-bus operations from the State Education Department to the Public Service Commission was proposed today by the chairman of the Joint Legislative Committee on Motor Vehicles.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- Secretary of Commerce Luther H. Hodges is concerned over mounting criticism that he is "anti-business."

MARY FICKETT, the actress, and Harry Reasoner, the dry observer of the contemporary scene, made their debut yesterday in a new program called "Calendar," and they are herewith nominated for the head of the class in daytime television.
NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 2 -- India celebrated today the ninety-second anniversary of the birth of Mohandas K. Gandhi with fresh dedication to his ideal of all men as members of one family.
Seven Negro longshoremen charged yesterday that they had been "severely" discriminated against by locals of the International Longshoremen's Association in Manhattan and Brooklyn.

THE bride who sets about cooking with trepidation should take heart. She has considerable company. Cooking is at once one of the most gratifying and inexact of all the arts. It is a rare chef, indeed, who has not bemoaned a fallen souffle or an overcooked omelet.

THIS will be known as the Year of the Home Run. Never before has one phase of the game so dominated the sport or so captured public interest. The man who provided the high drama was Roger Maris, of course. He kept ducking under deadlines and brushing against disaster like Pearl White in that ancient serial, "The Perils of Pauline."

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 2 (AP) -- David J. McDonald, president of the United Steelworkers of America, accused the United States Steel Corporation today of procrastinating on the question of a cost-of-living wage adjustment for union members.

Cosmetic stocks moved up sharply yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Heavy advertising breaking over the week-end to introduce new items had its effect on the market. Several issues went up two or more points in active trading.
CHICAGO, Oct. 2 (AP) -- The grain futures markets were mostly weak today, with wheat leading the downturn. Rye and soybean prices finished steady.
The Bath Iron Works Corporation plans to expand its activities through the proposed purchase of the closely held Hyde Windlass Company of Bath, Me.

Many veterans of the magazine industry believe that a magazine, like a human being, has a specific life expectancy. A magazine will come into being to fulfill a prevailing need or taste of times. It will bloom briefly and, when that need or taste has disappeared, it, too, will disappear.
A 36-year-old unemployed salesman walked into a trap yesterday after holding up a bank teller for $2,100 with a toy pistol.

One of the most distressing features of the civil defense program is its effect on our values. For large numbers of people civil defense is reducing complex international problems to the question of personal survival.

Jack Paar attacked Senate and House members and sections of the press last night for their criticism of his recent visit to West Berlin, where he filmed American troops standing guard at the East Berlin border.

HARTFORD, Oct 2 (UPI) -- Connecticut Republican scored many victories today in municipal elections held in 124 communities. They won upset victories in Torrington and Middletown, and retained control in Bristol.

Mickey Mantle may not be in the starting line-up when the Yankees square off against the Cincinnati Reds in the world series opener at the Stadium tomorrow. He said yesterday that he would not play unless he felt better.

THE recent supper club openings, which are generally noted for bringing out a dazzling array of new fall fashions, have for the most part been plagued by high temperatures and a blustery storm as a result of hurricane Esther.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 2 -- First Selectman David W. Deakin, who two years ago gave the Democratic party its first victory in Bethel in the town's 105-year history, was re-elected today for his second term. Mr. Deakin polled 1,900 votes to 1,227 for his Republican opponent, William Corbett, a State Representative.
A FRIEND of Abraham M. Lindenbaum remarked yesterday that if Mr. Lindenbaum had any fault it was that he was overly generous.
The mean temperature for last month was 73.6 degrees, which is something of a record for mean weather.

Eighteen rounds were completed in the international chess masters tournament at Bled with the playing of ten adjourned games from the sixteenth, seventeenth and eighteenth rounds, according to a report from Yugoslavia yesterday.

The following quotations are selling prices in United States dollars and cents for free market banknote transactions at New York. These notes do not apply to regular foreign exchange business transacted by banks.
The American Rocket Society announced yesterday that Dr. William H. Pickering had been elected president in September. He will take office on Jan. 1.

The financial printer is accustomed to demands for quick service. His clients require him to print and distribute registration statements, proxy material or stockholders notices often within a matter of hours.

The presidents and other high officials of three television networks met yesterday to discuss a joint effort to establish the children's hour recently proposed by Newton N. Minow, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Oct. 2 -- Abdel Harold Serraj, heretofore regarded as the "strong man" of Syria, has been arrested by the new revolutionary Government. This was announced today by Premier Mamoun al-Kuzbari in a conversation with foreign correspondents.
BERLIN, Oct. 2 -- The East Berlin State Opera has been crippled by cancellation of contracts by Western musicians and dancers as a result of the Communist closing of the Berlin city border.

FORT DIX, N.J., Oct. 2 -- Early this morning they were driven past the Manhattan skyline. By 11 A.M. they were surrounded by rows of Army barracks. These two vastly different scenes truly illustrated the way life changed in just a few hours for reservists of the 920th Transportation Company.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 2 (UPI) -- Mel McGaha, the 35-year-old first-base coach for the Cleveland Indians this season, was named manager today. He succeeds Jimmie Dykes, who was dismissed yesterday.
There is a shortage of physicians and it is growing worse, Dr. Lindsley Fiske Kimball, treasurer and trustee of the Rockefeller Institute, said last night.
The Air Line Pilots Association said yesterday it planned to provide counsel for a member who is being sued by the Government in a dispute over in-flight inspection of a trans-Atlantic airliner.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 2 (AP) -- John F. Kennedy, the youngest man ever elected to the Presidency, wished happy birthday today to Theodore Francis Green, the oldest ever to serve in the Senate.

This has been a discordant season for music lovers. First, the Metropolitan Opera Company threatened to cancel because of union trouble; now the New York Philharmonic and its unionized musicians are at odds. It is too much to expect that Secretary of Labor Goldberg, whose willingness to serve as arbitrator averted a blackout at the Met, will restore harmony once again.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Oct. 2 (AP) -- Little Bobby Kreese was pretty crushed today when he didn't see President Kennedy and Premier Khrushchev as he and his family stepped into a fall-out shelter for a week's stay.

Sal Durante, who caught Roger Maris' sixty-first home run ball, put on a dark blue suit, a white shirt and a blue tie yesterday, went to a television studio with eleven relatives and was permitted to touch but not accept -- as yet -- a $5,000 check.
ROME, Oct. 2 -- Pope John XXIII gave a "very special apostolic blessing" today to the United States and the American people as well as to President Kennedy and all his family.

What is believed to be the largest sale of electronic data processing equipment ever made, has been announced by the Radio Corporation of America. The buyer is the Compagnie des Machines Bull of Paris.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Paul Rand Dixon, chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, urged today heavier fines and mandatory jail sentences for repeated offenders under the antitrust laws. He also urged that bidders for Government contracts be required to submit sworn statements denying that any collusion was involved.
Two years ago, he was Patrick Henry Wade, a $65-a-week aide on virus research experiments in the laboratory of Dr. Jonas E. Salk at the University of Pittsburgh.

Patronesses for the third annual dinner dance through which fellowships will be set up for students from Austria at the Graduate School of Business of Columbia University have been announced. The dinner dance will take place Oct. 18 at Hampshire House.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) -- The Port of New York Authority said today that a Federal judge had erred seven times in convicting Austin J. Tobin, its executive director, of contempt of Congress.
The New York City Opera, which opens its fall season on Thursday, has reported an advance ticket sale of $150,000, the largest in its history.
Steel output rose again last week, making it nine consecutive weeks in which the level of production has not fallen from the preceding week.
Four tenants of a Bronx apartment received checks totaling $1,900 yesterday from the State Rent Administration representing overcharges paid for rooms in the apartment.
DETROIT, Oct. 2 (AP) -- The nation's automobile manufacturers built the 500,000th car of the 1962 model run today, considerably behind original schedules.
HAVING maneuvered Henry David Thoreau into the Hall of Fame at New York University, his advocates now have to pay the bill.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Dag Hammarskjold left his summer home on the windswept moorlands of south Sweden to serve humanity.
WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 2 -- Ten horses have been named for the $30,000 United States Harness Writers Trot at Roosevelt Raceway on Oct. 13. All are either 4 or 5 years old.
HEBER SPRINGS, Ark., Oct. 2 (UPI) -- At considerable sacrifice but without complaint, this little town today sent its National Guardsmen off to active duty.
More than 100 interviews with Abraham Lincoln as President-elect and as President have been brought together by Charles M. Segal in "Conversations with Lincoln." Putnam will publish it next Monday.
CHICAGO, Oct. 2 -- Substances that affect the growth of cancer have been found in the blood of human beings and of animals, according to two scientific reports made here today.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Oct. 2 -- David B. Pratt, the gentleman farmer who attempted last year to kill Prime Minister Hendrik F. Verwoerd, was found dead last night. He had hanged himself.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 2 AP) -- The AllisChalmers Manufacturing Company said today that it had cut the pay of its 13,000 salaried employes 5 to 25 per cent effective yesterday. The company said that the salary cut was "only a stopgap, interim measure to increase profit margins.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Oct. 2 (UPI) -- The tanker S.S. Hess Mariner sank today about 110 miles east of here after an engine room explosion ripped a hole in the 523-foot vessel last night. All thirty-seven men aboard were rescued.

DETROIT, Oct. 2 -- Negotiators for the Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile Workers worked into the night tonight in an effort to reach a contract settlement before tomorrow's 10 A.M. strike deadline.
LIBERTY, N.Y., Oct. 2 (AP) -- State Controller Arthur Levitt said today he would propose a complete revision of the system of state aid to localities to the 1962 Legislature.

Senator Jacob K. Javits offered a new proposal for medical care for the aged last night. It would take account both of the Kennedy Administration's Social Security approach and views of those like himself who have favored voluntary plans.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (UPI) -- The United States announced today that it was taking urgent measures to help South Vietnam combat an increase in Communist guerrilla activity.
Something akin to a medical Peace Corps has been set up by the American College of Cardiology. It has support from the State Department.
The new Board of Education was brought up to full nine-member strength yesterday when Mayor Wagner, in a brief City Hall ceremony, swore in John F. Hennessy as a member until May, 1964.

The annual card party for the school building and scholarship fund of the New York City Chapter, National Society Daughters of the American Revolution, will take place in the Grand Ballroom of the Pierre on Nov. 20.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- The Supreme Court opened its new term today with a break in tradition.
Striking out on their own, six of the nation's finest bowlers may well have the pot of gold within reach.
Most commodity futures prices declined yesterday on the New York exchanges.
HONG KONG, Oct. 2 -- Communist China and Cuba issued a joint communique tonight calling United States "imperialism" the "most vicious enemy" of the peoples of the world.
ALGIERS, Oct. 2 -- French authorities here announced today the arrest of a "high official" of the security police in a move against leaders of the outlawed Right-Wing Secret Armed Organization.
SHANNON, Ireland, Oct. 2 -- A group of 103 Chicagoans stranded here for five days was delayed again tonight, this time because of a $6,000 fuel bill owed to Shannon Airport by President Airlines.

Halsey, Stuart Co. Inc. and associates are offering to the public today $30,000,000 of thirty-year 4 1/2 per cent first mortgage bonds of Public Service Company of Colorado priced at 101.322 to yield 4.42 per cent.

President de Gaulle showed no signs of being dismayed by criticisms of his regime when he spoke to the French people last night. He spoke with firmness and with confidence. He has not changed his policy in any recognizable way.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 2 -- The Soviet Embassy strongly disputed today the right of the Western Allies to use the Berlin air corridors for civilian traffic.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- The Treasury announced plans today to borrow $500,000,000 on Tuesday, Oct. 10, by enlarging the issue of one-year bills that must be refinanced at that time. This will be the third and final part of a $5,000,000,000 schedule of borrowings announced last month.
Consumer installment debt outstanding in the nation edged up by $26,000,000 in August following a $74,000,000 decline in July, the Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday.

MARY McCARTHY tells a story about a gifted undergraduate writer who glowed with coming success. The promising work of fiction the girl had in progress lacked only some stylish essentials. After that it would be ready for possibly splendid triumph.

NUTLEY, N.J., Tuesday, Oct. 3 -- Members of Local 400 of the International Union of Electrical Workers set up picket lines early today outside six New Jersey laboratories of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 2 (AP) -- The International Convention of Christian Churches refused today to order the integration of National City Christian Church in Washington and adopted a statement saying the decision was based on a tradition of church government rather than the racial issue.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 2 -- Chancellor Adenauer began in earnest today to prepare the ground for a possible coalition government with the Free Democratic party.
Two Alfred Hitchcock horror programs that chilled their television sponsor were described to Federal investigators here yesterday.

Sal Mineo will play his first starring role on Broadway this season in "Something About a Soldier," Ernest Kinoy's military drama. The play is scheduled to open early in January under the sponsorship of the Theatre Guild and Dore Schary.
The musicians of the New York Philharmonic struck yesterday after negotiations for a new contract broke off.
Sales of the major department stores in the metropolitan area last month declined from the September, 1960, levels, according to a survey of seven of the eight stores by The New York Times.
Four destroyer escorts of the Naval Reserve were recommissioned yesterday at their bases in the metropolitan area.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- President Kwame Nkrumah of Ghana has asked President Kennedy to decide by Oct. 13 whether the United States intends to aid Ghana's Volta River project.
The market for high-grade debt securities had another day of quiet but firm equilibrium yesterday.

RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Oct. 2 -- President Mohammad Ayub Khan declared today that Pakistan would resist by all the means at her disposal what he called the "thoroughly unreasonable and irredentist" designs of Afghanistan.

CHICO, Calif., Oct. 2 (AP) -- Thirty-eight transcontinental travelers who seek a spot safe from the hazards of nuclear explosions began settling in northern California today after a false alarm from the stork.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) -- The Chamber of Commerce of the United States will continue to participate in the international labor organization, Richard Wagner, chamber president, announced today.
The trustees of Columbia University yesterday named Frederick vanPelt Bryan, United States Judge for the Southern District of New York, an alumni trustee.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2 -- The Chicago Board of Health started today a mail-order detection program to combat an infection that can lead to heart damage from rheumatic fever. Children 5 to 14 years of age are especially vulnerable to the infection.

Despite forecasts of a collapse in the real estate market following the passage of new zoning regulations in the city last year, the value of improved real estate has attained greater stability, according to James Felt, chairman of the City Planning Commission.
DETROIT, Oct. 2 (AP) -- The head of the National Association of Manufacturers called on business men today to lead "a positive offensive aimed at reducing the scope of Federal authority."

The city will hold a festival program tomorrow night on the steps of the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street, to mark the fourth full year of its Salute to Seasons celebrations.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 2 (AP) -- The National Association of Shippers Advisory Boards opens its twenty-fifth annual meeting here tomorrow. It will plan legislative action in "a monumental struggle for equality in competition."

Following the "grass is greener" principle, a leading foreign film distributor has decided to establish a separate company to release 16-mm. versions of his films. Simultaneously, a prominent 16-mm. distributor yesterday announced plans to invade the theatrical field.

MADISON, Ind., Oct. 2 (AP) -- Bill Muncey of Seattle, driving Miss Century 21, followed Bill Cantrell in Gale V, across the finish line today in the final heat of the Governor's Cup regatta on the Ohio River.

PARIS, Oct. 2 -- The exact age of Jose Meiffret is not known. Meiffret is between 47 and 50 years old. A florist by profession, he is small, nearly bald and fragile in build. He has a poor stomach and a weak heart.

ONE of the nicest things that has happened to the working girl is the gradual mushrooming of small midtown shops that specialize in selling smart and reasonably priced clothes. And, as the numbers of these stores increase, the old-timers remain as excellent as ever.

VIENNA, Oct. 2 -- The Indian and Soviet delegations to the fifth general conference of the International Atomic Energy Agency obtained today a twenty-four-hour postponement of the election of Dr. Sigvard Eklund as the next Director General.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 2 -- The Security Council met briefly today and postponed debate on the applications of Mauritania and Outer Mongolia for admission to the United Nations.
DENVER, Oct. 2 -- New developments in Denver's spreading police scandal, including the involvement of several more policemen, were suggested today by state investigators.
The Academy of Religion and Mental Health will hold its first annual dinner Oct. 26 at the Plaza.

Back from a trip to Outer Mongolia, William O. Douglas, far-ranging Supreme Court Justice, reports the country's intellectuals "starved for contact with the West." If there were a thousand scholarships for Mongolians in American schools, he states, there would be 2,000 applications.
A young man with a beard is packing them in at the Abraham Straus Import Fair, which will be held until Oct. 14.
Senator Jacob K. Javits accused President Kennedy yesterday of having timed his support for the New York World's Fair to help Mayor Wagner in the midst of his campaign for re-election.
LONDON, Oct. 2 -- Britain declared today that it was premature to talk of a Big Four foreign minister's meeting next month on the Berlin question.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) -- The United States may withdraw from the Warsaw Convention, a treaty that regulates the liability of airlines toward passengers in international air transportation, it was indicated today.
