Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa assailed the City Planning Commission's $746,624,713 capital budget for 1962 yesterday as "nothing but a political propaganda pitch."
Kenosha, Wis., borrowed $4,690,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance public improvements.

BRADFORD, N.H., Oct. 2 -- If the leaves on the trees of the sovereign state of New Hampshire could bleed, then the ground of choice grouse and woodcock covers would be running red today from sprayed bird shot.
May I thank you for devoting a special article to myself in your edition of Sept. 23.
Rocky Graziano dropped into the St. Nicholas Arena for a visit last night. He must have been an inspiration to the boxers.

While Cliff Livingston, Sam Huff and their playmates slept till noon, pampering bruises on soft mattresses, the offices of the New York Football Giants were filled yesterday morning with the voices of men in pursuit of victory.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (9P) -- The Supreme Court was told today that a special master's plan for ending a long legal fight over Colorado River water "would be a regional disaster, seriously injuring every part of the Colorado River Basin."
Iowa maintained its grip on the No. 1 spot among the nation's football teams today and powerful Mississippi continued as the No. 2 team in the Associated Press weekly poll.

LONDON, Oct. 2 -- Opening of the new bookkeeping account period on the stock exchange here today brought no improvement to industrial shares prices. Most stocks continued to decline, the leaders by around a shilling (14 cents).

LONDON, Oct. 2 -- Part of the fund-raising activity of the Imperial Cancer Research Fund in England is the sponsorship of a bridge tournament and the publication of a "Book of Hands" to which the leading British bridge players contribute their favorites.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 2 -- Brig. Gen. Frank L. Howley, former United States Commandant in Berlin and now a vice president of New York University, testified today that events in Angola had been distorted to Portugal's disadvanage in published reports and statements.
The trustees of the bankrupt New Haven Railroad have told a Federal Court that they are investigating the chances of cutting some passenger and freight services and revising passenger fares.
BLACKPOOL, England, Oct. 2 -- A Left-Wing move to reopen the case of a union ousted from the Labor party was decisively defeated today at the party's sixtieth conference.
CHICAGO, Oct. 2 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- Top officials in the United States and Soviet space programs appealed today for greater international cooperation in the peaceful exploration of space.

A DISARMING reach for an original approach marks "The Sap of Life," he musical that arrived last night at One Sheridan Square. The experiment is not entirely successful, but when it works, it has appealing quality and taste.
ATLANTA, Oct. 2 -- The issue of hotel segregation sharply reduced attendance today at a national meeting of Employment Security Program Administrators.
The Brass Rail, Inc., a leading restaurant and food service chain, and the Interstate Vending Company of Chicago are discussing merger.

In increasing numbers suburban families are building shelters against radioactive fall-out in their basements and backyards -- or are preparing to do so. But just how many is virtually impossible to determine because of an almost universal insistence that the projects be kept secret, a survey shows.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Oct. 2 (AP) -- An intercontinental range Atlas missile carrying several special experiments successfully shot 5,000 miles into the south Atlantic Ocean today.

ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Oct. 2 -- The snarled attempts to negotiate on the problem of white mercenaries in the Katanga army are jeopardizing the provisional ceasefire between United Nations and provincial forces.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- The plan of White House political advisers for policy-making members of the Administration to conduct seminars in a number of key cities has the primary purpose of producing public pressure on the Eighty-seventh Congress for legislating major domestic programs which failed at its first session.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 2 -- Ethiopia called on sister African states today to set up their own regional organization to deal with African problems and keep out "cold war" influences.

Net operating earnings of the Irving Trust Company of New York aggregated $12,049,188, or $2.23 a share, for the first nine months of 1961, the bank reported yesterday. This was a 12 per cent decline from the $13,743,859, or $2.54 a share, for the first three quarters of 1960.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 2 -- The United States rejected today a revised Soviet proposal under which an acting Secretary General, with three deputies, would conduct the affairs of the United Nations "in a spirit of concert."

CHICAGO, Oct. 2 (AP) -- The United States Government filed today a suggested plan for disposal of more than $3,000,000,000 worth of General Motors Corporation stock held by the E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 2 (UPI) -- A Passaic, N.J., chiropody student was found slain on the rear lawn of the John Hay High School here today.
PARIS, Oct. 2 -- President de Gaulle threatened tonight to dissolve Parliament and reassume dictatorial powers if necessary to carry through his domestic and international policies.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- Labor Secretary Arthur J. Goldberg indicated today that he would dispute Michael Quill's call for readmission of the Teamsters Union to the merged labor movement.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company and its principal telephone subsidiaries reported yesterday that operating revenues and net income for the quarter ended on Aug. 31 rose from the year-earlier levels.
Charles G. Tierney, general attorney of the State Insurance Fund, was unanimously nominated by the Bronx County Democratic executive committee yesterday to run for City Court Justice.
Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz asked the city's 1,200 union locals yesterday to let him appear at their meetings "in the interest of fair play" and present his views about labor relations.
Following is the text of President de Gaulle's address yesterday in France, as made available here in translation by the French Information Service:

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 2 (AP) -- The United States Davis Cup tennis downed India, 3 -- 2, today in an interzone final. The Americans will play Italy next in Rome where, Captain David L. Freed said, "Prospects are "pretty dismal."

DALLAS, Tex., Oct. 2 -- The head of the natural gas industry's trade association today praised the Federal Power Commission's recent endorsement of "area pricing" for the regulation of field prices of gas.
The small but vigorous United Taxpayers party staged a sidewalk demonstration outside the Board of Elections yesterday in preparation for its fight to stay on the ballot.

The Franklin National Bank, the largest bank with headquarters on Long Island, may be feeling the heat of competition from even bigger New York City banks that have opened branches on Franklin's home grounds during the last year.

ATLANTA, Oct. 2 (AP) -- A Federal court suit accuses the successor to the late Bishop Charles M. Grace of using church funds to maintain himself "in unbelievable luxury" after illegally seizing the bishopric.

ELKINS PARK, Pa., Oct. 3 -- An aggressive Philadelphia team beat the women's field hockey squad of England, 3 -- 0 today. Rain fell throughout the sixty-minute game while 1,000 spectators watched at Wall Park.

In your assessment of the accomplishments of the Eighty-seventh Congress during its first session I was particularly impressed by the assertion that failure to pass Federal aid to education was in part due to "an artificial religious issue."
The forward price spurt in prime corporate debt securities came to a halt yesterday in a quiet trading session. United States Government securities tended to ease in price, too.
RYE, N.Y., Oct. 3 -- Doug Ford won the Westchester Golf Association's open championship today as a sort of going-away present.
DUBLIN, Oct. 3 -- The pipe bands have been out in the Street these last two nights and flags have been flying from the speaker's platform on the bullet-scarred steps of the Post Office.

The school system asked the city's teachers yesterday to remember to speak positively in talking with parents. In a "compilation of observations of speech patterns that lead to difficulty in meeting with parents," it urged teachers to avoid words and phrases that "inadveterntly suggest prejudice" of all kinds.

A SONG recital of considerable distinction was given in Town Hall last night by William Lewis, tenor, and Earl Wild, pianist. Both artists are well known in this city, since Mr. Lewis has sung with the Metropolitan, the New York City and other opera companies here, and Mr. Wild is distinguished recitalist in his own right.
NUCLEAR weapons, rather than conventional arms, are the key to the Berlin crisis in the opinion of many United States generals and diplomats in Europe.

" THE HORIZON BOOK OF THE RENAISSANCE"* is one of the most beautiful picture books in many years, which is reason enough why it will undoubtedly be one of the most popular Christmas books of this season. But, unlike many handsome picture books, it is also a joy to read.
MOGADISHU, Somalia, Oct. 3 -- The first United States Senators to visit Somalia since independence left yesterday after a twenty-four hour visit here.

Thoroughbred racing moves from Belmont to Aqueduct today. Harbor View Farm's Wolfram will carry the high weight of 126 pounds in the feature, the $28,750 Long Island Handicap, a mile and three-sixteenths event on the turf.

ELMONT, L.I., Oct. 3 -- Ninety passengers were injured when a Long Island Rail-Road train slid into a bumper while attempting to stop at the station inside the Belmont Park racetrack area today -- last day of the Belmont season.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 3 -- Canada said today that the United Nations had to find a way to force all nations to refrain from testing nuclear weapons. Howard C. Green, Canada's Secretary of State for External Affairs, asked the General Assembly to "insist" on an end of nuclear testing to protect present and future generations from the hazards of radioactive fall-out.
The Motion Picture Production Code was amended yesterday to enable filmmakers to deal with the subject of homosexuality.

Debutante daughters of members of the Society of Mayflower Descendants of the State of New York will be presented at a reception before the society's dinner-dance in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza on Nov. 3.

The blockfront on the east side of Broadway between Neptune and Brower Avenues in Woodmere, L.I., has been sold by the estate of Cyril de Cordova Brower. It was bought by Fulhilt, Inc., representing George Berkman and Michael Berger.
Michael J. Quill tried hard yesterday to work up a boom for Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg as a candidate for Governor in New York State next year.

Mayor Wagner declared yesterday that he would place the city's 1962 fiscal and legislative program "squarely in the middle" of his campaign for re-election by submitting it to "the state" within the next few days.
LONDON, Oct. 2 -- Gold from Communist China obtained a "good-delivery" rating on the London bullion market today. This means that the gold is of a sufficiently high quality to be traded.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 3 -- A citizens group here has embarked on a program to transform Princeton University's McCarter Theatre into a cultural center for secondary schools throughout New Jersey.

The County Trust Company, White Plains, N.Y., has reported record total assets of $549,103,429 on Sept. 30, compared with $504,760,216 on Sept. 30, 1960. Deposits also were at a new peak of $497,468,015, up from $458,448,382 at the end of September last year.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Following is the text of a statement by President Kennedy today on signing the education bill:
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 3 -- Trevor Gardner, former Assistant Secretary of the Air Force, called today for permanent military control of United States operations in space.
The Aluminum Company of America reduced yesterday by 2 per cent the price of calcined alumina A-2, a grade used widely by manufacturers of abrasives and refractory and ceramic products.
Joseph Steiner has been appointed works manager of the Jersey Tab Card Corporation of Union, N.J. He will be in charge of production, purchasing and procurement.

When Del Shofner lines up at left end for the New York Football Giants, corner backs fret and safety men worry. They are self-conscious over the fact that this lanky, elusive passcatcher can make any defender look bad.
CHICAGO, Oct. 3 (AP) -- The national president of the Amateur Athletic Union charged the National Collegiate Athletic Association today with "plotting to take over control of all amateur athletics."
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 25 to 60 cents a bale yesterday.
NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 2 (AP) -- A local group plans to buy a 200-acre island in the middle of Narragansett Bay from John W. Mackay of New York, who once used it as a hunting preserve.

The United States Steel Corporation said yesterday that it would participate in a stainless steel plant venture in Italy. This will mark the first steel rolling effort abroad by the largest steel producer in the United States.

Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg told the National Association of Manufacturers yesterday that it was "not a good thing" to have a strike in the auto industry when President Kennedy was confronted with crises in Berlin and elsewhere.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- President Kennedy paid tribute today to the Adams family of his native Massachusetts. Their vitality and devotion to the public interest, he said, was "the most exceptional scarlet thread which runs throughout the entire tapestry of American political life."

BONN, Germany, Oct. 3 -- A group of sixteen East German families consisting of fifty-five persons staged a mass escape into West Germany in the Goettingen area last night to elude deportation from their homes by the East German Communists.

THE Cincinnati Red Stockings once went through an entire baseball season without a defeat. That was in 1869. The current collection is nowhere near so formidable or invulnerable as their ancestors, the first professional team ever organized.
ACCRA, Ghana, Oct. 3 -- The Government announced tonight the arrest of forty-eight persons accused of clandestine and dangerous activities.

While economists in this country wonder just when the consumers here will step up their purchases to quicken the recovery, a leading world salesman is pondering a market abroad where consumers are bound to increase their buying.
Dancers of the Leningrad Kirov Ballet, who see New York in hasty glimpses between rehearsals and performances, find it a city of contrasts.
LONDON, Oct. 3 -- The United States announced today that because of the Berlin crisis it had changed its mind about closing four Air Force bases in Britain.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Oct. 3 (AP) -- The captain of the sunken tanker Hess Mariner refused here today to discuss the sinking until after the end of an official hearing.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (UPI) -- The National Labor Relations Board ruled today that an employer had violated the Taft-Hartley Act by moving a blouse factory from Philadelphia to Ware Shoals, S.C., to obtain concession from a union.
Russ Warren, a 197-pound halfback from North Hatfield, Mass., was named the Ivy League back of the week yesterday for his performance in Columbia's 50 -- 0 victory over Brown last Saturday.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. 3 (UPI) -- The Federal Government accused Mississippi authorities today of making a "trumped-up charge" against a Nashville, Tenn., Negro in an attempt to intimidate Negroes in Walthall County, Miss.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Nine witnesses refused to answer questions today as the House Committee on Un-American Activities sought to find out whether the new National Assembly for Democratic Rights was influenced by the Communist party.

ALTON, N.Y., Oct. 3 (AP) -- Better foods in greater variety are flowing to the shelves and freezers in homes all over the nation. Mechanization in the fields, orchards and processing plants is largely responsible for this development.
Many tickets already' have been sold for the Artur Rubinstein recital to be held at Carnegie Hall on Nov. 3 for Big Brothers, Inc. The pianist will donate the proceeds of the event to the agency.
The British Overseas Airways Corporation announced three changes in its top managerial personnel yesterday to cope with the "challenging" problem on its North Atlantic routes.
Harold A. Felix, City Labor Commissioner, refused yesterday to intervene in the strike of the musicians of the New York Philharmonic.

The office leasing field is a relatively new aspect of real estate and there are many misconceptions about its operation, according to H.K. Negbaur, president of H.K. Negbaur Co., midtown office leasing concern.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Oct. 3 (AP) -- A Minneapolis housewife won $25,000 in a baking contest today with her candy bar cookies. Mrs. Alice H. Reese took the top prize in Pillsbury's Grand National Bakeoff.
LONDON, Oct. 3 -- British Government securities continued to advance today while industrial shares fell further. The Financial Times index of industral shares fell to its lowest in two years.
The parents of children attending Public School 119 in Harlem charged yesterday that the Board of Education had treated them as "second-class citizens."
NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 3 (AP) -- Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower made a visit to Newport today and said it was like a homecoming.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Prince Sihanouk of Cambodia takes us to task (in a letter to this newspaper today) for the changing intentions of U.S. foreign policy. For example he cites the shift from Mr. Dulles' belief that neutrality is "immoral" to Mr. Harriman's search for "true neutrality" in Laos.
Columbia University has been accused of an attempt to drive Negroes and Puerto Ricans from the Morningside Heights area.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Oct. 3 -- The Labor party, the leading Opposition group with one-third of the votes in Parliament, supported today a proposal to place Netherlands New Guinea under a United Nations authority.

The board of directors of the Endicott Johnson Corporation elected P.J. Casella as president yesterday. This was the first time in the leading shoe manufacturing company's history that someone outside the founding Endicott or Johnson families has been named to the presidency.
SHANNON, Ireland, Oct. 3 (AP) -- A DC-7C charter airliner carrying ninety-eight passengers who were stranded here for a week took off for Chicago early today.
The First National City Bank of New York is opening an exhibit today designed to tell in flashing lights and recorded reports the story of banking.
BROWNSVILLE, Tex., Oct. 3 (UPI) -- The crew of a tug removed fourteen men today from a $5,500,000 oil-drilling barge that had been battered by wind and twenty-foot waves in the Gulf of Mexico.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- The kidnapping of a high South Vietnamese official, following three attacks by the Communist Viet Cong in battalion strength, has hardened doubts here about the usefulness of the International Control Commission.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Members of Congress will soon be getting a service making it easy for them to smother city areas with mail.
DETROIT, Oct. 3 -- The United Automobile Workers called a nation-wide strike today against the Ford Motor Company, the nation's second largest automobile producer.
The new Cure D'Ars College Seminary of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York will be built in Hartsdale, Cardinal Spellman announced yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 3 -- A group of small-power delegates started work today on a compromise plan to break the deadlock over the appointment of a temporary successor to the late Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold.
The American Broadcasting Company yesterday decided to go it alone in developing a children's program for next season.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- President Kennedy has called in the chairmen of the three national radio and television networks to see what they can do about correcting what he feels to be a poor image of the United States abroad.

" THE ART OF ASSEMBLAGE," opening today at the Museum of Modern Art, is that institution's first big spectacle of the year and just about as spectacular as any it has ever staged. Theatrical to the limit, it is a dazzler from start to finish, from the best things in it to the worst.

TORONTO, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Floyd Patterson, the world heavyweight boxing champion, will defend his title in Toronto against Tom McNeeley of Arlington, Mass., on Dec. 4, the promoters of the bout said today.
NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 3 (AP) -- The nonplaying captain of the United States Davis Cup team said today it was "a tough blow" that Bernard Bartzen would be unable to play against Italy.
LONDON, Oct. 3 -- Postponement of a second charter flight of President Airlines of Los Angeles delayed the return of more Americans today.
A Harlem landlord who has failed to provide heat for more than a year was sentenced to sixty days in jail and fined $150 in Housing Court yesterday.

A Kings County rackets grand jury investigating the disposition of boats built by students at a Brooklyn high school filed a report yesterday disclosing that it could find nothing criminal in the project.
ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Oct. 3 -- The cease-fire discussions between the United Nations and Katanga have apparently broken down.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Secretary of Commerce Luther H. Hodges said today he wished many areas officially designated as depressed would pull out of the Federal aid program and conduct their own economic development projects.

Generalissimo Franco this week reached the twenty-fifth anniversary of his undisputed rule as the Caudillo, or military dictator, of Spain. It was typical of him that he should have celebrated it with some further demands on the United States.

The resignation of Abraham M. Lindenbaum from the City Planning Commission should not end the inquiry into the ill-conceived luncheon roll-call through which builders and real estate operators doing business with the city were induced to contribute to Mayor Wagner's campaign.
A $3,000,000 Hollywood film based on a true story of contemporary India will start production in Bombay early next month.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- The Pentagon ordered a draft of 495 physicians, 154 dentists and 67 veterinarians today in support of the military build-up.

The First National City Bank of New York has reported net operating earnings of $52,523,000, or $4.21 a share, for the nine months ended last Saturday. This compared with $56,015,000, or $4.49 a share, for the 1960 period.

Gulf States Utilities Company awarded $15,000,000 of debentures yesterday to Lehman Brothers and associates on a bid of 100.181 for a 4 5/8 per cent interest coupon. The group is reoffering the twenty-year debentures to investors today at 100.978 to yield 4.55 per cent to maturity.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- A secret evaluation of United States-Polish relations by Ambassador Jacob D. Beam, containing suggestions for changes in policy toward Warsaw, was among classified United States documents passed to the Polish Government earlier this year.

Mrs. Charles S. Guggenheimer, known to thousands of music lovers as Minnie for her work in arranging summer concerts at Lewisohn Stadium, was honored by the 100 Year Association of New York last night.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 3 -- To hear Dick Colman talk, Columbia is all the football team it figures to be from its 50-0 stampede over Brown.
ALBANY, Oct. 3 -- Public hearings on proposed new lines for New York's Congressional Districts were ruled out today.
CHICAGO, Oct. 3 (AP) -- A rally that developed late in the session raised almost the entire list of grain futures on the Board of Trade today.
TULSA, Oct. 3 (AP) -- The defender in the United States Golf Association's senior amateur tournament, Michael Cestone of Montclair, N.J., was eliminated today on a missed putt.

DETROIT, Oct. 3 -- The director of the Ford Department of the United Automobile Workers has found both challenge and satisfaction in his work as a labor leader. One of the challenges reached a climax today when the nation's 120,000 Ford workers went out on strike.
A sanity hearing for Oct. 25 has been set for Burton N. Pugach, disbarred lawyer who has been found insane by psychiatrists in Kings County Hospital.

MIAMI, Oct. 3 -- An informal honor guard of old-time pilots was waiting here today to greet Capt. Dick Merrill, one of the nation's foremost airline fliers, at the end of his last flight on active duty.
The elections of Thomas E. Moffitt and Herbert L. Barnet as directors of the Marine Midland Trust Company of New York were announced yesterday by George C. Textor, president.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Oct. 3 -- After two hours and ten minutes of deliberation, a Union County jury today acquitted retired Police Chief Albert P. Pfirrmann of Westfield on charges of misconduct in office. He had been accused of downgrading eight traffic tickets.
Trading on the New York commodity exchanges yesterday showed further declines for coffee and cocoa, but greater stability for copper futures.

Two New Jersey officials of the International Longshoremen's Association refused yesterday to answer Waterfront Commission questions on a five-day work stoppage in May, 1960, at the American Export Line pier in Hoboken.

" THE NEW BREED," not too different from the old police breed, came to Channel 7 last night. The new show sported familiar trappings. This one was about the Metropolitan Squad of the Los Angeles Police Department.

A UNIFORMED doorman rolled out a red carpet in front of the Broadhurst Theatre last night, and then spent the better part of the evening trying to keep people and mud off it. The lemonade concession had been closed in deference to first night.
The Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corporation (Transco) filed an application yesterday for a certificate from the Federal Power Commission for a $49,000,000 expansion program.
CHICAGO, Oct. 3 -- "Encouraging" results from trials of a new method of treating heart attack were reported at a medical meeting here today.
BLACKPOOL, England, Oct. 3 -- Hugh Gaitskell and his policy of modern, moderate socialism made three important advances today at the Labor movement's annual conference.
WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 3 -- Those Roosevelt Raceway fans who were shut out at the daily double windows tonight had no excuse.

THE American Ballet Theatre came to life last night in the second performance of its season at the Fifty-fourth Street Theatre with a highly effective presentation of Birgit Cullberg's "Miss Julie." Toni Lander had the title role, as she has had on previous occasions, but as Jean, the butler, Caj Selling was making his first appearance here in an important role.

The current effort to preserve both the Alexander Hamilton Grange, now located at Convent Avenue and 141st Street, adjoining the City College campus, and the old Merchant's House at 29 East Fourth Street prompts the writer to alert our citizenry before it is too late.
DAMASCUS, Syria, Oct. 3 -- The revolutionary Government of Premier Mamoun al-Kuzbari is being carried by a wave of nationalist and anti-Egyptian feeling, but challenges to its existence are looming.
PARIS, Oct. 3 -- The French Parliament opened its autumn session today smarting under the scorn heaped upon political parties by President de Gaulle last night.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 3 -- Failure to legislate the aid-to-education measures proposed by President Kennedy constitutes a threat to national strength, Abraham A. Ribicoff, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, said here today.
A total of 1,030 persons were hurt in auto accident here last weeek, compared with 967 in the like 1960 period, the Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- President Kennedy reluctantly approved tonight a two-year $900,000,000 bill on school aid that represented only a small part of the program he had sought.
The theft of $250,000 in securities from a finance company last April was reported solved yesterday by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 3 -- President Arturo Frondizi's long-held middle course between the United States and Cuba has been severely jolted by disclosure of the Purported Cuban-directed campaign of subversion in Argentina.

AS a book writer, composer, lyricist and director Noel Coward is an old pro. He has summoned all -- well, nearly all -- his gifts into assembling "Sail Away," which was piped into the Broadhurst last night.
The Young Women's Christian Association of the City of New York will hold its annual luncheon in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria on Oct. 18.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Oct. 3 (AP) -- A century of segregation ended in Memphis today when thirteen Negro first graders were admitted to white schools.

UNION About 120,000 members of fifty-eight local unions of the United Automobile Workers are on strike. These workers have been employed in .eighty,. eight facilities of the Ford Motor Company in twenty-six states.

BEDFORD VILLAGE, N.Y., Oct. 3 -- The 1680 deed by which Indians sold 7,673 acres here to white settlers for $13, has been found by historians Bedford town officials said today the land was worth $19,182,500 in the current market.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP) -- A marked upsurge of interest in fall-out shelters throughout the United States was reported today by state civil defense chiefs at the opening of a four-day fall conference here.

NUTLEY, N.J., Oct. 3 (AP) -- Fifteen-hundred workers struck the Federal Laboratories of the International Telephone and Telegraph Company today, but company and union officials disagreed as to the effect of the strike.
Elsa's three lion cubs are alive. At least they were seen alive last August by George and Joy Adamson, who raised their mother from an orphan cub to the animal kingdom's most celebrated lioness.
VIENNA, Oct. 3 -- The appointment of Dr. Arne Sigvard Eklund of Sweden as the next Director General of the International Atomic Energy Agency was confirmed tonight at the agency's annual conference.
NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 3 -- The economically advanced countries were urged today to establish freer trade policies to supplement their aid to under-developed nations.
LIBERTY, N.Y., Oct. 3 -- Governor Rockefeller called tonight for local government officials to show greater "courage" and halt "the concentration of power in Washington."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- The State Department has refused permission for a group of Soviet space scientists now in Washington to attend the annual scientific meeting of the American Rocket Society in New York City next week.
City Council President Abe Stark charged yesterday that most gasoline suppliers raised their wholesale prices about 2 cents a gallon in Nassau County last week after his call for an inquiry.

! Girls Town, Inc., at 4316 Van Cortlandt Park East, the Bronx, where girls between the ages of 12 and 16 are given help in mending their broken lives, will receive the proceeds of a dinner dance at the Savoy Hilton on Oct. 27.

A British physician said here yesterday that a world-wide trend existed toward impersonal medicine and that it was caused by technological advances rather than governmental interventon in the health field.

THE Sicilian confectioner is prodigal in his use of sugar, frosting and artistic flourishes. His shop window in big cities like Palermo and Catania is ablaze with brightly colored marzipan fruits, exotic, cream-filled pastries and cakes iced in patterns as richly elaborate as baroque architecture.

FREEMAN GOSDEN and Charles Correll in recent years have had a difficult problem: how to keep active in the entertainment field without the two characters that once upon a time were part of the American idiom, "Amos 'n' Andy."
Vada Pinson and Frank Robinson will bat third and fourth for the Cincinnati Reds against the Yankees today -- weather permitting -- at the Stadium.
Vito P. Battista, the United Taxpayers party candidate for Mayor, was ruled off the ballot at a stormy hearing yesterday at the Board of Elections.
Some people who struck a gold mine with "Bye Bye Birdie" will be reunited in "The King of the Gypsies." The musical is scheduled for Broadway in the fall of 1962.
The City Planning Commission has undergone a remarkable change from gloom to good cheer between preparation of the 1961 and 1962 capital budgets for New York. This is, of course, an election year.
DENVER, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Seventeen suspended members of the Denver Police Department appeared in District Court as defendants today in the city's law enforcement scandal.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 3 (AP) -- A Supreme Court Justice from Pennsylvania urged a change of name today for the Cincinnati baseball team. Anything but Reds would do, he said.

The appointment of Royce H. Savage, United States District Judge for the Northern District of Oklahoma, as general counsel of the Gulf Oil Corporation, effective Nov. 1, has been announced. Judge Savage has announced his intention to resign his judgeship on Oct. 31.
BERLIN, Oct. 3 -- Farmers in several parts of Communist East Germany were reported today to have begun a slowdown of the harvest.
Plans to improve the image of discount selling and establish standards for the field were announced yesterday by a group of leading discount merchants.

A New York brokerage concern, four of its officers and Lowell M. Birrell, the fugitive financier, were indicted yesterday for conspiracy in a $250,000 stock fraud involving the sale of unregistered common stock of Jeanette Minerals, Ltd., a Canadian corporation.

The Imperial Cleaning Company, owner of a wholesale dry cleaning business in the metropolitan area, has leased about twenty stores in an expansion of the chain. Several of the shops have been subleased to retailers, who will operate them under a franchise system.

Profits of the Glidden Company and its Canadian subsidiaries fell slightly but sales rose in the fiscal year ended on Aug. 31, according to a preliminary report in a proxy statement being issued to shareholders.
ROME, Oct. 3 -- An informed Italian Communist predicted today that the Communist parties of Western Europe would support Premier Khrushchev against "Maximalists."
The opening of a student-run discount bookstore in a bare-walled, one-room flat at Broadway and 112th Street has stirred a controversy at Columbia University.

SARANAC INN, N.Y., Oct. 3 -- American high schools are coming under in a crossfire of conflicting demands, the seventy-ninth annual meeting of the State Council of City and Village School Superintendents was told today.
DALLAS, Tex., Oct. 3 -- W. M. Elmer, president of the Texas Gas Transmission Corporation of Owensboro, Ky., called on the gas industry here today to unite or suffer serious financial setbacks.

DETROIT, Oct. 3 -- The Ford Motor Company said today that its operations had been halted by the United Automobile Workers' strike at eighty-eight plants and facilities where the union has eighty-five separate bargaining units.

Phil Hill of Santa Monica, Calif., the new world road racing champion, will watch the Grand Prix of the United States from a track-side seat on Sunday at Watkins Glen, N.Y. He has accepted the post of honorary chief steward for the last championship whirl of 1961.

Plans to consolidate Food Fair Properties, Inc., and the Major Realty Corporation through an exchange of stock were announced jointly yesterday by Samuel Friedland, president of Food Fair Properties, and Matthew B. Weinstein, president of Major Realty.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP) -- The chairman of the House Judiciary Committee said he would oppose what he termed a dangerously monopolistic proposal by the Morgan New York State Corporation to become a holding company.
CHICAGO, Oct. 3 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
A cabaret troupe that shows how Germans laugh at themselves is here for a six-day visit.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 3 (UPI) -- An official of the Bureau of Mines said today that the United States demand for coal would increase by about 236,000,000 tons in the next fourteen years.
The swift pace of events in Ghana is clearly leading to some re-evaluation of policy within and outside that country, the first of the sub-Saharan African states to be given its independence.

LONDON, Oct. 3 -- The reserves of gold and convertible currencies held by Britain as central banker for the sterling area rose last month by 24,000,000 ($67,200,000). This brought the total to 1,269,000,000 ($3,553,200,000).

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Following are excerpts from the remarks of President Kennedy today at the luncheon in observance of the publication of the diary and autobiography of John Adams, constituting the first four volumes of the Adams papers:

Paperboard production dipped to 349,991 tons in the week ended Saturday from a record 350,512 tons in tile preceding week, the National Paperboard Association reported yesterday. A year ago 324,667 tons were produced.
Anthony Anastasia, leader of longshoremen on the Brooklyn waterfront, said yesterday that discrimination charges made Monday by several Negro dockers were "unfounded."

DANBURY, N.H., Oct. 3 -- In a woodcock cover near here yesterday, Dan Tibbetts, a state conservation officer, shot a woodcock found by his pointers, Pat and Dick. After the bird had been retrieved, he stroked its brown, mottled feathers and said, "It's a pity we can't put them back after the hunt."

The Leningrad Kirov Ballet began its second installment of New York appearances last night by giving a complete performance of "Swan Lake" at Madison Square Garden. The company was in full costume, but the elaborate sets that go with the production were not there.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- The Federal Home Loan Bank Board has quietly issued a policy resolution opposing any racial discrimination in mortgage lending by the 4,700 savings and loan associations that it supervises.
WASHINGTON Oct. 3 -- The Surgeon General of the United States Public Health Service was elected chairman today of a Pan American conference on health problems.

At the turn of the century tuberculosis was the second major cause of death in the United States, with a mortality rate of 184.7 per 100,000. Over the years it has been gradually reduced, until today it ranks thirteenth among the causes of death in this country.
The election 6f Avery Rockefeller Jr., New York investment banker, as chairman of the board of governors of the National Association of Securities Dealers for 1962 was announced yesterday.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 3 -- Striking, masters and mates approved the unloading of one ship and continued to picket, several others here today as their coast-wide walkout went into its sixth day.

RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Oct. 3 -- President Mohammad Ayub Khan urged today that the United States "use its influence" to help settle the fourteen-year-old dispute over Kashmir between Pakistan and India.
Casey Stengel has come back to New York. As the manager of the Mets, New York's 1962 entry in the National League, it would seem he never left town.
MOSCOW, Oct. 3 (AP) -- A band of peace marchers completed an 8,000-mile trip to Moscow today and as the marchers approached Red Square they waved banners calling for disarmament.
The East Bay Municipal Utilities District, Calif., is planning the sale of $30,000,000 of bonds on Jan. 9. The issue will be secured by the general taxing power.

CHICKS and ducks and geese sometimes scurry to receive the affectionate caresses of visitors to the new Children's Zoo in Central Park, at Fifth Avenue, between Sixty-fifth and Sixty-sixth Streets. Other exhibits include houses of straw, sticks and bricks inhabited by the Three Little Pigs; MacDonald's Farm with sheep and donkeys, a barn with a cow and calf and a ring where children may pet small animals.
WARSAW, Oct. 3 -- Poland and Czechoslovakia made public today a joint statement in support of the Soviet charge of West German "aggression" and "reaction."

MONROVIA, Liberia, Oct. 3 (AP) -- In a crackdown against what it calls pro-Communist or anti-Western plots, the Liberian Government announced today restrictions on the activities of all foreign diplomatic and consular missions here.

The New York Mets and the Houston Colts, who will be added to the National League next year, will have to choose chiefly from veteran players in the draft to be held the day after the world series ends.

Back in 1939, when the New York Yankees last faced the Cincinnati Reds in a world series, a manufacturer of safety razors decided to take a bold gamble. To the surprise of Madison Avenue, the Gillette Company announced it would be the sole sponsor of the Series on radio at a then considerable cost of $100,000 plus air time.
WARSAW, Oct. 3 -- Preparations for fall military maneuvers by the Warsaw Pact forces are publicly in evidence in Poland.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Nonagricultural employment last month reached 61,372,000, a record for September, the Labor Department reported today. However, the seasonally adjusted unemployment rate hung close to 7 per cent for the eleventh straight month. It was at 6.8 per cent, a decline of one-tenth of 1 per cent from the August rate.

The keynote speaker at the annual convention of the National Consumer Finance Association, L. Walter Lundell, said yesterday that the role of consumer credit would become increasingly important in the future in achieving national economic goals.
KANSAS CITY, Oct. 3 (AP) -- The International Convention of Christian Churches rejected today a proposal that it criticize the National Council of Churches for pronouncements on political issues.
Television ratings, often criticized as incomplete and inconclusive, were defended by a sponsor's representative here yesterday.
The election 6f Avery Rockefeller Jr., New York investment banker, as chairman of the board of governors of the National Association of Securities Dealers for 1962 was announced yesterday.
Television ratings, often criticized as incomplete and inconclusive, were defended by a sponsor's representative here yesterday.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Oct. 3 -- The Minister of Economic Affairs said today that unemployment in South Africa was rising.
For the first time in twenty-nine years, 70-year-old Charles Kierst wasn't first, he said last night.

GENEVA, Oct. 3 -- A broad range of trade problems will be studied next month by ministers of the member nations of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT), the trade group's council announced here today.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 3 -- Glen H. Taylor, head of President Airlines, offered tonight an explanation for the stranding of two planeloads of passengers in Britain and Ireland.

TRENTON, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner said today his vetoes of two Port of New York Authority resolutions had forced the bi-state agency to temper its demands for increased rentals from bus companies and induced it to review its public relations operations.

LONDON, Oct. 3 -- London bridge clubs, with one exception, resemble those of New York City, except that there are more bridge clubs in London and the more elaborate of them are somewhat more elaborate than New York's best.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- The outlook now is for a calm, if limited, discussion of the German problem between President Kennedy and the Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei Gromyko, here later this week.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- President Kennedy and his foreign aid administrator told the under-developed countries today that their willingness to make social and economic reforms would help determine their share of United States aid.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 3 -- David T. Wilentz charged today that the Department of Defense had "short-changed this state and the nation" in deciding to close the Raritan Arsenal and curtail activities at the Lakehurst Naval Air Station.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Citing budgetary needs, President Kennedy vetoed tonight a bill that would have given $60,800,000 in annual pay raises to the 560,000 postal workers through changes in the longevity system.

Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz called yesterday for a "penetrating inquiry" by the State Investigating Commission into the fund-raising luncheon that produced $25,000 in pledges for Mayor Wagner's campaign.
LONDON, Oct. 3 -- Queen Elizabeth conferred an earldom today on Antony Armstrong-Jones, her brother-in-law.
Stocks jogged a little lower yesterday in a dull and listless session of the New York Stock Exchange. Volume was smaller than on Monday, more stocks fell than rose and the market averages declined.
POTTSTOWN, Pa., Oct. 3 -- This was a cold and rainy day at The Hill School but athletic activity, once classes were over, hummed as if it were Indian summer.

The Japan Development Bank raised-$20,000,000 in the United States capital market yesterday through the sale of fixed-interest securities. The bonds were offered in four series and a spokesman for the investment bankers who negotiated the financing said that the issue was oversubscribed.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 3 -- Eight top miltary advisers of the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization met here today in secret conference under the shadow of crisis in Vietnam and continued uncertainty in Laos.
SANTA MONICA, Calif., Oct. 3 (AP) -- Marion Davies left an estate in excess of $8,000,000, according to a will and codicil filed today.
BOSTON, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Fires last year took 11,350 lives and caused $1,544,000,000 in property damage, the National Fire Protection Association reported today. It was the worst year on record.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 4 (AP) -- Navy expects a tough football game when the middies meet Miami in the Orange Bowl Friday night.
The head of France's largest non-Government bank expects Britain's entrance into the European Common Market to take place by 1963.
The City Investigation Commissioner, Louis I. Kaplan, spent three hours and twenty-five minutes before the State Investigation Commission yesterday, appearing by request.

ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Oct. 4 -- Negotiations between the United Nations and Katanga for a return of the secessionist province to the Congo have reached a virtual stalemate. The United Nations is now pressing for direct reconciliation talks between Katanga officials and leaders of the Central Government.

Vito P. Battista, United Taxpayers party candidate for Mayor of New York, has been ruled off the ballot for the Nov. 7 election on the grounds that his failure to have his acceptance of the nomination notarized made it invalid under state election law.
The city's newest fireboat, the Governor Alfred E. Smith, joined the fire fighting fleet yesterday morning.

Miss Ann McKiernan, a 26-year-old waitress who was arrested Sept. 24 after a traffic dispute with the son of a Paraguayan diplomat, was fined $25 yesterday in Manhattan Arrest Court on a disorderly conduct charge.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4 (UPI) -A party of Irish-American tourists, waving shillelaghs and sporting the green, came home to a reunion with relatives today after having been stranded since last Thursday at Shannon.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (UPI) -- The Soviet Union exploded today the seventeenth nuclear weapon in its current test series. This was one more than the sixteen fired in its last series in 1958.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 4 (AP) -- The new chairman of the Genearl Aniline and Film Corporation said today that litigation tying up the sale of the company to private enterprise would continue at least six more years according to Department of Justice estimates.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Oct. 4 -- Premier Jan Edouard de Quay indicated today that the Dutch Government would seek a change in the Constitution to abandon sovereignty over Netherlands New Guinea.
A section of East Harlem wasI approved by the City PlanningI Commission yesterday as suit-I able for urban renewal redcvel-t and rehabilitation.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 4 -- The outlook is rather grim for the Pennsylvania football team today as it awaits the coming of Dartmouth to Franklin Field on Saturday.
A white lawyer was chosen yesterday as chief legal spokesman of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People in its battles against discrimination.
Although sales of United Merchants and Manufacturers, Inc., climbed to a record of $471,597,283 for the fiscal year ended on June 30, net income fell to $9,757,570, the company reported yesterday.

Calm appears to have returned to Syria though less than a week has passed since the successful revolution against continued union with Egypt in the United Arab Republic. President Nasser has made it clear he does not intend to try to re-conquer Syria by overt use of Egyptian military forces.

City Council President Abe Stark telegraphed a request to Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy yesterday for "an immediate full-scale investigation" of the wholesale price structure of gasoline in the metropolitan area.

MIAMI BEACH, Oct. 4 -- Representatives of the nation's airlines will meet in Washington tomorrow and the next day on two major problems -- the passenger who fails to claim his reserve seat and "frills" in cabin service.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Johnny Sellers, the nation's leading jockey, equaled an American record today by extending his winning streak to eight at the Atlantic City race course. After winning the last three races yesterday, Sellers won the first five this afternoon before his streak ended.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 4 -- There was a little bit of everything in the canine line at an unusual dog show in an unusual setting today. The event was held in the park at Rittenhouse Square. The judging was mostly catch-as-catch-can and the competition less than earnest.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 4 -- An Eastern European source said today that Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet Foreign Minister, would raise the question of choosing an Acting Secretary General for the United Nations with Secretary of State Dean Rusk.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board delayed public disclosure today of documents involving Northeast Airlines, the Atlas Corporation and the Hughes Tool Company.

The farmer of today is no hick from the country baffled by city slickers, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia. In its latest monthly review it says: "We see the continuing growth of a new breed of farmer -- the business man-farmer."

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 4 -The Westchester Hills Stable's Vineddy from Chester, N.Y., scored a two-and-one-half-length victory over Mocking Byrd in 2:04 2/5 in the Brookville race before 13,000 fans at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.
CHICAGO, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Grain futures prices failed today to maintain yesterday's advance and prices eased after opening mostly higher.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- The United States has offered its good offices to help improve relations between Pakistan and Afghanistan.
Rising bids reappeared in the high-grade bond market yesterday after a one-day pause.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Communist China is again shopping for grain in the non-Communist world to ease the effects of another poor harvest.
UTICA, N.Y., Oct. 4 (AP) -Lieut. Gov Malcolm Wilson said today that Governor Rockefeller was "not encouraging the Republican nomination for President in 1964."
Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street looked more like an outdoor theatre last night than a business corner. It was the scene of the city's fourth annual Salute to Seasons festival celebration.
Top-level school officials agreed last night to transfer twelve classes from Public School 119 in Harlem to other schools until repairs to the sixty-one-year-old building had been completed.
Paul Gregory, who is involved with "The Captains and the Kings," due here Jan. 15, has become attached to "Rx: Murder," scheduled to arrive in New York before Easter Sunday, April 22.
All hands in the Cincinnati dressing room conceded that the Yankees' world series opening-game victory at the Stadium yesterday was clean-cut and conclusive.

Production of electric power rose to 15,340,000,000 kilowatt-hours in the week ended Saturday, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. This compared with 15,025,000,000 kilowatt-hours the week before and 14,161,000,000 kilowatt-hours in the same period last year.

GERTRUDE Berg and Sir Cedric Hardwicke, whose association in "A Majority of One" proved a two-year success on the Broadway stage, are reunited in a new television series entitled "Mrs. G. Goes to College."

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 4 -- The United States District Court was told today that the proposed merger of the Philadelphia National Bank and the Girard Trust Corn Exchange Bank would reduce banking competition here and would violate the antitrust laws.
MANILA, Oct. 4 (UPI) -Carlos P. Romulo, one of the Philippine's most eminent diplomats, announced tonight he was retiring from the Philippine Foreign Service.

IT has been likened to the Karljohans Gate, the main street of Oslo. It has been called Julekake Boulevard and Fish Cake Thoroughfare. It is, in fact, Brooklyn's Eighth Avenue, best known for its Norwegian markets.

A tanker under charter to the Turkish Government was refused bunker oil at Port Said in Egypt Monday and had to put about without going through the Suez Canal, according to reports in shipping circles here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) -- President Kennedy signed today a bill regulating the recruiting of farm workers from Mexico. But he said the measure did not include provisions "which I believe necessary to protect domestic farm workers."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- The President's Committee on Equal Employment Opportunity upheld today a union complaint of racial discrimination in hiring by a Miami contractor working on a Federal project.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (UPI) -- The Air Force announced today that it was abandoning its ice-island research station, which has been operating in the Arctic for the last nine years.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 4 -West Germany again rejected today "numerous speculations" that a basic change was taking place in the Western position on Germany and Berlin.
Six members of the Congress of Racial Equality spent last night in a sit-in at a Brooklyn real estate office to protest alleged discrimination in renting an apartment.

OUT of a scabrous derelict and two mentally unbalanced brothers Harold Pinter has woven a play of strangely compelling beauty and passion. "The Caretaker," which opened last night at the Lyceum, proclaims its young English author as one of the important playwrights of our day.
The efforts of the Federal Trade Commission to step up its policing of the advertising industry are causing growing concern along Madison Avenue.
The soaring costs of sponsoring television programs were outlined before representatives of the Federal Communications Commission here yesterday.
The New York Committee for Democratic Voters is re-examining its role in a study that could lead to its dissolution.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 4 (AP) -- Coach Bump Elliott said today he planned to use the same ingredients that powered Michigan to a 29-6 victory over the University of California in Los Angeles last week when the Wolverines meet Army on Saturday.
CHICAGO, Oct. 4 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Degarfnt of Agriculture follows:

The Chase Manhattan Bank has reported net operating earnings for the first nine months of 1961 of $51,700,986, or $3.70 a share, compared with $55,205,307, or $3.95 a share, for the like period of 1960. This represents a decrease of 6.3 per cent, based on the 13,967,554 shares outstanding.

Theodore Roosevelt called him "one of the men who tend to keep alive my hope in America." On another occasion, while Assistant Secretary of the Navy, T.R. expressed the wish that he would "do something about the Navy some time," but this never happened.
EAST PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 4 -- A football course for mothers got under way here last night in the adult education school at East Paterson Memorial High School. Forty women attended.
McCOMB, Miss., Oct. 4 (UPI) -- A group of 114 Negro high school students marched on City Hall today, protesting "discrimination." They were arrested after a scuffle broke out on the steps.
The 18,500-ton Navy tanker Sabine entered the Twenty-seventh Street, Brooklyn, yard of the Bethlehem Steel Company yesterday for a sixty-days activation and repair job.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- The visa of Michel Struelens, chief of the Kantanga Information Services, has been canceled, the State Department disclosed today.
DENVER, Oct. 4. -- Police Chief James Childers resigned today in the wake of investigations of the Police Department.
On the last day of the summer meeting at Aqueduct -July 29 -- Milton Ritzenberg's Wise Ship scored an impressive victory in the mile-and-five-eighths Man o' War Turf Handicap.
DETROIT, Oct. 4 -- The strikebound Ford Motor Company will not be able to resume operations before next week at the earliest.
Supreme Court Justice George Tilzer ruled yesterday that a race track "tip sheet" was an information service subject to the city's 3 per cents sales tax.
The Visiting Nurse Service of New York yesterday opened its 1961 fund drive for $608,000 to carry out the home care nursing program of the sixty-eight-year-old agency.
The management of the Certain-teed Products Corporation recommended yesterday a 25 per cent stock dividend.
DUBLIN, Oct. 4 -- Ireland chose a new Dail Eireann (Parliament) today alter the quietest election campaign in memory. Ballots will be counted tomorrow.

A gangland figure was shot dead yesterday afternoon on a busy Brooklyn street corner. He was Joseph Magnasco, 36-year-old lieutenant of the notorious Gallo brothers, jukebox and vending machine racketeers.
Columbia, for the first time in many years, will be favored over Princeton when they meet Saturday at Baker Field.

A lifeboat of the American Export Lines passenger vessel Atlantic traveled through rough seas about 550 miles southeast of here yesterday afternoon to take aboard two critically injured seamen from the Belgian bulk carrier Marly I.

The one-story taxpayer occupying a plot 170 by 200 feet at 277 to 287 A Front Street, Hempstead, L.I., has been sold by Mrs. Sylvia L. Bishop, who constructed it in 1937. The property, containing six stores, was purchased by the First Nan-Mark Corporation for cash over a first mortgage of $85,000 and a second mortgage of $60,000 that was taken back by the seller.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -Maj. Gherman S. Titov, the Soviet astronaut, felt sick during much of his twenty-five-hour trip through space last August, two Russian scientists disclosed today.

President Kennedy has signed "with extreme reluctance" the opportunistic school-aid bill Congress passed after it had junked the Administration's program for meeting the real needs of education. We wish the President's belated declaration of unhappiness had been accompanied by a clear announcement that he intended to fight for his full program next year -- and to give the fight the degree of personal involvement that was so conspicuously missing this year.

BLACKPOOL, England, Oct. 4 -- The Labor party decisively rejected today proposals for unilateral disarmament by Britain and for a foreign policy of nonalignment. It adopted such proposals one year ago.
TOKYO, Oct. 4 -- The Government, trying to keep Japan's economic rise under control, asked the steel industry today to cut back its planned investment by 5 per cent.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 4 -- The United Nations' aid agency for Palestine refugees declared today that its financial situation had grown "precarious."
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 4 -The Rev. Leslie R. Smith of Lexington, Ky., was elected today president of the International Convention of Christian Churches (Disciples of Christ.)

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) -- The Government said today the fueling of the first nuclear-powered merchant ship, the N.S. Savannah, had been delayed because part of the reactor system had failed to perform as expected.
FLORAL PARK, L.I., Oct. 4 -- Members of the Universalist Church of Floral Park voted tonight to merge with the Unitarian Fellowship of Central Nassau in Garden City.

LONDON, Oct. 4 -- A mass-circulation British newspaper announced today that Antony Armstrong-Jones would remain "Mr. Jones" as far as it was concerned, despite the earldom conferred on him by Queen Elizabeth II.
A construction company charged in Supreme Court yesterday that its low bid on a city project had been rejected on orders of Deputy Mayor Paul R. Screvane.
CAIRO, Oct. 4 -- Arab observers asses the fiscal situation in Syria as "bad," but not so chaotic as might be expected as a result of the rupture with Egypt.

LISTED below are three Norwegian recipes from the collection of Olea Aanrud, an exponent of Norwegian cuisine. The recipes use ingredients normally found on Eighth Avenue in Brooklyn. Miss Aanrud, a contralto recitalist, also contributes articles on food to Nordisk Tidende, the Norwegian-American newspaper that celebrates its seventieth anniversary this month.
A long-drawn-out meeting of the City Planning Commission yesterday dealt with four matters that had become tangled with the city's mayoral campaign.

In his letter published Sept. 28 John T. Cahill referred to the New York City edition of "Facts for Voters," an annual publication of the League of Women Voters. We appreciate his complimentary remarks on our efforts.
BERLIN, Oct. 4 -- The West Berlin police said that they had engaged in a gun fight with policemen of Communist East Berlin over the Iron Curtain border tonight.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 4 -- Jaja Wachuku, Foreign Minister of Nigeria, championed the cause of polygamy today but relented after feminine protests.

James Thurber underwent emergency brain surgery at Doctors Hospital last night. A spokesman for the writer's family said early today that Mr. Thurber's condition was grave, but that he had responded encouragingly to the operation.
The Yankees and Reds will switch today and use righthanders for the starting world series assignments.

The New York and American Stock Exchanges reported yesterday, pursuant to the Securities and Exchange Act of 1934, the following changes in the holdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed companies:

Mikhail Tal of Latvia, a former world champion, won the international chess masters tournament at Bled, according to a report from Yugoslavia yesterday. He took his nine-teenth-round game and finished with totals of 14 1/2 -- 4 1/2.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -President Kennedy appointed today a nine-man bipartisan commission to make recommendations about reducing the dependence of Presidential candidates on private contributors.

The Seven to Eleven Dinner Gala, arranged for Monday evening in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria, will have many socially prominent persons among its patrons. The event's proceeds will aid the recreational therapy program of Comeback, Inc.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 4 -- Harvard's continued objection to the disclaimer affidavit will keep the university out of the Federal student loan program for a fourth year.

QUEBEC, Oct. 4 -- Savings bankers from New York State were told today that they were losing out to commercial banks in the competition for the saver's dollar. They heard the warning from James M. Bristow, president of the Savings Bankers Association of New York State.

At the end of her life the American poet Hilda Doolittle (or H.D. as she preferred), must have seemed entirely cut off from those forces that had once nourished her. She had been an expatriate for almost fifty years; the Imagist movement of which she had been the stanchest and most authentic figure had long since become a chapter of literary history; the critics, by and large, ignored her.

A circle under a broken circle is the emblem on posters that will soon be seen all over town on behalf of the Community Service Society's annual fund appeal. A goal of $2,000,000 was announced yesterday to 350 volunteers at an opening rally in the Biltmore Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -President Airlines' authorization to fly trans-Atlantic charter flights expired Sept. 30, records at the Civil Aeronautics Board showed today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Sept. 27:
WEST LONG BRANCH, N.J., Oct. 4 -- Dr. William G. Van Note, president of Clarkson College of Technology in Potsdam, N.Y., has been named the new president of Monmouth College here.

About 120,000 members of fifty-eight local unions of the United Automobile Workers are on strike. These workers have been employed in eightyeight facilities of the Ford Motor Company in twenty-six states.

IT had been five years since Jacques Abram had given a piano recital in New York, and a middle-sized crowd was on hand at Carnegie Hall last night to welcome him back. Mr. Abram's program consisted of five warhorses, newly scrubbed and repainted for the new season; Bach's Chromatic Fantasia, Mozart's A minor Sonata, Beethoven's "Les Adieux," Liszt's Concert Etude No. 4 and Schumann's "Carnaval."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -President Kennedy signed a bill today establishing a Woodrow Wilson Memorial Commission. He then gave the first pen he used to Mrs. Wilson.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 4 -- The rapid evolution of farming dining the Nineteen Fifties brought European agriculture practically within the realm of manufacturing industries, according to a United Nations study.

The Cities Service Company has acquired a substantial interest in Ammoniaque Synthetique et Derives (ASED), a principal subsidiary of Evence Coppee Cie. of Brussels. This marks the company's entry into Europe as a producer.
The Soviet press has reported that Premier Khrushchev's virgin lands program suffered a severe setback in grain production in Kazakhstan this year.

TULSA, Oct. 4 (AP) -- The medalist, Joseph Morrill of Great Barrington, Mass., was upset today in the United States Golf Association's senior amateur tournament at the 7,476-yard, par-71 Southern Hills Country Club.
Juan Bosch, president of the opposition Dominican Revolutionary party, is on his way home after more than a quarter century of voluntary exile.

The New York group of the Investment Bankers Association of America installed Allen C. DuBois as chairman last night at the group's forty-first annual dinner meeting in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- President Kennedy will meet Friday with Andrei A. Gromyko, the Soviet Foreign Minister, for another review of the main issues in the dispute over Berlin and Germany.

THE American Ballet Theatre presented last night the world premiere of Birgit Cullberg's "Eden -- Pas de Deux" at the Fifty-fourth Street Theatre, with its cast consisting of Mariane Orlando and Caj Selling. The music is Hilding Rosenberg's "Concert for String Orchestra," the decor and costumes are by Per Falk, and if only Nananne Porcher, who did the lighting, were Swedish, it would be an all-Swedish production.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- In reversing its earlier 3-to-2 decision that an "agency-shop," enforced on nonunion workers by a management-union contract in states forbidding compulsory unionism, equally violates a specific guarantee of the Taft-Hartley Act, the National Labor Relations Board was obliged to rely on a 1954 Supreme Court opinion instead of the letter of the Federal labor relations law.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) -- President Kennedy signed legislation today permitting dual freight-rate schedules by ocean steamship companies.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -Ibrahim Abboud, President of the Sudan, received military honors and a warm greeting from President Kennedy today upon his arrival for an eleven-day state visit.
ALGIERS, Oct. 4 -- A deep-seated reorganization of Algeria looking toward an independent state has begun here.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court announced today the appointment of John F. Davis, a lawyer with the Justice Department, to be clerk of the court effective Oct. 23. The post pays $21,500 a year.
The world series and a stock market rally distracted enough commodity futures traders yesterday to be considered factors in reducing the volume on the exchanges here.
CATASAUQUA, Pa., Oct. 4 -- The textile industry, seeking a brighter future, is counting on quality, mill modernization and style innovation.

LISBON, Portugal, Oct. 4 (Reuters) -- One policeman was killed and another was wounded by African insurgents who attacked a police column in northern Angola today, the Portuguese news agency ANI reported.
Edward Charles (Whitey) Ford, the star performer in the Yankees' victory over the Reds in yesterday's world series opener, is recognized as a "pitcher's pitcher."
It was 57 degrees yesterday at Fordham University's Jack Coffey Field, but the New York Giants managed to keep warm in a number of ways.

Forces of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization in Europe are stronger, in nuclear weapons than the Communist troops facing them. But the Soviet and satellite forces outnumber the Allied units on the ground and in the air, and are somewhat better equipped and trained for non-nuclear warfare.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Three American eye surgeons and an ophthalmic nurse will leave for Hong Kong Oct. 23 to perform a series of sight-restoring operations on blind and near-blind Chinese.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 4 -- New Zealand told "friendly countries" today that exclusive regional economic blocs were a threat to small countries.
PARIS, Oct. 4. -- Brig. Gen. Ahmed Rafa, the French Army's only Algerian Moslem general officer, was named today to command all infantry forces serving in Algeria.

PARIS, Oct. 4 -- France's conservative Independent party proclaimed tonight virtually open opposition to the Government of President de Gaulle but remained silent on the future of three members of the party serving as Ministers.
The names of members of the dance committee for the Fall Ball have been announced. The annual event, to be held at the Plaza Oct. 19, will benefit the Boys Club of New York.

As a dramatic spectacle, the opening game of the world series was a big disappointment at Yankee Stadium yesterday. It had less excitement than that normally generated by a late-season contest between minor league tail-enders.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 15 cents a bale off to $1 up yesterday, with far months showing the most strength.

" TODAY when the subtlest researches and a finer taste have reduced to a principle the art of pleasing, a low and treacherous uniformity subsists in our customs, so that all minds seem to have been cast in the same mold."

The Soviet Union exploded the seventeenth nuclear weapon of its current test series in the atmosphere yesterday, and still Premier Khrushchev has not informed the Russian people that any nuclear explosions are taking place these days at all, much less that Russian tests are rapidly increasing radioactive poison in the air throughout the world.

CALDWELL, Idaho, Oct. 3 -Idaho potato growers are beginning to haul their famous product into cellars for storage after the first frost. These often huge dirt-and-straw-covered, well-ventilated structures dot the irrigated farmlands along the southern end of the state. Flocks of geese have finished, for 1961, their job of weeding fields of mint.
TRENTON, Oct. 4 -- The state Department of Education will make a comprehensive, statewide study of student withdrawals in an effort to minimize this problem in New Jersey's 2,100 public schools.

DURHAM, N.C., Oct. 4 -- Unless American children are prepared to deal effectively with the revolution in world affairs, "the United States could have the shortest tenure of a greatpower position in history," Dr. Grayson Kirk warned tonight.
LAHORE, Pakistan, Thursday, Oct. 6 -- About 500 Afghan irregular troops were reported last night to have attacked across the Pakistani border and to have been repulsed.

Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz asked for a Supreme Court order yesterday directing the Board of Elections to place his name on the voting machines as the Non-Partisan party's candidate for Mayor.
THE solidly built 36-year-old white man who was named yesterday as the chief legal advocate for the country's Negroes in their fight for civil rights has been described as a man who worships the law.

THE work of three artists in current exhibitions prompts me to coin a phrase for them that might go "I know exactly what I'm doing and I like what I do." For all are highly intelligent, and know that the best thing with which to create illusions is a clear head.

The Salvation Army has bought the seventeen-story Parkside Hotel at 18 Gramercy Park South for use as a non-profit residence for young business women. The building was purchased for $1,100,000 from the Parkside Company and will be renovated at a cost of $600,000 after the 175 tennants have been relocated.
TORQUAY, England, Oct. 4 -- The European bridge tournament will enter its last day tomorrow with the championship conceded to Great Britain, as it was four days ago.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 4 -- Allied military experts conferring here on a common plan to defend Southeast Asia against Communist aggression are dealing with problems of great urgency.

SAYVILLE, L.I., Oct. 4 -Five years ago this South Shore village was the locale of a United States Information Agency television movie that depicted life in an American small town. Shown on TV screens and movie houses in many parts of the world, the film presented Sayville as a warm, friendly community.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 4 -- Nationalist China asserted today that the United Nations would go the way of the League of Nations into inaction, ineffectiveness and extinction if the Chinese Communists were admitted.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 4 -- Former Gov. Goodwin J. Knight identified today a Los Angeles man who he said had offered him "any job in California" to stay out of the 1961 gubernatorial race.
ELIZABETH, N.J., Oct. 4 -A grand jury today criticized Union County welfare payments as rewarding illegitimacy and laziness in some cases.
State Superintendent of Banks Oren Root and the State Banking Board said "yes" twice yesterday and "no" once to three separate merger proposals of six New York banks.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 4 -- Mrs. Golda Meir, Foreign Minister of Israel, remarked today that the world's great problems might be closer to solution if political leaders allowed themselves to "feel more and think less."

HIGHTSTOWN, N.J., Oct. 4 -- Mickey Shuman, head coach of football at Peddie School, has been working on what he calls "torpedo plays." He plans to release them on Admiral Farragut's eleven when the Sailors come here for their annual game on Saturday.
It appears that the Yankees will have to do without the services of Mickey Mantle again today in the second game of the world series.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Manufacturers of carbonated beverages will be given the chance to delay a Government order requiring them to label their ingredients.

The nation's inventories of gasoline declined by 3,115,000 barrels in the week ended last Friday, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. At the week-end, total supplies were 184,484,000 barrels, compared with 187,599,000 a week earlier and 187,417,000 a year ago.
The strike of the New York Philharmonic goes into its fourth day today without any prospect of settlement.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- The Prime Minister of British Guiana, Dr. Cheddi B. Jagan, will visit President Kennedy at the White House toward the end of this month, it was disclosed today.

DETROIT, Oct. 4 (UPI) -Secretary of Commerce Luther H. Hodges criticized United States business men today for lack of "daring" and for being bogged down by "too much self-satisfaction" with things the way they are.

VIENNA, Oct. 4 -- Fears that the Soviet Union would withdraw from participation in the International Atomic Energy Agency after yesterday's election of Dr. Arne Sigvard Eklund of Sweden as director general proved groundless today.
EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Oct. 4 (AP) -- An X-15 pilot streaked 2,850 miles an hour today with his tiny ship deliberately crippled.
Pan American World Airways, Inc., confirmed yesterday the sale this week of its 30 per cent interest in Panair do Brasil, S.A. Neither the price nor the purchaser of Panair's stock were disclosed.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct 4 -Johnny Antonelli, the once strong left-handed pitcher considered washed up at the age of 31 by many baseball men, would like to try again -- but not with the National League's new Houston club.
KIEV, U.S.S.R., Oct. 4 -A military court trying two young Dutchmen here on espionage charges attempted to show today that a United States agent had initiated their spying mission to the Soviet Union.
Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz offered a program yesterday to lift New York City but of the economic decline into which he said Mayor Wagner had pushed it.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Five members of President Kennedy's Cabinet, backed up by teams of career experts, will go on the road next month to explain the Government to its citizens.

A public borrowing of about $78,500,000 on public housing bonds secured by subsidy contracts with the Public Housing Administration will take place in about a month, according to reports in underwriting circles yesterday.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., Oct. 4 -- Mrs. Evans Morgan of Wee Burn won the Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association one-day tournament by four shots with a score of 43, 46 -- 89 at Pelham Country Club today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (UPI) -- Small producers of lead and zinc will become eligible for subsidies beginning on Jan. 1 under a four-year, $16,500,000 stabilization program signed today by President Kennedy.
WHILE helping children develop sound study habits may not be the easiest task for parents, arranging a workable study area is comparatively simple and will help ease the path to learning.

The Humble Oil and Refining Company, chief domestic affiliate of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), made upward and downward adjustments yesterday in the prices it pays for crude oil in several fields in Texas and Louisiana.
Governor Rockefeller told an overflow gathering of business men at the New York Chamber of Commerce, 65 Liberty Street, yesterday, that they must learn to live with big government.

The position of the Secretary General in the United Nations merits objective examination. We should not close our minds to a desirable change simply because the Soviet Union favors related changes which are undesirable.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- The fate of an Air Force project to develop a manned space glider will be settled within two weeks, Pentagon officials said today.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Oct. 4 -- Lights burned throughout the country until the early hours today as Israelis listened to a broadcast of the examination of Bible champions from eighteen countries.

THE bully boys from the Bronx manhandled the policeman's son in the world series opener at the Stadium yesterday.
