They felled Jim O'Toole with two clouts in their own quaint version of cops and robbers. The muscular Elston Howard hit one homer and the even more muscular Bill Skowron hit another as Whitey Ford guarded home base with such zealous artistry that the Reds didn't score at all.
With the rails taking a boisterous lead and rushing forward 3.6 per cent, the stock market advanced on a broad front yesterday.
Four foreign films have been added to the schedule for the San Francisco Film Festival, starting Nov. 1.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4 -- The American College of Surgeons will disclose details of a survey in two weeks that reportedly shows that about half the operations performed in American hospitals are done by "unqualified" doctors.
LONDON, Oct. 4 -- The stock market took on a brighter look today with a rise in industrial shares and a continued advance in Government securities.

The problem of finding an Acting Secretary General for the United Nations and reorganizing its Secretariat ought not be confused by semantics and jockeying for position by regions or individual countries. The goal to be pursued by all members desiring to see a genuine international organization is to have a Secretary General, or an acting one, who has independence and authority.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 4 (AP) -A Nigerian diplomat traveling to New York with his family was refused table service at a restaurant on U.S. 40 northeast of Baltimore yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce said today it licensed only $907,000 worth of goods in September for shipment to Communist-bloc countries -- the lowest amount for any month since 1955.

Three one-act operas by Giacomo Puccini -- written to be performed as a single evening's entertainment but not done that way in New York since 1918 -- will open the fall season of the New York City Opera Company tonight at the City Center.

Eugene R. Black, president of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank), declared here last night that United States foreign aid must in the future stress "quality of investment," not "quantity of money."
The three television networks have terminated a joint effort to establish a children's hour as proposed recently by Newton N. Minow, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission.
Mayor Wagner accused both Governor Rockefeller and former Vice President Richard M. Nixon last night of trying to make the city election serve Presidential ambition for 1964.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday he had directed his campaign treasurer to reject $25,000 pledged to his campaign by real estate men and builders at a fund-raising luncheon in Brooklyn last week.
Sidney Gruson's dispatch of Sept. 26 reports that the cry of "sellout" is being raised in West Germany over proposals to settle the Berlin crisis on a sensible basis.

The director of real estate of the Port of New York Authority, Robert S. Curtiss, will leave the New York-New Jersey agency on Jan. 1 to become president of Horace S. Ely Co., a century-old New York real estate concern.
LIGONIER, Pa., Oct. 4 (AP) -- Course records were set for two events and a third mark was tied today on the opening day of the Rolling Rock Hunt Racing Association's twenty-fourth annual meet.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- A "cold war" variation on the classic live trap story began unfolding in Federal Court today at the trial of Irvin C. Scarbeck.
The Reynolds Metals Company announced yesterday that it would manufacture finished aluminum cans for frozen citrus juice concentrates and sell them directly to packers.

The Yankees defeated the Cincinnati Reds in the first game of the 1961 world series at the Stadium yesterday, 2 to 0. To the majority in the crowd of 62,397, the performance followed a pattern they had seen many times before.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Republican hopes for capturing control of the House of Representatives next year are clouded by confusion in many states resulting from the reshuffling of Congressional dis-
WARSAW, Oct. 4 -- Twelve prominent Western European journalists arrived here this week for a round-table discussion of German and European security with Communist journalists.

A MAN in early middle age recently offered his 10-year-old son the Tom Swift books he had treasured thirty years ago. They were rejected. The "old" Tom Swift (there is also an up-to-date series) was a fuddy-duddy, and what is such a big deal about riding a motorcycle, his son asked.
Many thanks for your editorial of Sept. 23 "Hope for the Dunes" and for your thoughtful support for conservation.
DALLAS, Tex., Oct. 4 -- The natural gas industry was told here today that it would have to work hard to achieve the record growth that had been predicted for it.

FEW people would guess that the town house at 12 East Sixty-eighth Street contains a three-floor salon dedicated to the health and beautification of the feminine form. Inside the lobby only an insignificant name plate above a buzzer indicates that this is where Manya Kahn and a staff of ten give her course in beauty through corrective rhythmic movements, relaxation and massage.

BERLIN, Oct. 4 -- Travelers along the internal highway beween Hamburg and West Berlin reported that large evacuation operations were under way today along a sixty-mile stretch of Communist East German territory bordering on West Germany.

UTICA, N.Y., Oct. 4 (AP) -Associated Laundries of America, Inc. announced today it would acquire the Best Coat Apron Manufacturing Company, Inc., diversified linen-supply and textile concern whose gross was estimated at between $20,000,000 and $25,000,000 a year.
MOSCOW, Oct. 4 -- The United States-Soviet search for a formula that will permit the opening of negotiations for a settlement of the Berlin dispute has entered a decisive stage.
James R. Hoffa, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, has been invited to address the convention of the Transport Workers Union here tomorrow and has accepted.
The New York Mets and Houston Colts, dissatisfied with the players offered them for the $75,000 draft price, have requested National League officials to amend the list.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Theatre in the royal tradition was introduced to the White House tonight and was royally applauded.
Plans for a new $6,000,000 research building at New York Medical College, Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospitals were announced yesterday.

Safeway Properties, Inc., Bernard Siegel, president, has purchased the blockfront on the west side of First Avenue, between Eighty-third and Eighty-fourth Streets, for cash over mortgages amounting to $473,000. The sellers were the 1613 Realty Corporation and Dr. Joseph Sterling.
The Houston Colts agreed yesterday with officials of the American Association to allow the amount of indemnity the Houston club is required to pay the league be set by a board of arbitration.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 5 -- The United States decided today to acquiesce in a proposal for the election by the Security Council of U Thant of Burma as Acting Secretary General of the United Nations, provided that two conditions are fulfilled.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 5 -- Reliable sources said today that the United States had sounded out the West German Government on whether it would be willing to conduct negotiations with East Germany regarding the rights of access of the Western powers to West Berlin.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Reversing a prior ruling, the National Labor Relations Board decided yesterday by a vote of 3 to 2 that a union's seven-month picketing of a church construction job did not violate the Taft-Hartley Act.
DUBLIN, Oct. 5 -- Fianna Fail, the party that has headed Ireland's Government since 1957, held a precarious lead tonight in the voting for members of the new Dail Eireann (Parliament).
Many New York families look to voluntary hospital clinics for medical care. There are many kinds of clinics in United Hospital Fund member non-profit hospitals.
A first public marketing was made yesterday of common stock of the Playskool Manufacturing Company, Chicago manufacturer of toys for pre-school children.
A preview of the 1961-62 student program of Lincoln Center will be given today to about 200 principals of junior and senior high schools in the New York City area.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- It may be that the "proof" offered by former Governor Knight of California in support of his charges against Richard M. Nixon will be evaluated as conclusive by persons other than those who for years have been favorably disposed toward all attacks on Nixon's character.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Oct. 5 -- Dr. Robert Lindsay, American Baptist missionary, who was injured three weeks ago in an attempt to smuggle an Arab boy out of Jordan, was returned by Jordanian authorities tonight to Israel, where he has been living for the last sixteen years.

T.J. Ross, senior partner in the firm of Ivy Lee and T.J. Ross, announced yesterday that the public relations concern had changed its name to T.J. Ross and Associates, Inc. Mr. Ross had been senior partner since the death of Ivy Lee in 1934.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- The King of Afghanistan has replied favorably to President Kennedy's offer of good offices of the United States in an effort to ease the border dispute between Afghanistan and Pakistan.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) -- The Senate Internal Security subcommittee has set Monday for the start of hearings to question James R. Hoffa, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, about communism.
Clusters of golden balloons adorned the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza last evening for the dinner dance arranged as a benefit for the Recreation Service for Children of Bellevue.

Jimmy Piersall was traded to the Washington Senators yesterday. In return for the center fielder, the Cleveland Indians received Dick Donovan, a pitcher; Gene Green, an outfielder-catcher; Jim Mahoney, a shortstop, and an unidentified player to be delivered by Jan. 1.
The strike of 120,000 Ford workers, so soon after the tie-up at General Motors, is fresh proof that our collective-bargaining machinery needs improvement.

AKRON, Ohio, Oct. 5 (UPI) -- Technical assistance for the manufacture of a polyester plastic resin for synthetic textile fibers will be given by the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company to Toyo Spinning Company, Ltd., Osaka, Japan, under terms of an agreement announced today.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 5 -- A manufacturer of automobile heaters filed a $2,400,000 antitrust suit today against the Ford Motor Company and General Motors Corporation.
Princeton and Columbia will meet for the thirty-first time on the gridiron tomorrow, and Buff Donelli's Lions are determined the occasion will be a day of reckoning.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) -- The International Academy of Astronautics gave an award and a $1,000 cash prize today to Sir Bernard Lovell, director of Britain's huge Jodrell Bank radio telescope.

OTTAWA, Oct. 5 -- Arthur Goldberg, United States Secretary of Labor, told Michael Starr, Canadian Minister of Labor, today that if world peace was maintained, the United States should be able to reach "a gross national product of $600,000,000,000" by the end of next spring.

Gustav S. Eyesell, president of Rockefeller Center, Inc., will speak at a luncheon meeting of the Young Men's Real Estate Association of New York next Tuesday at the Shelburne Hotel, Lexington Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street.
LONDON, Oct. 5 -- The Government eased its squeeze on credit slightly today by reducing the bank rate to 6 1/2 from 7 per cent. But it was emphatic in declaring that it was not changing its policy.
MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 5 -- Toxic fumes from a chemical ingredient in a model-airplane glue are being inhaled by some youngsters to obtain a feeling of elation similar to that of narcotics.
Two burglars decided that a West Side apartment that had a double-lock combination on the door must he worth looting.

Two new Coopers consigned to Stirling Moss were unloaded at Watkins Glen, N.Y., late yesterday afternoon, completing the supply of equipment to be used by nineteen of the world's foremost road-racing drivers in the Grand Prix of the United States there on Sunday.
DETROIT, Oct. 5 -- Negotiators for the Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile Workers concentrated today on resolving individual plant problems.

EASTCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 5 -- George Cohen and Mrs. Max Perl of Rockrimmon today won low gross honors in the Metropolitan Golf Association's Pinehurst mixed foursomes tournament at the Leewood Golf Club.
THE American Ballet Theatre did itself proud last night at the Fifty-fourth Street Theatre with its attack on Harald Lander's beautiful and very difficult ballet, "Etudes."
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 5 -- A record United Nations budget of $80,340,550 was presented here today to cover administrative expenses for 1962.
Fifth Avenue buses began a revised turnaround operation in Washington Square Park yesterday.

SO striking and natural is the military bearing of Ibrahim Abboud, it has been remarked, that he can look like a commander reviewing troops while, clad in a bathrobe, he gazes upon his gardens at dawn.
LONDON, Oct. 5 -- The stock market here had its best day in months today, stimulated by the announcement of a cut in the bank rate from 7 to 6 1/2 per cent.

Production of lumber dipped to 227,920,000 board feet in the week ended Saturday from 236,850,000 board feet in the preceding week, according to reports received from regional associations. In the same 1960 period 229,129,000 board feet were produced.

HAMBURG, Germany, Friday, Oct. 6 (Reuters) -- About twenty persons were killed and fifty injured when a packed commuter train slammed into a repair train on a curved section of the elevated railroad here last night.
Fidelity Capital Fund, Inc., reported yesterday that new highs were reached in practically every phase of its operations in the twelve months ended on Aug. 31.
WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 5 -- Seven trotters will race in Roosevelt Raceway's $25,000 Trader Horn Handicap at a mile tomorrow night.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- President Kennedy today held out a hope of favorable Congressional action next year on an appropriation for the New York World's Fair of 1964-65.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 5 -- Representative Steven B. Derounian, Republican of Nassau, made today what he called "a blanket indictment" of the Washington press corps as biased.

BUFFALO, Oct. 5 (AP) -- A psychiatrist said today that schools in the United States must start dealing with problems of mental illness. Many parents, he said, are shirking resposibility for the emotional development of their children.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Traditionally neutral Sweden declared today her willingness to enter negotiations for full association with the European Economic Community, or Common Market.
Harry Van Arsdale Jr., president of the Central Labor Council, announced yesterday that the newly formed Brotherhood party was bidding for a permanent role in state as well as city politics.

Baseball fans have been exhibiting quite a bit of excitement over the World Series, but that is nothing to the enthusiasm, evidently, of Frenchmen for the annual auto show that opened yesterday in Paris in the huge glass-domed Grand Palais.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Oct. 5 (UPI) -- The Air Force fired a dummy nuclear warhead a third of the way around the world today at a speed of about 17,000 miles an hour. It then recovered a small capsule containing data from the flight.
Market dealings in prime debt securities broadened yesterday with demand predominant and with prices tending generally to rise.

Brown has no "secret weapon" for upsetting Yale in the Bowl at New Haven tomorrow, but the Bruin student body feels mass psychology might do the trick. Undaunted by the 50-0 trouncing Columbia handed their football team last week, the Brown students will stage an old-fashioned pep rally on the. ProVidence campus] tonight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall said today he would attend no Washington Redskin football games as long as the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People was picketing them in protest against the absence of Negroes in the Redskin line-up.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Fur coats reappeared today but without a suggestion of scandals of previous years.

Two refiners in the Southwest yesterday raised the price of No. 2 fuel oil, the type used in home furnaces, by 1/4 cent a gallon. Other refiners were reported to be studying the situation, with a view to advancing prices. The new range of prices for unbranded grades are 8 1/2 to 9 1/4 cents a gallon, or slightly below the levels a year ago.

RYE, N.Y., Oct. 5 -- The Women's Tri-County Golf Association's team of twenty players defeated the Garden State Women's Association today in a better-ball team match. Playing over the 5,753-yard, par-73 Apawamis Club course, the Westchester squad triumphed by 24-6.
The largest stock fraud case ever reported in this area was announced yesterday by United States Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau with the indictment of four men on stock fraud conspiracy charges.
Two men linked to Brooklyn's underworld were indicted yesterday on charges of attempting to kill Lawrence Gallo, a 33-year-old Brooklyn racketeer, in a Flatbush tavern on Aug. 20.

Pleasure boating has been growing so fast in middle Jersey that the skippers of Ocean County are organizing a new unit of the United States Power Squadrons and will discontinue their membership in the Shrewsbury Squadron, which also covers Monmouth County.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- President Kennedy completed action today on all bills sent to him by the first session of the eighty-seventh Congress. Pierre Salinger, White House press secretary, announced "for the statistically minded" that Mr. Kennedy's first year in office had resulted in somewhat more legislation than that of his predecessor, Dwight D. Eisenhower.

THE famous illustrator Charles Dana Gibson can never be forgotten for having created a type of feminine beauty that identified the American girl the world over. But in his last years he turned away from this adorable idealization to devote all his talents to oil painting, to landscapes and figure studies, a selection of which, done from 1932 to 1944, is now at the Berry1Hill Galleries, 743 Fifth Avenue.
Building permit values in 200 cities rose 18.8 per cent in August to a new high of $861,936,825, according to Dun Bradstreet Inc.

The city's Board of Ethics declared last night that the solicitation of campaign funds by public officials from persons doing business with the city was "offensive to proper ethical standards." The board said, however that the Democratic fund-raising luncheon in Brooklyn on Sept. 27 at which real estate men and builders pledged $25,000 to Mayor Wagner's campaign did not violate the Code of Ethics.
Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union held separate conversations Wednesday with Cyrus S. Eaton, industrialist, and Bernard M. Baruch, financier.
The football Giants began tapering off yesterday in preparation for their National Football League game against the Cardinals in St. Louis Sunday.

One or two other major league pitchers may be taller than Joey Jay (Gene Conley of the Red Sox and Frank Sullivan of the Phillies certainly are), but none is heavier than the hero of the Reds' triumph over the Yankees yesterday. The right-hander carries 225 pounds on a 6-foot-4-inch frame.
PARIS, Oct. 5 -- The Soviet Union was reported today to have shown no sign of any conciliatory "give" on the Berlin issue in recent exploratory talks.

Three members of the standing-room crowd watching the Reds and Yankees in the world series at the Stadium yesterday were asked why they preferred standing to seeing the game on television in the comfort of their own living rooms.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 5 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Reds, winners of a 6-2 world series game with the New York Yankees, returned home by plane tonight and got the red-carpet treatment.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Oct. 5 -- Mrs. Leon J. Weil of the Inwood Country Club shot a 38, 43 -- 81 to score 38 points and win the Women's Long Island Golf Association point-par tournament at the North Hempstead Country Club today.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 5 -- The Federal Government has achieved a generally excellent record in refraining from infringements on academic freedom and independence in its grants to universities, according to a Harvard University report.

A change in state leadership and early discussion of candidates for the 1962 state election are getting important consideration in talks Mayor Wagner is holding with Democratic leaders from suburban and upstate counties.

Some of the most vexing Latin-American problems confronting the Kennedy Administration are in large part due to the deterioration of United States relations with its neighbors to the south. This view is expressed by William Manger in "Pan America in Crisis," which Public Affairs Press of Washington will issue Oct. 23.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 5 -- Pote Sarasin, Secretary General of the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization, said today he believed the existence of Allied defense machinery for this area had deterred the Communists from pushing aggression further in South Vietnam, Laos and possibly other countries of the region.
The trustees of the bankrupt New Haven Railroad have been told that the way back to prosperity is for the line to do everything the airlines do -- except fly.
The United States Vitamin and Pharmaceutical Corporation reported yesterday a slight increase in sales but a small decline in earnings for the nine months ended on Aug. 31.

STEUBENVILLE, Ohio, Oct. 5 (UPI) -- The Cincinnati Royals tonight completed the sweep of a three-game exhibition series with the New York Knickerbockers of the National Basketball Association by winning, 63 -- 56, in an abbreviated contest watched by about 1,500 persons.
The problems of obtaining suitable scripts for a television drama series were discussed at a Government hearing here yesterday.

Lester Osterman has completed production arrangements for Robert L. Joseph's new play, "Isle of Children." The producer said yesterday that it would open on Broadway Feb. 28 after trial engagements in New Haven (Feb. 7) and in Boston (Feb. 12).
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Antique wallpaper that was carefully peeled from the walls of an old Maryland home was accepted for the White House today by Mrs. John F. Kennedy.
DETROIT, Oct. 5 -- New car sales rose sharply in the final ten days of September, as 1962 models demonstrated strong customer appeal.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Pentagon officials said today that most of the 40,000 troops ordered overseas last month to reinforce the Army in Europe would be in their new billets by Nov. 1.
The Protestant Council of the City of New York will give a benefit dinner Oct. 18 at the Astor to open its fund drive for $100,000 for its work with young people in areas of high delinquency.
The Board of Estimate yesterday approved a thirty-year lease of the city's proposed $l9,000,000 sports stadium in Flushing Meadow Park, to the Metropolitan Baseball Club, Inc.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 5 -- The eight-day ship officer strike in West Coast ports may run for a long time despite strenuous Federal efforts to effect a solution, shipping men said today.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 5 (UPI) -- Twelve rural electric cooperatives in Ohio have filed suits in Federal Courts here against twenty-two electrical manufacturing companies. The cooperatives charged violation of the Sherman Antitrust Law through price fixing and conspiracy.

WENTWORTH, England, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Three of Britain's Ryder Cup players -- Bernard Hunt, Harry Weetman and Ken Bousfield -- reached top form today in their last tournament before next week's cup matches with the United States.
The Rev. Thomas F. Heneghan has been appointed a vice chancellor of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, Cardinal Spellman announced yesterday. There are now five vice chancellors.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported the following spot primary market prices for the dates shown:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- A security officer of the State Department said today that Irvin C. Scarbeck had acknowledged making a deal with the Polish secret police to supply them with information from the United States Embassy in Warsaw.

About 120,000 members of fifty-eight local unions of the United Automobile Workers are on strike. These workers have been employed in eighty-eight facilities of the Ford Motor Company in twenty-six states.
Midtown workers yesterday combined business with the pleasure -- or agony, depending upon partisan leanings -- of following the progress of the world series.
Being fit for a king, "Macbeth" and "The Tempest" are obviously fit for the President of the United States, as well as his wife and his state guest, President Ibrahim Abboud of the Sudan.
WHILE many women are still putting finishing touches on their fall wardrobes, the Fashion Group yesterday looked into the future to forecast what colors will be worn in the spring of 1962.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (UPI) -- Treasury officials welcomed today's cut in the British bank rate as a sign that the British Government was avoiding any policy that might touch off a repetition of last year's heavy flow of dollars from the United States.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- President Ibrahim Abboud of the Sudan said after a White House conference today that his Government was opposed to "colonialism in all its forms." He also called for a universal ban on nuclear testing and for general disarmament.

LONDON, Oct. 5 (Reuters) -- Jack Cotton and Charles Clore, British property developers, will join forces with Diesel Construction, the United States construction company, in property projects overseas, it was announced here today.

GENEVA, Oct. 5 -- Some progress has been made in private talks that have supplanted formal sessions at the fourteen-nation conference on Laos here, qualified sources said today. The conference is seeking to guarantee the independence and neutrality of Laos.

ONE of the most interesting and most gifted of living novelists is an Australian who is little regarded in his own country but highly admired in England and the United States. Patrick White is a literary lone wolf, an artist who goes his own way, sometimes a peculiar way, with lordly independence.
Four operas will be presented by the New York City Opera Company at City Center this week-end. The Company opened its season Wednesday night.

FORAYS into the country to admire the fall foliage and enjoy the remaining brisk sunny days often include a stop at a roadside stand to load the car with harvest bounty in the shape of pumpkins, apple cider and bushels of apples.
THE able reportorial staff of the Columbia Broadcasting System was seen to excellent advantage last night in a sober and balanced analysis of the world crisis.

Words are the currency of communications and, like any currency, can be devalued by inflation. This is exactly what is wrong with a well-meaning report issued by the Human Relations Unit of the New York City school system, which tells public school teachers to avoid "speech patterns" that create feelings of inferiority.

Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz said yesterday that if elected Mayor he would end the "terror in the streets" that, he said, had turned the city into a "jungle" during Mayor Wagner's administration.

Ralph Houk stood up to his first world series setback as a manager with a certain tightlipped grimness. It seemed to indicate that while he accepted the fact of defeat he was not willing to concede that the Yankees had been beaten.
New Haven, Conn., borrowed $10,288,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance public improvements.

Your editorial of Sept. 26 "The Game of Parking" emphasized to me one of the reasons why New York will be a better and happier city if Attorney General Lefkowitz becomes its Mayor. The editorial describes some of the new "street games" which, it tells us, the lax administration of Mayor Wagner has permitted, if not encouraged.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Richard J. Hughes, the Democratic candidate for Governor of New Jersey, spent a half hour with President Kennedy today and made it clear he would welcome some Presidential campaigning on his behalf.
OXNARD, Calif., Oct. 5 -- An Air Force public information officer has been removed from his post for making anti-Communist speeches off the base, friends of the officer reported today.
There is little for the military experts of SEATO to be cheerful about as they meet in Bangkok to plan for future contingencies in Southeast Asia.

Mayor Wagner made a walking tour of two Brooklyn neighborhoods last night -- shaking hands, rubbing shoulders with voters and mildly chastising a group of supporters of his opponents, Louis J. Lefkowitz.

The Union Bag-Camp Paper Corporation is planning to enter the sanitary paper products field through the proposed purchase of Doeskin Products, Inc. A $4,662,000 cash offer will be considered at a court hearing here on Nov. 10, as ordered by Federal District Judge Edmund L. Palmieri of the Southern District of New York.

Almost the very same dedicated group that welcomed the horses back on Tuesday turned out to watch yesterday's proceedings at Aqueduct. The turnout of 19,173 was nineteen more than were on hand the day before.
A dispute between state and city agencies over jurisdiction in housing discrimination here has been temporarily resolved by an agreement announced yesterday.

THE suspicion is taking hold that the Reds are as much destiny's darlings as were the Pirates a year ago. A capricious fate smiled benignly on the zingers from Zinzinnati in the second game of the world series at the Stadium yesterday. The leprechauns and the elves and the little people were turned loose to help them.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- The heads of the three major broadcasting networks were asked at a White House luncheon today to provide more films and tapes for government use overseas.
CHICAGO, Oct. 5 -- A new system for keeping animals alive at freezing temperatures was described by a Harvard surgeon here today.
BOSTON, Oct. 5 (UPI) -- Jimmy Piersall predicted today he had a "lot of good years" to give to his new Washington Senators owners.

A committee of lawyers, professionals and business people to help elect acting Supreme Court Justice Emilio Nunez and Gustave G. Rosenberg, Liberal party candidates for the Supreme Court was formed yesterday.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 5 (AP) -- Duke Rodney was made the favorite today to take the Kentucky Futurity trotting race tomorrow. The total purse for the sixty-ninth Futurity is $59,330.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 5 -- Former Gov. Goodwin J. Knight, who charged yesterday that an emissary for Richard M. Nixon had tried to lure him out of the California gubernatorial race, was the target of a similar charge today.

VIENNA, Oct. 5 -- The chief of the Soviet delegation said today that he might recommend to his Government that it withdraw from the International Atomic Energy Agency, now holding its fifth general conference here.
A task force of leading economists published extensive proposals yesterday for the first nation-wide reform of the high-school economics curriculum.

A half-hour of music and comedy from "Do Re Mi," the current Broadway musical starring Phil Silvers and Nancy Walker, will be televised Oct. 22 on the "Ed Sullivan Show" over the Columbia Broadcasting System.
James Thurber was resting comfortably yesterday after having undergone surgery for removal of a blood clot on his brain Wednesday night.

BEGINNING Monday, thousands of hunters will be taking to the fields and woods in the state for small game. Later they will seek bigger targets, such as deer and bear. Aside from their interest in the sport, they will have one thing in common: each will have a gun in hand.
TO Whom It May Concern: Aux Armes! A musical version of Sergeant Bilko may be produced without Phil Silvers.
KIEV, U.S.S.R., Oct. 5 -- A Soviet military court sentenced two young Dutchmen today to thirteen years' detention on espionage charges.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5 -- Win or lose, University of Nebraska football players felt stronger and had more endurance than their rivals on a pre-game liquid diet, according to a report to be published Saturday in the American Medical Association Journal.
Following are excerpts from a statement issued lost night by the city Board of Ethics concerning campaign contributions:

BERLIN, Oct. 5 -- An East German border guard shot at and barely missed a West Berlin policeman today. The incident occurred in the Bernauer-strasse, scene of a wild exchange of gunfire across the line between East and West Berlin less than eighteen hours earlier.

COLOGNE, Germany, Oct. 5 (AP) -- A "Fly American" campaign in the United States was sharply criticized by West German Lufthansa officials today. They said it might cause the West German airline to stop ordering planes from the United Sates.
CHICAGO, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Grain futures prices declined again today, with most corn and oats contracts dipping into new low ground for the season.
CHICAGO, Oct. 5 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
Mayor Willy Brandt of West Berlin said on his arrival here last night that the crisis over his beleaguered city would be met and resolved without war, as other crises had been.
CAIRO, Oct. 5 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser formally gave up tonight all claim to Syria as part of the United Arab Republic.

Increased activity in the field of business forms was announced yesterday by the International Business Machines Corporation. However, the company said that "plans have not yet reached the stage where any product announcements can be made."

ESSEX FELLS, N.J., Oct. 5 -- Nick Marra and George Waller of Copper Hill won the New Jersey State Golf Association best-ball tournament today by shooting a 2-under-par 35, 34 -- 69 at the Essex Fells County Club.

The director of the U.N. Relief and Works Agency for Palestine refugees is once more compelled to report to the General Assembly that this tragic problem has not been solved. The costs for the basic necessities are, and have been for years, seven cents a day for each refugee. Nobody under U.N.R.W.A.'s supervision is starving for food.

HONG KONG, Oct. 5 -- A treaty delimiting the border between Communist China and Nepal was signed in Peiping today by Liu Shao-chi, Chinese head of state, and King Mahendra Bir Bikram Shah Deva of Nepal.
The series of jazz concerts that has been given in the Sculpture Garden of the Museum of Modern Art all summer moved indoors last night to the museum's auditorium for one final fling.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Abraham A. Ribicoff stood up before almost 1,000 leading educators today, threw away the text of his prepared speech and told them they did not care about education.
PARIS, Oct. 5 -- United States and West German business men met here today to discuss possibility of coordinating Western private investment in underdeveloped countries.
DETROIT, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Automotive News said today that the strike at the Ford Motor Company was expected to hold total industry output to an estimated 106,146 passenger cars.
I take issue with a letter published in The Times on Sept. 25 headed "Make-up of School Board Queried."
TORQUAY, England, Oct. 5 -- Great Britain scored a double victory in the European Bridge League's annual tournament that ended here today after twelve days of play.
One of General de Gaulle's mistakes, according to your editorial of Oct. 2, has been "his failure to make preparations for a successor."
Their patience at an end, garment center traffic policemen yesterday ticketed the same trailer truck twenty-two times in six hours, for a possible total of $330 in fines.
Cotton futures moved 5 cents a bale off on the near March contract to 15 to 85 cents up on the others on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday.
The United States Seventh Army provides the hard core of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's ground defenses in Germany.

ATLANTA, Oct. 5 (UPI) -- The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr, a leader in the integration movement, charged tonight "an apparent reign of terror" was being waged against Negroes taking part in a voter registration drive in two south Mississippi counties.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- The news of Sam Rayburn's condition stirred new speculation here today about a successor as Speaker of the HoUse of Representatives.
Mayor Wagner and Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz shook hands yesterday and signed a pledge condemning any attempt to inject religious bigotry in the mayoral campaign.

For centuries pamphleteering has been one of the liveliest and most volatile forms of publishing. Political dissidents of all shades of opinion have ground out their leaflets and newsletters, sometimes on creaking basement presses, to present their views to the world.

Two mutual fund management companies handling three mutual funds announced merger plans yesterday. Their respective distributing organizations also would be merged. Involved in these mergers are combined portfolio management of three mutual funds with assets of $50,000,000 and private investment advisory accounts totaling $150,000,000

IF cooler weather has pepped up appetites sufficiently to do justice to generous servings of poultry, this is a good week-end to invest in a large-sized turkey. One chain offers turkeys more than sixteen pounds for only 29 cents a pound, while other stores price these big birds in the low thirties.

LONDON, Oct. 5 -- Duncan Sandys, British Secretary for Commonwealth Relations, ended three days of talks in Accra, Ghana, today convinced that the air had been cleared for a visit by Queen Elizabeth next month.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- The Civil Rights Commission urged President Kennedy today to issue a broad executive order banning racial discrimination in Federally aided housing and by Federally supervised mortgage lenders.
The Encampment for Citizenship will hold a Gala Caribbean Dinner in the Embassy Ballroom of the Summit on Oct. 23 for the benefit of its First Encampment in Puerto Rico.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- The President's Science Advisory Committee sought today to give last-minute reassurances to worried astronomers that the launching of a belt of needles around the earth would not obscure their vision of the heavens.
IN "The Investigators," the new crime series that started last night on Channel 2, the command post for a murder syndicate was in a school of dancing.

Negotiations covering details of the Tuesday night television debate between Mayor Wagner and Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz, his Republican opponent in the mayoral election, were still snagged yesterday on format.
DALLAS, Oct. 5 -- House Speaker Sam Rayburn, 79 years old, is suffering from cancer. Hospital tests today showed that there was no hope of his recovery.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- The State Department blamed the East German Communist authorities today for the outbreak of shooting along Berlin's intra-city border and warned that further incidents could jeopardize peace and public order there.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 5 -- A domesticated ocelot with a gourmet's appetite has been ousted from his dormitory home by Princeton University.
Lyle S. Garlock, former Assistant Secretary of the United States Air Force, has been named as Eastern Air Lines' chief representative in Washington in relations with the Government and Congress.

A dinner dance will be given on Oct. 28 in the Statler Hilton as a benefit for Cooley's Anemia Blood and Research Foundation for Children. Joseph A. Caltabiano is chairman of the fifth annual event, tickets for which may be obtained from the beneficiary at 480 St. John's Place, Brooklyn.

Phil David Fine, deputy administrator of the Small Business Administrator, warned small business investment companies yesterday that they must concentrate more on their business -- providing capital for small concerns.
The Atlantic Refining Company of Philadelphia has ordered a big tanker for its oil carrier fleet.

BLACKPOOL, England, Oct. 5 -- The Labor party refused today to approve Britain's proposed entry into the European Common Market unless a future Labor Government retained power to use nationalization and planning to attain socialism.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 5 -- A watchdog committee for world peace was proposed by Thailand today to take the heat out of political disputes.

The uproar over the incredibly crass fundraising at a campaign luncheon for Mayor Wagner will have a constructive result if it prompts a search at all levels of government for better ways to guarantee that gifts to candidates will not cloud the integrity of the governmental process after Election Day.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Secretary Robert S. McNamara forbade civilian and military defense officials today to express politically partisan views at meetings sponsored by nongovernmental groups.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- The Air Force has turned down a Navy request for permission to use 127 houses on Mitchel Field on Long Island and it appears now that these houses will be disposed of along with the rest of the base.
ATHENS, Ohio, Oct. 5 -- Dr. Vernon R. Alden, 38-year-old associate dean at the Harvard Graduate School of Business, was named today president of Ohio University.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- The Government's effort to borrow $2,000,000,000 through the sale of nineteen-month notes attracted $5,684,000,000 of applications from investors, very largely commercial banks, the Treasury reported today.
Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz ventured into hostile labor territory yesterday, made a vigorous speech, appealed for votes and left half an hour late to warm applause.

A tenor whose singing must be familiar to just about every true music-lover in New York gave his first full solo recital here in Town Hall last night. He is Charles Bressler, who appears regularly with the New York Pro Musica in its many concerts as well as with many other outstanding ensembles.

Nowhere in Fred Hutchinson's baseball background is there existence that might indicate he is a "wisecracker" or an "I told you so" guy. But the manager of the Cincinnati Reds could not pass up the opportunity to draw a loud laugh a few minutes after his National Leaguers had squared the world series by beating the Yankees at the Stadium yesterday.
Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation is stepping up its manufacturing and marketing operations in the chemical field.
QUEBEC, Oct. 5 -- New York State mutual savings bankers discussed today the need for legislation to help them compete for the savings dollar.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) -- A new version of the Military Petroleum Advisory Board is being organized under pressure of the tense international situation.
ALBANY, Oct. 5 -- The Rockefeller administration is putting considerable pressure on the Thruway Authority to reduce its huge debt to the state and help balance the state's 1962 election-year budget.
President Joaquin Balaguer estimated yesterday that the ruling Dominican party could poll "70 to 75 per cent" of the vote in a free election in the Dominican Republic at this time.
MOUNT CLEMENS, Mich., Oct. 5 (UPI) -- A "work or else" edict was issued today by welfare authorities in Macomb County. They suspect that 650 men now on relief prefer welfare aid to employment.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif. Oct. 5 -- John Frankenheimer, the director, is an admitted Hollywood heretic. He thinks color film should be confined, almost entirely, to musicals and travelogues.

The Citizens Union yesterday urged "yes" votes for the new City Charter and for a separate proposal on the Nov. 7 voting machines that seeks to insure five minority seats in the City Council out of ten new seats to be filled on a burough-wide basis.

PARIS, Oct. 5. -- Although France, under President Charles de Gaulle, sometimes seems almost oblivious to world opinion, the highest officials of the French Government are deeply upset at the "bad image" of France that emerged from the bargaining at Vienna this month over a new plan to strengthen the world monetary system.

NEWARK, Oct. 5 -- The Hudson and Manhattan Railroad Company has been ordered by the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners to postpone until Jan. 30, 1962, its proposed 5-cent intrastate fare increase.
MIAMI, Oct. 5 (UPI) -- The University of Miami Hurricanes, led by George Mira at quarter-back and Bill Miller at end, will meet a young and eager Navy football team tomorrow night at the Orange Bowl.
Trans World Airlines navigators late last night called off a strike set for 12:01 today. Earlier they had planned to defy a Presidential order postponing the walkout.

THE New York City Opera Company opened its fall season last night at the City Center with the three one-act operas of Puccini's triptych: "Il Tabarro," "Suor Angelica" and "Gianni Schicchi." It has been many years since New York had an opportunity to see all three at once in a full-fledged production.

The Women's League for Israel will hold its thirty-fourth annual Harvest Luncheon in the Grand Ballroom of the Astor on Oct. 26. Mrs. Arthur Schumer and Mrs. Charles Strier are co-chairmen for the event, which will be highlighted by a fashion musical.

TULSA, Okla., Oct. 5 (AP) -- George Dawson of Glenn Ellyn, Ill., became the favorite in the United States Golf Association senior amateur tournament today with a 4-and-3 victory over Merrill L. Carlsmith of Hilo, Hawaii.

Louis Goldfarb, realty investor, has taken title to the four-story building on lot 25 by 110 feet at 861 Third Avenue, twenty-five feet north of Fifty-second Street. He bought the property for cash over mortgages amounting to $202,000. William O. Land was the broker in the sale.

The Investment Company Institute, trade association of the mutual funds industry, announced yesterday the election of Charles H. Schimpff as president. Mr. Schimpff is president of American Mutual Fund, Inc., of Los Angeles and senior vice president and member of the' investment committee of Capital Research and Management Company, which is adviser to three other funds in addition to American Mutual.
LONDON, Oct. 5 -- Jamaica will become independent only next year and will be sponsored by Britain as a full member of the Commonwealth.
Dr. Hans Hirschfeld, a key figure in the recent spy trial of Dr. Robert Soblen, was identified here yesterday by the defense as a former aide of Mayor Willy Brandt of West Berlin.
MOSCOW, Oct. 5 -- About twenty Western peace marchers visited Moscow University today and, in a stormy meeting, sought to persuade Soviet students to back their appeal for unilateral disarmament.

In his capacity as Yankee batting coach, Wally Moses conducted a verbal and visual investigation of Roger Maris during batting practice at the Stadium yesterday. He hoped to learn why the home-run king had been such easy prey for Cincinnati's pitching aces in the world series.
EDISON, N.J., Oct. 5 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner urged the White House and the Pentagon today to reconsider the recent decision to deactivate Raritan Arsenal.

The largest weekly increase in the Federal Reserve System's outright holdings of Government securities in more than ten years was effected during the week ended Wednesday, a spokesman for the Federal Reserve Bank of New York said yesterday.
Prices on the New York Stock Exchange advanced yesterday, the railroads for the seventh successive day.
The Hughes Tool Company made public yesterday the terms of the "memorandum of understanding" between it and the Atlas Corporation with respect to proposed financial assistance to Northeast Airlines.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 5 (UPI) -- The executive secretary of the Minnesota High School League said yesterday he would rule ineligible any high school player who attended Minnesota Viking professional football games free of charge.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 5 -- The Center of Alcohol Studies, at Yale University for forty years, will soon move to Rutgers University.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., Oct. 5 -- The touring women's field hockey team of England gained its ninth victory in thirteen games in this country by defeating an all-college team, 8 -- 0, today at the Germantown Cricket Club.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Department store sales in the nation for the week ended last Saturday were 5 per cent above the year-earlier level.
Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System increased by $7,000,000 to $34,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Railway freight loadings last week were up from both the preceding week of this year and the corresponding week of last year. Favorable loadings figures were also shown by the trucking industry.
Prices slipped to new lows for the lives of all "B" and "M" coffee contracts yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange.
I have read with despair Julian Rosenberg's letter published Sept. 14 opposing aid to the neutral nations because of the things said and left unsaid at Belgrade.

THE authors of "Blood, Sweat Stanley Poole" have been profligate with their material. On television it could be spun out in endless segments, which would be shorter, if not drearier, than what was revealed last night at the Morosco.
RENO, New Oct. 5 -- Governor Rockefeller of New York called today for creation of a Federal Department of Transportation.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Friday, Oct. 6 (Reuters) -- A 19-year-old American girl, Toby Ellen Saks, won the first prize early today in the junior section of the third Pablo Casals International 'Cello Contest. No first prize was awarded in the senior section, and no competitor was found worthy of the Casals Grand Prize.
A series of seven concerts of music by Beethoven will be given in Carnegie Hall this season by the Symphony of the Air. This will be the first regular series presented by the orchestra since 1957.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- If the Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei Gromyko, is coming to Washington tomorrow in a less pugnacious mood, as officials here seem to think, it is scarcely surprising. For while the Soviets are not getting everything they want these days, they are making more progress than is generally realized.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) -- President Kennedy today accorded the personal rank of Ambassador to John W. Tuthill while he serves as United States representative with the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.

The city's efforts to increase its police force by recruiting outside its boundaries has resulted in the failure of more than half of 107 applicants to pass the first written and medical examinations.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 5 (AP) -- The Honolulu Oil Company recorded today a transfer of its properties to other oil companies to complete a deal the Government wants to stop.
The United States monetary gold stock dropped $101,000,000, to $17,351,000,000, during the week ended on Wednesday, it was reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 5 -- Chancellor Adenauer and Dr. Erich Monde, chairman of the Free Democrats, reached agreement on the "essential aspects" of foreign and defense policies in their second round of coalition talks tonight.

The Cincinnati Reds, in an astonishing reversal of form, turned on the high and mighty Yankees at the Stadium yesterday and thrashed the American League champions in the second game of the world series, 6 to 2.

CAIRO, Oct. 6 -- For 5,000 years or more Egyptians have tied their fate to the Nile and its annual flooding. They have had to reconcile themselves to the fact that flood and earth fertility go together. As everyone knows the rushing, moody, waters bring silt deposits that enrich the soil for the next year's crops.
Imports of foreign goods by the United States dropped 8 per cent in August from July's high level, the Department of Commerce reported yesterday.
Peter Minuit Post, the real estate unit of the American Legion, will hold its monthly meeting at 6:00 P.M. Oct. 19 in the Shelburne Hotel, Lexington Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street.
What may prove to be the prize local offering of the intercollegiate football season will be on view today at Baker Field.
Buried deep in statistics just issued by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board is the latest chapter in a tale of industry growth.

Executives of Trans World Airlines and the carrier's flight navigators agreed yesterday to submit a joint recommendation to President Kennedy on the composition of a three-man emergency fact-finding board to investigate their dispute.

A community meeting has been called for next Thursday in an effort to gain city police protection for Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village. A 29-year-old mother was raped in her Stuyvesant Town apartment last Thursday morning.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 6 -- Steins of beer were flowing freely on the banks of the American Rhine tonight.
MIAMI, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Jim Stewart raced 83 yards to a second-period touchdown tonight and Navy went on to upset Miami, 17 -- 6, before 53,182 fans.
WATKINS GLEN, N.Y., Oct. 6 -- Olivier Gendebien of Belgium was slightly injured today when his car skidded off the road during practice for Sunday's Grand Prix of the United States.
DARIEN, Conn., Oct. 6 -- Maybe every little American boy would like to be President, but a large number of grown-ups here don't want to be Town Meeting Representatives.

The New York Mets, who will play their first National League season in the Polo Grounds next year, signed a thirty-year lease with the City of New York yesterday for use of the proposed $19,000,000 sports stadium in Flushing Meadow.
And now the United States Davis Cup team goes forth to face the formidable Nicola Pietrangeli Co. on Rome's clay courts.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Plain English has been adopted is the official language of form 1040.
VIRGINIA BEACH, Va., Oct. 6 (UPI) -- A crippled Navy jet was shot down with sidewinder missiles over the Atlantic today to keep it from crashing in a populated area.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 6. -- The Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway Company now is convinced that the Western Pacific Railroad Company no longer can continue operating independently, according to Ernest S. Marsh, Santa Fe president.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- To surmount the Berlin crisis successfully the President must manage a triple play and, in dealing with Mr. Gromyko today, he was dealing with but one of three major elements in the problem. For Mr. Kennedy faces three negotiations, not just one.

Vito P. Battista was reinstated on the Nov. 7 ballot yesterday as the mayoral candidate of the United Taxpayers party. He had been disqualified by the Board of Elections on Tuesday because his written acceptance of the nomination had not been notarized.

CONVENT STATION, N.J., Oct. 6 -- A four-foot cylindrical statue of St. Vincent de Paul, sculptured by Sister Marie Imelda to obtain her Master's degree in fine arts, will be placed in a building that is being erected at the College of St. Elizabeth.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- John J. McCloy said today the failure to achieve a nuclear test ban at Geneva "constitutes the most discouraging exercise in disarmament negotiations since the close" of World War II.

MIAMI, Oct. 6 (UPI) -- A Cuban Government in exile was set up here today by a group of refugee Cuban judges and magistrates. The new Government will be a rival of the Cuban Revolutionary Council headed by Dr. Jose Miro Cardona.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 6 -- The Philadelphia Orchestra Association today canceled all scheduled concerts of the 1961-62 season pending settlement of a contract dispute with Local 77 of the American Federation of Musicians.
The election of Milton A. Cole and James C. O'Hara as vice presidents of the Chemical Bank New York Trust Company was announced yesterday by Harold H. Helm, chairman.

St. John's and Fordham reached the final round of the Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference fall tournament yesterday with decisive victories over Iona and New York University, respectively. The winners will meet today at the Creedmoor State Hospital Field, Queens Village, Queens.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 6 -- A reliable source repeated today that the United States had sounded out the West German Government on its willingness to conduct negotiations with East Germany regarding the rights of access of the Western powers to West Berlin.
LONDON, Oct. 6 -- Industrial shares continued their advance in the stock market here today but at a slowed pace. Gains of around six pence (7 cents) pre-dominated in most groups.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (UPI) -- Space scientists forecast today that the cost of a round-trip to Mars in 1980 would be $1,000,000.

CERALDINE FARRAR'S father played first base for Philadelphia. When Jackie Robinson joined the Dodgers he made baseball safe for democracy. The day Bill Wambsganss made his unassisted triple play in a world series game another target was set by a hapless batter who, as a part of the attendant chaos, managed to achieve five outs in two times at bat.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- President Kennedy hailed yesterday the progress in desegregating schools in Memphis, New Orleans and elsewhere. He said it reflected credit on the United States throughout the world.
ACCRA, Ghana, Oct. 6 -- The Government moved today to establish a special court to deal with crimes against the state.
Jerry Barber, the captain of the United States Ryder team, which leaves tonight to meet the British, has become a convert to the British, or smaller-sized golf ball.
The Waterfront Commission yesterday denied charges that it had been lax in processing complaints of discrimination filed by Negro longshoremen.
Steel mills shipped 6,139,418 tons of finished steel products in August, compared with 5,120,808 tons in July, and 5,071,953 tons in August, 1960.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 6 -- Military advisers to the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization have "strengthened existing defense plans to take into account the broadening Communist threat to free countries" of Southeast Asia.
ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Oct. 6 (AP) -- Marilynn Smith established a women's course record today with a first-round score of 70 in the $8,000 Albuquerque Ladies Professional Golfers Association tournament.
MOSCOW, Oct. 6 -- The Juilliard String Quartet received the acclain of Moscow's music critics and a standing ovation in the Tchaikovsky Conservatory tonight as it opened a tour of the Soviet Union.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Provincial guardsmen, in a bayonet and pistol assault, have killed forty-six members of a Communist battalion southwest of Saigon in the swampy Mekong Delta, the Government announced today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Wheat futures prices rallied today to finish mostly higher after early easiness had carried prices to their lowest level in several months. Other grains finished mixed to lower.
A dental and pharmaceutical Center that will provide care for 6,500 textile workers was opened yesterday at the textile union's headquarters.

THE new director general of the International Atomic Energy Agency is a modest Swedish physicist who thrills at the thought of working for a world organization. But the Soviet Union is not happy over the installation yesterday of Dr. Arne Sigvard Eklund.

Tilden High School recorded its second consecutive shutout of the Brooklyn Public Schools Athletic League season yesterday by whipping Boys High, 40 -- 0. It was the first Tilden triumph over the Red and Black at Boys High Field since 1953.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Oct. 6 (Reuters) -- Constitutional talks broke down here today over the formation of a coalition govern ment for this British East African colony.
The Anaconda Company, a major copper producer, plans to expand its related lumber operations into an integrated timber products organization reaching from the forest to the consumer.
WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 6 -- Air Record, owned by F.E. Ross and George Sholty, scored a nose victory over Merrie Duke in the $25,000 Trader Horn Trot tonight before 24,177 fans at Roosevelt Raceway.
CAMP TUTO, in Northwest Greenland, Oct. 6 -- Amid unexpected drama, the Army inaugurated last night its tunnel town 100 feet below the surface of the Greenland ice.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Military sources said today that they had been advised by officials of the Defense Department that military manpower might be cut back sharply if the Berlin crisis eased and no major crisis developed elsewhere.
Although momentum slowed noticeably, the market on the New York Stock Exchange continued its upward move yesterday.
DUBLIN, Oct. 6 -- The hopes of Prime Minister Scan Lemass for a clear majority in Ireland's new Dail (parliament) were frustrated today.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 6 -- Mickey Mantle demonstrated today that he still could swing a bat with lethal power. But whether he will be able to return to the Yankee line-up tomorrow is a question that remains as open as the painful wound on the right hip that kept him out of the first two games of the world series with the Reds.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 6 -- The United States pressed today for prompt consideration of a treaty to ban nuclear weapons tests and insisted that the General Assembly "can take action here and now."

The one-story building at 3061 Atlantic Avenue in the East New York area of Brooklyn has been leased by Queens Metal Fabricators, Inc., fabricator of metals and allied products for the building trades. It contains 21,000 square feet of space.

THE activity on the part of the many small gift shops sprinkled all over town is incessant. Stuart Becker, for one, opened its doors two years ago at 1053 Third Avenue. Several months ago, when the building was taken down, the shop disappeared.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 50 cents a bale up to 60 cents off yesterday.
A PIE shell is a versatile item. It will act as a roof, a bed or an envelope and, according to the filling, is equally suited to the main course as to the dessert.
M'COMB, Miss., Oct. 6 (UPI) -- Two Negro integration leaders were arrested here today as an aftermath of an anti-segregation protest march on City Hall by 116 Negro high school students.

The twelve-story store and office building at 63 Vesey Street, corner of Greenwich Street, has been hold by a group of corporations controlled by Theodore, David and Albert Ornstein. It was bought by a syndicate of investors headed by Alvin M. Greenstein, Solomon Klausner and Shep Lieberman.
A Broadway producer believes he has found the answer for theatregoers who feel prices are too high. It lies half-price tickets to previews of forthcoming attractions.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Bell Telephone Laboratories, Inc., will receive a patent next week for an important link in the proposed system of satellite communications. The invention is an amplifier that detects faint radio signals such as those expected from satellites in polar orbits 7,000 miles high.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 6 -- If things work smoothly for Bob Purkey against the Yankees in the third game of the world series tomorrow, the Red's 6-foot-2-inch, 198-pound right-hander will deliver approximately 120 pitches.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 6 -- The United States gave a preliminary outline today of President Kennedy's proposal that the United Nations set up a ten-year program for the advancement of under-developed countries.
The world premiere of Douglas Moore's "The Wings of the Dove" will lead off the second week of the New York City Opera's fall season Thursday night at the City Center.
Three men high in the ranks of finance began making calls on top corporate executives this week seeking donations for philanthropy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Administrator Najeeb E. Halaby of the Federal Aviation Agency said today that design and operating modifications had reduced the operating risk of DC-8 jet commercial aircraft to an acceptable level.

Prof. Oliver H. Radkey in his letter published Sept. 21 criticizes Arthur Krock for his endorsement of two proposals by Senator Claiborne Pell: recognition of the Oder-Neisse boundary, and holding back nuclear weapons from West Germany.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Labor unions have been put on notice that President Kennedy's appeals for wage and price restraint were not made just for the record.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- A panel of college leaders urged the American Council on Education today to support Federal aid to elementary and secondary schools.

ANY net dipped into the teeming sea of Picasso's creations is bound to surface with curious and interesting specimens, both of which will be found in the small catch at the Saidenberg Gallery, 10 East Seventy-seventh Street.

The New York Telephone Company received 120,957 calls for the score of the second game of the world series, a spokesman said yesterday. On the first day of the series, the company received 96,287 calls for the score.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 6 (AP) -- An Interstate Commerce Commission examiner wound up two weeks of regional hearings here today on rival bids of two big Eastern railroads to control the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company.

According to vital statistics, there are more people this year than ever before who can rejoice that they are no longer young -- if they feel that way. Some have been talking in this fashion for thousands of years.
NEW HAVEN, Oct. 6 -- One hundred Negroes staged a sit-out demonstration here tonight to protest discrimination in housing.
Many of this city's leading judges and lawyers will attend New York's sixth annual Protestant service on Tuesday "to invoke God's blessings" on the courts of justice.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 6. -- An authoritative source said here today that West Germany was willing to discuss an improvement of administrative and technical contacts with East Germany but emphasized strongly that these discussions "will never become a back door to the de facto recognition of the Communist regime."

SANDERSVILLE, Ga., Oct. 6 (AP) -- Assistant Secretary of the Interior Kenneth Holum said today the Kennedy Administration planned Federal participation in development of the nation's power resources without dominating or monopolizing the field.

Mrs. Eustace Seligman and Mrs. Waldo M. Hatch, co-chairmen of patrons for the New York Arthritis and Rheumatism Foundation theatre party Oct. 26, have announced the names of the patrons. The benefit will be at a performance of "Let It Ride" at the Eugene O'Neill Theatre.

According to Bob Gaiters of the New York Giants, natural physical equipment can take a rookie fullback only as far as the line of scrimmage in the pro league. His progress from there depends mainly on his brain.

The Building Department issued summonses yesterday to the managements of seven East Harlem tenements as a result of a tour of the area made last Friday by Manhattan Borough President Edward P. Dudley and other officials.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- President Kennedy and President Ibrahim Abboud of the Sudan agreed today on the importance of a nuclear test ban agreement based on an effective system of inspection and control.

James R. Hoffa received yesterday his first hearing in four years by a major affiliate of the merged labor movement. The president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, which was expelled from the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations in 1957, addressed 750 receptive delegates at the convention of the Transport Workers Union in the Roosevelt Hotel.
Record sales and earnings were achieved by Montecatini Mining and Chemical Company, Ltd., Italy's largest chemical producer and mining company, in the six months ended on June 30.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- The Navy ordered today an additional year of active duty for some of the future college students in its Reserve Officers Training Corps.
TORONTO, Oct. 6 -- The Canadian Shakespearean Festival at Stratford, Ont., has decided to remodel its famous apron stage for the 1962 season.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Americans were pictured today as spending more than a billion dollars a year in false hopes of getting well, getting slim or regaining lost youth.
Representative Paul A. Fino challenged Mayor Wagner yesterday to say whether he favored the admission of Communist China into the United Nations.
Mayor Willy Brandt of West Berlin said yesterday that the wall that divides Berlin is a brazen challenge to the West that must not be allowed to stand.

A horse fifteen hands high was carried into the lobby of the United States Courthouse at Foley Square yesterday, hitched to a buggy and left there. It was part of a Fire Department exhibit to be displayed in the lobby during Fire Prevention Week, which starts tomorrow.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 6 -- Iraq's Foreign Minister Hashim Jawad, told the General Assembly today that "the world is no longer governed by the big powers" and that they must accept the influence of the "non-aligned" nations.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- President Kennedy made interim appointments today to seventeen Federal judgeships, six of them in New York.

The last walking tour of the season will start at 2:30 P.M. Sunday at the statue of Washington in Union Square. Under the direction of Architectural Historian Henry Hope Reed, the group will walk through Washington Square and along Fifth Avenue, learning how the area appeared in the day of Henry James.
FREEPORT, L.I., Oct. 6 -- A plan to establish a marine nature center on 162 acres of tidal marshland here is being considered by village officials and the Town of Hempstead.

PARIS, Oct. 6 (UPI) -- Sources close to the French Atomic Energy Agency said the Soviet explosion today was one and a half to two times as strong as the one of Oct. 4, which was measured at several megatons.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 6 (AP) -- Duke Rodney won the sixty-ninth Kentucky Futurity Trot today after his chief competitor, Caleb, had set a world record in the first heat.
Brazilian coffee futures prices continued to slide to new lows yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Prices of the "M" contract, however, recovered somewhat and closed irregular.

Jesse Corsover, a 43-year-old Lawrence, L.I., lawyer, was convicted in Special Sessions Court yesterday on one count of conspiracy and four counts of hiring others to solicit business for him -- commonly known as ambulance chasing.

President Kennedy has signed a two-year extension of the law authorizing the importation of Mexican farm labor, even though it lacks provisions necessary to prevent further erosion of the already wretchedly depressed wages of American migratory farm workers.
DALLAS, Tex., Oct. 6 (UPI) -- House Speaker Sam Rayburn, doomed by cancer, talked today with Vice President Johnson.
The City Fusion party opened its campaign for Mayor Wagner's re-election yesterday with a charge that Louis J. Lefkowitz, the Mayor's opponent, was a "puppet of the Republican county bosses."

TORONTO, Oct. 6 (Canadian Press) -- The president of the Famous Players Canadian Corporation announced today that the Paramount Pictures Corporation would take over the operating costs of the pay-television system operated by Famous Players in suburban Etobicoke Township on Jan. 1.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Oct. 6 -- Sir Edgar Whitehead, Prime Minister of Southern Rhodesia, was given mandates today by the United Federal party to take two steps aimed at removing racial tension in the territory.

A fourteen-acre industrial property with a frontage of 1,000 feet on the Hudson River at Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., has been bought by Tappan Tanker Terminal, Inc., fuel oil distributor. The property was acquired from the Harshaw Chemical Company, of Cleveland which leased back about 40 per cent for its own use.
A new national weekly newspaper called World will be on sale at newsstands for the first time next Thursday morning.
The Food and Drug Administration's approval of a new odorless, tasteless propellant for aerosol cans opens the way to wider use of the push-button packages for a variety of food specialties.

A toy manufacturer's representative told a Federal Communications Commission hearing yesterday that shows written for children sometimes failed because "the intelligence level of the writing was below that of the children."

The invasion of New York City by residents of Cincinnati was not confined to baseball circles this week. Last night at Town Hall another team appeared -- the husband-wife bass-soprano team of Maurice and Louise Mandell -- and it proved to be considerably more than second string.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Theodore Tannenwald Jr. resigned today as special assistant to the Secretary of State on foreign aid legislation. He will resume the private practice of law in New York.
JERSEY CITY, Oct. 6 -- The Port of New York Authority will be asked to assist in developing this city's waterfront, Mayor Thomas Gangemi announced today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- The Department of State denied today a report that the United States had approached the West German Government on whether it would be willing to negotiate with East Germany on the access rights of the Western powers to West Berlin.
IRONWOOD, Mich., Oct. 6 (AP) -- A group of upper Michigan men have joined to buy the Sunday Lake Iron Company mine at Wakefield, Mich.
A first public sale of common stock of the Barton Distilling Company of Chicago is being planned by a banking syndicate headed by Smith, Barney Co., Inc., and Fulton, Reid Co., Inc.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Oct. 6 (UPI) -- The Air Force fired a Titan missile with a new guidance system 5,000 miles across the Atlantic tonight to a target off the west coast of Africa.
Mrs. Walter S. Gubelmann and Mrs. Stanley C. Hope, co-chairmen for the Imperial Ball to be held Dec. 7 in the Plaza, have announced the names of the committee in charge of the souvenir journal.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 6 -- John Macy Willis, who helped make Baltimore a major shipbuilding port, was killed today, with his butler-chauffeur, in a traffic crash.
GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, Oct. 6 -- Disorders marked the opening today of British Guiana's first Parliament as an internally self-governing colony.

TULSA, Oct. 6 (UPI) -- Col. William K. Lanham of Glenville, Ill., and Dexter H. Daniels of Winter Haven, Fla., advanced today to the final of the United States Golf Association's senior amateur tournament at Southern Hills Country Club.
The only violence on the Randalls Island gridiron yesterday was that generated by two squads of healthy, husky high school football players.

MOSCOW, Oct. 6 -- Mme. Nina Petrovna Khrushchev told Western peace marchers today that the Soviet Union was not building air-raid shelters because "we are not getting ready for war." Ten marchers, all but one of them women, met with the Premier's wife over tea to discuss nuclear testing.

Your editorial of Oct. 2 on the poem "Babi Yar" by the Soviet poet Yevgeny Yevtushenko, is debatable on many grounds, but one thing is clearly undebatable -- the apparently deliberate omission of the historical responsibility for the killing of Jews at Babi Yar.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 6 -- A 1 1/2-cent hourly cost-of-living wage increase for basic steel employes was announced today by the United States Steel Corporation and the United Steel-workers of America.
OTTAWA, Oct. 6 (Canadian Press) -- A strong gain in July exports to the United States helped produce a $63,900,000 surplus for Canada's total trade for the month.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- The Labor Department reported today that employment conditions improved in the late summer months in two-thirds of the 150 major job areas of the nation.

Although most big business corporations in New York probably will be reporting sizable increases in their earnings when the end of 1961 rolls around, most of the big banks in town will have a different story to tell.
Interference by Egypt with shipping in the Suez Canal of nations that have granted recognition to Syria appears to have ceased.
Corporation Counsel Leo A. Larkin said last night that a City Charter provision barring political contributions by city employes was not intended to prohibit "voluntary" contributions.

Dr. James E. Allen Jr., the State Education Commissioner, has been invited to meet with the members of the new city Board of Education on Thursday. The session could have a bearing on whether Dr. John J. Theobald remains as Superintendent of Schools.

DETROIT, Oct. 6 (AP) -- A Federal grand Jury indicted today the business agent of the home local of games E. Hoffa, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters. The agent, George Raxburgh, is accused of having taken illegal payments from an employer.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 6 -- The Ministry for All-German Affairs published today excerpts of an East German decree of Sept. 14 that constitutes the legal basis for the current deportation of "unreliable" citizens residing within three miles of the border with West Germany.
LONDON, Oct. 6 -- The United States, Britain and France will ask West Germany to establish and nourish a wider range of contacts with Last Germany, qualified sources said today.
Senator Claiborne Pell of Rhode Island proposed yesterday that a large proportion of new immigrants pass a physical test similar to the Army's.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (UPI) -- William E. Miller, Republican National Chairman, accused President Kennedy's press staff today of trying to use reporters as political propaganda agents.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission said tonight the Soviet Union had exploded another atmospheric test in the Arctic.
HIGHTSTOWN, N.J., Oct. 6 -- The death of a 17-year-old honor student at the Peddie School here was being investigated tonight by the State Police.
A $65,802,655 Army contract for combat radio communications sets has been awarded to the Avco Corporation.

Events today: Kimio Eto, koto player, Town Hall, 5:15 P.M.; Mirdza Naruna, pianist, and Gil Treimanis, 'cellist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30 P.M.; Musica Aeterna, Frederic Waldman, conductor, Joan Sutherland, soprano, Rogers Auditorium, Metropolitan Museum of Art, 8:30 P.M.
ROME, Oct. 6 -- The Communist party speculated publicly today that the Roman Catholic Church might be reappraising East-West relations and called for a massive drive to win Catholics for neutralism.

ALBANY, Oct. 6 -- The Court of Appeals has refused to hear an appeal by Anthony (Tony Cheese) Marchitto of a contempt conviction for refusing to answer questions before the bi-state Waterfront Commission.
GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 6 -- A record fleet of seventy-four yachts set sail tonight in the sixth annual Stratford Shoal overnight race of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club.
CHICAGO, Oct. 6 -- The American Medical Association's Committee on Cosmetics announced today its opposition to the use of drugs in cosmetics.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Maj. Gen. Edwin A. Walker said today that he had been invited to submit his views in writing to a Senate subcommittee investigating charges that the Pentagon had "muzzled" military critics of communism.
DETROIT, Oct. 6 -- Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers, reported progress today in achieving local plant agreements with the Ford Motor Company.
CHICAGO, Oct. 6 (UPI) -- Two Chicago banks today announced plans for a merger which would make the combined institution the sixth largest bank in the city in terms of capital and undivided resources.
GENEVA, Oct. 6 -- Shipowners and seamen failed today at a meeting here called by the International Labor Organization to break a deadlock on the issue of air-conditioned quarters for crews.
