HIN HEUP, Laos, Oct. 6 -- The Princes who head Laos' three rival political factions held their long-awaited meeting today. No progress toward a settlement of the complex Laotian political problems was discerned.

LONDON, Oct. 6 -- The 300 players and officials who had gathered at Torquay on the English Channel for the European bridge team championships, which ended yesterday, are returning home via London today.
PARIS, Oct. 6 -- The French Line's new trans-Atlantic liner, the France, will have her first sea trial on Nov. 19.

Premier Khrushchev must have found this year's farm production in Kazakhstan's virgin lands area nothing less than a debacle. No internal innovation in post-Stalinist Russia is more intimately bound up with Khrushchev's public reputation than this vast project which has seen tens of millions of acres of grassland plowed up and planted to wheat.

The British Labor party completed an all-week annual conference at Blackpool yesterday without providing a single surprise. As predicted, Hugh Gaitskell, Leader of the Opposition in the House of Commons, consolidated the victory he had previously won for himself and for his moderate policies.
Political posters and billboards are bursting into garish bloom all over town, but it is almost impossible to tell a candidate's party unless you have a scorecard -- or know the score.
FLORENCE, Italy, Oct. 6 -- The long-lost head of the statue of Spring that adorns the Bridge of Santa Trinita in Florence was found today on a sandbank in the Arno River.
BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 6 -Concordia Prep's Clippers legistered their second victory of the football season today by defeating Montclair Academy of New Jersey, 15 -- 0.

Secretary Ribicoff, in his harsh lecture to the nation's college and university presidents, appears to have spoken more in anger than in sorrow. He said Federal school aid legislation had run into "an iceberg of indifference" and charged that nobody, including the leadership of higher education, really cares enough about education as a whole to fight for it.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture set today incentive prices of 62 cents a pound for the 1962 wool crop and 74 cents for that year's mohair crop.

QUEBEC, Oct. 6 -- New York State savings banks are pleased with the success of a new organization that solicits large deposits and distributes them among the individual banks, which are limited to $10,000 an account.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 6 -- Cuba accused the United States today of having tried to upset the Castro regime's relations in Latin America by circulating bogus documents.

A new book by Pal Kelemen, author of "Medieval American Art" and "Baroque and Rococo in Latin America," will be published Monday by Macmillan. In "El Greco Revisited -- Candia, Venice, Toledo," the author presents the personality of the sixteenth-century emigre and discusses the Byzantine, Italian and Spanish cultural backgrounds against which he moved.

One indisputable dividend from the session of Congress which has just ended is the confirmation of sixty new judges for Federal district and circuit courts across the nation. Another seventeen have now been given recess appointments. This desperately needed increase in judicial manpower was made possible largely by the omnibus judgeship bill enacted last May.
Representatives of the New York Philharmonic's musicians union agreed yesterday to call a meeting of its members to vote again on a management offer they previously rejected.
The three leading candidates for Mayor will conduct campaigns next week to urge voters to register for the coming election.
With no counter attractions lure them elsewhere, and with the weather so delightful that it was almost a pleasure to lose a bet, 24,331 persons attended the races at Aqueduct yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- President Kennedy was presented with the Grand Cross and Insignia of the Order of the Holy Sepulchre today. He also received an invitation to visit the holy places of Jerusalem.
William J. Maher has been named training director for personnel of the four Sheraton Corporation hotels in New York.
There was only one oversized truck in the garment area yesterday, and it was moved after the police appeared ready to repeat a multiple-ticket procedure they had used on Thursday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- President Kennedy and Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet Foreign Minister, exchanged some blunt views on Germany and Laos this evening, but made virtually no progress on either issue.
NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 6 -- Communal rioting broke out today within twenty miles of this capital as antagonism between Hindus and Moslems appeared to be spreading.
BERLIN, Oct. 5 (UPI) -- The Communist wall across Berlin is a twenty-five-mile-long chain whose links are concrete, brick, barbed wire and water.
MIAMI, Oct. 6 -- Two expansion projects were set in motion today at Miami International Airport.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- President Kennedy set a civil defense goal today of "fall-out protection for every American as rapidly as possible."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Average wholesale prices in primary markets declined 0.2 per cent during the week ended last Tuesday, to 118.5 per cent of their 1947-49 base, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.
ELIZABETH, N.J., Oct. 6 -- Victor H. Eichhorn, chairman of the Union County Welfare Board, today denied that relief allotments in the county were "excessive."
CAIRO, Oct. 6 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser faced the enormous task today of disentangling Syria from the affairs of the United Arab Republic.

Philip H. Gilsten, former deputy city treasurer and a Bronx Democratic leader, failed to appear yesterday to answer questions involving improper literature distributed during the recent mayoral primary campaign.
Eight motor vehicle examiners and one supervising examiner for the Department of Motor Vehicles have been suspended on charges of accepting bribes from driver-license applicants.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- A Government security officer declared today that Irvin C. Scarbeck said he received about $400 from Polish secret police after four months of providing them information from the American Embassy in Warsaw.

GEORGE BIDDLE'S large retrospective exhibition at the Cober Gallery, 14 East Sixty-ninth Street, might be considered a sort of seismograph that registers from a safe distance the shocks and earthquakes of a half-century of art.

William J. Gottlieb of the Automobile Club of New York made a series of excellent suggestions recently for relieving the city traffic problem. The failure of buses to draw up to the curb was among them; but why he did not mention even worse offenders -- namely, the taxis, is a mystery.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- The Opera Society of Washington opened its season here tonight with Verdi's "La Traviata." The work will also be given Sunday and Monday in the Lisner Auditorium.

VIENNA, Oct. 6 -- Prof. Vasily S. Yemelyanov carried out his threat today to walk out of the general conference of the International Atomic Energy Agency in protest against the installation of Dr. Sigvard Eklund as director general.
A Brooklyn underworld figure who had been sought since Sept. 27 surrendered yesterday to face a charge of trying to kill Lawrence Gallo, a 33-year-old Brooklyn racketeer, on Aug. 22.

THE International Society Contemporary Music, American branch, struggling to get back on its feet after being moribund for a number of years opened a series of concerts last night at the New School for Social Research.

LONDON, Oct. 6 -- Antony Armstrong-Jones, husband of Princess Margaret, formally became the Earl of Snowdon tonight. ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 7 -- A study of nearly 3,000 families indicates that Americans give more than $17,000,000,000 annually to churches, charity and the needy.

AMSTERDAM, Oct. 8 -- The market here advanced last week on better feelings about the international political situation. The share turnover rose to 11,600,000 guilders nominal from 9,100,000 in the preceding week.

There has been a modification of plans for the documentary television series featuring former President Harry S. Truman. It will contain thirty-nine half-hour programs instead of twenty-six hour-long shows as announced initially.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., Oct. 8 -- A preliminary budget calling for total expenditures of $41,346,669 for 1962 will be presented tomorrow at the regular meeting of the Suffolk County Board of Supervisors.
WARSAW, Oct. 8 -- Poland's university year has begun with a record number of students at their desks and Marxist professors more firmly entrenched behind their lecterns.
In negotiating with the Russians it is necessary to have an accurate idea of their diplomatic goals and methods and useful to know what they suspect to be our own goals and methods.
CHICAGO, Oct. 8 (AP) -- The liquidation of wheat contracts and the persistent hedge-selling of soybeans depressed prices of futures on the Board of Trade last week.

GWYNEDD VALLEY, Pa., Oct. 8 -- A 3-year-old imported Welsh terrier, Ch. Caradoc Llwyd of St. Aubrey, went best in show today in a field of 486 at the Montgomery County Kennel Club's twenty-seventh annual all-terrier event.
GREENEVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 8 -- Efforts of a group of unemployed will result in the reopening under new management of a cabinet plant that has been closed since January.

SYOSSET, L.I., Monday Oct. 9 -- A youth was killed and a patrolman seriously wounded early today during a gun battle that followed the policeman's attempt to arrest the youth and a companion for reckless driving.
MOSCOW, Oct. 8 -- Soviet engineers have begun survey work for a railroad between Guinea and Mali.

The international president of the 280,000-member Communication Workers of America denounced James R. Hoffa yesterday and urged the merged labor movement not to readmit his International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Bobby Mitchell wrecked Washington today as the Cleveland Browns defeated the Redskins. 31 -- 7. It was the twelfth straight National Football League defeat for Washington over a two-year span.

LONDON, Oct. 8 -- "We will make Hugh Gaitskell scrub the floors of Transport House, when the Red revolution comes." These words sung by the Labor party's left-wingers to the tune of "John Brown's Body" during the party conference at Blackpool reflect the vitality of the enmity for Mr. Gaitskell which, even after his triumphs, remains one of British socialism's major problems.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (UPI) -- The Soviet Union detonated today its nineteenth atomic blast since resuming tests Sept. 1.

James Felt, chairman of the City Planning Commission, said last night that he had resigned Sept. 27 as a co-chairman of a $100-a-plate Democratic dinner. He acted, he explained, because he had doubts about the propriety of being identified with the fund-raising aspect of the dinner, which will be held tonight.
Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within twelve months amount to $84,271,679,554. They consist of Treasury securities as follows:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Dr. Ralph E. Lapp, atomic scientist, expressed the opinion today that the Soviet Union's current nuclear tests had already exceeded the "safe annual limit" of fall-out-danger.

The New York Exchange for Woman's Work will benefit from the Oct. 24 performance of the Noel Coward musical comedy "Sail Away" at the Broadhurst Theatre. Mrs. Robert L. Hamill and Mrs. John Amos Norman are co-chairmen for the theatre party.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 8 (AP) -- "I could see the blood coming through the uniform and I knew I had to quit. I just couldn't play any more. It hurt like the devil."

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Oct. 8 (AP) -- Dallas scored after recovering a fumble on the opening kick-off today and went on to wallop the Minnesota Vikings, 28 -- 0. The victory left the Cowboys in a tie for the Eastern Conference lead of the National Football League.
The big mutual funds -- those with assets exceeding $10,000,000 -- are not ready yet to step aside for the little fellows.
The over-the-counter market last week staged one of its strongest rallies in months.

KENOSHA, Wis., Oct. 8 (AP) -- Local 72 of the United Auto Workers rejected by a narrow margin tonight the profit-sharing plan worked out with the American Motors Corporation, leaving the future of the proposal uncertain.
MIAMI Fla., Oct. 8 (AP) -- An anti-Castro exile organization said today that Premier] Fidel Castro's Government would execute a woman Tuesday, an important Cuban holiday.
TUNIS, Oct. 8 -- The Algerian Nationalist Provisional Government is prepared to discuss with France its participation in a "transitional administration" and national police force in Algeria.
Ten new films are scheduled to arrive in local theatres this week. The programs follow:
ST. JOHN'S, Nfld., Oct. 8 -- Tomorrow is Canada's Thanksgiving Day and Newfoundland is in a festive mood on the eve of the official opening here of its new $20,000,000 university.

Earnings of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, Inc., the nation's largest supermarket chain, rose slightly for the first half of this year from those of the 1960 period, Ralph W. Burger, president, said in a report issued today.
The Galicia Honduras and the Newark Portuguese played a 4-4 tie yesterday in an American Soccer League fixture at Eintracht Oval.
All the land within fifty miles of Times Square will be built up by 1985 if present construction and zoning patterns continue, the Regional Plan Association predicted yesterday.

It is no wonder that an entire television show is to be given over to sounds, as is scheduled to happen tonight with "The Sound of the Sixties," for never before have sounds played so important a part in our lives.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 8 -- The Yankees defeated the Cincinnati Reds, 7 to 0, today and moved within a game of winning the 1961 world series.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 8 -- Mayor Willy Brandt of West Berlin said today that his two-day visit to New York had convinced him the United States would maintain the freedom of Berlin "at all costs."
An unusual step has been taken by the management of the newly opened "Blood, Sweat and Stanley Poole" to stimulate trade at the Morosco Theatre.
CAIRO, Oct. 8 -- Cairo was somewhat puzzled today by the recognition of the new Syrian Government by three Communist countries.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 8 -- The air-conditioning unit on the Pullman train from New York gave Whitey Ford a stiff neck. By game time this glorious summer afternoon his condition had improved considerably.

The Honolulu Oil Corporation has announced the receipt of a tax ruling from the Internal Revenue Service in connection with the sale of its assets. The company said that it appeared adequate to permit consummation of the transactions, but that it would be some time during this week before the ruling could be fully analyzed and evaluated.
ASBURY PARK, N.J., Oct. 8 -- Columbus has done it again. In 1492 he sailed for the Indies and found San Salvador. Today he landed in Asbury Park.

A NEW star is shining on Broadway these days. The hairdresser, long a backstage necessity, has been brought up front. Selected as carefully as the costumes or scenery, the coiffures he creates are as painstakingly planned as any role to be portrayed.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 8 -- There's a night-and-day difference between a world series game here at Crosley Field and one at Yankee Stadium in New York.

"LACK of money was the most important consideration in decorating my one-room, $22-a-month flat," says Alwin E. Stahl. That was four years ago when Mr. Stahl was studying at Parsons School of Design and earning pocket money by doing odd upholstery and drapery jobs.

Nationalist China's chief delegate to the United Nations indicated last night that his Government might be backing away from its previous hard line against admitting Outer Mongolia to the world organization.
NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 8 -- President Kennedy has booked a Western speaking tour for mid-November, his office announced today.
BERLIN, Oct. 8 -- A group of East German border guards staged a mock escape attempt tonight and then opened fire on four West Berlin civilians who tried to help them.

For more than four decades the League of Women Voters has been making a noteworthy contribution to the vitality of the democratic process by building a bridge of improved understanding between the citizen and his government.

DENVER, Oct. 8 (AP) -- The Denver Broncos rallied for two touchdowns in the last six minutes, but it wasn't enough to offset early mistakes and the Dallas Texans scored a 19-12 American Football League victory today.

A WEEK-END of solid musical accomplishment by the New York City Opera Company was climaxed at City Center last night by a splendid production of "Aida." Urged on by a large and warm-hearted audience, conductor and principals joined forces for a performance that winged its way through Verdi's masterpiece with style and assurance.
WATKINS GLEN, N.Y., Oct. 8 -- Innis Ireland, a Scotsman who lives in England, drove a British-built-Lotus to a stirring victory before a crowd of 60,000 today in the Grand Prix of the United States.
IN the Nassau Championships played at the Malibu Beach Club in Long Beach over the week-end, the winners of the pair events were:
Louis J. Lefkowitz, the Republican candidate for Mayor, attacked Mayor Wagner's civil rights record yesterday, terming it "one of inaction and indifference -- of pious promises and poor performance."

MADRID, Oct. 8 (AP) -- The Spanish security police have seized Joseph Ortiz and sixteen other exiled French foes of President de Gaulle's Algerian policy, official sources said today. The politicians and former French Army officers were captured in raids yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Americans for Democratic Action urged Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara today to continue his "unyielding opposition to certain Birch-oriented officers who use their positions to influence the politics of their troops."
The 125th anniversary of the founding of a Protestant Episcopal parish in Brooklyn was commemorated yesterday at St. Mary's Church, Classon and Willoughby Avenues.
The proposed new Charter for this city was assailed yesterday as making the Mayor a "fiscal dictator" but also defended as simply centralizing responsibility in him.

The Port of New York Authority announced yesterday the appointment of J. Douglas Maynard as assistant general manager of tunnels and bridges. Lawrence J. Lewis, of Jersey City, was promoted to Mr. Maynard's former position of manager of the Holland Tunnel.

ELMSFORD, N.Y., Oct. 8 -- Edward H. Meyerding, associate director of the National Committee for a Sane Nuclear Policy, 17 East Forty-fifth Street, New York, died today in Grasslands Hospital, Valhalla, of injuries suffered about four hours earlier in a fall from a ladder.
Seaboard World Airlines, the only all-cargo trans-Atlantic carrier, is seeking to capture a larger share of the North Atlantic air freight market -- with the cooperation of its competitors.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 8 (UPI) -- The San Francisco Forty-Niners' trounced the Los Angeles Rams, 35-0, today in a National Football League game.
NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 8 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru declared today that war was no solution for problems created for India by Pakistan and Communist China.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- A special industry committee is expected to recommend to the Government this week the creation of a nonprofit corporation to own and operate a communications satellite system.

Home gardeners may be threatened with the loss of late-ripening tomatoes unless the plants are protected at night with burlap or other similar material when early frosts are forecast. Tomatoes ripened on the vine have superior flavor, for the conditions are ideal for the sugars and flavoring materials to develop.

Aided by a three-and-a-half-minute allowance, Bill Schwab of Bloomfield, N.J., a former Brown University star, outran thirty-six others to win a five-mile handicap cross-country run at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx yesterday.

DETROIT, Oct. 8 (AP) -- The Chicago Bears, with Mike Ditka making two dazzling pass receptions and Willie Gaiimore racing 52 yards, scored three fourth-quarter touchdowns today and upset the Detroit Lions 31 -- 17, in a National Football League game.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Oct. 8 -- Ira Weisenfeld's gray gelding, The Gem, scored 14 points to win the open junior jumper championship today during the Hollows School fall horse show for the benefit of the United States Equestrian Team.
SEATTLE, Oct. 8 The only sure way to rid the road of drunken drivers is to install a device to prevent them from operating cars, a traffic research authority said today.

The Interstate Vending Company, Chicago, confirmed yesterday that it had completed arrangements to combine operations with the Brass Rail, Inc., New York, one of the largest food-service concerns in the nation.
GREEN BAY, Wis., Oct. 8 (UPI) -- Paul Hornung of the Green Bay Packers put on a scoring show today in a 45-7 victory over the Baltimore Colts.

An investing client of Robert P. Sheldon, Inc., broker, has leased with an option to purchase the three five-story apartment buildings at 1333 to 1343 Merriam Avenue, between 169th and 170th Streets, the Bronx, to William Michelman, realty operator.

Workmen were busy yesterday installing the space age at the Coliseum.
A pontifical mass yesterday commemorated the fifty-first anniversary of the consecration of St. Patrick's Cathedral.
In its first session the Eighty-seventh Congress demonstrated an active concern for natural resource problems. As in other areas of legislation, however, the lawmakers left much work unfinished.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Oct. 8 -- The Liberal, which won 11 per cent of the votes cast in the national election in March, moved today to take advantage of Belgium's shifting political situation by reforming as the Party of Liberty and Progress.

The Gilbert and Sullivan wing of the New York City Opera took over at the City Center yesterday afternoon for a performance of "The Mikado" that did it credit. There was one debut, Janice Broadhurst, who sang Pitti-Sing, but otherwise, most of the cast was familiar to those who have watched the emergence of a distinctive and pleasurable Savoy style within the company's ranks.

The first book of Bruce Catton's three-volume "The Centennial History of the Civil War" will be published Oct. 20 by Doubleday. Called "The Coming Fury," it opens with the almost festive Democratic convention in Charleston in 1860 and ends with the nation torn apart by the first battle of Bull Run.
The Russian siege of Berlin continues. No change for the better is evident as a result of President Kennedy's talk with Foreign Minister Gromyko.
ACCRA, Ghana, Oct. 8 -- Ghana's political crisis has had no apparent effect on the lives of most people here in the capital. To a foreigner, daily routines seem to be much as they were two years ago.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 8 -- Aided by mayhem-minded defenders and their new passing combination, the New York Giants recovered from a dreadful start and downed the Cardinals. 24 -- 9, in a National Football League game at Busch Stadium today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8. -- Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara's injunction against military participation in certain types of seminars and public forums has had a varying impact at the Pentagon.
The writer read with considerable interest and a degree of shock your editorial of Sept. 22 entitled "Decency at Newburgh?" Perhaps this letter might be entitled "Shall We Subsidize Immorality?"
PRADES, France, Oct. 8 (Reuters) -- The bodies of thirty-four victims of the crash of a DC-3 into a mountain were carried down to this French village today.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 8 -- Steel mills officials see some brighter prospects for their industry but no sign yet of a sharp pick-up.

A READER queried this department recently about directions for preparing turtle meat, which she had received as a gift. Her quandary is understandable because not many general cookbooks give directions for cooking turtle.

The Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church's new pipe organ was heard yesterday for the first time by the congregation.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 9 -- Sierra Leone's Foreign Minister, John Karefa-Smart, forecast today that all or most of sub-Saharan Africa would eventually be united in one form of government or another.

THE team-of-four event in the Nassau tournament played at Long Beach, L.I., last week-end was won by a Bronx team headed by Jules Tilles, who is business manager of the Greater New York Bridge Association. His team-mates included Dr. Norman Buch, Richard Budd and Michael Carroad.

PARIS, Oct. 9 -- An old and battered bike racer finally called it quits the other day. In twenty years of competition he had entered hundreds of races and won many of them. In 1947, he won the biggest of all, the Tour de France.

LONDON, Oct. 9 (Reuters) -- Following are the members of the British Conservative Government's Cabinet after its reorganization today:

The choice of neutralist Prince Souvanna Phouma to be Premier of a coalition government in Laos solves one of the points of disagreement that has blocked a settlement of the Laotian war; but other important issues remain to be dealt with.

For many years the shore path, below the Palisades from below George Washington Bridge to the state line, was the finest walking path within easy reach of the city. It was the only really fine place for a walk when the hiker could spend only part of a day enjoying it.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 50 cents a bale off to 25 cents up yesterday. The near months were weakest.

Traditionally, book publishers have had their offices in low-cost space in semi-loft buildings. Recently, however, there has been a trend toward moving from downtown areas to newer and more efficient space in mid-town.
A leading space scientist discounted yesterday any danger that military needs in space would be neglected by the assignment of much research work to the civilian space agency.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture estimated today that this year's cotton crop would total 14,334,000 bales of 500 pounds gross weight. The estimate represents an increase of 72,000 bales over a forecast of a month ago.
Trading was quiet on the New York commodity exchanges yesterday, and price movements were narrow.

The United Shoe Machinery Corporation and its domestic associated companies registered slightly lower sales and earnings for the quarter and six months ended on Aug. 31 than in the 1960 periods, the company reported yesterday.

Mayor Wagner and Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz will face each other for an hour on television tonight for a discussion of city issues. Billed as a debate, the meeting is expected to resemble more closely a joint televised news conference.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) -- The Cheseapeake and Ohio Railway concluded today its case for control of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad by challenging a major point of objection raised by the New York Central Railroad.
A plan to alleviate traffic congestion in Manhattan south Of Twentieth Street improved conditions considerably yesterday in its first day of operation.
The Brotherhood of Coaches of the American Football League (San Diego and New York branches) met yesterday over hash and buttered encomiums at the football writers luncheon at the Hotel Manhattan.

The big experiment in bowling, known by its backers as "major league," gets under way Thursday night in Dallas when the first National Bowling League match takes place. This project has to prove it's a "major league."

DETROIT, Oct. 9 -- The United Automobile Workers set Thursday as the target date today for settling the seven-day strike against the Ford Motor Company.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- Two loans aggregating more than $2,200,000 for industries in Peru and Argentina were approved today by the Inter-American Development Bank. The bank also agreed to send a technical assistance mission to Guatemala to study measures for improving economic development through state bank contributions.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 9 (Reuters) -- The armies of the Communist Warsaw Pact nations are carrying out "creeping mobilization" under cover of military maneuvers a West German Defense Ministry spokesman said here today.

Conn McCreary had a big day at the Aqueduct race track yesterday. He saddled the first winner of his new career as a horse trainer. The 40-year-old former jockey, who has had more than a fair share of vicissitude in his turf career, sent out Mrs. Leona Lober's Punic War for a six-furlong-sprint against eight others, and Punic War won by a neck.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 9 (AP) -- Former Senator Theodore Francis Green, looking cheerful and healthy, left the hospital today after having been in critical condition with a heart ailment.

Against a backdrop of the current international scene, celebration today of the 100th anniversary of the birth of Fridtjof Nansen takes on added poignancy. For despite the heroic work of such men as Nansen, who struggled and pleaded for refugees in the early years of the twentieth century, more than ever ours looks like the era of the homeless.

The S.H. Kress Co. store on Fifth Avenue, which once specialized in items costing a nickel and a dime, took on a new sparkle yesterday when it became the city's first variety store to sell diamonds.

VIENNA, Oct. 9 (Reuters) -- Vasily S. Yemelyanov, chief Soviet delegate to the conference of the International Atomic Energy Agency, which ended here last Friday, attended the first meeting of the agency's new board of governors today, despite his announced resignation.
In a generally dull session of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, prices either were barely lower or moderately lower according to the measuring rod used.
Although the city school system educates about 2.5 per cent of the nation's children, it accounts for 8 per cent of all pupils on double sessions, the City Planning Commission was told yesterday.
LONDON, Oct. 9 (AP) -- The United States and British Ryder Cup golf players were the dinner guests tonight of London's Lord Mayor, Sir Bernard Waley-Cohen.

The Age of Space, as measured by the calendar, dates back only four years to the launching by Russia on Oct. 4, 1957, of the first artificial satellite in orbit around the earth. Yet in a sense the Age of Space began when the first of the species Homo Sapiens emerged from the cave one enchanted evening in his prehistoric past and wondered about the stars and the immensity of space around him.

Investing clients of Wien, Lane Klein, lawyers, who recently bought thirty-two properties in Manhattan and Queens from the Rhinelander Real Estate Company, have taken title to nineteen of the parcels.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 9 -- Foreign Minister Subandrio of Indonesia rejected today as a "fairy tale of self-determination" the Netherlands' plan to grant her New Guinea territory independence under United Nations auspices.

SOUTHBOROUGH, Mass., Oct. 9 -- Though this was the warmest day of the season, there was no let-up in activity at St. Mark's today. The entire body of 232 boys perspired to football, soccer or physical fitness tests.

Ring Lardner Jr. confirmed yesterday that he had been a member of the Communist party in 1947, when he declined to testify before the House Un-American Activities Committee.
ATLANTA, Oct. 9 -- Gov. Ernest Vandiver said today the Georgia Legislature would reconsider the law under which a 15-year-old Negro has been sentenced to the electric chair.

OSLO, Norway, Oct. 9 (AP) -- All seven living winners of the Nobel Peace Prize and the five members of the Nobel Peace Prize Committee of the Norwegian Parliament published today a declaration of peace.

Tattooing, a colorful method of self-expression and a source of infection for thousands of years, has been banned in the city except when used for medical purposes. The Health Department prohibition takes effect Nov. 1.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Government witnesses denied today that Irvin C. Scarbeck, former diplomat charged with giving secret papers to Polish agents, was under arrest when they first questioned him.

The photo products department of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., announced yesterday it had begun full-scale production of "Dycril" printing plates by a new process. The plates would be turned out in a new plant at Parlin, N.J., the company said.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Ronald Zinn, a senior at the United States Military Academy, West Point, N.Y., won the national Amateur Athletic Union 15-kilometer walking championship yesterday with the time of 1 hour 15 minutes, 3 seconds.

LONDON, Oct. 9 -- Uganda will attain independence on Oct. 9, 1962, it was announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) -- The Public Health Service granted a license today for manufacture of the second of three new type oral poliomyelitis vaccines being developed for general use in this country.

LANSING, Mich., Oct. 9 (AP) -- Otis M. Smith, state auditor general, was appointed to the Michigan Supreme Court today by Gov. John Swainson. He will be the first Negro ever to sit on the high state court.

Robert Weede, who is costarred with Mimi Benzell and Molly Picon in "Milk and Honey," is on the sick list. The singer is suffering from an upper respiratory infection with other inflamations, according to his physician, Dr. Leo P. Reckford.

MOSCOW, Oct. 9 -- The Soviet Union accused Marshal Georgi K. Zhukov, former Defense Minister, today of having sought to curtail the nation's submarine building program.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 9 (AP) -- John D. Hertz, founder of the Hertz Rent-A-Car System, Inc., and of the Yellow Cab Company, died last night He was 82 years old.

MEMORIES of delicate pink crab apple blossoms become dim at this time of year but another colorful sight has taken their place -- the crab apple crop is ready to be harvested. Five women and three men, accused by a prosecutor of "falsely wearing the garb of Roman Catholic nuns and bishops," were ordered out of a General Sessions courtroom yesterday.

MELVIN RITTER and his wife, Jane Allen, gave a violin and piano program last night at Carnegie Recital Hall that was quite as enterprising and musical as their previous appearances here in the last two years.

THE BROOKLYN MUSEUM opens a daring exhibition today, "The Nude in American Art." Daring because the unabstracted nude, which afflicted our grandfathers with moral unease when publicly displayed, suffers today from the stronger taboo of cornballism.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 9 -- The racially mixed Highlander Folk School made known plans today for a center here.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 9 (AP) -- On Sept. 26, the day the Reds won the National League pennant, an estimated 30,000 persons celebrated in Fountain Square. There was drinking in the streets and the Cincinnati players had a hard time getting from the bus to a microphone to tell the crowd how much they appreciated all this.

LONDON, Oct. 9 -- "Meteoric," a word seldom used in the almost glacial movement of Conservative party politics, was being used tonight to describe the rise of Iain Norman Macleod. This ambitious, tough-minded son of a Scots physician in Yorkshire moved into a commanding position in the Conservative party hierarchy.
Sir John Elliot travel expert, Civil War buff and Yankee fan, completed a three-week Cook's tour of the United States yesterday and pronounced it ripe for tourism.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 9 -- "They were all great! Everyone played his heart out."
THULE, Greenland, Oct. 7 -- The northernmost medical practice in the world is that of a Danish woman who can trim a blubber lamp as well as she can wield a scalpel.

SOME cookbooks on home freezing make the sweeping statement that all cheeses can be kept at zero degrees successfully. But anyone who has tried storing a wheel of Cheddar in the freezer has learned that this is not true.

KATMANDU, Nepal, Oct. 9 -- Communist China has conceded Nepal's claim to the peak of Mount Everest under a boundary treaty signed in Peiping Oct. 5 by Mahendra Bir Bikran Shah Deva of Nepal and Liu Shao Chi, Chinese Chief of State, authoritative sources said today.
Scrutiny of any possible ties between organized gambling and college football is planned this season by college officials.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- In agreeing today to review the ruling of the Federal Court of Appeals, Second Circuit, in the so-called Glidden case, the Supreme Court excluded reconsideration of the basic finding of the lower court that has greatly disturbed employers throughout the United States. Nationalist China is today celebrating, although not under the happiest of circumstances, fifty years of freedom from the Manchus. It was on Oct. 10, 1911, that, under the inspiration of Dr. Sun Yat-sen, what is called the Wuchang uprising began.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) -- The probability of health damage to anyone in this country as a result of the fall-out from the current Soviet nuclear explosions is extremely small, the Public Health Service said today.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 9 -- Israel called on the Arab states today to join in making the Middle East a "pilot project" for disarmament. Mrs. Golda Meir, Israeli Foreign Minister, proposed that the regional plan be undertaken simultaneously with the search by the great powers for agreement on world disarmament.

GERMAN director Wolfgang Staudte is not one to close the book on the wickednesses of former Nazis and accept them as "good" Germans today. In his best-known film, "Murderers Among Us," he took a quick, vicious poke at the breed, and he is doing the same in his "Roses for the Prosecutor," which came to the Fifty-fifth Street Playhouse yesterday.
A Moore-McCormack Lines announcement yesterday is expected to set the country's lean and hungry shipbuilders vying for a fat piece of new business -- a contract estimated at $60,000,000.

I am grateful for James Reston's Sept. 24 column in which he commented on Senator Margaret Smith's speech, saying: "She was not choosing the destruction of the human race, but merely saying what women know better than men -- namely, that life must sometimes be risked in order to perpetuate life."

CINCINNATI, Oct. 9 -- Not satisfied with the various unofficial checks that have been made in this season of mass home run production, the major leagues have ordered their own test of the liveliness of the baseballs now in use.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 9 -- The record book will list today as the day the Yankees won the world series. But Fred Hutchinson, the manager of the routed Reds, didn't see it that way, a few minutes after his team had passed the point of no return.

ROME, Oct. 9 (AP) -- The official line-up of the United States Davis Cup team was given to Italian tennis authorities just before the deadline tonight. The name of the Wimbledon finalist, Chuck McKinley of St. Louis, was not included.
CHICAGO, Oct. 9 (AP) -- The corn futures market reacted optimistically today to reports that the Government was selling storage corn for 10 cents a bushel above Friday's prices.
SEATTLE, Oct. 9 -- Traffic safety authorities today tossed bouquets and brickbats at the automobile industry.

Philip H. Gilsten, former deputy city treasurer and a Bronx Democratic leader, obtained a court order yesterday temporarily preventing the state Attorney General from questioning him about the alleged distribution of "scurrilous" literature during the recent primary campaign.
Ralph Houk did yesterday what had been done only twice before in baseball: He won the world series in his first year as a major league manager.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- The Arena Stage, one of the nation's best-known repertory theatres, dedicated its new $850,000 home here today.

Directors of the Arabian American Oil Company have named Thomas C. Barger, president, to be chief executive officer, effective on Dec. 1. Norman Hardy is retiring as chairman, according to the announcement made yesterday.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Oct. 9 -- Most diplomats and foreign observers here think that the selection of Prince Souvanna Phouma as the next Premier of Laos has pushed this country closer to the Communist bloc.
Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz, Republican candidate for Mayor, accused the Wagner administration yesterday of "dismal failure" in combating slums in New York City.
The market for high-grade debt securities lost some of its firmness yesterday as the bids of dealers for United States Government securities were lowered all along the line.

The most optimistic rumor at the forty third annual American Gas Association convention in Dallas, Texas, last week was that the mighty General Electric Company was about to enter the gas appliance field. This, it was said, would be quite a setback for the electric appliance business.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 9 -- The Yankees defeated the Cincinnati Reds today, 13 to 5, and won the world series for the nineteenth time in twenty-six attempts.

DETROIT, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Strikes at General Motors and Ford have delayed -- probably until after New Year's -- a full test of the public's response to the so-called in-between size cars of the 1962 model year.

Carlos Almoina, former director of the Cuban Tourist Institute, has been held in La Cabana Fortress in Havana without a trial for the last six months, Senora Rocio Almoina, his sister, said yesterday.
HERKIMER, N.Y., Oct. 9 (AP) -- The expected payment of the Thruway Authority debt to the state will be insufficient to continue a 10 per cent income-tax rebate, Governor Rockefeller said tonight.
French and American committee chairmen for the April in Paris Ball, which will take place in the Seventh Regiment Armory on Oct. 20, have been announced by Mrs. Winston F.C. Guest, general chairman.

BALTIMORE, Md., Oct. 9 -- Plans to merge the Martin Company of Baltimore and the American-Marietta Company of Chicago were approved today at simultaneous special meetings of Martin's stockholders here and Marietta's shareholders in Chicago.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court dismissed today a challenge to Virginia's 1958 fair trade law, which allowed manufacturers of brand name goods to set retail prices.

A Norwegian explorer, Helge Ingstad, has discovered ruins on the northern tip of Newfoundland island where he believes Vikings under Leif Ericson came to the North American Continent 500 years before Columbus.
MILLBURN, N.J., Oct. 9 -- James P. Mitchell said today that if elected he would "end forever the threat of a jetport for Northern New Jersey."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Senator Strom Thurmond, whose criticism led to a Senate investigation of charges that the Pentagon is censoring speeches by military critics of communism, began two weeks of active military duty today.

I was exceedingly pleased to read Topics of Sept. 18. I have just returned from a two-year visit to Los Angeles and various large centers throughout the country. I had occasion to observe the traffic problems each of these centers is confronted with, owing to the explosive expansion of population and motor vehicles, as well as the remarkable control their police forces have over the pedestrian and over vehicular traffic.
Royall, Koegel Rogers, a law firm, has leased a floor in the Pan Am Building, now being built at 200 Park Avenue, adjoining Grand Central Terminal.
The toy industry's first spring and summer toy market week got off to a late start yesterday morning, when Mayor Wagner got his armories mixed up.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Oct. 9 -- A Netherlands policeman punched the Soviet Ambassador today in a fist fight between the police and Soviet officials over the custody of a Russian woman whose husband defected to the West. Mme. Aleksei Golub, 32 years old, announced she was ready to return to the Soviet Union after the fight and after Dutch officials had arranged a meeting with her husband.

The matinee on Nov. 19 of the Bayanihan Philippine Dance Company, one of the two performances to be given in New York by the troupe, will be a benefit for the Big Sisters. The event will be at the Metropolitan Opera House.
Many party-givers take great ride in their expertness at mixing drinks and jealously guard their secret formulae for working up a martini or a daiquiri.
BETHLEHEM, Pa., Oct. 9 -- A new $25,000,000 Bethlehem Steel Company research center was dedicated here today.
BERLIN, Oct. 9 -- Mayor Willy Brandt said today he would discuss with Western Allied authorities whether the West Berlin border police were armed well enough to cope with the East Berlin guards.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- President Kennedy made a flying trip to Texas today and paid a call on an old comrade of the legislative wars, Speaker of the House Sam Rayburn.
A $100,000-a-month bookmaking operation in the General Motors Corporation's Chevrolet assembly plant in Tarrytown, N.Y., was broken up yesterday by agents of the Internal Revenue Service.

Following are the texts of a statement issued by Mayor Wagner yesterday dealing with Republican fund-raising practices and excerpts from an address by the Mayor last night at a Democratic fund-raising winner:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- The State Department held talks today aimed at reducing Western differences and finding a workable basis for starting negotiations with the Soviet Union on Berlin.
Commissioner Arthur J. Benline's television program, as reported in The Times on Oct. 2, points out the great importance of controlling the hazard of air pollution by every practical means.

GENEVA, Oct. 9 -- Publicly, the attitude of the Western delegations at the fourteen-nation conference on Laos here is one of cautious optimism that there will be an agreement guaranteeing the independence and neutrality of the tiny Asian kingdom.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 9 (UPI) -- Congress should give the transport industry faster tax write-offs on new rolling stock. Michael Forgash, president of the United States Freight Company, said today.
VATICAN CITY, Oct. 9 (AP) -- The Jesuit periodical La Civilta Cattolica said today that it was "simply immoral" to risk one's life in sport.
The president of Queens College nullified yesterday a student organization's invitation to Benjamin J. Davis, national secretary of the Communist party, to speak on the campus.
NEWARK, Oct. 9 -- Richard J. Hughes predicted today that Governor Rockefeller of New York would contribute "generously" to the campaign of his Republican opponent, James P. Mitchell.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. 9 (AP) -- Four Negro ministers named along with The New York Times in a series of libel suits contended today that the complaints were part of a conspiracy to deny them their civil rights.

The American Radiator Standard Sanitary Corporation has entered into an agreement to sell its Youngstown Kitchens division to a new group that will operate the properties under the name of the Mullins Manufacturing Corporation.
No representative of Italy will attend either the dinner tomorrow night or the parade on Thursday sponsored by the Columbus Citizens Committee.

PARIS, Oct. 9 -- Britain's chief negotiator in her effort to join the European Economic Community, or Common Market, arrived in Paris today for the formal presentation and explanation of his country's position.

MADISON, N.Y., Oct. 9 (AP) -- Mrs. Jane Smith, a 32-year-old housewife from Ridley Park, Pa., won the New York-New Jersey Class A stock hydroplane competition yesterday and thereby captured the national championship of the American Powerboat Association.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 9 -- The Yankees sharpened their batting eyes with considerable vigor and eclat during the fifth game of the rounders tournament on this delightfully warm and pleasant day. It was an endeavor without a future. There is no baseball season left. There isn't even a world series.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) -- The Supreme Court refused today to review a Kansas ruling that agency shop agreements were illegal in that state.

THE role of the enchantress in literature, as in life, is vast. Her sorceries may dishevel creation. But none can doubt that in any manifestation she relieves the tedium of the commonplace, the mundane, in man's fate.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 9 -- The United States reported progress today toward solving the problem of finding a successor to the late Dag Hammarskjold as United Nations Secretary General.
JACKSON, Miss., Oct. 9 (AP) -- Fourteen Protestant Episcopal ministers pleaded not guilty again today to charges that they breached the peace during an attempt to integrate a bus station.

The Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria was turned into a jungle setting last night for the Seven to Eleven Dinner Gala at which a fashion show of furs by Georges Kaplan was presented. More than 500 guests attended the event for the benefit of Comeback, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- The Federal Reserve Board announced today that it would hold a hearing on Dec. 7 on the application of the Morgan New York State Corporation for approval as a bank holding company.
RIVER VALE, N.J. Oct. 9 -- A circus clown was charged today with the murder of a woman who also was a veteran circus performer.
MOSCOW, Oct. 9 (UPI) -- Irina Press bettered her world pentathlon record at the Soviet Union's track and field championships, Tass, the official Soviet news agency, reported from Tiflis today.

NEWARK, Oct. 9 -- More than 1,300 production employes at the Newark and Union plants of the Weston Instruments Division of Daystrom, Inc., went on strike this morning, shutting down operations at both plants.
CINCINNATI, Oct, 9 (AP) -- Forty-two world series records were broken and twenty-one tied during the past week by the New York Yankees and the Cincinnati Reds.

Purporting to heed the cultural prodding of Newton N. Minow, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, Twentieth Century-Fox Television announced plans yesterday for a vidpix series based on Homer's "The Odyssey" and "The Iliad."

Borough President Edward R. Dudley of Manhattan made an inspection tour of three East Harlem slum buildings yesterday and said he was appalled by the "terrible" conditions he found. They were the worst he had ever seen, he declared.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:
LONDON, Oct. 9 -- Iain Macleod was named Leader of the House of Commons and chairman of the Conservative party today in the most significant of a number of changes in the Conservative Government.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- The Kennedy Administration called on the Supreme Court today to spur the reapportionment of state legislatures.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 9 -- England today became the third country to be committed to representation in the Washington D.C. International with the acceptance of an invitation by the owner of the 5-year-old stakes winner High Perch.
INSTEAD of cruising in a squad car, Constable Linc Vail, the hero of "Everglades," the television series that began last night on Channel 4, uses an air boat.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- The Senate Internal Security Subcommittee questioned today the 1959 decision by a New York police examiner that Povl Bang-Jensen, a Danish diplomat, committed suicide after his dismissal as a United Nations aide.
SYOSSET, L.I., Oct. 9 -- A 23-year-old unemployed plumber was charged with attempted murder in the shooting of an off-duty Suffolk County policeman early today.

BRISK fall weather brings out the classic sweater combinations, the classic tweeds and with them, of course, the classic alligator pumps. As seen in the fall shoe collection at Saks Fifth Avenue, the alligator pump has been given a 1961 twist with a flattened squared toe and a high instep buckle.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Oct. 10 (UPI) -- United States Navy helicopters rescued seventy four merchant seamen today from two typhoon-battered freighters that went aground on Kita-Daito-Shima, an island south of here.

In the wake of the recent Belgrade conference of unaligned states, suspicion of Yugoslav neutrality has clearly intensified in Washington. American irritation over Yugoslav foreign policy was increased at the conference by President Tito's astonishingly mild reaction to the renewal of Russian nuclear tests. The result has been a series of hints that the Kennedy Administration is planning to reduce drastically economic aid to Yugoslavia.

PARIS, Oct. 8 -- Gen. Valentin Gonzales, who as El Campesino led loyalist guerrilla forces during the Spanish Civil War, was arrested tonight on the Ile de Brehat off the coast of Brittany. He had been in forced residence there since Aug. 24.
George Meany rejected yesterday a proposal that the International Brotherhood of Teamsters under the leadership of James R. Hoffa be readmitted to the merged labor movement.

The important role of the cattlemen in the development of the American West is told by Lewis Atherton in "The Cattle Kings." The author, who is Distinguished Professor of History at the University of Missouri, describes the careers, adventures and contributions to the national scene of such men as Charles Goodnight, George W. Littlefield, Shanghai Pierce, the Langs, the Marquis de Mores and Richard King. Indiana University Press will issue the book Nov. 17.
The Moran Towing and Transportation Company announced yesterday the appointment of Frank O. Braynard as public relations manager and editor of the company's monthly magazine Tow Line.

The living theatre faces the possibility of economic strangulation, Representative John V. Lindsay warned yesterday, unless every level of government -- municipal, state and Federal -- considers the dramatic arts a special problem of general public interest.
Steel production declined 1.4 per cent last week, marking the first decrease in output in ten weeks, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- The Treasury's short-term borrowing cost rose for its ninety-day bills marketed this week.

LONDON, Oct. 9 -- Industrial shares had more losses than gains in the stock market here today. Losses ranged to around a shilling (14 cents).

A 67-year-old man was struck and killed by a hit-and-run car in Queens Sunday night. His body was apparently flung by the impact under a parked car.

LONDON, Oct. 9 -- The Earl of Home, Britain's Foreign Secretary will confer tomorrow night with Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet Foreign Minister. He will try again to persuade Mr. Gromyko that the West, while resolute in defense of its rights is prepared for reasonable discussion of the Berlin issue.

LOON BAY, N.B., Oct. 9 -- Only woodcock hunters, who by their very calling confess they are a bit eccentric, could hope for cold, foul weather as a matter of course. Recently Senator Fulbright said at a news conference in London that the West is not entirely blameless in the Berlin crisis. "We bear heavy responsibilities for the stupidities of this situation," he said.

THE days when women engulfed themselves in folds of opulent furs seem to have come to an end. In Gunther Jaeckel's fall collection presented at Bonwit Teller yesterday, the minks, sables and chinchillas were neatly tailored with narrowed shoulders, high waists and a hint of flare in back.

IN 1625 Peter Minuit purchased Manhattan Island from Indians for trinkets said to be worth about $24, thereby making himself one of the two most celebrated real estate dealers in the island's fabulous history.

Students at Queens College protested yesterday the cancellation of a speaking invitation extended to a Communist party leader.

NEVER was there an autobiography remotely like "Promise at Dawn,"* by Remain Gary. Tragic and pitiful, comic and hilarious, wise and foolish, it contains a more-than-life-size portrait of one of the world's most endearing and extraordinary women, M. Gary's heroic mother; a life-size self-portrait of a likable and exasperating young man; and more wonderful stories than seems possible.

Carry Back will be back among his own kind today. Mrs. Back Price's popular colt, who won the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness as well as several her important contests for year-olds, will compete in the 55,100 Lawrence Realization makes at Aqueduct.
Golden dragons and dancing unicorns bobbed and weaved to the beat of gongs through Chinatown yesterday to celebrate the fiftieth anniversary of the overthrow of the Manchu Dynasty.
The dispute between the Columbia University Press and a student-run discount bookstore was settled yesterday.
The nation's ambitions in space exploration have greatly outrun its basic scientific competence in space science, Dr. James A. Van Allen said here yesterday.

Los Angeles, Calif., borrowed $35,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance public school construction.

Potato futures prices made slight declines in active but lackluster trading yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
GARY, Ind., Oct. 10 (UPI) -- A workman, suspended for talking back to his supervisor, killed four men and wounded three others in a steel mill here today.

PARIS, Oct. 10 -- Britain announced today her readiness "fully to subscribe to the aims and objectives" of the European Common Market.

The senior bishop of a Brooklyn church, whose members have been called "nothing more than panhandlers" by an Assistant District Attorney, testified yesterday in behalf of two "sisters" on trial for assaulting a policewoman.

The general election in the Irish Republic was indecisive but nonetheless important and interesting. Sean Lemass, the Prime Minister and leader of Fianna Fail, which was the majority party in the Dail Eireann (Parliament), is now left without his majority.

THE Mercury space capsule, the satellites Echo and Transit, and a proposed design for a lunar colony may be seen at the Space Flight Report to the Nation, an exhibition at the New York Coliseum. The exhibition is open from 5 to 10 P.M. through Friday, on Saturday from 10 A.M. to 10 P.M., and on Sunday from 1 to 8 P.M.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 10 -Dr. Erich Mende, chairman of the Free Democratic party, moved today to prepare his party to accept Chancellor Adenauer for another term.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- Officials of the Justice Department are concerned about growing racial tension in southern Mississippi.
Meteoroids puncturing a space craft could cause a flash explosion that might kill the crew, two scientists reported yesterday.
Sales by the nation's retail stores in September declined by about one-quarter of 1 per cent from the August level, the Department of Commerce reported yesterday.

Construction has been started on the first section of the Commack Shopping Plaza, a fifteen-acre development at Jericho Turnpike and Veterans Highway in Commack, L.I. The center, which is being built by Irving Berger Associates, the owner, will contain a branch of the S. Klein Department Stores, Inc.

Senator John L. McClellan, Democrat of Arkansas, has signed a contract with Duell, Sloan Pearce for the publication of a book tentatively titled "Crime Without Punishment." Its purpose is to "arouse public feeling" and support for reforms of abuses such as those the Senator's committee has uncovered.
The William Zeckendorf interests signed a contract yesterday to buy a 33 per cent controlling interest in the Yonkers Raceway. The purchase price was given as between $16,000,000 and $17,000,000.

The directors of Martin-Marietta Corporation voted yesterday a dividend of 25 cents each on the shares of the new company. It is payable on Dec. 27 to holders of record of Dec. 4.

The planners of the New York Ball are well on their way toward creating a miniature of the fabulous fete that welcomed the Prince of Wales (later Edward VII in 1860. That ante bellum ball, which had the same effect on Gotham as V-J Day, was held in the old Academy of Music in Fourteenth Street.

TAIPAI, Taiwan, Wednesday, Oct. 11 -- Chinese Nationalist officials denied today persistent reports that it had been decided not to bar Communist Outer Mongolia from the United Nations by a Chinese Nationalist veto in the Security Council.
LEVITTOWN, L.I., Oct. 10 -- An intensive campaign to open up Long Island housing to Negroes has been started by the Long Island Chapter of the Congress of Racial Equality.

Mayor Wagner and Attorney General Lefkowitz have now both spoken out in favor of more stringent laws to deal with the problem of campaign contributions. This is progress. NEW CITY, N.Y., Oct. 10 -There was a five-way tie for the medal at 71 in the seventh annual Jack Moone Memorial mixed Scotch open golf championship at the Dellwood County Club today.

Gary Collins of Maryland, an outstanding end on both offense and defense, today was named the lineman of the week by The Associated Press for his brilliant play in the Terrapins' 22-21 upset victory over previously unbeaten Syracuse last Saturday.

A series of practical and recreational adult courses will be given at the Evening Community Center of Joseph Pulitzer Junior High School, Seventy-Ninth Street near Northern Boulevard, Jackson Heights, Queens.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Cuban charges that the United States is training new invasion forces at twenty United States and nine Caribbean bases were denounced today as "totally unfounded" and "ridiculous" by the State Department.

PEIPING, Wednesday, Oct. 11 -- Foreign Minister Chen Yi has said that Communist China is willing to have talks with the United States at the foreign ministers level as a step toward easing tension between the two countries.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. Oct. 10 -- United States-Soviet talks today on the problem of naming a new Secretary General failed to make any progress. A spokesman said the talks had been "disappointing."

The Italian Ambassador to Washington, the Italian Consul General in New York City and a large number of the best elements in the Italo-American community in New York are staying away from the Columbus Day banquet this evening and the parade being held tomorrow. In doing so they are showing a higher sense of propriety and dignity than New York officials and politicians and a number of other dignitaries.

John Pfeiffer, who blocked two fourth-quarter punts that led to Alfred's 12-6 victory over Union last Saturday, headed the weekly all-East small-college football team announced yesterday by the Eastern College Athletic Conference.

THE school bell has an ominous ring to many bright children who cannot seem to harness their brain power in the classroom. An influential civic group asked the three top candidates for Mayor yesterday to pledge themselves to seek changes in the proposed new City Charter in 1962.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Sonny Liston and Albert Westphal of Germany have signed for a feature bout in Philadelphia Dec. 5 contingent upon Liston's reinstatement by the Pennsylvania Athletic Commission, boxing sources said today.
LONDON, Oct. 10 -- The dull trend in industrial shares continued in the stock market here today. Losses again ranged to a shilling (14 cents) or so.

PORTSMOUTH, R.I., Oct. 10 -- If Ralph Hewitt, the star Columbia quarterback of three decades ago, gets grayer than usual this season, it will be small wonder. The one-time Lion, now coaching Portsmouth Priory's eleven for the seventeenth season, claims he has been caught in midstream.

The Hudson Theatre at 139-41 West Forty-fourth Street has been sold by the National Broadcasting Company and will be replaced by a parking garage. It has been purchased by Samuel Lehrer, parking garage builder and operator, for more than $1,000,000.
A total of 1,108 persons were hurt here in car accidents last week, the Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday. This was a decline of thirty-three from the like 1960 period.
LUANDA, Angola, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Governor General Venancio Augusto Deslandes asserted today that the Angola rebellion was over. He said Portuguese casualties totaled 1,400 in six months.
In an unusual switch, the "G.E. College Bowl" show will appear in New York next Sunday on WPIX (Channel 11) rather than on the Columbia Broadcasting System's local outlet on Channel 2.
More than $200,000 was raised here last night to support cultural institutions in Israel and a program of cultural exchange between the United States and Israel.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 10 -- At 10 A.M. today the National League brass assembled forty-five strong in a third-floor conference room of the Netherland Hilton Hotel to help stock the New York and Houston clubs for the 1962 season.

Sales and earnings of the General Electric Company rose slightly in the third quarter from the 1960 levels. For the first nine months of this year sales were higher than a year earlier but earnings were down considerably.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 10 -Nine colts and a filly today were named for the $85,135 Westbury Futurity for 2-yearold trotters on Oct. 20 at Roosevelt Raceway. The race is the richest in the nation for 2-yearold trotters.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- The Treasury sold $2,000,000,000 of one-year bills today at discounts averaging 2.975 per cent. At the last sale of a comparable issue -- $2,000,000,000 of one-year bills in July -- the average discount rate was 2.908 per cent.

Your editorial of Oct. 4, apropos United States assistance to Ghana's Volta Dam project, urging us to avoid pique as well as the temptation to dictate Ghana's foreign and domestic policies as a condition for help, deserves daily reading. It contains some general principles extending far beyond Ghana and which have applicability to our relations with older allies and "neutralists" everywhere.

Three industrial buildings on a tract of seventeen acres at the intersection of Route 17 and Summit Avenue, Hackensack, N.J., have been bought for investment by the Raywin Realty Company of Passaic. The structures, which are two blocks north of Route 46, were sold by the Maple Garden Realty Corporation, the builder. J.I. Kislak, Inc., of Newark was the broker.
CHICAGO, Oct. 10 (AP) -Corn futures prices advanced again today despite a Government denial of reports that it planned to end a policy of selling storage corn at cheap prices.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 10 (UPI) -- Billy Hitchcock, an infielder with five American League clubs in an eleven-year major league career, was formally introduced as the Baltimore Orioles' new manager today.

Japan has been seeking to correct a chronic shortage of capital and a crucial foreign trade imbalance. Yoshizane Iwasa, deputy chairman of the Fuji Bank, Ltd., said yesterday at a news conference here that "Exporting more and better quality goods to the United States and other markets is probably the best solution,"

Your editorial of Sept. 23 "Face-Lifting for Slums" and your article of Sept. 24 "Median Housing Is Found Scarce" underlined two serious threats to the health of New York City: The physical deterioration of the city and the absence of reasonably priced housing for the middle-income family.

IT seems peculiarly appropriate that Walter Steg man is devoting his radio programs this week to a series of recordings called "The History of Music in Sound." For taken together, Mr. Stegman's program selections in the seven years he has been broadcasting, represent something of a history of music in themselves.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- The United States announced today its third underground nuclear explosion since its atomic tests were resumed in mid-September.

THE next team of six players to represent this continent in play for the world championship will be selected in a five-day tournament at Houston, Nov. 18-22.

Senator Warren G. Magnuson called upon the nation last night to speed the development of communications satellites able to carry educational television to the "uncommitted peoples and the under-developed areas of the world."

CINCINNATI, Oct. 10 -- At a combined cost of $3,650,000, the New York Mets and the Houston Colts today fished forty-five players out of the 136-player pool made available to them by the eight established National League baseball clubs.
Total net assets of The Lehman Corporation rose to $346,214,601, or $30.91 a share, on Sept. 30, the corporation announced yesterday in a nine months interim report.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Coach Weeb Ewbank of the Colts is thinking about benching his star quarterback, John Unitas.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Mr. McConnell questioned Mr. Saunders on the ownership of N. W. stock and directors serving both the N. W. and the Pennsylvania.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Oct. 10 (AP) -- The Minister of Youth and Sport, Michel Mongali, criticized the Congolese today for taking their soccer too seriously. A man should play to relax his mind and spirit -- not to win, he said.

The International Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots announced yesterday formal ratification of a four-year agreement with tanker operators by its ten Atlantic and Gulf Coast offshore locals and branches.

A course for nursing-home administrators will start today under the auspices of the Columbia University School of Public Health and Preventive Medicine.
A tartan motif is in order for the forthcoming covers of British motor magazines. For, at long last, a Scotsman has won a "grand epreuve," a race in the series for the world road racing championship.
The appointment of C. Bradford Mitchell as director of information of the American Merchant Marine Institute was announced yesterday by Ralph E. Casey, president of the steamship trade association.

A HEARTWARMING integrity shines through "Milk and Honey," which arrived last night at the Martin Beck Theatre. An endearing asset in any theatre work, it is remarkable in a musical.

The last chance for New Yorkers to qualify to vote in the municipal elections on Nov. 7 will be in the four-day registration period beginning today.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 40 cents a bale up to 5 cents off yesterday. The near October contract showed the best gain.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Oct. 10 -- Though Laos may soon be officially declared neutral in the "cold war," developments are will continue to affect the security of pro-Western South Vietnam and Thailand and therefore will remain of the highest concern to the United States.

THE pleasures of residing in Connecticut were not exactly diminished by last night's engagement between Mayor Robert F. Wagner and Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz. Come Election Day and there's going to be a new zest to commuting.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 10 -- Foreign Minister Jaja Wachuku of Nigeria accused the big powers today of failing dismally to provide world leadership.

Harvard's upset of Cornell last Saturday, largely engineered by Ted Halaby, has earned the honor of Ivy Back of the Week for the Crimson quarterback. Halaby, a 21-year-old senior and younger brother of another celebrated Crimson performer, Sam Halaby, scored his team's two touchdowns and ran Coach John Yovicsin's T formation with efficient poise.
Capital punishment, as provided for in the New York Penal Code, is un-Christian and should be abolished, Protestant lawyers were told yesterday at a special service in Trinity Church.

ONE swallow doesn't make a summer, but one great picture easily makes the day. This was the splendid early still-life from the exhibition of still-life paintings on view at the Mortimer Brandt Gallery, 11 East Fifty-seventh Street.
The Dynamic Management Corporation was fined $400 in Housing Court yesterday for violations in an East Harlem tenement where a 10-month-old baby had been bitten by a rat.

PARIS, Oct. 10 -- A political offensive against the Government and its farm policy collapsed in the National Assembly today at the start of debate on a bill establishing procedures for setting agricultural prices.
LONDON, Oct. 10 -- Uganda, scheduled to become independent a year from now, will be governed by a Parliament elected through universal adult suffrage.
TRENTON, Oct. 10 -- Richard J. Hughes proposed today the construction of a $97,250,000 toll bridge across Delaware Bay that he said would assure a new era of industrial growth in South Jersey.
Prices of long-term United States Government obligations continued to drift downward yesterday in another quiet day in the bond market.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP) -- A Senate subcommittee reported today on its investigation into charges that two Assistant Secretaries of Agriculture had threatened farm groups opposing the Kennedy Administration's farm program in Congress.

SEATTLE, Oct. 10 -- The American Automobile Association demanded today that all highway facilities be made tollfree. It had condoned toll road instruction where traffic needs required it and state funds were at available.
Thirteen international airlines have adopted a statement of policy intended to discourage the carriers from "luring away" one another's employes.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 10 -The proposed merger of the Northern Pacific and Great Northern Railroads possibly is needed more in the interests of Northern Pacific stockholders than of the Great Northern's stockholders, according to Robert S. Macfarlane, president of the Northern Pacific.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Secretary of Commerce Luther H. Hodges allotted today $231,250,000 of Federal highway aid to the states. His action completed the distribution of $925 million for the so-called "A.B.C." program.
Upon a signal from Robert Moses, the first large steel section of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge was put into place yesterday, 300 feet off the Staten Island shore at Fort Wadsworth.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 9 -- Ground was broken today for a $15,000,000 research and office center to be constructed jointly by the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and a Boston industrial development company.

According to The Times of Sept. 30, the United States Information Agency's reporting service listed the concern of the French and German press with the President's speech before the U.N. The French newspapers, according to the agency, "reflected concern that signs of Western flexibility in the approach to negotiations on Germany would be mistaken for weakness and were therefore dangerous."
STRATFORD-ON-AVON, England, Oct 10 -- The Royal Shakespeare Theatre introduced Sir John Gielgud in the title role in "Othello," tonight in the sixth and final production of the season.

In a recent conversation Mr. Khrushchev evolved his own contribution to the science of anthropology. Darwin, he observed, had shown how different species evolved from the primeval swamp.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today favorable September weather increased the prospective volume of 1961 crops nearly 1 per cent above last month's forecast. However, production is expected to be about 3.3 per cent below last year's record.

BOSTON, Oct. 10 (AP) -- A move was opened today to draft Henry Cabot Lodge, former American delegate to the United Nations, to run next year for the Senate seat he once held, but Mr. Lodge disowned it immediately.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- The chief of the United States Weather Bureau said today that man stood on "the threshhold of possible control," of one of nature's most powerful and destructive phenomena -- the hurricane.

Demand for corrugated boxes is now at a record high, but manufacturers' profits continue to be affected by low price levels for their products, Jerome H. Stone, president of the Fibre Box Association, said yesterday.

A one-sided dispute over changes in seniority rules affecting the hiring of longshoremen is brewing in the Port of New York.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -President Nkrumah has sent a second letter to President Kennedy denying that Ghana has become closely indentified with Soviet policies.
Directors of Canadian Javielin, Ltd., yesterday elected as a director Mark J. Millard, a partner in the investment banking firm of Carl M. Loeb, Rhoades Co.

SEOUL, Korea, Oct. 9 -- After five months in power, South Korea's military Government faces a fight on factionalism. In South Korea factionalism is the constant formation within a government of contending cliques based on family or regional ties, age or business connections or the desire for power.
MADISON, Wis., Oct. 10 -Dr. Robert H. Hamlin called today for "thorough government regulation" of voluntary health and welfare agencies through uniform accounting and financial reporting.

BOSTON, Oct. 10 (UPI) -The Boston Bruins and the New York Rangers, the only two teams to miss the Stanley Cup play-offs last season, share the honor of opening the National Hockey League season at Boston Garden tomorrow night.

A prominent scientist told the National Council on the Aging yesterday that shortening the work week to three days would add to the social problems that science had created.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 10 -- The Philco Corporation announced today that it would establish a coast-to-coast chain of dry cleaning and laundry centers within the next five years.

" The Heart Is a Lonely Hunter," Carson McCullers' delicate first novel about a deaf-mute's effect upon a small Southern town, will be filmed next summer by the stage director, Jose Quintero.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- The United States formally recognized today Syria's withdrawal from the United Arab Republic and offered to establish diplomatic relations with her new Government.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- The first Senate report ever published with illustrated covets, according to Government records, came off the press here today. As Congressional documents go, it is expected to be a best-seller.

A., The Chase Manhattan Bank and other investment interests completed arrangements yesterday for the initial financing of a $72,000,000 petrochemical complex. After a slow start, stocks on the New York Stock Exchange picked up speed yesterday and ended with a moderate gain and prices still rising.

The second American opera commissioned under a Ford Foundation grant, Douglas Moore's "Wings of the Dove," will have its world premiere tonight at the City Center in a production by the New York City Opera Company.

A lighthearted look at the contemporary scene in the nation's capital is taken by Russell Baker, a Washington correspondent for this newspaper, in "An American in Washington."
