A member hospital of the United Hospital Fund has begun an experimental pilot project that may make history in patient care for the critically ill.

BRIGHTON, England, Oct. 11 -- The Earl of Home, Britain's Foreign Secretary, declared today that the West had convinced the Soviet Union that it was risking a "head-on collision" and nuclear war with its Berlin policy.

WHEN the American League held its rummage sale a year ago to stock two new teams, the paucity of talent in the grab bag did not go unnoticed by the holier-than-thou guys in the National League. They viewed the offerings with supercilious disdain.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The Defense Department announced today further reinforcement of United States forces in Europe. Units going overseas include an armored cavalry regiment and eleven squadrons of fighter planes.

Although Roger L. Stevens finds himself with more entries on his agenda than any other producer, he has managed to squeeze in another play that aroused his enthusiasm. Newly added to a crowded list of prospects is "Tender Loving Care," which will be done with Alton Wilkes.

No matter what the viewers and television critics have to say about "The Wonderful World of Toys" next month, the special show will find its master of ceremonies speechless. The role will be filled by Harpo Marx, who has found in his long professional career that silence can be lucrative as well as golden.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -President Kennedy dismissed today a Chinese Communist proposal that the United States take the initiative in opening high-level discussions with the Peiping regime.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (UPI) -- Pilots of nineteen airlines have requested labor contract amendments that would allow them to picket any carrier operating with alleged strike breakers, the Air Line Pilots Association announced today.
The Kratter Corporation, a real estate investment company, has acquired a 19 per cent interest in the Canal-Randolph Corporation, it was disclosed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- Following is a statement issued today by President Kennedy on the need for a national plan in mental retardation:

If, as our leaders tell us, we face the possibility of being pulverized by an atomic attack or, if we survive, the probability of poisoning and death by the subsequent radioactivity, would it not be logical that public, organized, government-sponsored programs be instituted at once for the construction of adequate shelters for all, instead of leaving this to the pitiful efforts of individual home owners?

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Oct. 11 (AP) -- President Joaquin Balaguer indicated tonight he might be willing to discuss opposition demands that some members of the Trujlllo family be expelled in the interests of national unity.
RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 11 (UPI) -- Negroes filed suit in Virginia's highest court today in an attempt to force Prince Edward County to reopen and operate its public schools.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 11 -- In a shift comparable to the conversion of Don Holleder in 1955 from an end to a quarterback, Army has moved Joe Blackgrove from quarter to left halfback in the T formation for the football game with Penn State Saturday.

ROME, Oct. 11 -- Jon Douglas, 25 years old, who used to play quarterback for the Stanford football team, and Whitney Reed, 29, from Alameda, Calif., will play for the United States against Italy in the Davis Cup interzone tennis final. The series begins Friday.

The Administrative Council of the City University has temporarily banned speeches by members of the Communist party on any of the city's campuses pending a review of its present policy on such appearances.

BERLIN, Oct. 11 -- Ever since the Communists built their wall in mid-August to split Berlin in two the West Berlin police have patrolled the borders with East Berlin and with the surrounding East German territory.
A total of 30,588 New Yorkers went to polling places yesterday on the first day of registration for the municipal elections on Nov. 7.

A Republican lawyer has complained to the Queens District Attorney that his children -- aged 13, 8 and 7 -- have received letters soliciting their votes for Paul R. Screvane, Democratic candidate for Council President.
BAMBERG, Germany, Oct. 11 (AP) -- A brigadier general and a colonel were identified today as two of the six victims of the crash of a United States Army helicopter yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The Administration has developed doubts about the wisdom of a tax increase next year to balance the budget.
Recent events in southern Mississippi raise new and most disturbing questions about the application of criminal justice there as well as about race relations.

The American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations decided yesterday to take in local unions that break away from the International Brotherhood of Teamsters. The locals would become separate affiliates.

Directors of the M.A. Hanna Company approved yesterday a wide-ranging simplification of the ownership and management of the company's interests, extending into the iron ore, steel, coal and shipping industries, and announced a new dividend policy.
CHICAGO, Oct. 11 -- Dr. Albert V. Crewe, 34-year-old Professor of Physics at the University of Chicago, was appointed director of the Argonne National Laboratory today.

NEW CITY, N.Y., Oct. 11 -- Billy Farrell of Baltusrol and Mrs. Gordon Park of Glen Ridge upset the defenders in the first round of the seventh annual Jack Moone Memorial mixed Scotch open golf tournament at the Dellwood Country Club today.
Detailed plans for a middle-income cooperative housing development in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn were announced yesterday.

PARIS, Oct. 11 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, who has been conferring with government leaders of Western Europe, issued an optimistic report today on the condition of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board has ordered the commercial-pilot rating of Air Force Lieut. Raymond Jolly suspended for sixty days effective next Monday, for low flying over the Columbus, Ohio, area on April 30, 1960.
Following is a transcript of President Kennedy's news conference yesterday in Washington as recorded by The New York Times:
An Eastern College Athletic Conference committee made three recommendations yesterday "to remove the atmosphere of professional gambling from intercollegiate athletics."

Among those who serve at dog shows without pay or particular praise are the stewards. They are men and women who free the judges of the mechanics of ring operation. They pay their own traveling expenses and in return derive satisfaction from service, have fun and get a free admission ticket and an occasional free meal.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (UPI) -- The Public Health Service is strongly recommending influenza shots for pregnant women, persons over 65 years of age and those with chronic ailments as a precaution against an expected increase in cases this fall and winter.
The curious saga of a short book called Reality in Advertising continues to confound Madison Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Oct. 4:
Governor Rockefeller said yesterday he was "somewhat embarrassed" by the lack of efficient leadership in the Republican party in the city.
CHICAGO, Oct. 11 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
Reports trickling down from the jazz festival at Newport last July told of a great success scored by a singer who had appeared, seemingly, out of the blue. Her name was Carol Sloane.
BERLIN, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Despite the tension here and the border incidents, West Berlin's 9,000 hotel rooms are booked solid for the week-end.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- The Treasury announced today that it would borrow $100,000,000 of new cash in next Monday's sale of its regular weekly bills. The additional amount would be raised by enlarging the 182-day issue, making it $600,000,000.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- A national effort to discover the causes, cure and means of prevention of mental retardation was urged today by President Kennedy.
EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Oct. 11 -- Air Force Maj. Robert M. White flew the X-15 rocket plane more than forty miles above the earth today in a record ride to the threshold of space.

City Investigation Commissioner Louis I. Kaplan refused yesterday for the second time to give Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz information about alleged bid-rigging in Board of Education plumbing contracts. Mr. Lefkowitz threatened legal action against the Commissioner.

After a twelve-hour bus trip that brought him from Cleveland to New York yesterday, Cecil Shorts was inclined to regard his ten-round main event against Jorge Jose Fernandez in Madison Square Garden Saturday night as light exercise.

The committee planning Dutch Treat dinners preceding the Legal Aid Society's two theatre parties is headed by Mrs. Henry Harfield of 558 East Eighty-seventh Street. Both dinners will be at the Columbia University Club.
America, national Jesuit weekly, presents a scathing denunciation of the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer film "King of Kings" in its current issue.
CHICAGO, Oct. 11 (AP) -- An electronics manufacturer declared today his industry was being threatened through increasing Government ownership of patents.
A $2,050,000 low-rent housing project, designed to "disappear" into the suburban landscape, will be started in the Town of Greenburgh, N.Y., on Saturday by Governor Rockefeller.

Several independent surveys indicated yesterday that 1,000,000 to 1,250,000 persons watched all or most of Tuesday night's television discussion of city campaign issues by Mayor Wagner and Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz.

The Regional Plan Association predicts that all the land within fifty miles of Times Square will be built up in twenty-five years if present development trends continue. It foresees a "spread-city," swallowing suburbs and exurbs and obliterating almost every sizable spot of green in a 7,000-square-mile stretch of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
SOMETIMES the strongest tournament fields are encountered in games that do not have official championship rating and in clubs that are not known primarily as bridge clubs.
MIAMI, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk called tonight for a new, flexible trade law to give the United States more leeway to deal with the changing international economic situation.

BRIGHTON, England, Oct. 11 -- The Conservative party Conference adopted by a large majority today a resolution asking the Government for quick action on "the uncontrolled number of immigrants" were entering Britain.

The approval of two new piers on the Brooklyn waterfront was voted yesterday by the Commissioners of the Port of New York Authority at their regular monthly meeting. The new piers and related facilities will cost $11,144,900.
Mayor Wagner and Deputy Mayor Paul R. Screvane received Columbus Day medals yesterday from the Italian Consul General in a brief ceremony at City Hall.
Joseph Gallo, one of the thirteen gangsters rounded up by Brooklyn detectives on Tuesday, denied yesterday that the gang had declared war on a rival faction in the Brooklyn underworld.
Irving Ben Cooper was sworn in yesterday for an interim term as a Federal judge in the Southern District of New York. He will serve in this capacity until the Senate can vote on his appointment.

For the first time in two years, Yale's football team is an underdog. Word from New Haven yesterday listed the Bulldogs as short-enders for the game with Columbia at Yale Bowl this week. In recent years the Lion has been little more than soft touch for the strong sons of Eli.

JAMES Alward Van Fleet, the 69-year-old retired general who was named by President Kennedy yesterday to help train guerrilla fighters and check on the combat readiness of the country's reserves, has probably not kept all of the bounce and burliness that marked his frequent frontline appearances in Korea.
We must face our enemies calmly and with concern for "the long future of our race" -- so you state our position in your recent editorial. It is well stated.
The Jones and Laughlin Steel Corporation reported yesterday that third-quarter earnings were nearly three times those in the 1960 period on a 19 per cent increase in sales.

The nation's inventories of gasoline increased 626,000 barrels in the week ended last Friday, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, total stocks were 185,110,000 barrels, compared with 184,484,000 a week earlier and 188,642,000 a year ago.

Manufacturers and buyers of textile machinery agreed yesterday that President Kennedy's revision of the depreciation schedule on textile facilities would help considerably to spur orders for new machinery.
NEW HAVEN, Oct. 11 -- The three trustees attempting to reorganize the New Haven Railroad will receive the maximum annual compensation set by the Interstate Commerce Commission.
The head of the space agency said yesterday that an initial experiment to test the idea of guiding a satellite to rendezvous with another in orbit would be conducted by next July.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) -- A White House spokesman contended today that Senator Margaret Chase Smith, Republican of Maine, did not know what she was talking about in charging that the Administration had attempted to steer a rifles contract to a West Virginia company.

ACCRA, Ghana, Oct. 11 -Manpower problems in Ghana are hampering the country's economic development plans, according to a Ford Foundation survey team. The team's recommendations are under consideration by Ghana's Government.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -The United States' first criterion in giving foreign aid is the recipient's desire to maintain national independence, President Kennedy said today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (UPI) -- Spokesmen for the natural gas industry told the Federal Power Commission today that there was only enough discovered and deliverable natural gas in the United States to last ten to thirteen years at present consumer demand levels.
A word on the insanity of bomb shelters, fall-out shelters or whatever you choose to name the current homestead necessity. The fantasy is twofold.

Sherluck, Jacob Sher's stakes colt, has a good luck charm and his name is Braulio Baeza. In the $54,600 Lawrence Realization at Aqueduct yesterday Sherluck was the winner by a length and a quarter over Ambiopoise, and Ambiopoise had the surprising margin of eight lengths over the heavily favored Carry Back.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Oct. 11 -- The General Assembly's Budgetary Committee recommended today that the new six-story library that is being completed at the United Nations headquarters be named after the late Dag Hammarskjold.
A taxicab driver and a midtown jeweler were under arrest yesterday in thefts totaling at least $200,000 in jewelry and furs, principally from fares at piers and airports.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -President Kennedy said today that a month of quiet talks between the United States and the Russians had given him no hope of an early or easy solution in Berlin and Germany.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- Thus far the critics of President Kennedy's efforts to find a basis of negotiation with the Soviet Union on West Berlin have displayed the fatal weakness of having no constructive alternative to propose. Their common demand that he "stand pat," and that anything less is "appeasement," would be a constructive alternative if the Berlin situation were desirable to the West, or even to the United States, to maintain.
A $150,000 exhibition of color lithography was opened yesterday by Mayor Wagner at Grand Central Terminal.

A two-year contract was signed yesterday by the Sugar Workers Council of the International Longshoremen's Association and the American Sugar Refining Company. It covers 800 employes in the Brooklyn plant and 600 in Philadelphia.

The president and two directors of the Chicago and Eastern Illinois Railroad Company have sold all of their common stock in the railroad. This was revealed yesterday in the latest report of the New York Stock Exchange on dealings by directors, officers and large stockholders of listed companies.

Unpredictable events often make economists change their minds and make economics a lively venture. That was suggested by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York in its latest monthly review when it spoke of "special influences" that slowed the advance of the economy.

DETROIT, Oct. 11 -- The Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile Workers reached a new three-year national agreement tonight. Both Walter P. Reuther, presi dent of the auto union, and Malcolm L. Denise, vice president of labor relations for Ford, said they hoped the company would be able to resume operations by Monday.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 11 -- Following are excerpts from the speech today in the General Assembly by Eric H. Louw, South Africa's Minister of External Affairs:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -President Kennedy announced today a new schedule of depreciation on textile machinery, amounting to a tax concession.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 11 -- A Federal judge ruled today that procedures for nominating and electing international officers of the United Steelworkers of America were illegal.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 11 -- Theatre owners have scored a triumph in a fight with Warner Brothers over the movie, "Fanny." The dispute is whether the film is suitable for a children's audience.
The New York City Opera Company's initial performance on Saturday of its new production of "Madama Butterfly" has been chosen by the Women's Guild of the New York City Opera as its autumn benefit.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed unchanged to 90 cents a bale off yesterday. The far months showed the most weakness.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, President Kennedy's military representative, will go to South Vietnam this week to study means of helping that country against attacks by Communist guerrillas.
NORWALK, Conn., Oct. 11 -- The State Highway Department disclosed its plans today for relocating the new multi-lane Route 7, which ends in this city.
The Government said yesterday that if Dr. Hans Hirschfeld, a former aide to Mayor Willy Brandt of West Berlin, came to this country, he could not be guaranteed immunity from criminal prosecution.
DAMASCUS, Syria, Oct. 11 -- The new Syrian Government has proposed a pan-Arab federation to be called the United Arab States.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 11 -- The Great Northern Railway's earnings picture "is less than bright," according to John M. Budd, president.
Rails rumbled ahead in yesterday's session of the New York Stock Exchange and touched the highest level in The New York Times average since Sept. 1, 1959.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Former President and Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower left Walter Reed Army Medical Center today after a nearly twenty-four-hour stay for their annual check-ups.
RAMSEY, N.J., Oct. 11 -James P. Mitchell cited Federal statistics tonight to paint a dismal picture of the loss of 78,000 manufacturing jobs in New Jersey in the last six years.

May I add a warning to the excellent letter from Arthur Springer (Oct. 3) on the effect of civil defense? This speeded-up program which, as he says, is "developing all the illusions of any heresy born of fear," deliberately and officially sets the stage for serious neuroses in our children.
Communist China has made a major concession in acknowledging Nepal's claim to the peak of Mount Everest, a move that completes the long process of defining their mutual boundaries.
Sales and earnings of the Allied Chemical Corporation declined slightly for the quarter and nine months ended on Sept. 30, Kerby H. Fisk, chairman, reported yesterday.
The Greater New York Fund yesterday elected Dale E. Sharp president and Hermann G. Place chairman of the board.

Edward Schwartz, realty investor and builder, has resold the property at 16 to 22 Avenue A, southeast corner of Second Street, to the 16-22 Avenue A Corporation, Morris Schertz, president. The property consists of four apartment and store buildings on a plot 102 by 89 feet.

Production of electric power dipped to 15,035,000,000 kilowatt-hours in the week ended Saturday from 15,340,000,000 the preceding week, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. Output totaled 14,107,000,000 kilowatt-hours in the same week last year.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 11 -- Yale University will hold a two-day convocation, beginning Friday, on financial support of higher education in this country. More than 1,000 Yale alumni and their wives will take part.

Directors of the Kayser-Roth Corporation declared yesterday an extra 2 per cent stock dividend, a year-end extra cash dividend of 10 cents a share and the regular 10-cent quarterly dividend on the common stock.

A half-page advertisement appeared in The New York Times Wednesday morning expressing faith that the United States would survive despite the present dangers and would remain whole and free. "I Am Not Afraid," it said.
Two new films will open at local theatres today.
Columbia University yesterday announced the establishment of a Latin-American Institute.

DETROIT, Thursday, Oct. 12 -- The executive board of the United Automobile Workers ordered a new vote today by members of Local 72 in Kenosha, Wis., on the profit-sharing agreement with the American Motors Corporation.

PARIS, Oct. 11 -- The Shah of Iran, Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, and his wife, Queen Farah, arrived here today for a three-day state visit, the first state visit to France by an Iranian sovereign in seventy-five years.

The New York and American Stock Exchanges reported yesterday, pursuant to the Securities and Exchange Act of 1934, the following changes in the holdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed companies:
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Oct. 11 (UPI) -- The Soviet Embassy here accused the Netherlands today of having kidnapped Aleksei Golub, a Soviet scientist, and of having tried to kidnap his wife.
The Wagner administration concentrated its heaviest fire on Governor Rockefeller yesterday as it fought Republican critics on three fronts.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Striking deck officers voted tonight to end a fourteen-day West Coast maritime strike. They began notifying shipowners that the forty-four tied-up ships would be manned again tomorrow.

Sponsors have been announced for a theatre party to be given for the benefit of the Margaret Sanger Research Bureau. It will take place at the Oct. 25 preview performance of "Write Me a Murder" by Frederick Knott. The play will open the next night at the Belasco Theatre, with Kim Hunter and James Donald in the leading roles.

QUICK desserts that are warm or cold or a combination of warm and cold ingredients are especially good during fall days. The serving temperature of such desserts may be varied to suit the rest of the menu or the weather.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -President Kennedy strongly defended his national security policies at his news conference today. But he avoided several opportunities to hit back at Republican critics.
The minimum cost of providing essential facilities for the metropolitan region by 1985 was set at $170,000,000,000 yesterday.

Paul Hornung of the Green Bay Packers went on the season's biggest scoring spree Sunday when he collected 33 points in the Packers' 45-7 rout of the Baltimore Colts. He scored four touchdowns, 6 extra points and a field goal.

LYTHAM-ST. ANNES, England, Oct. 11 (UPI) -- The United States team toured the Royal Lytham and St. Annes golf course today with scores in the middle 70's. Strong winds and bright sunshine prevailed over the layout where the 1961 Ryder Cup tournament will be played on Friday and Saturday.

The United States may be jeopardizing its chances of space supremacy by failing to devote sufficient effort to the use of nuclear energy for rocket propulsion, a speaker told the American Rocket Society yesterday.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 11 -The United States was reliably reported today to have decided that a Western foreign ministers' conference on the Berlin and German problems at this time would be "premature."

" LOVE SONG TO THE PLAINS,"* by Mari Sandoz, is a splendid lot of lore about the American land that slopes from the Mississippi to the Rockies, the country of Spaniards in clanking armor, Indian first families dispossessed, warriors, cattlemen, homesteaders, oilmen and characters out of the novels of Willa Cather.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 11 -- Pessimism over the choice of a temporary successor to Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold increased tonight.
Police Commissioner Michael J. Murphy denounced the leadership of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association yesterday for having endorsed Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz for Mayor.
Mayor Wagner yesterday announced the start of a privately financed study on bail procedures in the Court of Special Sessions and the Magistrates Felony Court.

The twenty-goal Aiken (S.C.) polo team will play a benefit match at 3 P.M. Sunday against twenty-two-goal Circle F of Dallas at the Meadow Brook Club, Jericho, L.I. Proceeds will aid the Day Camp for Hndicapped Children opened by the Human Resources Foundation last summer.
DUBLIN, Oct. 11 -- The Irish Republic's new Parliament met today and elected Sean Lemass Prime Minister.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Oct. 11 -- Premier David Ben-Gurion declared in the Knesset today that Israel would not agree to the repatriation of the Arab refugees.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (UPI) Irvin C. Scarbeck testified today that he had broken down and confessed "everything" to save his 22-year-old Polish mistress from a threatened prison term in West Germany.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 11 (UPI) -- Walt Alston was signed today to a new one-year contract to manage the Los Angeles Dodgers despite his failure to win the National League pennant with the club that had been ranked as the preseason favorite.

The eighth annual art show of the Junior Committee of the South Brooklyn Neighborhood Houses will open tomorrow night at Grace Protestant Episcopal Church, Grace Court and Hicks Street, in Brooklyn Heights.

McCOMB, Miss., Oct. 11 (UPI) -- Two young white men who said they were reporters were dragged from their car by a white man and beaten today as they drove alongside a group of Negroes making an antisegregation march.
ORLANDO, Fla., Oct. 11 (AP) -- A Federal grand jury returned a sixteen-count indictment today against James R. Hoffa, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, Oct. 11 -- The parliamentary elections for which the Turks have waited seventeen months are only four days off.

Lloyd Merwin, who was elected president of the Fibre Box Association yesterday, said that there was a possibility that prices of corrugated boxes would be raised again around the start of the next year. He cited an "unusually high" rate of demand for the containers, which are used to pack and ship a wide variety of industrial goods.
NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 11 -- A new era began today on the creeping Rajasthan Desert, which occupies nearly 11 per cent of the area of India.

DALLAS, Tex., Oct. 11 (UPI) -- House Speaker Sam Rayburn caught pneumonia today and sank into a coma. But within hours and with the help of oxygen, a breathing machine and antibiotic drugs he rallied and regained consciousness.
An $800,000 drive for a new aerophysics laboratory at New York University's Daniel Guggenheim School of Aeronautics was announced today.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Oct. 11 (AP) -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk said today the United States was consulting with the other American republics on the problem of Cuba.

LONDON, Oct. 11 -- Britain had another deficit in her balance of payments on current account during the first half of this year but it was smaller than those registered in the two preceding six-month periods. In a white paper published today, Britain's Treasury said that the deficit for the first half of this year amounted to u83,000,000 ($232,400,000).

THE much awaited "David Brinkley's Journal" began last night in an engagingly low-pressure and sardonic tone. Two out of three items covered on the half-hour, seen on tape and film over Channel 4, were amusing winners.

BOSTON, Oct. 11 -- A portrait of a royal child-bride by Van Dyck, at once elegant and appealing, heads a list of nine paintings recently presented to the Boston Museum of Fine Arts. The collection is valued at $500,000.
SYRACUSE, Oct. 11 (AP) -Farmers are subsidizing the American consumer at a rate ranging to $16,000,000,000 a rear, a farm cooperative leader laid here today.
The students of Walton High School, the Bronx, who decided last December to "adopt" a remote village in the Province of Punjab, India, have raised $1,800 for its people.

You published on Oct. 3 a letter from Arthur Springer which sharply criticized civil defense programs. They were characterized as promoting a religion of personal survival from which one loses his motivation to see that a nuclear war never occurs.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -President Kennedy said today he planned to keep out of any contest over the choice of a Speaker of the House if Representative Sam Rayburn is unable to resume the post next year.

TO the frequently posed question, "And what do you do?" Mrs. Richard Tucker replies: "I cook." And, in response to the surprised expression of one who expects the answer to be "I sing," or "I paint," she adds: "What's more, I cook as well as my husband sings."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (UPI) -- The National Geographic Society reported today that the British Parliament might have delayed the invention of the airplane for sixty years.
ATHENS, Oct. 11 -- Greece warned Bulgaria today that if she executed the sexton of the Greek Embassy chapel in Sofia it would be regarded as a "hostile action."

Additional jet service at Newark Airport was authorized yesterday by the Port of New York Authority. At their monthly meeting, the commissioners granted Trans World Airlines permission to make a single jet arrival and departure daily.
