JACKSON, Fla., Oct. 11 -- Five hundred delegates to the annual convention of the Propeller Club of the United States began today an examination of the state of the shipping industry, its ills and its prospects for the future.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Oct. 11 -- The integration of a British-built turboprop all-cargo aircraft with the domestic-freight network of the Air Force Logistics Command was demonstrated today.
Three young American singers have been chosen as winners of the twentieth annual Marian Anderson Scholarships, following auditions attended by 147 contestants in Philadelphia last week.
A minor landmark is disappearing from Grand Army Plaza at Fifth Avenue and Sixtieth Street.
CLUTTER and breakage are problems in any home. Often the stakes are treasured collections. The solution can be a shadow box.
PENNS GROVE, N.J., Oct 11 -- Richard J. Hughes proposed a state constitutional amendment today to assure continued low property tax assessment for farmers.
EVER hear of the power of a good woman? John Patrick has rediscovered it in a grimly whimsical little effort called "Everybody Loves Opal," which opened last night at the Longacre.
Park Commissioner Newbold Morris asked the City Planning Commission yesterday to add $684,429 to its proposed 1962 capital budget allocation of $52,959,248 for park improvements.
LONDON, Oct 11 -- The decline in the stock market prices gathered momentum here today. Buying was further inhibited by some pessimistic company statements.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) -- An official of the Norfolk and Western Railway testified today that improvements costing $35,700,000 were planned in a proposed consolidation of N. W. with two other railroads.

There is today unlimited wealth of audible and visible information at hand about what goes on here, there and everywhere. One would have to go to some trouble to remain long ignorant of the latest events in Europe, Asia, Chicago, Washington or the more remote sections of Long Island, to mention but a few localities that can and do make news.

Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa, Citizens party candidate for Mayor, charged yesterday that the Transit Authority sought to buy 1,00 new subway cars on long-term credit as "an excuse to extend its life beyond June 1, 1961, the termination date of its ten-year lease."

The Peoria Public Building Commission, Ill., borrowed $4,500,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance public building construction. The money was raised on serial bonds secured by lease rentals to be financed by municipal tax appropriations.
The abstract painter Willem de Kooning could not appear in court to answer an assault charge, his lawyer said yesterday, because he must shut himself off from society during his work periods.
CARPET tiles are a new device for do-it-yourself carting.

Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz carried his Republican mayoral campaign into the West Thirty-fourth Street shopping area last night, appealing to package-laden housewives and homeward-bound office workers.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 12 -- David J. McDonald's opponent in 1957 for the presidency of the United Steelworkers of America said today he would seek to void Mr. McDonald's unopposed re-election this year.
MIAMI BEACH, Oct. 12 (AP) -- The United Church Women, with membership drawn from more than thirty denominations, today elected Mrs. Theodore F. Wallace of Kansas City president for three years.
THANKS to the resourcefulness of readers, the discussion of woolly prose can be continued today, fortified with some ironic examples.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Oct. 12 -- Cornelius (Glit) Shields Jr. sailed Aileen to victory today in the annual Lay-Up Regatta of the International Class as a fleet of thirty-four raced off the Larchmont Yacht Club.

Andy Bathgate scored three goals and was credited with an assist last night as the New York Rangers defeated the Boston Bruins, 6 -- 3, before 14,065 fans. It was the largest opening-night crowd for a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden since 1949.

FORT BRAGG, N.C., Oct. 12 -- President Kennedy is now learning what many Presidents have learned before him: that nothing restores a man's confidence and perspective more quickly than a day away from the contention of Washington among the simpler people of the nation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- Every United States President in time of crisis has had to seek an equilibrium between the reality of opinion and the reality of power. President Kennedy set out about nine months ago with strong hopes of what might be accomplished through the moral force of world opinion.
DETROIT, Oct. 12 -- The National Ford Council of the United Automobile Workers overwhelmingly approved today the agreement reached last night with the company.
Supporters of the work of the Children's Village in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., have arranged a theatre party at the Nov. 16 performance of "Sail Away" at the Broadhurst Theatre.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 12 -- Foreign Minister Heinrich von Brentano indicated today that West Germany was prepared to talk with Communist East Germany under specific, limited conditions.

LYTHAM-ST. ANNES, England, Oct. 12 (AP) -- Jerry Barber, captain of the United States Ryder Cup golf team, left himself off tomorrow's opening foursomes against Britain -- and put the spotlight on Arnold Palmer.
The election of Peter Black and Arthur W. Gilbart as vice presidents of the Freeport Sulphur Company was announced yesterday by Langbourne M. Williams, chairman.
Lieut. Gen. Bernard A. Schriever said yesterday that a detailed plan for accelerating work on the Dyna-soar manned space glider would be put before the Defense Department within thirty days.
Governors of the American Stock Exchange appointed yesterday a committee composed of some of the most prominent Wall Street figures to make a thorough study of the organization.

In recent weeks twenty-two interviewers from the Group Attitudes Corporation, a subsidiary of Hill Knowlton, Inc., have been traveling around the country visiting 180 prominent educators, religious leaders, editors, business men and Government officials.
A Republican spokesman said yesterday that the Democrats had accepted advertising from many of the same companies that had advertised in the state Republicans' 1961 yearbook.
A three-dimensional view of a portion of Staten Island, designed to show how Richmondtown probably looked two centuries ago, will be on display today at the Cooper Union Museum.
The New York Knickerbockers will make their season debut in Madison Square Garden tonight when they face the College All-Stars in the tenth annual Free Milk Fund for Babies game.
The Wollman Memorial skating rink, at times giving a surface imitation of a swimming pool, opened yesterday in Central Park for its eleventh season.
HONG KONG, Oct. 12 -- Nepal and Communist China have agreed that the boundary line between their two countries "runs through" Mount Everest.
TUNIS, Oct. 12 -- A three-day meeting of the rebel Algerian Provisional Government here as been followed by what appears to be a nationalist campaign for renewed peace negotiations with France.
MADISON, N.J., Oct. 12 -- Dr. Robert Fisher Oxnam was installed this afternoon as the eighth president of Drew University, a ninety-four-year-old Methodist institution.

Following are the texts of three documents issued yesterday by William L. Pfeiffer, treasurer of the Republican State Committee, dealing with Democratic party fund-raising practices. They are a statement by Mr. Pfeiffer, a table attached to his statement and a copy of a letter from Michael H. Prendergast, chairman of the Democratic State Committee, to companies that advertised in the Republican State Yearbook for 1961:
PARIS, Oct. 12 -- A renewal of the peace talks between France and the Algerian rebels may take place in complete secrecy, it was hinted here today.
TUNIS, Oct. 12 -- President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia threatened today to reopen the "battle of Bizerte" if France would not agree to evacuate her air and naval base there.

In the late Thirties, Ralph Houk used to dream that some day he might earn as much as $400 a month in organized baseball. Yesterday he signed a contract to manage the Yankees through the next two years for an annual salary estimated at $50,000 -- a little more than $4,000 a month.

William W. Callahan was appointed vice president of the Homart Development Company, a wholly owned subsidiary of Sears, Roebuck Co. He had been promotion director of the Hillsdale Shopping Center in San Mateo, Calif. Homart owns and builds shopping centers that include a Sears department store.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 12 (AP) -- The Honolulu Oil Corporation proceeded today with plans for a $362,000,000 sale of assets to two other petroleum companies after a Federal judge refused to halt dissolution of the company.
CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Oct. 12 -- President Kennedy said today it was a "dangerous illusion" to believe that "we shall soon meet total victory or total defeat" in the global struggle with communism.

An offering of 120,000 shares of Sterling Seal Company's common stock at $12.50 a share will be made today by Fulton, Reid Co., Inc., and Walston Co., Inc. Of this 20,000 shares are being sold by the company and the rest by stockholders.
Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower told a national television audience last night that if he were in office he would not debate a political rival on television.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 12 -- Foreign Minister Eric H. Louw of South Africa bitterly reproached the United States today for having failed to defend him from a vote of censure by the General Assembly.
WARSAW, Oct. 12 -- The Polish People's Army declared today that it possessed "defensive rocket weapons."
Mayor Wagner asked Governor Rockefeller yesterday to admit Democratic legislators to the Albany hearings on the next state budget or "explain why they are being excluded."
A massive city-state testing program will begin this month as part of an evaluation of the instructional quality of the city school system.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (UPI) -- Irvin C. Scarbeck's attorney listened to a tape recording of the former diplomat's alleged confession today. He said afterward the tape might have been shortened.
The Rockefeller Foundation appropriated almost $33,000,000 in grants in 1960, with increased emphasis on world-wide aid for the advancement of knowledge.
HIGHLAND PARK, Ill., Oct. 12 -- Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy deplored tonight "the great variation" in sentences handed down by Federal judges.
Verne O. Gehringer, purchasing agent for San Diego County, Calif., was elected president of the National Institute of Governmental Purchasing Agents at its annual meeting in New York.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Oct. 12 -- An American Senatorial delegation that had been apprehensive about Congolese political leadership left here today deeply impressed with Premier Cyrille Adoula. The three visiting Senators consider him perhaps the ablest political leader they have met on a tour of Africa that has included meetings with Tanganyika's Julius Nyerere and with Kenya's Jomo Kenyatta, men far better known as African leaders.

ASK any Mount Holyoke College student or alumna out Deacon Porter's hat and basis likely to reply, "Oh yes, its delicious." Deacon Porter's dish is a steamed, spicy pudding that is served regularly at Mount Holyoke, the oldest woman's college in this country.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- The National Labor Relations Board made a decision today that appeared to widen its authority over labor representation questions involving seamen working on American operated ships of foreign registry.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (UPI) -- The Western Maryland Railway Company, which was expected to oppose a proposed four-way railroad consolidation, supported the plan today after receiving a promise that its freight routes would not experience "disastrous losses."
Approval of a proposed State Constitutional amendment providing for a reorganization of the judiciary was urged yesterday by the Citizens Union, a nonpartisan civic organization.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP) -- The appointment of seven new members to the Advisory Committee on the United States National Health Survey was announced today by Surgeon General Luther L. Terry.

The National Broadcasting Company announced yesterday that Jack Paar would take final leave of his late evening television show on March 30 and re-emerge next fall as the star a weekly program in prime evening time.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 12 -- A simple, inexpensive test that detects one important cause of mental retardation in time to permit effective treatment was described to the eleventh annual convention of the National Association for Retarded Children here today.

DETROIT, Oct. 12 (UPI) -- The board chairman of General Motors, Frederic G. Donner, said tonight charges that the corporation had conspired to prevent sale of Chevrolet cars through Southern California discount houses were "without foundation."
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Oct. 12 -- The Government ordered two Soviet Embassy attaches today to leave the country.
The Cuban Revolutionary Council, which staged unsucessful April 17 invasion of Cuba, announced the addition of fourteen new members yesterday. Provisions made for the naming of a fifteen new member.

Standard Poor's Corporation, century-old statistical and securities-rating organization, is going to "go public." It is understood that the company, in conjunction with its bankers, is drawing up a registration statement, which it is expected to file soon with the Securities and Exchange Commission preparatory to public sale of its securities.

LONDON, Oct. 12 (UPI) -- Premier Kassim's "final offer" was that the Iraq Petroleum Company should relinquish 90 per cent of the group's concession area forthwith and that the company should grant new terms more favorable to the Government than the existing 50-50 arrangement covering their production operations, a company statement said today.
Off Off Broadway is in orbit once again. A new season finds the coffeehouses and theatre cafes still way, way out and continuing to expand up and down Greenwich Village.
CHICAGO, Oct. 12 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

The Midgley Steel Products Corporation, an affiliate of Igoe Brothers, Inc., appliance and hardware dealers, has sold the warehouse on Fifty-first Avenue, between Seventy-second Street and Seventy-second Place in Woodside, Queens.

A Flushing inn has canceled a reservation for a lecture tonight by Dr. Cheddi B. Jagan, the controversial. Prime Minister of British Guiana, but a new site has been found. The inn management said yesterday the cancellation had been made under "community pressure."

ROME, Oct. 12 -- Jon Douglas, a 25-year-old former Stanford quarterback, a Marine corporal and the sixth-ranked tennis player in the United States, will meet Fausto Gardini, 32, six times national champion of Italy, in the first match of the Davis Cup interzone final tomorrow.
DETROIT, Oct. 12 (UPI) -- Charles E. Botz, a former accounts payable clerk for Ternstedt Division of the General Motors Corporation, was arrested today in an $89,000 shortage in his accounts.
Ralph Ursillo, a halfback from Englewood, N.J., was named captain of the Columbia lightweight varsity football squad yesterday. He succeeded Ed McCreedy of New York, who was graduated last June.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 12 -- A Federal grand jury indicted the General Motors Corporation today on charges of having conspired to prevent the sale of Chevrolet cars through discount houses in Southern California.
A device that enables a computer to give oral replies to inquiries from hundreds of remote points was introduced yesterday by the Remington Rand UNIVAC division of the Sperry Rand Corporation.

The sixteen-story, air-conditioned apartment house at 105 West Thirteenth Street, northwest corner of the Avenue of the Americas (Sixth Avenue), has been sold by Greenwich Towers Associates, the builder. It was completed about three months ago and is one of the latest to join the growing list of new luxury apartments in Greenwich Village.
Bank clearings in the twenty-six leading cities of the nation totaled $27,026,888,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, Dun Bradstreet, Inc. reported yesterday.

Nickel Boy discovered yesterday what he had been searching for all year -- the winner's circle. The 6-year-old who races for Max Gluck's Elmendorf Farm took the mile-and-sixteenth Manhattan Handicap at Aqueduct, beating his nearest rival, Gustave Ring's Troubadour III, by two lengths.

MOSCOW, Oct. 12 -- The Moscow radio asserted today that Washington had "openly aggressive" plans to send troops to South Vietnam. It declared that such a step could "seriously complicate the situation in that part of the world."

LINDEN, N.J., Oct. 12 -- Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. and six Democratic candidates were ordered away from the gates of two industrial plants here this morning while they were distributing campaign literature.

ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Oct. 12 (AP) -- President Moise Tshomhe of Katanga Province is ready to sign a permanent ceasefire agreement with the United Nations, a semi-official statement in an Elisabethville newspaper said today.

Fred Hutchinson, who led the Cincinnati Reds to their National League pennant victory, was unanimously selected yesterday as the league's manager of the year by United Press International's board of thirty-six experts.

DALLAS, Oct. 12 -- The National Bowling League, one of the most expensive experiments in the history of professional sports, got off to a fair start at the Bronco Bowl tonight. In the premiere performance of this nation-wide ten-team league, the Dallas Broncos met the New York Gladiators before about 2,000 persons.

The Civil Aeronautics has scheduled a meeting Washington today to help complaint of New York Air against a C.A.B. proposal would reduce the helico airline's $2,623,000 annual subsidy by about $623,000.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (UPI) -- United Press International described today as "unjust, arbitrary, capricious and unlawfull" the Federal Communications Commission's proposed new schedule of prices for leased teleprinter and telephoto services.

LAS VEGAS, Nov., Oct. 12 (UPI) -- Mickey Wright capped a four-under par 67 with an 80-foot chip shot on the eighteenth hole to take a five-stroke lead today in the opening round of the $15,000 Ladies' Professioinal Golfers Association tournament.

In his recent speech General Franco stated, among other things: "The foresight and arrangements of our foreign policy do not need revision. It suffices to point out that the main axis of this policy lies in the Iberian bloc and in the treaties with the United States of America, and presently constitutes one of the most solid guarantees for the defense of Europe, and point of support and liaison with the Western nations."
Prime Minister Ibrahim Abboud of the Republic of the Sudan arrived here yesterday from Chicago on his eleven-day state visit to this country.
Three servicemen and their families face eviction from trailer homes in the Bergen Beach section of Brooklyn, rimming Jamaica Bay.
ST. STEPHENS, N.B., Oct. 12 -- With cold weather continuing to avoid southeastern New Brunswick, woodcock shooting is still distinctly not what it should be at this time of the year.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Oct. 12 -- Three African chiefs who attended the opening here today of a two-day meeting of twenty-one chiefs from various parts of Southern Rhodesia blamed African nationalists for having caused unrest in native reserves.
Cotton futures prices declined 5 to 60 cents a bale yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. The near months were weakest.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 12 (AP) -- A lung cancer sufferer who lost a $1,250,000 damage suit against a tobacco company in Federal court at Pittsburgh won a new trial today.

Retailing, aircraft and domestic oil stocks stood above the ruck in yesterday's session of the New York Stock Exchange. With the banks closed for Columbus Day, volume held up better than might have been expected but areas of interest were restricted.

Sixty-seven members of the U.N. General Assembly have voted to censure Foreign Minister Eric H. Louw of South Africa for what they called an "insulting" and "racist" speech. South Africa itself was the only dissenter. The United States was among the twenty-nine members who either abstained or did not participate in the vote.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 12 -- The nation's best 4-year-old and 5-year-old trotters will race tomorrow night at Roosevelt Raceway in the thirteenth United States Harness Writers' Trot. The distance will be a mile and a quarter.
David Merrick has acquired two more British productions and plans to present them on Broadway next season.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- The Pentagon moved today to make its new long-range air and ground striking force ready for combat operations by the end of the year.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 12 -- U Thant, the Burmese diplomat who is the leading candidate for Acting Secretary General, has drawn up a list of five high-ranking United Nations officials whom he proposes to name as his principal assistants.

A concert of orchestral works by Americans was given last night in Town Hall under the direction of Arnold Gamson. The composers were Ned Rorem, Virgil Thomson, Gid Waldrop and Marvin David Levy, and all the works except that of Mr. Thomson were new to New York.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 12 (AP) -- Baldwin-Lima-Hamilton Corporation disclosed today it was negotiating for acquisition of Riley Stoker Corporation of Worcester, Mass., but declined to state the progress of the talks.

BRIGHTON, England, Oct. 12 -- Britain's proposed entry into the European Common Market triumphed today over the powerful opposition of those Conservatives who argued that the union with Europe would impair national sovereignty and sever ties with the Commonwealth.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 12 (AP) -- A two-week deck officers' strike that left forty-four ships-idle along the West Coast has ended.
Registration of New York City voters picked up yesterday.
Six hundred residents of Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village met last night to seek means of improving crime prevention in the two East Side developments.
DALLAS, Tex., Oct. 12 (UPI) -- House Speaker Sam Rayburn recovered today from pneumonia, which had him in a coma yesterday.

The Bethlehem Steel Company said that millions of tons of previously unusable iron ores found in the Lake Superior region and in foreign fields were now available for blast furnace processing by the company, through a newly patented method of preparing wet iron ores for sintering.
THE South Sea islands inspired Gauguin to paint and James Michener to write, but as far as Guy Douvier is concerned they are Nowheresville.

Believers in trade union decency will agree with the decision of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. Executive Council to issue charters to Teamsters Union locals that want to escape the polluted atmosphere of their giant union. Four years of leadership by James R. Hoffa have brought scant correction of the abuses that prompted the Federation to cast out the teamsters in 1957.

To be effective any deterrent to war must be powerful enough to inflict unacceptable damage on the potential enemy. But it must also be credible; that is, the other side must believe it will be used in defense of vital interests. This is the nub of the Berlin problem, a dilemma which the President did not directly meet in his press conference defense of the national security program.
Columbus Day was observed by some New York commodities markets yesterday.
, BONN, Germany, Oct. 12I !Sharp criticismhas greeted the! iCeman edition of William L( Shirer's "The Rise andFall ofi the Third Reich."
The action of leaders of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association in endorsing Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz for Mayor has irked a number of the organization's members.

Events today: New York Philharmonic, Leonard Bernstein, conductor, Stanley Drucker, clarinetist, Vera Zorina, narrator, Irene Jordan and Virginia Babikian sopranos, McHenry Boatwright, baritone, The Schola Cantorum, Carnegie Hall, 2:15 P.M.; "Carmen," by the New York City Opera, City Center, 8:15 P.M.; Nancy Silsbee, harpsichordist and pianist, Town Hall, 8:30 P.M.; Robert De Pasquale, violinist, Judson Hall, 8:30 P.M.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (UPI) -- Manufacturers, especially makers of durable goods, expect their sales and inventories to rise in the last three months of 1961, the Department of Commerce reported today on the basis of a survey it made in August and September.

ERIK HENDRIK LOUW, the quietly pugnacious Afrikaner whose defense of South Africa in the United Nations has aroused fierce opposition, must find his position a familiar one. He has been wading through hot water for years.
September proved a disappointment to many business men and economists, as strikes, storms, unseasonable weather and recalcitrant consumers slowed the business recovery.
The Federal Power Commission said yesterday that residents here paid on the average $1.47 more a month for electricity than the national average.

The question of Outer Mongolia's admission to the United Nations has stirred a domestic political storm for Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek. Members of the Legislative Yuan in Taipei are threatening to oust the Cabinet of Premier Chen Cheng if the Chinese Nationalist Government alters its previously announced intention to veto United Nations membership for Outer Mongolia.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- Railway freight carloadings rose slightly last week from the levels of the preceding week. The Association of American Railroads reported today that the total of 639,941 cars represented an increase of three-tenths of 1 per cent from the preceding week, but a dip of nine-tenths of 1 per cent from the 1960 level.

Columbia's starting eleven that will face Yale in the Bowl at New Haven tomorrow remains unsettled. Coach Buff Donelli of the Lions contemplates at least two changes in the team that opposed Princeton's football squad last Saturday.

Twenty-five years ago I was fortunate enough to be a founding sponsor of the Foster Parents' Plan for Children, a humanitarian agency that has since become one of America's central pillars of international goodwill. It is amazing and gratifying to note the growth of the Foster Parents' Plan through the quarter of a century gone by.

Allen Webb, a 27-year-old rookie halfback from Arnold College, was added yesterday to the active list of the New York Football Giants. Webb will replace Phil King, who reinjured his shoulder last Sunday in the Giants' victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.

BORDENTOWN, N.J., Oct. 12 -- Richard J. Hughes promised tonight to expand and improve this state's civil defense facilities if elected. He also urged the building of fall-out shelters by individual families as well as industrial plants.
CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Oct. 12 -- Following is a transcript of President Kennedy's talk at the University of North Carolina here today:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today a reduction of 1.9 per cent in the 1962-crop cotton planting allotment despite appeals from growers, the industry and some Southern Congressmen that it be increased. The national allotment was set at 18,101,718 acres, compared with 18,458,424 for the 1961 crop, a decrease of 356,706 acres.

Allan Haymes Associates, realty investors, have bought and taken title to the warehouse formerly occupied by McKesson-Robbins as a drug distributing center at 3674 Third Avenue, adjoining the corner of East 170th Street, the Bronx.

DETROIT, Oct. 12 (UPI) -- Bob Pulford's freak second-period goal from behind the net and Dickie Duff's goal on an open net in the closing seconds of play tonight enabled the Toronto Maple Leafs to score a 4-2 victory over the Detroit Red Wings in the season opener for both teams.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 12 -- The Prime Minister of Western Samoa, a territory that will receive its independence next Jan. 1, told the United Nations today that his country would need continuing, foreign aid.
BERLIN, Oct. 12 -- Troops of the United States garrison in Berlin will hold extensive three-day-maneuvers in the Grunewald forest next week, the Army announced today.

THE latest manifestations of abstract expressionism, America's decisive-contribution to mid-twentieth century art, are generously surveyed, and handsomely installed, in the exhibition "American Abstract Expressionists and Imagists, 1961," opening today at the Guggenheim Museum.

The Jewish Guild for the Blind forced on Wednesday to abandon its headquarters at 1880 Broadway because of fire damage, set up shop yesterday across the street at 1861 Broadway, at Sixty-second Street.
WHILE Red Rolfe was managing the Detroit Tigers, the Yankees released Charlie Keller and the Maryland Strong Boy was promptly grabbed by his one-time team-mate.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- Department store sales in the nation in the week ended Saturday, Oct. 7, were 5 per cent above the year-earlier level.
The nation's production of lumber in August was the highest for any month so far this year at 3,047,000,000 board feet, the National Lumber Manufacturers Association reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP) -- Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas granted Mickey Cohen, Los Angeles gambler, release today on bail of $100,000 pending appeals from his conviction for income tax violations.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 12 -- Guy Green, the British film director, disagrees with two theories widely accepted among theatre-trained actors here.
CHICAGO, Oct. 12 (AP) -- Soybeans and most wheat futures contracts scored small advances on the Board of Trade today, but most feed grains turned downward.

With the New York City banks closed and the market for United States Government securities shut down because of Columbus Day, little business took place yesterday in prime debt securities outside the public securities exchanges.
More than 75,000 Celebrants of the discovery of America marched up Fifth Avenue yesterday in the sixteenth annual Columbus Day parade.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- The Public Health Service said today that fall-out from Soviet nuclear tests had increased the amount of radioactive iodine 131 in milk and fresh food in certain areas of the United States.
BAGHDAD, Iraq., Oct. 12 (Reuters) -- Talks between the Iraqi Government and oil companies operating here have broken down and Iraq plans to take "legal steps" in the dispute, it was announced today.
THIS is a great year for apples. Throughout the nation the crop is expected to be more than 10 per cent above average, with New York State taking over from Washington as top producer.

Balloting by mail began last week in the annual elections of the American Boat and Yacht Council and will close Nov. 30. Chris-Craft's executive vice president, A.W. (Bill) Mackerer, the former New Yorker now a transplanted Floridian in Pompano, where the new Chris-Craft headquarters have been established, is the choice of the nominating committee to be the new president.
NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 12 (UPI) -- New Orleans Public Service, Inc., which operates the city's buses and streetcars, hired its first two Negro drivers today.

KASSEL, Germany, Oct. 12 (AP) -- A group of American investors will take over control of 44 per cent of the capital stock of Henschel-Werke, G.M.B.H., a leading German machinery manufacturer, the company announced tonight.
The world has reached a point of development where the war between the sexes no longer can benefit either sex, Dr. Margaret Mead, the anthropologist, said here last night.
STANFORD, Calif., Oct. 12 (AP) -- The rising toll in high school football fatalities is disturbing, said Jack Curtice of Stanford, the president of the American Football Coaches Association, today.

Suburban shopping centers and downtown department stores were crowded with Columbus Day shoppers yesterday, but as an overcast day turned sunny, the stores had to compete for customers with golf courses, picnic grounds and parade routes.
WITH precision, speed and cooperation that might surprise their parents, thousands of New York City school children evacuate their classrooms in record time twice each month during fire drills.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP) -- The Republican national chairman, William E. Miller, accused President Kennedy today of trying to dismiss criticism of his foreign policies as "only a battle between the mimeograph machines" of the Democratic and Republican National Committees.

Mariane Orlando and Caj Selling, the Swedish dancers, took over the central roles in Birgit Cullberg's "Moon Reindeer" last night in the American Ballet Theatre's performance at the Fifty-fourth Street Theatre. The work was scarcely recognizable as the same one that was presented on the season's opening night.
THE hand shown today is a tournament hand, much discussed when it was played.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- The "agency-shop" is now involved in a conflict over its legality between state and Federal jurisdictions. This is the device by which unions, which are authorized collective bargaining agents for both union and non-union employes in a plant or industry, seek to acquire from the latter group the financial assistance for this common activity that state laws barring compulsory union membership deprive them of.

IT must have seemed as safe a parlay as a handicapper could dope. As a straight play, "Three Men on a Horse" was a galloping champion. Why shouldn't a musical with similar blood lines be an easy winner?

MOSCOW, Oct. 12 -- Premier Khrushchev called today for a disengagement of armed forces in Central Europe and a ban on supplying nuclear weapons to both East and West Germany. The Soviet leader put forward these proposals as part of a five-point program to settle the Berlin dispute and to avert the danger of war.
Women are needed in the labor force in larger numbers to support the nation's industry and defense, Federal officials told a group of women leaders yesterday.
The Kennedy Administration plans further tax concessions to help industry renew its plant and equipment.
ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 12 -- A week ago Cornell was blithely sailing the empyrean on Cloud 9.

NEW CITY, N.Y., Oct. 12 -- Al Feminelli, the home club professional, and Mrs. Alfred Slaner led the way into the quarter-final round the seventh annual Jack Moone Memorial mixed Scotch open golf tournament of the Dellwood Country Club today.

THE televised memoirs of former Presidents are going to afford a rich mine of material for future historians. The first of a series of conversations with former President Dwight D. Eisenhower was offered last night on "C.B.S. Reports''; the emerging study of man, personality and philosophy suggested that he probably could be re-elected tomorrow morning.

The Walter J. Schneider Corporation, a national realty investment company with offices at 67 West Forty-fourth Street, has bought a $225,000 junior mortgage on Rockland Plaza, a twenty-two-acre shopping center on Route 59 in Nanuet, N.Y.

Joanne Woodward and Richard Beymer have been signed to co-star in "Celebration," the screen version of William Inge's play, "Loss of Roses." The Jerry Wald production will go before the Twentieth Century-Fox cameras the first week in December.
MARQUETTE, Mich., Oct. 12 (AP) -- The freighter Northern Venture, freed of pickets by a court order, took on her first cargo in weeks at this Lake Superior port today.
The first two mu nicipal offstreet parking units in the Bronx -- a split-level parking lot and a multi-level parking garage -- were opened yesterday.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Oct. 12 -- A two-point Federal program to spur development of a greater merchant marine was proposed today by Senator George A. Smathers of Florida.

Operations of Hiram Walker-Gooderham Worts, Ltd., for the year ended on Aug. 31 resulted in net income of $26,362,652, equal to $3.05 a share. In the preceding fiscal year, the distilling company cleared $25,050,258, or $2.91 a share.
A single rocket experiment a little more than a month ago has virtually doubled at one stroke man's accumulated data on the whole spectrum of radiations from the sun, a scientist said here yesterday.
THE decorating services of New York department stores are available for furnishing a mansion or choosing a lampshade. The cost may be $150,000 or nothing.
A developing shortage of influenza vaccine and the likelihood of a flu epidemic this winter were described yesterday by an official of the city's Health Department.
For Eastern Air Lines, Inc., "1961 is going to be a very bad year," according to Malcolm A. MacIntyre, president and chief executive officer.
The Penn Ice Company made no deliveries at Franklin Field last Saturday. However, it hopes to make up for the slack business tomorrow at Princeton.
CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 12 (AP) -- Brookfield Farm's Intentionally, a 5-year-old son of Intent, scored a front-running victory today in the $27,375 Quaker City Handicap at a mile and an eighth.
MOSCOW, Oct. 12 -- The Soviet Union asked the United States tonight to extradite an Estonian accused of war crimes on behalf of Germany in World War II.

The oil companies here interested in operations in Iraq who were asked for comment on the development were unclear as to just what the next move of the Iraqi Government would be in its efforts to obtain a 20 per cent participation and other benefits in petroleum production in that country.
NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 12 -- The United States made clear in India today that it did not welcome the attitude in some nonaligned countries toward the resumption of nuclear weapons tests.

Representative Paul A. Fino, Republican candidate for City Council President, during a speech before the Downtown Lions Club in Brooklyn advocated abolishing radio station WNYC. Calling that station a "waste," he said (Times, Oct. 3):
JERUSALEM (Israeli sector), Oct. 12 -- The untimely demise of an elephant has touched off a friendly feud between a zoo official in Tel Aviv and a zoo official in Jerusalem.
The Lone Star Cement Company announced yesterday small price increases for next year on certain types of cement at most of its fifteen domestic plants. This was its price increase in two years.

Sales and earnings of the Consolidated Foods Corporation for the twelve weeks ended on Sept. 23, set records, Nathan Cummings, chairman, disclosed at the annual meeting of stockholders in Chicago yesterday.
Approximately 125,000 aircraft passengers will he grounded for a twelve-hour period this week-end when airline operations will be shut down during a test of the North American air defense system.

The House Committee on Un-American Activities apparently considers its legislative role to include accusing as Communist sympathizers anyone who speaks at a meeting with which the committee is not in sympathy. Such is the conclusion one must draw from the Oct. 3 Times story concerning the investigation into a rally sponsored by the National Assembly for Democratic Rights.
BARROW, Alaska, Oct. 10 -- The Navy is working on plans for a special ship to be frozen into the drifting Arctic pack ice and carried across the North Pole from the Pacific to the Atlantic.
CHICAGO, Oct. 12 (AP) -- A doubled-barreled cancer treatment melted away the tumors in eight patients with localized cancers diagnosed as incurable, a medical researcher reported today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- The first criticism of President Ken nedy's modified determination to balance the budget next year came today from his own party.
LONDON, Oct. 12 -- Industrial shares continued to retreat on a broad front on the stock exchange here today.

In his perceptive enumeration of the "diet of principles," some of which now give us political indigestion, C.L. Sulzberger fails to mention one of the chief culprits: self-determination, first popularized by Woodrow Wilson. It ultimately created a group of nationalist states in wide areas of mixed populations, with resulting oppression of many minorities in Central and Eastern Europe.

Opening the United Hospital Fund drive, Dr. L.F. Kimball of the Rockefeller Institute called attention last week to the pressing problems that must be solved if this country is to avoid a shortage of doctors in the years ahead. The basic outline of what needs to be done was revealed by a study sponsored by the Surgeon General of the United States, and it makes sober reading.

Documents obtained from a Cuban defector show that the Castro regime is trying to destroy the free press of Argentina and other Latin-American countries as a prelude to Communist revolutions, according to an official of the Inter-American Press Association.
A small group of history enthusiasts at Fordham Preparatory School celebrated a Revolutionary War anniversary yesterday with a compass, map, magnifying glass, two shovels and high hopes.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Oct. 12 -- Walter Harvey Shaw, who assertedly created electronic equipment for a multi-million-dollar bookmaking ring in Westchester County, was being held here today in $75,000 bail as a fugitive from justice.

TRENTON, Oct. 12 -- James P. Mitchell, the Republican candidate for Governor, charged today that the Democratic organization was spending almost $1,500,000 in "a desperate attempt to buy the New Jersey gubernatorial election."

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct. 12 -- Vassar College ended observance of the centennial of its founding today with an academic convocation. Three hundred educational institutions, many of them older than Vassar, were represented.

Directors of the Hoover Company have declared the regular quarterly dividend of 15 cents and an extra of 10 cents on the Class A and B common, payable on Dec. 12 to holders of record of Nov. 17. A similar extra, paid in March, 1960, was the only extra that year.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 12 -- The United States challenged the Soviet Union tonight to sign a treaty immediately to end all nuclear weapons tests.

The united labor movement yesterday censured A. Philip Randolph, its only Negro vice president. It charged that he had caused "the gap that has developed between organized labor and the Negro community."

HENRY JAMES would normally appear to be the least likely candidate for opera. His books are subtle, somewhat precious and over-refined, with plots that circle around and come to the point only by hesitation and indirection.
CHICAGO, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Continued lack of hedging pressure and rains that held up harvesting in the Midwest attracted support to soybean futures on the Board of Trade today.
The Brandywine Area Joint School Authority, Pa., has scheduled the sale of $3,280,000 of serial revenue bonds for Oct. 24. The issue win come due from 1963 to 1981.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Oct. 13 -- The commitment of the United States in South Vietnam's struggle against Communist guerrillas is expected to be strengthened significantly as a result of the visit next week by Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, President Kennedy's military adviser.
The Champagne Stakes, vintage 1961, will be offered at the Aqueduct race track today. A field of ten 2-year-old horses will compete in the ninetieth running of the mile race with the bubbly title.
Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System declined $5,000,000 to $29,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
Sid Caesar has made a triumphant return to one of his early conquests -- the Copacabana.

Events today: New York Philharmonic, young people's concert, Leonard Bernstein, conductor, Carnegie Hall, 12 noon; "Cosi fan tutte," presented by New York City Opera, City Center, 2:30 P.M.; Renan De Camp, pianist, Town Hall, 5:15 P.M.

Johnny Antonelli, who won twenty-four games for the Giants in 1954, the year the then New York club won the world series in four straight games, was purchased by the New York Mets yesterday. The terms of the contract signed by Antonelli were not disclosed by George Weiss, the general manager of the new National League club.

Robert Coulson, a lawyer, has bought the nine-story apartment building at 314-16 West Seventy-seventh Street for investment. The seller was the Riverview Realty Corporation. Joseph Hidalgo Sons, Inc., was the broker.

A BAND of internationalists, led by a Dane of Russian parentage and including a French secretary, a Spanish translator and several Americans, is waging its own battle of the bulge at the United Nations.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct, 13 -- A scheduled visit to Belgrade by Senator Hubert H. Humphrey apparently has been canceled following a remark by the Minnesota Democrat listing Yugoslavia among countries that are not free.

CHICAGO, Oct. 13 -- Robert S. Macfarlane, president of the Northern Pacific Railway Company, said today that the railroad industry would be unable to fill its role in the nation's transportation needs in case of war.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- President Kennedy today urged Americans, "young and old," to give generous support this year to the United Nations Children's Fund.
BRIGHTON, England, Oct. 13 -- "Of course, old boy, you must understand, we talk for the nation," said a young Conservative.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Oct. 13. -- Acts of sabotage have taken place in recent weeks in South Africa.

LONDON, Oct. 13 -- Tengku Abdul Rahman, Prime Minister of the Federation of Malaya, is scheduled to come to London in early November for talks on the possibility of a new federation with Singapore and Britain's Borneo territories.
It seemed like the end of a great epoch the other day when our laundryman informed us that he didn't do detachable stiff collars any more.
MATHEMATICS is a guide to the play of many bridge hands, but often there are other factors that are at least as important.

AS any connoisseur of oriental cuisine knows, one of the tastiest -- and most expensive -- delicacies to be had in a first-class Chinese restaurant is bird's-nest soup. Not just any bird's nest will do for the main ingredient.
Queens residents, who often have to brave rain and snow while waiting in long lines for buses, were offered relief yesterday by the Board of Estimate.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 13 -- The Soviet Union announced today that it would accept an Acting Secretary General of the United Nations with full power to make executive decisions.
UNITED NATIONS, Oct. 13 -- Ibrahim Abboud, President of the Sudan, advanced today three arguments in support of Communist China's admission to the United Nations.
The swirling, oily, debris-laden waters of the Harlem River have been adopted by stately wild swan.
HONG KONG, Oct. 13 -- Communist China and Burma concluded today a "protocol relating to the boundary between the two countries."
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved $1 a bale off to 65 cents up yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The State Department denied today that Secretary of State Dean Rusk had agreed last week to study again Communist plans for an atom-free zone in central Europe.
One of two hold-up men was shot and killed yesterday by a Harlem druggist whose store had been robbed seven times previously. The second man escaped.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Oct. 13 -- The scope of the Soviet merchant ship construction means that this country's building program must be re-evaluated, Thomas E. Stakem told shipping industry conferees here today.

While it is premature to make definitive judgments on the long-term. significance of the Syrian revolt against President Nasser's regime, there is one powerful lesson which should be driven home to United states policy-makers. It is the fact that a tyrannical government which incites hatred toward the United States and the West should not be appeased merely because, from outward appearances, it is strong and seems to command a wide following.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- A thousand-mile-long chain of undersea mountains has been discovered in the North Pacific, the Commerce Department reported today.
HOW to store, where to store and, most perplexing of all, how long to store are problems that plague housewives almost more than the daily question: "What shall we have for dinner tonight?"

CHICAGO, Oct. 13 -- Dr. Walter W. Heller, chairman of President Kennedy's Council of Economic Advisers, said today that "the critical period" for price stability might come toward the end of next year, By then, he said, the Federal budget is expected to be a restraining force.
Mayor Wagner campaigned against Representative Charles A. Buckley in the Bronx County Democratic leader's home territory last night.

LYTHAM-ST. ANNES, England, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The United States took a 6-2 lead over Britain today in the foursomes play of the Ryder Cup golf competition. The favored American pros need only seven victories in tomorrow's sixteen singles to retain the golden trophy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The United States disclosed today that it had sought to address the Soviet people to present Western views of the Berlin crisis, just as Moscow has been able to circulate its views in this country.
The Goodwill Industries of New York, which operates a training program for the handicapped, will receive aid from three Thursday morning invitation lectures at the Cosmopolitan Club.
Methods of modernizing the Hudson Manhattan Railroad will be studied by two research organizations for the Port of New York Authority.
Jorge Fernandez, the favorite at 3 -- 1, is expected to weigh 150 pounds for his ten-round bout against Cecil Shorts in Madison Square Garden tonight.

DETROIT, Oct. 13 (UPI) -- An official of the United Automobile Workers accused the Ford Motor Company today of trying to wash out local agreements. Signing of a new three-year contract between the company and the union was postponed indefinitely.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- James R. Hoffa defended today mutual assistance pacts between the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and unions that are generally regarded as Communist-dominated.

The "remarkable" post-war bull market in common stocks has been explained in many ways, but Dr. John Harriman, an economist, likes to dig up fundamentals: "When all is said and done, it boils down to a question of demand and supply."
For myself and many of my colleagues I wish to express our distress at the unfairness and the poor taste shown by your Topics editors attempted comical rehashing of the Bertrand Russell case.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Peru moved today to convene a conference of Western Hemisphere foreign ministers, presumably to consider the problem of the Fidel Castro regime in Cuba.

For a pleasant change, deep-seated tendencies toward lethargy and indecision hampered the New York Knickerbockers only spasmodically last night in their first appearance at Madison Square Garden this season.

MOSCOW, Oct. 13 -- Thirteen Soviet citizens have been sentenced to death in Minsk, capital of the Byelorussian Republic, on charges of assisting Nazi troops in the murder of more than 10,000 people during World War II.

ABOUT ten years ago Dimitri Mitropoulous conducted Darius Milhaud's "Les Choephores" with the New York Philharmonic. At that time the work made a big impression by the strength and startling innovations of the fourth and fifth sections.

BRIGHTON, England, Oct. 13 Selwyn Lloyd, Chancellor of the Exchequer, declared today that the Government would stick to its "wage pause" policy despite attacks from organized labor and from within the Conservative party itself.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The formation of a nonprofit corporation to develop and operate a commercial system of communications satellites was recommended to the Government today by a special industry committee.
A goddess who lost her head at some remote time has regained it through a discovery of New York University archaeologists exploring an ancient city in Turkey.

Esquire Books, a new publishing concern, will issue its first two volumes this fall and winter. One will be "Fabulous Yesterday," a picture and text study of Coronet magazine's twenty-five years of publishing. The other will be "Esquire's Great Men and Moments in Sports," which will include paintings and illustrations of the events by noted persons in the world of sports.
NEWTON, N.J., Oct. 13 -- A 300-pound black bear that came into town last night and was wounded by a policeman was killed this morning by a young farmer who had joined the hunt.
Builders began a last-minute rush to file plans for multiple dwellings in the city under expiring regulations.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 13 -- Richard M. Nixon has confirmed, in conversations with friends, that he doesn't believe the 1964 Republican Presidential nomination will be worth much.
SINCE the New York City Opera has so many handsome productions, perhaps it can be forgiven its fourth-rate "Carmen."

Rosalind Elias, the Metropolitan Opera Company's young mezzo-soprano who published an advertisement in The New York Times last Wednesday expressing her faith in the United States, has been overwhelmed by the public response.

The British Conservative party, which ends its annual conference at Brighton today with an address by Prime Minister Macmillan, had a harder row to hoe than the Labor party. The Socialists held their conference the week before at Blackpool, but had decided most of their controversies in advance.
Four Protestant churches in Brooklyn Heights have banded together to give a helping hand to the community's first Jewish temple.

AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 13 (AP) -- Gov. Price Daniel of Texas, chairman of the Interstate Oil Compact Commission, urged Gov. Jack Gage of Wyoming yesterday to bring his complaints over an oil reserves study before the commission in December.
CHICAGO, Oct. 13 -- Federal Judges still showed a disparity of views on sentencing convicted criminals, even after two days of discussion on the problem.

Beginning with the Dutch, who bought the land from the Indians at a scandalously low price, New York City has had wave after wave of immigrants -- Irish, Germans, Italians, Jews and many other nationalities, races and religions.

Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg said yesterday that when he made his arbitration award in the dispute between the Metropolitan Opera Association and its orchestra he would deal also with the "related problems of the future of the performing arts in our society."

MOSCOW, Oct. 13 -- The Soviet Union recalled its Ambassador to the Netherlands today and ordered the expulsion of the Dutch Ambassador in protest against what Moscow described as the scandalous manhandling of members of its embassy staff by the Dutch police.
Emile Baume, French pianist, will give a Chopin recital Tuesday evening at Town Hall in behalf of the Foundation for Advancement of Arts and Letters in Memory of Rudolf Steiner.
The L.E. Waterman Pen Company, Ltd., of Montreal, has reorganized its management at the top level, electing a new resident and a new chairman.

In spite of the billions of dollars this country has spent on foreign aid of various kinds, the question of purpose still comes up. What are we trying to do? Under what terms shall we help Poland, which is squarely, if sometimes unhappily, behind the Iron Curtain? What conditions should we impose on Yugoslavia, which operates under its own special brand of communism?

BERLIN, Oct. 13 -- East German border guards fired about 250 shots into West Berlin early today after nine youths had crashed a heavy truck into the border barriers and leaped to safety. No one was injured in the hail of bullets, according to the West Berlin police.
EAST SETAUKET, L.I., Oct. 13 -- A saloon was torn down and a small brick bank building constructed in its place here on Main Street in 1920.
UNITED NATIONS, Oct. 13 -- Australia declared today that Soviet war threats over Berlin had brought the Western powers closer together.
Dr. Hans Emil Hirschfeld, a prominent West German who has been accused of being at wartime Soviet spy, was offered limited immunity yesterday if he testified the Soblen espionage case here.

The premieres of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's "Bridge to the Sun" (on Tuesday) and Universal's "Flower Drum Song" (next at the Radio City Music Hall) may mean a great deal to the career of James Shigeta, a 28-year-old native of Hawaii and one of the few Nisei artists in recent years to emerge as a Hollywood leading man.
Four persons were injured, one critically, in Brooklyn last night when a stolen car driven by a youth hit two pedestrians and then smashed into a truck and two cars.
The Appellate Division yesterday unanimously upheld a State Supreme Court order keeping Vito P. Battista on the ballot as the mayoral candidate of the United Taxpayers party.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Maj. Gen. Edwin A. Walker was assigned to Hawaii today as an assistant chief of staff for training and operations of the Army forces in the Pacific.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Oct. 13 (AP) -- Radiating the possessive smiles of a life-long companionshsip, Dwight D. and Mamie Eisenhower climbed into their big black sedan this evening and drove off to a birthday celebration.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 13 -- Elaine Rodney, despite a "break" approaching the mile, rallied spectacularly and won the United States Harness Writers' Trot before 24,390 fans at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. The 4-year-old mare, with Clint Hodgins in the sulky, triumphed over Hickory Pride by a length and three-quarters in near-record time for the mile-and-a-quarter race.

GENEVA, Oct. 13 (Reuters) -- The International Sugar Conference, meeting here to review the international sugar agreement, is split over a Cuban application for a quota of 7,285,000 tons, conference sources said today.

A BATTERY-OPERATED pepper mill is nothing to sneeze at, according to Ham macher Schlemmer. This week a mechanical grinder appeared in the store and within hours word had spread among East Side gourmets and inquiries were coming in rapidly.

KIEV, U.S.S.R., Oct. 5 -- The citizens of Kiev find no large headlines in their morning papers dealing with the Berlin issue or the threat of war. Like the residents of other Soviet cities, the inhabitants of this Ukrainian capital lead a curiously soothing, cushioned existence, sheltered from the turmoil of international affairs.
All civil aircraft, commercial as well as private, will be forbidden to fly over the United States or Canada for twelve hours beginning at 1 P.M. today.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Oct. 13 -At first glance, it would seem highly incongruous that the men charged with maintaining the soundness of the nation's state-chartered banks should choose as the site for their annual meeting Las Vegas, Nev., the city where everyone's aim is to "break the bank."

The Federal Reserve System increased its holdings of Government securities by $344,000,000, to a record of $28,275,736,000, in the week ended on Wednesday, a spokesman for the Federal Reserve Bank of New York said yesterday. The rise includes $218,000,000 of securities purchased outright, and $126,000,000 held under repurchase agreements.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Peachy Booker, proprietor of Flanders Cleaners in Riverhead, L.I., has patented an airborne landing platform. It is intended to fly to the rescue of disabled planes and take them in its back.
Irwin Vincent Powell, a 41year-old securities dealer, was indicted here yesterday in the kidnapping of Morton S. Robson, a former United States Attorney, last month.
NEW CITY, N.Y., Oct. 13 -- Al Feminelli and Mrs. Alfred Slaner of the home club reached the final round of the seventh Jack Moone Memorial Scotch mixed open golf championship today.

ROME, Oct. 13 -- The American Davis Cup team stunned the Italian tennis world today by taking a 1-0 lead over heavily favored Italy when Jon Douglas beat Fausto Gardini, 4 -- 6, 4 -- 6, 7 -- 5, 10 -- 8, 6 -- 0.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Oct. 13 -- Two local business men and six other Westchester residents are satisfying long-standing ambitions to find out what it is like to operate an FM radio station to broadcast music and news.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The most extensive revamping of the mandatory oil import control program since its inception two years ago appears in the offing. Contrary to some reports, a draft of proposed changes has not yet been submitted by the Department of the Interior's Oil Import Administration to other Federal departments and agencies for their reaction.

Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz yesterday charged Mayor Wagner with failing to act effectively to curb the increase in juvenile delinquency. At the same time, the Republican candidate for Mayor proposed a program to reverse the trend.
The attitude taken in the letter published Oct. 10 endorsing Senator Margaret Chase Smith's views makes my blood boil.

Vice President Johnson received yesterday the Grand Cross of Merit of the Sovereign Order of Malta, one of the oldest of Roman Catholic orders. Mr. Johnson, the first American to be so honored, is a member of the Christian Church, a Protestant denomination.
A Cuban exile leader appealed to the press of the Americas yesterday to promote a "great crusade" to restore democracy to Cuba and to stop the spread of communism to the rest of the hemisphere.

ALBANY, Oct. 13 (UPI) -- A teacher organization today accused Dr. James E. Allen Jr., state Education Commissioner, of having almost dictatorial powers that were "inconsistent with our democratic heritage."
RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 13 (AP) -- The White House has expressed annoyance over an interior decorator's criticism of the $12,500 wallpaper project in its diplomatic reception room.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The United States sold 130 jet fighter airplanes to Yugoslavia last March, the State and Defense Departments disclose today.

A broadcast monitored in Aden, British protectorate adjoining the Kingdom of Yemen in the southern tip of the Arabian peninsula, raised the question yesterday whether the Imam, or King, of Yemen had abdicated.
Cypress Hills Street, a major north-south route between the Bushwick district of Brooklyn and the Ridgewood area of Queens, was reopened yesterday after a $590,000 widening and modernization.

EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Oct. 13 (UPI) -- The X-15 "accidentally" set a world speed record for manned, winged aircraft Wednesday at the same time it achieved an altitude mark of forty-one miles, the Air Force disclosed today.
TOKYO, Oct. 13 (UPI) -- Japan is expected to seek a $300,000,000 loan from the International Monetary Fund to meet the decrease in the nation's foreign exchange reserve. The Japan Times said today.

Even for those who always put things off to the last minute, time has about run out for registration to vote in the Nov. 7 election in New York City. Polling places in every local election district will be open from 7 A.M. to 10:30 P.M. today. This is the last day to register.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 13 -- Richard J. Hughes, the Democratic candidate for governor, made a strong plea for support at a party rally on the Rutgers University campus here tonight.
The Board of Estimate voted yesterday to abolish the 5 per cent city tax on tickets to legitimate theatres.
GLENS FALLS, N.Y., Oct. 13 (AP) -- An unemployed laborer was charged today with having set a pre-dawn fire that damaged eight buildings and threatened a large section of the city's east end.

The real root of the discord lies in the insistence of Negroes on speedier progress toward leveling the encrusted walls of racial exclusion in every aspect of American life.
KANSAS CITY, Oct.13 (AP) -- College athletic officials introduced a program today to combat gambling.

Preserving the landmarks of our great city is indeed a worthy project and grows more urgent as glass and metal towers crowd each other ad nauseam. Your correspondent Francis Keally (Oct. 4) deserves to be heard and, if The Times were to embark on a crusade, this is one worthy of your influential backing.

FRANKFURT, Germany, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Luther H. Hodges, United States Secretary of Commerce, told German business men today restrictions on United States Government buying abroad would be kept as long as needed.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (UPI) -- A lawyer for Irvin C. Scarbeck charged today that the former diplomat had been compelled to confess that he slipped secret documents to Communist agents in Poland.

The last in a series of design forums keyed to the needs of homemakers will be presented Wednesday at 2:30 P. M. on the sixth floor of the National Design Center, 415 East Fifty-third Street. The topic under discussion will be "How to Use Art and Accessories."
The Citizens Union announced yesterday its ratings on concilmanic candidates in Queens, the Bronx and Staten Island.
Gerald M. Abrahams, who arrived in New York from London a few days ago, announced with satisfaction yesterday that increasing numbers of American men were wearing clothes with the British look.

BOSTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- George Blanda kicked a 25-yard field goal five seconds before the final gun tonight to give the Houston Oilers a 31-31 tie with the Boston Patriots in an American Football League game marked by the record passing performance of Jackie Lee.

Major issues of fixed-interest securities valued at $271,351,900 are expected to be offered in the new capital market next week. Major bond issues of California and New York State will lead the municipal list. A bond issue of Public Service Electric and Gas Company leads the corporate offerings.
The healthier state of the world's freight market for dry cargo tramp shipping has pushed Liberty ship prices to their highest levels in three years.

Robert A. Willey, whose first Broadway producing venture was "Greenwillow," the musical based on a novel by B.J. Chute, has bought fifty-two short stories by the author. They will serve as source material for the stage and television.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- A year after it was supposed to have gone silent, the United States satellite Explorer VII was still broadcasting in space today, its second birthday.

GENEVA, Oct. 13 -- The European Common Market Countries, Japan and India have formally accepted the agreement reached here last July to regulate trade in cotton textiles, it was officially announced today.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 13 -- West Germany will oppose any proposals for a solution of the German problem going beyond those the Western Allies offered the Soviet Union at the Foreign Ministers' conference in Geneva in 1959.
Yesterday's session of the New York Stock Exchange found every group irregular. Even the foods, which have been strong recently, produced almost as many minus as plus signs.
The metropolitan area's booksellers, aroused by best-selling books marked below cost to attract customers to discount houses, grocery chains and other outlets, met yesterday to discuss price-cutting.
PARIS, Oct. 13 -- Six Moslems, including a Child, were killed today in communal clashes in Oran between Moslems and Europeans.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (UPI) -- Marketing of watered hams from Federally inspected packing plants will be banned effective Nov. 18, the Agriculture Department announced today.

Two men who said they were former Cuban police lieutenants were captured yesterday after they allegedly had taken $2,200 in the robbery of a Fiftieth Street restaurant. They later told the police they were trying to raise funds to fight Fidel Castro.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The Civil Rights Commission today urged Congress to pass legislation banning racial discrimination by labor unions.
LAS VEGAS, Oct. 13 (UPI) -- Mickey Wright scored a 77 today to hold a two-stroke lead after the wind-swept second round of the Ladies Professional Golfers Association tournament.

RIVERSIDE, Calif., Oct. 13 -- Jack Brabham of Australia won the pole position today for the fourth annual Riverside Grand Prix for sports cars Sunday. Driving a Cooper Monaco, Brabham was timed in 2:01 in the qualifying lap.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- President Kennedy today accepted the resignation of Maj. Gen. Ulysses S. Grant 3d, as chairman of the Civil War Centennial Commission and appointed Allan Nevins, the historian to take his place.
Carnegie Hall, spared from demolition last year, needs to be saved again, its management told the Board of Estimate yesterday.
WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Oct. 13 -- The College of William and Mary, the nation's second oldest, inaugurated its twenty-third president today in ceremonies attended by some 4,000 persons.
Two stakes in the six-figure added-money category are the main attractions in thoroughbred racing today.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, Oct. 13 (Reuters) -- Iraq's Oil Minister, Dr. Mohammed Hassan Salman, said in an interview with the English-language newspaper Iraq Times today that a committee was already preparing the statutes for a national oil company" to be formed in the near future.
Dr. Cheddi B. Jagan, Prime Minister of British Guiana, called last night for the economic liberation of his and other Latin-American countries from domination by industrialized powers.
ONTARIO, Calif., Oct. 13 (UPI) -- George Bayer, the first-round leader in the $20,000, 72-hole Ontario open, maintained the top spot today at the 36-hole mark with a second-round 71.
Two West Side landlords were fined a total of $700 in Housing Court yesterday for Health Code violations, particularly rat infestation.

LONDON, Oct. 13 -- News of an increase in Britain's adverse trade gap in September quickly halted a rallying tendency on the stock exchange here today. Most industrial shares groups had more net falls than gains.

A residence house for twenty-five boys from Wiltwyck School for boys who have "done well" will be opened in Manhattan next month, Justine Wise Polier, Justice of the Domestic Relations Court, announced yesterday.

ROME, Oct. 13 -- The Left-Wing Socialists, under Pietro Nenni, have decided to support a Center-Left Government that undertakes to follow a foreign policy to "ease international tension and promote peace."

Thirteen witnesses, including three whose names were kept secret, testified yesterday before the Kings County rackets grand jury investigating the attempted garroting of Lawrence Gallo and the murder of Joseph Magnasco.

The leaders of a reform group within the membership of the American Stock Exchange that has been critical of the "Little Board's" administration indicated yesterday that they now were satisfied with a plan for a full-scale review of the exchange's rules, practices and procedures.
VANDENBERG AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Oct. 13 (UPI) -- A Discoverer satellite carrying the newest in experimental gear streaked into orbit over the poles today.

On Oct. 10 The Times reported closure by the City Health Department of all New York tattooing parlors. At first glance this seems an unimportant, though proper action. Closer consideration suggests that it may rather constitute an unduly harsh governmental repression of a few marginal and relatively defenseless individuals.
Columbia's freshman football team defeated Yale's freshmen by 19 -- 8 yesterday at Baker Field. The victory was the first for a Lion freshman eleven over Yale since 1948.

LONDON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Premier Khrushchev has accused Senator Margaret Chase Smith of beating "all records of savagery" in a Senate speech she made last month.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The index of average wholesale primary market prices remained unchanged during the week ended last Tuesday, at 118.5 per cent of its 1947-49 base, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.
LONDON, Oct. 13 -- Senior diplomatic officials of the United States, Britain, France and West Germany are to meet here Thursday to resume talks on Berlin and Germany, the Foreign Office said today.

JERSEY CITY, N.J. Oct 13 -- James P. Mitchell called on Hudson County Democrats tonight to "let the rest of the nation know that the days of boss rule have come to an end, here, by voting for your own liberation on Nov. 7."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Following are the text of notes exchanged by the United States and the Soviet Union on the subject of freedom of information, made public today by the State Department. The United States note was dated Sept. 22.
A total of 38,171 registered yesterday for the municipal elections, bringing the total for three days. The total number of qualified voters in the city is now 3,417,606.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (UPI) -- The Right Rev. Angus Dun, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of Washington, declared today that it was "utterly immoral" to talk about using guns to drive neighbors away from a family fall-out shelter.
Vice President Johnson called on all United Nations members last night to make "at least a brave start' toward banning nuclear weapons from space.

CHICAGO, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The American Medical Association, noting that there have been thirteen high school football fatalities this season, suggested a five-point program today to curb grid iron accidents.

The Dow Chemical Company reported yesterday that operations in its first fiscal quarter, ended on Aug. 31, followed the same pattern as those of the preceding fiscal year -- sales rose but earnings fell.

MIAMI, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Big Jerry Hillebrand pounced on a fumble deep in Miami territory, then turned the break into a 37-yard, fourth-quarter, field goal that gave Colorado's Buffaloes a 9-7 victory over the injury-ridden Miami eleven tonight.

BONN, Oct. 13 -- Defense Minister Franz Josef Strauss said today that he suspected the current maneuvers of the Warsaw Pact forces in East Germany were meant as "cover support" for future Soviet actions over Berlin.
The New York Football Giants ran through a signal drill yesterday and then flew to Dallas for their game with the Cowboys on Sunday.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 13 -- Sixteen nations expressed their concern to the General Assembly today over "the prolonged exposure of mankind to increasing levels of radioactive fall-out."
Undefeated John Adams of Queens routed James Monroe of the Bronx, 33 -- 7, yesterday in a Division I Public Schools Athletic League football game at Wilson Field in Baisley Park, Queens.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Saturday, Oct. 14 (UPI) -- Communist North Vietnam protested today to the International Control Commission for Vietnam against the scheduled visit of Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, according to Hsinhua, the Chinese Communist press agency.
ALBANY, Oct. 13 -- The names of 1,038 persons who passed the bar examination last July were announced today by the State Board of Law Examiners.
Trans World Airlines pilots set a Wednesday strike deadline yesterday and announced they had broken off contract negotiations.
New York University will sponsor a "Workshop for High School Editors" series this month to celebrate the fiftieth anniversary of its Journalism Department.
Gamble-Skogmo, Inc., Minneapolis, a wholesaler and retailer of general merchandise, announced yesterday the sale of Walker Co. to the Naegele Advertising Companies, Inc., also of Minneapolis.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board has ordered the Flying Tiger Line to stop flying F-104 fighter planes to Germany, as cargo in its big new freighter planes, under a contract with Germany's Lufthansa Airline.

KATMANDU, Nepal, Oct. 13 -- The dispute between Nepal and Communist China over the peak of Mount Everest has been settled on the basis of existing maps, which show the peak on the border. The accord is contained in the text of a treaty signed in Peiping Oct. 5 and made public here today.

The Board of Education is planning to retain consultants to evaluate its construction, repair and maintenance efforts. The evaluation, one of several to be made of school operations, is expected to enable the new board to make improvements where necessary.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (UPI) -- Five young Europeans, including an alleged member of a West German gang of thieves, have been rescued by a United States destroyer escort in the remote Pacific, it was reported here today.

A weakness in coffee futures developed yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. By the end of the day, prices of the "B" contract dropped 60 to 85 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on the sale of 22,500 bags of 132 pounds each.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- An effort is being made to salvage from the walls of the Capitol a 100-year-old mural said to be worth $150,000.

A new one-story building on Jefferson Road in Parsippany, N.J., has been leased by Sun-Ram, Inc., the builder and owner, to Pacquin, Inc., manufacturer of toilet preparations. WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- The optimism toward the fiscal future of the United States Government and its people that President Kennedy expressed last July with such certainty vanished with his remarks on the same subject at his news conference this week. Morse had introduced the daguerreotype into America in 1839, the process that made every man "his own painter," had become a flourishing industry and an alluring means of livelihood for hundreds of persons across the land.

ALL the world loves vanilla. Aptly somehow, the delicate flavor that beguiles millions of palates each year comes from the fruit of an orchid. This fruit is the vanilla bean, long and slender and resembling a mahogany-colored snap bean. Vanilla originated in Mexico but most of today's production is from the island of Madagascar. Here are recipes using pure vanilla extract that are thoroughly recommended.

Former Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell yesterday applauded the merged labor movement's decision last week not to readmit James R. Hoffa's Brotherhood of Teamsters.
IDAHO FALLS, Idaho, Oct. 14 (UPI) -- A new atomic power plant is nearing completion at the National Reactor Testing Station.
BERLIN, Oct. 14 (UPI) -- Refugees reported today that jubilant East Germans threw flowers at maneuvering Communist Czechoslovak troops, who were mistaken for liberating Americans.

Oct. 14 (Reuters) -- Crown Prince Louis Rwangasore of Urundi, Premier of the southern half of this Belgian trust territory bordering the Congo, was assassinated by an unidentified gunman here last night. The assassin escaped.

THE Bronx Zoo has opened a hall called "The World of Darkness" where visitors (human) can watch the nocturnal activities of such creatures as rats, hedgehogs, bats and flying squirrels. The hall is illuminated with red light in which humans can see, but most animals cannot.

SALZBURG, Austria, Oct. 14 -- German and non-German scholars found themselves separated by a broad gulf this week when they attempted to discuss East-West relations at the first International Conference for the Comparative Study of Civilizations.

NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 14 (UPI) -- Some hardy workers are toiling at the bottom of Lower Chesapeake Bay today so that motorists can rove seventy miles of driving along the Atlantic Coast within a couple of years.

FOR reasons best explained by naturalists, autumn in America is gayer, brighter, more joyous than anywhere else. After the long summer there is a quickening in the air and for children it is a time for doing and a time of discovery.

THOUGH typewriters and duplicating machines long ago became basic implements of big government, one small office in the White House gets along without them very well. Its occupants still practice calligraphy, the ancient art of fine penmanship.
