THOSE beguiling narratives that counsel the tourist to arise and go now, because it is cheaper in the off-season, are helping to work a minor revolution in vacation habits. Thousands of Americans now visit the right places at the wrong time of year.

A CLEVER educationist once told me how he cured a girl "problem-reader" who, though reading well, stonily rejected everything but confession magazines. He persuaded her to try an unusually long confession-story about a beautiful woman married to a cold, sour husband, who eloped with a dashing young officer and ended up a remorseful suicide.

An unidentified man was stabbed fatally in front of a Brooklyn church yesterday morning. The police quickly arrested a suspect with a record of mental illness, who was said to have told them he "just had to kill somebody."

IN her review of Oscar Lewis' "The Children of Sanchez." Miss Elizabeth Hardwick's comparison of literature based upon tape recordings to the motion picture raises some interesting points. It must first be emphasized that only a documentary type film, comprising images from actual life, can qualify for this analogy; fictional movies more closely resemble fictional literature.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Oct. 14 -- On his seventy-first birthday today Dwight D. Eisenhower was hard at work on the one big job he could never quite bring off as President -- the remaking of the Repub lican party in his own image.

AS a florid, flamboyant, unashamed dream of glory, "The White Rajah" pays respectful tribute to the shimmering images of Rafael Sabatini and Errol Flynn. AS American college students grow increasingly world-minded, study in foreign lands -- the "junior year abroad" -- has become academically fashionable. But, most educators agree, few students can fit into a foreign institution without suffering scholastically. Stanford University, in California, thinks it has the answer: establishing its own "campuses" abroad, staffed by its own faculty.

A full-scale mock-up of the Orbiting Astronomical Observatory, largest scientific satellite currently under development by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, was exhibited last week at the American Rocket Society's Space Flight Report to the Nation at the New York Coliseum. The 9 1/2 feet high by 6 1/2 feet wide octagonal-shaped mock-up was shown by Gruman Aircraft Engineering Corporation, prime contractors and systems managers for the project.
The processing of waste water for agricultural use has assumed top priority in Israeli water planning, the chief sanitary engineer of the Israel Ministry of Health said here yesterday.
HACKENSACK, N.J., Oct. 14 -- Voters in three Bergen County school districts this week approved bond issues totaling $6,267,000.
LAFAYETTE, Ind., Oct. 14 (UPI) -- Purdue whipped Miami of Ohio today, 19 -- 6, for its second football victory in three starts this season.

Robert Gatling of Bronx Vocational and Richard Duggan of Holy Cross won their varsity-section runs in the eleventh annual St. John's University interscholastic cross-country meet at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday.

ROCKPORT, Mass., Oct. 14 -- The first amateur art festival here ended tonight. A total of sixty-eight paintings was received and hung by the Rockport Art Association and the Rockport Board of Trade, joint sponsors of the venture, which opened Thursday.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Oct. 14 -- The fourteenth annual thrift sale of the Junior League of Morristown will take place in the Presbyterian Parish House at 65 South Street on Wednesday from 9 A.M. to 8 P.M. and on Thursday from 9 A.M. to 1 P.M.
Shipping executives and Government maritime officials will open a four-day meeting in Chicago tomorrow on safety.
New construction details were given last week concerning the largest movable structure man has ever attempted to build for installation on land.

A system of regional counselors to help improve the teaching of physics in secondary schools has been established jointly by the American Association of Physics Teachers and the American Institute of Physics.

The tempo of retail trade quickened a bit last week under seasonal influences. Ideal shopping weather and widespread promotions were the motivating factors. In Kansas City, the annual American Royal and Future Farmers of America events attracted more than 10,000.

HANDEL: Water Music; Brno State Philharmonic, conducted by Janos Ferencik (Parliament PLP 146). The chief distinction in this low-cost disk is the agile and beautiful playing of an unnamed oboist. The rest of the disk, however, is also of good quality.

" REVOLT in Hungary," a repeat on the Hungarian uprising in 1956, and "Hungary Today," a recently filmed documentary, will be televised on successive Sundays this month by the Columbia Broadcasting System's "Twentieth Century."

NEW IBERIA, La. -- An old mansion with an unusual name, Shadows on the Teche, is being preserved here as a relic of the opulent plantation days before the Civil War. As an outstanding example of the old Louisiana bayou country home, it is considered one of the most beautiful buildings in the South.

ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 14 -- An election day that Turks have long awaited comes tomorrow. The prospect is that about 11,000,000 of them will vote in the elections for a new Parliament to transfer the Government from military to civilian hands.

THE Leningrad Kirov Ballet has ended its siege at Madison Square Garden and headed west, leaving us the poorer for its going but immeasurably the richer for its having come. YOU can look at the Brooklyn Museum s current exhibition, "The Nude in American Painting,'' in any one of several ways. If you expect a fine technical display, as would be natural considering the position of the nude as a showcase item, you will be disappointed.

DAVID MORAY, wealthy widower, is serenely enjoying life on his beautiful lakeside Swiss estate when mention of the Scottish Lowlands shatters his peace. He flies back to Scotland seeking the girl he had loved when he was a poor medical student and abruptly deserted for an heiress bride.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Oct. 14 -- Fifteen young women were the guests of honor tonight when they made their debuts in the Tuxedo Club at the seventy-third annual Tuxedo Autumn Ball, which was attended by more than 500 persons.
PIRAEUS, Greece, Oct. 14 -- A court here sentenced a 26-year-old American to death today. A jury of seven men and three women found him guilty of having killed two Greek seamen.

Sales and earnings of the Eastman Kodak Company were higher in the third quarter than they were in the 1960 period, it was reported yesterday by Thomas J. Hargrave, chairman, and William S. Vaughn, president.

Purchases of mutual fund shares in September amounted to $236,131,000, reflecting a decline from the $244,717,000 level of August but a sizable increase from the September, 1960, figure of $171,081,000, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

Ninety-eight of approximately 530 horses that will compete in the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden from Oct. 31 to Nov. 7 will be in the saddle and fine harness classes.

The new City Charter, which would be made effective by a Yes vote on Question No. 1 on Nov. 7, adds greatly to the responsibilities of the City Council. The hope and assumption is that this would make the Council itself more responsible. But the Mayor's Charter Revision Commission did not rely on this possibility alone in its effort to strengthen the city's government.
Tyrone Guthrie's version of "H.M.S. Pinafore" will be televised by station WNBC-TV twice this season.
NORTHPORT, L.I., Oct. 17 -Baymen and local officials are trying to re-establish the succulent bay scallop on the natural ishellfish grounds of Northport Bay.

LONDON, Oct. 17 -- A slight increase in demand and a slackening of the selling pressure enabled industrial shares to rally on stock market here today. Gains seldom exceeded a shilling (14 cents) and most groups had a good sprinkling of falls.

MOSCOW, Oct. 17 -- At the opening of the twenty-second congress of the Soviet Communist party Premier Khrushchev took the stage at 10 A.M. He ended his first day's performance nine and one-half hours later without relinquishing the spotlight.
The Federal Housing Administrator said last night that this nation's urban renewal program could continue only if it were "accompanied by greater freedom of choice for Negroes in housing."
Mayor Wagner promised residents of Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village yesterday that their developments, which take in twenty-four square blocks, would be patrolled by the police.
Poetry -- ancient and modern -- was praised and read in the main salon of Gracie Mansion yesterday.

An auxiliary weapon called the "BB-Gun" passing formation has been added to the arsenal of the New York Giants in support of their rapid-fire "automatics" triggered from the conventional T with split backfield.

SINCE the turn of the century scores of books have been published in English on the subject of French cuisine. Many of these books have been written by French chefs via the test kitchens of publishing firms with myopic and underfed editors.
Advertising men must take a more constructive role in the drive to do away with objectionable ads, a prominent Madison Avenue executive urged yesterday.
CUIDAD TEUJILLO, Dominican Republic Oct. 17 (AP) -- The University of Santo Domingo, scene of student rioting, was ordered closed today for the remainder of the year.
ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, Oct. 17 (UPI) -- An Egyptian legal expert called today for arbitration as a method of settling disputes between oil companies and the producing states.
A QUIET revolution in our musical life has been taking place with the arrival of superb young instrumentalists who are gifted, musical and up to date.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 17 -- Western European delegates protested today against any deal that would exclude a Western European from the high command of the United Nations Secretariat.

The Association of the Bar of the City of New York last night approved ten judicial candidates as well qualified to serve on the bench. It found three not qualified and expressed no opinion on one candidate.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) -- A State Department spokesman criticized today a Polish plan for a nuclear-free zone in Central Europe and other Communist-sponsored proposals.

The objection raised this week by Dr. James B. Conant to the transfer of Negro children to predominantly white schools were described as "socially unwarranted and psychologically unsound" yesterday by a spokesman for the American Jewish Congress.

TOTOWA, N.J., Oct. 17 -- The first match of the National Bowling League in the metropolitan area was staged tonight before about 500 fans at Gladiator Arena, where the Kansas City Stars defeated the New York Gladiators, 17 -- 8.

Proposals to improve the architectural and engineering services of the Board of Higher Education through a larger staff, higher pay and more efficient organization were applauded by Mayor Wagner yesterday.

The New York Philharmonic has scheduled four subscription concerts in May in Carnegie Hall to make up for those canceled two weeks ago because of the orchestral strike. Leonard Bernstein will conduct them.

MADISON, N.J., Oct. 17 -- Richard J. Hughes, the Democratic candidate for Governor, continued his attack on the qualifications of his opponent today as he carried his campaign into Republican-dominated Morris County.

The Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company doubled its earnings on an 18 per cent sales gain in the third quarter of 1961, compared with the 1960 period, according to a report issued yesterday by the big Youngstown, Ohio, steel producer.
The boom in the construction of hotels, motels and furnished apartments has resulted in the formation of a new type of company that supplies and installs everything from rugs to pictures on the wall.
TRENTON, Oct. 17 -- Attorney General David D. Furman of New Jersey told all twenty-one county prosecutors in the state today that it was not a crime to sell Henry Miller's "Tropic of Cancer."

The board of directors of the Scott Paper Company authorized yesterday a three-for-one split of the concern's common stock and voted to increase the quarterly dividend to 60 cents a share from 55 cents on the present shares.

MOSCOW, Oct. 17 -- Marshal Kliment Y. Voroshilov was identified publicly today as one of the original leaders of the so-called anti-party group that was ousted in 1957. This morning the former Soviet chief of state was elected to the forty-one-member Presidium of the twenty-second congress of the Soviet Communist party.
CHICAGO, Oct. 17 -- The tools of stevedoring automation may become lethal weapons, a speaker said here today at the annual convention of the marine section of the National Safety Council.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) -- After two recent strikes, Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg said today he had obtained a renewed no-strike pledge from unions involved in missile-base construction.

LONDON, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Eddie Machen of Portland, Ore., scored a technical knockout over Brian London tonight when the former British heavyweight champion retired at the end of five rounds. London weighed 209 pounds and Machen 200 for the scheduled ten-round bout at the Wembley arena.
Members of the Inter-American Press Association were told yesterday by its Committee of Freedom of the Press that they were "at war" with the forces of totalitarianism in this hemisphere.
The Army Corps of Engineers contended yesterday that a hurricane striking New York Harbor could cause $5,000,000,000 in damage and flood 23 per cent of the city's total land area.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- The Justice Department clarified today its role in the decision by three major railroads serving the South to end segregation in their station facilities.

TOM McNEELEY has been depicted as a sacrificial lamb about to be placed on the altar of the pugilistic gods so that Floyd Patterson, the high priest, can chop him to bits. This ceremonial bloodletting is to take place in Toronto on Dec. 4. That's what the script says, anyway.

Directors of Investors Diversified Services, Inc., a $4,000,000,000 Minneapolis investment company complex, voted yesterday to split the company's class A common and ordinary common stock ten for one.

Despite a disastrous fire last winter, the Navy's new attack carrier Constellation will he commissioned here next week a better ship than the one originally planned, her commanding officer said yesterday.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Oct. 17 -- South Africa's general election campaign ended quietly today. South Africans will vote tomorrow for a new Parliament.

LONDON, Oct. 17 -- Britain's Foreign Secretary proposed today a "free vote, internationally supervised" in East and West Germany on whether the country should be united or divided as a final settlement of the German problem.
President Kennedy's call for a "national solution" to the problem of mental retardation was challenged last night by Dr. Leonard W. Larson, president of the American Medical Association.
NEW HAVEN, Oct. 17 -Trustees of the New Haven Railroad today amended their request for a $15,000,000 Federally guaranteed loan to keep the carrier running for another year.
MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 17 (AP) -- Dade County voted today to retain its strong central government.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 17 -- Film critics were applauding today the premiere of Ingmar Bergman's "most important" production, "Through a Glass Darkly."
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 25 cents a bale up to 50 cents off yesterday.
A major political fight with religious overtones over proposed Amendment 6 to the State Constitution came into the open yesterday.
BOSTON, Oct. 17 -- Distributors of the nation's consumer goods and services predicted today that leisure and convenience would play an important part in merchandising ten and twenty years from now.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 17 -- A representative of the Congo hinted today that his country would seek aid from the Soviet Union to crush Moise Tshombe, President of secessionist Katanga Province, unless the United Nations acted against him.

PARIS, Oct. 17 -- Thousands of Algerian Moslems clashed violently with the French police and security forces here tonight. At least two Moslems were officially reported killed and scores of persons were believed to have been injured.
Thirteen members of the Gallo gang, now held in $25,000 bail each as material witnesses, sought their freedom in lower bail yesterday before State Supreme Court Justice Louis L. Friedman.

Premier Khrushchev continued his war of nerves against the free world when he spoke for more than six hours to the Communist Party Congress in Moscow yesterday. In doing so, he has momentarily eased some of the tension he himself has created on the German issue by hinting broadly that he has given up his plan to sign a separate peace treaty with East Germany by the end of the year.
A SUCCESSFUL swindle plus good technique gave declarer his contract plus an overtrick in this deal, but the defense was not very keen.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) -- The American Newspaper Publisher Association protested today a proposed order by the Federal Communications Commission on the ground that it would increase substantially press costs for news wires leased from the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

Total net assets of the One William Street Fund rose to $294,100,000, or $14.72 a share, on Sept. 30, the fund announced yesterday in its nine-month report. The net asset value a share was the highest ever reported by the fund.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) -- "It's all very short and sweet," the voice of Irvin C. Scarbeck said today on a rumbling tape recording. "I was given the treatment. It's right out of the book."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- It would be fun to be a Communist for a day at the Soviet Party Congress now going on in Moscow.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 17 -- Seventy-four governments announced today their pldeges of funds for United Nations programs for economic aid to less developed countries in 1962.
ANKAR, Turkey, Oct. 17 -- Rival party leaders exchanged proposals today on coalition support to provide Turkey's new Parliament with a working majority.
Twenty-four cases involving rodent infestation were brought to Housing Court yesterday the Health Department.
The Leningrad Philharmonic Orchestra will make its first American tour in the fall of 1962 to give thirty concerts in the eastern half of North America.

DURING the four years preceding his death in 1954 the great French painter Henri Matisse made a large number of pasted gouaches. These brilliant constellations of color and form were intended as designs for murals, stained-glass windows, and church vestments.
French and United States shipping leaders, in an unusual arrangement, have agreed to limit the competition of their two superliners through an alternating schedule.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 17 -- Secretary of the Treasury Douglas Dillon declared here today that the Administration planned a balanced budget next year.
Community leaders made public yesterday a long-awaited master plan for the Jamaica section of Queens.
On Nov. 7 the voters of New York State are to approve or reject a proposed amendment to Article 10 of the State Constitution for which there has been as yet no adequate public discussion.
Johnny Kucks, a former Yankee, was purchased yesterday by the Baltimore Orioles from their Rochester farm club.

Motel City, a complex of three buildings running through the middle of the blocks between Tenth and Eleventh Avenues from Fortieth to Forty-third Street, has been sold by the builders for a reported price of $10,000,000.

I was rather surprised at your editorial of Oct. 3 "Hail Wisconsin!" approving the action of Wisconsin in making seat belts compulsory in cars. Although I'll agree that seat belts reduce the chance of injury or death to the user. I see practically no chance that the use of such belts by anyone will keep him from injuring someone else.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 17 -- The United States team gained its' third straight international jumping triumph of the Pennsylvania National Horse Show tonight.
PARIS, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Igor Markevitch, who has led the Lamoureux Concert Orchestra for three years, said today he had decided to resign his post.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- More than 500 jet and propeller-driven aircraft were given or sold to Yugoslavia during the Eisenhower and Truman Administrations, the White House said today.
PARIS, Oct. 17 -- In a preliminary and unofficial assessment today of Premier Khrushchev's speech, Paris discerned some encouraging signs for improved East-West relations.

MOSCOW, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Premier Khrushchev referred in his address to the Communist party congress today to the Communist doctrine that a struggle is inevitable between imperialist states, seeing in it a division in the Western alliance.

Communists and conservatives are being barred from speaking at two of the city's public colleges trader circumstances that impair their standing as citadels for the free exchange of ideas. Queens College has nullified an invitation by the student Marxist Discussion Club for a campus speech by Benjamin J. Davis, the Communist party's national secretary.

TUNIS, Oct. 17 -- The first public high-level meeting between officials of the United States State Department and the Algerian rebel Provisional Government took place today when G. Menen Williams, Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, lunched here with two Algerian Ministers.
An effort to win immediate City Council action to restrict political fund-raising methods was rebuffed yesterday.
President William V.S. Tubman of Liberia arrived here yesterday for a visit during which he will confer with President Kennedy and address the United Nations General Assembly.
MOSCOW, Oct. 17 -- Premier Khrushchev said today that he would withdraw his deadline for a German peace treaty this year if the Western powers showed readiness to negotiate on Berlin and Germany.

WHEN Eugene Burdick is not busy at his official task as an associate professor of political science at the University of California at Berkeley, he is busier still writing books and gathering the material for them. His novel about politics, "The Ninth Wave," did not cause much literary excitement.
PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 17--The undergraduate editor who intended to transform Princeton's eighty-year-old humor magazine. The Tiger, into a publication of serious articles and fiction has resigned.

JERSEY CITY, Oct. 17 -- Tens of thousands of persons turned out in Newark and Jersey City today to cheer former President Dwight D. Eisenhower as he campaigned for James P. Mitchell, the Republican candidate for Governor.

SIDNEY FOSTER is one of the brilliant young American pianists of the 1940's who has developed into a mature and interesting artist. Last night at Carnegie Hall he showed this again not only by how he played but also by what he played.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 17 -- Sam M. Fleming, president of the Third National Bank in Nashville, Tenn., today was elected president of the American Bankers Association at the association's eighty-seventh annual convention being held here this week.

DETROIT, Oct. 17 -- Walter P. Reuther made it clear today that he expected the Chrysler Corporation to follow the pattern of the recent labor settlements by the Ford Motor Company and the General Motors Corporation.
The twenty-second Soviet Communist party congress, which opened yesterday, continues a tradition Soviet historians trace to a small clandestine meeting in Minsk in March, 1898.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- The United States Ambassador to Canada, Livingston T. Merchant, has been appointed President Kennedy's personal representative in the effort to solve the Pakistan-Afghanistan border dispute.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:I address myself to the item appearing in The Times on Oct. 10 in which an account is given of an inspection conducted by Manhattan Borough President Edward R. Dudley of "three East Harlem slum buildings."
One of the nation's best-known touch-football players told a dinner of sports champions last night that Americans were losing their old stamina and vigor and that something should he done about it.
Moved by the Columbia College football team's 50-0 defeat of Brown and 11-0 triumph over Yale, thirteen Barnard girls have formed a Columbia cheering section.

WHAT a keen observer and acute psychologist Eugene O'Neill was! More than forty years ago, in a play called "Diff'rent," he brought to agonized life a woman betrayed by her repressions. In its perception his work presaged the explorations of some of our ablest contemporary playwrights.
Willie Naulls was re-elected captain of the New York Knickerbockers yesterday. He had the job last year on a game-to-game basis.
PARIS, Oct. 15 -- The influence of the Paris fashion salons, already the most formidable in the world, will take an important step to the east today.

American designers are now showing their spring collections to stores, preceding the openings in Paris and Italy. Spring fashions are not shown in Europe until January and February. General trends of the new designs are described below. The clothes will be in stores by about the first of the year.
Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz said yesterday he would demand the immediate ouster of School Superintendent John J. Theobald if elected Mayor on Nov. 7.
LONDON, Oct. 17 -- The Duke of Edinburgh told British business men today that they were leading their country to a defeat as bad as any lost military campaign.
Allen Co., a leading New York investment firm, has announced the formation of a new French investment banking concern in which it has a significant participation.
LONDON, Oct. 17 -- British European Airways was given permission today to cut single night fares to the equivalent of $8.42 for the 400-odd miles between London and Glasgow, Edinburgh or Belfast.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- President Urho K. Kekkonen of Finland said today that his country must hold the confidence of the Soviet Union to realize its possibilities for close cooperation with the West.
Mayor Wagner announced a three-point program yesterday for curbing crime and juvenile delinquency and for making the city's streets and parks safer.

To each of the thirty-three players, the manager and other personnel of the Yankees who were voted full shares, victory in the recent world series was worth $7,389 and change. Although losing to the New Yorkers in five games, thirty members of the Cincinnati Reds organization earned $5,356 each plus breakage.
United Nations policy in the Congo has been incomprehensible to many students of international affairs.

A number of Eastern supermarket chains are considering marketing their own brands of cigarettes. This was disclosed yesterday by Louis A. Bantle, president of the United States Tobacco Company. He said that his company was negotiating with some supermarket chains concerning the possibility of manufacturing the cigarettes for the retail food outlets.
Independence lowered the course record by two seconds at Aqueduct yesterday as he won the $28,050 Grand National Steeplechase Handicap by half a length from Peal.
A bill that would exempt restaurant meals up to $1.50 from the 5 per cent sales tax was introduced in the City Council yesterday. The exemption now applies to meals up to $1.

Public Service Electric and Gas Company borrowed $50,000,000 in the public capital market yesterday at an interest cost of 4.629 per cent a year. The money was raised through the competitive sale of twenty-year debentures that went to Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., on a bid of 101.57 per cent for the securities as 4 3/4 per cent obligations.
Business picked up in the high-grade bond market yesterday. The reappearance of bidders generally gave prices a slight lift.

HOUSTON, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Mac Speedie resigned today as the end coach of the Houston Oilers of the American Football League. Speedie's resignation left the new head coach, Wally Lemm, with only two assistants.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 17 -- Chancellor Adenauer challenged the restive Christian Democratic Union today to find a candidate to succeed him. In the showdown, his party backed down.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 17 -- William E. Miller, the Republican national chairman, called today on President Kennedy to make "a clear statement" of United States policy toward Berlin.

The Western discussions on Berlin are like a four-wheeled vehicle. The two front wheels of the United States and Great Britain are turning smoothly but there is a brake on the two back wheels of Germany and France. The extent to which the West is being hampered by differences of opinion becomes dismayingly clear at the moment Premier Khrushchev propounds his one-man, one-party policy from his rostrum in the Kremlin.
Six fires were set at the Sheraton-Atlantic Hotel last night, four of them while fire marshals were in the hotel.

Following is a condensed version of the speech yesterday to the Soviet Communist party's twenty-second congress by Premier Khrushchev, as transmitted in English by Tass, the Soviet press agency. Part of the condensed version is in quotation and part in paraphrase.
It seems to me that I detect a curious inconsistency in your juxtaposed editorial comments on Ghana and Spain in The Times of Oct. 4.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 17 (UPI)--Five Negro players on the Boston Celtics and two on the St. Louis Hawks teams of the National Basketball Association left town tonight after they were refused meal service at the hotel at which they were staying.

The St. Charles West, an apartment development covering ten acres in Elmhurst, Ill., a suburb of Chicago, has been purchased by Jack P. Schleifer and Eugene L. Colman, New York realty investors. The price was $3,000,000.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17 (UPI) -- John F. Gordon, president of General Motors Corporation, said tonight that self-styled safety experts and "amateur engineers" were trying to impose Federal regulation of vehicle design on the automotive industry in an "unrealistic" approach to traffic safety.
A medical controversy that up to now has occupied only a small circle of allergists in the United States -- principally a group in Boston -- erupted into international proportions here yesterday.

CHILDREN may ice skate without charge on Saturday mornings at the Wellman Memorial Skating Rink in Central Park. The free session, from 10 A.M. to 1 P.M., is also held on holidays and during school vacations.
CHICAGO, Oct. 17 (AP) -- The grain futures markets finished mostly lower today with losses in soybeans ranging up to more than a cent a bushel. Oats were independently strong and rye was mixed.

A noteworthy series of revivals of old Paramount films will start tomorrow at the uptown New Yorker theatre, with "Double Indemnity" and the W.C. Fields farce, "It's a Gift," as the opening double bill.
It is incredible that this city of eight million people can be tied up as it was with the Columbus Day parade.

In his "Revolt on the Campus," a survey of political ideas held by American undergraduates, which will be published on Nov. 13 by Regnery, M. Stanton Evans has reached some controversially conservative conclusions.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Prince Souvanna Phouma, Premier-designate of a proposed coalition to unify and neutralize Laos, said today "I am a good friend to Communists abroad, but I do not like them at home."
The Transport Workers Union has eliminated from its constitution all references to its affiliation with the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations.
CHICAGO, Oct. 17 -- The American Civil Liberties Union will stay out of Chicago's efforts to suppress Henry Miller's "Tropic of Cancer," a spokesman said today.
THE true hero of contemporary America is the doctor, according to 1,200 college students.
The Department of Justice started an investigation yesterday of possible antitrust violations in the gasoline price differential between New York City and Nassau County.
Motor, rubber and electronic issues moved up yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange but small losses were fairly common in other groups and the market as a whole was down a trifle.

EMILE BAUME, the French pianist whose many appearances here in the Nineteen Thirties and Forties were highly regarded, returned last night to Town Hall to give his first New York recital in fourteen years.
EASTVIEW, N.Y., Oct. 17 -- Federal officials rejected final appeals by friends of an Indian physician today that he be allowed to remain in this country.
DEERFIELD, Mass., Oct. 17 -- Since there is no pre-season practice at Deerfield Academy, getting varsity football squads in top condition as quickly as possible is an important matter.

Although the stock market in recent weeks has been considerably less than spectacular -- "grinding around" is one common description on Wall Street -- something pretty spectacular has been happening behind the scenes in market trading.
Two restaurants, said by the District Attorney's office to be doing a policy business of $1,500 a day, were raided by the police yesterday. Five persons were arrested.
The nation's leading store chains increased their sales in September 6.3 per cent above the 1960 level, according to a survey yesterday by the New York Times.
Five new programs in support of the visual arts, providing almost $1,500,000, were announced yesterday by the Ford Foundation.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 17 -- Mike Turnesa, the Knollwood, professional, and Dave Taddeo of Mount Kisco C.C. won the final one-day pro-amateur tournament of the Westchester County Golf Association season today. With a best-ball 34, 30 -- 64, seven under par, they triumphed by one stroke.

William F. Buckley Jr., editor of The National Review, which has been prohibited from conducting forums at Hunter College, charged yesterday that the college's new policy constituted discrimination against the publication.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 17 (AP) -- Leroy Plowman, a 26-year-old rider from Monroeville, Pa., was reported in fair condition at a hospital today after surgery for head injuries suffered in the horse show last night.

MOOSE RIVER, Me., Oct. 17 -- The forces of nature have a devilish sense of humor. A week ago when the upland bird season should have been at its peak with frosty fall weather, it was unspeakably warm. As if to show that they can really arrange things as they should be, these same forces have sent along December-like freezing weather and snow for the opening of the deer season in this portion of Maine.

There may be a delay in the razing of the Hudson Theatre, 139-41 West Forty-fourth Street. The playhouse recently was sold by the National Broadcasting Company for $1,150,000 to Samuel Lehrer, garage builder and operator, who intends to build a garage on the site.

Ribbons in warm Oriental hues formed the canopy and walls of a huge tent in which several hundred international diplomatic and social leaders and their guests danced at the Hope Ball last evening. The red, cerise, yellow and shocking-pink scene was the ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17--The United States called upon the Soviet Union tonight to reconsider the planned explosion of a fifty-megaton atomic weapon.
A preview of a new trade-promotion film about the movement of export freight through the New York-New Jersey port was held for the press yesterday by the Port of New York Authority.
EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Oct. 17 (UPI) -- The X-15 rocket ship set a speed record of 3,920 miles an hour for controlled aircraft today.
TORONTO, Oct. 17 (Canadian Press) -- Fair Juror, a 4-year-old Canadian bred geld ing, set a world record of 1:14 3/5 for six and a half furlongs in winning today's fourth race at New Woodbine Park.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 17 -- The Del Miller-trained entry of Apex Hanover and Lullwater Frost was established as the early-line favorite at 3-1 to win the second Westbury Futurity this Friday night at Roosevelt Raceway.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- The general feeling in the Administration today was that Premier Khrushchev had moderated the tone if not the substance of his stand on Berlin and Germany.
NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 17 -- A stiff electoral battle loomed today for one of the most controversial figures in India, Defense Minister V.K. Krishna Menon.

At the annual banquet of the Holland Society of New York, to be held at the Summit on Nov. 3, Dr. Detlev W. Bronk, president of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research, will receive the society's gold medal for distinguished achievement.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 17 -- The slingshot passer whose presence or absence could be the determining factor in Saturday's football clash between Syracuse and Penn State was carrying his left arm in a sling today.

The New York State central school district composed of Paris, Bridgewater and Litchfield in Oneida and Herkimer County borrowed $1,150,000 in the bond market yesterday.
A total of 1,116 persons were injured in car accidents last week, the Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday. This was an increase of thirty-six over the like period last year.
ROME, Oct. 17 -- Senator Luigi Einaudi, second President of the Italian republic, was recovering in a private nursing home here today from what was described as "cardiovascular disturbances."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- The Methodist Board of Missions has sent a telegram to the Secretary of State protesting the arrest by the Portuguese of four Methodist missionaries in Angola.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 17 -- Britain and France received praise today from a former African colony for their "humanitarian activities" as colonial powers.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Oct. 17 (AP) -- Paul Hornung, the leading scorer in the National Football League, was called to active duty by the Army today, together with Ray Nitschke, his team-mate on the Green Bay Packers.

Although sales of the General Foods Corporation for the quarter ended on Sept. 30 fell from the level of the 1960 period, volume for the first six months of this fiscal year registered an increase, the food and grocery producer reported yesterday.

MONTEREY, Cal., Oct. 17 -The vanguard of machinists and drivers who will compete in next Sunday's Pacific Grand Prix for sports cars arrived in this old town beside the ocean today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (UPI) -- Representatives of the National Football Foundation notified President Kennedy today that he was the winner of the organization's annual Gold Medal Award.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17 (AP) -- An airline pilot urged today that an emergency landing fields in the United States be equipped to accommodate jet airliners when faulty hydraulic equipment prevents them from lowering their wheels.

BERLIN, Oct. 17 -- East Germany reacted with disappointment to Premier Khrushchev's announcement today that the signing of an East German peace treaty may be postponed beyond the year-end deadline the Soviet leader had originally set.

PARAMUS, N.J., Oct. 17 -- Mrs. Joseph Cralle of Montclair paced the Women's New Jersey Golf Association team to a 32 -- 13 victory over Westchester and Fairfield County for the Mrs. J.J. Thomson Trophy today at the Arcola Country Club.
HARTFORD, Oct. 17 -- George J. Ritter, an incumbent councilman, led the field in a non-partisan primary today for the city council election on Nov. 7.

Reports of sporadic anti-Government violence in Communist North Vietnam should not raise any great expectations of an immediate or extensive revolt against the regime. Widespread discontent does exist in the North, where failures in farm production similar to those in Communist China have resulted in drastic food shortages and general suffering; but the Northern regime's toughness, determination and totalitarian controls make it very difficult for malcontents to build a successful insurrectionary movement.
The Chicago and North Western Railway cleared $501,079 last month on operating revenues of $18,392,353. In the 1960 month the road lost $679,416 on revenues of $16,763,026.

The possibility that a new syndicate would build a 12-Meter yacht as a defense candidate for the America's Cup developed yesterday. It was reported that if such a craft were built for the match against Australia next September, Raymond C. Hunt, the Boston naval architect, would be her designer.
Two employes of a Lower East Side winery died yesterday, apparently of toxic fumes from a fourteen-foot vat in which grape mash was fermenting.

JEROME ROBBINS' "Ballets: U.S.A." presented the second program of its season at the ANTA Theatre last night. It consisted of new work, "Events," with music by Robert Prince and decors by Ben Shahn; and three works previously presented by other companies: "The Cage," "Afternoon of a Faun" and "Interplay."
MOSCOW, Oct. 17 -- Premier Khrushchev said today that the Soviet Union was moving closer to the day when it would score an economic victory of "world-historical" magnitude over the United States.
A rebellious faction of the National Collegiate Track Coaches Association is making a pitch to dislodge the Amateur Athletic Union as the controlling body of track and field in this country.

Dr. Herbert Axelrod, a vigorous, intense, 34-year-old publisher, has some of the world's best fish stories to tell, and his believing audience has included, among others, school boys, an emperor, a former prime minister and assorted ichthyologists.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Oct. 17 (AP) -- The National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today it had postponed indefinitely the first flight test of the saturn super-booster in order to make refinements in the control system.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 17 -- The United States warned the General Assembly today against being "tricked" into accepting an uninspected moratorium on nuclear tests after Moscow explodes its planned fifty-megaton nuclear device.

Volume and earnings of the B.F. Goodrich Company in the first nine months of the year were below those of a year earlier, the company reported yesterday. However, sales and earnings for the third quarter were above the 1960 levels.
Two former postal clerks at the United Nations were indicted here yesterday on charges of grand larceny. They were accused of stealing $20,000 from the sale of stamps.

Shulton, Inc., cosmetics and toiletries manufacturer of Clifton, N.J., will acquire all the assets of the Aerosol Corporation of America, Wellesley Hills, Mass., in exchange for 30,769 shares of Shulton stock.
Two new measures intended to curb irregularities and improve the efficiency of the school repair program were disclosed yesterday by Max J. Rubin, president of the Board of Education.
NEWARK, Oct. 17 -- A brush fire burned over a seven-acre area most of the afternoon today.

New York City needs a new Mayor. Of the several candidates available, there is no doubt in our minds that Louis J. Lefkowitz is the man to elect. He is a hard worker, intelligent, conscientious, of proven ability in public office. He is a man of warm sympathies and strong convictions backed by political courage and long political experience.
The City Planning Commission took initial steps yesterday toward rehabilitating a fifty-four block area of upper Manhattan.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 18 -- Rudolph A. Peterson, San Francisco and Hawaii banker, has been named vice chairman of the Bank of America, it was announced yesterday by S. Clark Beise, president.
Firmness prevailed in the high-grade bond market yesterday, with evidence of broadening demand visible particularly among United States Government securities of short and intermediate term.

THE New York Knickerbockers were scrimmaging at a furious pace on the basketball court in the Fordham gymnasium yesterday morning when a photographer arrived. He studied the scurrying characters for a moment.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 18 -- If admission to Harvard were based solely on outstanding academic ability, some of the college's most distinguished alumni probably would not have made the grade or even wanted to come, according to Wilbur J. Bender, former Dean of Admissions.
James P. Mitchell, the Republican candidate for Governor of New Jersey, joined last night in helping to start $100,000 campaign against juvenile delinquency here.

John Fraser, an English actor who has been seen here in several British motion pictures, has been selected to play the title role in a television dramatization of Oscar Wilde's "The Picture of Dorian Gray."

MOSCOW, Oct. 18 -- Premier Khrushchev called today for the unity of the Communist bloc in its final drive to defeat capitalism. He spoke on the second day of the twenty-second congress of the Soviet Communist party.

A display of national flags and a mammoth reproduction of the United Nations Seal will set the theme for the Salute to the United Nations Ball in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria next Tuesday, United Nations Day.

In your editorial of Oct. 6 "The Palestine Refugees" you ask, in apparent disbelief, whether the children of refugees are also refugees. The answer is yes. All international and governmental agencies dealing with refugees have accepted this fact.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Oct. 18 -- President Ngo Dinh Diem placed South Vietnam in a "state of emergency" today. He took this action a few hours before holding the first of a series of conferences with Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, the head of a United States mission studying ways in which Washington can assist the South Vietnamese Government in meeting the increasingly serious Communist threat.

The police yesterday seized four men suspected of operating a policy racket in a Bronx tenement apartment with a weekly intake of $250,000. Ten adding machines were found on the premises. One of the suspects suffered a heart attack and was taken to a hospital.
The Liberal party, which is backing Mayor Wagner, urged yesterday that the city be given the right to tap revenues of The Port of New York Authority and Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority.
Angry Greenwich Villagers caused an uproar in City Hall yesterday when the City Planning Commission designated their neighborhood a blighted area suitable for urban renewal.
TALLAHASSE, Fla., Oct. 18 -- "The Last Days of Lincoln," first play by the Pulitzer Prizewinning poet Mark Van Doren, had its world premiere here tonight.

The Texas Railroad Commission continued yesterday an eight-day producing pattern for November for the seventh consecutive month. The commission estimated production next month at 2,706,095 barrels a day, an increase of 48,548 from this month.

A 27-year-old Manhattan man who, the police said, was carrying seventeen ounces of pure heroin was arrested by narcotics squad detectives yesterday. They said the heroin was worth $300,000 at current street-sale prices.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 18 -- Cyprus proposed today establishment of a permanent military force "enrolled by and for the United Nations.
The Emma Willard School in Troy, N.Y., will benefit from a performance of Mozart's "Cosi Fan Tutte" at the City Center on Oct. 25, which is national Emma Willard Day.

No team that has won the Ivy League title since its formal beginning in 1956 has lost more than one league game during the season of seven Ivy games. If this is to become a continuing tradition there are three teams considered to be contenders that will have to watch their P's and Q's Satur day or else suffer Ivy loss No. 2 of the year.
City Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa said yesterday that 3 per cent of the budget could be saved "in any business without curbing services and without layoffs."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP) -- A nation-wide women's "strike for peace" will be staged Nov. 1 to dramatize the belief that the world must "move back from the brink of war if humanity is to survive."
CHICAGO, Oct. 18 (AP) -An explosion in a chemical-blending building of a cosmetics company rocked a ten-mile area of Chicago's West Side today, injuring more than 250 persons. There were no deaths.

Col. Frank Foster Davis of Alexandria, Va., a dog show judge since 1922, said yesterday that the breed to which a dog belonged had no bearing on his temperament. He thought it wrong for any person to condemn a specific breed because of a bad impression gained through one or two experiences.

Consolidated net income of the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation for the nine months ended on Sept. 30, 1961, was $28,492,355, or $1.85 a share, compared with $27,439,003, or $1.77 a share, for the 1960 period.
IT has been said that brilliant plays in contract bridge are just a matter of considering what cards other players may hold, then playing accordingly.
BLOOMFIELD, Conn., Oct. 18 (AP) -- The Air Force claimed a new world altitude record today for an H-43B Huskie rescue helicopter that climbed to 32,000 feet.
The work of the Peace Corps in Nigeria will not be affected by the repercussions over a postcard written by a young American teacher, R. Sargent Shriver, the corps director, said yesterday.
LONDON, Oct. 18 -- The tone of the stock market here continued to be relatively cheerful today, although net changes among the industrial sections were irregular and small.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk indicated today that the United States was impatient over the delay in negotiating new executive arrangements with the Soviet Union for the United Nations.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP) Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen, Republican of Illinois, said today the Kennedy Administration "is floundering" and had not solved "the question of our national direction."
NEW HAVEN, Oct. 18 -Dr. Willis E. Lamb Jr., a Nobel Prize winner, has been appointed the first Henry Ford 2d Professor f Physics at Yale University.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Wednesday, Oct. 11:
CHICAGO, Oct. 18 (AP) -The reo of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows;

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Oct. 18 (UPI) -- Gene Fullmer of West Jordan, Utah, and Benny (Kid) Paret of Cuba were matched today in a Dec. 9 bout for Gene's National Boxing Association middleweight championship.

THE wife of a Fifth Avenue store president was photographed in her handsome white chiffon ball gown and the picture appeared in a familiar publication. An actress wore a high fashion dress on a national television program.
The Army's new M-14 rifle is a good case history of bureaucracy. After almost fifteen years in development it is just being issued in quantity.

IN the good old innocent days -- a generation ago, let's say -- Bach masses were done with immense choral forces, a large orchestra and perhaps an organ thrown in. Then the scholars began to work on performance practices in Bath's own day.
The Public Health Service is initiating a medical self-help training program here to teach Americans how to survive a national disaster, especially a nuclear bomb attack.
Portugal said here last night[ that the had revoked authoriza-! tion for the United Nations to l fly planes over Portuguesel AfiScan territory en route tol the Congo.
DETROIT, Oct. 18 (AP) -The Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile Workers broke off negotiations today on a working agreement for a key plant.

POTTSVILLE, Pa., Oct. 18 (AP) -- The burglary trial of Lillian Reis ended in a hung jury tonight after the panel of five women and seven men was unable to reach a verdict in sixteen and one-half hours of deliberation over a two-day period.

HARDIN, Mont., Oct. 18 (AP) -- Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall called today for cooperation by private power companies with the Federal Government to make all the power capacity in this area more valuable and economical.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Following are the texts of opening statements by Secretary of State Dean Rusk at his news conference today and excerpts from questions and answers at the conference:
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 18 (AP) -- The Franklin Institute honored tonight seventeen scientists from the United States and Europe.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -Secretary of State Dean Rusk rejected today military disengagement in Central Europe as a solution to the crisis over Berlin and Germany.

LONDON, Oct. 18 -- The Earl of Listowel, former Governor General of Ghana, said today that it was the British Government's constitutional duty to cancel or postpone Queen Elizabeth II's visit to Ghana next month if there was the slightest fear for her safety.
Cafe society, having ignored rock 'n' roll for years, has suddenly, by an apparent process of mass hypnosis, embraced the teen-age craze.
Black Thumper, a sleek-as-silk 4-year-old gelding, closed powerfully in the middle of the track at Aqueduct yesterday and won the $27,550 Nassau County Handicap by two and a half lengths.

WARSAW, Oct. 17 -- Communism is weakened in its ideological struggle with the West by needless clinging to dictatorial ways in the areas it controls, in the view of Poland's senior Marxist philosopher, Adam Schaff.

Premier Khrushchev's declaration of confidence that the Soviet Union would soon outproduce the United States appeared to be based upon the success his country has had in narrowing the United States' production advantage.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- In the name of Lyndon, the Compassionate, the Beneficent, the Well-Publicized, here we indite the moving tale of L.B.J. and the poor Camel-Driver of Karachi:

PURCHASE, N.Y., Oct. 18 -- The Harrison Town Planning Board reported today its disapproval of an application by the International Business Machines Corporation for permission to build a world headquarters or other large office structure on thirty-eight acres of old estates here.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 18 -- A number of informal remarks attributed to high-ranking United States officials are as much behind Bonn's current fears about American policy toward Germany as any formal suggestions made by Washington.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 18 -- The General Assembly's Political Committee decided today to take up the question of prohibiting nuclear tests as the first item on its agenda.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 18 (AP) -- Eight locals of the United Automobile Workers rejected today a proposal by the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company to extend its present labor contract for a year without change.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -The Atomic Energy Commission has begun a survey into how much time and money it would take to restore the Eniwetok proving grounds for atomic tests in the atmosphere.

LONDON, Oct. 18 -- The board of directors of the Cunard Steamship Company, Ltd., met today in Liverpool amid widespread and widely credited rumors that the line was abandoning the idea of replacing the aging Queen Mary with a new 75,000-ton liner.

An affiliate of the Sire (Small Investors Real Estate) Plan has started construction of a seven-story hotel with 139 rooms on Ditmars Boulevard, near Grand Central Parkway, at La Guardia Airport. The building will be known as La Guardia East and will cost $2,500,000.

TEANECK, N.J., Oct. 18 -- A proposal for a $450,000,000 system to provide direct railroad transportation from northeastern New Jersey to New York was made public today by the Teaneck Township Council.
Twenty-five members of the City College faculty have declared their opposition to the City University's decision to bar Communist speakers from the seven municipal colleges temporarily.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP) -- United States diplomats have been asked to cut down on long-winded dispatches.
John J. Gilhooley, the Republican candidate for Controller, made a pitch for the "Gilhooley vote" yesterday by inviting every New Yorker with that name to a reception at the Commodore Hotel.
The Association of Reform Rabbis of New York City and vicinity said yesterday that the candidates for Mayor had "engaged in little more than name-calling and accusation."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Pan American World Airways asked the Civil Aeronautics Board today to grant it non-stop authority between New York and Jamaica.

For the last few weeks Assistant District Attorney Leonard Newman has shuddered whenever he heard his telephone ring. The reason: He has been receiving forty to fifty calls a day from women who want him to help them get their fur coats back.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Oct. 18 (AP) -- Policemen attacked student demonstrators with clubs tonight in one of the worst flare-ups of violence since the assassination of Generalissimo Rafael Leonidas Trujillo Molina last May.

WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 18 (AP) -- Honolulu Oil Corporation, which got started fifty-three years ago because of scarcity of the then new fuel, sold out today -- because there is too much oil on the world market.

THE comforts and rewards for the gangster who knows how to make crime pay attracted David Brinkley's droll irony last night on his program over Channel 4. It was a good way to call attention to the hoodlums now enjoying the veneer of respectability.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (UPI) -- An attorney for sixteen Negro sit-in demonstrators told the Supreme Court today that their conviction on charges of disturbing the peace in Baton Rouge, La., last year was unconstitutional.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (UPI) -- Personal income rose in September because of employment gains in some lines and pay increases required by the new minimum wage law, according to the Commerce Department.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Thursday, Oct. 19 -- The white-supremist Government led by Prime Minister Hendrik F. Verwoerd won a new five-year term in yesterday's general election.
BOSTON, Oct. 18 -- The 46,000-ton tanker Monticello Victory was named here today in a shipboard ceremony at the Bethlehem Steel Company's East Boston yard.
City police protection for some of the interior areas of Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village took effect at 4 P.M. yesterday. The protection had been promised by Mayor Wagner on Tuesday.
BERLIN, Oct. 18 -- Three East Berlin women aged from 54 to 78 staged a daring escape into the French sector by automobile today.

JERSEY CITY, Oct. 18 -- The Duncan Apartments, where the late Mayor Frank Hague formerly lived, and the Gothic Towers, another large Jersey City apartment house, have been sold for $2,100,000, it has been announced.
Forlornly sitting on a fourteen-foot ice pedestal in the Arctic Ocean is an abandoned transport plane.

A Brooklyn Supreme Court Justice paved the way yesterday for two members of the Gallo gang to get their freedom by reducing their $25,000 bail to $10,000. They have been held as material witnesses in the borough's crime inquiry.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (UPI) -- The National Aeronautics and Space Administration fired a 278-pound payload ninety-five miles over Wallops Island, Va., today to test behavior of liquid hydrogen under conditions, of "zero gravity."
A university senior and three musicians were arrested yesterday after a quantity of heroin was said to have been found in an automobile in which they were seated at Eighty-fourth Street and Broadway.

Don Schwall, a fifteen-game winner despite the fact that he didn't join the Boston Red Sox until May 21, was the overwhelming choice yesterday of the United Press International's board of baseball experts as the American League's rookie of the year.
DETROIT, Oct. 18 -- Ford announced today that it would grant pay increases and other benefits to most of its 49,000 salaried employes.

HAVANA, Oct. 18 (AP) -President Osvaldo Dorticos Torrado of Cuba today denounced Peruvian and some other Latin American governments, charging that they were "trying to isolate Cuba as a preparatory step to armed attack." He called them puppets of the United States.

DENVER, Oct. 18 (UPI) -- Stockholders of the Argo Oil Corporation will vote at a meeting on Dec. 5 on whether or not to accept the offers of the Atlantic Refining Company and several other concerns to purchase all of Argo's producing and nonproducing properties.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (UPI) -- President Kennedy acted today to set up machinery to carry out the sixteen-nation textile agreement reached at Geneva on July 21.

MOSCOW, Oct. 18 -- Premier Khrushchev said today that Soviet economic policy under the Communist party's new twenty-year program would give heavy industry a smaller edge over consumer-goods output than in the past.

President William V.S. Tubman of Liberia said last night that increasing Government revenues were making possible the opening ow two schools a week in his country. President Tubman spoke at a dinner given in his honor at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel by bankers and business men.

President Kennedy sent word to foreign correspondents at the opening of the Foreign Press Center here yesterday that "if our effort helps you in your pursuit of truth, we shall be adequately rewarded."

With city and state investigators still checking differing prices of gasoline in New York City and on Long Island, another company raised its prices to dealers in Nassau and Suffolk counties yesterday.
The State Supreme Court upheld the right of the State Power Authority yesterday to investigate possible fraud or collusion in electrical equipment bids.

TOKYO, Oct. 18 -- The Chinese Communists made public today a speech hailing their "unbreakable" friendship for Albania less than twenty-four hours after Premier Khrushchev had criticized the little East European nation for its espousal of Stalinism.
YORKTOWN HEIGHTS, N.Y., Oct. 18 (AP) -- Residents of this Westchester County community may now construct fall-out shelters without having to pay building-permit fees.
President Urho K. Kekkonen of Finland arrived here yesterday for a four-day visit before setting out on a tour of the country.

At Dallas last Sunday, the football Giants came to life on offense. With Bob Gaiters and Alex Webster running dynamically, the New Yorkers for the first time mounted an honest-to-goodness ground attack in support of Y.A.

TOMS RIVER, N.J., Oct. 18 -- Richard J. Hughes, the Democratic candidate for Governor, today attacked "inconsistencies" and "hypocrisy" in the campaign speeches of James P. Mitchell, his Republican opponent.

THE solid virtues of the ensemble approach to opera -- as opposed to the star system -- were handsomely demonstrated last night at the City Center, as the New York City Opera Company revived its mettlesome production of Mozart's "The Marriage of Figaro."
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 18 (UPI) -- The State Congress of Parents and Teachers urged New York school boards today today to work toward adjustment of school districts that may be racially segregated.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 18 -A leading banker warned here today that the United States faced a "renewed deterioration" in its balance of international payments despite a resurgence of domestic economic activity.

In your Oct. 11 editorial deprecating the presence of Fortune Pope at the Columbus Day celebration you commend the "higher sense of propriety and dignity" evidenced by those who stayed away from the celebration because of Mr. Pope's part in it.
The appointment of Vice Admiral Ralph E. Wilson as vice president of J.J. Henry Co., Inc., naval architects and marine engineers, was announced here yesterday.
The Douglas Aircraft Company reported yesterday that although sales dropped in the quarter ended on Aug. 31, the company operated at a profit, contrasted with a loss in the 1960 quarter.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- A spokesman for New York patent lawyers opposed today legislation limiting patent rights on new prescription drugs to three years. He said this would stifle the incentive to invent the drugs and halt the spread of valuable technological information.

LEONARD WITHINGTON MAYO, chairman of President Kennedy's Committee on Mental Retardation, is a doctor of social science who prefers to be called "mister". He has cut quite a swath in the health and welfare field since he moved into that area from his early work as a high school teacher and director of athletics.

The Presbyterian Home at 49 East Seventy-third Street will be the beneficiary of a recital at Carnegie Hall on Dec. 1 by Galina Vishnevskaya. The Russian soprano is being presented here as part of the State Department's Cultural Exchange Program.
Whither go the New York Knickerbockers in the National Basketball Association this season? Will a new coach and a covey of promising rookies enable them to break their lease on the cellar?

Not since the Cominform's 1948 and 1949 denunciations of Yugoslavia has there been any parallel for Premier Khrushchev's treatment of tiny Communist Albania. In effect the Soviet leader has read the present Albanian Communist leadership out of the Soviet bloc, accusing it of practicing Stalinism at home and supporting Stalinism abroad.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- The Pentagon has again decided to discontinue the production of B-52 strategic bombers next year and to limit investment in developing the B-70, a high-altitude, supersonic bomber.

We are now entering the twelfth year of state rent control of apartments. That law declares that "a serious public emergency continues to exist in the housing of a considerable number of persons" and that there is "an acute shortage of dwellings."
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Oct. 18 (Reuters) -- Iraq will spend $1,558,000,000 in various fields of development under a five-year economic plan outlined here today.

EASTHAMPTON, Mass. Oct. 18 -- Williston Academy's student body, which was composed of only 180 boys when Phillips Stevens became headmaster here in 1949, continues to grow. The enrollment now is 379, the largest since 1846.

PARIS, Oct. 18 -- The French Government announced today that 1,500 Algerian Moslems who participated in last night's riots in the Paris region would be sent immediately to enforced residence in their home villages in Algeria.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- United States aid has undoubtedly helped Yugoslavia to remain independent of the Soviet bloc, Secretary of State Dean Rusk said today.

The Yassky Corporation, a national realty investment company headed by Harold H. Yassky, has contracted to buy the leasehold on a thirty-seven-story office building at 19 Rector Street. The term of the lease with renewal options is 102 years.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Thomas W. Gleason, executive vice president of the International Longshoremen's Association, was elected today to the presidency of the union's Atlantic District Council.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 18 -- Excavations in the ancient Roman city of Petra in Jordan have unearthed a theatre stage and on it a marble figure of Hercules that was caught in an earthquake about 1,500 years ago.

TWENTY-FIVE years ago, a young singer named Perry Como joined a Midwestern band led by Ted Weems. In the years that followed, the group, including Elmo Tanner, Country Washburn, Parker Gibbs and Red Ingle, became one of the most popular musical combinations in the country.

MOSCOW, Oct. 18 (AP) -Accounts in the official Soviet press raised a question today as to exactly what Premier Khrushchev said about setting off a fifty-megaton bomb. The question: Is the Soviet Union going to explode the bomb or is it just a probability?
Oils, drugs, office equipments and a number of the high-price stocks known as "split candidates" led the market on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.
Mayor Wagner appointed a Commissioner of Mental Health Service yesterday and announced other city steps to fight mental illness.
Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower said last night the Western world should capitalize on its "unique" spiritual strength in the "cold war" with the Communist world.

Paperboard production in the nation totaled 349,905 tons in the week ended Saturday, Oct. 14, compared with 349,930 tons in the preceding week, the National Paperboard Association reported yesterday. A year ago 326,613 tons were produced.
EMERSON, N.J., Oct. 18 -For the first time since the state Republican convention in May, the three men who fought bitterly for the party's nomination for Governor appeared together today.
The Inter-American Press Association voted yesterday to ask the Organization of American States "to adopt all corrective measures provided in its charter" against Cuba.

The thermonuclear explosion now promised by Mr. Khrushchev, equivalent in power to 50,000,000 tons of TNT, would be twenty-five hundred times more powerful than the atomic bombs that devastated Hiroshima and Nagasaki. It has some military importance in the dreadful lexicon of Armageddon which is the product of the nuclear age -- but only if deliberately linked to the same kind of terror tactics that Hitler used.
ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 18 -- The sentiments in favor of forming a national coalition Government appeared to gain ground today.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., Oct. 18 -- Communities must organize, plan and sacrifice time and money to promote industrial development, Secretary of Commerce Luther H. Hodges said here tonight.
Seven thousand men will be examined physically each month for the next six months to fill the city's draft quota, Col. Paul Akst, director of Selective Service for New York City, announced yesterday.
Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz promised yesterday that if elected Mayor he would tackle two problems that irritate most New Yorkers -- dirty air and crowded subways.
The Georgia Power Company sold at competitive bidding yesterday $10,000,000 of first mortgage bonds and $7,000,000 of preferred stock in separate transactions.
PARIS, Oct. 18 -- Strikes cut electric power for several hours today over a large part of France. Train service was also disrupted and gas supplies were lowered.
ANYONE can start decorating a room, but not everyone can finish one or knows the art of when to stop.

Premier Khrushchev spelled out yesterday in the greatest detail his and the Soviet Communist party's picture of the future Communist Utopia. It is essentially a picture of a highly developed welfare state, but without the freedom of political choice or the richness of economic choice which are both available now to the hundreds of millions of workers who dwell in the Free World.
LUANG PRABANG, Laos, Oct. 18 -- King Savang Vathana asked Prince Souvanna Phouma today to form a new government. The Prince is the leader of the neutralist faction in Laos.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (UPI) -- The Department of Commerce reported today that new orders for factory durable goods rose in September to their highest level in more than two years. Economists consider new orders a leading business barometer, and an indication of what is ahead for production.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 18 -- Gov. Edmund G. Brown warned today that any community or individual trying to monopolize fall-out shelters in an attack would be opposed by the California National Guard.
Cocoa prices soared yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange, continuing Tuesday's late rally.

The American Electric Power Company reported yesterday that net earnings for September set a record for that month at $4,512,000. This represented an increase of 4.7 per cent from the $4,308,000 cleared for September, 1960.
FAIRFIELD, Calif., Oct. 18 (UPI) -- A small civilian transport plane crashed and burned today, killing the four military men and three civilians aboard.
Governor Rockefeller offered a program yesterday to provide middle-income housing for 1,000,000 persons in 250,000 families here within ten years.
CHICAGO, Oct. 18 (UPI) -- A veteran airline captain charged today that noise abatement procedures were beginning to interfere with safety.

Assets of the United Funds, Inc., a Kansas City, Mo., group of four mutual funds, rose to $1,115,986,150 at the end of the third quarter of 1961 from $774,274,622 a year earlier, it was announced yesterday.

PINEHURST, N.C., Oct. 18 (AP) -- A retired insurance executive, Frank Ross, eliminated the medalist, Egon Quittner of Rydal, Pa., from the North and South senior golf tournament today with a 2-and-1 victory at the Pinehurst Country Club.
A Polish physician who has lived under two names received court permission yesterday to adopt a third.

Dr. John J. Theobald, Superintendent of Schools, was cleared by a Queens grand jury yesterday of anonymous charges that he had used school construction materials to repair his Sands Point, L.I., home.
The pomp and ceremony associated with the convening of the House of Lords and the House of Commons (on October 17 this year) is a spectacle dearly loved by Londoners.
Whether the politically controversial State Investigation Commission report on three officials -- two Democrats and one Republican -- will be made public remained uncertain yesterday.
DALLAS, Oct. 18 (UPI) -Doctors caring for House Speaker Sam Rayburn said today that they were waiting for him to gain strength before they resumed treatment of his cancer.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 18 (AP) -- A camel driver from Pakistan and a former mule skinner from Missouri traded banter today as Bashir Ahmed met with Harry S. Truman.
A bridge party and fashion show will be held Tuesday at the Colony Club to raise funds for St. Christopher's School in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.
Doug Harvey, the player-coach of the New York Rangers, said the other day that his team would have to "skate a lot faster in order to beat Montreal."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct 18 -- If the operations of all of New York City's ticket brokers were combined with those of an important concert management outfit, the result would approximate the unusual Los Angeles firm known as Moss Hayman.

Carl Sandburg, poet, novelist, autobiographer and author of a world-famous biography of Lincoln, is the subject of a new biography, "Carl Sandburg," by his North Carolina friend and neighbor. Harry Golden. Mr. Golden, the editor of The Carolina Israelite, is a practiced hand at reminiscing as he proved in "Only In America" and "For 2c Plain."

BERNARD REDER has a most active and kinetic imagination. His large retrospective exhibition of drawings and prints at the World House Galleries, 987 Madison Avenue, will run, hop and jump through mid-November. His sculptures, reviewed a few Sundays ago, are currently animating the Whitney Museum. So Mr. Reder has come to town.

STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 18 -Hair tints that can be used with almost unlimited frequency and rapidity will be on the market in a few years, according to Lawrence M. Gelb, chairman of the board of Clairol Inc., a manufacturer of hair coloring products.

THERE is a place on Broadway for the kind of bubbling, saucy comedy that is a specialty of the Paris boulevards, particularly if it is an elegant specimen. But "A Shot in the Dark," which opened last night at the Booth, is only a moderately entertaining example of the genre.

SOME people pick lucky numbers, others have lucky days, but Mary Rattray's lucky card has been her key to success. The Queen of Diamonds is both the well-known insigne and the name of Mrs. Rattray's jewelry shop on St. Mark's Place.
The International Rescue Committee elected William J. vanden Heuvel president at a board meeting at the Lotos Club yesterday.

On the wings of a 14-to-0 victory over the University of Delaware last Saturday, Hofstra College soared from sixth to first place yesterday in the poll for the Lambert Cup, emblematic of Eastern small-college football supremacy.

No country has had more remarkable success in coping with problems growing out of the last war than Finland. She was saddled by defeat with heavy reparations to Russia and with nearly half a million refugees from territories seized by the Soviets.

The Alliance Realty Company, I. Jerome Riker, president, announced yesterday that it had bought the Stanhope Hotel at Fifth Avenue and Eighty-first Street from Webb Knapp, Inc. Mr. Riker, who also is president of Riker Co., realty brokers and managers, said the price exceeded $10,000,000. The building is opposite the Metropolitan Museum of Art. It will be converted to a cooperative, Mr. Riker said.
QUITO, Ecuador, Oct. 18 (UPI) -- New political rioting swept two Ecuadoran cities today. The army was called in Cuenca and the police and university students clashed in the streets of Guayaquil.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 18 -- The United States widen its lead in the international team jumping championship tonight when Night Owl, under Frank Chapot of Wallpace N.J., won the fifth consecutive event for the Americans.
A Southern Negro who spoke in defense of Mississippi's segregation laws aroused a Columbia University audience yesterday.
LONDON, Oct. 18 -- The television heroes of British children may be going continental, the British Broadcasting Corporation hinted today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- The Federal Communications Commission ordered a Miami television company today to go off the air Nov. 20 because of its backdoor tactics in obtaining the channel.

The Yankees called up nine young players from the minor leagues yesterday and added them to the club's winter roster. At the same time the world champions reduced their off-season reserve list to the maximum of forty by cutting five other players.
LONDON, Oct. 18 -- The Soviet Union has been convinced that the Western powers are determined not to surrender in the crisis over Berlin, Prime Minister Macmillan declared tonight.
HONG KONG, Oct. 18 -- Premier Khrushchev's opening address to the Twenty-second Congress will put Chinese-Russian relations to a new test, according to observers here.

Strong increases in sales and earnings in both the quarter and nine months ended on Sept. 30 were reported yesterday by the Continental Can Company, a leading producer of metal, paper and glass containers and plastic packaging materials.

During the last several months, the Lehigh Coal and Navigation Company has been disposing Of various assets of its wholly owned subsidiary, the Lehigh and New England Railroad, in a progressive liquidation of the carrier.

The Shell Oil Company, owner of large reserves of natural gas in western Oklahoma, announced yesterday that it would participate in ownership of the new Oklahoma Illinois Gas Pipeline Company. Shell did not disclose the extent of its interests.

Mayor Wagner set in motion a campaign yesterday for the election of two Liberal nominees for the Supreme Court. He said he was ready to stake his "political fate and future" to keep the "bosses" out of the courts.

OUR good neighbors, like ourselves, own some untamed neighborhoods. These are likely to be inaccessible and picturesque. They are worth knowing -- but learning directly about them requires financing, time, stamina and ardor. Fortunately we can take our learning vicariously in such books as Peter Matthiessen's excellent new volume, "The Cloud Forest: A Chronicle of the South American Wilderness. "The range of these travels is astonishing."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 18 -- A preliminary investigation of the plane crash that killed Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold last month "has so far failed to determine any positive causes of the accident," the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland said today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- President Kennedy will make a one-day trip to Arkansas and Oklahoma for the opening of the Ouachita National Forest Road on Oct. 29, the White House announced today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18 (AP) -- Grain futures rallied in the final hour of trading today to finish mostly up. Earlier, both grains and soybeans had declined, reflecting hedge-selling, liquidation and favorable crop news.
LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Oct. 18 -- Mrs. Charles W. Gleason of The Creek Club was re-elected president of the Women's Long Island Golf Association in its annual meeting at the Piping Rock Club today.
