CHICAGO, Oct. 18 -- W. Lyle Bull, executive vice president of American Export Lines, and Capt. R.E. Mackey, assistant manager for operations of the Marine Department of Texaco, Inc., were named here today to head the Marine Section of the National Safety Council.

ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, Oct. 18 (AP) -- An American oil adviser to the Saudi Arabian Government said today that oil-producing countries had a legal right to oversee all major phases of exploitation within their countries by private oil companies.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- A group of top-level business economists believes that the upward trend of the nation's economy will not be so strong next year as the Government's experts predict.
SAN SALVADOR, Oct. 18 -Five major political parties may form a coalition to oppose the military-led National Conciliation party in the December elections.

Regarding your important lead editorial of Sept. 29 "Industry and the I.L.O.": The decision of the National Association of Manufacturers to quit the International Labor Organization may be of deeper import and more far-reaching than ill-serving the business community.

Roosevelt Raceway established two races for 4-year-olds yesterday, one for trotters and one for pacers. The winner of each stands to earn a $50,000 bonus and a brand new trophy. But there is a string or two attached.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 18 (UPI) -- Beauty, a three-year-old chimpanzee at the Cincinnati Zoo, will not be able to attend her own art exhibition in New York next week for the benefit of the Cincinnati Zoological Society.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 18 -- Officials here apparently have put off ratification of a cease-fire agreement between the United Nations and the secessionist Katanga Province in the Congo.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 45 cents a bale up to 25 cents off yesterday. The near months were all higher.
MOSCOW, Oct. 18 -- Premier Khrushchev has used the twenty-second congress of the Soviet Communist party to make public his version of the so-called anti-party plot of 1957.

Production of electric power in the nation rose to 15,125,000,000 kilowatt-hours in the week ended Saturday, Oct. 14, from 15,035,000,000 the preceding week, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. A year before 14,120,000,000 kilowatt-hours were produced.

The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday, pursuant to the Securities and Exchange Act of 1934, the following changes in the holdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed companies. The American Stock Exchange did not issue an insiders' report yesterday.
The Queens District Attorney's office has declared that the facts "do not indicate any violation of the Penal Law of New York" in the case of letters soliciting the votes of three children.

DETROIT, Oct. 18 -- John F. Gordon, president of the General Motors Corporation, told a group of railroad executives today that his company would continue to try to build the best and sell the most Diesel locomotives despite Government antitrust prosecution.
THE age-old fiscal problems of old age will be less acute in the years ahead, an authority on the aging predicted yesterday.
Crucible Steel Company of America reported a gain in third-quarter earnings over second-quarter levels and termed September its "best month in over a year."
United States copper mine production reached 98,666 tons in September, up from 86,316 tons, in August, according to the Copper Institute.
The National Amputation Foundation will hold the "amputee invitation pro-celebrity golf tournament Sunda at the Great River Country Club, Great River, L.I.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP) -- The Post Office Department said today its quiet campaign against obscenity in the mails had shown an increase in arrests and convictions so far this year.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 18 -- Representatives of the United States and the Soviet Union met again tonight but failed to break a deadlock over the appointment of an Acting Secretary General of the United Nations.
Leases taken by law firms in downtown buildings were among space deals reported yesterday.
The San Francisco Forty-Niners have put together a team that looks unbeatable. It is No. 1 in the National Football League in offense and No. 1 in defense.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP) -- A union leader said today that organized labor could not accept limiting wage increases by making them dependent on increases in productivity. This limit is being urged by the Kennedy Administration.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP) -- Workers holding down several jobs are not robbing fellow toilers of a chance to earn a living, the Labor Department suggested today.

BERLIN, Oct. 18 -- Nearly half the troops of the United States garrison in West Berlin set out this morning for three days of maneuvers. The exercises are aimed at testing the combat readiness of small infantry units under simulated conditions of nuclear warfare.
The Dartmouth football team leads the nation in total defense, according to National Collegiate Service Bureau statistics released yesterday.

THE employe relations programs of large industries take many forms. They may include bowling leagues, choral groups or drama clubs. One of the most novel of such programs is that of the Schering Corporation, a pharmaceutical concern, in this sprawling metropolis.
For the first time in six months the short interest position on the New York Stock Exchange increased in the month ended on Oct. 13.
PARIS, Oct. 17 -- The country's leading economic planners have taken a look at "the American way of life" and have decided it is not for France.
ALBANY, Oct. 18 -- The Court of Appeals reserved decision today on an attempt to disqualify Vito P. Battista as the United Taxpayers party candidate for Mayor of New York.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 18 (AP) -- Secretary of Labor Arthur Goldberg tonight won an eleventh-hour postponement of a threatened telegraphers strike against the Southern Pacific Railroad Company.

The International General Electric Company announced yesterday that it had received a record order for twenty-four super-voltage power transformers from a Brazilian hydro-electric agency. The transformers will be used to transmit up to 1,200,000 kilowatts to local utilities serving Rio de Janeiro, Belo Horizonte and other cities.
HAMILTON, N.Y., Oct. 18 -It was miraculous, said Alva Kelley today, that Colgate defeated Harvard, and he would not want to play the Crimson again.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- President Kennedy said today that mental retardation "should be brought out into the sunlight and given a ful lnational commitment.' He was addressing the committee that he named last week in their first meeting.

Marion Harper Jr., president and chairman of Interpublic, Inc., has been elected chairman of the American Association of Advertising Agencies. The announcement was made last night at the association's western regional meeting at Coronado, Calif.

ERNIE KOVACS is no Alec Guinness and director-producer William Castle, who unveiled his latest horror potboiler yesterday, is not Edgar Allan Poe. Anybody naive enough to attend yesterday's new Columbia double bill on the circuits will find painful proof in, respectively, "Five Golden Hours" and "Mr. Sardonicus."
Austin J. Tobin, executive director of the Port of New York Authority, yesterday criticized "headline hunters with catchpenny ideas" for transportation's future.

Patrice Munsel will be starred in "Chrysanthemum." The former Metropolitan Opera singer and television star will appear in the American premiere of the London musical hit on Jan. 22 at the Royal Poinciana Playhouse in Palm Beach, Fla.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- A former economic adviser to the Gold Coast of Africa said today that bickering educational missionaries were badly confusing people in the underdeveloped nations.
The S.H. Kress Co. variety store chain has purchased six variety stores in New York City and New Jersey from the Fisher-Beer Company, Inc. The terms of the cash purchase were not disclosed.

RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Oct. 19 -- A promise to resort to armed force if necessary to obtain independence for Kashmir was made today by K.H. Khurshid in the Azad (Free) Kashmir capital of Muzaffarabad after he was sworn in as "elected president of the government of the whole state of Kashmir and Jammu."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- The State Department needs a loan to tide it over the winter.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- The Administration believes that Chancellor Adenauer will visit Washington soon after he has organized a new West German Government, probably early in November.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 19 (UPI) -- Southern Pacific trains were running on schedule today after a temporary restraining order prohibited a scheduled strike by telegraphers.
David S. Jackson, in recent months has assumed the role of a self-appointed "conscience" of the troubled American Stock Exchange.

A theatre party to the musical comedy "How To Succeed in Business Without Really Trying" at the 46th Street Theatre on Nov. 17 will benefit the National Scholarship Service and Fund for Negro Students, 6 East Eighty-second Street.

BERLIN, Oct. 19 (AP) -- The Communists are offering prizes to children who betray people trying to escape from East Germany. Footballs and track suits have been handed out to young informers in the border area, the military correspondent of the Communist newspaper Das Volk reported.
Signs saying "Crush The Crimson" filled the Columbia University campus yesterday, but the Light Blue football players approached tomorrow's task against Harvard with considerable caution.

ONCE upon a time a voter in the weekly balloting for the leading college football teams never had to ponder about filling in the No. 1 spot. He automatically wrote down Notre Dame. Then he usually asked himself "Who else is there?" before starting to assess the credentials of the other candidates for top rank.
Bank clearings in the twenty-six leading cities in the nation aggregated $27,818,306,000 in the holiday week ended on Wednesday, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday.
The Brotherhood party announced a platform yesterday calling for full employment in the city at a minimum wage of $1.50 an hour.
A Federal Maritime Commission examiner has upheld a steamship line in refusing to pay a fine imposed by a steamship conference for alleged malpractice.
Two of the sightless workers who escaped the fire at the Jewish Guild for the Blind were married this week. But both are again working side by side, so they deferred their honeymoon.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 19 (AP) -- The Kennedy Administration and the Business Council renewed relations here today after a nine-month lapse. The lapse was brought in after a dispute with Secretary of Commerce, Luther H. Hodges.
The poster child for the 1962 March of Dimes is Debble Sue Brown, a 5-year-old from Clarkston, Wash.
ALBANY, Oct. 19 -- The Court of Appeals ruled today that Vito P. Battista could run for Mayor of New York as the United Taxpayers party candidate.

BRUCE CATTON is not only a distinguished historian. He is a literary phenomenon. His first book about the Civil War, "Mr. Lincoln's Army," was published ten years ago. His ninth, "The Coming Fury,"* is published today. To the best of my knowledge no other historian has ever written so many fine books in so short a time.
MAN'S dependence on water and the ways in which he is approaching the brink of a critical water shortage were demonstrated in arresting style last night over Channel 2.
Average daily borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose $116,000,000 to $145,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

Record sales were reported yesterday by the American Cyanamid Company for the first nine months of 1961. Profits, however, were below those of the 1960 period. Both sales and earnings in the September quarter rose from 1960 levels.
GLENS FALLS, N.Y., Oct. 19 (UPI) -- Governor Rockefeller said today that the state's expanding economy would preclude a basic tax increase.

Anyone who plans to send an American electrical appliance to friends overseas might be interested in the booklet "Electric Current Abroad," which gives the characteristics of electrical current in principal foreign cities around the world.

Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of Columbia University, appealed yesterday for approval of the proposed revision of the New York City Charter. A referendum on the revision is being held at this year's election.

Our hopes for a fruitful new assignment in the Peace Corps go to Margery Michelmore, the 23-year-old Smith College graduate whose postcard about squalid living conditions in Nigeria stirred an uproar there. Her indiscretion in putting her comments on an open card and then carrying it around until she lost it was admittedly a mark -- but not a very serious one -- of youthful bad judgment.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- The head of the American Jewish Congress praised Roman Catholic and Protestant leaders tonight for trying to eliminate the religious basis of anti-Semitism.

MOSCOW, Oct. 19 -- Following are the 1960 output and the 1970 and 1980 goals for selected commodities under the twenty-year program presented by Premier Khrushchev yesterday to the twenty-second congress of the Soviet Communist party:
CHICAGO, Oct, 19 (UPI) -- Earl Ingarfield, Camille Henry, Guy Gendron and Dean Prentice led the New York Rangers to a 4-2 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks tonight.

The property occupied by Arnold Constable Co. at the southeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Fortieth Street has been bought by the New York Public Library for investment. The six-story building has been occupied by the department store under lease since 1915.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 19 -In an effort to persuade the Free Democratic party to join a coalition government, Chancellor Adenauer's Christian Democratic Union offered today to set up a special two-party advisory committee.

DETROIT, Oct. 19 (UPI) -- Vic Stasiuk's three goals in the third period powered the Detroit Red Wings to a 7-3 victory over the Boston Bruins tonight. It was the first National Hockey League triumph of the season for the Wings.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- General Maxwell Taylor's mission to South Vietnam has produced a series of reports that the United States is about to plunge into the guerrilla warfare of Southeast Asia.
James Felt, chairman of the City Planning Commission and a member of Mayor Wagner's inner circle, differed yesterday with his chief for the second time in two days on matters of concern to Manhattan.
ON the fourth day of the collections, with Jane Derby, Mollie Parnis, Teal Traina and Samuel Winston showing, certain trends continued to emerge:
Al Kaline of the Detroit Tigers, who increased his batting average 46 points after having had his poorest season in 1960, was named the American League's comeback player of 1961 yesterday.

THREE members of the cabbage family that deserve special attention now that they are appearing in quantity in local markets are cauliflower, broccoli and Brussels sprouts. They can offer variety, color and a change of pace to family meals.

Net income of the Republic Steel Corporation in the quarter ended on Sept. 30 rose to $12,702,513, or 81 cents a share, from $7,310,271, or 47 cents a share in the like quarter a year earlier, the company reported yesterday.

Turnover on the New York Stock Exchange continued to rise yesterday and the tone remained good. Prices advanced steadily until about 2 P.M., then declined a little to the close, but the net result was a solid gain.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 19 -- When Robert F. Blumofe came here in 1953 as a sort of one-man West Coast division of United Artists, he was as welcome as a strike. He has since become a Hollywood symbol of cinematic revolution.
A QUESTION arose in the mind of a young Hungarian physicist more than thirty years ago: how much better is the ear than the telephone system?

Billy Williams, a 23-year-old Alabama-born outfielder who hit .278 for the Chicago Cubs, was named the National League's rookie of the year yesterday by the United Press International's board of baseball experts.
The 1961 apartment house appeal of the Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association will be opened by a tea and cocktail party Tuesday at Gracie Mansion.
John Crichton, editor of Advertising Age, will be the next president of the American Association of Advertising Agencies.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 19 -- Worth Seein' was precisely that tonight at Roosevelt Raceway. She also was worth betting on in the $25,745.01 Proximity, which the classy filly won in track-record time for a 2-year-old trotter.
Federal officials declined to comment yesterday on a report published by evening newspapers that a grand jury is investigating an alleged $25,000 attempt to fix a Federal court decision in Brooklyn.

An American in the United Nations said yesterday that Freedom Rides and lunch-counter sit-ins provided the "most striking evidence" to other nations that the spirit of freedom was still strong in this country.
In a realignment of its top management, Dancer-Fitzgerald-Sample, Inc., has named Chester T. Birch as president of the agency. He succeeds Clifford L. Fitzgerald, who becomes chairman.

At a luncheon in the Plaza Hotel yesterday the Lighthouse, the New York Association for the Blind, opened its campaign for $1,101,000 to finance its work. The event was attended by 300 business and professional men and women.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP) -- A security officer insisted today that a tape recording of his interrogation of Irvin C. Scarbeck showed that "no force or pressure" had been used to obtain a signed confession from the diplomat.
The first large group of tourists under the "see America" program of the Department of Commerce arrived at New York International Airport last night.
Cortland J. Strang, mechanical superintendent of The New York Times from 1940 to 1960, will retire at the end of the year, Arthur Hays Sulzberger, chairman of the board, announced yesterday.
Blocks of equity securities valued at more than $10,800,000 will be placed on the market today by investment syndicates, as follows:

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Friday, Oct. 20 -- The impending transfer of a popular dean set off an uproar of protests yesterday among students and teachers at the Long Island Center of the State University at Oyster Bay. At an impromptu meeting of 100 students a boycott of classes was called for today.
Yesterday afternoon "What's Wrong with Men?" on Channel 4 was more of a commentary on what's wrong with society.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 19 (AP) -- A cadet disappeared from the United States Military Academy Aug. 30, six weeks after he had entered as a plebe, or freshman. No trace of him has been found since.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP) -- A team of Harvard brain surgeons reported today development of a kind of electrical lobotomy technique for relieving the overwhelming pain of incurable cancer without causing major psychological damage.
DETROIT, Oct. 19 -- The Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile Workers reached an agreement late today on working conditions at a key stamping plant near Cleveland.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 19 (AP) -- The resignation of Edouard Van Remoortel as conductor of the financially troubled St. Louis Symphony Orchestra at the end of the current concert season was announced today. His resignation is effective next April.
GLEN COVE, L.I., Oct. 19 -- Ernest W. Kremer, assistant executive director of the Greater New York Fund, died today in the Community Hospital here after a brief illness. He was 53 years old.

I am puzzled, pained and very indignant about an editorial mention of me in your paper on Oct. 12 wherein I was linked with a notorious "madam," Polly Adler, in a discussion of how the English language should be used.

Having endorsed Louis J. Lefkowitz for Mayor, we consider today those other offices of next and large importance: Controller and President of the City Council. Ordinarily, other things being equal or nearly so, we would regard these as offices that should be filled by men from the same political party as the Mayor, making up a governmental team.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 19 -- A Harvard University physicist who specializes in the mechanism of hearing has won the 1961 Nobel Prize in medicine.

The Proctor Academy football team of Andover, N.H., will leave today for Montreal to play Westmount High at 10 A.M. tomorrow. This will be the thirteenth game between the schools. One half is played under American rules and the other half under Canadian.
Loans to business by the fourteen weekly reporting member banks in New York City rose $86,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

Representative Cleveland M. Bailey, Democrat of West Virginia and a member of the House Education and Labor Committee, has drawn up the outlines of a new approach to Federal aid for public elementary and secondary schools. Briefly, his plan would annually give to every state Fedderal funds equal to 2 per cent of its own expenditure for public education.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Oct. 19 -- The Nationalist party led by Prime Minister Hendrik F. Verwoerd found itself today with more electoral support than ever.
ORLANDO, Fla., Oct. 19 (UPI) -- James R. Hoffa pleaded not guilty today to charges of using the mails fraudulently to promote a private land development deal with union funds.

Pleasure-boat owners had a nudging reminder this week from Rear Admiral Edwin J. Roland, the Third Coast Guard District Commander, about a midwinter chore they face. Their old-style carbon tetrachloride fire extinguishers, which have been having a grace period for the past three years, will not be approved as acceptable equipment after Jan. 1, 1962.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 19 -- All efforts to have reluctant members pay their bills for the United Nations military operations in the Congo were reported tonight to be hopelessly deadlocked.

CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 19 (UPI) -- Johnny Sellers, continuing his drive for the national riding championship, rode three winners today, including the first half of the $240.40 daily double, at Garden State Park.

THINGS are looking up at food stores this week-end, which means, of course, that prices have gone down. A number of vegetables have dropped from 2 to 4 cents, including cauliflower, squash, lettuce and cucumbers.
The city had three visitors yesterday who, until this week, had never seen a wheel, a telephone, or a television, or heard a radio or turned on an electric light or water faucet.

PINEHURST, N.C., Oct. 19 (AP) -- Robert Bell of Worthington, Ohio, defeated the 1959 champion, Walter Pease of Plainfield, N.J., 1 up, in the quarter-finals of the North and South senior golf tournament at Pinehurst Country Club's No. 2 course today.
A live rat was taken into Housing Court yesterday by a tenant as evidence of conditions in an East Harlem tenement.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct 19 -- Livingston T. Merchant arrived here today as a special representative of President Kennedy to help settle the problem of moving goods between Pakistan and Afghanistan.
The New York County Democratic organization, one of the richest such groups in the state when it was known as Tammany Hall, is now living on handouts from Mayor Wagner's campaign headquarters.

Prices of United States Government securities and other prime-risk, fixed-income obligations continued firm yesterday as banks and other financial institutions became more impatient and skeptical about the predicted business boom.
NO matter how fouled up your outfit in the war may have been, men, it was a smart operation compared with the proceedings at the Pacific island rehabilitation center in "A Cook for Mr. General."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- The Administration has ordered that all necessary preparations be made by the Atomic Energy Commission and the Defense Department for resumption of atomic tests in the atmosphere, high officials said today.

USUMBURA, Ruanda-Urundi, Oct. 19 (AP) -- The police have announced that four men, including a former Secretary of State and a Mayor, have confessed to the assassination of Prince Louis Rwangasore, Urundi's first Premier.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 40 points a bale off to 65 cents up yesterday. The far months were strongest.
CHICAGO, Oct. 19 -- More forceful leadership by officers on merchant ships and other supervisors was urged today to stem the tide of injuries to seamen.
PARIS, Oct. 19 -- Storm warnings of an imminent new crisis for France and the Fifth Republic were flying here and in Algeria today.
The hotel that brought some of the shimmer of Miami Beach to Manhattan three months ago lost a small battle to New York's conservatives yesterday.

A program of give races will make up the day's program tomorrow at the thirty-first annual Monmouth County Hunt Racing Meet at Woodland Farm, estate in Middletown, N.J., of Mr. and Mrs. Amory L. Haskell. Many local charities will again benefit from the event.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 19 -- The United States served notice today that it would resume nuclear tests in the atmosphere unless a treaty prohibiting tests, with effective controls, was signed promptly.
Dr. Georg von Bekesy, who yesterday won the Nobel Prize in Medicine, received another honor from the Deafness Research Foundation here.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 19 -- The United Nations reported today that it had accelerated its recruitment of African staff members. But it reported also that it had made "rather slow progress" in the recruiting of Soviet-bloc citizens.
The 1961 Egleston Medal, Columbia University's highest award for "distinguished engineering achievement," will be given to Charles M. Brinckerhoff, president of the Anaconda Company.
The wholesale commodity price index inched upward to 83.8 on Wednesday from 83.7 on Tuesday. The index, compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, stood at 83.9 on Oct. 13, 1960.
DETROIT, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Passenger car production in the United States this week will hit its highest mark since last December, Automotive News said today.
LEOPOLDVILLE, The Congo, Oct. 19 -- The anger and frustration over Katanga's secession touches virtually everything in Leopoldville life these days.
JERSEY CITY, Oct. 19 -- Richard J. Hughes today proposed a network of suburban transportation centers that would link highway, rail and air travel into a single complex.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Oct. 18 -Outraged reaction has been aroused here by the discovery of the tortured body of Col. Hoang Thuy Nam in the Saigon River.

SYLVI KEKKONEN strolled quietly through Georg Jensen yesterday morning touching an enamel plate, lifting a crystal globe to the light, patting a whimsical bird sculpture as if she were greeting old friends.

QUITO, Equador, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Students demanding the resignation of President Jos Maria Velasco Ibarra clashe with police in two cities las night. The riots were out growths of political sparring i the capital.

Production of lumber in the nation dipped to 218,636,000 board feet last week from 219,482,000 the preceding week, according to reports from regional associations. A years ago, 223,972,000 board feet were produced.
PARIS, Oct. 19 -- Wilfrid Baumgartner, French Minister of Finance, painted a rosy though partly contested picture of France's economy before the National Assembly today.
LYALLPUR, Pakistan, Oct. 19 (Reuters) -- The Marylebone Cricket Club of England beat the Governor's eleven by 29 runs with forty-five minutes to spare today.

LUANG PRABANG, Laos, Oct. 19 -- Leaders of Laos' Right-wing and neutralist factions left this royal capital today for their respective administrative capitals. Prospects for an early settlement of the country's political problems appeared to have been little improved by their two days of consultations here with King Savang Vathana.
Jacob S. Potofsky, the labor leader, warned last night of a "new kind of discrimination, quiet and discreet, but ironhanded nonetheless."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- Imports of steel rose again in August and exports fell, the Department of Commerce reported today.
PARAMUS, N.J., Oct. 19 -- Better planning of urban areas will let their residents know what trees look like without going 1,000 miles to find out, Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. said here today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19 -- Abraham A. Ribicoff, Secretary of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, endorsed today Dr. James B. Conant's contention that unschooled idle youth constituted "social dynamite."

Cargo traffic through the St. Lawrence Seaway from April to September of this year was 1,474,807 tons above the comparable totals of last year, a rise of 9.7 per cent, the St. Lawrence Seaway Development Corporation reported yesterday.

One of our elder paperbacks, The Old Farmer's Almanac for 1962, will appear this year on Oct. 31. South of its habitat in Dublin, N.H., it is sold by Pocket Books, Inc., at 35 cents the copy, complete with a handy hole for a string or a nail.

A proposal to discontinue all fee-supported recreational and educational activities in the city schools has been made by Dr. John J. Theobald, the Superintendent of Schools. The proposal involves summer day camps sponsored by private groups and such after-class activities as music lessons.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Civilian defiance stiffened today against the Dominican Government. Three members of the Trujillo family were reported to be preparing to leave the country.

WEST CALDWELL, N.J., Oct. 19 -- Mrs. Henry Doubilet of the Hollywood Golf Club was elected president of the Garden State Women's Golf Association today. She succeeded Mrs. James Whelan of Springdale for a two-year term.
Trans World Airlines has proposed a new domestic air freight tariff that offers rate reductions up to 47 per cent.

Your editorial comment of Oct. 10 concerning the contemplated withdrawal of United States economic aid to Yugoslavia proved once again your almost fanatical concern for the welfare of Marshal Tito and Company.
Mayor Wagner yesterday rejected an invitation to appear on a debate type of television program with Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz, his Republican rival in the mayoral campaign.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- Department store sales in the nation for the week ended Saturday, Oct. 14, were unchanged from the level of the corresponding week last year.
CHICAGO, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Unfavorable weather for harvesting and aggressive buying by shorts helped corn and soybean futures today.
ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 19 -- Yale and Cornell have a confrontation here Saturday and it's do or die.
Are comparisons between college and professional football necessary and relevant? There are those who feel that the games are so inherently different that valid comparisons can't be made.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Oct. 19 (AP) -- Robert R. Corradini has been reinstated as an aviation cadet after being washed out because his sister was a member of a "Fair Play for Cuba" group, Cadet Corradini's father said today.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Oct. 19 -- The International Business Machines Corporation has offered its 70,000 employes in the United States $70,000,000 in interest-free loans to build fall-out shelters at their homes.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 19 (AP) -- Harvard University announced today a $100,000 gift to establish an endowment in the field of industrial relations in memory of the late Meyer Kestnbaum of Chicago, president of Hart Schaffner Marx, who died last December at the age of 64.
General of the Army and Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower attended Aqueduct race track yesterday for a relaxing day at the races, and that is exactly what they had.
The Police Department assigned patrols to Riverton Houses yesterday in another move to protect the tenants of large housing developments.
Live radio broadcasts of Saturday matinees by the Metropolitan Opera will be carried by more than 100 stations throughout the country beginning Dec. 9. They will be heard here over WOR.

Federal Judge William B. Herlands considered a motion yesterday by Dr. Robert A. Soblen, convicted as a spy for the Soviet Union, for a new trial based on allegedly new evidence. He reserved decision.

The uncertain status of the proposed World Trade Center at the eastern end of Wall Street has prompted the New York Stock Exchange to study other possible new sites for the exchange. This was disclosed yesterday by the exchange in its quarterly report to members and allied members.
Early action was forecast yesterday on a major portion of the long-projected $30,000,000 reconstruction of the West Side (Miller) Highway.

Thirteen American cities will participate in the annual series of Metropolitan Opera Auditions, through the National Council of the Metropolitan Opera. The auditions are open to young singers between the ages of 19 and 35.

John Mills has been signed by David Merrick to star in the forthcoming production of "Ross," the Terence Rattigan play about Lawrence of Arabia. John Williams is set for a featured role. The production will make its Broadway debut on Dec. 25.
Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz attacked Mayor Wagner's housing policies yesterday and proposed a program of his own, calling for "a new sense of urgency."
Brown, without a touchdown in three Ivy League games this year, has the law of averages going for it tomorrow at Philadelphia. A Bruin eleven hasn't won against Penn in Franklin Field in fifty years.

The Janard Realty Corporation has sold the six-story apartment building at 20 Clinton Street, between Houston and Santon Streets, to an investing client of George H. Ross, lawyer. The building, which Jannard constructed in 1939, contains thirty-eight apartments, six stores and a self-service elevator.
A way of transforming some drug-resistant germs to a state in which they are drug-susceptible has been reported by specialists at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center here.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 19 (AP) -- Holden Evans Jr., general manager of the state Thruway disclosed today that the state planned to light the thoroughfare's interchanges and eventually pave the shoulders the entire length of the highway.

BERLIN, Oct. 19 -- Communist East German authorities declared today that 253,061 members of the state youth organization had pledged themselves to serve "voluntarily" in the East German People's Army.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 19 -- Nationalist China has been persuaded not to veto the application of Outer Mongolia for United Nations membership, Western diplomatic sources said today.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 19 (AP) -- Bowl of Flowers upset the 3-to-5 favorite, Airmans Guide, and won the $84,400 Spinster Stakes today on a sloppy Keeneland race track.

Consumer complaints of home improvement frauds have increased so much in the last few years that they are now the biggest problem confronting the New York State Rackets Bureau, a legislative investigating committee was told here yesterday.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Oct. 19 -- Daily dynamiting of hundreds of tons of trap rock for removal from the Montclair State Teachers College grounds here is putting home owners in the area in an explosive frame of mind.
MOSCOW, Oct. 19 -- Premier Khrushchev has put peas and beans next to corn as an answer to the Soviet Union's farm problem.
East midtown Manhattan has no parks. But it does have plenty of buildings, especially large, block-filling behemoths which cut off light and air and stifle the pedestrian.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 19 -- The American Dental Association remained steadfast today in its program to recognize publicly and list dental products deemed useful and safe.
A half-century ago telephone booths were equipped with curtains and carpets and, by today's standards, some were nearly large enough to be rented as one-room flats.
The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. will portray "Senator King of Georgia" in the screen version of "Advise and Consent."
WALKING through the Indian summer along the restfully frantic sidewalks of Madison Avenue proved somewhat more enjoyable than many of the exhibitions that punctuated one's perambulations.

Luis A. Ferre, twice an unsuccessful Republican Statehood candidate for Governor of Puerto Rico, said yesterday that he would campaign for Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz, the Republican candidate for Mayor.
FLORENCE, N.J., Oct. 19 -- James P. Mitchell accused the present Democratic state administration tonight of "driving" manufacturing industries out of New Jersey.
The cty was accused yesterday of deliberately blocking justice for the families of textile workers who died in a loft building fire on lower Broadway three years ago.
Mayor Wagner yesterday belittled Governor Rockefeller's proposal for a ten-year middle-income housing program to provide new homes for 1,000,000 persons.
The United States monetary gold stock dropped $48,000,000 to $17,303,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

BOSTON, Oct. 19 (UPI) -- Robert H.W. Welch, Jr., founder of the John Birch Society, says the infiltration of "comsymps [communist sympathizers] into the Catholic clergy has been extremely less than in the Protestant clergy."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- Railroad carloadings rose last week from the levels of the preceding week, but were below the 1960 period. Truck loadings showed a sharp dip from the week before, but were substantially above the year-ago level.
Orthodox Jewish congregations that are contemplating the construction of synagogues have been asked to include fall-out shelters in their building plans.
Several cocktail parties were given yesterday in advance of the Fall Ball, a dinner dance for the Boys Club of New York, that was held in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- It now appears that there is no head-on conflict between an agency-shop decision by the Kansas Supreme Court, which the Supreme Court of the United States recently left in force, and a 4-to-1 ruling on the same subject by the National Labor Relations Board on Sept. 29.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- The Supreme Court grappled today with some of the legal problems posed by the lunch-counter sit-in campaign in the South.

PARIS, Oct. 19 -- A new and important step in improving French-Tunisian relations was taken tonight when the French Government announced that it was authorizing about 3,000 French teachers to return to their posts in Tunisia.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 19 -- West Germany dropped its objections today to the resumption of Soviet-United States exploratory talks before a meeting of the Western Allies to iron out their differences.

The Irving Trust Company has leased 48,400 square feet of space in the Sperry Rand Building which is being erected at 1290 Avenue of the Americas (Sixth Avenue) in the block front between Fifty-first and Fifty-second Streets.
CHICAGO, Oct. 19 -- Secretary of Commerce Luther H. Hodges called today for a cut in Federal income taxes, both corporate and individual.

TUCKAHOE, N.Y., Oct. 19 -- The Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association endorsed its resolution today to permit nonwhites to become eligible for membership in the professional Golfers Association national body.
Mohawk Airlines has opened a central reservations office here that handles the reservations calls made in a dozen major cities. The new center is in the East Side Air Terminal.
Directors of the Pacific Gas and Electric Company voted yesterday to split the company's common stock three for one. The move is subject to approval by stockholders at a special meeting on Dec. 20.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 19 -- Reliable sources said today that Valerian A. Zorin, chief Soviet representative at the United Nations, had asked Moscow for instructions regarding the deadlock with the United States over the selection of an Acting Secretary General.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 19 -- Lester Markel, Sunday editor of The New York Times, said tonight in a talk on the metropolitan newspaper that there was no longer any such thing as "foreign news."
It has been thirty years since Stell Andersen made her Town Hall debut, but the vigor and freshness of her piano playing there last night made this fact somewhat hard to believe.

Poland's leading Marxist philosopher, Adam Schaff, has tread upon dangerous territory -- for Communists anyway -- in his discussion of the dangers to individual freedom in the present pattern of Communist rule.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (UPI) -- Two new missionary bishops of the Episcopal Church were consecrated in Washington Cathedral today for service in Cuba and Liberia.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- The Pentagon's director of research and engineering sharply assailed today the way Government-operated military research activities have been carried out.
MOSCOW, Oct. 19 -- Premier Chou En-lai of Communist China openly contested today Premier Khrushchev's decision to banish Albania from the Communist bloc.

" The Kitchen," a British-made version of the play by Arnold Wesker, will open Oct. 31 at the Fifty-fifth Street Playhouse and the Fifth Avenue Cinema. The Kingsley International release was directed by James Hill and stars Carl Mohner and Mary Yeomans.

Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower greeted the Rev. Philip B. Clayton of Britain yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The President gave the Anglican minister a message for the Winant Volunteers.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Oct. 19 -Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor conferred today with top South Vietnamese and United States military authorities on the growing Communist threat to this seven-year-old republic.
A new musical that closed in Chicago last Saturday gave its first, and what may be its last, performance on Broadway yesterday in a gallant attempt to stave off extinction.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 19 -- For almost a week now the Yugoslavs have been uncharacteristically silent in the face of criticism from both East and West. When this restraint might end no one would hazard a guess.

Great Britain expects to increase its steel-making capacity by almost one-third by 1965, although not more than 70 to 75 per cent of present potential is being worked now, top technical and trade officials of the British steel industry said here yesterday.
ALEXANDRIA, U.A.R. Oct. 19 (AP) -- Arab delegates to the Third Arab Oil Conference angrily accused the Soviet Union today of dumping oil in the world market with the help of Italy.
HACKENSACK, N.J., Oct. 19 -- The Bergen County grand jury handed up four indictments today against four companies and four individuals in the sale of Henry Miller's "Tropic of Cancer."
LONDON, Oct. 19 -- The Cunard Steamship Company announced today that it had decided to postpone for the present the replacement of the 81,237-ton Queen Mary.

ALBANY, Oct. 19 -- The Board of Regents today urged support of a controversial proposal to place the state's credit behind $500,000,000 worth of bonds to finance new facilities at public and private colleges.

An architect's resume of his experience, dated last October, was offered yesterday as proof that the controversial urban renewal project for the West Village had been prepared in a builder's office five months before the city made the proposal public.
The Citizens Union, a. nonpartisan organization, yesterday recommended the election of Deputy Mayor Paul Screvane as President of the City Council. He is the Democratic-Liberal candidate.
THE annual Metropolitan Championships begin this afternoon at the Statler-Hilton Hotel and will continue through Sunday.

LONDON, Oct. 19 (AP) -Margery Michelmore, 23-year-old member of the United States Peace Corps, left for Bermuda by plane tonight without breaking her silence on the furor that forced her out of Nigeria.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- A warm but admittedly venturesome welcome is being prepared here for Dr. Cheddi B. Jagan, the new Prime Minister of British Guiana.

A LOVELY touch of theatre was brought to television last night. It came in the form of "Feathertop," a musical fantasy of beguiling and tuneful gentleness that illumed Channel 7 with a glow of charming make-believe for very nearly a full hour.

The Caribbean island of Curacao plans to invest $100,000,000 in bridges, airports, its Willemstad harbor and other facilities to pave the way for large-scale investment by United States and European business. Sylvius G.M. Rozendal, the island's Commissioner for Economic Affairs and Finance, announced the ten-year program yesterday.
Hayden Publishing Company. Inc., announced acquisition yesterday of the Ahrens Publishing Company, 40-year-old business magazine concern specializing in the hotel and restaurant fields.

ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Oct. 19 (UPI) -- The Katanga radio reported today that central Congolese troops have entered Katanga Province from South Kasai yesterday and clashed briefly with Katangese forces.
Finland was portrayed yesterday as eager -- and solvent -- for partnership with United States business in a large expansion of two-way trade and investment.

ATLANTA, Oct. 19 (AP) -- William Askew, regional postal director, has restated his decision to dismiss W.W. Law, a Savannah letter carrier who is president of the Georgia branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

The unwary listener, whose eye wanders over Quincy Jones' big, boisterous band as it plays at Basin Street East, might be startled to discover that the third trombonist from the right is wearing long, white, pendant earrings.
The State of Texas borrowed $25,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance loans to war veterans acquiring land.

PLATTSBURGH, N.Y., Oct. 19 (AP) -- The police concluded today that a nervous condition and mental depression had driven Philip C. Marsh Jr., a civilian security officer at Plattsburgh Air Force Base, to suicide.

MOOSE RIVER, Me., Oct. 19 -- Deer hunting in the basic form practiced in this thickly forested region around Jackman consists merely in arming one's self with a lethal weapon and endeavoring to move into proximity to the quarry.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- Two African leaders, President William V.S. Tubman of Liberia and President Kwame Nkrumah of Ghana, spoke out today against Soviet testing of nuclear weapons.

HARRIMAN, N.Y., Oct. 19 -- Decisions taken by the Kennedy Administration during the last eight months to accelerate the national space effort should accomplish within ten years what had been envisioned as the goals for fifteen years, the nation's space administrator said here tonight.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 19 (AP) -- A burglar whose criminal record, the police said, goes back to 1926 and includes a fifteen-year term in Alcatraz proved no match for the nuns of St. Therese School early today.
In The Times of Oct. 15 J.H. Carmical ably explained why the Government's new feed program is a failure. Unlike the wheat referendum, growers were given no opportunity to vote for or against it.
PARIS, Oct. 19 -- The idea of a meeting of Western foreign ministers in Paris to map tactics in the Berlin crisis is gaining favor in some Allied diplomatic circles here.

A STORE that caters to carriage trade customers with import copies twice a year has expanded its young fashion collection until now it includes clothes from eight European countries. Ohrbach's started the venture on a small scale six years ago, and now it takes over a large part of the store's children's department on the sixth floor.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 19 -- Ksar d'Esprit, under William Steinkraus, scored the United States' sixth international jumping victory tonight at the Pennsylvania National Horse Show.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP) -- The United States fired a rocket more than 4,000 miles high today in a study of the ionosphere.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19 (UPI) -- A Canadian labor union official has charged that several large grain and shipping companies are "cooperating" with an attempt by "left-wing-dominated" unions to control shipping on the St. Lawrence Seaway.
Cocoa futures prices, which had soared on Wednesday, dropped yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange.

POTTSVILLE, Pa., Oct. 19 (AP) -- District Attorney Robert M. Harris said today his office would fight any move to dismiss a burglary charge against Lillian Reis and he raised the possibility she might be retried as early as next month.
WASHINGTON, Oct 19 -- A beaming camel driver from Pakistan was treated almost like visiting royalty today, and he reacted with all the dignity of a chief of state.
CHICAGO, Oct. 19 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

The Tip Top Brush Company, manufacturer of painters' and artists' brushes and rollers, including the Red Devil line, has bought the two-story industrial building at 151 West Side Avenue, Jersey City. The company had been occupying a floor in the building under lease since June, when it moved from Manhattan.
PORTSMOUTH, Ohio, Oct. 19 (UPI) -- A friend of the missing cadet said today he had written to her that he did not like the regimentation of the Military Academy but that he was proud to be a cadet.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Oct. 19 -- Czechoslovak industry is recalling pensioners to work and recruiting women to make up for manpower lost in the emergency build-up of the country's armed forces, official sources declared today.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 19 (UPI) -- John McHale, the president of the Milwaukee Braves, today made a sweeping reorganization of the team's front office that will enable him to retain the job of general manager, and, he said, provide a "more successful and stronger operation."

Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corporation's third quarter earnings more than tripled those of the 1960 period but were slightly below the second quarter profit level this year, according to the report issued yesterday.

WAYNESBORO, Va., Oct. 19 (AP) -- Turner Catledge, managing editor of The New York Times, said here today that the way to meet the magnitude of the challenge posed by the Soviet Union was for the American people "to know what it is all about in every major detail."

James Talcott, Inc., an industrial finance and factoring company, announced yesterday the election of Kenneth Rush as a director of the company. Mr. Rusk is executive vice president and a director of the Union Carbide Corporation.

LAWRENCE, Kan., Oct. 19 -- Dr. Martin Scheerer, Professor of Psychology at the University of Kansas and an authority on cognitive function of the brain, died today at Lawrence Memorial Hospital. His age was 61.
Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower called yesterday for the support of women's colleges as "an investment in the future that you are entrusting to your children."

Ray Robinson may be an old man as far as professional athletes are concerned, but the former five-time middleweight champion of the world is earnest about his latest quest to don championship robes again.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 19 -- The Federal Government hopes to have in the hands of every family by the end of the year a pamphlet setting forth Federal standards for home bomb shelters, Frank B. Ellis, director of the Office of Emergency Planning, said today.
ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 19 -General Cemal Gursel, Turkey's head of state, said today he would seek the Presidency of the Second Republic to form a coalition government on the broadest possible basis.

WASHINGTON. AFTER designing perishable theatre scenery for about forty years, Boris Aronson has designed something permanent. He has designed the platform area -- the Ark, Crown, Eternal Light and Menorah -- at Temple Sinai, Military Road, Washington.
The packaging industry was told by Senator Estes Kefauver here yesterday that some packaging practices regarded as standard trade procedures were confusing the consumer.
The modern city "is a success" and planners must preserve its beneficial features, the Federal Government's top highway official said yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Oct. 19 -- President Urho K. Kekkonen cited his country to the United Nations today as an example of the progress that could be made by steering between the conflicts of the great powers.

Except for an occasional pause for some idle and unproductive meditation, the New York Knickerbockers were a team of hustling men in motion at Madison Square Garden last night. They rarely trailed as they routed the fledgling Chicago Packers, 120 -- 103.
The R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company reported yesterday that sales and earnings for the quarter and nine months ended on Sept. 30, were the highest in its history.

A left halfback who would rather run the option play than eat, sleep or miss pre-season practice and two soap-slippery ends are three of the reasons why the New York Football Giants fear the Los Angeles Rams.

Last night's repetition of "Aida" by the New York City Opera at the City Center brought three changes of cast: Carol Smith as Amneris, John Macurdy as Ramfis and Andrew Frierson as the King. All three were singing their roles with the company for the first time.

LONDON, Oct. 19 -- The advance among the industrials continued today and almost every important section benefited from a renewal of buying. However, turnover remained relatively light and the majority of gains were less than a shilling (14 cents).
TRENTON, Oct. 19 -- New Jersey beekeepers have a profitable sideline in renting bees, the State Department of Agriculture reported today.
TUNIS, Oct. 19 -- President Leopold Senghor of Senegal denounced Communist and African neo-colonialism today as possibly more dangerous than efforts by Western nations to maintain colonial positions.
The investor-owned part of the public utility industry increasingly favors the sale of common stock when it comes to new financing.

A new closed-end investment company that plans to place its funds mainly in equity securities of Japanese companies filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday.

The high-grade bond market closed the trading week yesterday with prices tending upward. The volume of business slackened from the pace of midweek, but dealers' quotations were solidly underpinned with bids.
The Long Island banker who led an unsuccessful fight to keep New York City banks out of the suburbs has acquired two sites in Manhattan and applied for permission to open branches on them.
MIAMI, Oct. 20 -- Community leaders here are warning of a growing resentment against large numbers of Cuban refugees who are taxing the area's economy.

JERSEY CITY, Oct. 20 -- Only cash payments from the state and tax exemptions can save commuters here from a 5-cent increase in fares on the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad next month, according to Herman L. Stichman, trustee in bankruptcy for the road.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Oct. 20 -- Prime Minister Hendrik F. Verwoerd pledged today to continue the policy of white supremacy in South Africa.

MOSCOW, Oct. 20 -- Communist leaders at the Soviet party congress pressed their attacks against Albania today despite an appeal by Premier Chou Enlai of Communist China against such criticism in public.

THE subtly seasoned cuisine of North Italy is less familiar here than the robust dishes of Naples that so many restaurants serve. But there are at least two places in this city where the diner can sample, at a relatively low cost, the specialties of Milan, Genoa, Venice and the capital of Italian cuisine, Bologna.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 20 -- Two of President Kennedy's top economic advisers sought stronger bonds today between the Administration and America's business leaders.
CHICAGO, Oct. 20 (UPI) -- A union president who led a successful fight against a labor racketeer was found shot to death today in a car that had been wired with dynamite.
The Norfolk and Western Railway may eventually include the Erie-Lackawanna Railroad in its merger plans.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Oct. 20 -- President Joseph Kasavubu, in a rare radio address, gave his support last night to the Government of Premier Cyrille Adoula in its attempt to end the Katanga secession. Mr. Kasavubu said that it was the duty of the Adoula Government "to resort to its own means to attain the end pursued by the nation ending Katanga's separatist stand."

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 21 (UPI) -- Wilt Chamberlain shattered two court records with a 57-point outburst tonight to lead the Philadelphia Warriors to a 122-155 victory over the Los Angeles Lakers in a National Basketball Association game.

A round of price increases averaging 3 to 5 per cent at the distributor level is in the making for home appliances. The advance represents what appears to be a reversal of a downward trend that has been in effect several years.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 20 -- Six countries in the direct path of Soviet fall-out asked today that the General Assembly "solemnly appeal" to Moscow to abandon its plan to explode a fifty-megaton nuclear bomb.
BERLIN, Oct. 20 (AP) -- Pictures of Walter Ulbricht, the Communist leader of East Germany, are disappearing in East Berlin.
FASHION designers seem increasingly susceptible to fit of professional wanderlust these days. After making names a creators of women's apparel they are tempted to try their wings in other fields.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Oct. 20 (UP) -- Scientists worked today on the delicate guidance system of a ten-story rocket that is scheduled to carry a 670-pound payload 685,000 miles into space Sunday morning.

Mayor Wagner assailed the Republican-controlled Legislature yesterday for having outlawed the dating of milk by the city. He charged the Republicans with "blatant disregard for the consumer" by this action last year.

Not long ago on the eve of the current school year two dozen companies making teaching machines and vitally interested in their promotion held a two-day conference and exhibit in this city under the sponsorship of the American Management Association.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20 (UPI) -- More than 300 of the nation's top airline pilots headed back to flight duties today after a three-day safety forum that emphasized the need for improvements in air-traffic control.
BELGRADE, Oct. 20 -- The continued absence from Belgrade of Nenad Popovic was the subject of excited gossip in Belgrade today.
Police Commissioner Michael J. Murphy transferred six high-ranking officers yesterday -- two borough commanders and four officers in charge of divisions.

BUFFALO, Oct. 20 (UPI) -- Explosions and a fire at a huge generating station in outlying Tonawanda disrupted power to homes and industry today for up to two and a half hours. More than 200,000 persons were affected.

Samson Francois played Ravel's "Gaspard de la Nuit" at the end of his program in Carnegie Hall last night and, as with any superior performance, it worked its traditional magic. The French pianist had the technique to do the difficult composition justice, besides producing lovely soft figurations in "Ondine," delicate colorations in "Le Gibet" and brilliant ones in "Scarbo."

Football buffs jammed the Grand Ballroom of the Hotel Astor yesterday to praise the New York Giants in song and unmetered superlatives. If half the adjectives used to describe the club were accurate, it should have no trouble handling the Los Angeles Rams in tomorrow's National Football League game at Yankee Stadium.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (UPI) -- The nation's output of goods and services rose to a record rate of $526,000,000,000 a year in July, August and September, the President's economic advisers reported today.

The first nation-wide fundraising and public relations campaign of the National Hemophilia Foundation began yesterday with the announcement that John A. Walstrom had been made chairman. The campaign will reach its climax during National Hemophilia Month in February.

METUCHEN, N.J., Oct. 20 -- James P. Mitchell today denounced a suggestion that he might be a "phony liberal". because of his role in the alleged dismissal of an Assistant Secretary of Labor while he was the Secretary in the Eisenhower Cabinet.

BY naming Clarence Belden Randall head of a team to review the Volta River hydroelectric project in Ghana, President Kennedy has called out of retirement a man who believes the years of retirement can be the most creative ones.
PARIS, Oct. 20 -- French officials indicated today that France would not be averse to an eventual meeting in Paris of the four Western foreign ministers directly concerned with the Berlin problem.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- The wholesale price index for the week ended last Tuesday was unchanged at 118.5 per cent of its 1947-49 base, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.
Thousands of anti-Castro leaflets have been mailed to Cuba from near-by countries in the Caribbean during the last week, according to reliable sources.
The Carmel and Putnam Valley Central School District, N.Y., is planning the sale of $1,720,000 of serial bonds on Nov. 2.
Prof. Samuel Hendel, chairman of the Political Science Department at City College, yesterday criticized a recent ban on speeches by members of the Communist party.
Teen-age ruffians caused a campaign parade for Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa to be called off as it wound through the Red Hook section of Brooklyn last night.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Oct. 20 -- The Dominican police used semiautomatic rifles, water hoses and tear gas to attack rioting youths today in the bloodiest street fighting here since the assassination of Generalissimo Rafael Leonidas Trujillo Molina May 30.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 10 cents a bale up to 40 cents off yesterday.
There are occasions in politics, as in nature, where severe storms are predictable. Every sign points to a bad time ahead for France and Algeria.
PALO ALTO, Calif., Oct. 20 (AP) -- Sigurd F. Varian, who with two associates invented the klystron tube, basic element of radar, was killed in a plane crash in Mexico, his office was informed today.
PORT JEFFERSON, L.I., Oct. 20 -- The First Baptist Church of Port Jefferson will be 100 years old tomorrow.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 20 -- The University of Idaho will become the 142d rival in Army football history when the Vandals play at Michie Stadium tomorrow. A crowd of 20,000 is expected to witness the game, in which Army is the overwhelming favorite.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- President William V.S. Tubman said today that the right of self-determination should apply not only to Africans but to the people of all nations, including those living under communism.

DESPITE considerable artlessness in the craftsmanship, "Anthony on Overtime," the new comedy by Rose Grieco with which the Blackfriars' Guild opened its twenty-first season on West Fifty-seventh Street last night, is a lively, well-balanced mixture of humor and characterization.
MADISON, Wis., Oct. 20 (UPI) -- The University of Wisconsin Board of Regents today dismissed Dr. John Z. Bowers as dean of the medical school.
Steel production in 1962 is expected to top 1961 output, steel executives say, but this year's tonnage may fall short of earlier expectations.

Coporate profits should increase next year to record levels, according to a man who keeps a close watch on this key economic indicator. He is Stephen B. Packer, an associate editor of Standard Poor's, the national statistical and advisory service.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- President Kennedy named Clarence B. Randall today to head a special mission to take a "final hard look" at the prospective United States aid to Ghana's Volta River project.
Two groups of broadcasters, one educational and the other primarily commercial, were served generous helpings of criticism and hope with their lunches here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- President William V.S. Tubman of Liberia said today "there is nothing we can do" to stop American ship owners 'from continuing to withdraw their ships from Liberian registry.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 20 -- Harvard and Columbia will meet at Harvard Stadium tomorrow in an important Ivy League contest for both teams. The Lions are favored after scoring 81 points against three Ivy opponents and shutting out Yale last week, 11 -- 0.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) -- An international conference of educators and economists recommended today that the developed nations devote more resources to improvement and expansion of education.
CHARLESTON, W. Va., Oct. 20 (AP) -- Snow in depths of up to twenty three inches snarled highway and air traffic, closed schools and disrupted telephone and power services in West Virginia today.
The Federal Maritime Commission is developing a set of rules to govern the operations of independent ocean freight forwarders under the new licensing law passed by congress this year.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- President Kennedy has started a daily program of exercises designed to strengthen his muscles and remove fear that his chronic back trouble will flare up again.
As you might assume, I was very disappointed with the decision of The Times to endorse Louis J. Lefkowitz over Mayor Robert Wagner.
PARIS, Oct. 20 (AP) -- United States Air Force officials said today that four United States bases in France would be put back in action as part of the defense buildup in Western Europe.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Lincoln White, State Department press officer, confirmed today that the United States has granted entry visas to two brothers of the late Generalissimo Trujillo. The brothers are Hector Bienvenido and Jose Arismendi Trujillo.
EATONTOWN, N.J., Oct. 20 -- Billy Farrell of Baltusrol and his amateur partner, Jack Spahn, won the Long Branch Trophy today with a gross better-ball 32, 34 -- 66 at the Old Orchard Golf Club.

COSTA MESA, Calif., Oct. 20 (UPI) -- Buddy Sullivan of Yuba City, Calif., who led the first round of the $17,500 Orange County open with a seven-under-par 64, slipped to a 72 today but held a one-stroke lead at 136 after thirty-six holes.

The president of a company that shipped packages to persons in the Soviet Union was arrested here yesterday in the disappearance of more than $200,000. He was said to have collected the money from the package senders for customs payments to the Soviet Union.

Several years ago the Sanitation Department introduced street litter baskets. On the planning board such a measure had every prospect of success. It could have succeeded, under ideal conditions, with full cooperation of the public, strict enforcement of the Sanitary Code, making sure that such baskets be used properly, and emptied daily.

In the Bronx and Queens, Brooklyn and Staten Island and even in most of Manhattan it was autumn in New York last night. The exception was the interior of the Seventh Regiment Armory, where it was April in Paris.

Today marks the halfway point in the schoolboy football season and showdown time for several of the metropolitan area teams. In what shapes up as the best Saturday program of the season, games between undefeated elevens abound like leaves on the ground these fall days.

LONDON, Oct. 20 -- Shares prices maintained their improvement in the stock market here today and turn-over expanded despite the usual end-of-week restraining influences. The advance was scarcely affected by an increase in profit taking.
OYSTER BAY L.I., Oct. 20 -- Students at the Long Island Center of the State University boycotted classes here today to protest the reported transfer of the Dean of Students.
WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 20 -- Frank Ervin barely flicked his whip as he drove Sprite Rodney to the easiest of victories in the $85,135.02 Westbury Futurity Trot at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.
A three-judge Federal statutory court refused yesterday to invalidate New York State's English-language literacy test for voters.
The creation of the Dwight D. Eisenhower Research Fund to investigate cerebral palsy was announced at a dinner last night honoring the former President and Mrs. Eisenhower.
Americans are worshiping "the false gods" of status, security, science, sex and self, twenty-five theologians said in an article in this week's issue of Christianity Today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- An engineer who grew tired of tossing beer cans into the air for target practice has patented a "gun" to do the throwing. His Targeteer is already on the market, and about 3,500 have been sold.

HAVING made a more or less clean break with tradition, nonobjective art tends to run to extreme positions, there being no satisfactory middle course between old and new. Two of the principal extremes, at opposite poles, are illustrated in two exhibitions of painting now on view.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 20 -- Egypt has begun to confiscate the property of its richest citizens, in some cases arresting them, diplomats and business men who have just returned from Cairo reported today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) -- Dick Drummond scored four touchdowns tonight as George Washington University routed William and Mary, 49 -- 12, in a Southern Conference football game.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (UPI) -- The Government concluded its case against Irvin C. Scarbeck today after presenting a statement in which the diplomat said he was ready to accept "any and all punishment" for giving United States secrets to Polish agents.

MONTEREY, Calif., Oct. 20 (AP) -- Stirling Moss pushed his pea green Lotus Monte Carlo to a course record of 92 miles an hour at Laguna Seca today during qualification runs for the Pacific Grand Prix.

Four guest songsters joined an eleven-man chorus of Yale alumni Whiffenpoofs in East Harlem yesterday to help dedicate a housing project named in honor of a fellow alumnus, the late. Senator Robert A. Taft, class of 1910.

As a motion picture source, Canada is known primarily for a series of excellent, government-subsidized shorts (from its National Film Board) and for the picturesque locales utilized by visiting outsiders (such as Alfred Hitchcock's "I Confess").

DETROIT, Oct. 20 -- Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers, said today that he hoped a new national agreement could be reached with the Chrysler Corporation in the next week. If not, he said, the union's international executive board will consider setting a strike deadline at a special meeting next Friday.
YONKERS, Oct. 20 -- A business man has decided that if the advertising world's twenty-five-words-or-less technique will sell breakfast food, it may help combat communism.
The Presbytery of New York will install the Rev. Graydon E. McClellan as its General Presbyter, or chief executive officer, at 8:30 P.M. Tuesday in the Interchurch Center Chapel, 475 Riverside Drive.

The enterprising concert series known as "Young Masters" began its third season in Carnegie Recital Hall last night, sponsoring a debut recital by the American tenor Mark Bellfort Chalat. Lawrence Smith, who will have a concert of his own later this season, was the supporting pianist.
TOKYO, Oct. 20 -- Japan and South Korea began a new round of negotiations today in an attempt to settle their long-standing disputes.
BUFFALO, Oct. 19 -- One of this politically turbulent city's most seasoned and impartial observers was asked this week who he thought would win Buffalo's hectic four-man contest for Mayor.
Nenad Popovic, one of Yugoslavia's leading economists, was reported yesterday to have defected to the West.

Probably only a few of the thousands of passengers who have been in a taxicab driven by Benjamin G. Benno know that he is an artist whose work has hung with that of Picasso, Max Ernst and Salvador Dali.

PARIS, Saturday, Oct. 21 -- Several thousand Algerian women and children demonstrated peacefully in Paris and elsewhere in France yesterday against restrictions imposed on Moslems in the capital and in favor of independence for Algeria.

A group of 5,000 Board of Education employes said yesterday that Joseph R. Weiss, who has been suspended as Deputy Superintendent of Schools, had got into trouble because he stepped on the toes of "powerful interests."

SAIGON, Vietnam, Oct. 20 -- Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor has scheduled a third meeting with President Ngo Dinh Diem on the question of how the United States can best help South Vietnam meet the deepening Communist crisis.
A dispute is reported to have arisen among Wagner campaign workers over whether the Mayor should seek the support of Democratic district leaders who fought him in the Sept. 7 primary.
BEDFORD VILLAGE, N.Y., Oct. 20 -- The 1680 deed covering the sale of 7,673 acres by Indians to the white settlers of this area for $131 was donated to the Town of Bedford last night.

Three notably different books are published today. The first -- alphabetically -- is "The Ape I Knew," an account of carnival life by George W. (Slim) Lewis (Caxton Printers, $5). Second is "The Great Adventure of Modern Art" (L'Illustration du XXe Siecle) a paperback original (Tudor, $5.95).
ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 20 (AP) -- A New York real estate man has bought a one-mile tract of beachfront land on near-by Brigantine Island and reportedly pulans a $15,000,000 development there.
The naming of Fredrick M. Eaton as co-chairman of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center Development Committee was announced yesterday.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 20 -- Princeton's football team, minus two starting players, will face its final non-Ivy League opponent tomorrow when it meets Colgate at 2 P.M. in Palmer Stadium.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 20 (AP) -- The Pennsylvania State Athletic Commission lifted its suspension of Sonny Liston today and the leading heavyweight contender immediately went into training for a Dec. 4 fight.

A Manhattan physician, irked by the receipt of a ticket while he was parked at a meter in front of Metropolitan Hospital, said yesterday he was planning to plead not guilty and make a test case of the ticket.

CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 20 (AP) -- Unless a horse is subject to overconfidence, Christopher T. Chenery's Cicada looks like money in the bank in tomorrow's seventh running of the Gardenia Stakes at Garden State Park.
With billions being spent to help others and win friends for ourselves, it is urgent that we consider several basic propositions:
CHICAGO, Oct. 20 (AP) -- Near-by wheat contracts attracted support on the Board of Trade today but the deferred deliveries declined along with rye and soybeans. Corn and oats advanced.

Your vigorous editorial of Oct. 17 commenting upon Dr. James B. Conant's "Slums and Suburbs," is indeed appropriate. It is ironic that in the face of the well-known conditions in so many schools which serve as breeding ground for delinquency, it took "construction irregularities" to stimulate drastic action by the State Education Department.
Two youths were arraigned in Felony Court yesterday on a homicide charge in the fatal shooting of 51-year-old Peter J. Kibiles of Ogdensburg, N.J.

WEBSTER, S.D., Oct. 20 (AP) -- Secretary of Interior Stewart L. Udall, dedicating the nation's first completed plant for sweetening brackish water, said today the availability of water had been taken for granted for too long.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 20 -- Favored by good weather in most producing countries, global output of cocoa reached a historic peak of 1,170,000 metric tons in the 1960-61 season. The total exceeded that of the preceding year by 13 per cent, and was 30 per cent above that of either of the two years 1956-57 and 1958-59, when volume stood at 900,000 tons.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 20 -- Placing four runners in the top ten places, Princeton's cross-country team outpointed Fordham and St. Joseph's in a triangular meet on the Palmer Stadium course today.

James J. Kirk, president of the Neighbors Committee, which is supporting a proposed urban-renewal study in the western part of Greenwich Village, denied yesterday that his organization was a "puppet" of Roger Shafer.

HONG KONG Oct. 20 -- Premier Chou En-lai's address to the Soviet Communist party congress constitutes a more explicit Chinese challenge then before to Russian claims of ideological leadership in the Communist bloc, observers here ocmmented today.

Lower sales in the third quarter resulted in a net loss for the period, the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company reported yesterday. The company operated at a profit in the corresponding period last year.

ONE thing can be said for "The Gallic Approach," which is the subject around which Leonard Bernstein has built his programs for the first part of the New York philharmonic season: music of the widest diversity in effect can be grouped under this heading, and there is no danger of the programs' becoming monotonous.

TUNIS, Oct. 20 -- The Algerian Nationalist Provisional Government charged today that "nearly fifty" Algerian Moslems had been killed in the demonstrations in Paris Tuesday night, "among them several women."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- A program under which Army troops in Europe may learn about Communist operations in Berlin almost at first-hand will begin next week.

Our generation may be known as the one that built so many roads. The surface of the earth all across the country from the Atlantic to the Pacific is patterned and scarred with highways that an astronomer on Mars would be able to pick out.

Another member of the Gallo family appeared before the Kings County rackets grand jury yesterday. But he volunteered no information about the attempted strangling of his brother Lawrence or the murder of Joseph Magnasco, a convicted hijacker.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 20 -- Behind the public forum of the General Assembly Hall is the delegates lounge. Its real function is not indicated by the name.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- The Kennedy Administration mounted tonight what it called a counterattack against the "rising mood of national frustration" over the contest with the Soviet Union.

PARIS, Oct. 20 -- The Assembly of Captive European Nations appealed to all non-Communist nations today to demand before the United Nations that "the unversally valid right of self-determination be recognized and assured to the nine European countries subjugated by Soviet Russia."

KINGS POINT, L.I., Oct. 20 -- The United States Merchant Marine Academy football team meets Hofstra, the No. 1 squad in the Lambert Cup standing, on Captain Tomb field, tomorrow. Kings Point is sixth in the cup selections.

A special commission appointed by Governor Rockefeller heard so much conflicting testimony on labor conditions at thoroughbred race tracks yesterday that it has decided to get up before dawn to see how stablehands live and work.
WASHINGTON. Oct. 20 (AP) -- The Department of Defense said tonight that the number of troops to be made available for use in a motion picture in France had been cut from 700 to 250.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 20 -- Other countries will act to force action by the Security Council on picking a Secretary General unless the big powers break the present deadlock, it was said today.
A rabbi was sentenced to thirty days in jail and fined $500 in Housing Court yesterday for violations in a lower East Side tenement where a 5-month-old child had been bitten by a rat.
The Salute to America Ball, a benefit for the Girls Club of New York, will be held Thursday in the Sheraton-East.
IN the "Electra City, U.S.A." show opening today at 1 P.M. at the Coliseum, a host of gimmicks and gadgets for home use are being previewed.
HARRISBURG Pa., Oct. 20 -- The United States won the Prix des Nations international jumping event of the Pennsylvania National Horse Show tonight and clinched the international team championship.
MIAMI BEACH, Oct. 20 -- A biological explanation in part of how cigarette smoking may be linked to heart disease was presented here today to the American Heart Association.
Kelso, the champion 4-year-old owned by the Bohemia Stable, will not lack company in the weight-for-age Jockey Club Gold Cup at Aqueduct today.
