SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 20 (AP) -- The Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation said today it was buying 1,500 acres near Oswego as a possible site for an electricity generating plant that might be fueled by an atomic reactor.
President Urho Kekkonen of Finland spent yesterday in a round of official and unofficial activities.

FRANCOIS MAURIAC'S "The Frontenacs"* is a novel about a French dynastic family in the country around Bordeaux. Although M. Mauriac wrote it in the Nineteen Thirties -- long before he won the 1952 Nobel Prize -- this translation, by Gerard Hopkins, marks the first time we have had the story in an English version.

SAN SALVADOR, Oct. 20 -- Jay H. Cerf, Assistant Secretary of Commerce, told an audience of Salvadoran business men, industrialists and agriculturalists last night that Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba was not "a cause but a symptom."

CHICAGO, Oct. 20 -- The Kennedy Administration, if it is to be "tagged" at all, is "pro-business," Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg declared here today at the annual meeting of the Illinois Chamber of Commerce.
Today is the last day of the New York Antiques Fair at the Seventy-first Infantry Armory, Park Avenue at Thirty-fourth Street. The fair is open today from 1 to 6 P.M. Admission is $1.50.

Mrs. Millicent C. McIntosh, president of Barnard College, predicted yesterday that the demand that everyone in the United States be permitted to go to college would be met by widespread adoption of the California philosophy of higher education.

Fischer-Landis, realty investors, have sold the four-story office and showroom building at 236-38 East Fifty-third Street, near Third Avenue. Te buyer was an investing client of John J. Reynolds, Inc., the broker in the deal.

Events today: New York Philharmonic, Leonard Bernstein, conductor, Gold and Fizdale, duo-pianists, William Lincer, violist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30 P.M.; New York City Opera Company, City Center, "H.M.S. Pinafore," at 2:30 P.M. and "Carmen" at 8:30 P.M.
THE Metropolitan Championships at the Statler-Hilton Hotel continue today with a two-session open pair contest at 2 and 8 P.M. A one-session pair game also will be held at 8 P.M.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (UPI) --The Federal Power Commission hereafter will not grant temporary authority for building interstate natural gas pipelines until notices of application have been issued and hearings held, according to F.P.C. officials.

HARRIMAN, N.Y., Oct. 20 -- If an agreement on control of space is not reached, there is a possibility that high-yield thermal devices could be put in orbit and exploded to destroy half a continent with one blast, the American Assembly was warned today.

MONTEREY, Calif., Oct. 20 -- Forty drivers started qualifying tests today for Sunday's $20,000 Pacific Grand Prix. The race will be run in two 100-mile heats over the picturesque 1.9-mile Laguna Seca course on the Fort Ord Army reservation.
Dominick R. Comenzo, who was expelled by the American Stock Exchange on Thursday for violations of the exchange's rules, denied yesterday the charges motivating the expulsion.
Bashir Ahmed, the driver of camels, gathered materials yesterday for a thousand and one nights of story-telling in the tea houses of Pakistan.
New York welcomed yesterday the first visitors from Europe arriving under the wing of the United States Travel Service, the See-America agency that has bene set up by the Federal Government.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Postmaster General J. Edward Day announced today a plan to raise parcel post rates by about 6 per cent, revise size and weight limits on parcels and increase mail-catalogue rates by 13.8 per cent.
The grand jury investigating an alleged $25,000 attempt to fix a Federal Court decision in Brooklyn is now expected to reconvene on Friday, Nov. 3.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) -- The St. Lawrence Seaway Development Corporation will open a field office, probably in Detroit, to distribute information and promote the development of traffic.
SYRACUSE, Oct. 20 (AP) -- The Syracuse Diocese of the Roman Catholic Church urged the state today to authorize religious instruction in any program to improve the education of retarded children.

TORONTO, Oct. 20 (Canadian Press) -- American-owned horses will be favored tomorrow at the New Woodbine track in the twenty-fourth Canadian Championship. The race will be run at a mile and five furlongs on the grass course.

Strong in the final ninety minutes after a discouraging opening, the stock market managed to show a small gain yesterday. Utilities and heavy chemicals took over the leadership. Other major groups were irregular or down.
BONNER SPRINGS, Kan., Oct. 20 (UPI) -- Mrs. Melba Mitchell's new living room carpet is installed on the ceiling in the new home she shares with her six children.
The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King said yesterday that he would not portray a Georgia Senator in the film version of the novel "Advise and Consent."

ALEXANDRIA, U.A.R., Oct. 20 (AP) -- The Secretary-General of the Third Arab Oil Congress, Hassan el Kholy, said today that final resolutions of the conference would not reflect any attacks on Western oil companies.

Fred Schmidt scored two touchdowns as Erasmus defeated Lafayette, 21 -- 7, yesterday in a Public School Athletic League Division II game at Boys High Field in Brooklyn. The victory was the Dutchmen's second in three starts. The Frenchies have lost two.
Samuel Beckett's "Happy Days" will end its run at the Cherry Lane Theatre "in a few weeks," according to a spokesman for the production.
With traders evening up their trading positions for the weekend, most commodities markets were relatively quiet yesterday.
The Citizens Union yesterday rated Mayor Wagner and Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz better qualified than other candidates for Mayor. But it expressed no preference between them.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 20 -- Officials here have set two firm conditions on ratification of a truce settlement between the United Nations and the secessionist Congo province of Katanga.
Plans for major securities offerings were announced yesterday by the Hanna Mining Company, Arizona Public Service Company and Northern Natural Gas Company of Omaha.
Roman Catholics over the world will observe Mission Sunday tomorrow at the request of Pope John XXIII.
McCOMB, Miss, Oct. 20 -- A Negro student revolt has pushed this segregationist stronghold in southwestern Mississippi to the brink of a serious racial crisis.
Daniel Abrams dug into the most difficult kind of piano program last night at the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum and emerged with something like half a triumph.

The Kratter Corporation has taken title to the leasehold on the blockfront on the west side of First Avenue, between Sixty-third and Sixty-fourth Streets. The property is known as 1153 to 1167 First Avenue.

A factory designed exclusively for the manufacture of automation equipment was opened yesterday in Silver Spring, Md., as robot-like devices were unveiled at formal dedication ceremonies. Rowland Burstan, Assistant Secretary of Commerce in charge of international affairs, told the other guests at the dedication that such a production installation was essential for this country to meet world competition.
AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Oct. 20 -- After months of rumors, New Zealand learned officially today that it had valuable supplies of natural gas and oil.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., Oct. 20 (UPI) --Adios Butler, ranked among the great horses of harness racing even before his retirement, will make his last appearance in a mile race tomorrow when he opposes nine rivals in the first leg of the $80,000 American Pacing Classic.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 20 -- Undefeated Rutgers will attempt tomorrow to make Lehigh University's football team its fourth victim of the season.
Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz promised yesterday that if elected Mayor he would try to provide New Yorkers with "the best job opportunities in the nation."

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 20 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru delivered a sharp attack tonight on Portuguese Colonialism and what he called the support given to it by the great powers because of the pressures of the "cold war."
A large volume of new debt financing is scheduled for market next week. Major issues to be sold at competitive bidding aggregate $192,115,000.
Sugar Ray Robinson, a career man among comeback fighters, is favored at 12-5 to defeat Denny Moyer of Portland, Ore., in their ten-round middleweight main event tonight in Madison Square Garden.
Sugar Ray Robinson, a career man among comeback fighters, is favored at 12-5 to defeat Denny Moyer of Portland, Ore., in their ten-round middleweight main event tonight in Madison Square Garden.

BERLIN, Oct. 20 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay, President Kennedy's personal representative in West Berlin, was on hand at sunrise today to witness the final phase of a three-day maneuver involving half of the United States garrison here.

The pacific Lighting Corporation reported yesterday that its consolidated net income in the twelve months ended on Sept. 30 dipped slightly to $26,338,000, equal to $3.05 a share, from $26,708,800, or $3.10 a share, in the comparable period a year earlier.
DETROIT, Oct. 20 -- Striking back with three touchdowns in the final quarter, Navy survived an aerial blitz by the brilliant Jerry Gross and downed previously unbeaten Detroit 37 -- 19, tonight.
SAVANNAH, Ga., Oct. 20 (AP) -- The Military Order of World Wars today censured the Defense Department for what is called "hasty and ill-considered disciplinary action" against military leaders.
The city yesterday began distributing 700,000 copies of a pamphlet titled "You and Your Landlord" to the tenants of multiple dwellings in the city.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 20 (AP) -- Premier Sarit Thanarat today accused the leader of "a certain country" of threatening to attack Thailand and warned that his Government "may have to take definite steps to preserve the safety and honor of our nation."

BONN, Germany, Oct. 20 -- The leaders of the Christian Democratic Union and the Free Democratic party reached agreement today on the terms and personnel of a coalition government under the 85-year-old Dr. Konrad Adenauer as Chancellor.

THE ill wind that blew over the rooftop playground of Hunter College Elementary School last year has changed the lives of 450 children. In less than a year, as a result of instant parental reaction to a 14-yea-old child's concussion, a safe, contemporary "playscape" has just been installed.
Notre Dame, the magic name in football in the glamorous years of Knute Rockne and Frank Leahy, finds itself a cynosure again today.

American Export Lines has decided to put greater stress on the cruise and vacation aspects of trans-Atlantic ship passenger travel next summer for the sailings of its two luxury liners in Mediterranean service.
A $8,360,939 contract for radio transmitters of the Air Force's B-52 bomber has been awarded to the Hallicrafters Company.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 20 (AP) -- American military aid officials emphatically denied today a report to Congress charging excessive requisitions of military aid by Thailand.
A $35,000,000 order of Braniff International Airways for British Aircraft Corporation BAC-111 jets is the first commitment by a United States carrier for the near short-haul transports.
The second annual "Les Boutiques de Noel" will take place for five days starting Nov. 14 at Milliken House, former residence of the late Dr. Seth M. Milliken at 951 Madison Avenue.

Kalimian Brothers and Fraydun Manocherian, who recently built the Diplomat, a twelve-story and penthouse apartment building at 345 East Eighty-third Street, have obtained a first mortgage loan of $2,612,200 on the property.

The Washington discussions of the relationship between the Western world's investment in education and the prospects for economic growth underlined facts crucial to the future of freedom itself. In sponsoring this conference the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development has given public notice that it was dealing with issues of highest priority.

COLUMBUS, Ga., Oct. 20 (UPI) -- A Muscogee County jury deliberated only seventeen minutes today before finding a Columbus bondsman innocent of killing a Negro client who was slow in paying a bond fee.

Miss Margery Michelmore the Peace Corps member whose postcard wounded Nigerian sensibilities, said here yesterday with good humor that she should have written: "Having wonderful time. Wish you were here."

WASHINGTON. AT 26, when most diplomatic wives, are still learning the ropes and only dreaming of the time when their husbands may be named ambassadors, Mme. Habib Bourguiba Jr. is the polished and fashionable chatelaine of Tunisia's handsome hilltop Embassy in suburban. Washington.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. (AP) -- President Kennedy named a three-member emergency board today to investigate a dispute in Philadelphia between the Reading Company and employes represented by the International Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots, Local No. 14. The dispute involves parity in wages and conditions with commercial tug operations in Philadelphia Harbor.

John Whalen and Bob Esposito, two backfield stars of the undefeated Brooklyn Prep football team, became the center of a controversy yesterday that threatened to curtail the schedule of the Catholic Schools Football Conference.
A report on stevedoring operations in the Port of Haifa, Israel, for 1960, shows that the productivity of dockworkers increased 4 per cent over 1959.
COMMACK, L.I., Oct. 20 -- Commack's school district, the fastest growing in Suffolk County, has established a "supermarket" of materials for enriching its children's educational diet.

GLASSBORO, N.J., Oct. 20 -- Between 150,000 and 200,000 boys and girls will be deprived of a college education by 1970 unless New Jersey increases its facilities for higher education, Richard J. Hughes predicted here today.

DELIGHTING passers-by on Third Avenue at Seventeenth Street is a floor-to-ceiling, wall-to-wall glass window. Behind it is a pebble garden "planted" with an assortment of colored candies guarded by a battalion of pert wooden animals -- elephants, monkeys, owls, bears, cats, rabbits and mice.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) -- The Soviet, Union detonated another nuclear device today, the twenty-first to be announced by the Atomic Energy Commission since Sept. 1.
DALLAS, Oct. 21 (AP) -- When a player gets fined for punching the referee in the American Football League, it can be made public from now on by Joe Foss, the Commissioner.

JACKMAN, Me., Oct. 21 -- Residents of Maine enjoy talking about deer. One aspect of this subject now being discussed at length is the value of early opening dates. They were started last year when the state switched to a system of zones for hunting.

QUITE literally, the house shown here was homework for twenty-three-year-old Yale architectural student Charles Gwathemy. He redesigned this former stable and also did most of the reconstruction himself, for a summer project.

About 80 per cent of all institutions of higher learning now receive Federal funds; and 20 per cent of the total expenditure for higher education in the United States now comes from the National Government.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 21 -- Sweden is rushing extraordinary precautions against the danger, however remote, of perilous fall-out from Soviet nuclear tests.
Mendel N. Fisher, a lifelong Zionist leader, will retire at the end of the year as executive director of the Jewish National Fund of America, a major arm of the World Zionist Organization.

The third ball of the Police Athletic League will be held Nov. 28 in the Grand Ballroom of the Sheraton-East. Mrs. Winthrop Aldrich is honorary chairman and Miss Mary McFadden and Miss Denise Lawson-Johnston are honorary co-chairmen.

A theatre party is being arranged for the benefit of the Jennie Clarkson Home for Children in Valhalla, N.Y. It will take place at the Jan. 5 performance of "Subways Are for Sleeping" with Sydney Chaplin and Carol Lawrence in the leading roles.

" CAMPUS U.S.A." is the liveliest, most interesting volume on higher education to appear in many a year. It consists of "intimate and searching" portraits of ten American colleges and universities, with a rather pretentious introduction, "What the Catalogues Never Tell You," and a concluding chapter, "American Colleges: a Summing Up," that is the most penetrating brief critique of current American higher education this reviewer has seen.
The United Nations, which has already been weakened by the death of Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold, is now confronted with the re-emergence of the Congo crisis in an acute form.
BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Oct. 21 -- Robert Moses today called the Palisades Interstate Park System, "immediately adjacent to a great city," a unique public reservation.
I wonder how many Americans would venture to counter the opinion of an Indian enthusiast, P.U. Narayana, as expressed in a letter to The Madras Mail:

THE ideal fictional sports hero walks a moral tightrope. He must excel personally and as one of a team. He accepts laurels modestly but carries them with due pride. He competes fiercely but with utter fairness. If a winner, he accepts victory with grace.

THE illustrator would like to reply to the comment of Christopher G. Janus in his review of Lloyd W. Daly's "Aesop Without Morals." He objected to the drawing of a two-humped camel to illustrate an Aesopic fable. That the Greeks, by the fifth century B.C. at least, were quite familiar with the two-humped variety is unequivocably evidenced by Herodotus in his account of India.
DURHAM, N.C., Oct. 21 (UPI) -- Jim Parker's passing and running led Clemson to a 17-7 victory over Duke today before 30,000 Homecoming Day fans.
STROUDSBURG, Pa. -- For years, Main Street here has carried the traffic of several major tourist routes and, consequently, has been one of the most formidable highway bottlenecks in the East.
NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 21 -- India was urged today to take the lead in planning "concerted action" in support of nationalists fighting to throw off Portuguese colonialism.
BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Oct. 21 (AP) -- Indiana University's Hoosiers whipped Washington State's football team, 33 -- 7, today and ended an eight-game losing streak.
Sugar Ray Robinson gained a unanimous decision over Denny Moyer of Portland, Ore., in a ten-round bout at Madison Square Garden last night.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 21 - Federal District Judge Robert P. Anderson approved today a petition of the trustees of the New Haven Railroad to borrow $7,500,000. This amount, it was believed, will permit the railroad to operate through next June.

The stock market did not make much headway last week as investors watched the "chess game" being played between Premier Khrushchev and the Free World. Prices moved within a narrow range for the second consecutive week, with trading volume showing little inclination to expand.
Dr. Allison Montague, Columbia University's psychiatric adviser for students, was found dead yesterday in his apartment a day after he had reported falling and cutting his head.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 21 -- Most Americans believe that elderly persons should avoid living with their grown children, according to a study by the University of Michigan Survey Research Center.

Dr. Maurice Ewing has won the American Geographical Society's Cullum Geographical Medal for his contributions to man's knowledge of the oceans, Dr. Walter A. Wood, president of the society, announced yesterday.

DURING a single year The New York Times publishes more than 1,000 recipes. They come from endless sources. Some are translated and adapted from European books on food, others are borrowed from already published regional recipes of America.
MONTREAL, Oct. 21 -- The city of Montreal announced plans last night to build a $150,000 subway.

GUY GREEN, the British director who has impressed American movie-goers with such socially conscious features as "The Angry Silence" and "The Mark," is ready to start another film, which, he trusts, will not be merely an adventure.
The post of food store manager, once considered socially and economically undesirable, has become one of the most challenging and best paid careers for high school and college graduates.

STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 21 -- Barnard College alumnae in this area are planning a weeklong art exhibition at the Stamford Museum starting Nov. 4 as their first fund-raising effort for scholarships at the college.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Oct. 21 (UPI) -- Reginald Webster's Count Amber showed some semblance of his 1960 form today when he outraced the favored Orleans Doge to win the $28,575 Narragansett Special at Narragansett Park.

The Yale Towne Manufacturing Company is planning further enlargement of its overseas divisions, it was disclosed last week by Gordon Patterson, president, in a talk before the New York Society of Security Analysts.

TORONTO, Oct. 21 (Canadian Press) -- Our Jeep, owned by John M. Schiff of New York, today won the $57,500 Canadian Championship Stakes by a neck before a crowd of 21,189. The mile-and-five-furlong race was run over the turf course at New Woodbine.
Retailers who think that progress will go away if they just ignore it were reminded last week that the future lies ahead.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 22 (AP) -- Roman Line survived a foul claim to win the $59,170 Breeders Futurity today on the final day of the Keeneland fall meet.

ROOF gutters which develop leaks or become clogged are almost as bad as no gutters at all. They permit water to pour down the outside of the house walls, washing out foundation plantings, causing paint to peel and, sometimes, basements to flood.

IN "The Price of Liberty," Alan Barth effectively presents the thesis that liberty is being imperiled in the United States for the sake of order. Neurotic anxiety about crime, he contends, is nurturing a police state mentality.

Brisk fall business despite unseasonable weather was reported by resident buying offices here last week. Mink-trimmed coats were in demand, and untrimmed coats and leather coats and jackets also were active. Better Cocktail dresses sold well, with beaded and sequined styles continuing to be popular.

A new September record in building construction was set in Philadelphia. Construction costs reported for permit purposes during the month totaled $20,524,624, or 135 per cent above the August level. The total of $132,031,455 for the first nine months of 1961 was exceeded only in 1925.
LAUREL, Md., Oct. 21 (AP) -- Francois Dupre's Match was added today to the list of entries in the $100,000 Washington D.C. International at Laurel Race Course on Nov. 11.

THERE are in New York City up to eighty neighborhoods characterized by housing officials as ranging from "black" to "gray." The measure is the degree of blight. The "black" neighborhoods are hopeless. In these, the pervasive pattern is such substandard housing and such deprived people that the communities have no hope left.

CAMBRIDGE Mass., Oct. 21 -- The marble-paved shopping street of Sardis where Lydians hunted bargains 1,500 years ago has been uncovered by an American expedition in its fourth summer in western Turkey.

AMHERST, Mass., Oct. 21 (AP) -- Massachusetts scored its third football victory of the season, downing Rhode Island, 25 -- 0, today in a Yankee Conference game. The Redmen remained tied for first in the conference with Maine.

The John Adams High football team, after three straight triumphs, was upset by New Dorp, 12 -- 7, yesterday in a Public Schools Athletic League Division I game at Port Richmond field in Staten Island. It was the second victory in four games for the Warriors.

NAHA, Okinawa -- For most American tourists, the island of Okinawa is just an airfield between Tokyo and Manila. A flashing view of beaches and ocean as the plane comes in, some hazy memories -- "Don't they have a lot of soldiers here!" -- time enough at the airport to pick up a few bottles of tax-free liquor, and off again.

ON these cool autumn nights a good ear can detect the light lisping notes of migrating birds. The nocturnal stridulations of katydids, crickets and long-horned grasshoppers, so overpowering in August and early September, have subsided with the seasonal drop in temperature, allowing us to hear the unobtrusive voices of the small travelers overhead.

Magnets, which in medieval days in the form of compasses guided travelers across, uncharted areas of the earth, today inside gyroscopes are helping rockets navigate uncharted space. This and more than 40,000 other uses have pulled the magnetic materials industry into the $100,000,000-a-year class.
New York University had the individual winner but St. John's gained team honors yesterday in a three-school cross-country meet at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx. Navy was the third participant.

The immense popularity of the classical guitar was demonstrated yesterday afternoon by the crowd that filled Carnegie Recital Hall for the recital by Manuel Gayol. The audience was rewarded by an afternoon full of charm and delight.

ROBIN ROBERTS was sold to the Yankees the other day by the Phils for $25,000. The Phils should regard this as the slickest investment they ever made. They originally paid a $25,000 bonus to the artful pitcher when they plucked him off the Michigan State campus in 1948. Inasmuch as this sum was returned to them eventually, Roberts cost them nothing.

TOKYO, Oct. 19 -- Tokyo's department stores this fall are chock full of customers and culture. Wildly original, brilliantly comic, brutally gruesome, it is a dazzling perform ance that will probably outrage nearly as many readers as it delights.

The Soviet Communist party's Twenty-second Congress, billed in advance as the "Congress of the Builders of Communism," appears likely to go down in history more accurately as the "Congress of the Crisis of World Communism." Advertising by the airlines has been growing increasingly disputatious in recent months. Leading carriers have quarreled openly over which line offers its passengers the ultimate in speed, safety and economy.

MANY years ago people who ran little old Steel businesses in this country thought there was really no other way to do it. An immutable law of necessity governed such things. What things? Why, the custom of running steel mills on a twelve-hour day and a seven-day week.
Louis J. Lefkowitz, in one of his bitterest attacks on Mayor Wagner, accused the Mayor yesterday of conducting a campaign "without parallel in moral dishonesty."
Mayor Wagner formally dedicated a new air sampling station for the Department of Air Pollution Control yesterday atop the Sheraton-Whitehall building at 17 Battery Place.

A spokesman for the National Committee for a Sane Nuclear Policy reported last night that a second secretary at the United Nations Mission of the Soviet Union had said that a fifty-megaton nuclear bomb had not been exploded yesterday but that such a weapon would be tested Oct. 30.

The insurance industry remained divided yesterday on the merits of the New York State "Freedom of Contract" Law specifying brokers' and agents' commissions for the previous twelve months among the factors to be considered in approving new rates.

DETROIT, Oct. 23 -- James R. Hoffa and the International Brotherhood of Teamsters filed a $1,000,000 libel and slander suit today against George Meany and twenty-four other top officers of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations.

WITH the swift grace of a gull wheeling in flight, Gordie Howe swerved in front of the net in Madison Square Garden yesterday morning. A quick flick of his wrists and the puck went whistling into the cage. He skated casually back as another line of Detroit Red Wing attackers went swooping in.

"The old bay mare, she's still what she used to be," chanted Victor Hugo-Vidal Jr. at the Cedar Lodge Farm riding school outside of Stamford, Conn. He referred to the 14-year-old jumper Toraine, with whom he had taken the Maclay Trophy at the National Horse Show in 1951.
Thousands of subway riders were delayed or inconvenienced yesterday morning by a series of IRT service disruptions.
Lieut. Col. Charles Earle of London has been appointed secretary general of the International Cargo Handling Coordination Association.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Oct. 23 (AP) -- The Navy successfully fired an advanced A2 Polaris missile from a submerged submarine for the first time today, but scientists again were frustrated in their efforts to launch a Ranger 2 satellite on a million-mile journey into space.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- The Supreme Court acted today to assure the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People its day in court in Alabama.

Warren Spahn of the Milwaukee Braves captured his third National League earned-run championship and Dick Donovan of the Washington Senators paced the American League in 1961, according to the official averages issued yesterday.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 10 cents a bale off to 25 cents up yesterday. Only the near monts were traded.

A final decision has not yet been made; but it now appears likely that Nationalist China will refrain from vetoing Outer Mongolia's application for admission to the United Nations. The withdrawal of Taipei's opposition would insure membership for the Mongolian Republic, and, incidentally, cause Russia to show her real motivation in opposing United Nations membership for Mauritania.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Oct. 23 -- The Central Government indicated today that it was prepared to ask the United Nations Security Council for a new mandate to deal with Katanga's secession from the Congo.

A Robert J. Crean play entitled "Come Home to Carthage" has been selected for the second program in the series of six original dramas to be televised on "Westinghouse Presents" over the Columbia Broadcasting System.
ORAN, Algeria, Oct. 23 -French policemen opened fire here today to disperse European rioters. Never before had the security forces acted so vigorously in the face of European-Moslem strife in Oran.

Garwol, the Harbor View Farm's 3-year-old who was favored in the 1960 Garden State Stakes, was a lukewarm third choice it the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday. But this quotation meant nothing to Ismael Valenzuela, Garwols rider.
The National Collegiate Athletic Association's master plan for improving the over-all administration of amateur sports in the United States was spelled out more clearly yesterday.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 23 -- Caleb, the fastest 3-year-old trotter, in history, was made the 2 -- 1 choice today for Friday night's $83,175 Dexter Cup Trot at Roosevelt Raceway at a mile and a sixteenth.
BOSTON, Oct. 23 (UPI) -- A Federal judge refused today to dismiss indictments against three lawyers charged with attempted bribery of an internal revenue official.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) -- The Internal Revenue Service has given to New York members of Congress fresh ammunition in their fight to get more defense contracts for their state.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Oct. 23 -- Today was just another day in Budapest.

Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa, the independent Citizens party candidate for Mayor, held Mayor Wagner and Board of Education "bureaucrats" responsible yesterday for delays in starting construction of seventeen schools.

A PETITE Englishwoman is holding out the banner of fashion for other small women on a budget. From an apartment at 143 East Eighteenth Street, Terri Halpern has started her own concern with dresses, suits and coats especially designed for sizes 5 to 10.

The bond market marked time yesterday as it awaited several tax-exempt flotations and a major corporate issue that are to be marketed today. Most dealers spent the day attending pricing meetings on the scheduled issues.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 23 -- Abraham A. Ribicoff presented a prospectus tonight for changing the Government's approach to social welfare.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 23 -- South Africa took part today in the United Nations debate over its racial policies for the first time in fifteen years.

With President Kennedy wishing it well, the Metropolitan Opera opened its new season last night. The venerable company, although perhaps too old to be a bride, nevertheless entered its seventy-seventh year equipped with something new, something borrowed and something blue.
Magistrate Morton R. Tolleris ordered an investigation yesterday of a slum landlord who had pleaded guilty in Housing Court to 287 building violations.
LONDON, Oct. 23 -- The shrill echo of a trumpeted "Fanfare for Heroes" rang through Westminster Abbey today in tribute to the late United Nations Secretary General, Dag Hammarskjold.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 23 (AP) -- The effects of a fifty-megaton bomb explosion would be felt throughout the world for at least the next five years, an official at the Johns Hopkins Hospital said today.

GARLIC has been described as "just like an onion, only more so." And, just like an onion only more so, garlic has been ascribed medicinal properties of every description. Not content with recommending it for all sorts of physical ailments, some enthusiasts have gone so far as to prescribe garlic as an aid to spiritual health.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Archie Moore floored Pete Rademacher eight times and scored a sixth-round technical knockout tonight in their scheduled ten-round non-title fight at the Coliseum.
OSLO, Norway, Oct. 23 -- The Nobel Peace Prize Committee announced today the award of the 1961 prize to the late Dag Hammarskjold and of the 1960 prize to Chief Albert John Luthuli of South Africa.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- The Soviet Union conducted the largest man-made explosion in history early today by detonating a thermonuclear bomb with a force equal to 30,000,000 tons or more of TNT.

The Oct. 19 report on urban renewal in Greenwich Village indicates once more the complete disregard some public officials have for the people they are supposed to serve. James Felt and the Planning Commission, in voting to raze the designated West Village area to make room for urban renewal, are bringing closer that time when Greenwich Village will be no more than a memory.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 23 -- President William V. S. Tubman of Liberia deplored today the tendency of some powers "to seduce and coerce" other nations into adopting their system of government.
An absent-minded professor who could not remember what program he was scheduled to appear on last night for the National Broadcasting Company ended up as a special guest on two programs.

ST. GEORGE'S, Grenada, B.W.I., Oct. 23 (Reuters) -Agents for the fire-stricken Italian liner Bianca C. arranged today for the Italian Line's Amerigo Vespucci to take on 285 of the ill-fated ship's passengers.

The Armco Steel Corporation reported that third-quarter earnings advanced to $14,513,437, or 98 cents a share, from $11,693,836, or 79 Cents a share, in the 1960 period. The figures for the latest period represented the best quarterly profit level achieved by the company thus far in 1961.

In his letter of Oct. 13 the delegate of Spain to the United Nations deplores the conduct of nonaligned nations in general and economic aid to Yugoslavia in particular. Although there is much to be criticized about the recent passivity of neutralist leaders in the face of growing tension between the Soviet Union and the United States, it seems that in Sr. Cacho-Zabalza's case the pot is calling the kettle black.

The board of directors of New York Americans for Democratic Action yesterday endorsed Leo Brown, Liberal candidate for Borough President of Queens, Jacob Zukerman, Liberal candidate for Borough President of Brooklyn.
The Wishnow Horowitz Real Estate Company was the broker for the sale recently of five apartment houses in the Bronx. Four were five-story buildings and one had five and a half.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Oct. 23 -- The director of teacher training at the State University's Long Island Center resigned his post today amid charges that the president of the center had undermined the programs.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Oct. 23 -- President Joaquin Balaguer said today that some members on the Trujillo family, which has been under severe Opposition attack here, would leave the country in the next few days.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Tuesday, Oct. 24 -- Government leaders declined to comment last night on the award of the Nobel Peace Prize to Albert Luthuli.
OUTDOORSMEN who want to avoid the bang of firearms these days might do worse than to pick up a fishing rod and investigate the striped-bass and bluefish fishing available near-by.
Science has at its command the knowledge to feed every hungry person on earth, but the problem remains because no one could pick up the check, a scientist and college president said yesterday.
ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 23 (Reuters) -- The four parties that participated in the Turkish general election earlier this month have agreed to form a coalition Government.
After sixteen years and many disillusionments, the words of the United Nations Charter still have power to move us. On this, the sixteenth birthday of the U.N., we think of them.

THERE is a delightful little baroque theatre at the Casa Italiana, 1161 Amsterdam Avenue, at 117th Street, complete with balcony, chandeliers, and coats of arms. Through the cooperation of various Italian Government agencies, some thirty large pieces of contemporary Italian sculpture have been assembled under its ornate roof.
Denying women the chance to develop fully their intelligence depresses the ability of both sexes to think, Dr. Margaret Mead said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -President Kennedy returned to the White House today after his seventeenth consecutive holiday week-end. On his calendar for tomorrow were two important conferences.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -The Bureau of the Census published today the first installment of a statistical cliff-hanger called "Business Cycle Developments" -- a story, in numbers, of where the economy has been, where it is, and where it may be headed.

The Kennedy Administration will have made one of its most serious mistakes if it conducts any atmospheric nuclear test as Adlai Stevenson threatened in the U.N. on Oct. 19. It is possible that the Russian fifty-megaton test by itself will contaminate most of the world's food and milk above the maximum permissible concentration of thirty-three strontium units, as established by the International Commission on Radiological Protection.
MADISON, WIS., Oct. 23 (UPI) -- State School Superintendent Angus Rothwell today banned the use of the McGuffey Readers even as supplementary material in Twin Lakes schools.
John Ranck gave a program of French piano-music last night at Carnegie Recital Hall.

The Nuclear Corporation of America is offering holders of its capital stock rights to subscribe for $2,087,800 of 5 1/2 per cent convertible subordinated debentures due Nov. 1, 1976, on the basis of a $100 debenture for every 300 capital shares held of record of yesterday. The subscription price is 100.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 23 -- Pakistan protested to the Soviet Union today against derogatory remarks made about her by Premier Khrushchev to the Communist party congress in Moscow last Tuesday.

ANOTHER season, another Metropolitan Opera opening. Last night's was elegant off stage and on, with a distinguished audience and a most unusual opera. Puccini's "La Fanciulla del West" -- "The Girl of the Golden West" -- had not been in the vicinity of the Metropolitan since the 1931-32 season.
The State of New Hampshire plans to offer at competitive bidding on Nov. 15 $16,415,000 of highway and various purpose bonds.
Several prominent specialists said yesterday that they almost invariably told their patients when they had cancer, but differed as to when, in the course of the disease, it was best to do so.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 23 -- Dag Hammarskjold's efforts to maintain or mend the world's peace, which won for him today the posthumous award of the Nobel Peace Prize for 1961, covered a wide range of activities.

STORMVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 23 (AP) -- The 1,966 inmates of Green Haven State Prison ended a three-day hunger strike tonight after receiving promises from the warden and the State Commissioner of Correction that their grievances would be looked into.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Monday, Oct. 23 -- Government-promoted production of supersonic jet airliners would aggravate the problem of passenger overcapacity and force airlines back on public subsidy, a transportation official warned today.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 23 -The United States Deputy Secretary of Defense offered West Germany today a wide-ranging integration of the two countries' military logistics in West Germany.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Fourteen Midwestern power companies have offered to supply the Federal Government with electricity when Federal hydroelectric plants along the Missouri River are unable to operate up to capacity.
BARRE, Vt., Oct. 23 (AP) -- "I don't think anybody is unbeatable," Governor Rockefeller of New York said today when asked whether a Republican could defeat President Kennedy in 1964.

The directors of Botany Industries, Inc., have voted the first dividend on the common stock since 1949. It will be in the form of one common share of Premier Industries, Inc., for each ten shares of Botany common held.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) -- A Government expert on radiation said today that he did not expect such an explosion as the thirty-fifty megaton blast by the Soviet Union would push the fall-out level in the United States to a danger point.

SEOUL, Korea, Oct. 23 -- Lieut. Gen. Chang Do Young, former head of the South Korean junta, and twenty-five of his military followers were indicted today on charges of having engaged in anti-revolutionary activities.

Middle South Utilities, Inc., and its subsidiaries reported yesterday a slight decline in total operating revenues for twelve months ended on Sept. 30. Electric operating revenues alone rose by 4.7 per cent.

Army and Syracuse were invited yesterday to play in the Gotham Bowl, the post-season football game at the Polo Grounds Dec. 9. However, West Point officials and Lew Andreas, director of athletics at Syracuse, indicated little receptiveness toward the invitation.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 23 -- Outer Mongolia and Mauritania are expected to be approved for United Nations membership when the Security Council meets Wednesday, diplomatic sources said today.
GENEVA, Oct. 23 -- The six-week-old United Nations Sugar Conference recessed here today after failing to break a deadlock over a demand by Cuba that her export quota be enlarged.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 23 (AP) -- The state's Correction Commissioner attacked a segment of the press today and said it was "high time that all of us [in prison work] stand up and speak in our defense."
BERLIN, Tuesday, Oct. 24 -- East and West Berlin policemen fought a duel with tear gas grenades for nearly half an hour last night, the West Berlin police reported today.
Vito P. Battista, mayoral candidate on the United Taxpayers ticket, said yesterday the Wagner Administration handled the city's traffic problem "on a par with the horse and buggy era."

SAIGON, Vietnam, Oct. 23 -The impression has spread here that South Vietnam's leaders are now inclined to view the possibility of United States military intervention in their Communist-threatened country more favorably than before.

A Board of Higher Education investigation has cleared Dr. John J. Theobald, the Superintendent of Schools, of anonymous charges that he misused city supplies while he was president of Queens College from 1949 to 1958.
Northeast winds an a full moon combined yesterday to create flood conditions in sections of lower Manhattan and New Jersey.
LONDON, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Three fillies tonight led the call-over for Saturday's Cambridgeshire Handicap -- a horse race that has not been won by a filly since World War II.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today a reduction of 100,000 tons in the Continued on Page 58, Column 2 Continued From Page 49 allocation of sugar authorized for purchase in 1961 from three countries in an effort to increase the price of raw sugar in the United States.

I make this reply to Senator Herbert H. Lehman's letter in the Oct. 21 Times supporting Mayor Wagner. I have every respect for my predecessor, but I believe this exchange may bring out clearly a vital point in this campaign that will enable voters to decide wisely.
A wealthy man with a penchant for helping human derelicts was arrested yesterday for extending the hospitality of his Harlem shelter to narcotics addicts.

A new television station -- the city's eighth -- went on the air for the first time yesterday before an audience of hardly anyone. It was WUHF, operating on Channel 31, a channel that cannot be seen on most existing sets without the purchase of a converter.

PARIS, Oct. 23 -- Frenchmen of all shades of political opinion joined today in a wave of protest against alleged police brutality in the suppression of Algerian demonstrators here last week and what were termed inhuman detention conditions since.
SYRACUSE, Oct. 23 -- A permanent watchdog committee on school finances was proposed here tonight by Joseph F. Carlino, Speaker of the New York State Assembly.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -Treasury bill rates declined on today's sale of the regular weekly issues. The sale raised $100,000,000 of new cash for the Government, in addition to the $1,600,000,000 needed to retire this week's maturing issues.
Two young teachers blamed college teacher-training programs yesterday for much of the reading difficulties in the city schools.
YONKERS, Oct. 23 -- A total of 133 head -- racing stock, broodmares and yearlings -- brought $171,150, an average of $1,286 apiece, as the Old Glory Horse Sales opened at Yonkers Raceway today.

CHESTERTOWN, Md., Oct. 23 -- On the theory that "creative selling" can build the greatest prosperity this country has ever known, a school for executive salesmen -- the men who direct salesmen by the thousands in the field -- was put into action today.

LAKEVILLE, Conn., Oct. 23 -- Boarding-school headmasters have operated for years on the theory that all work and no play makes anyone a dull boy. However, there is a definite trend now to put greater emphasis on work.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- The man who opens the sessions of the Supreme Court with the cry of "oyez, oyez, oyez", was admitted to the bar of the court today.
THE collection Bill Blass has done for Maurice Rentner Ltd. is being praised by the press and buyers. It stresses the dominant looks prevalent in fashions for spring:

The Studebaker-Packard Corporation reported yesterday that it operated at a smaller loss in the third quarter of this year than in the comparable 1960 quarter. However, the loss for the first nine months of the year was more than $10,000,000, contrasted with a small profit in the 1960 period.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 23 (AP) -- A Federal District Court today ordered full desegregation of all schools in Lebanon and Wilson County, effective next Jan. 2.

BERLIN, Oct. 23 -- Maj. Gen. Albert H. Watson 2d, the United States commandant in West Berlin, protested today to his Soviet counterpart in East Berlin against the detention last night of a United States diplomat by East German guards.

ALBANY, Oct. 23 -- The Court of Appeals has upheld the right of labor union locals to quit an international union expelled from the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations because of unethical practices.
Nine major college football teams remain undefeated and untied this season, an Associated Press survey showed yesterday.
CHICAGO, Oct. 23 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
The National Maritime Union is embarking on a program of closer cooperation with maritime-workers groups in the Caribbean and Central America.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 23 -- The announcement that Dag Hammarskjold had been posthumously awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for 1961 was welcomed by many here today.

YORK, Pa., Oct. 23 (AP) -Representative Leslie C. Arends of Illinois, House Republican whip, rebuked the Kennedy Administration today for what he said was "spending money to be politically popular at home and diplomatically popular abroad."
MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 23 -The Nassau Democratic County Committee sent a $10,000 check today to the campaign fund of Robert W. Dill, the Republican candidate for County Executive.

GENEVA, Oct. 23 (UPI) -The United States called today on the sixteen participants in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) textile conference to adopt a policy of "orderly expansion" in textile trading.

LYNDHURST, N.J., Oct. 23 -- Richard J. Hughes said here today that the election of James P. Mitchell, his Republican opponent for Governor, could re-open the doors to organized gambling and underworld activities in Bergen County.

An indictment charging John Dioguardia, the labor racketeer known as Johnny Dio, with conspiracy and extortion in an $11,500 shakedown was dismissed yesterday by General Sessions Judge Gerald P. Culkin.

GENEVA, Oct. 23 -- Qualified sources here said today that the United States would nominate Bastiaan W. Haveman of the Netherlands tomorrow for director of the thirty-nation InterGovernmental Committee for European Migration.
The first step toward establishing a municipal land bank was taken here yesterday.
Stocks sank in a soggy market yesterday, registering the widest losses in The New York Times combined and industrial averages since Sept. 25.

The Twist Party, a dinner dance to be held at the Four Seasons on Nov. 6, will benefit Girls Town in Mount Plymouth, Fla. For the occasion a plastic dance floor will be put over the pool at the restaurant. The Twist will be one of the dances on the program.

Mayor Wagner was endorsed for re-election yesterday by the three daily newspapers published in New York by S.I. Newhouse. They are The Long Island Press, The Long Island Star-Journal and The Staten Island Advance.
MOSCOW, Oct. 24 -- Mikhail A. Sholokhov, the Soviet novelist, complained today that Soviet literature and drama were backward. He said much of the mediocrity stemmed from artificial city life.
HONG KONG, Oct. 24 -- Mao Tse-tung, chairman of the Chinese Community party, greeted Premier Chou En-lai at Peiping Airport today as the Premier returned from Moscow.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) -- The nations two principal manufacturers of lock bolts were indicted in Detroit today on antitrust charges, the Justice Department announced.
St. Peter's High of Staten Island won the sixth annual Christian Brothers High Schools cross-country championship at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx, yesterday.
The popular "Wagon Train" series will hitch its horses to American Broadcasting Company television next season after five years of trekking cross-country with the National Broadcasting Company.
East and West met last evening as dancing partners and as each other's guests at the Salute to the United Nations Ball.
Police Commissioner Michael J. Murphy has cautioned Mayor Wagner against promising greater police protection to private housing developments.
PRETORIA, South Africa, Oct. 24 -- Albert S. Geyser, a Dutch Reformed Church minister and university professor, went on trial today behind closed doors on a charge of heresy.

City controller Lawrence E. Gerosa charged yesterday that Mayor Wagner was being supported by "sinister elements of the racket-ridden garment industry" in his bid for re-election.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 24 -- An Acting Secretary General to succeed Dag Hammarskjold as head of the United Nations will be named this week, Adlai E. Stevenson, United States delegate to the international organization, said tonight.

Considering the current evangelical tone of sophisticated cabaret humor, it is not too startling to find that Jackie Mason has actually come to his profession from the ministerial ranks. The Ford Foundation announced grants yesterday of more than $15,000,000 for the long-term development of non-Western and other international studies.

LONDON, Oct. 24 -- Fewer ships were being built in British shipyards at the end of last month than at any time in the last sixteen years.

ST. GEORGE'S, Grenada, B.W.I., Oct. 24 (AP) -- The 18,427-ton Italian liner Bianca C. sank off Point Saline in St. George Anchorage today after having burned fiercely since Sunday morning from an engine room explosion.

Union Settlement will benefit from a theatre party to the Nov. 15 evening performance of "The Complaisant Lover" at the Ethel Barrymore Theatre. Tickets may be obtained from the beneficiary's headquarters at 237 East 104th Street.
A ground-breaking ceremony was held yesterday for the Arthur H. Murphy Houses, a state-aided public housing project to be built in the Bronx by the New York City Housing Authority.

ROME, Oct. 24 -- Hugh Gaitskell, leader of the British Labor party, assured the seventh congress of the Socialist International today that his party "fully accepts the obligation" to protect freedom of the people of West Berlin.
Let me commend The Times for its immediate editorial of Oct. 17 on Dr. James B. Conant's report on schools in the nation's metropolitan areas.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -Pablo Casals, world-famous violoncellist, will play for President and Mrs. Kennedy and their guests on Nov. 13.

DESMOND YOUNG, a retired English officer and gentleman who now lives on the island of Sark in the Channel Islands, is one of those daring and enterprising men who fill lesser men with envy. Stuck in their well-worn ruts between house and office, clinging to the familiar and the secure, they dream of leading a life like Mr. Young's.
LONDON, Oct. 24 -- A new Constitution for Malta was promulgated today.
HONG KONG, Wednesday, Oct. 25 -- An increasing number of refugees are fleeing from Communist China to Hong Kong as winter draws near.
MIAMI, Oct. 23 -- Active opposition to the regime of Premier Fidel Castro in Cuba is reported to be rising markedly.

DETROIT, Oct. 24 (AP) -The United Automobile Workers reported today substantial progress in negotiating settlements on working conditions at the Chrysler Corporation plants.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The Navy has won a significant commitment for the role of the super-aircraft carrier in the country's future defense forces, qualified sources said today.

A $20,000,000 issue of New Zealand bonds is being Offered in the United States public capital market today. Priced at 97 1/2, the fifteen-year bonds bear 5 3/4 per cent interest coupons. Kidder, Peabody Co., the manager of the offering, originally registered $15,000,000 of the bonds, but increased the aggregate upon indications of widespread interest.
The Navy is reported to be planning ocean tests soon of a new kind of battery that uses carefully selected strains of bacteria to promote the flow of electricity.
The Cambodian Chief of State has acted with characteristic excitability and imperiousness in initiating a break in relations between Thailand and Cambodia.
One of five locals of milk truck drivers and plant workers went on strike yesterday after rejecting an employer proposal to continue negotiations beyond a 4 P.M. deadline.

After fourteen years as a leading New York film society, alternately presenting medical documentaries, experimental short subjects and revivals of old features, Cinema 16 plans to concentrate in the future on the little-known works of prominent foreign filmmakers.
Thirty-three cases containing 582 violations in buildings managed by David B. Solove were adjourned in Housing Court yesterday after a statement of good faith by Mr. Solove.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Secretary of Commerce Luther H. Hodges said today he was "still as bullish" as ever about economic prospects even though his department had reported a "slowdown in the business upsurge."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Government scientists today reiterated their view that the nation's new "copper curtain" experiment in space was innocent of any connection with television interference reported in some parts of the United States and abroad.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Democratic leaders from New Jersey came here today in quest of high-level support for their candidate for Governor, Richard J. Hughes.

FOR everyone who has ever been caught up in the last-minute frenzy of Christmas preparations and vowed to "start early next year," now is not a minute too soon to begin ordering gifts that must be personalized.

General of the Army Omar N. Bradley was re-elected board chairman of the Eleanor Roosevelt Cancer Foundation at the board's annual meeting yesterday in the Savoy-Hilton Hotel.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Oct. 24 (UPI) -- A Giant Titan missile fired on an ocean-spanning flight tonight was detected successfully by a new "spy-in-the-sky" Midas IV satellite.

Directors of the prosperous Norfolk and Western Railway at a meeting in Philadelhpia yesterday agreed that "some day" their system would be willing to discuss an affiliation with the troubled Erie-Lackawanna Railroad.

CHICAGO, Oct. 24 (AP) -After a feeble show of firmness in initial dealings the grain futures market began a slow drift into weakness today and finished with numerous losses of major fractions to more than a cent a bushel.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (UPI) -- The Washington Post and Times-Herald ran an obituary notice on its editorial page today for the "unnumbered hundreds of thousands" who will die-because of yesterday's huge Soviet nuclear test.

Tennessee Polytechnic Institute of Cookeville, Tenn., and East Tennessee State College of Johnson City, Tenn., were placed on probation yesterday by the National Collegiate Athletic Association for violating the rules on recruiting and financial aid to athletes.

The Gulf Oil Corporation reported yesterday for the nine months ended on Sept. 30, a consolidated net income of $248,935,000. This was equal to $2.36 each on the 105,377,698 capital shares that will be outstanding after the payment of a 2 per cent stock dividend in December.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Foreign investors had an $18,400,000,000 stake in United States business at the end of last year -- one-fifth the American stake abroad -- the Department of Commerce reported today.

MIAMI BEACH, Oct. 24 -- Federal spending for research is increasing at such a rate that there are said to be fears, within the American Heart Association, that public support for private research will be seriously weakened.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Oct. 24 -The development of nuclear-propelled rockets, essential for interplanetary travel, could be accomplished a year sooner with more funds, the chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission said today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Fall-out from the current Soviet tests is expected to increase the amount of radioactive strontium 90 in children's bones in the Northern Hemisphere by as much as 50 per cent.

BUFFALO, Oct. 24 -- The record of the Rockefeller Administration on labor legislation was attacked today by a state labor leader. He said that the Governor's "conservative action speaks louder than his liberal words."

The Appellate Division yesterday thwarted a campaign led by Harry Weinberg, a Dallas transit operator, to win control of Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc. The five-man tribunal unanimously reversed a judgment handed down by Supreme Court Justice Henry Epstein last June.

BERLIN, Oct. 24 -- A spokesman for the United States mission in West Berlin said tonight that American civilians had been "advised" to "go slow" about entering East Berlin until more was learned about new Communist orders governing such entry.

Paperboard production in the nation totaled 355,206 tons last week, compared with 349,905 tons the preceding week, and 327,941 tons in the comparable 1960 week, the National Paperboard Association reported yesterday.
LOYAL alumni can take their children in tow for a visit to the alma mater on a football week-end. A drive through the countryside during this season of blazing foliage is a bonus.
The City Planning Commission yesterday dropped its controversial proposal to rezone a 150-acre tract just east of the New York International Airport.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The Administration had under "full review" today the case of a former Cuban secret service colonel who is employed by the Immigration and Naturalization Service in Miami.
The United States will not impose population control on any nation receiving foreign aid, the deputy United States Representative to the United Nations said last night.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed unchanged to 20 cents a bale off yesterday. Only the three near months were traded.

Robert E. Lee, a member of the Federal Communications Commission, has cautioned television servicemen and do-it-yourself tinkerers in the metropolitan area not to judge the effectiveness of the city's newest station, WUHF, until the ultra-high-frequency station was operating on full power with a regular antenna radiating in all directions.

LONDON, Oct. 24 -- Prices of British Government securities bounded ahead in the stock market here today, while industrial shares were depressed by the prospect of an early introduction of a short-term capital gains tax.
Police Commissioner Michael J. Murphy yesterday inspected the first of the new Emergency Service Division patrol cars that will replace twenty older models.

SYDNEY, Australia, Oct. 24 (UPI) -- It will be ten or fifteen years before the ordinary traveler can use supersonic planes moving three times the speed of sound, and much longer before he can zoom through outer space aboard a rocket, the United States' former space agency chief told the International Air Transport Association today.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 24 -- Thailand disclaimed today all responsibility for the Cambodian rupture of relations with this country and said Cambodia must bear all consequences "for any increased frictions and tension and for any deterioration in the relationship between the two countries."
CHICAGO, Oct. 24 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
Vito P. Battista, the United Taxpayers candidate for Mayor, charged yesterday that it had become "a badge of dishonor" to own property in New York City.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 24 -- An agreement between the world's most influential talent agency and the Screen Actors Guild that may have considerable impact on the nation's show business was announced today.
Subscribers to the Nov. 8 performance of "Sail Away" at the Broadhurst Theatre have been announced. The theatre party will aid the Citizens Committee for Children.

The Raytheon Company, Lexington, Mass., has reached an agreement in principle to buy all of the business and assets of the Rheem Semiconductor Corporation, Mountain View, Calif., a subsidiary of the Rheem Manufacturing Company, New York.

Briggs S. Cunningham, one of the nation's outstanding sportsmen, was named the first winner of the Edmund G. (Ned) Anderson Trophy last night at the annual dinner of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) -- The Public Health Service has set up three new fall-out detection stations in Alaska "to get the earliest possible indication of the stuff from the big bomb."

BOSTON, Oct. 24 -- A member of the United Nations Secretariat, Robert K.A. Gardiner of Ghana, delivered a fervent appeal today for preserving the role of Secretary General as personified by the late Dag Hammarskjold.

PORT JEFFERSON, L.I., Oct. 24 -- Mike Fetchick, Tony Kaczenski and Tom Strafaci shared the lead with par-equaling 72's as the Port Jefferson open got under way on the Harbor Hills Country Club's rolling course today.

There was good news for many stockholders yesterday in the form of announcements of dividend increases, extra dividend payments and stock dividends. In contrast, there were a few reports of dividend omissions or reductions.

In England, Arthur L. Kopit's play with the long title, "Oh Dad, Poor Dad, Mamma's Hung You in the Closet and I'm Feelin' So Sad," constituted the entire program. Here it will be preceded by a curtain raiser, "Sing to Me Through Open Windows," also bearing Mr. Kopit's trade-mark.
MOST people buy furniture not in one fell swoop but over a period of months and years. And often, between the first and the last purchase, there is a sharp divergence in their preferences.
MOSCOW, Oct. 24 -- The chief propaganda official of the Soviet Union declared today that the "authority of a leader" must not be confused with the "cult of personality."

A DAZZLING off-Broadway show opens today on Fifth Avenue. It is an exhibition of the designs of Faberge, the Russian goldsmith and court jeweler. Actually it is a double show for it was planned to coincide with the formal opening of A La Vieille Russie's new galleries at 781 Fifth Avenue, at Fifty-ninth Street.

POUND RIDGE, N.Y., Oct. 24 (UPI) -- The Newburgh city manager, Joseph McD. Mitchell, struck back today at criticism of his welfare reform program by Abraham A. Ribicoff, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, as "unfair, unfounded and following the Liberal-Socialist party line."

A Supreme Court justice yesterday ordered that the 12-year-old son of divorced parents be indoctrinated in the Jewish faith, his father's religion, despite his professed wish to become a Christian Scientist, like his mother.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The use of computers and other improved techniques will speed up the Pentagon's $93,000,000 fall-out shelter survey sufficiently to provide data next February for new proposals by the Administration, civil defense officials predicted today.

The State Investigation Commission released yesterday a report accusing Armand D'Angelo, City Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, of an impropriety "in lending his office" for promotional purposes. He immediately denied the charge.
JERSEY CITY, Oct. 24 -- Six North Jersey Mayors agreed today to seek a state subsidy for the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad to avert a 5-cent-fare increase.

AS it did two years ago, the Philadelphia Orchestra last night began its New York season with its "second" New York program. The reason for the omission of the first one was the same as in 1959: a strike at home.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Three Senators, returning from a month's tour of fifteen countries of Africa, expressed confidence today that freedom was winning there and that most countries were rejecting communism.

In accepting the resignation of Royce H. Savage as a Federal district judge in Oklahoma, President Kennedy omitted the usual good wishes. Evidently he was troubled, as others have been, by the circumstances of the resignation. Judge Savage left the bench to become general counsel of the Gulf Oil Corporation. Less than two years ago he had acquitted twenty-nine oil companies, including Gulf, of criminal antitrust charges.
In the lead editorial in The Times for Oct. 19 you characterized my attitude as negative.

Commercial paper rates were cut yesterday by one-eighth of a point on the shortest-term maturities by many of the major specialty finance companies, with the Commercial Credit Company leading the way.
LLOYD BRIDGES gave an exciting performance last night in a television dramatization of true adventures of a United States Air Force officer captured by the enemy in North Korea.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Oct. 24 -- About 500 women protested today to the Inter-American Human Rights Commission against excessive police action and appealed for help in obtaining the release of political prisoners.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (UPI) -- The airlines are abandoning their plans to eliminate liquor and meal service for coach passengers, industry sources reported today.

It is encouraging to the future of organized amateur athletics in this country that the colleges and high schools are beginning to take a more active interest in the administration of sports on the national and international levels.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 24 -- The United Nations celebrated its sixteenth anniversary today in an atmosphere of serious concern that reflected the tone of observances throughout the world.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 24 -- A Protestant theologian and a Roman Catholic prelate, both national leaders in social welfare, disagreed today on the place of government in this field.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- President Kennedy received a letter from Chancellor Adenauer today in which the West German leader stands firmly by the hard line he has taken on negotiations with the Soviet Union on Berlin.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) -- President Kennedy took part today in ceremonies marking completion of the first transcontinental telegraph circuit a century ago.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 24 -The Nassau Democratic County Committee was criticized today for its offer of $10,000 to the Republican candidate for County Executive if he debates campaign issues with "any eighth-grader in a Nassau school."

American designers are now showing their spring collections, to stores, preceding the openings in Paris and Italy. Spring fashions are not shown in Europe until January and February. The clothes described below will be in the stores by the first of the year.
Some, including Charlie Conerly, might think that last Sunday's dramatic, game-winning performance by the 40-year-old Mississippian regained for him the first-string, quarterback job with the Giants.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) -- A Kentucky couple can take an income tax deduction for the $45,000 they spent in fighting an income tax claim against them, the United States Tax Court has ruled.

The New York City Opera is commissioning an opera based on "Mamba's Daughters," a hit play of the Nineteen Thirties by Du Bose and Dorothy Heyward. The Heywards were the authors of "Porgy," the play on which George Gershwin's "Porgy and Bess" was based.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 24 -- The United States assured West Germany today that its promises to give Bonn's armed forces nuclear capability would be fulfilled. A communique on the two-day meeting of the American Deputy Secretary of Defense, Roswell L. Gilpatric, and West Germany's Defense Minister, Franz Josef Strauss, said:
A nation-wide system of centers where able students could register for Federal scholarship aid was proposed yesterday by John F. Morse, a former chief of the National Defense Student Loan Program.

Proposed Amendment 6, which will be up for referendum on Nov. 7, deserves the support of all New York State voters who desire improved and expanded facilities for the colleges and universities of the state. This measure, it may be stated immediately, was conceived with great care by legal experts.

THREE items, presumably unrelated, appeared in the most recent edition of The Sporting News, the baseball journal of record. Each seemed to have no overwhelming significance by itself. But when tied together in one untidy package, they provide grotesque and alarming outlines for the future.
LONDON, Oct. 25 -- Edward Albee's "The American Dream" and "The Death of Bessie Smith" opened here tonight at the Royal Court Theatre.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Oct. 24 -- Ministers of the six-nation European Economic Community cut the proposed administrative budget sharply today to leave vacant positions for Britain, Denmark and other countries that may join.

MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 22 (AP) -- An explosion blasted out the front of a building in North Miami occupied by Teamster Union Local 290 and littered the street with glass and debris tonight. No one was injured.
Michigan borrowed $35,000,000 yesterday at a net interest cost of 3.7641 per cent.
President Kennedy will be asked to intervene in behalf of 3,700 civilian employes, including 750 longshoremen, who face the loss of their jobs if the Brooklyn Army Terminal is closed.
The Robert A. Taft Institute of Government yesterday announced a program to promote political education and to combat political apathy among Americans.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 24 -- High officials here have ratified a truce pact between the United Nations and secessionist Katanga Province in the Congo. Their action was regarded here as the most important executive decision in the five weeks that the Secretary General's post has been vacant.
Mayor Wagner moved yesterday to revive a plan for the city to invest about $12,000,000 in the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts.
The New York Rangers will be out to gain sole posession of first place in the National Hockey League when they skate against the big Chicago Black Hawks at Madison Square Garden tonight.

James Reston in his column of Oct. 6 discusses the German problem from a viewpoint which ought not to he left unanswered. Mr. Reston writes that the questions now are (1) "whether the West German Government will accept the present Polish boundary and grant de facto recognition to the East Germans and (2) what the psychological and political reaction will be in West Germany if it does."
Hardly a minute passed in which the New York Knickerbockers failed to distinguish themselves last night while beating the St. Louis Hawks, 112-110, at Madison Square Garden.
ARE you nostalgic for Paris? Join Yves Montand at the John Golden Theatre on a personally conducted tour that is almost as gay and sentimental as a visit.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Oct. 24 -- At least seven persons were killed and about fifty were injured as a result of riots and other violence in La Paz last night.

This is the time of year when television screens suddenly seem to come alive with squawking dolls, walking teddy-bears make-believe robots, toy missiles and myriad other playthings, as toy manufacturers pour millions of dollars into their final pre-Christmas sales drives.

CLARK, N.J., Oct. 24 -- A two-acre laboratory with the single purpose of finding new uses for polymers in plastics was dedicated here today by the Celanese Polymer Company, a division of the Celanese Corporation of America.
The Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation borrowed $70,000,000 in the new capital market yesterday in separate competitive sales of mortgage bonds and common stock.

The Institute for the Crippled and Disabled is planning a major expansion of research, professional education and patient services, its newly elected president, Mrs. H. Lawrence Bogert Jr., announced yesterday.
A descendant of a former Mayor of New York was accused yesterday in Felony Court of possessing two hypodermic needles and of having permitted narcotics addicts to loiter in his home.

RED BANK, N.J., Oct. 24 -- The Air Taxi Company established new flight volume records for the first nine months of 1961, James Loeb, president of the company, announced today. Total revenue trips for the period came to 7,492, up 24.4 per cent over the comparable period in 1960.
ONE of the most difficult problems confronting the television dramatist is how to raise his voice on contemporary moral issues without running afoul of the home screen's distaste for controversy.
Sales of the Union Carbide Corporation rose to a record for the quarter ended on Sept. 30, but net income fell from the level of the 1960 period, Morse G. Dial, president, reported yesterday.
LONDON, Oct. 24 -- Voit Gilmore, director of the United States Travel Service, ended a two-week European tour tonight convinced that a "tide" of visitors was ready to go to America.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Irvin C. Scarbeck's lawyer said today that the former diplomat's relationship with a 22-year-old Polish woman had been primarily "altruistic," that he had tried to pull her "up from the gutter."

While some business forecasters have been predicting lately that the consumer is about to embark on a buying spree, a contrary opinion was voiced yesterday by a panel of sales finance company executives.

Following is the text of statement yesterday by Goodman A. Sarachan, chairman of the State Investigation Commission, together with a commission report dealing with the affairs of former Deputy City Treasurer Philip H. Gilsten; Francis Kenna, former Republican leader of Queens County, and Armand D'Angelo, city Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity:
THE following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is offered for an easy-to-prepare main dish.

WASHINGTON, Oct 24 -- A State Department official told a Senate investigating panel today that the United States had no way of knowing that its exports to Yugoslavia, Poland and other Communist countries were not being transshipped to the Soviet Union.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., Oct. 24 -- Three fire hydrants here glow in the daytime and reflect light at night as an aid to firemen and motorists.

MIAMI BEACH, Oct, 24 -- Dr. Julian Scott Butterworth, a New York City cardiologist who was installed today as the president of the American Heart Association, is one of the world's leading authorities on the LUB DUB sound that the beating human heart makes.
TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 24 -- Democrats are hopeful and Republicans concerned this year about the political outlook in New Jersey's five western counties, now as ever a hotly contested battleground.
The State Appellate Division ruled unanimously yesterday that the widow of Arde Bulova, the watch manufacturer, had waived her right to half of his estate.

BOSTON, Oct. 24 (UPI) -- Walter A. Brown, the owner of the Boston Celtics, today ordered legal action taken against Bill Sharman, who left the National Basketball Association champions to play for and coach the new Los Angeles Jets.

A woman identified by the police as a sister of Francisco Molina, who was sentenced last June to twenty years' imprisonment for murder, was critically wounded last night in a knife fight with another woman on a West Side street corner.

For some years the New York Stock Exchange has been trying to persuade more of the important foreign companies to list their shares on its board. However, its stringent requirements as to reporting earnings, providing proxy material and such have dampened the interest of the European companies.
The controversial West Village urban renewal project has been dropped, the Housing and Redevelopment Board said yesterday.

Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower accused the Kennedy Administration last night of doing "a good job of confusing me and all my friends." General Eisenhower appeared at two Republican campaign rallies in support of Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz, the Republican candidate for Mayor, but most of his criticism of Democrats was directed at Washington.

MOZART'S "Cosi fan tutte," unaccountably missing from the Metropolitan Opera since the 1955-56 season, returned there last night in fine estate. Again the smart Rolf Gerard sets gleamed prettily. And while Carl Ebert has been responsible for the staging, his direction follows, if memory serves, that of Alfred Lunt very closely.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- There are now two interesting debates going on in the world. On the other side of The Wall, the Communists are debating the heresy of dissent. On our side, we are debating the right of dissent, including the old conflict between ethics and politics, expediency and morality.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Postmaster General J. Edward Day reinstated today a Negro letter carrier whom he regards as unsuited for the job.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) -- President Kennedy, who has avoided golf and other strenuous exercise while his strained back mends, has been spilled twice by chairs.
