MONTREAL, Oct. 24 (UPI) -- Andy Bathgate has made a fast start in pursuit of his long-time dream -- the National Hockey League scoring title.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Hundreds of New York and New Jersey military reservists have appealed to their Congressmen for information or help in getting deferments from active duty during the current defense build-up.
The election of Joe Zel as president, chief executive officer and a director of United Printers and Publishers, Inc., was announced yesterday by Louis Berkman, chairman.

Sales and net income of the American Tobacco Company, a leading producer of tobacco products, climbed to record levels for both the quarter and nine months ended on Sept. 30, Paul M. Hahn, president, announced yesterday.
Residents of Cooper Square were told yesterday that a good deal of their own plan for the area's redevelopment would be used by the City Planning Commission.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Oct. 24 -- South Vietnam lodged formal charges of aggression against Communist-ruled North Vietnam with the International Control Commission today.
Seven examiners who were suspended Oct. 5 on charges of accepting illegal fees from driver license applicants have resigned, state Motor Vehicle Commissioner William S. Hults said yesterday.
Dealers in municipal and corporate bonds held the spotlight in the bond market yesterday as large quantities of new debt securities reached the market.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- British Guiana's Prime Minister, Dr. Cheddi B. Jagan, challenged the United States today to aid his country's development even though he plans a program of socialism and "active neutralism."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Mrs. Robert F. Kennedy, the wife of the United States Attorney General, didn't place, but she made a game try at the Washington International Horse Show tonight.
There can be no question about the poor state of Cuba's economy nearly three years after the revolution began. In the last six months there has been a clear deterioration.
The Democratic majority in the City Council made certain yesterday there would be no revision of the city's Code of Ethics before the Nov. 7 election.
How American citizens can provide for "dynamic national growth" while preserving their individual freedom is discussed by Lawrence Fertig in his book, "Prosperity Through Freedom."

Mayor Wagner assailed yesterday a proposal by State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz that the city take over the administration of rent control from the state. The Mayor called the plan a "smokescreen" and a "fraud."

The growth of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., was marked in three directions yesterday as the giant utility registered plans for a major financing, announced record sales and revenue figures, and awarded a large construction contract.

IF the ghost of an American Pilgrim materialized in Manhattan on Thanksgiving, it would witness a striking phenomenon. This is the appearance at greengrocers of fresh corn-in-the-husks, a vegetable more readily associated with the Fourth of July.
TUNIS, Oct. 24 -- The Premier of the Algerian nationalist Provisional Government proposed tonight negotiation with France on "the principle, the means and the date of a proclamation of independence."
A relative handful of bettors in the crowd of 22,106 at Aqueduct yesterday collected on an $884.20 daily double, the third highest of the New York flat-racing season.
A total of 1,085 persons were injured in automobile accidents here last week, the Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday. This was an increase of twenty-one over the like period last year.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 24 -- Following is the text of the protocol agreement reached between the United Nations and Katanga Province Oct. 13 an made public here today:

The Rev. Dr. Theodore E. Bubeck, for thirty-eight years a Baptist missionary in the Belgian Congo, now the Congo Republic, denied yesterday a statement that bickering educational missionaries were badly confusing people in the under-developed nations.
NEWARK, Oct. 24 -- James P. Mitchell, the Republican candidate for Governor, charged here tonight that his Democratic opponent, Richard J. Hughes, lacked the experience necessary for the job.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 24 -- A reliable source said today that U Thant of Burma, the leading candidate for Acting Secretary General, had begun work on the declaration he would make after his election about his relations with his principal subordinates.
A plan for ultimately banning all buses from Washington Square Park and rehabilitating the park was put forward yesterday by Manhattan President Edward R. Dudley.
ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 24 -- The Turkish military high command exacted from political party leaders today a formal pledge to meet military demands in forming and conducting a new civilian government.
The City Council moved yesterday to investigate increases in the price of fuel oil for home heating during the last year.
Sugar, coffee and cocoa futures were actively traded yesterday in an otherwise dull day on the New York commodity exchanges.
A storm of indignation, protest and condemnation swept the non-Communist world yesterday over the explosion Monday by the Soviet Union of the largest nuclear bomb ever tested.
DALLAS, Tex., Oct. 24 (UPI) -- X-ray treatments for cancer-stricken Sam Rayburn began today.
Oils, aircrafts and utilities did fairly well in yesterday's session of the New York Stock Exchange but the market as a whole drifted down in rather confused trading.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 24 -- The United States warned today that South Africa's racial policies, if allowed to continue, could "rock the entire continent of Africa."
The Sheraton Corporation of America will operate the 450-room motor hotel being constructed by the Glickman Corporation of Nevada at Forty-second Street and Twelfth Avenue.
PARIS, Oct. 24 -- Today's statement of the Algerian rebel position on peace prospects was encouraging in tone but unacceptable in detail, according to authoritative French sources.

CLIFTON, N.J., Oct. 24 -- A group of patients who miss their doctor have started a campaign to get him out of the Army and back on his rounds here. But they are encountering stiff opposition -- from the physician.
A dispute between a landlord and tenants reached international proportions here yesterday.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 24 -Stalking a walking wounded Tiger is likely to be dangerous business, in Palmer Stadium as well as on safari.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 24 -- Demands for a ban on all forms of nuclear testing grew today in the Political Committee of the General Assembly.

EDWIN DEVENY, a young Texas pianist who was trained in his native state and in Cincinnati, made his New York debut last night, playing a formidable program in Carnegie Recital Hall. The program included Bach's Partita in B flat, Copland's Sonata, Schumann's "Kreisleriana," Bartok's "Improvisations on Hungarian Folk Songs," and Prokofieff's Sonata No. 7.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 24 - The Pakistani-backed regime in Western Kashmir marked its fourteenth anniversary today with warnings of new strife with India.
SYRACUSE, Oct. 24 -- A state aid-to-education program that would give New York City almost $600,000,000 a year by 1965 has been proposed by representatives of the state's six largest cities.

The parking lot on the west side of Bailey Avenue, 300 feet north of West 231st Street, the Bronx, has been bought by Harry Nussbaum Son, builders, for improvement with a sixty-family apartment building.

A COLLEAGUE who owns a mountain hideout in the Catskills mentioned the other day that he was up to his earlobes in raccoons. This brought to mind that the state, recognizing there can be too much of a good thing, lately has been exhorting hunters to do in a few of the masked marauders as a contribution to a safe and sane society.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Chief Albert John Luthuli, winner of a Nobel Prize for his fight against South Africa's white supremacy policies, said today he would seek permission to go to Europe to receive the award.
A PSYCHIATRIST who works with the aged offered this prescription yesterday for a happy old age: Be born rich, become well-educated and stay physically healthy.

ROME, Oct. 25 -- Guy Mollet declared in the congress of the Socialist International today that the Socialist party of France, of which he is a leader, stands squarely with all other Socialist Democratic parties to save the freedom of Berlin.

Title to the building containing twenty apartments at 214 East 126th Street has been taken by Herman S. and Richard O. Wolfman, a father-and-son team of realty investors. They own the adjoining houses at Nos. 210 and 212.

WINDSOR, Conn., Oct. 25 -- Undefeated and untied in seven games last season, The Loomis School's football squad is finding the pickings a little more difficult this year. So far, the Maroon and Gray has won only once while bowing twice and tying once.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 25 -- A chemical that sterilizes rather than kills the housefly was announced here today at the formal opening of the agricultural chemicals research laboratory of the Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Wednesday, Oct. 18:
Greg Mather, Navy's place-kicker, has been on such a booting spree this season that he's within striking distance of several collegiate football records.

ARTICHOKES, the green, thistle-like delicacy now abundant on vegetable stands, are said to be as old as the Grecian isles. The Greeks, as a matter of fact, were among the first to cultivate the vegetable, which they called kaktos.
DETROIT, Oct. 25 -- New contract negotiations between the United Automobile Workers and the Chrysler Corporation are approaching a critical phase.
Three world auction records for paintings were set here last night. A work by Pierre Bonnard, the French post-impressionist, brought the highest figure, $101,000.
THAT indomitable one-man expeditionary force called Mr. Justice William O. Douglas of the United States Supreme Supreme Court has been marching marching, marching again around creation.
CHICAGO, Oct. 25 (AP) -- Prices for grains finished in a mixed to weak range today after holding steady to firm through most transactions on the Board of Trade.

Harry G. Silverstein Sons, realty investors, who recently took title to the twenty-two-story office building at 801 Second Avenue, southwest corner of Forty-third Street, have announced plans for remodeling the property.
Cotton futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 20 cents a bale up to 50 cents off yesterday. The sole rise was on a bid.

The Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc., yesterday urged approval of Amendment 3, which would authorize state liability for $100,000,000 in bonds issued by the Port of New York Authority to help finance commuter railroad equipment.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Seaboard World Airlines asked the Civil Aeronautics Board today to expedite the airline's proposal to offer reduced-rate passenger service across the Atlantic in the rear of its cargo planes.
Johnny Longden, at the age of 54, is still breaking speed records. The star jockey rode T.V. Lark to an American turf mark yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (UPI) -- A Federal jury pondered the fate of Irvin C. Scarbeck tonight. He is charged with turning classified material over to the Communists while stationed in Warsaw as an aide at the American Embassy.

I am writing in reference to David Binder's recent article on rebuilding in Leipzig. I visited Leipzig myself during the trade fair in March, 1959. As a former construction worker I was naturally interested in the rebuilding there and talked to many people concerning what had been done and what was planned.

A bail-jumping charge against a 30-year-old masseur who said he had been a Hungarian freedom fighter was dismissed yesterday -- the end result of a set of circumstances forgotten by a General Sessions judge, recalled by an assistant District Attorney and explained to two courts by a defense lawyer.
The rarity of the same dog winning best in show at the same event for the third successive year occurred at the Hotel St. George in Brooklyn yesterday.
The Union Theological Seminary, at Broadway and 120th Street, last night commemorated the 125th anniversary if its founding.

NEWARK, Oct. 25 -- The Defense Department will turn over 460 acres of the Sandy Hook peninsula to New Jersey for development as a state park, Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall announced tonight.

" This Side of Paradise," F. Scott Fitzgerald's first novel, will be produced on the stage. Dramatized by Sydney Sloane, the play will open in December or January at an off-Broadway house. Herbert Berghof will direct the offering, to he put on by Jesse Osuna, Alice Scudder and Arthur Peltz.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 25 -- A solemn appeal to the Soviet Union to call off its planned fifty-megaton nuclear bomb test was voted tonight by the General Assembly's 101-member Political Committee.
State Supreme Court Justice Samuel H. Hofstadter called yesterday for a law making it a crime to use a telephone as an aid in committing a crime.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP) -- The Republican National Committee challenged today a Democratic claim that the Kennedy Administration was so busy that many of its employes could not find parking space to work Saturdays and Sundays.
ALBANY, Oct. 25 (AP) -- The odds were with the bears and deer today for the start of the big-game hunting season in New York State's northern zone. The season ends there on Dec. 5.

TATIANA DE SANZEWITCH ended her recital in Town Hall last night with Gabriel Pierne's Variations in C minor. Whether or not this was a first United States performance of the work, as the pianist thought, it is so rarely played as to seem like a premiere.
The establishment of a Speech and Hearing Center was announced yesterday by Teachers College, Columbia University.
Prices of most commodity futures rose in trading yesterday on the New York exchanges.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The major developments of the current Soviet Communist party congress are believed here to add up to an affirmation of Premier Khrushchev's less militant prescriptions for the triumph of world communism.

Details of the indictment of Albania's Communist leaders at the Soviet Communist party's congress in Moscow have been presented by two members of the Soviet party's Presidium, Anastas I. Mikoyan and Mikhail A. Suslov.

The harshest effect of the strike that has cut off most of the city's milk supply is the anxiety it causes New Yorkers with small children or invalids to care for. However, a Health Department survey indicates that stores will have plenty of evaporated and powdered milk and that the milk needs of hospitals, schools and other institutions will be met through an emergency delivery system manned by the strikers.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Oct. 25 -- Richard J. Hughes, the Democratic candidate for Governor, today branded his Republican opponent, James P. Mitchell, the "most brazen hypocrite ever to campaign for state-wide office in New Jersey."
Eastern railroad presidents served notice on ten Governors yesterday that the financial plight of their lines had reached the proportion of a "real public crisis."
Surprising developments on and off the court last Tuesday night have heightened interest in a National Basketball Association double-header scheduled at Madison Square Garden tonight.
UTICA, N.Y., Oct. 25 (AP) -- Governor Rockefeller appealed to New York State farmers tonight to join in preparations to resume food production after a nuclear attack.
I compliment you on your editorial of Oct. 13 on the subject of South Africa's Eric Louw and his recent contretemps in the United Nations.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Oct. 25 (AP) -- The attempt to launch the Ranger II satellite on a 1,000,000-mile round trip into space was postponed indefinitely today because of troubles encountered on another launching 3,000 miles away.

Officials of New York State insurance companies told the Joint State Legislative Committee on Insurance Rates and Regulations yesterday that they had been losing pension and annuity business "because of arbitrary restrictions."

The Socony Mobil Oil Company, Inc., reported yesterday that estimated net earnings for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 were $161,600,000; or $3.33 a share. This was 19 per cent more than the $135,900,000, or $2.80 a share, cleared for the 1960 period.

In wrapping up its three-day fall meeting here, the eighteen-man policy-making council of the National Collegiate Athletic Association yesterday solidly endorsed a special report aimed at combating the gambling-bribery menace in basketball and football.
Collectors of abstract art flocked to an East Side gallery yesterday, where they purchased forty finger-paintings by a three-year-old chimpanzee.

Activity rose slightly in the market for high-grade bonds yesterday. Treasury bonds were quoted up 2/32 to 14/32 on the persistent rumor that the Bank of England would lower its official rate from 6.5 per cent, to 6 per cent.

TOUGH and dictatorial, Gen. Enver Hoxha of Albania remains a Stalinist, a position that has brought him and his nation under attack in Moscow and other Communists capitals of Europe. Yesterday at the twenty-second party congress in Moscow, details of the charges against Albania were given.
Farid Salim, the Argentine middleweight champion who is tall enough to play basketball, looked impressive in his first New York unveiling at the Eighth Avenue Gym yesterday.

National awards have been established for motion picture creativity by young American writers and directors, it was announced yesterday by the Society of Cinematologists at a reception held in the New York University Club, 123 West Forty-third Street.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The Federal Communications Commission gave the green light today to a new educational television station for the New York metropolitan area.

Leonard C. Rose was elected president and a director of The Colorado Fuel and Iron Corporation yesterday. Alwin F. Franz, who has been president since 1952 and who has reached his 65th birthday, was named chairman of the board of directors.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 25 -- Western European delegates appointed two representatives today to impress upon the Soviet Union their conviction that an Acting Secretary General of the United Nations must have a Western European assistant.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 25 -- Though Oscar night is still nearly six months away, the movie industry's equivalent of the Presidential campaign is already under way.

Production of electric power in the nation climbed to 15,162,000,000 kilowatt-hours in the week ended last Saturday, from 15,125,000,000 the preceding week, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. A year ago 14,191,000,000 kilowatt-hours were produced.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The White House said today that President Kennedy believed Richard J. Hughes would make "an excellent Governor" of New Jersey, and he would be glad to say so in a letter on request.

I cannot forbear to wonder how many of our moral betters of the nonaligned nations saw, in The Times of Oct. 14, the handsome picture of H.E., the President of the Sudan, acknowledging the cheers of the crowd as he rode up Broadway, and, in the very next column, your headline, "Abboud Urges U.N. to Seat Red China."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -A Senate inquiry heard a new and intriguing explanation today for the fact that some packages of soapflakes, cake mixes and other supermarket wares are not always filled to the brim -or even thereabouts.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The United States-West German talks are moving slowly, and at times painfully, toward a common understanding on future negotiations with the Soviet Union.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 25 (UPI) -Nine Western door manufacturing concerns were indicted by a Federal grand jury today on charges of price-fixing.
LAS VEGAS, Oct. 25 (UPI) -- Tony Lema and Juan (Chi Chi) Rodriguez tied for the second-day lead in the $15,000 Sahara pro-amateur golf tournament today with 36-hole scores of 134.
Legislation to provide a national market for conventional mortgages will be introduced when Congress reconvenes next year, it was learned yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The Consumer Price Index rose two-tenths of 1 per cent in September to set a record, the Labor Department reported today.

Early last year the editors of The Diners Club Magazine found themselves facing a battery of thorny problems. National advertisers were snubbing the magazine because it was mailed free to subscribers. The Post Office Department wanted to withdraw its second-class mailing permit on the ground that the publication was a promotion piece and not a real magazine.
EAST ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 25 -- Many cocktail and dinner parties will precede the Ball of the Oranges on Friday evening at the Suburban Hotel.
The State of Kentucky borrowed $40,000,000 in the public capital market yesterday at a net interest cost of 3.2947 per cent.

Joel Wells remained on the New York Giants' doubtful list yesterday after the club's long workout at Yankee Stadium. The 198-pound running back was unable to participate because of torn ligaments in his right foot.
BERLIN, Oct. 25 -- "My Fair Lady" opened here tonight.
Presidents and other officials of forty-four liberal arts colleges yesterday toured Columbia University's new $8,300,000 engineering building, where their students are now being trained.
Net new orders for machine tools, the machines used to make the machinery of production lines, rose sharply in September.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The Council of the Organization of American States agreed today to delay action on a Peruvian proposal calling for measures against the Cuban regime of Premier Fidel Castro.

Raymon H. Mulford was elected president of the Owens-Illinois Glass Company yesterday. He succeeded Carl R. Megowen, who was elected vice chairman of the board and chairman of the executive committee.

LONDON, Oct. 25 -- The International Exhibition of Modern Jewelry, with displays from thirty-three countries showing designs from 1890 to the present, opened here today. The collection aims to show various trends in the design of modern jewelry, with full credit given to the designer rather than the owner.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 25 (UPI) -- The Pope and Talbot Lines announced today it would cease intercoastal operations Nov. 3 because of "insurmountable difficulties" caused by rising costs and wages.
A wine barrel, being cleaned in the basement of a Brooklyn home, exploded last night, killing one man and injuring three.
LONDON, Oct. 25 (AP) -- The Moscow radio accused the United States of warmongering today, and said the Soviet Union would not be frightened.
Missouri Republicans picked the wrong Farley when they sent a letter here to James A. the former Democratic National Chairman, soliciting funds for the 1962 and 1964 campaigns there.
Time Parents Association of the Collegiate School wilt receive time proceeds of Artur Rubinstein's recital Nov. 6 at Carnegie Hall for its scholarship fund.
Joey Jay was named the National League pitcher of the year yesterday by United Press International's board of baseball experts.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- New and stricter export control laws and more vigorous enforcement of restrictions on shipments to Soviet bloc countries were urged today by Senator Kenneth B. Keating.
GENEVA, Oct. 25 -- The American Joint Distribution Committee said here today that it would use German reparation funds to survey the needs of mentally-ill European Jews.
A special stockholders meeting of the Lionel Corporation got off to a slow start yesterday morning, but was soon highballing along with a full head of steam.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- President Kennedy gave his approval today for an underground nuclear explosion in the salt caverns of New Mexico as the first step in developing peaceful uses for atomic explosives.

The prestige of Ivy League football will be severely tested this week-end when half of the league squads face nonleague rivals. The Columbia Lions of Buff Donelli, victors in three of their four league starts, will engage a determined Lehigh squad, which scored an upset victory over Harvard in the season's opening game.

In speaking recently of the German situation, British Foreign Secretary Lord Home said: "One false step, one failure in communication, even one failure in comprehension, might mean war." This is the all-important fact to keep in mind as West and East go through their tortuous and delicate diplomatic game of seeking a base for negotiation, and as dangerous flare-ups occur in Berlin itself.
HASKELL, N.J., Oct. 25 -- James P. Mitchell, the Republican candidate for Governor, made his most vigorous attack of the campaign on "bossism" as he toured Passaic County today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (UPI) -- President Kennedy appointed former Representative Frank M. Coffin, Democrat of Maine, today to be deputy administrator of the Agency for International Development, the new foreign aid organization.
Mickey Mantle of the Yankees was the major leagues' slugging leader for 1961 with a percentage of .687, according to statistics released yesterday by The Associated Press.
PARIS, Thursday, Oct. 26 -- A nation-wide strike in the Government-operated rail and air services began early today and was to continue for twenty-four hours.

George Seewagen Jr., a 16-year-old sophomore from Bayside High School, won the singles final of the metropolitan interscholastic hard-court tennis tournament at Poly Prep in Brooklyn yesterday. Seewagen turned back Mike Hayes, a senior from Bayside, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 3.
IN the deal shown today a false-carding play that has become standard practice was used and seemed to succeed, but it was all an illusion.

LINCOLN, Mass., Oct. 25 (AP) -- The state police tonight had "good clear" fingerprints and sought a blue sedan in their investigation of the apparent bludgeon-abduction of Mrs. Joan Risch, 30 years old, mother of two.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Oct. 25 -- Sir Roy Welensky accused the Government of India today of "irresponsible hysteria" in alleging that the Rhodesian Federal Government was permitting mercenaries and war material to cross its border into Katanga.

The American Broadcasting Company television network, which currently signs off at 11:15 P.M., plans to add another hour to its program schedule next fall. Reruns of the network's one-hour Western and adventure shows will be presented from 11:15 P.M. to 12:15 A.M., Monday through Friday.

National Steel Corporation reported yesterday that its third-quarter earnings declined to $7,009,051, or 92 cents a share, from $8,061,074, or $1.06 a share, in the 1960 period, despite a gain in sales.
RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 25 (AP) -- For less than $15 a radio can be equipped with an electronic device to turn it into an automatic attack warning alarm, the inventor of the device said yesterday.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 25 -- Fifty including jurists have drafted a penal code to help the courts eliminate organized crime.

As candidates for Controller and President of the City Council we thank The Times for its endorsement of our candidacies. But we want to express deep disappointment over the complete inconsistency of your failure to endorse the head of our ticket, Mayor Robert F. Wagner.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 25 -- Meadow Farr, who has trotted a mile in 2 minutes, is the 7-5 overnight favorite in the $26,325 Lady Suffolk Stakes for 3-year-old fillies at Roosevelt Raceway tomorrow night. Seven are entered in the mile-and-a sixteenth trot.

GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 25 -- The brothers Mike and Willie Turnesa of the Knollwood Country Club were standouts today in the Westchester Professional Golfers' Association final pro-amateur tournament of the season at the Round Hill Club.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 25 (UPI) -- Earnings of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation for the third quarter of 1961 plunged to $5,451,000, or 14 cents a share, from $20,226,000, or 57 cents a share, for the 1960 period, the company reported today.

YONKERS, Oct. 25 -- Irish Grattan, who has earned more than $30,000 this season, was sold for $25,000 to Leo Pelletier, an agent from Montreal, as the Old Glory horse sale finished a three-day run at Yonkers Raceway today.

The Port of New York will become one of the principal points in a bulk-cement vessel distribution system now being planned along the coast by the Atlantic Cement Company, Inc., a new concern formed earlier this year.
Assemblyman William F. Passannante charged yesterday that New York University still maintained a "callous indifference" on the housing needs of Greenwich Village.

Mayor Wagner and former Senator Herbert H. Lehman said yesterday that Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz, the Republican candidate for Mayor, was a conservative and a candidate of political reaction.

THE liveliest conversation piece of the football season undoubtedly is the shotgun offense that Red Hickey has given to his San Francisco Forty-Niners. Abandoning the now classic T-formation, the wily redhead installed a spread variation of Pop Warner's ancient double-wing attack. In it the quarterback is stationed 5 yards behind the center and takes a direct snap.
LAST Sunday was the 150th anniversary of the birth of Liszt and last night at Carnegie Hall Jorge Bolet honored the anniversary with a notable performance of the Liszt B minor Sonata.

The police arrested the national secretary of the Socialist party yesterday at the Soviet United Nations Mission headquarters, 680 Park Avenue, after ejecting three women and a man who had protested nuclear testing.
LONDON, Oct. 25 -- Britain is to repay by next Tuesday 100,000,000 ($280,000,000) of the $1,500,000,000 it drew from the International Monetary Fund in nine currencies only last August.

Consumers may be holding back somewhat on their buying at present, but one leading business man has great hopes about them for the future. George Struthers, vice president of merchandising for Sears, Roebuck Co., predicted yesterday that retail sales, now at a rate of $220,000,000,000 a year, would reach $275,000,000,000 within five years.
Two of North America's leading makers of distilled beverages announced yesterday that sales for their latest reporting periods had exceeded year-earlier levels.

Seven proposed changes in the State Constitution are being submitted to referendum on Nov. 7 on a state-wide basis. New York City also has three local questions to decide. The ten issues are spread across the top of the voting machine.
A REVUE called "The Seasons of Youth" occupied Channel 7 for one hour last night. It was a major misfortune despite the efforts of a few talented members of its cast.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (UPI) -- The Soviet Union, defying protests from the non-Communist world, exploded another nuclear bomb in the Arctic atmosphere today.
LONDON, Oct. 25 -- Uncompetitive prices and delivery dates were cited today as the two main reasons British shipyards have lost orders to foreign yards.

Doug Harvey, the player-coach of the New York Rangers, has been asking for more skating. He got it from his men last night as the Blues played a 1-1 tie with the big Chicago Black Hawks, the Stanley Cup champions, at Madison Square Garden.
Cornelius Bass of Jackson won individual honors and Jamaica High captured the team laurels in the Queens Public Schools Athletic League cross-country championship yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park.
CHICAGO, Oct. 25 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
Borough President Edward R. Dudley of Manhattan called on Governor Rockefeller yesterday to add anti-slum legislation to the agenda of the special session of the Legislature that will be held Nov. 9.

Four more members of the Gallo gang were freed as material witnesses yesterday in the Brooklyn grand jury investigation into the attempted garroting of Lawrence Gallo and the murder of Joseph Magnasco.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP) -- The Government today hired two outside economic research concerns to help in developing new international aviation policies.
International Minerals and Chemical Corporation and Husky Oil Company announced yesterday an agreement to develop phosphate reserves in Idaho estimated at 50,000,000 tons.

RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct. 25 -- Three men on their way to the Radio Corporation of America plant in Harrison, N.J., were killed today in a head-on collision with a truck at Route 17 and Meadow Road here.

A decline of 436,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks last week was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. Total supplies were 185,305,000 barrel last Friday, compared with 185,741,000 a week earlier and 187,002,000 a year ago.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 25 -- President Tito declared today that there were no differences between the Soviet and Yugoslav varieties of communism as to their ultimate aims. The dispute between the two, he said, concerned only the means by which those ends should be achieved.
Almost all milk deliveries to homes and stores in New York City and on Long Island will be cut off today, following the extension of the milk strike to two more teamster locals yesterday.
Federal Judge Leo F. Rayfiel yesterday jailed three men involved in an alleged $25,000 attempt to fix a court decision now being investigated by a special grand jury.

A collection of critical essays about the controversy over reading instruction will be published next Tuesday by Atlantic-Little, Brown. It will be called "Tomorrow's Illiterates." In one essay, the editor, Dr. Charles C. Walcutt examines the origin and development of the "look-and-say" method that is widely used today, and points out weaknesses and fallacies in its theory and practice.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Oct. 25 -- The United Nations announced tonight that an exchange of prisoners with Katanga Province had been completed and that United Nations forces had withdrawn from all positions as specified in a ceasefire accord.

The Pennsylvania Railroad, the nation's largest operated at a net profit of $1,022,400 last month. But because of large deficits recorded earlier in the year, the carrier ended the first nine month of the year with a net loss of $12,768,700.
Building materials and motors were weak on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday but chemicals, aircrafts, oils and drugs were strong and the market showed a considerable gain.
A granite cornerstone was dedicated yesterday for the $12,500,000 Garrard Winston Memorial Building at Roosevelt Hospital.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Qualified officials here believe that the Soviet Union has yet to explode its promised fifty-megaton nuclear bomb.
Statistics were released by the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics yesterday on fuel prices here, which the City Council holds are out of line with other consumer prices.

Municipal Court Justice Maxwell Shapiro, the Republican-Civic Action candidate for the Supreme Court in Manhattan and the Bronx, called upon the Appellate Division and the Court of Appeals yesterday to direct the publication of all court appointments.
DETROIT, Oct. 25 (AP) -- The Federal Government's food stamp program, under experimental operation here for almost four months, was praised yesterday by both local and Federal officials.

In recent months the lot of this city's policemen has indeed been an unhappy one. Beer-bottle barrages, near-riots, unsettled issues of pay and moonlighting, alleged interference in local politics have added to their burdens.
Only five persons who speak Eyak are known; hence, an effort is being made to record at Alaskan language on tape before it vanishes entirely.

The new 110-mile pipeline of Esso Standard Libya, Inc., an affiliate of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), extending from the Zelten field in Libya to Port Brega on the Mediterranean was formally opened yesterday. King Idris I of Libya opened a valve to start the flow of oil to a tanker moored in the harbor.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The State Department announced tonight that the Soviet commander in Berlin had rejected a protest by the United States commander against an East German order requiring all foreigners to show their passports to enter East Berlin.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Dr. Cheddi B. Jagan, British Guiana's Prime Minister, spent an hour and a half with President Kennedy today discussing his aid requests, his economic socialism and his political "active neutralism."

Three leaders of the Fundamentalist wing of American Protestantism expounded their views yesterday in a press conference held in connection with the annual meeting here of the American Council of Christian Churches.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Oct. 25 -- Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor urged today a "national mobilization" of South Vietnam's assets in the "political, economic, military and psychological fields" to repel the increasing threat by Communist insurgents.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Recent events in the area of international affairs have brought even more seriously in question the soundness of certain bases of the foreign policy of the United States. But with one exception there are as yet few indications in the Administration that the bases are being shifted because of these disturbing developments.
CANNES, France, Oct. 25 -- Avoiding well-wishers, Pablo Picasso spent his eightieth birthday quietly today in his out-of-the-way hill villa in fashionable Mougins.
The Japanese Government is negotiating with a group of private United States banks and the Export-Import Bank for a loan of $300,000,000, it was learned yesterday.

Sales of the General Motors Corporation, the world's biggest automobile producer, fell 10.6 per cent in the third quarter from the 1960 level, but earnings held about unchanged. For the first nine months of this year, sales were 16.4 per cent below those of last year, while profits fell almost 25 per cent.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 25 -- From the chaos of three weeks ago, when injuries were disorganizing it, Pennsylvania has progressed to the point that it has become a real football entity.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 25 -- The applications of Outer Mongolia and Mauritania for United Nations membership were approved today by the Security Council. The two countries are to be the 102d and 103d members.
A major oceanographic study of the Continental Shelf along the nation's Atlantic Coast was proposed here yesterday by a spokesman for the United States Department of the Interior.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The Air Force reported today that scientists had been unable to establish radar contact with the controversial package of "needles" rocketed into orbit Saturday.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 25 -- Alex Quaison-Sackey, chief of Ghana's delegation, proposed today that the Security Council consider the expulsion of South Africa from the United Nations.
BUFFALO, Oct. 25 -- Organized labor in the state gave its support today to four proposed amendments to the state Constitution, opposed two others and made no recommendation on the seventh.

SOME modern works of art tend to abolish the classic division between painting and sculpture. In three current exhibitions, one of sculpture and two of paintings, the sculpture behaves like painting or drawing, and the paintings cast shadows like sculpture.
Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz proposed yesterday the creation of a citizens' service bureau to end "the malign power of influence peddlers and political shakedowns at City Hall."
CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Oct. 25 -- About 500 opponents of the regime of President Joaquin Balaguer rioted today in Santiago, the second largest city in the Dominican Republic.
BERLIN, Oct. 25 -- The Soviet Union told the United States today that it must comply with the Communist East German order requiring all foreigners to show their passports on entering East Berlin.
The New England Power Company borrowed $20,000,000 in the public capital market yesterday through the sale of bonds at competitive bidding.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Carl Sandburg called at the White House today to salute President Kennedy's literary and political style and pay his disrespects to former President Dwight D. Eisenhower.
The National Council of Jewish Women will provide executive training for 2,000 women volunteers who manage its network of local educational and social service projects.

GENEVA, Switzerland, Oct. 25 (Reuters) -- Hong Kong proposed today to the International Conference on Cotton Textiles here that an impartial body should be created under a long-term agreement to rule on an importing country's right to impose quantitative restrictions.
ALGIERS, Oct. 25 -- The General Staff of the French forces in Algeria stated tonight that military action had been taken yesterday to silence Algerian rebel fire from Tunisian territory.
NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 25 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru appealed to Indian students today for a "spirit of tolerance" in the nation's "composite culture."

The city Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity declared yesterday that if Globe Lighting Products, Inc., of Manhattan had obtained any work on city buildings, it had not been through that department.

MILES CITY, Mont., Oct. 25 (UPI) -- A troop train carrying Wisconsin National Guardsmen on active duty mashed into a gravel truck at an unguarded crossing at dawn today. Five railroad men and the truck driver were killed.
THE fortunes of big business and the arts seldom mingle, but they did rather interestingly last night in the circumstances surrounding the local debut of Luigi Alva at Judson Hall.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 25 -- Msgr. John J. Dougherty, president of Seton Hall University, has asked New Jersey's two major candidates for Governor to make public their stand on state support of private colleges and universities in the state.

ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 25 -- The Second Republic of Turkey was born today as the newly elected Parliament convened here. It succeeds the Assembly that was dissolved after a military junta ousted the Government of Premier Adman Menderes in May, 1960.
The gravity of the current struggle within world communism has been emphasized by Chou En-lai's sudden and unexpected departure from Moscow.

MOSCOW, Oct. 25 -- The Soviet Communist party's congress here was told today that Vyacheslav M. Molotov, who was ousted from the Soviet leadership in 1957, earlier this month denounced the party's draft program as "anti-revolutionary" and "pacifist."

City Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa, the Citizens Party candidate for Mayor, called last night for the creation of five borough-level boards of education to expedite school construction and to bring control of schools closer to the people.
United Neighborhood Houses, a federation of fifty-one settlement centers in the city's most troubled and overcrowded areas, will receive the proceeds of two theatre parties.
INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 25 (UPI) -- The small-town movie theatres, which have been fading out of existence, may be saved by an experiment begun in Indiana today.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 25 -- A medical school in Nassau County, affiliated with Meadow-brook Hospital and the County Department of Health, was recommended by a county commission today as "absolutely imperative."
The United States is awakening to the "enormous potential" for inter-American progress, Dean Edward W. Barrett of the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism declared last night.
The Alfred P. Sloan Foundation has awarded $2,750,000 to New York University to be used for expansion and construction of the Washington Square Center.
An application for a zoning variance in Riverdale, the Bronx, that aroused a great deal of protest when it was first announced last spring will be heard by the city the day after Election Day.

J.C. Penney Co., large retail chain, and Alden's, Inc., mail-order company with headquarters in Chicago, are holding "preliminary exploratory discussions" conc erning the possible acquisition of Alden's by Penney.

ROME, Oct. 25 -- A diplomatic conference of forty-four nations today approved an international agreement protecting the rights of performing artists in the recording industry and broadcasting organizations.
LONDON, Oct. 25 -- Industrials strengthened on the stock market here today, reversing the trend of the last few days.
The ethics and economics of the profession of optometry will be argued this week in a suit that may have a serious impact on such stores as Macy's, Gimbels and Bloomingdale's.

Thirty years ago a skeptical National Guard colonel wanted to know if the just-completed George Washington Bridge would support the military parade scheduled to cross it during the dedication ceremony.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission has selected Milton H. Cohen, a Chicago lawyer, to conduct its investigation of the country's stock markets.

THERE are fine, tender, honest things in "Look: We've Come Through." The new play that opened last night at the Hudson, like last season's "Big Fish, Little Fish," marks Hugh Wheeler as a writer of uncommon freshness and integrity.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The White House said tonight that President Kennedy would receive advice on some of his future telecasts from Fred Coe, New York television producer.
The Child Study Association of America will take over the Rockefeller Center skating rink and the two adjoining restaurants for a benefit skating party and supper dance on Jan. 19.

American designers are now showing their spring collections to stores, preceding the openings in Paris and Italy. Spring fashions are not shown in Europe until January and February. General trends of the new designs are described below. The clothes will be in stores by about the first of the year.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 25 -- The president of the National Congress of Parents and Teachers said tonight that this nation's heritage "belongs equally to all American children where-ever they may live, whatever their creed or color, however handicapped or highly endowed they may be."
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 25 -- President Kennedy has unwittingly sparked new hostilities between the two principal Democratic factions in the nation's second largest state.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 25 -- The Swedish Government informed Parliament today that it planned to apply for association with the six-nation European Economic Community "within the near future."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP) -- Richard M. Nixon may have had troubles with television make-up artists, but it is not all clear sailing for the make-up people either, especially the feminine ones in Chicago.

DETROIT, Oct. 25 -Prof. Henry Steele Commager, historian and educator, has accepted appointment to the Public Review Board of the United Automobile Workers Union, it was announced today by Walter P. Reuther, the Union's president.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (UPI) -- The White House contradicted Alabama Gov. John Patterson today in a dispute over the path of an interstate highway.

SOONER or later, most young suburban matrons come down with a mild malady that is variously diagnosed as a creative urge or the desire to not conform. As a result of their exposure to the disease, Jane Adriance and Alice Burke of Princeton, N.J., have found themselves wrapped up in business.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Labor Secretary Arthur J. Goldberg urged today that Federal regulations be changed to enable more Government aides to take their wives on official trips, at no extra cost to taxpayers.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (UPI) -- The Federal Aviation Agency announced today a new anti-intoxication rule.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The Irish Army team won its first international jumping event of the Washington International Horse Show tonight when Loch an Easprig, under Capt. William Ringrose, captured the Martin Challenge Trophy.
The Green Bay Packers have taken over as the No. 1 offensive team in the National Football League, breaking the San Francisco Forty-Niners' hold on the league's two major statistical departments.
MOSCOW, Oct. 25 -- Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko declared today that President Kennedy and Premier Khrushchev must go down in history as the leaders of the era in which wars became impossible.

A Board of Education investigator has been assigned to ride on a school bus for blind and crippled children, as a result of complaints by parents that their children have been tardy and sometimes left stranded.

An official of the College Entrance Examination Board said yesterday that by 1980 "the great majority of American youth of college age will seek one year or more of formal education beyond high school."
A State Supreme Court justice rescinded yesterday an action of the former Board of Education prohibiting two construction concerns from doing further business with the school system.
PORT JEFFERSON, L.I., Oct. 25 -- Shelley Mayfield of Meadow Brook carded a 71 for 144 today and won the Port Jefferson open golf tournament at the Harbor Hills Country Club by one stroke.

Futures prices continued to climb in active trading yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. Sizable volumes also were reported for Central American coffee, which rose, and for cottonseed oil and Brazilian coffee, which were irregular.

Lawrence and Richard Zirinsky, builders and developers of industrial realty, and Jack P. Schleifer, New York lawyer and realty investor, have bought the Central Bergen Industrial Terminal in Garfield, N.J., for more than $3,000,000.
The Department of Water supply quietly has jettisoned its proposal to put roofs over the Central Park reservoir and four others because of prohibitive cost.
Royal Vision won the New York Turf Writers Cup hurdle race at Aqueduct yesterday, an achievement that brought his owner, Mrs. John Thouron, much satisfaction.
STEADY now, London Observer! "Curtains," by Kenneth Tynan, The Observer's drama critic, has just been published by Longman's in London. (It was published here by Atheneum last year.)

A work stoppage by about 250 longshoremen seeking steadier employment on the Brooklyn waterfront hampered loading and unloading operations of four freighters at a South Brooklyn pier yesterday afternoon.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 26 -- When the Navy varsity football candidates reported for practice last spring they were mostly a lot of Joes, but no Joe Bellino.

We were surprised to read your endorsement of Mr. Lefkowitz, followed by your endorsement of the candidates chosen personally by Mayor Wagner. It is obvious that these candidates have the experience the Republican organization candidates lack; it is equally obvious that the man who named them has the experience in city affairs that his opponent lacks.
MONTREAL, Oct. 26 (UPI) -- The Montreal Canadiens scored five times in the third period tonight to rout the Chicago Black Hawks, 7 -- 1, and remain unbeaten in six National Hockey League games.
The Administrative Council of the City University ruled yesterday that no known member of the Communist party of the United States could be permitted to speak on any of its campuses.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Postmaster General Day, a member of President Kennedy's Cabinet, has now publicly encouraged the belief that in this Administration pressure by special interest groups can keep in his job a Government employe of whose unfitness his over-all superior is fully convinced.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 26 -- A crippling nine-day bank strike ended today when President Joao Goulart acted quickly and forcefully amid threats of a Government crisis.

The junior committee of the Women's Division of American Friends of Hebrew University will give its third annual Mediterranean Masquerade Ball on Saturday in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria.

AN alarming number of fatalities has marred the current football season and aroused a growing concern. Twenty young men have lost their lives on the gridiron and that is a usurious price to pay for a marvelous sport that is matchless in disciplining the body, the mind and the spirit. The tragedies already have jolted administrators into probing for the causes in the hope of future elimination.

STATION WCBS-TV looked at the group of out-of-towners who represent their countries at the United Nations to find out how they felt about life in New York and came up with a neat half-hour feature last night.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct 26 -- Archbishop Ambrose Senyshyn was installed as head of the Ukrainian Catholic Archeparchy archdiocese -- of Philadelphia, and two bishops were consecrated for new Ukrainian dioceses in Chicago and England here today.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 26 -- A 36-year-old Chatham woman has become the first graduate of Douglass College in its forty-three years to attain a perfect academic record.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- The Government took today one of its most ambitious steps thus far to improve the science education of undergraduates in colleges and universities.

"We have a fairy strong first team, but we lack experienced depth." Next to "we'll play them one game at a time," this bromide probably crops up most frequently in pre-season and inseason conversations with football coaches.

LONDON, Oct. 26 -- The conflict between the Soviet Union and Communist China over the means international communism is to use to gain world domination remains as virulent as ever, according to the best informed sources here.

EAST PROVIDENCE, R.I. Oct. 26 (AP) -- A revolutionary method for driving foundation piles by sound waves, developed by C.L. Guild Construction Company over the last two years, was officially unveiled today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- San Lucas, under Frank Chapot of Wallpack, N.J., of the United States Equestrian Team, won the preliminary round of the two-part special international jumping competition for the President's Cup today at the Washington International Horse Show.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 26 -- Dr. Ivo Andric of Yugoslavia, author and former diplomat, has won the 1961 Nobel Prize in Literature.
It looks increasingly, as if Madison Avenue would soon converge with the Champs -- Elysees -- at least as far as the advertising business is concerned.
United Air Lines, the country's biggest air carrier, asked the Civil Aeronautics Board yesterday for permission to increase coach and first-class fares on domestic flights.

THE weather has been far worse at sea than on land recently, as higher prices at fish stores here indicate. Storms and high waves in the Atlantic kept fishermen at home with the result that many of the more popular varieties of fish are up in cost.

SEOUL, Korea, Oct. 26 (AP) -- The United Nations command closed the military demarcation line today to Communist vehicles carrying Communist members of the neutral nations supervisory commission to a camp near Panmunjom.

The Salute to America Ball was held in the Ballroom of the Sheraton-East last night for the benefit of the Girls Club of New York. National and state flags, Colonial mementos and table decorations in red, white and blue provided a patriotic theme for the event.

It seems to me that if we accept the advice of The Times and elect Lefkowitz, Beame and Screvane, New York City would be faced by its own peculiar version of government by troika, rent by unnecessary partisanship and indecisiveness in the absence of a clear mandate to either party.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Oct. 26 -- Lieut. Gen. Rafael Leonidas Trujillo, Chief of Staff of the Dominican armed forces, said today that the danger of a military coup had lessened since President Joaquin Balaguer had consolidated his Government and gained the sympathy of the military establishment.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 26 (AP) -- John H. Lyons, general president of the International Association of Bridge, Structural and Ornamental Ironworkers, died today after having undergone lung surgery at Barnes Hospital. He was 70 years old.
Ignoring a protest by Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa, the Board of Estimate voted yesterday to "assist and protect" tenants evicted from buildings to be demolished for new private housing.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- President Kennedy is expected to announce soon the appointment of William A. Crawford as Minister to Rumania.
A new live radio network that is short on cash and long on prestige was hailed last night by President Kennedy and Governor Rockefeller in ceremonies marking the chain's dedication.
The Board of Education announced last night that it would appeal a State Supreme Court decision ordering the reinstatement of two contractors.
The Crystal Ball, a dinner dance sponsored by the Bronxville (N.Y.) League for Service, will be held Nov. 4 at Schrafft's, Eastchester, N.Y.
CHICAGO, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Grain futures dealers traded on mostly bearish influences today and nearly all prices on the Board of Trade finished sharply lower. Rye, the only exception, closed firm.

State Controller Arthur Levitt yesterday urged the defeat of Amendment 2 on the November ballot. It would eliminate the names of state departments from the Constitution, fix their number at twenty and create the Executive Office of the Governor.
The Hudson Manhattan Railroad company announced yesterday that the last barrier to a five-cent increase on interstate fares on the Hudson Tubes had been removed.
CHICAGO, Oct. 26 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Despite the fact that Saint Subber believes "Look: We've Come Through" to be "the most beautiful play" that he has produced, he said yesterday that he was taking it off the boards after five performances.
Columbia Pictures has established a "working agreement" with the Circle in the Square Theatre to train and develop new talent for motion pictures.
SEOUL, Korea, Oct. 26 -- The South Korean military rulers relaxed today the penalties against business men accused of having illegally amassed fortunes under the former Government.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Many women shun careers in science because American society generally regards the field as traditionally belonging to men.
LAHORE, Pakistan, Oct. 26 (Reuters) -- England, sparked by a score of 66 not out by Capt. Tex Dexter, defeated Pakistan by five wickets today in the first match of a three-match cricket test series.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (UPI) -- Scientists have found a miniature dead sea in Antarctica so salty that it probably never freezes even though winter temperatures in its vicinity sometimes drop to 60 degrees below zero.

BOSTON, Oct. 26 -- G. Mennen Williams, Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, said today that the United States should commit itself wholeheartedly to the striving of Africans for independence.

Th controversial system of programed teaching, which permits students to proceed at their own pace, received strong support yesterday from the director of the Ford Foundation's Fund for the Advancement of Education.

Three religious dramas dealing with the Protestant, Roman Catholic and Jewish faiths will be televised this season by "General Electric Theatre." Stanley Rubin, executive producer, said the dramas were designed to offer a general understanding of the major faiths in this country.

Vito P. Battista, the United Taxpayers party candidate for Mayor, asked the State Supreme Court yesterday to bar supporters of Louis J. Lefkowitz, the Republican candidate, from imitating his party label.

The Pittsburgh and Allegheny County Auditorium Authority raised $15,000,000 yesterday in the long-term capital market to repay temporary loans incurred during the construction of Pittsburgh's new stainless-steel-and-concrete auditorium.

Russ Warren, Columbia's leading halfback, will see limited action, if any, against Lehigh tomorrow. Coach Buff Donelli said yesterday that his "best all-round back" had a badly bruised left knee, suffered in last Saturday's Harvard game.
Dr. Leonard W. Larson, president of the American Medical Association, said last night that public education in cancer quackery was second in importance only to early diagnosis.

Carolyn Lasater, the Miss America candidate from Utah who placed third in the recent contest, has received a ten-week, $3,000 contract from Warner Brothers. She will make her acting debut in the current "Lovers Must Learn" . . . Sidney Poitier and Bobby Darin will co-star in Stanley Kramer's new drama, "Point Blank," which faces the cameras next month.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 26 -- Dr. Ivo Andric said today the award of the 1961 Nobel Prize in literature was "a great honor for me and for Yugoslav literature."
Cotton futures moved 25 cents a bale up to 60 cents off yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.
The National Maritime Union and the Department of Justice were at odds yesterday over which side won in a suit brought by the department charging violation of labor laws in the union's 1960 election.

Three seamstresses were cited yesterday as grand prize winners in the Singer Young Style-maker Contest. The presentations were made in the ballroom of the Plaza Hotel. The winners were: Mary Jean Barnard, 20, of Salt Lake City; Rita Wituschek, 17, of Milwaukee; Sharilyn Bell, 13, Alberta, Canada.
Dr. Harold C. Urey, Nobel prize-winning scientist, said yesterday the American people had exaggerated the dangers of radioactive fall-out from nuclear testing.
DETROIT, Oct. 26 -- Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers, told the Chrysler Corporation today that he expected the company to make a new economic offer to the union tomorrow.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 26 (AP) -- A judge has ruled that it is not illegal for a deceased benefactor to force the Masonic homes at Elizabethtown, Pa., to wait 400 years for a $14,500,000 gift.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- A combination of loose talk in Washington and bad journalism in some parts of Europe is making the German crisis seem worse than it really is.
AUGUSTA, Mich., Oct. 26 -- An anticancer drug has been used to block one of the body's major immune mechanisms, an international scientific meeting was told today.

Mrs. Jerome Schack, president of the League of Women Voters, said yesterday the league would sponsor a series of town-hall meetings throughout the city to which all local candidates would be invited to discuss issues.

I was shocked to read of your endorsement of the Republican candidate for Mayor, especially after the high praise and support your editorial of Aug. 21 gave Mayor Wagner in the Democratic primary, "by reason of the fact that he has declared his independence of the party bosses De Sapio, Buckley and Sharkey and of disreputable Tammany Hall."

THE Pittsburgh International Exhibition of Contemporary Painting and Sculpture, which opens today at the Carnegie Institute, is not nearly so good a show as it should be, considering that this is the forty-second version of one of the most prestigious art events in the world.
PERTH AMBOY, N.J., Oct. 26 -- Richard J. Hughes, the Democratic candidate for Governor, tonight ridiculed education proposals by James P. Mitchell, his Republican opponent.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 26 (AP) -- The 375-room Chelsea Hotel has been sold to a company headed by Martin Shamberg, co-owner of the Coronet Motel.
DETROIT, Oct. 26 -- Average daily sales of new cars by dealers in the Oct. 11-20 period fell 6 per cent below the rate for early October.

The Inland Credit Corporation, a commercial financing organization, has leased a half-floor in the Pan American Building, which is under construction at 200 Park Avenue adjoining Grand Central Terminal. The lease involves 16,000 square feet of space and was arranged by Harold M. Mills Jr. of Cushman Wakefield, Inc., agent for the fifty-nine-story skyscraper.

Robert Gatling of Bronx Vocational successfully defended his Public Schools Athletic League Bronx cross-country championship yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park. Gatling covered the two-and-a-half-mile course in 13 minutes 13.1 seconds, the fastest time of any P.S.A.L. harrier this year.

TWO impressive publications dealing with safe gun handling have come to hand. They are "Shooting-Hunting," put out by the American Association for Health, Physical Education and Recreation, and a similar manual from New Hampshire.
Religion needs psychiatry to relieve "its neurotic tendencies, which obscure and distort its primary resources and task," the dean of the Harvard Divinity School said here last night.

MANY of the pumpkins so conspicuously displayed on vegetable stands now are destined for an inedible fate. They will be hollowed out and eyes, ears and nose will be cut out to make a pumpkin face. The candle that customarily burns inside will so char the flesh that the vegetable will not be good for eating after Halloween.
Gus Mauch, the trainer of the Yankees for thirteen years, was released by the American League local club yesterday.

BOSTON, Oct. 26 (UPI) -- Don Head's first National Hockey League shutout and a reshuffled first line gave the Boston Bruins their first victory of the season tonight as they beat the Detroit Red Wings, 4 -- 0.

A sharp worded attack on the cotton price support program, coupled with a suggestion that it should be dropped, was put before a textile group yesterday by James E. Robison, president of Indian Head Mills, Inc.
State Supreme Court Justice Owen McGivern refused yesterday to block a transfer of control in the American Trust Company, here, to relatives of Alfred L. Kaskel, financier and real estate operator.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP) -- With the White House silent, four Senate Democrats struck back today at an attack by former President Dwight D. Eisenhower on the Kennedy Administration's fiscal policies and the Peace Corps.

The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) had an estimated consolidated net income of $570,000,000 in the first nine months of this year, M.J. Rathbone, president, said yesterday. This was equal to $2.63 each on the 216,533,000 shares outstanding.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 26 -- U Thant of Burma said today that he saw no hope for a quick solution of the five-week deadlock over the naming of an Acting Secretary General.

John M. Bailey, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said in a magazine, article yesterday that major policy changes instituted by President Kenendy "will furnish lasting guarantees of the right of the public to know about its government."
GENEVA, Oct. 26 -- The new International Council of Jewish Social and Welfare Services held its first public meeting here today.

Your endorsement of Louis J. Lefkowitz must be viewed with some reservations on the grounds of ultimate effectiveness. Although The Times wields enormous influence, the possibility that the Republican candidate will be elected has been diminished as a result of the successful effort of the present Mayor in obtaining the Democratic nomination.
NEW HAVEN, Oct. 26 (AP) -- The Yale chapter of Delta Psi Fraternity initiated a Negro member tonight over the protests of five University of Virginia members who flew to New Haven.

President Kennedy has a list of persons who would assume administrative power should a nuclear attack or other disaster kill top Government officials, the national Director of Emergency Planning said yesterday.

Joe Walton, the New York Giants' offensive end who plays "tight" to the line, may not be fit when the Giants meet the Dallas Cowboys in their National Football League game at Yankee Stadium on Sunday.
"Did he win the Nobel Prize? That's wonderful!" declared a literary critic familiar with the work of Dr. Ivo Andric. "All I can say is that I am absolutely delighted -- he really deserves it."
THE business of executing a proper stem christe did come up at the Wednesday opening of Bergdorf Goodman's ski shop, but only in passing.

Events today: "Tosca," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P.M.; New York Philarmonic, Leonard Bernstein and Maurice Peress, conductors, Robert Casadesus, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 2:15; Berlin Philharmonic, Herbert von Karajan, conductor, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Oedipus Rex," and "Carmina Burana," presented by New York City Opera Company, City Center, 8:15.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP) -- William Bender of New York, a top official in the 8,000-member American Communications Association, invoked the Fifth Amendment today in refusing to say whether he is a Communist.
Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz charged yesterday that Mayor Wagner had "looked the other way" while "decay" developed in city hospitals and care of the sick became scandalous.
Mayor Wagner moved yesterday to strengthen the city's plans for protection against radioactive fall-out.
The presence of an "unauthorized person" in a Federal grand jury room during the taking of testimony was made the basis yesterday of a motion to dismiss a narcotics indictment against three men.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Health officials from most of the fifty states and Puerto Rico were briefed today on nuclear fall-out protection.
LONDON, Oct. 26 -- Price movements were irregular and small in the stock market here today. However, many of the blue-chip stocks finished higher.
Mayor Wagner attacked his Republican rival, Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz, yesterday as the candidate of the party of "slumlords" and "sweatshops."

The board of directors of Standard Oil Company of California, meeting yesterday in San Francisco, elected Otto N. Miller to be president, succeeding T.S. Petersen, who will retire next Tuesday at the age of 65.

In London yesterday the odds ran three-to-two among brokers and money market watchers that the British Treasury would cut the Bank of England rate this week from the present 6 1/2 per cent level. There was some surprise when no announcement came but the bets now are that it will come in a few weeks.
Business loans at fourteen major New York City banks declined by $57,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
MINEOLA, Oct. 26 -- Four union officials were indicted today by a Nassau County grand jury in connection with an alleged car-wash racket.

The owners of six Greenview Village coffeehouses were finish a total of $480 in Upper Manhattan Court yesterday on seventy-seven summonses sued during the last three months for operating cabarets without licenses.
A one-day work stoppage "soon" by trainmen on the Long Island, the New Haven, the New York Central and the Boston Maine was anounced yesterday by union leaders.

Bethlehem Steel Corporation nearly tripled this year in the third quarter its 1960 results on a 4 per cent gain in billings. The higher profit covered the 60-cent dividend for the first time in five quarters.
The annual Casita Maria Fiesta has been arranged for Nov. 17 in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza.
MOSCOW, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Premier Khrushchev told President Kwame Nkrumah of Ghana today that resumption of nuclear testing had been forced on the Soviet Union by the Western powers.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 26 (AP) -- T.V. Lark, a work horse among thoroughbreds, was chosen today to make up the United States team with Kelso in the $100,000 Washington D.C. International Nov. 11 at Laurel.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 26 -- Gus Salerno of Hampshire and Mario Laureti of Darien today tied with Herman Barron of Fenway and Toney Tiso of Vernon Hills for first place in the Westchester Professional Golfers Association's best-ball championship at the Ridgeway Country Club.

PAULINE TRIGERE, always an individualist, has created some of the most feminine and youngest clothes of her career. In her collection yesterday, she continued the high-waisted silhouette that she showed last season and also re-emphasized fluidity with bias cut.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Miss Eva B. Adams, long-time associate of silver partisans, will become director of the United States Mint Monday. Her induction was delayed a month, during which nearly all authority over silver policy was removed from her office.

The United Nations Political Committee spoke for the overwhelming majority of the world's people when it voted, 75 -- 10, in favor of a solemn appeal to the Soviet Union not to explode the fifty-megaton superbomb Khrushchev has been brandishing. Aside from its eight satellites and Cuba -- which by now seems to have become only another satellite -- Moscow had no supporters in the Political Committee.
The annual card party of the New York Society of Kentucky Women will be held Nov. 6 in the Grand Ballroom of the Pierre.
A 20-year old youth was shot and killed in the Carnarsie section of Brooklyn early today. A companion escaped after a gunman fired four shots.
ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 26 -- Parliament today elected Gen. Cemal Gursel the President of Turkey.
Despite increases in sales in both the quarter and nine months ended on Sept. 30, net income of the Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation fell from the 1960 levels, the company reported yesterday.
New York State has a "stable tax structure," Governor Rockefeller said yesterday in addressing the annual convention of the American Finance Conference.
City Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa, the Citizens party candidate for Mayor, accused Mayor Wagner last night of laxity in obtaining the city's fair share of state aid.

President Joaquin Balaguer of the Dominican Republic has renewed assurances of complete freedom of thought, free access to sources of information and free circulation of foreign newspapers in his country, in a message to the Inter-American Press Association. It was made public yesterday.
A musician fighting eviction from his studio in the Metropolitan Opera House contended in Municipal Court yesterday that Communists in the Metropolitan Opera Association were behind it.
Airlines operating Lockheed Electra turboprops have been urged to guard against failure in the hydraulic power system, particularly during take-offs.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 26 -- Foreign Minister Osten Unden of Sweden proposed today a "Non-Nuclear Club" whose members would make a fresh effort to get an international ban on atomic tests.

New York so often seems a snarl of skyscrapers, industrial plants and teeming residential districts that it is always a jolt to be reminded that sizable areas of Staten Island, Brooklyn and Queens remain undeveloped. The projected establishment of a municipal land bank offers promise that many of these sections will eventually become model communities, with well-planned streets, schools, parks and facilities.

An upswing in sales and earnings of Continental Copper Steel Industries appears to be underway, Mortimer S. Gordon, president, told the annual meeting yesterday. Mr. Gordon said that in the quarter ended on Sept. 30, sales rose to $11,798,181 from $11,583,225 in the 1960 period.
The Loral Electronics Corporation announced yesterday plans to acquire the Arco Electronics Corporation in a stock transaction. Both are New York companies.

The Board of Estimate yesterday approved two new pier terminal construction projects that are part of the Department of Marine and Aviation's $200,000,000 long-range waterfront development and rehabilitation program.

TAHITI has been called the enchantress of the South Seas and the emotional capital of the South Pacific. However, thanks to the inroads of civilization -- jets, tourists, movie-makers and supermarkets -- this tiny island is rapidly losing its picture-book quality, according to reports from recent tourists.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 26. -- The three-week-old coalition talks between Chancellor Adenauer and the Free Democrats broke down today.

The appointment yesterday of Milton Howard Cohen, 50, to head the Securities and Exchange Commission's "high-level" investigation of the nation's stock markets was the end result of weeks of siftings of names for that task.

Aircrafts took the lead in yesterday's session of the New York Stock Exchange and remained in front throughout the day. After a good start, which sent prices higher until noon, other groups faded quickly and continued downward until a small rally developed in the final minutes.

TEANECK, N.J., Oct. 26 -- A new kind of night life is brewing in suburbia. Coffeehouses are quietly popping up to compete with such things as television, the movies and the charcoal grill. And hardly a beatnik is in sight.

The American Jewish Committee reported yesterday that more than eighty American business concerns and seventy American-owned ships have been blacklisted by the Arab Leabue because of business relations with Israel.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- It is possible that too many high school teachers who are in the Reserves have been called up in the current mobilization, defense officials said today.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Oct. 26 -- New Jersey's big need today is to bring about a better climate for the economic growth of the state, James P. Mitchell, the Republican candidate for Governor, told a Kiwanis Club luncheon here today.

Supplies of milk for 10,000,000 persons in New York City and on Long Island ran nearly dry yesterday as the strike of milk truck drivers and plant workers continued. However, there were no reports of hardship or panic, with housewives turning calmly to substitutes.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 26 -- One of the favorite pastimes of Dr. Ivo Andric, who was awarded the Nobel Prize for Literature today, is watching children play basketball in Belgrade on courts built under the ruined walls of Kalamagden -- the rambling amalgam of Roman, Byzantine, Serbian, Turkish and Austrian fortifications that has frowned over the junction of the Danube and Sava Rivers for centuries.

THIS has been the decade of new American operas, and another was added to the list last night at the City Center. It was Robert Ward's "The Crucible," based on the Arthur Miller play and presented by the New York City Opera Company under a Ford Foundation grant.
MOSCOW, Oct. 26 -- Vyacheslav M. Molotov was accused today at the congress of the Soviet Communist party of having written a political platform "for further intrigues" against the party.

The hot competition in New York State for new savings deposits may soon get even hotter. New York State Superintendent of Banks Oren Root has scheduled a meeting on Nov. 2 with the Council of Administration of the Association of Savings Banks of New York.
Roger Sessions will be 65 years old on Dec. 28, but it was not until last night that a New York organization had the enterprise to present an all-Sessions program in this city.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Oct. 26 -- President Ngo Dinh Diem promised his beleaguered nation today to lead "a new awareness" of the Communist danger facing his country.
A 25-year-old woman and her 2-year-old son were killed yesterday afternoon when they were struck by a bus at West 106th Street adn Broadway.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Following is the text of President Kennedy's statement to Cabinet officers and agency heads today on the budget outlook for 1962 and 1963:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- Psychological satisfaction for the housewife, not deception or confusion, is the aim of the words "full quart" on fruit juice containers, "jumbo" on packages of soap flakes and "mammoth" for olives, a Senate inquiry was told today.

Last week it was the State University of New York's Maritime College on Fort Schuyler, the Bronx, that was host to a meeting of District 4 of the United States Power Squadrons. Tomorrow it will be the United States Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point, L.I., that will welcome members of pleasure boating's largest body to the annual fall education conference of District 3.
