Puccini's "Le Fanciulla del West" may have opened the Metropolitan Opera season on Monday with the glitter of novelty, but it took the same composer's old, familiar spell-binder, "La Boheme," which was given last night, to make the opera house seem like itself.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- The inhabitants of the northern Soviet village of Ust-Usa may have suffered unusually heavy fall-out as a result of a Soviet miscalculation in detonating the thirty-megaton bomb.

An anthology of writings about Jews by non-Jews is planned for Nov. 6 publication by Macmillan. Called "The Jew in a Gentile World," the volume shows how, from the fifth century to the present, the Jew has been loved or hated, accepted or rejected, held in esteem or in contempt.
A former convict who had been sought in a nation-wide hunt surrendered here yesterday and was charged with shooting a policeman.

A loss of $4,800,000 was registered by the Chrysler Corporation for the third quarter of 1961, in contrast to a net income of $1,400,000, or 15 cents a share for the 1960 period. The loss was slightly more than the new management team of George H. Love, chairman, and Lynn A. Townsend, president, had forecast during previews of the Chrysler cars last month.

MADRID, Oct. 26 -- The Spanish Government was reported tonight to be sending four French extremists here into exile in the isolated Canary islands. The four are Jose Ortiz, Pierre Lagaillarde and two former colonels, Charles Lacheroy and Antoine Argould.
LE ROY, N.Y., Oct. 26 (AP) -- Representative Samuel S. Stratton charged tonight that Governor Rockefeller was implying that a backyard fall-out shelter would deter an atomic attack.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 26 -- The General Assembly unanimously agreed today to set up an investigation into the death of Dag Hammarskjold.
LONDON, Oct. 26 -- Lord Fisher of Lambeth, the former Archbishop of Canterbury, said today that the Church of England in recent times had been its own worst enemy.
The board of directors of the Certain-teed Products Corporation voted a 25 per cent stock dividend and raised the present cash dividend by 25 per cent yesterday.

Production of lumber in the nation rose to 229,778,000 board feet last week from 218,636,000 a week before according to reports from regional associations. A year ago, 221,648,000 board feet were produced.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- The United States will make a formal diplomatic protest to the Soviet Union tomorrow against East German interference with the right of American officials freely to enter East Berlin.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Department store sales in the nation for the week ended Saturday, Oct. 21, were 4 per cent above the level of a year earlier.
Fish forecasting was presented yesterday as a new science.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 26 -- A leading Congressional critic of civil defense planning urged today that the Administration start a program of building fall-out shelters in the nation's schools.

Directors of the Monsanto Chemical Company announced yesterday in St. Louis the election of Robert K. Mueller, a vice president, as a director and a member of the executive committee. John R. Eck was elected a vice president and appointed general manager of the plastics division, succeeding Mr. Mueller, who has held the post since 1952.
The Hospital Council of Greater New York expressed concern yesterday over a continuing increase in the number of hospital beds here despite the fact that the population had declined slightly.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Following is the text of a Public Health Service statement issued today on fall-out surveillance and protection:

The Mayor's Committee on Baseball was honored yesterday for "outstanding accomplishments in preserving the pre-eminence of New York as the sports capital of the world" -- or, to be specific, for bringing a National League baseball team back to the city.

Bus service for handicapped children traveling from Queens to schools in the Bronx was improved yesterday after parents had complained that some children were more than two hours late arriving at classes and returning home.
A twenty-minute change in schedule can cost an airline ten passengers dally on a single flight, an expert on scheduling said yesterday.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 26 -- Students of Soviet affairs here believe that Premier Khrushchev is seeking to have his policies elevated to the rank of party doctrine binding on all Communists as a means of forestalling opponents at home and abroad.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 26 -- Once Meadow Farr, the 3-5 favorite, broke stride while rounding the first turn in the mile-and-a-sixteenth stake for 3-year-old trotters at Roosevelt Raceway tonight, the $26,325.22 Lady Suffolk became a virtual runaway -- make that trotaway -- for Speedy Princess.
FOR two acts there is nary a homicide in "Write Me a Murder." Finally in the first scene of the third the new play that opened last night at the Belasco arranges a killing with malice aforethought.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Oct. 26 -- The South African Broadcasting Corporation broadcast a scathing attack tonight on Albert John Luthuli, the former Zulu tribal chief who was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for 1960 Monday.
Some repaving of city streets will henceforth be done at night to expedite daytime traffic, Mayor Wagner announced yesterday.

Chief Samuel L. Akintola, Premier of Western Nigeria, arrived in New York yesterday for a five-day visit. In answer to what a newsman conceded was a "loaded" question, the Premier said he was sending "many postcards" to friends back home.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Oct. 25 -- The United States and Czechoslovakia appear to be at the point of signing a settlement of mutual claims after six years of slow negotiations.

A suit to enjoin New York Mailers Union No. 6, International Typographical Union, and the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union of New York City and Vicinity from striking or causing a work stoppage at The New York Times was filed yesterday in Federal Court here by the National Labor Relations Board.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- A marked rise in year-to-year and week-to-week loadings was reported today by both the railroad and trucking industries.
THE annual fall tournament of the North Jersey Bridge Association begins today and will continue through Sunday. It will be played at the Bergen Mall Auditorium at Paramus, N.J.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 26 -- The absence of a big issue to stir the electorate indicates that the campaign for Governor in southern New Jersey will turn on the effectiveness of party organization. The Republicans claim an advantage on this score.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 26 -- Tennessee Williams has written a new version of "Sweet Bird of Youth" that is radically different from the Broadway success.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- President Kennedy has reassured South Vietnam of his determination to help it resist Communist attacks and preserve its independence.
PEIPING, Oct. 26 -- Diplomatic sources said here today that Communist China was on the verge of openly acknowledging a rift in the world Communist movement.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Questions were raised today about the infrequency of President Kennedy's news conferences. The average has been one in two weeks.

Seapower is still the touchstone of national greatness, Secretary of the Navy John B. Connally told the annual dinner of the Navy League at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night. History has shown that any nation disregards that truth at its peril, he said.

Three years ago tranquillity reigned almost everywhere in South Vietnam. The little state, created by the division of Vietnam between a Communist North and a non-Communist South in the 1954 Geneva settlement of the Indochina war, had attained internal unity and was beginning to make much social and economic progress.

Knickerbocker prestige soared to another lofty peak last night as the New York quintet downed the Cincinnati Royals, 120 -- 117, in the most thrilling and evenly fought game at Madison Square Garden thus far in the young season.

TUNIS, Oct. 26 -- Authoritative Algerian nationalist quarters give two major reasons for the massive demonstrations being organized in the Algerian underground for next Wednesday, the seventh anniversary of the outbreak of the guerrilla war for independence.
NEW HAVEN, Oct. 26 (AP) -- The first birth control clinic in Connecticut since 1940 is expected to be opened shortly.

AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 26 (UPI) -- Students at the University of Texas have voted in favor of dropping the color barrier in intercollegiate athletics. They also elected the first Negro member of the Student Assembly -- Gwen Jordan of Houston.
PARIS, Oct. 26 -- Massive worker adherence to a twenty-four-hour strike call crippled France's Government-operated rail and air services across the country today.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 26 -- A United Nations inquiry committee recommended tonight the immediate termination of South Africa's mandate in South-West Africa.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Two passenger-freighters collided in dense fog sixty miles north of San Francisco today. Both caught fire. There was no report of any casualties.
BERLIN, Oct. 26 -- Thirty-three Soviet medium tanks, manned by Soviet troops, moved into the center of East Berlin tonight.

Although the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad Company succeeded in cutting its deficit slightly last month, the carrier's net loss for the first nine months of this year exceeded that of the 1960 period.
TOKYO, Oct. 26 -- Premier Khrushchev told the Japanese Government today that "war preparations" by the West had forced the Soviet Union to resume nuclear weapons testing.
ALGIERS, Oct. 26 -- European and Moslem leaders called on their fellow-citizens today to halt the present "explosion of hatred and violence" in Algeria.

A comparison of Soviet and American schools indicated yesterday that Russian children in the fourth grade use books with a vocabulary of about 10,000 words, while American pupils at the same point are limited to "basal readers" with a vocabulary of less than 1,800 words.

HONG KONG, Oct. 26 -- Specialists here on Chinese Communist affairs have concluded that Premier Khrushchev's attack on Albania has united Peiping's leaders solidly against him while driving a deep wedge between the Soviet Union and Communist China.
FOR many years the American Savoyards have been in contented and successful communication with Gilbert and Sullivan. This season they plan to take up, as well, with Lehar, Friml and Romberg.
Bank clearings in twenty-six leading cities in the nation declined slightly to $27,754,459,000 for the week ended on Wednesday, Dun Bradstreet Inc., reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (UPI) -- The Justice Department charged today that Negroes in Madison Parish (County), La., had been denied voting rights through the voucher registration system.
PINEHURST, N.C., Oct. 26 (AP) -- Maureen Orcutt made up four strokes today and won the North and South women's senior golf tournament for the second straight year with a 36-hole total of 153.
Average daily borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System fell by $90,000,000 to $55,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation reported yesterday gains in earnings, sales and backlog for the first nine months of this year compared with the 1960 figures. Third-quarter sales and net also rose.

HE was a little man, noisy, vulgar, bristling with conceit and arrogance. "The trouble with me," he used to say to his long-suffering friends, "is that all my emotion has gone into sex instead of into painting." It was a crude boast rather than an admission of his failure as a painter. Matthew Gorer as long as he lived never admitted that he was a failure. Genius was more like it in his own opinion.

How New Yorkers can still plan to vote for Mayor Wagner, after reading your masterful presentation of the real issues of the current campaign, can only be explained in terms of the unthinking reactions of those ritualistic Democrats who -- like the brethren they profess to scorn in the Southland -- actually prefer a one-party set-up.

When William Doppmann last played the piano here, it was as the 1954 Naunburg Foundation Award Winner. Last night Mr. Doppmann, now a venerable 27, pianist-in-residence and professor at the University of Iowa, returned to Town Hall for a second recital and fulfilled much of the promise that he showed on that earlier occasion.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- President Kennedy directed the heads of Federal agencies today to tighten up on spending.
The election of Charles G. Dougherty as a director of E.W. Bliss Company of Canton, Ohio, was announced by Bliss yesterday. Mr. Dougherty is a vice president of Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.
Treasury securities gained in strength in a fairly active market yesterday as money eased a bit and gave a psychological lift to trading activity.

About this time every football season, medical reports are almost as important as practice news in the Ivy League. Yesterday was no exception. Some teams received encouraging news from the infirmary while others groaned over their physical misfortune for tomorrow's games.
Three persons were awarded a total of $903,000 in damages yesterday by a jury in the Brooklyn Supreme Court as a result of an American Airlines' Electra plane crash in the East River Feb. 3, 1959.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Neale Fraser, the former Wimbledon and United States champion, said today that the United States Lawn Tennis Association twice had "docked his allowance" when he was given free private accommodations during American tournaments.

ROCHER NOIR, Algeria, Oct. 27 -- Louis Joxe, Minister for Algerian Affairs, said today that an early resumption of peace talks between France and the Algerian nationalist Provisional Government was "evidently possible."

Seventeen players from ten countries started play yesterday in the first of seventeen rounds of the women's world championship challengers' chess tournament at Vrnjacka Banja, according to a report from Yugoslavia.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- A Senate inquiry was assured today that major segments of the food industry were undertaking to correct packaging and labeling practices that had been criticized as deceptive.
" Don't ever look back" might be good advice for most folks, but it would never do for Andrew James Bathgate, the high-scoring right wing and captain of the New York Rangers.

ROCHELLE PARK, N.J., Oct. 27 -- Richard J. Hughes, the Democratic candidate for Governor, today challenged James P. Mitchell, his Republican opponent, to debate campaign ethics and bossism with him next week in Teaneck.
MOSCOW, Oct. 27 -- Premier Khrushchev told the Soviet Communist party today to halt a trend of building a "cult of personality" around him.
People, especially smokers, who cough at least three months of the year for two successive years may have chronic bronchitis, specialists in respiratory ailments said here yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 27 -- A solemn appeal to the Soviet Union to call off its planned fifty-megaton bomb test was adopted overwhelmingly tonight by the General Assembly.
LONDON, Oct. 27 -- Qualified sources said tonight that the British Government was considering reinforcement of the undermanned Army of the Rhine in Germany with troops from overseas garrisons.

Like a material that requires many different threads, the pattern of progress in any nation has many different warps and woofs. Spain, long considered slow in industrializing, recently has been catching the observing eye of quite a few stock market analysts.

MORRISTOWI, N.J., Oct. 27 -- James P. Mitchell, the Republican candidate for Governor, said today he assumed President Kennedy's scheduled visit to New Jersey next Thursday "means that he feels that the world situation is sufficiently secure to enable him to take time out for a political appearance."
Emerson Meyers, a pianist and composer from Washington, gave a recital last night in Town Hall.
The bond market closed the week on a quiet note, with Treasury securities higher on the day in a narrow market.
BERLIN, Oct. 27 -- An eerie quiet settled temporarily tonight at the Friedrichstrasse checkpoint as the muzzles of heavy tank guns pointed at each other.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Oct. 27 (UPI) -- President Kennedy has granted a full and unconditional pardon to Herman M. Greenspun, newspaper publisher, convicted in 1950 of violating the Neutrality Act in shipping arms to Israel.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 27 -- The General Assembly voted the admission of Outer Mongolia and Mauritania today as the 102d and 103d members of the United Nations.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 27 -- Princeton will put its unbeaten Ivy League football record on the line tomorrow when it clashes with Cornell in Palmer Stadium.

The Pittsburgh Steel Company is offering its common stockholders rights to subscribe for 1,189,947 additional common shares at the rate of three new shares for each four shares held of record of Oct. 26.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -President Kennedy and his top foreign policy advisers have been exasperated and angered by the conduct of the Indian delegation at the United Nations during the debate on nuclear testing.

The award of the 1961 Nobel prize for literature to the Yugoslav author and ex-diplomat Ivo Andric will introduce this unique and fascinating literary craftsman to a wide audience in this country and abroad. There is an accomplished narrative mastery in Andric's novels of his native Bosnia, in which suffering, infamy, disenchantment and the irrepressible springs of human hope are acutely and often shockingly explored.

Members of the Manhattan Junior Committee of the National Cystic Fibrosis Research Foundation are completing plans for the 400 Ball, which will take place the afternoon of Nov. 5 in the Cotillion Room of the Pierre.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Oct. 25 -- The twenty-second Communist party congress in Moscow is very much with Prague these days.
Normal longshore operations were resumed yesterday on the pier at the foot of Seventeenth Street in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (UPI) -- The National Labor Relations Board said today that the Bethlehem Steel Company had been guilty of a "limited unfair labor practice" but dismissed charges that the company had bargained in bad faith.

WRENSHALL, Minn., Oct. 27 (AP) -- An English teacher who was dismissed for insubordination after he had assigned students to read the book "1984" was reinstated last night. The action was taken at a meeting of the Wrenshall school board and representatives of the Minnesota Education Association.
The supercarrier Constellation, built in tragedy, was commissioned in triumph yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- A Soviet delegation told representatives of the B'nai B'rith Youth Organization today that the Communist aim of national unity prohibited any of the Soviet Union's nationality or religious sects from joining groups restricted to parochial interests.

Texaco, Inc., reported yesterday that consolidated net income for the three months ended on Sept. 30 rose to $110,512,630, or 89 cents a share, from $101,641,879, or 84 cents a share, for the 1960 period. Shares outstanding in the 1961 period averaged 123,573,934, against 121,076,324 shares for the 1960 quarter.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board ordered Pan American World Airways, Inc., today to start disposing of the stock it holds in National Airlines, Inc., within one year and to complete the divestiture by July 5, 1964.

As viewed by Charlie Conerly, a football field is like a king-sized chessboard and his job as quarterback for the New York Giants is to advance the attacking pieces against the most vulnerable segment of the defense.
National Airlines, Inc., slipped back into the red last month after having operated profitably in July and August.

" SCRAP IRONY,"* by Felicia Lamport, is an uncommonplace book of bright verse and lively prose soliloquies. Once you pick it up you can put it down all right. But you find yourself coming straight back to it for more entertainment. Of course if you are so guileless as to put it down where others can find it you may have a spot of trouble re-establishing rights of possession.
LAUREL, Md., Oct. 27 (AP) -- The Soviet Union will try for the fourth straight year to win the Washington D.C. International with a pair of 4-year-old colts.
UTICA, N.Y., Oct. 24 -- The Republican organization in this Mohawk Valley city is engaged this fall in a critical test of the durability of civic indignation.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 27 -- The American people "should make full use of their government in meeting welfare needs," a report to the Conference of the Churches on Social Welfare said today.

GAINESVILLE, Fla., Oct. 27 (AP) -- Vice President Johnson declared tonight that "good Americans" are unwittingly aiding the Communists by planting "seeds of doubt" about the loyalty of the nation's leaders and the fairness of its institutions.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -More than twenty insurance companies are forming a private association to insure against bad credit risks in the sale of exports.
Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz yesterday began an investigation of electrical industry dealings with public agencies.

In opening a series of three Bach concerts at Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium in the Metropolitan Museum of Art, last night, Rosalyn Tureck made use of three instruments -- a harpsichord, a clavichord and a grand piano.

ONE old-fashioned form of adult fun on Allhallows' Eve was to extract raisins from flaming brandy. After answering the doorbell to a succession of hobgoblins and witches, however, it would seem that older citizens have earned a more peaceful reward.

A one-day stoppage threatened by trainman on the Long Island, the New Haven, the New York Central and the Boston Maine railroads was deferred yesterday pending a meeting Tuesday at 10 A.M. in the State House in Boston.
MOSCOW, Oct. 27 (AP) -Premier Khrushchev, in a letter made public today, rejected appeals of Western liberals and scientists to end nuclear testing.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Boston University put together two goal-line stands and two touchdowns by a sophomore halfback, Joe DiPietro, tonight for a 20-to-6 football victory over George Washington.
Three maritime unions have reduced their manning scales in an attempt to keep a bankrupt shipping line in operation, an officers' union reported yesterday.
A realigment of high executives and the declaration of an extra dividend of 25 cents a share were announced yesterday by the Socony Mobil Oil Company, Inc.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 27 -- When the red light turns to green and reads "thank you" at any one of the automatic toll booths of the New England Thruway here, it does not always mean what it says.
MIAMI BEACH, Oct. 27 -- Regardless of world opinion, the United States must resume full-scale testing of nuclear weapons, Governor Rockefeller of New York said here today.

The National Labor Relations Board is expected to decide next week whether to count ballots cast in an election among clerical personnel of American Export Lines last Tuesday.

Montclair State Teachers College will seek its fourteenth straight football vietory in a two-season span tonight against Kutown (Pa.) State Teachers College. The game will be played at Clifton (N. J. High School Stadium.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission today ordered Indianapolis television station WLWI off the air by Nov. 30 and awarded its channel, 13, to WIBC, Inc.

The City Labor Department proposed yesterday that a single collective bargaining unit be established for all the city's public school teachers, regardless of whether they serve in elementary or secondary schools.

The trend toward fewer and larger banks "can be expected to slow down, if it is not reversed," Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennessee, said yesterday. He addressed the final session of the American Finance Conference annual convention here.

IF you dig the beats, then you might swing with "GO Show Me a Dragon," which open at the new Midway Theatre last night. If you don't dig the beats, then you will probably find the play dull and unimpressive, like.
CHICAGO, Oct. 27 (AP) -- A brisk late rally in soybeans lifted prices as much as 2 cents a bushel from the day's lows on the Board of Trade and sent all deliveries above Thursday's closes.
Four of eight youths accused of the fatal beating of a 20-year-old shipping clerk pleaded guilty to second-degree man-slaughter yesterday in Bronx County Court.
The Air Force has awarded a $34,386,000 contract to the General Electric Company for jet engines for T-38 aircraft.

Events today: Metropolitan Opera, "La Traviata" at2 P.M. and "Lohengrin" at 8 P.M.; New York City Opera Company, City Center, "Carmen" at 2:30 P.M. and "Aida" at 8 P.M.; New York Philharmonic, Leonard Bernstein and Maurice Peress, conductors, Robert Casadus, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30 P.M.; Yehudi Menuhin, violinist, Hunter College Assembly Hall, 8:30 P.M.

Business as usual was the order last night at the Metropolitan Opera, with a tried-and-true opera performed by a familiar cast. No condemnation is of course. "Tosca," with Dorothy Kirsten, Richard Tucker and George London adds up to a potent combination any day, any time.
HONG KONG, Oct. 27 -- Communist China broadcast an urgent warning tonight against radioactive fan-out for its northern provinces.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Mayor Wagner came to Washington today and won new support from President Kennedy for his re-election and for a Federal role in the 1964-65 New York World's Fair.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP) -- A research rocket was fired ninety miles into the sky from the civilian space agency's test station at Wallops Island, Va., early today in a study of electron density and temperature in the upper part of the atmosphere.

THE Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra, on its third visit to America, played last night in Carnegie Hall. For this occasion, which was attended by many notables, including Senator Joachim Tiburtius as the official representative of West Berlin, three composers were represented.
Five men, described by the police as rivals of the Gallo gang, were sentenced to long prison terms yesterday in the Federal Court, Brooklyn, for hijacking $75,000.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Paul Hornung, star halfback of the Green Bay Packers, originally scheduled for active Army duty next Monday, was directed today to take another physical examination requiring a ten-day hospital stay.

" Hunting Trails: A Sportsman's Treasury," an anthology compiled by Raymond R. Camp, will be published by Appleton-Century-Crofts on Nov. 6. The selections of fact and fiction range from accounts of big-game hunting in India and Africa to squirrel-hunting in the American Midwest and from stories of suspense and high adventure to humorous misadventure.

Another step in the permanent financing of the $325,000,000 Verrazano-Narrows Bridge is under way. Managing underwriters of a group now being formed announced yesterday that they were negotiating with the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority for the sale of a new issue of general revenue bonds that would result in a public offering about Nov. 14.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (UPI) -- The State Department plans to fulfill an agreement to help Yugoslavia in research for peaceful uses of atomic energy.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- A Government health official said today that radiation controls such as milk embargoes or diet changes were not likely to be imposed in the wake of Soviet nuclear tests.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 27 -- Yale and Colgate, both with 3-1 won-lost records in football, meet tomorrow in the Yale Bowl.
PARIS, Oct. 27 -- Western Europe appears to be headed for its fourth straight year of economic expansion and prosperity.
Tony Petrillo of Lincoln won the individul championship and Boys High the team laurels in the Brooklyn Public Schools Athletic League cross-country championships yesterday at Prospect Park.

ALBANY, Oct. 27 (UPI) -- Former Vice President Richard M. Nixon and Governor Rockefeller, possible rivals for the Republican Presidential nomination in 1964, will meet in New York on Monday for the first time since shortly after the national election.

NEWARK, Oct. 27 -- Two New Jersey housewives are busy these days advancing the political ambitions of their husbands. And frequently their efforts equal those of the husbands -- James P. Mitchell, the Republican candidate for Governor, and Richard J. Hughes, his Democratic rival.

TORONTO, Oct 27 (UPI) -- Jersey Joe Walcott was picked today to referee the Floyd Patterson-Tom McNeeley heavyweight title fight here on Dec. 4. This settled the question that had caused the bout to be shifted from Boston to Toronto.

ROSEDALE, Md., Oct. 27 (UPI) -- Five Negroes were arrested tonight after seeking service at a diner on heavily traveled Route 40, where the Government has been urging restaurant owners to drop their ban on Negro customers.
DAVID DIAMOND completed his Symphony No. 8 last year, and it received its world premiere yesterday afternoon. Leonard Bernstein directed the work with the New York Philharmonic at Carnegie Hall.
The National Assembly of Cambodia has taken cognizance, with deep indignation, of The New York Times' Oct. 25 editorial, which is an insult to the chief of state of Cambodia and to the Khmer people.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP) -- A prominent Protestant told a Roman Catholic meeting here today that, while "we are opposed to cummunism as a faith and as an ideology and as a political system," it is a "covert idolatry" to assume that God is always on the West's side in the "cold war."
The Times of Oct. 21 contained a letter from a veteran campaigner against the city's use of litter baskets.
Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz accused Mayor Wagner yesterday of fighting the crime problem with "paper swords."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- A preference for Senator Barry Goldwater of Arizona for the Republican Presidential nomination in 1964 has been indicated in a poll of last year's Republican convention delegates and alternates.

Felony Court rang with applause yesterday in a rare outburst of emotion. It came when the case of John S. Cram was dismissed and the magistrate and assistant District Attorney had called on the authorities to recognize narcotic addiction as a "social and medical problem,'' not a criminal one.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board said today that it planned to split equally among New York, Chicago and Los Angeles the helicopter subsidy voted by Congress this year.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Oct. 27 -- The United States space program took a large leap forward today when an eight-engine Saturn rocket was successfully fired on its first test flight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Mrs. John F. Kennedy, one of the few really good horsewomen to serve as First Lady, entered the spotlighted ring of the International Horse Show here tonight. She appeared not as rider -- a role that she has played at many shows in the past -- but as bearer of the new President of the United States Perpetual Challenge Cup for winner of the international jumping competition.

ABOUT one-half of "O Marry Me!," a musical based on "She Stoops to Conquer," is pleasant and gay. This new version of Oliver Goldsmith's satirical farce, with music by Robert Kessler and lyrics by Lola Pergament, opened last evening at the Gate Theatre.
ALBANY, Oct. 27 -- The state's two principal education officials suggested today that the state should pay a "substancial" share of the cost of building fall-out shelters in public schools.

Twenty-two feature-length movies from nineteen countries will be presented at the fifth San Francisco International Film Festival, to be held from Nov. 1 to Nov. 14 before an audience of international screen personages and contributors.
The Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island will elect a second Suffragan Bishop at a special diocesan convention one week from today in the Cathedral of the Incarnation in Garden City.
TOKYO, Oct. 27 (Reuters) -Japan was swept today by a radioactive rain, but the degree of contamination was still below the danger level.

Across the ocean in France there is being marked today the seventy-fifth anniversary of the Statue of Liberty in New York harbor. This link with the United States, perhaps more than any other, is a thing of great pride to the French.

Mayor Wagner called last night for both sides in the milk strike to meet with him at City Hall at noon today if no settlement of the four-day-old walkout has been reached by then.

Fundamental Investors, Inc., recorded a gain of almost 3 per cent in net asset value a share during the third quarter. The gain since the start of the year amounted to more than 16 per cent. These facts were disclosed in the quarterly report released yesterday.

The Society of St. Johnland, a charitable home in Kings Park, L.I., will be the beneficiary of the Nov. 30 performance of the musical "Sail Away" at the Broadhurst Theatre. Mrs. John Gerdes heads the benefit committee.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 27 (UPI) -- A Federal grand jury charged the police chief of Newport, Ky., and five others today with having falsely conspired to arrest George Ratterman, former football star, in a room with a striptease dancer.
The statement by the Administrative Council of the City University of New York barring Communist speakers from the municipal college campuses is an exercise in sophistry.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP) -- To encourage small companies to enter the export business, the F.C.I.A. will offer a special comprehensive guarantee available only to companies with a direct export volume of less than $50,000 in the preceding twelve months.

Operations of Sunshine Biscuits, Inc., resulted in a slight, decrease in net income in the nine months ended on Sept. 30, the company reported yesterday. Net earnings dipped to $5,269,855, or $4.43 a share, from $5,653,030, equal to $4.71 a share, in the first nine months of 1960.

PARIS, Oct. 27 -- Electricity was cut and gas pressure was reduced to a minimum throughout France today during a four-hour strike by employes of the Government-operated electricity and gas system. The stoppage began at 8 A.M.
GENEVA, Oct. 27 -- The United States expressed satisfaction today with the preliminary talks held here on a projected international agreement to regulate trade in cotton textiles.

Neither rain, sleet, snow, a dislocated finger, a sprained back nor a spirited New Year's Eve party have kept Tom Bosley from a perfect attendance record in "Fiorello!", the musical that closes at the Broadway Theatre tonight.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 25 -- West Germany, which is spending more than any other European country on civil defense, plans to intensify its air raid protection operations in the next few months.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The United States interpreted the appearance of Soviet tanks at the East Berlin-West Berlin border today as a "belated admission" of Moscow's responsibility for the affairs of the city and the behavior of East German authorities.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, Oct. 27 -- The free market for sheet rubber has been suspended until the end of 1962 by the Commissioner of Commodity Purchase for the Ceylonese Government.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Irvin C. Scarbeck was convicted today of having given classified Government material to the Polish Government.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- President Kennedy decided today to go to New Jersey next week to help Richard J. Hughes, the Democratic candidate for Governor.
Fulton Towers, a ten-story apartment building occupying one and one-third acres of land at 106 South Harrison Street, East Orange, N.J., has been bought by a group of New York investors.
DETROIT, Oct. 27 -- The Chrysler Corporation made a new economic offer to the United Automobile Workers today in an effort to achieve a national contract covering 60,000 workers.

CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 27 (AP) -- Carry Back, the winner of the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness, will try again to get back in the winner's circle tomorrow in the $75,000 added Trenton Handicap at Garden State Park.
A landlord who said she had never seen her property was fined $500 in Housing Court yesterday for violations of the Health Code, particularly rat infestation.
The Theodore Roosevelt Distinguished Service Medal was presented last night to three Americans for conspicuous service to the nation during the last year.
LONDON, Oct. 27 -- Turnover contracted in the stock market here today and prices of both British Government securities and industrial shares drifted lower.

Seagate Travel Agency, Inc., has leased half of the fifth floor at 420 Madison Avenue, near Forty-ninth Street, for a branch office. Gallant-Roth Co. were the brokers. The lessee has offices at 44 West Thirty-seventh Street and in Brooklyn.
Peal, Harry A. Love's excellent jumper, contributed the best performance of his career in taking the thirty-eighth Temple Gwathmey Steeplechase at Aqueduct yesterday.
Cedric Hardwicke has been signed to narrate "The Picture of Dorian Gray" on the Columbia Broadcasting System television network.

DALLAS, Tex., Oct. 27 (UPI) -- E.M. Dealey, publisher of The Dallas Morning News, said he told President Kennedy at a meeting today at the White House that grass-roots opinion was that Mr. Kennedy and his Administration were "weak sisters."

BONN, Germany, Oct. 27 -The West German Foreign Office rejected in a diplomatic note today a Soviet charge that West German authorities had ordered the searching of a Soviet diplomat's house last Friday.
THE skipper under whose experienced hand the Navy's largest warship, the supercarrier Constellation, will put to sea is a descendant of generations of New England whaler captains.

The Federal Trade Commission has ruled that the Union Carbide Corporation must divest itself of the polyethylene film assets it acquired in 1956 through its purchase of the Visking Corporation. Carbide will have one year in which to complete the divestiture.

Silvio Varviso, Swiss conductor, has been added to the roster of the Metropolitan Opera. He will make his debut at a benefit performance of "Lucia de Lammermoor" on Sunday, Nov. 26, in which Joan Sutherland will be heard with the company for the first time.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Rudolph W. Jones, a Cleveland radio engineer, denied today he had ever acted as a Communist courier.
PARIS, Oct. 27 -- France is planning to spend the equivalent of approximately $554,000,000 next year for African states to which she has granted independence but that continue to cooperate with her.
The hour that vanished in about half of the nation's households last April will return at 2 A.M. tomorrow when Daylight Saving Time bows out.

We at National Review are much obliged to you for counseling the Board of Higher Education, on Oct. 18, to overrule the administration of Hunter College and require it to continue to lease its facilities to the National Review Forum for the continuation of our programs, I should like, however, to raise a question or two about the way in which you make your points.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The primary market price index for all commodities for the week ended last Tuesday was unchanged at 118.6 per cent of its 1947-49 base, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 27 (AP) -- The New Jersey Bell Telephone Company announced today operating revenues of $92,112,903 for the three months ended on Sept. 30. This represented a rise of more than $4,000,000 from the level of the 1960 period.
The United States delegation to the United Nations successfully mediated a landlord-tenant dispute between an American woman and an Indian diplomat yesterday.
Ford C. Frick, the commissioner of baseball, announced yesterday that the major league player draft would be held at the Tampa Terrace Hotel, Tampa, Fla., beginning Nov. 27.
ELIZABETH, N.J., Oct. 27 -- Two car washers were convicted tonight of first-degree murder in the slaying of two socially prominent women in Plainfield on May 26.

ROME, Oct. 27 -- The seventh congress of the Socialist International condemned today the "savage brutality of the wall dividing Berlin. It called upon the West to take "a diplomatic initiative" to safeguard peace there and insure the freedom of the people.
ROME, Oct. 27 -- Pope John XXIII was confined to bed today with what the Vatican described as a "slight indisposition." All papal audiences were canceled.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (UPI) -- The Peace Corps, which has encountered criticism recently from former President Dwight D. Eisenhower and from Nigerian students, is also having trouble recruiting farm volunteers, officials said today.
The 200 cows that work for the city's last cow-owning milk producer went placidly about their business in Queens yesterday without creating much of a backlog in the milk strike.

The words Premier Khrushchev addressed to Communist China on the issue of Albania yesterday sounded suspiciously as though the Soviet leader were preparing his public opinion for an open break in the Communist camp.

A group headed by Walter Hoving, chairman and chief executive officer of Tiffany Co., has bought the 52 per cent controlling interest in the Fifth Avenue jewelry and silverware store held by Genesco, Inc.

BERLIN, Oct. 27 -- United States and Soviet tanks confronted each other tonight for the first time. They were less than 100 yards apart on the narrow Friedrichstrasse crossing point on the border between West and East Berlin.

NEWARK, Oct. 27 -- A Federal judge refused today to interfere with New Jersey law-enforcement officers who have been prosecuting the distributors and sellers of the Henry Miller novel "Tropic of Cancer."

Dissension within the United Taxpayers party erupted in Supreme Court yesterday at Vito P. Battista, the party's candidates for Mayor, tried to prevent the party label from being pinned on Louis J. Lefkowitz, the Republican nominee.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (UPI) -- The President's Committee on Equal Employment Opportunities said today a privately owned textile mill and the Charleston Naval Shipyard, both in South Carolina, had moved to end job discrimination against Negroes.
A drop in sales and earnings in both the third quarter and first nine months of 1961 was reported yesterday by the Flintkote Company, manufacturer of building products.

An enterprise that grubstaked Nineteenth Century prospectors along the iron-rich rim of Lake Superior plans this week to start a new chapter in a business saga closely interwoven with the nation's economic and political history.

TO take our minds off the sunny side of civilization, the English journalist, John William Rowdon, offers in his first novel an entertaining fantasy constructed of malicious wit, pellucid prose, some moments of real beauty and a great deal of excellent dialogue.
SYRACUSE, Oct. 28 -- A local tradition of electing Republican Mayors here has been broken only once since Calvin Coolidge was President. It appears unlikely to be reversed this November.

MADRID, Oct. 28 -- Spain's handsome capital is enjoying a mood of euphoria because everything seems to ge going Spain's way right now. For the Spaniards it is a welcome change from the long years of hostility and criticism their Government has been subjected to -- some feel unjustifiably.
DURHAM, N.H., Oct. 28 -- Three desperate second-half rallies failed to prevent Kings Point from losing, 8 -- 7, today to the University of New Hampshire in Cowell Stadium.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., Oct. 28 -- The purchasing directors of Long Island's prime industrial contractors will be guest speakers at six Small Business Workshops sponsored by the Long Island Association.

A boatwright who had been dismissed from his job at Columbia University yesterday morning was arrested later in the day and charged with having knocked holes in eight rowing shells. The damage was estimated at $19,000.
ATLANTA, Oct. 28 -- The handling of a Negro postman's reinstatement has aroused many protests in the South among the friends and foes of the Kennedy Administration.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Oct. 28 (Reuters) -- Output and sales by leading Jamaica industries increased during the first half of 1961, reflecting expanding local and foreign markets for Jamaican products, according to a report by Harold A. Braham, general manager of the island's Industrial Development Corporation.

WHEN the next to the last trumpet sounds, a chastened race of men may rise from the ashes and, having attended to the minimum necessities, may resume the amenities to make existence tolerable until the last trumpet. High on the list of priorities may be the theatre, and probably high in that category will be the sex comedy.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (UPI) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board hopes to speed its investigations of air crashes.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 27 -- The school system in West Germany is in the midst of broad reforms. Despite sharp criticism of some of the changes, there appears to be general agreement that new educational concepts have taken root.

David Shears, in his enjoyable article on American "politicking" ("Is Baby Kissing Really Necessary?" Oct. 8), mentioned that Harry Truman's pugilistic political reputation had preceded him to Oxford University, where he obtained an honorary degree in 1956, as evidenced when a student at the tradition-bound university shouted to him, "Give 'em hell, Harricum!"

WHAT motivates Red China? Where does she intend to go, and how? Denis Warner, Australia's most famous foreign correspondent and war reporter and an authority on Asia, makes a painstaking examination of these crucial questions in "Hurricane From China."
STROUDSBURG, Pa. -- Visitors entering the Pocono Mountain region from New Jersey this fall are quite likely to be given big blue tickets by officers at the major Delaware River crossings.

Dr. Glenn T. Seaborg, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, who won the Nobel Prize for his contributions to the synthesis of plutonium and other man-made elements beyond uranium, told the International Symposium on Aerospace Nuclear Propulsion at Las Vegas, Nev., last week that "the day is not far off when atomic energy will be available in many different packages for practical use in space vehicles."

THE jacket on "Blindness" is dead white, and the title is in large raised letters. Even if you were blind and had not learned braille, you could still read the title with your fingertips. Father Thomas J. Carroll, the author, is founder and director of St. Paul's Rehabilitation Center for the Blind in Boston, national chaplain of the Blinded Veterans Association and a member of numerous committees and councils in the field of blindness.

MADISON, Wis., Oct. 28 (UPI) -- Ohio State's relentless rushers, throwing only three passes, ground out a 30-21 victory today over Wisconsin and its passing star, Ron Miller, in a Big Ten football game.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 27 -- The regime of President Mohammad Ayub Khan marked its third anniversary today in a mixed atmosphere of pride, hope and frustration.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 28 -- In California, a working girl can be independent and self- supporting on an annual budget of $2,854.98, according to the State Division of Labor Statistics and Research.

Shipping rates on the nations inland waterways have risen less than 45 per cent in the last twenty-three years, according to Robert M. Tyrie, traffic manager of the Union Barge Line Corporation of Pittsburgh. This compares, he said, with a rise of 155 per cent in the price of finished steel.
FARMINGDALE, L.I., Oct. 28 -- Nassau County officials have agreed to discontinue the practice of assigning separate rooms to Negro and white patients at the county sanitarium here.
An experiment in speeding airmail from here to the West Coast by non-stop jet has proved successful, according to postal and airline officials. The service is being expanded tonight.

I don't understand why it is that many woman executives who have the same positions as men are paid $3000 less a year. These women are better qualified, and can really do a better job and bring better results for the company.

JOHNSON CITY, Tenn., Oct. 28 (UPI) -- One hundred eighty-one years ago this month a British colonel, Patrick Ferguson, in his headquarters at Gilberttown, N.C., sent an ultimatum across the mountains to settlers in the Holston River Valley of northeastern Tennessee and southwestern Virginia.
The privately owned merchant fleet of the United States declined by four units and 25,800 deadweight tons during September, it was reported here last week by the American Merchant Marine Institute.

To the Music Editor: MUSIC, says Thomas T. Tamlyn, in a recent letter to the Music Mail Pouch, is merely entertainment and not the measure of a nation's culture. Where does entertainment stop and culture begin?
VALLAURIS, France, Oct. 28 -- A ban on a Sunday bullfight featuring the matador Luis Miguel Dominguin marred today the Riviera's two-day celebration of Pablo Picasso's eightieth birthday.

HONG KONG, Oct. 28 -- An official of the Communist Chinese Foreign Ministry denied in Peiping today that the Defense Ministry had broadcast warnings to the Chinese people last night on the danger of radio-active fall-out.
A 15-year-old boy was accidentally shot and killed in Brooklyn yesterday while demonstrating a .22-caliber rifle to a friend in his father's television repair shop.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 28 -- Bird lovers learned here today that the number of bald eagles in the nation had fallen to 3,642, excluding those in Alaska.
SIOUX FALLS, S.D., Oct. 28 -- John F. Kennedy's stock has risen in this state, which favored Richard M. Nixon over him by a margin of 58 to 42 per cent in the election of 1960.

When Russian and American tanks face each other across a hole in the wall that now divides East Berlin from West Berlin, we are seeing one of the end results of the Russian conquest of German territory which was brought under their control by the trusteeship arrangements made at the end of the Second World War. WHEN Jerome Robbins set up a project called "Ballets: U.S.A." for a European festival and tour in 1958 and brought it home on the wave of its enormous success abroad, it looked as if he might have hit on a good idea and be on the way to something viable.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Oct. 28 -- A pair of star-crossed lovers held the attention of Arabs and Jews alike in Israel last week when a young woman was arrested and taken to court on a charge of kidnapping her own child from a state institution.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- In this Halloween season, a new man-made specter -- fall-out from atomic tests -- is beginning to haunt the world. How real a threat does it pose to present and future generations? There is no certain answer to this troublesome question that has reduced the diplomat and housewife to a common level of concern.
ROME, Oct. 28 -- Pope John XXIII celebrated the third anniversary of his election today with a broadcast address to the Roman Catholic episcopacy and the faithful.

WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 28 -- The multitude of public planners in Westchester County's 448 square miles propose to consult with one another more in preparing for 500,000 additional residents in the next twenty-five years. The present population is 808,891.

Seasonal job loss in the Twin Cities metropolitan area this winter will be held below 10,000, according to employer forecasts of hiring requirements to January. Last winter, by way of contrast, total employment in the five-county area declined by 23,000 jobs from September to January.
PARIS, Oct. 28 (UPI) -- France returned to normal today following two days of crippling strikes.
Central Connecticut State's cross-country team beat City College and Iona yesterday in a triangular meet at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx. Central Connecticut scored 31 points, City 32 and Iona 68.
About 250,000 children and youths in the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York will join others across the country beginning tomorrow in celebrating National Catholic Youth Organization Week.

Without pleasure boating with a good burst of speed there would be no water skiing. Without Fred Waller, once a Long Islander from Huntington who obtained patent No. 1,559,390 thirty-six years ago this week, the sport and craze of doing fantastic things on water skis might have been delayed many years.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah -- One of the nation's largest landlords, the Bureau of Land Management, is inching into the field of recreation. Because this Federal agency controls 177,000,000 acres, mostly in the western United States, plus an equal amount of acreage in Alaska, its decision to "think recreation" could be of major importance to vacationists, outdoorsmen, cattlemen, miners, oilmen and others now using the public domain.

City Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa, a Democrat running for Mayor as an independent candidate, made an open bid yesterday for the support of any disgruntled Democratic party district leaders.
Six debutantes, daughters of members of the Society of Mayflower Descendants, will be honored at a reception preceding the organization's annual dinner dance Friday at the Plaza.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 28 -- Several hundred of the nation's leading scientists will meet in a four-day convention on the La Jolla and Los Angeles campuses of the University of California, starting tomorrow.

ALBANY, Oct. 28 -- Governor Rockefeller said today he would recommend next year that special legislation be extended to prevent 378 cities, towns and villages from losing about $3,000,000 in per capita state aid because of declining population. New York City's share is $778,269.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- While most members of Congress take advantage of the current recess to travel, politick and tend to local business, at least one Congressional committee is keeping its axe to the Washington grindstone. It is that perennially controversial body, the House Committee on Un-American Activities.
NEWARK, Del., Oct. 28 (AP) -- Jim McKee's 48-yard field goal with one second left gave Ohio University a 17-16 victory over Delaware today.

VALLETTA, Malta, Oct. 27 -- The people of Malta are looking forward to a return of responsible internal self-government next year. But the announcement Wednesday of a new Constitution has not been received with acclaim.

RALEIGH, N.C., Oct. 28 (AP) -- Duke shackled North Carolina State's passing threat for three periods today and exhibited a flashy offense of its own in gaining a 17-6 football victory in the Atlantic Coast Conference.
Lehigh's football team rammed across the goal line twice in the second half yesterday and upset Columbia, 14 -- 7, in a non-league game at Baker Field.
A theatre party has been arranged for Nov. 17 at the preview that evening of "The Gay Life." The play will be at the Shubert Theatre.

ALGIERS, Oct. 28 -- The Secret Army Organization opposing President de Gaulle made a violent radio attack on him today, declaring that he intended to reach an accord with the Algerian rebels before the end of this year.

NEXT week, between forty and fifty million Americans will cast their ballots in what we rather slightingly call an "off-year" election. These voters will, in most instances, shut their eyes, cross their fingers and vote for candidates whose names, records, pronouncements and promises often are completely unknown to them.
SEOUL, Korea, Oct. 28 -- Representative Walter H. Judd said today that conditions in South Korea were "better than most Americans understood."

Spring apparel lines are making their appearance in the resident buying offices and are attracting considerable interest. Reports from the various offices at the end of last week indicated the emphasis was on femininity in the new spring styles for women.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Oct. 28 -- A United Nations official said today that the Congolese central Government had promised there would be no invasion of Katanga Province and was withdrawing its troops from the border.

THE jacket of "Weegee by Weegee: An Autobiography" (New York: Ziff-Davis. 159 pp. $5) calls Arthur Fellig, the author (nickname Weegee) "the World's zaniest photographer." The text confirms the title in a breathless recital of an amazingly varied and adventurous career spent mostly in New York City, in recent years also in Hollywood and Europe.
Two Columbia University graduate students who opened a discount bookstore last month in protest against prices at the campus store are eager now to sell out. Business is too good, they say.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 28 (UPI) -- The sophomore passing combination of Pete Beathard to Hal Bedsole provided the University of Southern California with a 14-10 victory over Illinois today. It was Illinois' fifth straight defeat.

DETROIT, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Disputes over working conditions in the plants plagued the United Auto Workers Union today as it sought to wrap up a new labor contract with the Chrysler Corporation by Tuesday night.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 28 -- A bill to keep money at home and reclaim any sent abroad is order consideration by the Brazilian Congress.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Oct. 18 -- The Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution has been cited here by a court in a decision that is likely to have a great effect on race relations.

MOSCOW, Oct. 28 -- Premier Khrushchev has indicated his determination to go ahead with the testing of a fifty-megaton nuclear bomb despite the appeals of those he described as "fair-minded people abroad."

IF I have to take to the woods someday to survive, I want the author as my mentor. A Marine Corps major, he is a survivalist of the first rank. He knows how to build a fire and a shelter; how to find and cook wild foods; how to treat poison ivy and snake bite; how not to get lost.

IN an unusual program decision, two separate episodes of the "Dick Van Dyke Show" will be televised by the Columbia Broadcasting System on successive nights early in November. The extra helping of Mr. Van Dyke's comedy is being rushed in to fill a breach where the network had hoped to present a White House tour conducted by Mrs. John F. Kennedy.

The American Cancer Society reported last week at its annual meeting in New York City that the cure rate from cancer has climbed during the past twenty-five years from one out of seven to one out of three. The society attributes the increased number of lives saved to improved methods of diagnosis and treatment as a result of research and to a growing awareness of the importance of early detection.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Oct. 28 -- President Ngo Dinh Diem listed today a number of ways in which he believes the United States could offer more effective assistance in South Vietnam's efforts to meet the intensified Communist challenge.
MILWAUKEE, Oct. 28 -- Two research engineers here have developed a system called Loox that reduces oxidation in gyroscopic instruments and thus increases the reliability or inertial guidance systems.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28 -- The will of John B. Kelly Sr., self-made millionaire, one-time Olympic champion and father of Princess Grace of Monaco, has become a "best seller."

PERHAPS the most exasperating experience for the flower arranger is to spend time carefully designing a centerpiece or bouquet, only to see it wither in a few days. Those who have met with such disappointment should be impressed with the results of recent research at Pennsylvania State University and Michigan State University, where scientists extended the lasting qualities of carnations up to twenty-two days.

MONTE CARLO, Monaco -- Like most resorts along this geographically spectacular coast, Monte Carlo is popular with budget-minded tourists. Unlike many of the other places, however, it also is crowded with luxury-loving visitors, those who arrive in chauffeur-driven cars, yachts and even private planes.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Oct. 28 (UPI) -- Offensive fireworks by the quarterback, Jim Costen, and a halfback, Billy Gambrell, provided as many touchdowns today as South Carolina had scored in five previous games and the Gamecocks stunned Maryland, 20-10.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The United States Equestrian Team won rider and horse trophies at the Washington International Horse Show tonight.

Ed Dean of Chaminade and James Harshbarger of Cardinal Hayes shared honors in the Catholic High School Athletic Association cross-country championships yesterday at Van Cortland Park in the Bronx.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- (AP) The Government added 126 areas today to the list of those eligible to seek Federal aid for economic development.

LIBEREC, Czechoslovakia, Oct. 23 -- Vaclav Dedek, a Communist politician here, was elected to Parliament in a landslide yesterday in this home town of Konrad Henlein, late Sudeten German leader.

FOR many years Frederick J. Pohl (a geographical detective, he calls himself) has been on the track of pre-Columbian voyagers. In earlier books, "The Lost Discovery" and "The Vikings on Cape Cod," and now in "Atlantic Crossings Before Columbus," he speculates on long-ago voyages, describes hints and clues concerning them, and tells how he ran them down.

The Women's League for the Brooklyn Academy of Music will hold a benefit luncheon at the Granada Hotel Brooklyn on Nov. 28. Proceeds will go toward enlargement of young people's programs at the Academy.

WHATEVER ills may beset other segments of the entertainment world, the festival business is currently showing no signs of anemia. Ample testimony to its healthy condition was produced at the three-day conference held here recently by the International Festival Association, a backstage organization with a membership that includes the managers of some of the major municipal celebrations in the country.
NEWARK, Oct. 28 -- Barringer dimmed South Side's bid for a City League championship with a 7-7 tie at Schools Stadium today.

NOW with the hunting season upon us the tenderhearted can take comfort from Roger Duvoisin's pictorial comedy about a reluctant Nimrod. From his little house on the edge of the forest Mr. Bobbin watches the hunters go by and thinks "it must be nice to look so big and bold and to walk through the forests, across field, up the hills and down the valleys."

NAIROBI, Kenya, Oct. 28 -- Jomo Kenyatta accepted today the presidency of Kenya's largest political party, the Kenya Africa National Union. The former Mau Mau leader said he intended to overhaul the party's countryside organization.

MIAMI BEACH, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Buren H. McCormack, vice president and editorial director of The Wall Street Journal was elected today as president and chairman of the board of Sigma Delta Chi, national journalism fraternity.

THE "spirit of Lumumba" lost, 7 -- 2, in a soccer match here the other day. The game was between city teams of Stanleyville and Leopoldville. Jumping up and down in their section of the bleachers, young men of the Lumumba Youth movement shouted rhythmic encouragement to the players from Stan: "For Lumumba, let's win!"

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP) -- The fall-out cloud from the Soviet Union's largest nuclear explosion was over the United States today. Weather Bureau observers said it was moving eastward along the northern states toward the Great Lakes.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP) -- United States farmers received almost 2 per cent more in cash receipts from marketings in the first nine months of this year than during the 1960 period.

Elizabeth Mannion is a mezzo-soprano front Seattle who has sung in opera in such diverse places as Bonn, Germany, New York and the United States Northwest. It was no surprise, therefore, that in her New York recital debut, at Town Hall late yesterday afternoon, she sang with assurance, intelligence, a well-schooled technique and an attractive voice.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28 (UPI) -- Some of the twenty-five deaths in organized football this year might have been prevented by using improved helmets, a committee of the American Medical Association said today.
Four decisions in second-round games were recorded yesterday in the women's world championship chess tournament at Vrnjacka Banja, according to a report from Yugoslavia.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP) -- The United States announced today that it had agreed to expand technical aid and to study other possible United States aid programs for British Guiana.

AUTUMN -- one of the two periods when scallops are in peak supply -- is a fine season for savoring this sweet, succulent mollusk. There are two versions, of course -- the thimble-size variety that comes from the bay and its larger oceanic cousin. They may be used interchangeably in any recipe.
BOSTON, Oct. 28 -- The Metropolitan Transit Authority doubled transportation costs for some riders today.

The dean of the New York University School of Law has urged American law schools to reconsider their "traditional methods and objectives" and abandon their "prejudices toward equality of opportunity."

Oct. 28 -- The annual Long Island Fall Flower Show, a horticultural fixture on the North Shore since 1904, will open a five-day exhibition here Friday afternoon at the Doris Lane showplace of the Glen Cove Neighborhood Association as a production of the North Shore Horticultural Society.

TORONTO, Oct. 28 (UPI) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs scored four third-period goals tonight and defeated the New York Rangers, 5 -- 1, in a National Hockey League game before 13,778 fans.
COLUMBIA, Mo., Oct. 28 (AP) -- A staunch Missouri defense, Bill Tobin's field goal and Andy Russell's touchdown gave the undefeated Tigers a 10-0 victory over Nebraska today.

MONTREAL -- Like the United States, Canada is eager to attract more tourists from Europe. In recent weeks, it has made significant progress in this direction. First, there was the easing of regulations for obtaining non-immigrant visas by tourists; second, there was the opening of Quebec House in Paris.

Seven years ago this Wednesday, guerrilla bands staged coordinated attacks at thirty scattered points throughout Algeria. The Algerian war for independence had begun. The fruitless struggle that followed brought France to the edge of chaos and helped to destroy the Fourth Republic. The search for a means to end the seven-year war has been the greatest challenge facing President de Gaulle.

To the Music Editor: I am in hearty agreement with the anti-subsidy sentiments expressed by Thomas T. Tamlyn in his recent letter. I am very fond of music. I listen to it; I sing in a choir; I go to the Philharmonic; I try with enthusiasm to play the tenor sax. But Mr. Tamlyn is entirely right; music is entertainment and should pay for itself -- that includes the Met and the Philharmonic.

The appointment of Anson Burlingame as director of Columbia University's Office of Projects and Grants was announced yesterday. Mr. Burlingame had been regional director of the Singer Sewing Machine Company's operations in Europe.

In this age of "people's capitalism,'' courses on basic investments are a dime a dozen. BORGHILD DAHL, who has written many an earnest and informative novel for teenagers, has once again turned to her favorite topic, a Norwegian-American family in Minnesota, at the turn of the century.

IT is easier to review a bad book than a good one, but the latter is more agreeable to read. DURING the last thirty years, relations between the United States and Latin America have gone full circle. In the early Nineteen Thirties they had reached an unprecedented low in terms of friendship, mutual confidence and cooperation between the two parts of the hemisphere.

KEY WEST, Fla. -- An air of optimism is mingling with the offshore breezes here these days. Although Key West's economy has suffered somewhat from the loss of tourist traffic between the United States and Cuba, several projects are creating a bright prospect for the future.

Public officials, athletes and sports executives joined yesterday in breaking ground for the $18,000,000 Municipal Stadium in Flushing Meadow Park, Queens. Three thousand spectators witnessed the exercises, which were held opposite the site of the 1964-1965 New York World's Fair.

HOWARD HANSON celebrated his sixty-fifth birthday yesterday. Those who enjoy his association in the daily doings of the Eastman School did not look upon this as a milestone indicating a forthcoming twilight of comparative inactivity. Quite to the contrary, the season now under way will be the busiest in his life.
Subscribers for the Bagby Music Lovers Foundation's annual night at the opera have been announced. The event will take place at the Nov. 9 performance of "La Boheme" at the Metropolitan Opera House.

I was surprised to find that in your picture article on the New York Children's Zoo ("Noah's Ark for City Kids," Oct. 8), you did not give the name of the architect, Edward Coe Embury. Since the buildings are so imaginative and original, it seems to me that this omission is equivalent to mentioning the pictures in an art exhibit and not giving the name of the artist.

FOREIGN photographers won five of the ten top awards in Popular Photography's $25,000 International Picture Contest. The prizes were in United States Savings bonds. First and fifth prizes in the black-and-white division went to Leif Eliasson and Sven Lundstrom, respectively, both of Karlstad, Sweden.

SINCE Billie Holiday died somewhat more than two years ago the term "jazz singer" has been badly out of focus. Miss Holiday had been the first singer who could be identified as a "jazz singer" as distinct from a "blues singer," which had been the form of vocalizing identified with jazz until her appearance.
The lay trustees of Iona College have arranged a dinner dance for Dec. 12 at the Astor to raise funds for the college's development program.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 28 -- Jim Traficant's two touchdown runs and a great defense by Pitt upset Navy today, 28 -- 14. The result ended the Panthers' four-game losing streak and the midshipmen's four-game winning skein.

THIS week Rome -- and the Roman Catholic Chuch everywhere -- will observe a sort of triple anniversary for Pope John XXIII. He was elected to the papacy on Oct. 28, 1958; his coronation followed on Nov. 4; his seventy-seventh birthday came on Nov. 25. Now, for his third anniversary as Supreme Pontiff and for his eightieth birthday, next Saturday has been designated a day of tribute and jubilation.

Travis, Alamo commander, young master of rhetoric; James Bowie, adventurer extraordinary; Davy Crockett, with coonskin cap and long rifle; Jim Bonham, who went back to the Alamo in defiance of good sense; James Fannin, reluctant leader and tragic villain; and Sam Houston.

A difference in rocket power is the main reason the Soviet Union has been first and the U.S. second in spectacular space feats. Russia's biggest known rocket has an estimated thrust of 800,000 pounds and has hurled a five-ton payload into orbit. The biggest operational U.S. rocket is the 365,000-pound-thrust Atlas, and the heaviest American payload ever fired into orbit was one and a half tons.

LEOPOLDVILLE, The Congo, Oct. 29 -- Two of the best-known mercenaries in the Congo attempted to escape from a United Nations prison camp here last night.

President Kennedy's order to his Cabinet for a "most careful and frugal policy" of Government spending is a stern reminder of the high cost of cold war and the diversity of the defenses we must erect to meet it. The Federal budget deficit of nearly $7 billion for the fiscal year ending June 30 obviously calls for maximum effort to squeeze waste out of every part of the Federal establishment.
The nation's electric power industry -- both public and investor-owned -- is expected to increase its generating capability by 13,000,000 kilowatts this year, to 187,900,000 k.w.

DETROIT, Oct. 29 (UPI) -- The Montreal Canadiens scored four goals in seven minutes during the second period tonight and went on to beat the Detroit Red Wings, 6 -- 3. The Canadiens remained undefeated in seven National Hockey League games.
State Senator Joseph Zaretzki, the Democratic minority leader, suggested a Federal subsidy for railroads yesterday.

When Yehudi Menuhin is at the top of his form, he need recognize few peers among living violinists. That was the way he played most of his recital at Hunter College on Saturday night, to the vociferous delight of a capacity audience.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Oct. 29 -- Border bandits are still operating as they have for centuries in the "Balkans of Asia."

DETROIT, Oct. 29 (AP) -- The Chrysler Corporation and the United Automobile Workers reached a local-level working agreement today covering a major assembly plant at Newark, Del. But eleven such agreements are yet to be attained before a new national contract is completed.
The grim remains of a desperate fight for life 2,000 years ago have been found on an Alaskan beach.
BERLIN, Oct. 29 -- The Russians moved for the first time today against the increase in United States patrols on the autobahn link between West Berlin and West Germany.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Oct. 29 -- A United States Army military adviser on a training patrol with a Vietnamese ranger platoon was shot in the leg by a Vietnamese Communist sniper today.

SATURDAY night's performance of "Lohengrin" at the Metropolitan Opera presented virtually a new line-up. Of the six leading roles, three were taken by singers making their Metropolitan debuts. And in two others, Jerome Hines was heard as King Henry and Irene Dalis as Ortrud, both for the first time in their Metropolitan careers.
In preponderantly Democratic Manhattan, the Democrats have long been confident of winning a majority of the borough's six City Council seats.

When the United States Tax Commissioner, Mortimer M. Caplin, indicated last week that there would be a tightening of the rules on tax deductions for travel and entertainment expenses, with or without new legislation, he confirmed what many tax observers had suspected.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 29 -- United States delegates held a long conference today on tactics for a sharp struggle on the question of a nuclear test ban, expected tomorrow in the General Assembly's Political Committee.

LAST night's production of "The Power and the Glory," starring Sir Laurence Olivier, was an absorbing paradox such as might occur only in television: At one and the same time it was both a proverbial milestone and a major disappointment.

Western Europe is enjoying the highest standard of living it has ever known, according to a study issued today by the Twentieth Century Fund, a privately endowed foundation for scientific research and public information.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 29 -- More than 6,000,000 poplar trees have been planted in Turkey since 1955, under a ten-year governmental program. Indications are that it may be expanded to benefit countries throughout the Near East.

The Right Rev. Horace B. Donegan, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of New York, complained yesterday of "inflammatory" writings about "the alleged Leftwing tendencies of all the non-Roman clergy in this country."
BUFFALO, Oct. 29 (AP) -- George Blanda threw four touchdown passes today in leading the Houston Oilers to a 28-16 victory over the Buffalo Bills in an American Football League game.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 29 -- "The war in Algeria will end some time between Oct. 31 this year and Oct. 31, 1962." This flat prediction was made to me some months ago by one of France's highest ranking generals, a man renowned in an army of divided loyalties for his allegiance to President de Gaulle.

TRENTON, Oct. 29 -- Paul Goldsmith of St. Clair Shores, Mich., Bill Randall of North Reading, Mass., and Hank Rogers of Point Pleasant, N.J., won in an auto racing tripleheader on the Trenton International Speedway today.

In the midst of its justified campaign against the Castro regime's total suppression of freedom of the press in Cuba, the Inter-American Press Association has just seen fit to award its Hero of the Free Press Medal to Jose I. Rivero, publisher of the Diario de la Marina, one of Havana's former newspapers.
Intensive negotiations last night and early this morning narrowed the gap between management and labor in the milk strike but failed to produce a settlement.
SEOUL, Korea, Monday, Oct. 30 (AP) -- The Revolutionary Court of the South Korean junta sentenced to fifteen years in prison today a leading Socialist on charges that he helped the Communist cause.
Proposed Amendment No. 1 to the New York State Constitution on the reorganization of the courts should be carried by an overwhelming majority at the polls next week.

The Trans-Atlantic Passenger Steamship Conference reported yesterday a decrease of 65,800 passengers in the first three quarters, a drop of 9.3 per cent in comparison with the similar period a year ago.
Representative Paul A. Fino charged yesterday that the Wagner administration planned "wholesale evictions of thousands of tenants" after the Nov. 7 election.
Programs of grants-in-aid have been announced by the Ford Foundation for musicians in three categories: choral directors, concert soloists and opera singers.
The Navy let a contract last week for the development of the largest American hydrofoil ship planned to date -- a 300-ton, 200-foot craft for possible use in antisubmarine warfare.
Aside from its regular virtue the "Aida" given by the New York City Opera Saturday night at the City Center was notable for the debut with the company of Mari Ferriero, the title role.
ALBANY, Oct. 29 -- The new Tri-State Transportation Committee reported today that it was studying automatic ticket-issuing methods for mass transit and possible consolidation of commuter stations.
