The Limeliters, a trio that sells cigarettes on television and records to its fans, gave a concert Saturday night.
The J.C. Penney Company and Alden's, Inc., said today the companies had failed to agree on terms of a proposed merger and that present discussions were called off.
Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa blamed Mayor Wagner yesterday for the high price of milk in New York City.

CONSIDERING the popularity of the impressionist school, which still more than holds its own with collectors, it is strange that Alfred Sisley (1839-99), who represents impressionism in its purest state, should not have had an exhibition in this country since 1921.

High school physics teachers will have an opportunity to receive special recognition for mastery of their subjects. The project, initiated experimentally by the American Association of Physics Teachers, will be supported by a three-year grant of $67,000 from the Carnegie Corporation of New York, an educational foundation.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The official midyear review of the Federal budget estimated today a $6,900,000,000 deficit for the current fiscal year, which ends next June 30.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 29 (UPI) -- The Cleveland Browns did all their scoring in the first half today and defeated the St. Louis Cardinals, 21 -- 10, in a National Football League game.

Spot pound sterling continued to show a firm undertone, though in mid-week it dipped on rumors of a possible cut in the bank rate. Business turnover was at a brisk pace. Canadian dollar fluctuated narrowly on moderate dealings.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The talk of Capitol Hill is a Cinderella story about the pretty young receptionist who had dinner with the President at the invitation of a handsome movie star.

In his letter published Oct. 25 endorsing proposed Amendment 6 to the State Constitution, Dr. Carroll Newsom urges that citizens study the provisions of the amendment with great care. We agree with this admonition, for we believe that such a study will lead to the contrary conclusion that the measure does indeed imperil the separation of church and state and should be defeated.

NEWARK, Oct. 29 -- The race for Governor of New Jersey looked at the start like a romp for James P. Mitchell, the Republican. However, a strong closing drive by Richard J. Hughes, the Democrat, is making a close thing of it.
WOMEN to fill overseas secretarial positions that pay $4,495, plus housing and other benefits, are being recruited by the International Cooperation Administration.

THERE was a distinct difference to the normal hum of shoppers at Bonwit Teller Friday morning. The unusually low murmur came from a crowd of men, breaking a sixty-six-year-old tradition with the store, for Bonwit's has opened a department devoted to men's furnishings.

Complaints that hearing-aid salesmen advertise falsely, use "scarce" tactics, make exaggerated claims and sell hearing devices to persons whose hearing is normal will be investigated by Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz.
MIAMI BEACH, Oct. 29 -- Efforts to achieve a national market for home loans, an elusive goal sought by many segments of the financial community, were discussed today by the nation's mortgage bankers.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 29 (AP) -- The Chicago Bears capitalized on a pass interference today for a fourth-period touchdown that defeated the Baltimore Colts, 21 -- 20. It was the Bears' fourth straight National Football League victory.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 29 (UPI) -- The Green Bay Packers, paced by the running of Paul Hornung and the passing of Bart Starr, struck for three touchdowns in the first half today and held on for a 28 -- 10 victory over the Minnesota Vikings.

ATHENS, Monday, Oct. 30 -- The National Radical Union party of Constantine Caramanlis, 54-year-old pro-Western former Premier, won what seemed on the count early today to be a landslide victory in yesterday's Greek general elections.

Iowa, picked in the pre-season polls as the best college football team in the country, was beaten by Purdue, 9 -- 0, Saturday, and the race for the national championship narrows to Michigan State, Mississippi, Texas, Alabama and Ohio State.
ARLENE SAUNDERS is a soprano who can sing beautifully, act effectively and illuminate any operatic stage fortunate enough to be raced by her talents.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (UPI) -- The Southern Pacific Railroad Company and the Order of Railroad Telegraphers settled tonight a dispute that had threatened to erupt into a strike tomorrow morning.

IN its current United States tour -- its third since 1955 -- the Berlin Philharmonic is not relying on soloists. But for two of its New York programs it decided to have as guest artists an American soprano and an Israeli pianist.
The Rev. John J. Barry, a new member of the clergy staff at St. Patrick's Cathedral, preached his first sermon there at the 10 A.M. solemn mass yesterday.
LONDON, Oct. 29 -- Quotations of industrial shares sagged in the stock market last week while British Government securities were showing strength.

THE clothes pictured here can never be bought in any store. From the sales point of view they are among the outstanding failures of some of America's best known designers. Because these clothes, all from the fall collections, were not ordered by enough stores around the country, they were never manufactured.
NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 29 -- Pro-Government Naga leaders made it clear tonight that they felt New Delhi was reneging on its agreement to grant them statehood.
MOSCOW, Oct. 29 -- The Soviet Union announced today completion of its series of Pacific rocket tests with a shot of, 7,500 miles.

The election of Waldemar A. Nielsen as president of the African-American Institute was announced yesterday. He was formerly associate director of the international affairs program of the Ford Foundation.
Negro parents have to pay what they call "the color tax" to provide career opportunities for children with ambition and initiative, a Negro mother said yesterday.
Kyle Rote got four passes, a touchdown, a champion Hereford steer, two automobiles and two fur coats for his wife yesterday.

PARIS, Oct. 29 -- "The experience of the recent past has been encouraging in demonstrating the extent -- unthinkable between the two world wars -- to which governments are now prepared to shape their economic policies in the light of the needs of their neighbors."
Republicans opened the final phase of their drive to capture City Hall yesterday with a two-hour television rally.
Two candidates with Southern accents are running for Borough President of Manhattan. Each formerly taught school, and each has a son.

The Department of Commerce has invited six advertising agencies and six public relations organizations to make formal presentations for selection by the new United States Travel Service.

The Russian soprano Galina Vishnevskaya will make her American operatic debut during the third week of the Metropolitan Opera Company's current season. Next Monday, Mme. Vishnevskaya will sing the title role in the season's first "Aida."
Sal Durante made another catch yesterday. This time it was a trim brunette with sparkling eyes.
Governor Rockefeller ordered yesterday a temporary freeze on the granting of rent increases under the equalization provision of the 1961 Residential Rent Control Law.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The Federal Trade Commission has ruled tentatively that R.H. Macy Co. was not guilty of an unfair trade practice when it solicited contri butions from its suppliers to help stage its centennial celebration in 1958.
In the region where the Americas and Eurasia almost touch, a "guest book" has been found whose record seems to extend some 6,000 years into the past.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Oct. 29 -- The heads of the Ecumenical Council of the Protestant Churches of Hungary explained yesterday their attitude to the Communist regime.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Cold Climate, owned by Mrs. J. Deane Rucker of Grosse Pointe, Mich., won the conformation hunter championship of the Washington International Horse Show tonight.
Eighty-two voluntary nonprofit hospitals are' members of the United Hospital Fund. All five boroughs are served by these hospitals, which constitute the largest voluntary hospital systemin the world.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (UPI) -- Sonny Jurgensen's 41-yard touchdown pass to Tommy McDonald in the last sixteen seconds enabled the Philadelphia Eagles to beat the Washington Redskins, 27 -- 24 today.

Vice President Johnson said here last night that the United States would not be "provocative" or "aggressive" but was prepared to "stand on our rights to preserve our integrity, decency and way of life."

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 29 (UPI) -- The New York Titans defeated the Oakland Raiders, 14 -- 6, in an American Football League game today that was marked by a number of windblown kicks. Bill Mathis scored both of the Titan touchdowns.

THE gazettes of 1883 described the first National Horse Show as being crowded to capacity "with ladies and gentlemen representing the wealth, culture and refinement of the city." Among them was Lily Langtry, the Jersey Lily, who may not have qualified on every count.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 29 (UPI) -- Jon Arnett thrilled a crowd of 49,123 today with a 105-yard touchdown run, but the passing of Jim Ninowski enabled the Detroit Lions to score a 28-10 victory over the Los Angeles Rams in a National Football League game.
STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 29 -- Two hundred teen-agers toned up their sleeves here today and started a clean-up of neglected city cemeteries.

MANY mothers are concerned that children receive more candy than is good for them on Halloween. Children will appreciate and enjoy variety in their "loot" in the shape of a big red apple or individually wrapped cookies that they may be glad to nibble along the way between later calls.

BIG CEDAR, Okla., Oct. 29 -- President Kennedy told the people of two states today of his determination to keep the nation free while continuing its progress. He dramatized that progress by attending a ceremony opening the Ouachita National Forest Road.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Several thousand women in twenty-five cities across the country will raise a concerted "hue and cry for peace" Wednesday.
ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 29 -- Dozens of members of the National Audubon Society today saw the first recorded New Jersey appearance of fulvous tree ducks.
"GOING TO AMERICA," a nostalgic, sad-happy journey in Yiddish to the long-gone world of Sholem Aleichem, opened Saturday night at the Educational Alliance Playhouse.
Gump Worsley's goal-tending helped put the New York Rangers back on the winning track last night at Madison Square Garden.

After a military interregnum Turkey has taken the essential big step toward re-establishing democratic rule by successfully holding new elections. The failure of any one party to obtain a clear majority, however, clouds the future.

Howard K. Smith's news analysis report from Washington, usually carried on Sundays at 8:15 P.M. by the Columbia Broadcasting System radio network, did not appear last night for the second consecutive week. MIAMI, Oct. 29 (UPI) -- Hurricane Hattie, with 125-mile-an-hour winds, slowed up in its advance on Cuba tonight but continued to menace a wide area in the Caribbean.
WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 29 -- At 2:15 o'clock this afternoon a British Redcoat fired the musket shot that was heard around West Harrison.
The running of the Dallas Cowboys helped make the passing attack by Eddie LeBaron effective yesterday at Yankee Stadium, according to the little quarterback.
Vito P. Battista, United Taxpayers party candidate for Mayor, said yesterday that Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz's charge that small-home owners were paying exorbitant taxes came too late.

Aided by a three-minute allowance, Lou Schiavo of Flushing, Queens, a 19-year-old Queens College sophomore representing the New York Pioneer Club, won the six-mile handicap cross-country run at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx yesterday.
An axiom of American politics -- that a politician would rather lose an election than lose control of his party organization -- is being tested in the city campaign this year.
A new paint component made from linseed oil and water may help stabilize sagging demand for flax from the Upper Midwest, according to a Cargill, Inc., sales executive.
The self-styled Cuban Provisional Government in Exile called yesterday for a "holy war" against the regime of Fidel Castro.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Sixteen years ago Steuart Lansing Pittnam, a young Marine lieutenant, commanded a Chinese guerrilla junk in a bizarre postscript to the era of wooden ships and iron men.

The 200-mile-wide fall-out cloud from the Soviet Union's latest nuclear explosions continued generally eastward across the United States yesterday. It covered the northern part of New York State, and parts of New Hampshire, Vermont and Maine and extended into the Atlantic.
CASTINE, Me., Oct. 29 -- Lieut. Melville W. Ackerman, a nuclear physicist, has joined the faculty of the Maine Maritime Academy here, the academy announced today.

Title to five acres of vacant land at Bruckner Boulevard and Leland Avenue, the Bronx, has been taken by Rose Associates, builders, who will construct two buildings with 480 rental apartments for middle-income tenants. Construction will be started in January.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 29 -- The United States will resist a new Soviet move to transfer China's United Nations seat from the Nationalist to the Communist Government, United States informants said today.

HE was nearly 40 now, a professional encyclopedist, the successful lover of numerous women. Sitting in his bachelor apartment in New York, brooding over memories that he was putting down on paper in fits and starts, he realized that all his life he had been an observer rather than a participator, the confidant of such a one as listens but is not a friend (the listener, he was certain, is never a friend), a rememberer.

I agree with Carol Fox' letter published Oct. 18 that parades in the center of New York are not only a nuisance but a great loss to business. But due to the total disregard of "no parking" laws, except when there is a parade, maybe we should have one every day in a different area of New York.

THE small size and dark brownish-green skin of the Seckel pears that are now so abundantly piled on greengrocers' counters may discourage shoppers from buying them. But as with so many fruits, bright color and bigness are not infallible indications of delectability.
Mayor Wagner and former Senator Herbert H. Lehman stumped through New Deal strongholds in Brooklyn yesterday to solidify the Mayor's following in these areas.

A committee of prominent American poets and writers, including e e cummings, Arthur Miller and Marianne Moore, has called for the preservation of the historic Walt Whitman building on Cranberry Street in Brooklyn Heights.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The Kennedy Administration has begun to study proposals for broadening the current $306,000,000 Federal civil defense program. The first round of discussion of next year's civil defense budget has begun at the Pentagon.

The admission of Outer Mongolia and Mauritania more than doubles the original membership of the United Nations. It also concentrates a vivid spotlight on some of the U.N.'s attributes and problems.

GENEVA, Oct. 29 -- Investors and operators shed some of their reserve to give volume a strong lift on the Swiss markets for most of last week. Prices often shot up only to be cut back by profit taking.
Morris B. Abram, former counsel for the Peace Corps, said yesterday that the nation's high school and college youths tended to be "confirmed conformists and conservatives."
MOSCOW, Oct. 29 -- Premier Khrushchev unveiled today Moscow's first monument to Karl Marx.
With the exception of one game, two rounds were completed yesterday in the women's world championship chess tournament at Vrnjacka Banja, according to a report from Yugoslavia.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The Kennedy Administration has a new shelter policy. But the impact of it has yet to get to the people, even in the sensitive areas of Washington's burgeoning suburbs.
VALLAURIS, France, Oct. 29 -- Scorning a Riviera prefect's ban on bullfighting, a Spanish matador, Luis Miguel Dominguin, killed a bull here today in honor of Pablo Picasso, the artist.
The Buffalo Philharmonic came to New York on Saturday night for the first time.

The world record for best-in-show victories by a Skye terrier grew longer yesterday at the Kingsbridge Armory in the Bronx. Ch. Evening Star de Luchar, the French-bred dog that holds the mark, gained another top award in the fortieth event of the Bronx County Kennel Club.
CHICAGO, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Grain futures prices held to a generally slow downward trend last week on the Board of Trade.

The Giants ran out of miracles yesterday. After scrapping, scraping and scrambling to five straight National Football League victories, the New Yorkers came a 17-16 cropper at the hands of the Dallas Cowboys.

The closing of the Lenin-Stalin Mausoleum in Moscow yesterday was certainly well timed. These past two weeks, Premier Khrushchev and his followers have been conducting a verbal war against the memory of the dead Stalin and against the reputations of Khrushchev's defeated rivals, all of whom are being stigmatized as Stalinists.

Henry Baker and associates have sold the four-story building on lot 20 by 64 feet at 174 Lexington Avenue, adjoining the southwest corner of Thirty-first Street. The property was altered recently. It is assessed at $50,000 and was bought by an investing client of Morris Hutter.

The American Civil Liberties Union described yesterday as "a clear infringement of free speech and due process of law" the State Department's revocation Oct. 4 of the visa of Michael Struelens, director of the information office here for the secessionist Katanga government in the Congo.
The trend of cotton futures prices last week was one of a slight improvement in nearer deliveries and a softening in the more distant months.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- A team of Cabinet members and Presidential advisers left today for Japan on a long-range experiment designed to head off economic rivalry and trouble in the Pacific.

JERSEY CITY, Oct. 30 -- Thousands of commuters to Manhattan were delayed up to forty-five minutes during the morning rush hour today because of the new 30-cent fare on the Hudson tubes. The new fare, up 5 cents, went into effect this morning.
Michigan State was ranked the nation's No. 1 college football team yesterday by The Associated Press for the third straight week.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Oct. 30 -- Premier Cyrille Adoula said tonight that a "police action" of regular central government soldiers was being taken "to liquidate the Katanga secession."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Treasury bill rates declined again today on the sale of regular weekly issues. The ninety-one day bills sold at discount rates averaging 2.280 per cent, compared with 2.325 per cent on last Monday's sale.

COLUMBIA, Mo., Oct. 30 (AP) -- Coach Dan Devine of Missouri ruled today that football workouts would be held in secret.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 30 -- The General Assembly acted today to insure that the 16,000 United Nations troops and aircraft would remain in the Congo until the end of the year.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Oct. 30 (AP) -- Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower, campaigning hard for a Republican Congressional candidate, attacked tonight "indiscriminate federal handouts" and "spendthrift programs."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- A labor agreement guaranteeing a worker his job or equivalent wages during his lifetime has been negotiated by the Southern Pacific Railroad and the Order of Railroad Telegraphers.

MOSCOW, Oct. 30 -- The Soviet Union asked Finland today to consult on measures for insuring defense of the frontiers of the two countries against what the Russians described as the threat of a military attack by West Germany and its allies.
The United States Rubber Company reported yesterday that sales and earnings continued to drop from the 1960 levels in the third quarter of this year.

An era of fantastic lies and falsification in Soviet history finally received its proper evaluation yesterday when the Soviet Communist Party Congress voted to oust Stalin's body from the huge mausoleum that stands on Red Square beneath the towers of the Kremlin.

A great deal of interest has been generated by the mayoralty election, but, unfortunately, general indifference seems to envelop other vital matters on the ballot. I believe that the position taken by some of the Democratic legislators on some of the more controversial amendments may help crystallize the views of the electorate.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- The United States protested in Moscow again today against attempts by the Soviet Union to delegate to East Germany the responsibility for maintaining the Western right of access to East Berlin.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 30 -- Dick Powell, president of one of the major television companies in Hollywood, predicted today that one-hour shows would be much scarcer next year.
AT the fifth international tournament of the Far Eastern Bridge Association, to be played at Bangkok next month, the bidding will be done in writing instead of orally.
NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 30 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru was reported tonight to have agreed to Naga demands for more powers in their new state in northeastern India.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30 -- The two men who served as director of the budget under President Eisenhower listened quietly today as their successor, David E. Bell, urged more sophisticated press coverage of the Federal budget.

Events today: "La Fanciulla de1 West," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P.M.; "The Crucible," presented by New York City Opera Company, City Center, 8:15; National Orchestral Asociation, John Barnett, conductor, Irene Jordan, soprano, Carnegie Hall, 8:30.
The Massachusetts Investors Trust reported yesterday new highs in net assets and share value as of Sept. 30.

Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa, the Citizens party candidate for Mayor, called upon Governor Rockefeller yesterday to make public a report by the State Investigation Commission on Mayor Wagner's relations with persons or concerns doing business with the city.

Commonwealth Edison Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday a gain of 4.9 per cent in kilowatt hour sales of electricity for the first nine months of 1961. Sales to residential customers rose by 7.6 per cent; to small commercial-industrial users by 3.8 per cent and to large commercial industrial customers by 3.1 per cent.

TOKYO, Oct. 30 -- United States radio experts and coding specialists are arriving in the resort of Hakone, near the foot of Mount Fuji, to prepare the communications facilities that will keep Secretary of State Rusk in touch with Washington while he is attending the Cabinet-level economic meeting between the United States and Japan.
ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 30 -- A form of licensing bird watchers, naturalists, picnickers and other users of National Wildlife Refuges, was proposed here today to the National Audubon Society.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 30 -- Foreign Minister Heinrich von Brentano announced today that he had offered his resignation. He said he would not serve in a new government.
BERLIN, Oct. 30 (AP) -- West Berlin's new opera house had an almost all-United States "Aida" tonight. Five of the leading roles were sung by Americans.

Columbia University has agreed to let Benjamin J. Davis, secretary of the Communist party of the United States, take part in a discussion of academic freedom to be held at the university's McMillin Theatre, Broadway and 116th Street, on Thursday.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Oct. 30 -- Nelson G. Gross, a Republican candidate for the Assembly, won a court fight today over his right to stay on the ballot despite protests by Democrats that he live at 130 East Sixtieth Street, New York. Mr. Gross owns a home at 820 Clauss Lane, River Vale.
CHICAGO, Oct. 30 (UPI) -- The American Medical Association came to the defense of milk today.

A man who spent more than fifty days in jail in the spring was cleared of assault and robbery charges yesterday in Queens County Court after it had been established that his arrest had been a mistake.
Army expects to be without the services of Dick Eckert, its top quarterback and passer, for the Detroit game on Saturday.
The planned merger of Montgomery Ward Co. and Interstate Department Stores. Inc., heralded as a major step in the movement of giant retailing chains into discount operations, has been called off.
LAUREL, Md., Oct. 30 (UPI) -- President Eamon de Valera of Ireland accepted an invitation today to race Sail Cheoil in the $100,000 Washington, D.C. International at the Laurel race track on Nov. 11.
A PRE-SEASON check of deer in the Catskills over the week-end indicated that hunters would have a fighting chance of seeing game this season.

The Times announces today a six-day weekday morning edition to be printed in Los Angeles, beginning about a year from now. The stadium will serve as the home of the New York Mets, the latest representative of our village in major league ball and also the team that will bring back the National League.
One man was killed and two others were injured yesterday morning when a 5,000-pound steel beam fell seventeen stories from a building under construction and crashed into West Fifty-fourth Street.
In a quiet session that saw most changes in minor fractions, prices on the New York Stock Exchange rose slightly yesterday.

Virginia Dare Stores Corporation has filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission proposing a public offering of 154,000 shares of a common stock. Of that total, 100,000 shares would be offered by the company and 54,000 shares by two selling stockholders.

DETROIT, Oct. 30 -- The United Automobile Workers made a new proposal to the Chrysler Corporation tonight aimed at providing the basis for a new general contract.

American designers are now showing their spring collections to stores, preceding the openings in Paris and Italy. Spring fashions are not shown in Europe Until January and February. The clothes described below will be in the stores by the first of the year.

State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz was accused by the city's Building Department yesterday of hampering its prosecution of a slum landlord.

The bond market behaved yesterday much the same as it did during most of last week. Trading activity was light, with prices mostly firm. The price changes that occurred were sore slight as to be devoid of real significance.

Yesterday, running as a pro in a bullring in San Sebastian, Spain, the 30-year-old Englishman received (he says) $800 in cash on the line.

Advertising agencies have moved increasingly into the limelight in recent years, but in at least one important respect they have rigidly maintained their privacy.
