Wayne County, Mich., borrowed $16,815,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance sewage disposal.
In spite of the date and the orange and black bunting, that was not a Halloween party at Madison Square Garden last night -- it was the opening of the National Horse Show.

ALGIERS, Oct. 31 -- Tension mounted tonight as troops moved into the city and joined the riot police in preparing to cordon off the Casbah and other Moslem quarters to isolate nationalist demonstrations scheduled for tomorrow, the seventh anniversary of the Algerian uprising.
An offering of 200,000 shares of Idaho Power Company common stock, at $37.25 a share, will be made today by Blyth Co., Inc., Lazard Freres Co., and associates.
BONHAM, Tex., Oct. 31 (AP) -- House Speaker Sam Rayburn came home by ambulance today.
The committee of securities of the American Stock Exchange announced yesterday it had suspended dealings in the $1 par common stock of the Buckeye Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- The radioactive cloud from the Soviet Union's biggest nuclear explosion was moving southeastward today over Central Siberia at the comparatively slow speed of fifty miles an hour.
LONDON, Oct. 31 -- The general tone of the stock market here was cheerful today, although most net rises were modest.

Prices of United States Government securities declined small fractions yesterday as the bond market waited for announcement of the Treasury's decision on refunding $6,963,000,000 of 2 1/2 per cent bonds maturing this month.
A total of 953 persons were injured in the city in automobile accidents last week, the Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday, 214 fewer than in the life period of 1960.
BERLIN, Oct. 31 -- City officials disclosed today that about 1,700 West Berliners had left their city each week since the Communists sealed the border between West and East Berlin eleven weeks ago.
CHICAGO, Oct. 31 (UPI) -- The New York Rangers scored three goals in the third period tonight and beat the Chicago Black Hawks, 4 -- 2, in a National Hockey League game.

HOUSTON, Tex., Oct. 31 (UPI) -- The Independent Petroleum Association of America today urged the United States Government to take steps to prevent the Soviet Union from taking over the world oil market to advance "the Soviet plan for world domination.''

Jerry Gross, a junior quarterback for the University of Detroit, figured in only twenty plays against Dayton last week and did enough to hold his spot as the total-offense leader among major college football players.
An interagency Government committee has all but agreed to recommend development of a new series of powerful hybrid rockets embodying varying numbers of "building block" units.

The rumored transfer of the sprawling Brooklyn Army Terminal, a major Defense Department ocean-shipping center, would be against the best interests of the country and the Port of New York, a leading maritime industry spokesman said here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Political and military pressures on the Administration to resume atmospheric nuclear tests mounted today.

Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa aimed a bitter personal attack at the Mayor yesterday and charged that Mr. Wagner was controlled by "liberals" and pressure groups. Mr. Gerosa, who is the Citizens party candidate for Mayor, made appearances during the day before a Kiwanis Club group and a gath ering at Marymount College.

MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 31 (AP) -- Radio reports received here today said that Belize, capital of British Honduras, had been battered by a hurricane that sent the Caribbean Sea rampaging into the Central American city.
The appointment of John D. Healy as executive director of the International Rescue Committee was announced yesterday by William vanden Heuvel, its president.

Maurice Meyer, former president of Meyer Brothers, operator of a department store in Paterson, N.J., died Sunday in a White Plains (N.Y.) hospital after a short illness: He was 84 years old and lived at the Sheraton-East Hotel.

MOSCOW, Oct. 31 -- The twenty-second congress of the Soviet Communist party ended today with Premier Khrushchev triumphant in matters of domestic policy. But it is believed that he suffered a loss of stature within the Communist bloc by deepening his ideological dispute with Peiping.

Leontyne Price, singing the role of Minnie in last night's performance of "La Fanciulla del West" at the Metropolitan Opera, had trouble with more than just Sheriff Jack Rance in the second act. Her voice gave out.

City Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa said yesterday that the recent appointment of John F. Hennessy, an electrical engineer, to the new Board of Education raised a question of "a possible conflict of interest."
The more notable changes in generally dull trading on the New York commodity exchanges yesterday were registered by rubber and cocoa, which rose, and by cottonseed oil, which declined.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Former President and Mrs. Harry S. Truman arrived today for a three-day round of events that will include dinner and an overnight stay at their old address, 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue.

NEWTOWN, Pa., Oct. 31 -- The George School has an excellent physical education program. It is highlighted by a nine-sport set-up that puts up twenty-four interscholastic teams every year. Formal physical fitness training, however, remains a major item at the Bucks County school.
Yesterday we considered the best qualified judicial candidates to be voted on in Manhattan and the Bronx. Today we cover those in Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island.
SEOUL, Korea, Oct. 31 -- The South Korean revolutionary court upheld today the death sentences on three executives of the Leftist newspaper Minjok Ilbo.

Persons who fear the lovely lines of the George Washington Bridge will be marred by the second deck that soon will span it may be a little relieved to know that Othmar Herman Ammann, one of this century's master builders of bridges, planned it precisely to carry such a deck. Mr. Ammann at 82 is consulting engineer for the improvement of the structure he completed thirty years ago.
BERLIN, Oct. 31 (UPI) -- The East German police opened fire twice tonight on refugees seeking to flee across the tense city border to West Berlin.

WEMBLEY, England, Oct. 31 (UPI) -- John Caldwell of Belfast retained his European bantamweight championship and the British version of the world bantamweight title tonight when he beat Alphonse Halimi of France on points in their fifteen-round bout.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Nov. 1 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk said here today that a "new and bright chapter" was starting in the partnership between Japan and the United States.

When football coaches get together and swap yarns about recruiting, the conversation usually centers on "the big ones that got away" -- most frequently as the result of alleged piracy by rival institutions.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- The National Association of Housing and Redevelopment Officials adopted a resolution today calling for equal opportunity in housing.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 31 (UPI) -- An official of the Carnegie Institute declined comment today on the refusal of a sculptor to accept a $1,000 prize for his entry in the institute's international Exhibition of Contemporary Painting an Sculpture.
Katherine Geddes Benedict, who died Sunday at the age of 77, left the income from two-fifths of her estate, estimated at $50,000,000, to her 20-year-old granddaughter, Mrs. Andre Porumbeanu.
THE Composers Group of New York City gave a Carnegie Recital Hall program of first performances last night. The evening included a semi-staged version of a short opera by John D. Robb.
The city's hospitals were ordered last evening not to use blood from commercial blood banks, following charges that outdated and useless blood and plasma had been sold here.
CHICAGO, Oct. 31 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
CHICAGO, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Speculators threw some support into the grain futures market today and steadied it somewhat after the sharp general decline of the preceding session.
Najeeg E. Halaby, Federal Aviation Administrator, has estimated that 28,000 persons would be needed to operate the proposed Federal Aviation Service.
PLAINFIELD, N.J., Oct. 31 -- The fifty-year-old plant of Mack Trucks, Inc., closed down today. The company is relocating in a new multi-million-dollar one-story plant in Hagerstown, Md.

Queens, the city's second most populous borough and its most volatile politically, is staging a replay of the three-cornered special Borough Presidential election that John T. Clancy, a Democrat, won two years ago.

New York's top Republicans said yesterday that President Kennedy was coming to the city tomorrow "to give a shot in the arm to the sagging Wagner campaign." That view of the Presidential visit in Mayor Wagner's behalf was expressed by Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz, the Republican candidate for Mayor, while Governor Rockefeller made a similar comment.

The landslide victory for Constantine Caramanlis' National Radical Union (ERE) in Greece's general election was a gratifying one for the West. It must also be gratifying for the Greek electorate, who produced the largest postwar popular vote in their country.

LONDON, Oct. 31 (Reuters) -- Waves of angry protest and alarm swept across the non-Communist world today in the wake of the biggest man-made explosion in history, set off yesterday by the Soviet Union.
WARSAW, Oct. 31 -- The break-up of a smuggling ring here has resulted in the arrest of several persons well known in Government and Communist party circles.

While most of the 1,000 complaints received daily by the city Health Department concern building violations or uncollected garbage, a complaint was made on West Twenty-second Street yesterday about a loquacious rooster.
Public offerings of new bonds in October were below the 1960 level, while offerings of new stock were higher.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 31 -- A reliable source said tonight that the United States was ready to propose the election of U Thant of Burma as Acting Secretary General, leaving to him the decision on how many top assistants he would have.
The student government of Barnard College has condemned Queens College and the City University for barring Communist speakers.
MOSCOW, Oct. 31 -- Premier Khrushchev emerged today from the final session of the twenty-second congress of the Soviet Communist party as firmly as ever in control of the party leadership.
Republicans have a fighting chance to win at least two of five City Council seats in Queens this year. Queens has been the only borough except Manhattan to elect a Republican Councilman since 1949.
Governor Rockefeller yesterday proclaimed tomorrow to be Court Reform Day in New York State and urged all voters to vote yes on Amendment 1.
MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 31 (AP) -- The cane harvest is under way in south Florida, and exiled Cuban sugar planters are participating in it.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Hollis B. Chenery, Professor of Economics at Stanford University, was named today to head the program review and coordination staff of the Agency for International Development.

MIAMI BEACH, Oct. 31 -- Mortgage bankers were asked today to work for the defeat in Congress of two key tax proposals of the Kennedy Administration on the ground that they would reduce the flow of money into the mortgage market.

Bruce A. Gimbel, president of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., department store chain, voiced concern yesterday over the effect of the growing trend toward casual dress on the behavior of the nation's boys and young men.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 31 -- Britain took the lead today in the fight for a ban on nuclear testing based on a firm treaty.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 31 -- Finland, Sweden, Norway and Denmark are calmly waiting for the Russians to reveal what they really had in mind in calling yesterday for Soviet-Finnish defense talks.

MASSAPEQUA, L.I., Oct. 31 -- A Puerto Rican family that sought unsuccessfully to buy a home in a white neighborhood here last spring has filed a suit in State Supreme Court against two residents of the neighborhood.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- The White House and Pentagon were evidently embarrassed today over a reported speech on foreign affairs by Gen. James A. Van Fleet. The retired Army general was to have begun serving yesterday as a defense consultant, according to an announcement Oct. 11.
MONTREAL, Oct. 31 (UPI) -- Claude Provost of the Montreal Canadiens is closing in on Andy Bathgate of the New York Rangers in the National Hockey League scoring race, the point table disclosed today.

BOSTON, Oct. 31 -- A railroad brotherhood spokesman said today that a decision on a proposed one-day strike against the New York Central, the New Haven, the Long Island and the Boston and Maine Railroads would be made after a meeting in Albany Saturday night.

Consolidated net income of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana) for the first nine months of this year was $112,025,000, John E. Swearingen, president, reported yesterday. This was equivalent to $3.13 a share on an average of 35,770,859 shares outstanding.
Mayor Wagner declared yesterday that the Republicans were seeking to make the mayoral election "a test of national issues and a direct challenge to the Kennedy Administration."
Waiters and bartenders in 140 major restaurants in the city stayed on the job last night past the expiration of their union contracts as negotiators continued to discuss a new agreement.
ALBANY, Oct. 31 -- Governor Rockefeller said today he did not intend to make any recommendations to the forthcoming special session of the Legislature on rent control.

WALDEMAR HANSEN has made a dogged attempt to probe the miseries of a Greek-American family in "The Garden of Sweets," which opened last night at the ANTA Theatre. Despite his good intentions, he has ended with a gray, sodden effort that refuses to grow the wings with which he hoped to endow it.

John W. Mather, of 37 Glenn Road, Larchmont, N.Y., vice president for industrial relations of the Lone Star Cement Corporation, 100 Park Avenue, died yesterday on a business trip in Pittsburgh. His age was 62.

LONDON, Oct. 31 -- The United States and Britain are prepared to test such nuclear weapons as the anti-missile missile if the tests are necessary to forestall aggression, Prime Minister Macmillan said today.
CAIRO, Oct. 31 -- The property of 422 persons has now been seized in a new drive by President Gamal Abdel Nasser to redistribute the riches of Egypt's wealthy class.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Defense officials told Senator Harrison A. Williams of New Jersey today that they would consider proposals for keeping the Raritan Arsenal in operation.

Eileen Heckart, who up to now has turned down star billing, will be awarded that distinction in "A Family Affair." The new musical comedy, due Feb. 3 on Broadway, was written by the Goldman brothers (William and James) and John Kander.

Investors Mutual, Inc., reported yesterday net assets of $1,843,492,415 as of Sept. 30, end of its fiscal year. This meant that the giant mutual fund retained its rating as the world's largest since Massachusetts Investors Trust reported on Monday that it had net assets of $1,761,798,350 last Sept. 30.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- International crises have their advantages. They frighten the weak but stir and inspire the strong. In sound societies they purify and clarify, elevating what is primary above what is secondary.

In an unusual move yesterday, the New York regional office of the Securities and Exchange Commission ordered a hearing to determine whether two brokerage houses, Sutro Bros. Co. and Schweickart Co., had violated margin requirements.
Three members of the Metropolitan Opera orchestra have moved uptown from Fortieth Street to Fifty-seventh Street to join the New York Philharmonic.

ANNISTON, Ala., Oct. 31 (UPI) -- Evidence of attempts to fix a jury caused a Federal Court judge today to delay the trial of eight men. They are charged with bombing the first Freedom Ride bus that entered Alabama.

EL PASO, Tex., Oct. 31 (AP) -- Leon Bearden was sentenced to life imprisonment today for the hijacking of a jet airliner Aug. 3. His 16-year-old son, Cody, was sentenced to a correctional institution until he is 21.
A MAN should keep his hat on for more reasons than warding off a draft or covering up his bald spot. According to one Park Avenue hatter, the purpose of a hat is psychological orientation.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Clarence N. Sayen, head of the Air Line Pilots Association since 1951, said today he would resign for "personal reasons."
NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 31 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru strongly censured the Soviet Union today for exploding a nuclear bomb of about fifty megatons in strength.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- President Kennedy asked the Japanese Government today to allow an expert from that country to work with the President's new panel on mental retardation.
FORT BENNING, Ga., Oct. 31 (AP) -- A sharp-eyed United States Marine officer set a record today for the international rapid-fire pistol range here.
THIS deal, discussed because it occurred in a game among experts who remember all the cards and discuss the play interminably would seem to be no candidate for discussion.

DETROIT, Oct. 31 -- The United Automobile Workers tonight set a deadline for midnight Thursday for a strike of 60,000 workers against the Chrysler Corporation -- if a new national agreement is not achieved by that time.
The United States and other developed nations were sharply criticized yesterday for restricting their imports from less developed nations while substantially increasing their exports to them.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- President Kennedy has named Ben D. Dorfman to the Tariff Commission for the second time. The appointment is expected to hold up this time.

Lisa Lane of Philadelphia, the national chess champion and one of the two United States representatives in the world championship challengers' tournament at Vrnjacka Banja, scored her second victory yesterday, according to a report from Yugoslavia.
Several high-level executive changes at Texaco, Inc., were announced yesterday by Augustus C. Long, chairman of the big oil company.

WALTER LORD is still devoted to disasters. The man who wrote "A Night to Remember," the engrossing account of the sinking of the Titanic, started a trend that shows no sign of ending. While others produce books about floods, fires, plagues and massacres in the sincerest form of flattery, Mr. Lord continues to show them how to do it.

The promised stiffer examination for mutual fund salesmen will be required in 1962, Raymond Moulden of the National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc., told yesterday afternoon's session of the mutual fund dealers convention in the Statler Hilton Hotel.

MONTAUK, L.I., Oct. 31 -- The striped bass are fighting back. They have gone on the offensive here with a devilishly ingenious strategy aimed at the warrior sportsmen deployed against them. The issue is in doubt and the front is fluid.

A fifty-megaton" brick was hurled through a window of the Soviet Mission to the United Nations yesterday. It was the first instance of violence since protest demonstrations began here Saturday against Soviet nuclear testing.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Farm product prices declined nearly 1 per cent between mid-September and mid-October.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- At the State Department this is the time of the anonymous letter and the mysterious telephone call.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Allied protests in Moscow against East German interference with the movement of some Western officials into East Berlin were reported today to have been rejected by the Soviet Government.
ALBANY, Oct. 31 -- Governor Rockefeller declined to today accept just now Richard M. Nixon's advice that he compete for the Republican Presidential nomination in the 1964 party primaries.

Paperboard production in the nation totaled 356,111 tons in the week ended Saturday. This figure compared with 355,206 tons in the preceding week and 318,032 tons in the same week last year, the National Paperboard Association reported yesterday.
Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz said yesterday that he had edged ahead of Mayor Wagner in the mayoral race.

I should like to correct certain inaccuracies contained in the Oct. 21 article by Foster Harley headed "High-Yield Bomb in Space Feared," which reported on the recent American Assembly conference on outer space.

RYE, N.Y. Oct. 31 -- Dr. Webster Stover was ordered in City Court today to pay a $25 fine or be jailed five days for keeping clotheslines in the front yard of his home in violation of a new ordinance.
ORAN, Algeria, Oct. 31 -- Algeria's second largest city was tense today after an all-night gun battle on the outskirts, and fearful of major turbulence tomorrow.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 31 -Five hundred miles out in space temperatures may fluctuate 1,000 degrees Fahrenheit.
A new lending technique that reduces required cash down payments in purchasing homes has been tested favorably by a large California savings and loan holding company.
Many readers of The Times, I am sure, are looking forward to the reasoning behind your recommendation on Amendment No. 5, which is before the voters on Nov. 7.
The city reduced its gross funded debt in fiscal 1960-61 for the first time in fourteen years, the annual report of Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa disclosed yesterday.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Dairy drivers voted overwhelmingly today to quit the Teamsters Union and join the independent Milk and Ice Cream Drivers and Dairy Union of greater Cincinnati.
The board of directors of Burlington Industries, Inc., voted yesterday to raise the quarterly dividend despite a drop in earnings for the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 31 -- Growing impatience over the failure to form a new government became evident today as the political parties continued behind-the-scenes efforts to find a successor to Foreign Minister Heinrich von Brentano.
JERSEY CITY, Oct. 31 -- Richard J. Hughes, the Democratic candidate for Governor, tonight called his Republican opponent, James P. Mitchell, "the jittery standard-bearer of a fading campaign."
As Aqueduct turns into the final month of the New York thoroughbred racing season today, the local scene is 692 horses short of normal.
The National Horse Show, which began its fashionable, glittering and often exciting stand in Madison Square Garden yesterday, had as its special star one of Ireland's foremost riders.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Henry R. Luce, editor in chief of Time-Life publications, believes anti-Communist schools are valuable, but Ralph McGill, publisher of The Atlanta Constitution, and Walter Cronkite, television commentator for the Columbia Broadcasting System, disagree.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 31 -- President Leopold S. Senghor of Senegal demanded today that the uncommitted nations, of which his country is one, put into practice the principles they were urging on the great powers.
MAHWAH, N.J., Oct. 31 -- James P. Mitchell, the Republican candidate for Governor, charged tonight that Richard J. Hughes, his Democratic opponent, had an "anti-labor record."
A program for "plugging the loopholes" in the state Rent Control Law was recommended last night by Mayor Wagner.
Actors Equity and the League of Off-Broadway Theatres and Producers announced agreement yesterday on a new three-year contract.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- The Soviet Union continued its intensive atomic test series today by detonating two explosions at its proving grounds in the Arctic, the Atomic Energy Commission announced.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- The Department of Justice asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today to disapprove a proposed merger of Seaboard Air Line Railroad Company and the Atlantic Coast Line Railroad Company.
The City Housing Authority is studying the possibility of providing fall-out shelters in its present and planned buildings, an authority spokesman disclosed yesterday.

A three-man board appointed by Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg held its first session yesterday with maritime labor and management on the controversial issue of "runaway" flags -- United States-owned ships registered under foreign flags.
Mayor Wagner swore in Dr. Marvin E. Perkins as the city's first Commissioner of Mental Health Services yesterday at City Hall.

October ended with a small rally in the stock market, sending at least one of the popular indexes to an historic high. This was Standard Poor's 500-stock index. The New York Times average remained 3.8 per cent below its 1961 peak.

The United States Steel Corporation reported yesterday that its third quarter earnings declined from both second quarter and 1960 period levels. Sales declined 1 per cent from second quarter levels, but topped year-ago volume.
First-century documents found in remote caves along the western shore of the Dead Sea were described here yesterday as the most important discovery of the period next to the Dead Sea Scrolls.

FOR much of the world breakfast is a point of view. To the standard American, it is bacon and eggs; to the average Parisian, a croissant or brioche with coffee. For many Orientals it is rice with tea.
Why do so many advertisements begin with a question?

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) announced yesterday that it was setting up a new Development Advisory Service. The aim is to provide a supply of expert talent to furnish economic and technical advice to less developed nations.
Prohibition has been replaced by excessive taxation as the primary threat to the liquor industry, the head of the public relations arm of the business said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (UPI) -- Negro leader charged today that the Post Office Department had suggested a "deal" on the controversial dismissal of a Negro mail carrier in Savannah Ga.

No football scout in the memory of man or fan has returned from a reconnaissance patrol and reported that yon enemy was a sitting duck. It is a prerequisite of the trade to at least view with alarm if one cannot manage to be downright pessimistic.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, said today the Kennedy Administration was "taking an unnecessary risk" by refusing to spend $780,000,000 that Congress provided for manned bombers.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Western officials and diplomats showed immediate and serious concern today over what they took be a major new Soviet diplomatic assault on Scandinavia.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 31 (UPI) -- Willie Naulls scored 37 points to pace the New York Knickerbockers to a 131-127 victory over the Cincinnati Royals in a National Basketball Association game tonight.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Oct. 31 (UPI) -- Jack Kramer, moving swiftly now that Australia's big tennis arenas have been opened to his professional troupe, today lined up a tournament for Kooyong Stadium here.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) Contending that the jury returned an inconsistent verdict, Irvin C. Scarbeck asked today for a new trial on charges that he passed United States secrets to Polish agents.

Mayor Wagner last night denounced merchants who were selling milk at premium prices and pledged to hold them up to public reprobation. He doubled the inspection force that has been working on this problem and related ones in the milk strike.
The milk strike has dragged on for a full week. The hardship it inflicts on millions of New Yorkers, especially those with small children, grows more indefensible each day.

BUFFALO, Oct. 31 -- Waiter J. Mahoney, majority leader of the state Senate, stepped onto what he termed the battleground of welfare tonight and fired a few salvos at social welfare and its "organization men."
ALBANY, Oct. 31 -- The states Republican high command has approved a Congressional reapportionment plan for upstate New York that will dismember and eliminate one of three Democratic districts.
AUTOMATION and its effects on labor and industry were studied last night in an engrossing telecast over Channel 7.
The aggregate of bonds called for redemption in October before maturity was the heaviest for an October since 1954 and considerably above the previous month's total.
The annual dinner and Mazurka. Ball to benefit the scholarship fund of the Paderewski Foundation will be held at the Plaza on Nov. 19.
A study of the effects of massive hydrogen bomb explosions indicates that they greatly reduce the value of fall-out shelters in metropolitan areas.

Sam Mele, the manager of the Minnesota Twins, and Dolph Schayes, the highest scorer in professional basketball records, were picked yesterday by the Varsity Club of New York University as the first winners of a new annual Violet award, the Alumni of the Year in Sports.

THE cries of America's college-educated housewives for stimulating part-time work has risen to a crescendo. Yet the demands greatly outnumber the opportunities. And many women who seek relief from monotonous household routine do not face up to the realities of working life.
Stock prices scored a small gain on average last month on the New York Stock Exchange.

Mr. Khrushchev is trying to frighten somebody with his ghastly superbombs, but it is not yet clear just whom. He is too shrewd to believe that the United States will be cowed by these vast explosions whose radioactive fall-out menaces Russians as much as anyone.
A three-hour taped telecast of two recent anti-Communist "seminars" in Southern California will be shown tomorrow night over WPIX (Channel 11).

The following table gives the amount of dealings in the stocks from which the averages are computed, the combined trading in both classes of issues, as well as the total daily transactions for week and month:

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 31 -- Mayor George Christopher of San Francisco, a leading although as yet undeclared candidate for the Republican nomination for Lieutenant Governor, had political controversy thrust upon him today.
The City Hall gripemobile, which for two years has been the repository of citizens' complaints and suggestions, will appear in a new dress today.

AFTER the Talmack showing yesterday, a buyer walked up to John Moore, the designer, and said: "Boy, you're really cooking with gas." What Mr. Moore had cooked up was a collection of simple, well-cut, carefully constructed clothes.
AN epidemic of scarlet fever that swept the house he lived in at Albion College in Michigan stimulated the curiosity of Marvin Earl Perkins in medicine.

A plea to President Kennedy to name an emergency fact-finding board in the dispute between Trans World Airlines and its pilots is in prospect. The question of submitting such a plea is being considered by the National Mediation Board.

" EXPLORING the World of Art," a program for children of high-school age, will be presented on Saturday at 11 A.M. at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue and Eighty-second Street. Admission is $1.

DONUT KING, a big and handsome 2-year-old colt, was rolling at an easy gallop in the middle of the Garden State race track yesterday morning. Watching him with contented but speculative eyes was his trainer, young Ron McAnally. The colt was loosening his muscles at a relaxing pace and the trainer relaxed with him, leaning against the rail along the backstretch.

The board of directors of the Republic Aviation Corporation voted at a special meeting yesterday to recommend stockholder approval of an increase in the authorized common shares to permit a two-for-one split of the common stock. The number of shares would be changed from 2,500,000 of $1 par value to 5,000,000 of 50 cents par value.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 31 -- Yale and Dartmouth play in the Bowl here Saturday before a crowd expected to number 40,000, and the coaches agree that the team that loses can pretty much count itself out of the running in the wide-open scramble for the Ivy football championship.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Oct. 31 -- United Nations forces are patrolling the Katanga-Kasai border with five Swedish jet fighters whose pilots have orders to ground any Katangese aircraft if possible and to shoot them down if necessary.
CHICAGO, Oct. 31 -- Members of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants adopted overwhelmingly here today a proposal for a stronger rule on professional ethics.
LONDON, Oct. 31 -- Augustus John, one of Britain's most eminent and colorful painters, died today at his home in Fordingbridge, Hampshire. He was 83 years old.

Seven years ago today small bands of Algerian terrorists, known as "fellaghas," slipped over the Tunisian frontier in the east and from Morocco in the west and staged some thirty murderous attacks inside Algeria. Military posts, farms, railways were shot up or damaged with explosives and incendiary bombs. At least nine persons were killed and thirty wounded.

THE jewelry masterpieces of Jean Schlumberger have been collected from their owners throughout the world and, in a manner befitting works of art, have been mounted, framed, lighted and hung in shadow boxes at the Wildenstein Gallery.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Procedural snags and the need to elect a new chairman of the Council of the Organization of American States are likely to delay any action on Cuba, at least until the middle of November.
Michigan State and Mississippi, racing toward possible undefeated seasons, remained one, two yesterday in the weekly United Press International college football ratings.

General Bancshares Corporation is planning to acquire a suburban St. Louis bank. Shareholders meeting yesterday approved a new issue of 4 1/2 per cent preferred $10 par stock for the purpose. Although 500,000 shares of the new stock were authorized, General Banschares said it has no plan at present to use any of the preferred beyond the amount needed for the acquisition of the Lindbergh Bank, Hazelwood, Mo.
JERUSALEM, Oct. 31 -- After eleven weeks of negotiating, a new coalition Government for Israel was agreed upon tonight.
The Kennecott Copper Corporation, the world's leading producer of copper, reported yesterday that sales and earnings for the quarter and the nine months ended on Sept. 30 were below the 1960 levels.

The office of Bronx Borough President has been held by a single political group, the "regular" Democratic organization, for the past forty-four years. That has produced the usual results of one-party rule.

POUNDING drums and brass fanfares would not have been out of order to proclaim the official opening Monday night of the Arena Stage's impressive new home. Nor would it have been an undeserved tribute to this valiant theatrical enterprise if the most glamorous personages of the New Frontier had joined in welcoming the happy occasion.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 20 to 40 cents a bale off to 25 cents up on the March, 1963, contract yesterday.

HISTORICALLY speaking, a monodrama was a work in which a speaker recited against a musical background. Berlioz, Schubert and others wrote monodramas (also called melodramas). So did Richard Strauss, who set "Enoch Arden" to music. But modern usage has decreed a slightly different meaning for the term.

Trans World Airlines, Inc., reported yesterday a $12,733,000 net loss, after an undisclosed amount of tax credits, for the first nine months of this year. In the 1960 period, the system operated at a net profit of $6,083,000.
With "The Young Doctors" already released as their first independent production, Stuart Millar and Lawrence Turman are looking ahead to three other projects.
Six persons were injured, two of them seriously, when a bus struck an automobile at Broadway and 122d Street last night.

THE British Isles have long nurtured a tradition of personal eccentricity, have taken pride in the capacity to breed "characters" whose gay defiance of convention has vastly increased the sum of enjoyment in a humdrum world.
Governor Rockefeller yesterday appointed Ogden R. Reid, former president and editor of The New York Herald Tribune, as chairman of the State Commission Against' Discrimination.
At the personal request of Mayor Wagner, both sides in the milk strike agreed last night to resume joint negotiations this morning.

An intimate biography of Mrs. John F. Kennedy has been written by Mary Van Rensselaer Thayer, a newspaper woman and magazine writer. Mrs. Thayer has known Mrs. Kennedy since she was a child and has had access to family journals, scrapbooks, photograph albums and letters.
It seems that everybody complains about the housing situation in our city but no one does anything appreciable about it.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Witnesses before a Senate subcommittee testified today that there was no adequate law now to bar monopolistic controls over prescription drugs and medicines through patents.
LONDON, Nov. 1 -- Direct Soviet pressure on Norway and Denmark is expected by British and Scandinavian diplomats to be the next step in the Soviet Union's new diplomatic offensive in northern Europe.

The visit of five United States Cabinet officers and their advisers to Japan to discuss Japanese-American trade and economic problems is a historic occasion. This is believed to be the first time an American President has sent so many members of his Cabinet abroad on a single mission.
MEKNES, Morocco, Nov. 1 -- Demonstrations for Algerian independence here today cost the life of one Moroccan and left twenty wounded, including seventeen policemen, according to witnesses.
The New York Ball, successor to the Prince of Wales Ball held 101 years ago at the old Academy of Music, took place last evening at the Museum of the City of New York.

GENEVA, Thursday, Nov. 2 -- More than 800 nuclear physicists from twenty countries have signed a petition warning that no "so-called military victory" would justify the "enormous and permanent destruction" caused by atomic weapons.
Radioactive debris from Soviet nuclear tests presents no threat to passengers or crews of high-flying jet airlines, according to the United States Public Health Service.

A plethora of little things occupied the minds and muscles of the New York Giants yesterday in an impressive workout at Yankee Stadium. Ideally, the minutiae will add up to big accomplishments, individually and collectively, in a National Football League contest with the Washington Redskins at the Stadium on Sunday.
The Very Rev. Edward J. Burke was installed yesterday as thirteenth president of St. John's University in a ceremony on the Jamaica campus.
Sales and earnings of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company were higher in the third quarter of this year than in the 1960 period, the company announced yesterday, following a meeting of the board.
HONG KONG, Nov. 1 -- In the view of observers here Communist China appears to be setting the stage for a showdown ideological debate with the Soviet Union.

PARIS, Nov. 1 -- The French Academy, an august body of dictionary makers, has reached the word "chauffe-eau" (water heater) and is now in the process of deciding whether it has an acceptable place in the French language.
EATONTOWN, N.J., Nov. 1 -- James P. Mitchell, the Republican candidate for Governor, charged here today that the Democrats would "seek to buy" Tuesday's election.
The Board of Elections reports 3,506,913 persons eligible to vote next Tuesday. It has been estimated -- we hope erroneously -- that at least a third of these eligibles will neglect to vote.
The six horses in the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday finished in numerical sequence, but a stewards' inquiry and a jockey's protest spoiled that order.
JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 1 -- A Federal order desegregating interstate transportation facilities encountered open defiance today in the Deep South.

Even though the economic outlook is generally bright nowadays, forecasts by some observers have become a bit somber. The predictions, in some cases, appear to be dominated by concern over international problems.

Committees have been announced by Mrs. John P. Lins, chairman, for the fifth annual Gold and Silver Ball. It will be held in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza on Dec. 29 and will benefit the Girls Service League.
Alabama's unbeaten football team remains the best defensive team for the second straight week.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 1 (AP) -- The Maryland legislative council approved by voice vote today a bill that would require restaurants and hotels in the state to serve all races.
CHICAGO, Nov. 1 -- The plans of the Kennedy Administration with regard to taxes in the January session of Congress were outlined here today by a top Administration official.
MOSCOW, Nov. 1 -- The Soviet people learned today that the body of Stalin had been removed from the Lenin Mausoleum and buried near the Kremlin wall.

It is not often these days that a benefactor can be of assistance to young people seeking a college education without involving the expenditure of personal or public funds. But that is exactly the opportunity presented to the citizens of the State of New York.
United States nuclear weapons scientists said yesterday that, contrary to some contentions, the so-called neutron bomb would not be an "answer" to the Soviet superbomb.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 1 -- President Urho K. Kekkonen of Finland reaffirmed tonight his country's dedication to democracy.

A new United States policy on international trade, calling for broad tariff reductions and a sharp departure from protectionism, was advocated last night by a top official of the Kennedy Administration.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Henry A. Wallace, a former Vice President and Secretary of Agriculture, said today that United States farm surpluses "represent national strength, not weakness," if properly used.
The Bankers Trust Company announced yesterday the election of Thomas E. Baggott, Isaac W. Hughes, Theodore R. Hilb and Henry E. Podsen as vice presidents.

The nation's gasoline stocks declined 2,127,000 barrels in the week ended last Friday, according to the American Petroleum Institute. The decline reflected in part lower gasoline output for the period, which amounted to 28,971,000 barrels, compared with 29,313, 000 a week earlier.

RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Nov. 1 -- Pakistan will seek economic aid and technical assistance "from anywhere," M.H.H. Zuberi, Secretary of the Ministry of Power, Fuel and Natural Resources, said here today.

Services will be held again in the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity in Brooklyn -- the old Melish church. But they will be conducted by the Church Army in the U.S.A., not by a regular congregation of the diocese.

A new issue of $27,500,000 of port facilities revenue bonds of the Virginia State Ports Authority is being offered for public subscription by a syndicate headed by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith and Blyth Co., Inc.

BACK in the darkest days of World War II professional sports were gasping in the stranglehold of the manpower shortage. Only the halt, the lame, the physically unfit kept them going. It reached such a point that the then St. Louis Browns even played a one-armed outfielder, Pete Gray.
BERLIN, Nov. 1 -- There is a new look in the United States mission in Berlin. It has been inspired by Gen. Lucius D. Clay.

Following are excerpts from a speech in New York last night by George W. Ball, Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, at the final dinner session of the forty-eighth National Foreign Trade Convention:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Military officials are pressing for United States atomic testing in the atmosphere to develop a new arsenal of nuclear weapons -- from bombs that would jam international communications to warheads that would knock down incoming missiles.
FORT MONROE, Va., Nov. 1 (AP) -- Gen. James A. Van Fleet telegraphed Adlai E. Stevenson tonight retracting statements he made about Mr. Stevenson's role in the Cuban invasion.

The trial examiner's report on Joseph R. Weiss, the suspended deputy Superintendent of Schools, was made public yesterday. It called Mr. Weiss an honest, capable and industrious man who had made "a number of serious mistakes" that justified his dismissal.
BUFFALO, Nov. 1 -- Governor Rockefeller took a calculated political risk today. He placed a share of his personal campaigning prestige behind the Republican candidate for Mayor of Buffalo.

Events today: "Tosca," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P.M.; "Il Trittico," New York City Opera Company, City Center, 8:15; New York Philharmonic preview concert, Leonard Bernstein and John Canarina, conductors. Zara Nelsova, 'cellist, and the Choral Art Society, Carnegie Hall, 8:30.

CAMDEN, N.J., Nov. 1 (AP) -- The Calumet Farm's Pied d'Or closed rapidly in the stretch to pass the long-shot leader, Pundit, and win the $23,025 Princeton Handicap by a length and three-quarters today.

The New York and American Stock Exchanges reported yesterday, pursuant to the Securities and Exchange Act of 1934, the following changes in the holdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed companies:
Republican polls indicate that Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa's independent candidacy and a big undecided vote hold the balance of power in the mayoral race here.

RECIFE, Brazil, Nov. 1 (AP) -- A Brazilian airliner on the last leg of a flight from Portugal crashed into a hillside near this northeast Brazilian city today. An airline spokesman said tonight that fifty-seven of the eighty-eight persons aboard died in the flames of exploding wreckage.
The establishment of a "Mayor's medal for outstanding service" to be awarded annually to two of the city's 225,000 employes for outstanding service was announced last night by Mayor Wagner.
Sales of the major department stores in the metropolitan area in October were 3 per cent higher than in 1960, according to a survey made yesterday by The New York Times.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Oct. 25.

BELIZE, British Honduras, Nov. 1 -- Hurricane Hattie killed at least ninety-nine persons in British Honduras and left a tragic trail of shattered, splintered coastal towns. There were many missing and the death toll from the storm yesterday was expected to go higher.
The Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences at New York University has begun operating an I.B.M. 7090 -- the most powerful computer in use at any Eastern university.
ORAN, Algeria, Nov. 1 -- A Moslem woman was killed and at least sixteen persons were injured here in shootings and bomb blasts during today's demonstrations in Oran, Algeria's second largest city.

Champ, a 6-year-old male brindle Boxer, will receive a medal of honor from the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals as soon as he recovers from smoke poisoning. He was in good condition yesterday at the society's hospital, 441 East Ninety-second Street.
The Regional Plan Association announced its opposition yesterday to a proposal for New York State to pledge $100,000,000 of its credit for the purchase of railroad commuter cars.

Twenty-six public housing authorities in sixteen states and in Puerto Rico borrowed $78,540,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance low-rent projects subsidized by the Public Housing Administration.
WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 1 -- Eight top pacers were selected today to oppose the world champion, Adios Butler, in his farewell event, the $50,000 National Pacing Derby at Roosevelt Raceway on Nov. 11.
ARMED with cellophane tape, cafe curtain hooks and pin-up boards, college girls wage an annual battle with standardized furnishings.
CHICAGO, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Paul Hornung of the Green Bay Packers will be able to play on the next two Sundays against the Baltimore Colts and Chicago Bears.
The electronic computer -- born, like many other tools of man, from the needs of war -- is a prodigious fifteen years old this year.
Mayor Wagner, angered at some merchants' selling milk at a premium during the strike but lacking legal power to stop them, moved yesterday to hold them up to scorn.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Following are excerpts from a report prepared by former Secretary of State Christian A. Herter and former Under Secretary of State Will Clayton for the subcommittee on foreign economic policy of the Joint Congressional Economic Committee:
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 1 -- Two resolutions embodying President Kennedy's proposal for a decade of development were circulated here today by a group of nine sponsoring nations.
Regarding your Oct. 19 and Oct. 20 editorials, there seems to be a contradiction in what you believe to be a notable trait for a candidate running for city office.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Nov. 1 (AP) -- An out of control Blue Scout rocket was blown up by the range safety officer today thirty seconds after it blasted off in an attempt to orbit a satellite to test the United States' worldwide man-in-space tracking network.

After forty-four years on the New York Stock Exchange, Transue Williams Steel Forging Corporation is moving its common stock to the American Stock Exchange, effective Dec. 26. On the following day shareholders will vote on a proposal to increase the authorized common stock from 500,000 shares to 1,000,000, preparatory for a two-for-one stock split.

The Sinclair Oil Corporation reported yesterday that net income for the three months ended on Sept. 30 was $3,387,866, or 23 cents a share on 15,146,805 shares outstanding, down sharply from $12,841,764, or 84 cents a share, for the 1960 period.
A 34-year-old longshoreman was sentenced to thirty days and fined $250 yesterday for having "a faulty memory" while testifying before the Kings County Rackets Grand Jury.

By the time they reach their eighty-fourth birthday, most men are content to stop fighting. Not so Thomas M. Storke, editor and publisher of The Santa Barbara (Calif.) News-Press, who is still busy living his conviction that no force in a community is so effective as a resolute editor.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 1 -Radiocarbon from nuclear tests has helped scientists trace air movements around the earth, a geophysicist reported today.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 1 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit upheld yesterday the dismissal of a suit filed by four Negro ministers who had sought to nullify libel actions pending in the Alabama courts.
The City Planning Commission adopted and sent to the Board of Estimate yesterday a proposed 1962 capital budget of $816,028,917.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The Library of Congress has acquired a large collection of previously unknown correspondence by Nicolo Paganini, the violinist.
BONHAM, Tex., Nov. 1 (UPI) -- House Speaker Sam Rayburn's doctor said today that Mr. Rayburn might be able to fight off death from cancer for weeks or months.

The American Broadcasting Company's Tuesday evening television schedule is expected to undergo changes effective Nov. 14. They will include the dropping of "Calvin and the Colonel," a cartoon show that will be rescheduled on another night later in the season, and the introduction of a game show starring Bert Parks.
A thumbnail summary of Graham Greene's "The Complaisant Lover," which opened last night at the Ethel Barrymore Theatre, would go something like this:

"Zazie," a French-made farce based on Raymond Quencau's satirical novel, "Zazie Dans le metro," will be the next attraction at the Paris Theatre. Louis Malle wrote and directed the color film, which depicts modern Parisian life as seen through the eyes of an irreverent little girl, Catherine Demongeot plays the title role.

The city Health Department cautioned 152 voluntary and proprietary hospitals here yesterday against using blood or blood plasma from four commercial blood banks now being investigated by the Federal Government.
The Sportsmanship Brotherhood yesterday gave its annual Grantland Rice Memorial Award, a bronze plaque, to Arthur Daley, the sports columnist of The New York Times.
OSAKA, Japan, Nov. 1 (AP) -- The Yomiuri Giants of Tokyo won the Japanese world series today by defeating the Nankai Hawks of Osaka, 3 -- 2, in ten innings for their fourth victory in six games.

Production of electric power in the nation rose to 15,263,000,000 kilowatt-hours in the week ended on last Saturday from 15,162,000,000 kilowatt-hours in the preceding week, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday.

Hundreds of women in twenty or more United States cities demonstrated yesterday against nuclear bomb testing. Called a "Strike for Peace," the demonstration was intended as a protest against the Soviet tests and against proposals for a renewal of United States testing.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- President Kennedy today ordered creation of an emergency board to investigate a dispute between Trans World Airlines and the Air Line Pilots Association.
OTTAWA, Nov. 1 -- The Boy Scouts world movement is having its troubles, like the rest of the world.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 1 (UP) -- The Union Commerce Bank sold today the Union Commerce Building, one of the nation's ten largest office buildings, to a real estate investment trust for $25,500,000. The bank simultaneously completed a lease continuing its control and operation of the building.

PINE BEACH, N.J., Nov. 1 -- In view of the unusual goingson at Admiral Farragut Academy these days, Stan Slaby, the Cadets' head coach, is surprised that he has been able to keep his football players interested.
A further price retreat of slight extent took place in United States Government Securities yesterday under the cloud of the $6,693,000,000 refunding that the Treasury must make this month.
BUFFALO, Nov. 1 -- Social welfare workers, under attack from the city of Newburgh and State Senator Walter J. Mahoney, heard a defense of their profession today.
Both history and a heavy Democratic majority seem to favor the Democrats in the four City Council races in the Bronx.
CHICAGO, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Significant market factors were absent today and prices in the grain futures trade held almost stationary in quiet dealings.
It was learned yesterday that the New York Stock Exchange had censured and fined some of the partners in three member firms for dealings with First Discount Corporation.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Automobile credit declined in September for the tenth consecutive month, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
Mayor Wagner charged yesterday that the Republicans in Albany had knowingly tried to "sneak through" a general rent increase, and now were trying to gerrymander the state's Congressional districts.
I have just read your editorial comment of Oct. 26 on Amendment No. 7 providing for the improvement of a highway in Hamilton County.

WILLIAM BRINKLEY'S new novel, "The Fun House,"* is a comic dramatization of private lives boiling in a fantastic American picture magazine. I enjoyed reading it. But I must say in candor that along its appointed course it bounces from low slapstick to lofty exhortation in an odd, erratic way.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Nov. 1 -- Commercial banks are a large untapped potential for investment in home loans, mortgage bankers were told today.
HARTFORD, Nov. 1 -- A thorough examination of air transportation and the problems that beset it will be conducted here over the next two days.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Puff balls, fungus plants like mushrooms that are commonly seen in Southern woods and pastures, are producing an apparently potent anti-cancer drug. This is known as calvacin.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The directors of the National Housing Conference have adopted a resolution urging President Kennedy not to compromise if he takes executive action to end discrimination in federally aided housing.
DETROIT, Nov. 1 -- The Ford Motor Company reported today that its consolidated net income for the third quarter of 1961 was $79,800,000, compared with $51,400,000 for the 1960 period.

EDISON, N.J., Nov.. 1 -- Richard J. Hughes, the Democratic candidate for Governor, said today that President Kennedy's visit to New Jersey tomorrow would be "not so much to help me in my campaign, as to defend his own Administration from contemptible attacks of the so-called 'loyal opposition.'"

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- A proposal that the United States form a "trade partnership" with Europe's Common Market was laid before Congress today by two ranking officials of the Eisenhower and Truman Administrations.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Senators heard testimony today that dangerous new drugs were being admitted to the market after "frighteningly limited" clinical testing of their effects on human patients.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed unchanged to 45 cents a bale off yesterday.
UTICA, N.Y., Nov. 1 (AP) -- "Your paycheck is late because I forgot," said the note in the envelope opened today by Mohawk Airlines' 400 top executives and supervisory personnel.
BERLIN, Nov. 1 -- West Berlin policemen today began checking the identity of Soviet-bloc diplomats entering West Berlin in civilian cars from East Berlin.
FORT BENNING, Ga., Nov. 1 (AP) -- Two officers and an enlisted man won today in qualifying competition for the United States team that will seek the world shooting championship next year.
The General Foods Corporation elected James D. North and Charles Overbeck as vice presidents of the corporation yesterday.

Pressures on the Administration, both military and political, to resume the atmospheric testing of nuclear weapons are mounting in Washington as the result of Russia's latest tests. Significant international support for such a move by the United States is indicated by Prime Minister Macmillan's declaration in the House of Commons that Britain would endorse any atmospheric tests necessary to maintain the balance of power in nuclear arms.
MASERU, Basutoland, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Violence broke out in this British protectorate today for the second day in a row. At least three Africans were reported to have been killed.

THIRTY years ago a French painter named Jean de Brunhoff amused his two sons, Laurent and Mathieu, by weaving stories about a little elephant named Babar. A year after he put the imaginative sales between the covers of a book.
The city yesterday announced a program to save the City College area from the physical and social blight that has occurred in many college neighborhoods.
BERLIN, Nov. 1 -- Communist attempts to split the German Evangelical Church were disclosed today by church officials in Berlin.

GENEVA, Nov. 1 -- Communist China warned today that if United States combat troops were sent to South Vietnam it would make pointless the negotiations here for an agreement to guarantee the independence and neutrality of neighborhing Laos.

Manhattan Borough president Edward R. Dudley accused State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz yesterday of "hoodwinking the public" into thinking the state was making effective warfare against city slums.

A $70,000 grant for the training of Negro physicians and surgeons was announced yesterday by the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation and National Medical Fellowships, Inc., of Chicago, which will administer the grant.
Michael H. Prendergast, the Democratic state chairman, urged yesterday the election of City Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa as Mayor.

It was with a deep sadness, almost with a sense of personal loss, that I read your Oct. 31 editorial containing your recommendations with respect to candidates for the Supreme Court in Manhattan and the Bronx.
The split in the Democratic party and a shift in Liberal support are creating a close contest for the Borough Presidency of the Bronx, a post held by the Democrats for more than forty years.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 1 (AP) -- Navy appeared ready today for a peak effort Saturday against Notre Dame at South Bend, Ind.

CAMDEN, N.J., Nov. 1 (AP) -- A pathologist testified today he had deliberately and, with possible prejudice to an osteopath accused of manslaughter, wrongly listed serum hepatitis as the cause of the death of one of Dr. Albert Weiner's patients.
A publishing merger between Harper Brothers of New York, and Row, Peterson Co., of Evanston, Ill., was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy will be the main speaker at the first White House regional conference, which will be held in Chicago Nov. 7 and 8.
MOSCOW, Nov. 1 -- The Soviet Communist party announced today the membership of its new Central Committee, the largest in the party's history.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Jacob D. Beam, the United States Ambassador to Poland, will leave Warsaw at the end of the year to take charge of political and negotiating affairs at the new Arms Control and Disarmament Agency.

Licia Albanese sang her first Mimi of the season in last night's Metropolitan Opera production of "La Boheme," and Heidi Krall appeared as Musetta. Otherwise, the cast was the same as last week's. Nino Verchi conducted.
Eleven adjourned games were played off yesterday in the women's world chess challengers' tournament at Vrnjacka Banja, according to a report from Yugolsavia.

Ch. Harrigan of Twin Haven, a 2 1/2-year-old red-and-white cocker spaniel owned by Mrs. Hilda G. Schroeder of Weston, Conn., joined dogdom's most exclusive circle this fall. He qualified for the Tracking Dog degree, the highest and rarest title in obedience training.

In a sweeping investigation of criminal "domination" of New York and New Jersey piers, the Waterfront Commission yesterday began around-the-clock interrogation of former convicts in the International Longshoremen's Association.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- For reasons he deems good and sufficient, President Kennedy has held no news conferences since Oct. 11, and today it was announced there is to be none this week. No man in public life knows better than he how useful these sessions can be to a President, or knows better how to make them so.

An experiment in training foreign workers in American methods in the production and distribution of gas and electricity has been undertaken jointly by the Consolidated Edison Company and Local 1-2 of the Utility Workers of America.

AT the opening today of the first Bohack supermarket in Manhattan, customers will be given a floor plan of what the company describes as "the city's largest supermarket," at the corner of Second Avenue and Seventy-third Street.

The action of The Times in endorsing the Republican candidate for Governor of New Jersey is a disservice to the voters of that state. The only explanation given for this choice -- that the Republican candidate is more experienced -- will not withstand scrutiny.
Automobile production in October was 9.8 per cent below the level of the 1960 month. The nation's auto makers assembled 557,200 cars last month, compared with 617,866 cars in October, 1960.
HAKONE, Japan, Thursday, Nov. 2 -- The United States urged Japan, the strongest industrial nation in Asia, today to devote a growing part of her economic power to help underdeveloped countries.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The head of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation urged Government and industry today to accept the necessity of working together for the survival of freedom and human dignity against Communist aggression.

A GREAT reputation often excuses the offering of trifles. At the Silagy Galleries, 960 Madison Avenue, some twenty-five drawings by Ernst Ludwig Kirchner are displayed with such taste and discretion that their slightness is almost masked.

The autobiography of Dr. George N. Shuster, who for twenty-one years was president of Hunter College, will be published on Nov. 10 by Farrar, Straus Cudahy. Called "The Ground I Walked On," the volume presents Dr. Shuster's recollections of his activities in the social, political and intellectual life of this city and the Nation.
ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 1 -- Bird watchers now have a new underwater counterpart called fish watchers.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The old Truman Administration took over the White House tonight.
Forty-seven Protestant and Eastern Orthodox communions in the United States contributed more than $2,500,000,000 to their churches in 1960, the National Council of Churches reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- President Kennedy's economy appeal produced today a $101,945,000 budget cut for health, education and welfare.
Faced with the imminent collapse of negotiations early today, Mayor Wagner asked both sides in the milk strike to conduct marathon talks to end the stoppage. They agreed.
LONDON, Nov. 1 -- A few items of cheerful company news that the widely-held expectation that the bank rate would be reduced tomorrow had a buoyant effect on the stock market here today.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 1 -- Chancellor Adenauer was expected tonight to name Dr. Gerhard Schroeder, Interior Minister in the outgoing Government, as his choice to succeed Dr. Heinrich von Brentano as Foreign Minister. Dr. von Brentano resigned Monday.

THE Monte Sano Pruzan collection, designed by Jacques Tiffeau, is brilliant. It is proof of this young designer's ability to create a silhouette and then execute it superbly. Tiffeau introduced the fitted suit jacket with the high bosom line and lifted waistline in his collection for fall.
New York State went to court yesterday in an effort to otbain triple damages from six large manufacturers of electrical equipment convicted last February of price-rigging.

TORONTO, Nov. 1 (UPI) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs handed the Montreal Canadiens their first defeat of the National Hockey League season tonight by scoring a 3-2 triumph on a third-period goal by Frank Mahovlich.
The domestic price of lead was reduced one-half cent a pound yesterday to 10 1/2 cents, reflecting a combination of downward pressures in this country and abroad.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Nov. 1 (UPI) -- The Illinois Senate refused today for the first time in a decade to confirm a gubernatorial appointment. It turned down Earl Dickerson, a Chicago Negro lawyer, as a member of the new State Fair Employment Practices Commission.

BUFFALO, Nov. 1 (UPI) -- Governor Rockefeller tonight rejected a request by Gov. Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey that New York State pass a law next week to permit the Port of New York Authority to take over the bankrupt Hudson Manhattan Railroad.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (UPI) -- The Federal Government announced that forty-eight companies would share in importing an additional 7,400 barrels of residual fuel oil a day through next March 31.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 1 -- A tough but tolerant Burmese who believes in keeping his "emotional equilibrium" appeared today to have passed the last obstacles on his way to the United Nations' top position, left vavant by the death Sept. 18 of Secretary General Dag Ham marskjold.

This is the time of year when the controversial issue of business gifts once again comes to the fore. Hundreds of companies around the country must decide whether to give Christmas gifts at all and, if so, how much to spend on them.
CHICAGO, Nov. 1 -- A strike by 3,500 teamsters today halted delivery of 10,000,000 gallons of gasoline and fuel oil in the Chicago area.

The illness of Leontyne Price, which resulted in the soprano's bowing out of Tuesday's Metropolitan Opera production of "La Fanciulla del West" after two acts, has caused some changes in this week's Met schedule.
I write with respect to your Oct. 19 editorial endorsing Mr. Lefkowitz for Mayor.

BOSTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Mrs. Moses Dyckman of New York was unanimously reelected president of the Mizrachi Women's Organization of America today at the closing session of the group's annual convention.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Nov. 1 -- More than 500 Vietnamese Communist guerrillas are reported to have been killed in clashes with Government forces in recent days.
Following is the text of a statement issued here yesterday by Michael H. Prendergast, the Democratic state chairman:
A portion of the proceeds of last evening's performance of the National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden was donated to the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.
Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa announced yesterday that he was investigating "the high cost of snow removal" last winter under the Wagner administration.
Austin J. Tobin said yesterday "discriminatory Federal policies were undermining New York's position as the nation's leading port.

The theatre party for the benefit of the Citizens Housing and Planning Council will he held at next Thursday's performance of "The Complaisant Lover" at the Barrymore Theatre. The Graham Greene comedy opened last night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- President Kennedy will take a hand tomorrow in two important off-year elections. He will appear in New York City in the afternoon on behalf of Mayor Wagner's campaign for re-election. At 8:30 P.M., in front of the War Memorial in Trenton, he will make a speech supporting Richard J. Hughes for Governor.

Memories of the days when "name" dance bands dominated popular music are being hopefully stirred in the Grill Room of the Roosevelt Hotel where Si Zentner and his orchestra introduced themselves to New Yorkers this week.
Renewed efforts by the United States and other nations to reduce trade barriers were urged yesterday in closing sessions of the forty-eighth National Foreign Trade Convention.

TEHRAN, Iran, Nov. 1 (Reuters) -- The general conference of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting countries (O.P.E.C.) has decided on firm joint action to obtain their demands from foreign oil companies, informed sources said today.

Nikita Khrushchev began the Soviet Communist Party's Twenty-second Congress by expressing fear that his own country might be hurt if Russian scientists detonated too powerful an H-bomb. He ended the congress two weeks later by expressing glee that the fifty-megaton bomb that was exploded turned out to be more powerful than anticipated.
The industry and labor community of the port of New York closed ranks yesterday to save one of its important assets -the Brooklyn Army Terminal.
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 1 -The Indian Government expressed strong displeasure today with criticism in the United States of its position on nuclear testing.
CHICAGO, NOV. 1 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Business equipment, rubber and electronics issues were strong in a broad and generally higher session of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. But steels and a generous assortment of blue chips worked downward.
Robert Moses charged yesterday that a State Senator was seeking $1,138,710 from the Long Island State Park Commission for land Mr. Moses said was worth $45,000.
