Following is the text of a statement issued last night by Mayor Wagner in reply to Mr. Prendergast:
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 1 -- Life in a Paris sewer, when reproduced in Hollywood, is more complex than in a Victor Hugo novel.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 1 (UPI) -- Nico Snijders, port director of Amsterdam, the Netherlands, said today that the St. Lawrence Seaway had led to a new pattern of grain shipments from the Midwestern United States to Europe.

Leonard Spigelgass, author of the successful comedy, "A Majority of One," which was his first Broadway attempt, is thinking of becoming a producer. What he intends to put on is "The Freethinkers," the play he wrote about his father.
LONDON, Nov. 1 -- The British Government announced plans today to control immigration from Commonwealth nations. The control measure will end centuries of tradition.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. -- The President of the Republic of Senegal gave a reading of his poems today before an academic audience at Harvard University.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 1 -- The United States reaffirmed today the West's readiness to sign a treaty banning nuclear testing despite the current Soviet tests.

The United States Equestrian Team appeared to have the international jumping event at Madison Square Garden all wrapped up last night until a protest dropped the Americans from contention and made Canada the winner.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 1 -- Mr. Krishna Mellon criticized the United States and the Soviet Union in a speech in the General Assembly's Political Committee on Oct. 17.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Nov. 1 (Religious News Service) -- The Rev. Dr. Billy Graham, the evangelist, entered the debate over fall-out shelters today with an appeal for community rather than private shelters.
Princeton, already suspected of suffering from overconfidence for its game with Brown at Providence Saturday, has another, more tangible, problem.
Most commodity futures rose in light to moderate trading yesterday on the New York exchanges.
DETROIT, Nov. 1 -- Both the Chrysler Corporation and the United Automobile Workers reported progress tonight toward reaching a new labor contract.

Exports of civilian goods dipped in September for the second straight month, the Bureau of the Census reported yesterday. They amounted to $1,613,200,000 on a seasonally adjusted basis, down 2 per cent from the August figure of $1,652,600,000.
LONDON, Nov. 1 -- The British Army of the Rhine, the major British element in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization forces, was described today as short of both manpower and equipment.
NORWALK, Conn., Nov. 1 -- A Negro has brought suit against a long-established integrated housing development here to permit him to buy one of its homes.

JERRY OESTREICHER, who is a regular Monday night bridge player, was declarer in the deal shown today. He made an unusual and very acute play to make his contract, while his friends professed amazement and insisted that he must have pulled the wrong card.
SANTA FE, N.M., Nov. 1 (UPI) -- The New Mexico Supreme Court today upheld an $18,700 jury award to a farm wife struck and injured by a basketball while watching a Harlem Globetrotter game.
NEWBURGH, N.Y., Nov. 1 -- City Manager Joseph McD. Mitchell offered today to resign Dec. 31 if his social and economic reform program was not endorsed in the election Tuesday.

BELIZE, British Honduras, Nov. 1 (UPI) -- Sir Colin Thornley had been scheduled to return to London today after completing a six-year term as Governor here. He remained to direct the relief operations and to get clean-up work started.
DETROIT, Nov. 1 (AP) -- The Detroit Pistons finally scored their first victory of the National Basketball Association season tonight by defeating the New York Knickerbockers, 111-95.

Almost three-quarters of the $40,000,000 authorized promissory notes offered to the public by the New York World's Fair 1964-1965 Corporation have been subscribed, the corporation announced yesterday.

ALGIERS, Nov. 1 -- Eighty-six persons were officially listed as having been killed and about 150 wounded in demonstrations in Algeria today. The demonstrations marked the seventh anniversary of the nationalist rebellion against France.

IT is the plain cooking that counts. Great dishes may be served for great occasions, but a simple dish well made gives the greatest pleasure day by day. This is the opinion of Edla Gustavsson who was trained for four years in European cooking schools.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 1 -- A Soviet spokesman said today that the Soviet Union was "near agreement" with the United States "on a reasonable solution" for the deadlock over the election of a temporary successor to Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold.

Los Angeles, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Elgin Baylor scored 41 points and Jerry West 30 in leading the Los Angeles Lakers to a 120-115 victory over the Cincinnati Royals in a National Basketball Association game tonight.

I believe that the time has come to clarify the issues in the campaign for the office of Controller of the City of New York, particularly in light of the letter of the Democratic candidate published Oct. 26.

The boards of directors of the Rapid-American Corporation and Motec Industries, Inc., formerly known as the Minneapolis-Moline Company, have worked out an agreement in principle for a merger of the two concerns.
CHICAGO, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
REDYEING is an economical way to redecorate the apartment or revamp a wardrobe.

More than fifty representatives of New York State savings banks sat down with State Banking Superintendent Oren Root yesterday to discuss a possible increase in the maximum interest rates the banks could pay on savings deposits.
Following are sketches of the Nobel prize winners in since for 1961, announced today in Stockholm:

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 2 -- Levi Eshkol, a habitual optimist and an affable and adroit politician, succeeded this week in making a coalition Government possible where Premier David Ben-Gurion had failed.
Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose by $19,000,000 to $74,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 2 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru attempted to explain here today why Indian thinking sometimes differed sharply from that in West.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- The Pentagon said today that Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara intended to keep a speaking engagement in Atlanta Nov. 11 despite a protest by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

A group of airlines has filed suit in Federal court in California against Air Travelers Credit Card, Inc., to keep the Hollywood company from infringing on the trade-mark and trade name of Universal Air Travel Plan.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Former President Eisenhower is urging three members of his Cabinet to run for Governor of their states next year as part of his campaign to revitalize the Republican party.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The city's chief pathologist was suspended for ten days today because, by his own word, he falsified the cause of death in an autopsy report.
TODAY'S deal is reported from one of the team matches in the Metropolitan Commercial Bridge League in New York, but it might have come straight out of a book of bridge lessons.

SOUTH PLAINFIELD, N.J., Nov. 2 -- Plans have been announced for a $22,000,000 light-industry and research community here. In addition to manufacturing and research facilities, it is to include a 200-room hotel, a recreation center and an expansion of Hadley Airport.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Nov. 2 (UPI) -- The Army tonight fired its versatile Pershing missile on a "zig-zag" flight across the Atlantic in a successful test of its guidance system.

It has been called to my attention that an editorial in the Nov. 1 issue of your eminent newspaper failed to show that the Queens County Bar Association had also listed Albert H. Buschman and Lester Holtzman as qualified in the Tenth Judicial District for the Supreme Court.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Freight movements last week were substantially higher than a year-ago levels, the railroad and trucking industries reported today.
Carmine G. De Sapio, former leader of Tammany Hall, announced yesterday that he would not vote for Mayor Wagner next Tuesday, but would vote for other Democratic candidates.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Harry S. Truman accused former President Dwight D. Eisenhower today of doing "the wrong things" on Cuba and of holding this country back by other "wrong and unwise policies."

Governor Rockefeller recently suggested a systematic program for building housing in the air rights over public improvements. In the discussion which has followed no one seems to have noticed that the first supra-highway housing in Manhattan is a tribute to the remarkable foresight of the City Council's minority leader, Stanley Isaacs.

GEORGE SUGARMAN has just won an award for one of his sculptures at the Pittsburgh International. By a coincidence, other pieces of his are currently on display at the Radich Gallery, 818 Madison Avenue, and they make up a quite madly arbitrary collection that is, at times, oddly attractive.
Six large corporations handed out new executive titles yesterday.
BERLIN, Nov. 2 -- A United States Army convoy bringing replacements to Berlin traveled without incident along the 110 miles of the Autobahn from West Germany today.

WARSAW, Nov. 2 -- Qualified Communist sources said today that the Soviet Union would announce within forty-eight hours that its nuclear explosions earlier this week, including the blast of about fifty megatons, were the last in its current test series.

Production of lumber in the nation rose to a four-month high of 237,160,000 board feet last week from 229,778,000 board feet in the preceding week, according to reports received from regional associations. This is the highest point since 240,648,000 board feet were produced in the week ended June 24. A year ago 225,662,000 board feet were produced.

The award of the Nobel Prize in Chemistry to Dr. Melvin Calvin of the University of California honors an outstanding American scientist for his fundamental discoveries in photosynthesis -- the harnessing of the energy of sunlight by the green pigment in plants, which creates the food for man and animal out of air and water.

A leading role in each of the one-act operas that make up Puccini's "Il Trittico" was in new hands in the performance by the New York City Opera at the City Center last night. Chester Ludkin was a new Michele in "Il Tabarro," Doris Jung a new Suor Angelica in the opera of that name, and Joy Clements a new Lauretta in "Gianni Schicchi."

A six-pound rhesus monkey with a tiny radio transmitter embedded in its stomach is scheduled to take a 6,000-mile ride aboard an Atlas missile in a week or so.
BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Nov. 2 -- George E. Davidson of Newark yesterday succeeded Robert Jacobson of Rumson as president of the New Jersey Golf Association.

Daniele Barioni, who has not sung with the Metropolitan Opera in the last two seasons, returned to the company last night. The Italian tenor sang the role in which he made his Met debut in February, 1956 -- Cavaradossi in "Tosca."

John Veckly, director of advertising of the United States Steel Corporation, has been elected chairman of the Association of National Advertisers. Mr. Veckly, who had been vice chairman of the association, succeeds Roger H. Bolin, director of advertising for the Westinghouse Electric Company.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Two more Soviet nuclear tests were exploded early today in the atmosphere, the United States Atomic Energy Commission announced. They were the twenty-ninth and thirtieth test explosions of the current Soviet series announced by the A.E.C.

The election of the Rev. Dr. Joseph P. Sternstein, spiritual leader of Beth Abraham Synagogue of Dayton, Ohio, as executive director of the Jewish National Fund of America was announced last night by Albert Schiff, president of the fund.
TRENTON, Nov. 2 -- President Kennedy told an enthusiastic Democratic rally here tonight that he was proud to come to New Jersey to urge the election of Richard J. Hughes as Governor.
ELISABETHVILLE, Nov. 2 (Reuters) -- The Katanga Government said today that its forces were pushing back the invading central Government army.
A study of pollution in Raritan Bay and its tributary, the Arthur Kill, was begun this week by the United States Public Health Service. It is expected to be completed next summer.

THE Christian Anti-Communism Crusade, which in recent months has been attracting substantial audiences in Southern California, came to New York last night by means of a three-hour telecast over Station WPIX (Channel 11).
NEWARK, Nov. 2 -- New Jersey will vote next Tuesday on four public questions, as well as choose a new Governor and local officials.

PERSEPOLIS, Iran, Oct. 31 -- For the first time since before Alexander burned Persepolis nearly 2,300 years ago the great Persepolis plain is echoing to the sound of hammers at work on a monumental construction.
EVANSTON, Ill, Nov. 2 -- The United States has decided to back a Nigerian resolution in the United Nations calling for the end of all colonial rule in Africa, by 1970.

Willie Shoemaker extended his lead over the other jockeys riding at Aqueduct by registering five victories yesterday. The cool-riding Californian has been capitalizing on the absence of his nearest rival, Manuel Ycaza, who is sitting out a ten-day suspension that will continue through Monday.

Dartmouth, which has been off the screen for six years, returns to television tomorrow with a variety show that promises to produce plenty of exciting entertainment for those not at the Yale Bowl. Some rugged critics in Yale football gear, however, are prepared to hand the Bob Blackman production bad notices -- they hope.
The Canadian Equestrian team earned its second international jumping victory of the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden last night when Tom Gayford won the Wagstaff Challenge Trophy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (UPI) -- In a move designed to protect the investing public, the Securities and Exchange Commission promulgated today five tough new rules to govern advertising by investment advisers. They will go into effect on Jan. 1, 1962.

The terms of the Treasury's $6,963,000,000 refunding operation, announced after the close of the Government bond market, made the market's closing statistics a matter of mere record. Some price rises registered yesterday are likely to be reversed today, it was said.
CHICAGO, Nov. 2 (UPI) -- Negotiators for gasoline and fuel oil distributors and the Teamsters Union came to terms tonight on a contract agreement to end a trucking strike here.
President Kennedy strongly endorsed Mayor Wagner yesterday for a third term.

ALMADEN, Calif., Nov. 2 (UPI) -- Larry Mowry, a San Diego professional and Johnny Lotz, a San Leandro (Calif.) amateur, tied for the first-round lead today in the $10,000 Almaden open golf tournament with 67's.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- President Kennedy ordered today that preparations be made for the resumption of atmospheric atomic tests that might be found necessary to maintain United States superiority in nuclear weapons.
The New York Daily News said in an editorial today that it was not supporting any of the candidates for Mayor.

All age groups will be entertained at a benefit to be held aboard the Liberte on Thursday for the building fund of the Lycee Francais de New York. It is being sponsored by the school's mothers committee.
PARIS, Nov. 2 -- The Liberte, the French Line's proud old flagship, sailed today on her last North-Atlantic crossing to New York.

PARIS, Nov. 2 -- Hopes for peace in Algeria survived yesterday's bloodshed during the Moslem demonstrations there and even rose slightly today on the strength of conciliatory statements by rebel leaders.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission said today it still was not sure, because of the electrical equipment price-fixing cases, whether Westinghouse and General Electric should be given renewed licenses for their radio and television stations.
HOUSTON, Tex., Nov. 2 (UPI) -- Walter W. Fondren Jr., son of an oil pioneer and president of the Fondren Oil Company, strangled on a piece of steak last night.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 2 -- An appeal to the atomic powers to refrain from nuclear tests was voted today 72 to 21, despite a clear-cut warning that it was opposed by the United States, Britain and the Soviet Union.

SEOUL, Korea, Nov. 2 -- Japan's chief negotiator in the talks with South Korea now in progress in Tokyo arrived here today, apparently to put a Japanese proposal directly before the leaders of South Korea's military Government.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (UPI) -- Howard Hughes, through his wholly-owned Hughes Tool Company, asked the Civil Aeronautics Board today for permission to supply money to Northeast Airlines at once.

ALBANY, Nov. 2 -- The Democratic legislative leaders registered their opposition today to the proposed constitutional amendment that would place the state's credit behind $100,000,000 worth of new borrowing by the Port of New York Authority.
BURLINGTON, N.J., Nov. 2 -- Mr. Hughes spent the morning and afternoon campaigning before going to Trenton tonight for the rally with President Kennedy.

The chairman of the political science department at City College told a student rally yesterday that the City University's ban on Communist speakers was "a gross violation of academic freedom unsupported by law."

Richard Amend, a 26-year-old New York pianist who last performed here in 1954, gave a concert last night at Carnegie Recital Hall. During the intervening years he has given concerts in Europe and has taught privately.

FOR better or for worse, one of the irresistible themes of song and story is the desperate effort of the actor or the clown behind the greasepaint to find and assert himself. "Kean," which arrived last night at the Broadway, handles it distinctly for the better.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (UPI) -- The United States announced yesterday a new program to speed the disposal of its stockpile of natural rubber. Effective today, it permits sales of up to 5,000 long tons (2,240 pounds each) a month at any market price.
SOUTHAMPTON, England, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The liner United States became today the largest ship to sail out to sea through the narrow westerly channel past the Isle of Wight, known as The Needles.
Pleasure boating is becoming safer. New York State's Conservation Department at Albany has tabulated fifty-four deaths in boating accidents so far this year, contrasted to seventy during 1960.

A crate filled with cosmic ray measuring equipment was shipped to the University of Minnesota yesterday as the result of the curiosity displayed by five passengers on a Europe-bound United States Lines freighter.
THE wealth, poverty, glamour and bitterness of Brazil were captured in eloquent bits of film on Channel 2's "C.B.S. Reports" last night.

STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 2 -- In their foreign travels, Radcliffe College alumnae who live in Fairfield County spread international goodwill through a highly respected custom. When they buy something they are likely to buy it by the dozen or better.
LONDON, Nov. 2 -- Hugh Gaitskell was re-elected leader of the Parliamentary Labor party tonight by an overwhelming majority of his fellow members.

PARIS, Oct. 31 -- A draft statute or treaty for a closer political union of the six nations of the European Common Market has been proposed by France and is being studied in the capitals of the five other member nations.
Quiet prevailed on all New York commodity exchanges yesterday. Trading was light.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 2 -- The United States defended the 1,200 professional staff members of the United Nationsl today in the General Assembly's Budgetary Committee.

HAKONE, Japan, Nov. 2 -- The United States was represented today as believing that Finland would receive the unanimous support of the non-Communist world if the Soviet Union made any move against her.
Bipartisan proponents of court reorganization through Amendment 1 to the State Constitution were optimistic yesterday as they looked forward to Election Day next Tuesday.
LONDON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Britain's amateur boxing team sent the United States to a 10-0 defeat tonight before an excited crowd of 4,000 fans at the Wembley indoor stadium.

ACCRA, Ghana, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Fifty members of the Peace Corps working in twenty-seven schools throughout Ghana are helping to ease the acute teacher shortage while winning new friends for the United States.
One of the more obvious marks of the fearless football player is a horizontal gash across the bridge of the nose. Mickey Walker, a rookie lineman with the New York Giants, has the mark.
A half-dozen New Yorkers intent on solving the world's housing problems, and maybe even a few of their own, have created something new in modern living -- a paper house.
STOCKHOLM, Nov. 2 -- Nobel prizes in science for 1961 were awarded today to a chemist and a physicist from the United States and a physicist from West Germany, now in the United States.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Department store sales in the nation for the week ended Saturday, Oct. 28, were 2 per cent above the level of a year earlier.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 2 -- The Department of Defense has authorized a study of the use of a proposed East-West freeway tunnel here as a fallout and bomb shelter. The study will be at the expense of the Federal Government.

Stocks advanced yesterday for the fourth consecutive day. The rise, although only moderate, was larger than the three preceding ones. Trading on the New York Stock Exchange was both broader and more active than on Wednesday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Medical experts voiced cautious hope today that progress was being made in the fight against cancer, but they warned against expecting any overnight miracles.

THE latest of the state's hunter-cooperative areas opened Wednesday with the small-game season at Ridge, L.I. Called the Suffolk County Hunter Cooperative, it consists of 3,500 acres and it will grow to 4,100 next week.

BELIZE, British Honduras. Nov. 2 (UPI) -- Three United States Navy ships and a British frigate brought aid today to this British crown colony shattered by a hurricane. Sailors stripped blankets from their bunks for the refugees.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The Weather Bureau said today that the cloud of radioactive debris from the Soviet Union's nuclear blast of about fifty megatons might brush across more of the United States than had been forecast earlier.

CANNED applesauce may not seem a particularly inspiring product at this season when the fresh fruit is at its peak of plenty. But from an economic point of view the canned sauce deserves attention. There is such a large stockpile of the product that prices are at rock bottom.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- The Treasury announced plans today for an exchange-and-cash refinancing next week.

SCARSDALE, Nov. 2 -- The development of a Westchester County art center costing at least $2,000,000 became a goal tonight of the new Westchester Art Society, successor to the Westchester Arts and Crafts Guild.

A new issue of $56,500,000 of revenue bonds of the Oklahoma Turnpike Authority is being offered for public subscription today by a syndicate managed by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner ner Smith, Inc., Allen Co., White, Weld Co., John Nuveen Co., Inc., B.J. Van Ingen Co., Inc. and Leo Oppenheim Co.

WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 2 -- Lehigh Hanover, a leading 2-year-old pacer this season, today drew the No. 7 post position in a field of eleven for the $86,533 Roosevelt Futurity Monday night. The event will be the richest harness race for juveniles this year.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Sara Kouri Barreto, sister-in-law of Dr. Raul Roa, Cuban Foreign Minister, requested political asylum in the United States today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- "Hot" money has been flowing again from the United States to London. The published figures do not show it yet, but official actions on both sides of the Atlantic reflect it.

SINCE Second Avenue isn't what it used to be, part of the Yiddish theatre has decided to move uptown. Last night, some troupers familiar to the Lower East Side settled just off Broadway and presented a musical play, "Go Fight City Hall," at the Mayfair Theatre.
CHICAGO, Nov. 2 (AP) -- A fast late decline in grain futures prices left the market mostly weak today after it had held generally firm in earlier transactions on the Board of Trade.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 2 -- A high State Department official indicated today that he believed the Soviet Union was no longer eager to have Communist China admitted to the United Nations.
JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 2 -- The Justice Department moved today to halt defiance of a ruling by the Interstate Commerce Commission against segregation in public transportation.

The Grand Ballroom of the Astor provided a gold and white setting last night for the Angels Ball. Ceiling streamers, tablecloths and napkins carried out the color scheme and the centerpiece on each table was a white angel with golden wings surrounded by golden autumn leaves and flowers.
TOLEDO, Ohio, Nov. 2 (AP) -- A new ordinance that prohibits discrimination in the sale, rental or financing of real estate was held unconstitutional today by Common Pleas Judge Harvey G. Straub.
ATLANTA, Nov. 2 (AP) -- A three-judge Federal Court to hear Georgia's attack on the Interstate Commerce Commission's bus station order includes one of the newest United States judges.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (UPI) -- The Vietnamese Ambassador, Tran Van Chuong, said today a "token force" of United States troops should be sent to South Vietnam to demonstrate United States willingness to fight and to prevent a Communist miscalculation leading to a big war.
HARRISON, N.J., Nov. 2 -- James P. Mitchell, the Republican candidate for Governor, today received his most cordial reception at an industrial establishment since the start of his campaign.
Chevrolet, which forty years ago was told "it could not hope to compete in its field," will mark its fiftieth anniversary today as the world's best selling car.
NEW HAVEN, Nov. 2 -- This state's eighty-two-year-old birth control law is being challenged anew by the Planned Parenthood League of Connecticut, Inc.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., Nov. 2 -- The growing tendency of big business to resist innovation and discourage innovators was decried today by William T. Brady, chairman of the Corn Products Company.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Senate rackets investigators were reported today deployed in New York, the Chicago area and cities overseas seeking evidence on prostitution and narcotics ringleaders.
Ambitious expansion plans were announced yesterday by Interstate Department Stores, Inc., which is rapidly increasing its discount operations, and the W.T. Grant Company, a variety store chain.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 2 -- The West German Government crisis was intensified tonight.

FURTHER proof of the concentration of significant twentieth century painting and sculpture in American private possession will be established in the exhibition, "Cincinnati Collects," opening today at Knoedler's, 14 East Fifty-seventh Street, for the benefit of the Cincinnati Contemporary Art Center.
Mayor Wagner announced last night that the city would guarantee that properly inspected milk could be brought into New York -- with police protection if necessary.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Business executives who would man Government posts in a national emergency will brush up on their roles at a series of regional conferences starting next week.
LONDON, Nov. 2 -- Stock market prices turned irregular here today after yesterday's general advance.

DETROIT, Nov. 2 (UPI) -- Gordie Howe's sixth goal of the season early in the second period tonight gave the Detroit Red Wings a 1-0 victory over the New York Rangers and snapped a three-game losing streak.

MONTREAL, Nov. 2 (UPI) -- The last-place Boston Bruins lost an early two-goal lead tonight but came scrambling back to upset the first-place Montreal Canadiens, 5 -- 2, in a National Hockey League game.
Two politicians of considerable experience are fighting for the job of Borough President of Staten Island.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Nov. 2 -- The Port of New York Authority was told today it must pay taxes on a factory it built on Teterboro Airport land in Moonachie and leased for twenty years to a private concern. The ruling was made by Superior Court Judge Charles W. Broadhurst.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 2 -- There appears to be no end to Army's bad luck in the loss of top personnel through injury.
President Kennedy has made a difficult decision in ordering preparations for tests of nuclear weapons in the atmosphere.

Directors of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), at a meeting held here yesterday, declared a final quarter dividend of 65 cents a share on the capital stock. The dividend will be paid on Dec. 11 to stockholders of record of Nov. 13.
LONDON, Nov. 2 -- The Government reduced the bank rate from 6 1/2 per cent to 6 per cent today. But it again stressed that it was not relaxing its credit restriction policy.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- President Kennedy and representatives of four Middle Atlantic States today signed the Delaware River Compact -- aimed at fuller development of the river basin's water resources.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 2 -- U Thant of Burma will be elected Acting Secretary General of the United Nations tomorrow to fill the unexpired term of the late Dag Hammarskjold. The term expires April 10, 1963.

MIAMI BEACH, Nov. 2 -- Federal Housing Commissioner Neal J. Hardy said today that steps were being taken to reduce the time -- now estimated at more than 100 days -- that it takes to close an F.H.A.-insured loan on a home.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Nov. 2 (AP) -- Alabama has retained a North Carolina anthropologist in a "scientific" approach to the race issue, The Montgomery Advertiser said today.

This year -- next Tuesday -- the conscientious voter must be relied on to be even more selective than usual in respect to the levers at the top of the voting machine. Our advice is to vote Yes on Amendments 1, 2, 3 and 4, then vote No on 5, 6 and 7.

Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa, the Citizens party candidate for Mayor, hammered away yesterday in Manhattan and the Bronx at the city's "fiscal mess" and Mayor Wagner's relations with persons doing business with the city.
Mayor Wagner and Police Commissioner Michael J. Murphy told a graduating class of patrolmen yesterday that freer use of their nightsticks would not solve the city's crime problem.

Details for the conduct of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's third annual soccer championship have been announced by Cliff Stevenson, Brown's coach and the chairman of the N.C.A.A. soccer rules committee.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Nov. 2 -- Another tribute was paid today to the fabled Adios, this time in the form of hard cash. Twenty-one progeny of the pacer were purchased for a total of $489,500, an average of almost $23,310, on the final day of the Standard bred Horse Sales here.

Loans to business by the fourteen weekly reporting Federal Reserve member banks in New York rose by $109,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
Russ Warren, Columbia's best all-around back, is a doubtful starter in the game with Cornell tomorrow at Ithaca.

IF Lee Grosscup, the forgotten quarterback of the Giants, needs any encouragement -- which he undoubtedly does -- he can take heart from the strange case of Sonny Jurgensen, quarterback of the Philadelphia Eagles and the sharpshooting leader among the National Football League forward passers this season.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Nearly 1,700 Cincinnati milk delivery drivers, rebeling against James R. Hoffa's Teamsters Union, received a charter of affiliation in the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations today.
James Thurber, the writer and humorist, died of pneumonia yesterday afternoon at Doctors Hospital, where he had undergone surgery a month ago for a blood clot on the brain. His age was 66.
The Port of New York Authority's $90,000,000 development along the Brooklyn waterfront became two-thirds finished yesterday with the dedication of Pier 8 in the Baltic Terminal Area.
BERLIN, Nov. 2 -- Ranking officials of East Germany's Socialist Unity (Communist) party answered questions about Stalinism and the "cult of personality" for the first time in a public forum tonight.

MOSCOW, Nov. 2 -- There are indications that Premier Khrushchev has plunged a significant section of the Soviet population into a state of profound shock and ferment by his latest charges of tyranny by Stalin. It is the view of experienced observers here that the social forces unleashed by Mr. Khrushchev will have a long-term effect on public attitudes toward the claims of infallibility of the Soviet regime and the credibility of its propaganda.
LONDON, Nov. 2 -- The British Government said today that the Soviet Government had shown little willingness to negotiate a reasonable and satisfactory solution of the Berlin crisis.

The North Atlantic Continental Freight Conference yesterday served notice to shippers that their dual freight rate contracts would be canceled in ninety days unless they agreed to a modification of their agreements.
Bank clearings in the twenty-six leading cities in the nation rose to $29,655,175,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday.

For nearly a month now it has seemed probable that U. Thant, permanent head of the Burmese delegation to the U.N., would be the next Secretary General. The discussion during the intervening weeks has not concerned U Thant's personality or ability, but his relationship to the membership and to the rest of the Secretariat.

When President Kennedy came to New York yesterday, he gave Mayor Wagner a bubble-top ride from the airport and the usual statement of support. He didn't snub him, but he didn't campaign for him, either.
A plan to speed homeward return of Puerto Ricans not eligible for long-term relief here was announced yesterday by the Department of Welfare and the Commonwealth's Migration Division.

" Double Bunk," a British comedy with Ian Carmichael and Janette Scott, will open at the Guild Theatre on Nov. 16, following the current "Question 7." Sidney James, Liz Fraser and Dennis Price are also in the Showcorporation release, which was directed and written by C.M. Pennington-Richards.
Twenty-three Syracuse milk dealers who allegedly engaged in price-fixing agreements have been enjoined from such practices, Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz said here yesterday.
In this final week of the gubernatorial campaign I want to express once again my wholehearted support of Jim Mitchell's candidacy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- President Kennedy is certain that the nuclear weapons tests the Soviet Union is conducting in the atmosphere are designed to provide information pertinent to their purpose. And since this purpose is to attain military mastery of the world, the President had to make a countering security move.
President Leopold Sedar Senghor of the Republic of Senegal said here yesterday that Africans were guided by a "principle of reunion" that was "oriented toward the complete communion of all people."
The wives of leading Republican candidates toured Brooklyn yesterday, beginning and ending with coffee parties.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Nov. 2 -- Prime Minister Hendrik F. Verwoerd announced early today the appointment of two English-speaking members of his Cabinet. They are Alfred E. Trolip, administrator of Natal province, and Frank W. Waring, a former South African international rugby football player.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 2 -- The world of Latin-American political and social upheaval is widely separated from the day-to-day world of garbage collection and road repair in a New Jersey suburban community. But William W. Marvel, father of two and a commuter, is involved in the complexities of each.
JERUSALEM, Nov. 2 -- Premier David Ben-Gurion won the approval of the Knesset (Parliament) tonight for a new coalition Government for Israel. The vote was 63 to 46.

The spiritual leader of the Park Avenue Synagogue, 50 East Eighty-seventh Street, will be honored tonight by his congregation on the twenty-fifth anniversary of his ordination to the rabbinate.

HAKONE, Japan, Nov. 2 -- Fourteen of the highest ranking officials of Japan and the United States sat around a table in a mountain top hotel today and tried to reconcile the needs of a political alliance with the pressures of economic competition.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Maj. Gen. Edwin A. Walker made known today his decision to resign from the Army.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., Nov. 3 -- Towering over the waters of Hampton Roads, the nuclear carrier Enterprise returned to her builder's yards today after successful sea trials.
HARTFORD, Nov. 3 -- Alan S. Boyd, chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, called today for mergers among the domestic airlines to reduce excess competition.
Roman Catholics here will pay reverent homage this weekend to Pope John XXIII, who will observe in Rome today both the third anniversary of his coronation and his eightieth birthday.
Maj. Gen. Edwin A. Walker's valedictory to the Army was a composite of exhortation, frustration and an almost fanatical belief in the rightness of his own views.
The Methodist Church announced yesterday it had filed plans for a $2,000,000 interdenominational church center for the promotion of peace and the study of international affairs.
It has been nine years since Arch Oboler's last movie, "Bwana Devil," the first film feature in 3-D (made for $323,000), took in a phenomenal $5,000,000 at the box office.

GREENSBURG, Pa., Nov. 3 (AP) -- Benjamin F. Fairless, 71 years old, former president of the United States Steel Corporatiofi, has filed suit for divorce on the ground of indignities. Robert E. Brooker, after one day as president of Montgomery Ward Co., indicated yesterday that he would seek to develop a strong source of supply for the products sold by the giant mail order and retail store concern.

DESPITE the fact that the exemption from duty on goods purchased abroad has now been reduced to $100, an American tourist can still indulge in a shopping spree here provided he buys antiques made before 1830.
AN hour of fun, much of it delightful, brightened Channel 2 last night in the course of the "Chevrolet Golden Anniversary Show."
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 3 -- The General Assembly unanimously elected U Thant of Burma as Acting Secretary General of the United Nations today.

" Hate literature" that was distributed in the primary campaign last September to picture Mayor Wagner as a "Communist puppet" has been traced to the regular Democratic organizations in the Bronx and Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The United States has borrowed $46,300,000 in Swiss francs from Switzerland's national bank as another step in the Treasury's increasing operations in the international money market.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 15 cents a bale up on the May contract, to 5 to 30 cents off on the others yesterday.

The administrators of the city colleges helped -- rather than hurt -- the interests of the Communist party with their recent decision to prohibit Communists from speaking at student forums. Witness the experience of Benjamin J. Davis, the party's national secretary, whose invitation to address a Queens College group led to the ban.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 3 -- Only a few weeks ago Dr. Gerhard Schroeder told a visitor to his office: "This chair suits me perfectly." He was talking about the job he had held since 1953 as West Germany's Interior Minister.

PARIS, Nov. 3 -- Industrial production in the European Economic Community has virtually flattened in the last four or five months after a steady climb since the beginning of 1959, the Executive Commission reported today.
Music in Greenwich Village is commonly thought to consist of beat and off-beat jazz, folk and avant-garde concerts conducted in parks and coffee houses, mainly between police raids.
DETROIT, Nov. 3 -- The new agreement between the Chrysler Corporation and the United Automobile Workers opens the way for three years of labor peace in the automobile industry.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- President Kennedy sent a message to Adlai E. Stevenson, United States representative at the United Nations, hailing the election of U Thant of Burma as Acting Secretary General.
Dr. John J. Theobald, Superintendent of Schools, indicated yesterday that hurricanes and snowstorms last year might cost the Board of Education $3,500,000 in state aid.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Oct. 31 -- "Internal emigration" is very much alive and active today in Budapest. There are many -- the number is impossible to determine -- who chose to "emigrate spiritually" from communism and remain physically at home after the 1956 revolt.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 3 -- Both geographically and ideologically the office of the chief executive of U.N. has been moving eastward. The United States professes delight with the selection of Mr. Thant as effective successor to Mr. Hammarskjold. We claim the choice as our diplomatic victory and point out that Russia has yielded on its demand for a ruling triumvirate.

One of the lightest weeks in months is ahead in the market for new capital, with only $28,742,000 in fixed interest securities up for sale. Several common stock issues are planned and would raise the volume, although not dramatically.
OTTAWA, Nov. 3 (Canadian Press) -- Canada's merchandise trade deficit for the year was cut sharply by a $22,900,000 surplus in August as the Canadian dollar's exchange discount made its effects felt.

A former Internal Revenue agent and a certified public accountant were indicted yesterday on bribery charges. The agent was said to have been bribed to "corruptly examine" corporate and personal income tax returns of Alexander L. Guterma, his wife and others.
ANNISTON, Ala., Nov. 3 (UPI) -- Federal Judge H.H. Grooms ruled a mistrial today in the case of seven men accused in the burning of a bus of Freedom Riders here on May 14.
LONDON, Nov. 3 -- Britain warned the Soviet Union tonight that she had enough nuclear power to eliminate most of the big Russian cities.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (UPI) -- The Justice Department moved today to block Louisiana officials from obstructing desegregation of bus terminals. The action was taken in a suit filed at Shreveport.

Mary Martin will be honored for her efforts in behalf of service men and the United Service Organizations at a luncheon to be given at the Pierre on Nov. 14. The "Salute to Mary Martin" is being sponsored by the New York City U.S.O. Committee.
LONDON, Nov. 3 -- Plans to launch a European satellite in mid-1965 were announced today.
Federal Judge William B. Herlands yesterday denied a motion for a new trial by Dr. Robert A. Soblen, the convicted Soviet spy.

LAST Tuesday, in an emergency arising from the mid-performance, illness of Leontyne Price, Dorothy Kirsten took over at a moment's notice the third act of Puccini's "La Fanciulla del West" at the Metropolitan Opera House.
BATON ROUGE, La., Nov. 3 (UPI) -- An outbreak of frenzied, impromptu pep rallies by Louisiana State University students nearly got out of hand early today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The National Cash Register Company has produced a boon for the supermarket checkout clerk -- an attachment that automatically counts trading stamps and hands them out for each purchase.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Nov. 3 (AP) -- Six Air Force technicians reportedly found a possible clue today to the mystery of the whir that has made a modest, brick cottage a madhouse for the Binkowski family.
May I sum up briefly about the proposed City Charter?
Bobbie Brooks, Inc., manufacturer of apparel for young women, has disclosed plans to acquired Stacy Ames, Inc., and Kelly Arden, Inc., New York City dress manufacturers.
MIAMI, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Miami's football team turned five breaks into touchdowns tonight for a 32-0 lead and then coasted with third and fourth stringers to a 32-7 victory over Georgia.

THE most publicized attic search in history has resulted in an informative exhibition of Presidential tablewares, which opened last week at the Art Institute of Chicago and will continue through Dec. 3.
PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 3 -- Thornton Wilder's play "Our Town" has returned for the first time to the scene of its premiere.

ROME, Nov. 3 -- Pope John XXIII spoke in a cheerful and optimistic tone today to three groups that gathered in the Vatican to offer congratulations on his eightieth birthday and the third anniversary of his coronation.

As the quarterback cocked his passing arm. Allan Webb cut in sharply from the sideline near the midfield stripe. The ball was slightly overthrown, but the rookie halfback halted its spiraling flight with one outstretched hand.

An off-duty Port Authority patrolman was fatally shot last night trying to halt a fight in a Brooklyn candy store.

Mrs. Katherine Geddes Benedict, who died last Sunday at the age of 77, left an estate worth about $7,000,000, according to an affidavit filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday by her lawyer, Francis A. Brick.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 3 -- The Tennessee Valley Authority, in a new petition filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission, opposes a Southern Railway proposal for a "sharp reduction immediately in grain rates in multiple-car movements from Ohio and Mississippi River crossings to certain destinations in the Southeast."

EXERCISING a talent for establishing moods of gentle refinement, the painter Stuart Kaufman has a show at the Davis Gallery, 231 East Sixtieth Street, in which figure studies get on the right wave lengths with sitters.

Warrants for the arrest of two members of Fidel Castro's 26th of July movement were issued yesterday by Federal Judge Thomas F. Murphy. The men are believed to have fled to Cuba by way of Canada.

Wise Ship sailed a close-hauled course in the $55,900 Lexington Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday and lasted for a neck victory over the fast-closing Our Jeep. Art Market finished third, a length and a half farther back.
ALBANY, Nov. 4 -- Walter J. Joseph Mahoney, majority leader of the State Senate, called today for the adoption of Amendment 6 to the State Constitution.

PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti -- "Let us make of every tourist a friend of Haiti." These are the opening words of a regular Government-sponsored radio program designed to educate this little Caribbean republic of 4,000,000 citizens to the importance of tourism in the national economy.

A festival at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday evening will start a fund campaign for a building to house the industrial training activities of the Federation for the Handicapped.

Carlos Damm Jr. of the Argentine Equestrian Team received a tidy little birthday present at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden last night. Today is his nineteenth birthday. He acquired the $3,225 winner's share of the $7,500 purse that was at stake in the international jumping competition.

On November 5, as an annual event, the English people gaily celebrate a day when someone tried to kill the King. In fact, the noisy demonstrations which mark it as one of the liveliest occasion the world over commemorate the abortive attempt some three and a half centuries ago to assassinate not only King James I but his ministers and all the members of the Houses of Lords and Commons as well.
BOMBAY, India, Nov. 3 -- A firm and vigilant policy in dealing with Chinese aggression was advocated yesterday in a draft election manifesto of the Swantantra party.

KINGSTON, Jamaica -- There are happy faces throughout Jamaica as the island prepares itself for the 1961-62 winter season. ATLANTA, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Georgia Tech's defense smothered the Florida attack today and the Yellow Jackets capitalized on Gator mistakes for a 20-0 victory in a Southeastern Conference football game. The triumph was Tech's sixth against a single loss.

A team of Columbia University physicists has completed a two-year project of assembling one of the world's heaviest nuclear particle counters.
BERLIN, Nov. 4 -- The Berlin Opera gave a production of Verdi's "Aida" this week with five American singers in the cast, four of them in leading roles.
BRUNSWICK, Me., Nov. 4 -- Mike Panteleakos, a senior full-back, scored four touchdowns today to lead Bowdoin to a 31-20 victory over Bates at Whittier Field.

ALGIERS, Nov. 4 -- The state of mind of the French Army is a passionate subject in Algeria because the army can make or break a coup d'etat -- a coup the die-hard European extremists still hope for with desperation.
Gretchen King's reaction to your weeping woman of Berlin photograph underscores Swift's view of people as a collection of Yahoos without understanding or self-knowledge.
CHAPPAQUA, N.Y., Nov. 4 -- Horace Greeley of Chappaqua spoiled Pleasantville's bid for its first all-winning football season today by grinding out a 21-13 victory.

FOR six weeks I left my oxen and sheep, and ventured to Court, where I find many lean and kinded beastes and some not unhorned. Much was my comfort in being well received, notwithstanding it is an ill hour for seeing the Queen.
TRENTON, Nov. 4 -- New Jersey voters will decide Tuesday whether to keep state government in Democratic hands or turn it over to the Republicans.

BRIDGETOWN Barbados B.W.I. -- This small, green island is Exhibit A, at least in the Caribbean, of the good that jet transportation can do for a resort. The flying time from New York to Bridgetown, the island capital, is now about six hours and, as a result, Barbados has returned to the position it held a century ago -- that of traffic center in the Caribbean travel and trade routes.

THE "white man's burden" now appears to have been a disheveled knapsack of dynamite neatly dripping its powder trains around every latent bonfire on the colonial map. As Joseph Kraft indicates, a bane was stored up for each boon from native contact with Western civilization.

THE accent on cruises this winter will be more American than it has been in any year since this type of vacation became popular. The addition of greater American flavor to this highly specialized segment of the passenger shipping industry, one that has been traditionally dominated by foreign-flag liners, will be imparted by the extensive participation of United States-flag luxury ships.

" HOW antisocial, yet how enjoyable." So Desmond Young describes an interlude in Hollywood. The comment is in keeping with this brisk, ebullient autobiography of a man who has been salvor and night-club proprietor, soldier and author, editor and theatrical handyman, and who, quite unashamedly, has had a whale of a time.

HOMOSASSA SPRINGS, Fla. -- The Gulf Coast towns of Homosassa Springs and Homosassa are only two and one-half miles apart geographically; yet, they offer the visitor divergent views of Florida that might well be separated by half a century.
ANDERMATT, Switzerland -- My wife and are collecting European mountain passes these days, and we have just driven over a thousand miles of them in the French, Swiss and Italian Alps.

DAVID SUSSKIND'S two-hour production of "The Power and the Glory," starring Sir Laurence Olivier, was illustrative of one of television's recurring items of controversy. In light of the lackluster level of so much present-day video, what are the critical standards to be applied to such a special undertaking?

SAARBRUECKEN, Germany, Oct. 31 -- Nearly five years after the French occupation ended and the Saar reverted to Germany, the people of this small and wealthy frontier territory have developed friendlier sentiments for France than they ever had before.

DETROIT, Nov. 4 (AP) -- The United Auto Workers Union told the Bendix Corporation today that the union would strike next Friday midnight of agreement on a new national contract had not been reached then.

THIS first book by Prakash Tandon is a triumph of composition, observation and good writing. Mr. Tandon writes carefully -- his eye always cocked for the smallest detail, and his intelligence keeps nostalgia and false emotion at arm's length.

ENDOWED with the greatest profile since Barrymore and one of the most passionate theatrical personalities of our time, Jean-Louis Barrault, whom American audiences know best for his unforgettable performance in the film "Les Enfants du Paradis" ("Children of Paradise"), has slowly been building another kind of immortality.

ACCRA, Nov. 4 (AP) -- At the time of the predawn explosions today President Nkrumah was at his residence, Flagstaff House, guarded as usual by troops and policemen. He was "not unduly concerned by the explosions," a spokesman said.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- A new hospital has risen in the wastes north of the Arctic Circle, an area where doctors often treat patients by two-way radio.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Nov. 4 -- Mrs. William Gardner Mundy of Glen Cove heads the committee that is completing plans for the main fund-raising event of the North Long Island Vassar Club. Called "Christmas Samplar," the event will be held Wednesday, Thursday and Friday at the Christ Church parish house on East Main Street.

VERACRUZ, Mexico -- The buses leave Mexico City for this Gulf port frequently during the day. A first-class ticket costs 38 pesos, roughly $3.20, and the trip makes an interesting excursion for a traveler who wants a variation from the usual tourist pattern here.
BOSTON, Nov. 4 (UPI) -- Bob Cousy led the undefeated Celtics to their fourth victory today, a 127-107 triumph over the Syracuse Nationals in a nationally televised contest at Boston Garden.

Your layout, "Front Page to Film" (Oct. 22), pointed up some international aspects of the movie, "Congo Vivo." The American actress Jean Seberg was shown in Leopoldville working in the production about the Congo's struggle for independence, with President Kasavubu and General Mobutu appearing briefly as themselves.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 4 -- Ohio State converted two pass interceptions and a fumble into touchdowns today and remained unbeaten in the Big Ten with a 29-13 victory over Iowa. A crowd of 83,795, the biggest ever to see the Buckeyes in action here, was on hand.

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) reported earnings of $17,000,000 for the fiscal quarter ended on Sept. 30. This was more than $1,000,000 greater than the figure of a year earlier.

The job of selecting an advertising agency is widely considered to be one of the most complex tasks of corporate management. The selection process generally involves a variety of difficult judgments on such matters as the agency's financial structure, the strength of its management and the job it has done for existing accounts.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- The huge nuclear-powered aircraft carrier Enterprise outraced one of the greyhounds of the fleet, the destroyer Laffey, during sea trials in the Atlantic this week.

ROBERT SHAW is an actor who is currently displaying his considerable talents on Broadway in "The Caretaker." He is also a novelist, but he is not nearly so interesting or successful in that role. His second book, "The Sun Doctor," is a moral study, or at least an attempt to investigate certain aspects of human action from an ethical, even a quasi-religious, point of view.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., Nov. 4 -- Richard J. Hughes, the Democratic candidate for Governor, today challenged Republicans to cite one constructive program their candidate has offered that would meet the state's real needs.

Jorge Bolet, Abram Chasins, Van Cliburn, Fou Ts'ong and Leonard Pennario -- to list them alphabetically -- constitute the latest quintet of performers to record all-Chopin disks.

A FATHER of two child en -- one biologically his own, the other his by law -- was entertaining a new acquaintance at his home. Looking at the two youngsters, who were playing within earshot, the guest asked, "Which is the adopted one?"

ENGLISH HARBOUR, Antigua, B.W.I. -- Beside this finest, safest, small harbor in the Caribbean, the famous Nelson's Dockyard will be ceremoniously reopened to the public, after restoration, on Tuesday, Nov. 14.

RICHARD Korn is a man who looks for all the world like the sort of authoritative individual who could convince a television audience that some brand of cigarette is the best in the world.

Undefeated Clinton captured its fifth football victory of the season yesterday by defeating Stuyvesant, 14 -- 8, at Randalls Island. The victory kept the Governors in first place in Division I of the Public Schools Athletic League with one game remaining.

A VISIT to the Peace Palace at The Hague, seat of the International Court of Justice, is an inspiring experience, yet one which inevitably brings a question to mind. Why are those chambers so neglected by a world torn with strife and threatened with disaster?

Recently you printed a letter from a reader who argued quite strongly against subsidies for music. Symphony, the equally brilliant C.B.S. Symphony and of smaller orchestras of the other networks.

A bettor playing the numbers game in its simplest form picks a three-digit number from 000 to 999. The winning number on any given day is the last three digits of a regularly published statistic supposedly invulnerable to chicanery -- for instance, the U.S. Treasury balance or that day's pari-mutuel play at a given track.
TRENTON, Nov. 4 -- All of New Jersey's planned major road routes in urban areas will be completed by 1965 or 1966, Dwight R.G. Palmer, the State Highway Commissioner, said today.

THREE color films that have been on the European market for some years now are definitely scheduled for sale and processing in this country. AMHERST, Mass., Nov. 4 (AP) -- The Boston University Terriers scored two fourth-period touchdowns today for a 21-7 victory over the University of Massachusetts.

WHEN the Supreme Court opened its new term not long ago, it handed down, as one of its very first actions, a tradition-shattering decision about its own work hours. Henceforth, the Court announced, it would begin sitting two hours earlier -- at 10 A.M. instead of the long-hallowed high noon.

THE long arm of the novel of psychiatry has reached even into the province of the exotic; and so, one picks up a novel set in Singapore expecting to find M.I. 5 at work among the sampans, or perhaps some Maughamesque irony, and discovers instead the crisis of a graduate student with a castration complex.

HAKONE, Japan, Nov. 4 -- The first Cabinet-level economic conference between Japan and the United States turned out to be something rather less than the "new era in partnership" that officialdom on both sides liked to call it and something rather more than the "honorable picnic" the politically cynical nicknamed it.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- With characteristic persistence, Senator Estes Kefauver is again pressing his campaign against high prices of antibiotics, tranquilizers, cortisones and the many other modern drugs deemed essential to the country's health.

NEWARK, Nov. 4 -- A post-high school technical institute is needed in Essex County, according to a survey conducted by the vocational division of the State Department of Education.

PHOENIX, Ariz. -- Shunpikers who avoid the busy highways are often the funstrikers. NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 4 -- The first interstate telephone call in history, according to the archives of the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company, will be commemorated here Thursday.
NEW CITY, N.Y., Nov. 4 -- An off-year record total of 55,000 votes is expected to be cast in Rockland County's local elections Tuesday.

REGISTRATION is now open for five short courses that will be given this month at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 1000 Washington Avenue. "Flower Painting on China," a four-session course, will get under way at 11 A.M. on Nov. 13.

IF Tennessee Williams remains steadfast in his present determination, Broadway will have seen the last of his plays for some time, following the opening of his "The Night of the Iguana." WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Four days before he left office, President Eisenhower submitted to Congress a budget that he said would give the Government a surplus of $1,500,000,000 for fiscal 1962. Last week-end the Kennedy Administration estimated the Government was running a deficit of $6,900,000,000.

TOKYO, Sunday, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Secretary of Interior Stewart L. Udall scaled snow-clad Mount Fuji's 12,397-foot summit today and started the descent after circling the rim of Fuji's extinct crater, the Japan Broadcasting Corporation said.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Nov. 4 -- Hofstra College's football team lost its first home game since Oct. 25, 1958, when it bowed today to Gettysburg, 7 -- 6. The Flying Dutchmen had won eleven straight on their gridiron previously.

Some time ago a letter in your newspaper asked whether the Egyptian people really wanted or would appreciate American support for the preservation of the Nubian monuments and for the attendant archaeological research. It was even asserted that such aid from the United States would be misunderstood and resented, and would in any case be better used and would make more friends if allotted to rural schools.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 4 (UPI) -- Bob Smith, a senior tailback, had his finest day in college football today as he scored 23 points in leading the University of California at Los Angeles to a 35-15 victory over California. The victory gave the Bruins sole possession of the Big Five Conference lead.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Nov. 4 -- The Right-wing Government here received another invitation today from Prince Souvanna Phouma for a meeting Monday of the heads of the three rival factions in Laos, according to informed sources here.
