The annual Christmas Fair of the Women's Association of Grace Protestant Episcopal Church will be held Wednesday at Grace House, 802 Broadway.
WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 4 -- Westchester will decide Tuesday whether the Republicans should retain the control of the county government they have held for fifty-two years.
PEIPING, Nov. 1 (Reuters) -- Chinese Communist officials are reporting big production increases for market gardeners now that they have been brought under the country's vast commune system.

Mrs. J. Clarence Davies Jr., chairman of the NYDA Ball, to be held at the Pierre on Dec. 1 for the benefit of the services of the New York Diabetes Association, has announced the formation of an arrangements committee for the event.
BETHLEHEM, Pa., Nov. 4 -- Lehigh University struck for three touchdowns in the first half today and upset Colgate, 20 -- 15, before 10,000 spectators.
LUBBOCK, Tex., Nov. 4 (AP) -- The Rice Owls coupled bruising line play with the slashing runs of Butch Blume and Roland Jackson to outclass Texas Tech's Red Raiders, 42 -- 7, today.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 4 (UPI) -- Hard-hitting Von Clay of Philadelphia, who accepted the fight on two days' notice, tonight scored an eighth-round knockout of Billy Hunter of Detroit in the nationally televised fight of the week at Olympic Auditorium.

SYRACUSE, Nov. 4 -- Pittsburgh's eleven, appearing in resplendent gold and blue uniforms, had poise, polish and power as it started play this afternoon at Archbold Stadium -- but Syracuse had big Ernie Davis.

After twelve years of work and the expenditure of more than $400,000,000, one of the world's greatest irrigation and power projects has reached the halfway mark. The Government of Australia announced recently that contracts worth some $47,000,000 had been awarded to two United States companies to begin work on the second stage of the vast Snowy Moountains Scheme "down under."

ABOUT as instructive, not to say bleak, an insight into the state of the current Broadway theatre as exists -- aside from a matchless skill in maintaining an almost unbroken continuity of dogs, cats and musical comedies -- is afforded by the employment record of Miss Julie Harris.
The Family Service Association of America has elected James L. Turrentine of Stamford, Conn, as president.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Jerry West and Elgin Baylor of the Los Angeles Lakers combined for 80 points tonight in leading the Western Division leaders to a 125-112 National Basketball Association victory over the Chicago Packers.

THE loan exhibition of twentieth century paintings and sculpture from private Cincinnati collections, now being shown at Knoedler's in aid of the Cincinnati Contemporary Arts Center, includes within a conventional framework a number of works of art of high average quality.

MONTREAL, Nov. 4 (UPI) -- Jean-Guy Gendron's goal with only thirty-seven seconds remaining enabled the New York Rangers to gain a 3-3 tie with the Montreal Canadiens tonight after they had squandered a 2-0 lead.

DOORWAYS are a perfect setting for the little bulbs that flower in late winter and early spring. The first robin seen through the kitchen window can be matched by the first crocus growing just outside the kitchen door.
Election Day, a legal holiday when banks will be closed, will be a regular working day at the Post Office, but the Department of Traffic will consider it a holiday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- The Weather Bureau estimated that the fall-out cloud from the Soviet Union's big nuclear explosion of last Monday was passing over the Great Lakes region and eastern Canada today.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Nov. 4 -- The Congolese people, who are fast becoming accustomed to uncertainties in their life, encountered this week a new and sizable question: Whether they are at war with Katanga.
DAR ES SALAAM, Tanganyika, Nov. 4 (UPI) -- President Kennedy was made an Elder of Wagogo today in appreciation for a United States gift of $4,900,000 in famine relief to Tanganyika.

MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 4 -- With versatile Sandy Stephens as the chief spear-carrier, Minnesota's razor-sharp football team punctured the bubble of Michigan State's invincibility marches the first and last times they had the ball and resisting fiercely in between, the once-beaten Golden Gophers trounced the previously undefeated Spartans, 13 -- 0, to the delirious joy of most of the 59,941 spectators at Memorial Stadium.
The business of distributing goods is going through some profound changes, and the country's merchants are cooperating rather unwillingly.

The hydrogen bomb that Russia detonated over the Arctic last Monday morning was the most awesome man-made explosion in history. It was more than 3,000 times as powerful as the bomb that destroyed Hiroshima in 1945, and it increased the radioactive contamination of the atmosphere by half.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Representative Thomas B. Curtis, Republican of Missouri, questioned today the propriety and legality of a series of regional conferences on a wide range of domestic affairs led by Cabinet members.

The swift evolution of the European Common Market has brought far-reaching reappraisals of the traditional trade relations among the non-Communist nations. The six nations of the Common Market are lowering tariff walls among themselves and erecting a common tariff wall to outsiders.

THE scorekeepers are busy deciding who is "winning" the cold war, but a short circuit has developed in the scoreboard. Somehow the debits, divisions, and difficulties of the free world are often featured, while the distressing outlook from the Kremlin balcony is less widely reported.

WITH the two greatest nations on earth now committed to the race for the moon, there can be no doubt that we will see lunar landings in the Nineteen Seventies (or even the Sixties) and expeditions to the planets a little later. Such matters as the colonization of the moon and planets are therefore no longer the concern of fantasy; indeed, it is now unrealistic and escapist not to examine them seriously.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Nov. 4 -- The new generation of business men paying the bills for the Illinois Republican party decided after last year's election to become more active in party affairs. But their program to broaden the party's appeal, particularly in Democratic Chicago, was jolted this week by conservative downstate Republicans in the Legislature.

ANDRE MALRAUX published the four novels that were to establish his unique position among French intellectuals and to win him an outstanding place in contemporary literature in his thirties. Two of them, "Man's Fate" (1933) and "Man's Hope" (1937), raised the fame of the young man to the height of Byronic glory: from then on the writer was identified with the heroes he had created; their deeds were attributed to him.

MADRID, Nov. 4 -- Midnight revelers bidding goodnight to American friends in a fashionable midtown apartment here have often been surprised by the scent of new-mown hay and the sound of gentle mooing falling on the night air.
ALGIERS, Oct. 30 -- French officials here say of Benyoussef Ben Khedda, Premier of the Algerian nationalist provisional government and thus their No. 1 enemy: "He thinks like a Frenchman."
TORONTO, Nov. 4 (UPI) -- A third-period goal by Dave Keon enabled the Toronto Maple Leafs to beat the Chicago Black Hawks, 2 -- 1, tonight in a National Hockey League game.

No measure of our economic health is closer to people than our ability to provide jobs for everyone willing and able to work. The October employment statistics provide fresh evidence of how hard it is to attain any reasonable approximation of that goal.

NEW DELHI. THE United States will be host this week to one of the most respected, sometimes one of the most controversial, of world statesmen, Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India. His views will be sought on a broad range of critical world issues -- Berlin, nuclear tests, disarmament, Laos and others.

IN an article written in 1876 Henry James expressed "an acute satisfaction in seeing America stretch out her long arm and rake in, across the green cloth of the wide Atlantic, the highest prizes of the game of civilization."

In Wall Street this has been a year of "hot issues," that is, securities of new companies that, coming new on the market, have immediately rocketed to quotations twice the issuing price, or more. The ability to provide one's customers with such tidbits is such a coveted mark of status that it is surprising to find a Wall Streeter who declares he wants none of these.

HUBERT HERRING makes the following comment in his review of "The Cuban Story" by Herbert L. Matthews: "The story of Cuba and Fidel Castro, the most disturbing chapter in Latin-American history since the days of Simon Bolivar and Jose de San Martin, is now told by the man who knows more about it than any American -- or, for that matter, any Cuban."
REMODELING barns, of course, is an old American custom. The remodeling reported on these pages is outstanding because of the success with which it has preserved the timeless beauty of the original.
ALLENTOWN, Pa., Nov. 4 -- The United States Merchant Marine Academy defeated Muhlenberg, 43 -- 42, this afternoon in football. The victory was the fifth for Kings Point.

TOURIST returning from France report that things in Paris are still pretty much the same: the food is magnificent, the girls chic, the traffic insane. And, oh, yes -- the pinball machines are improving.

In the excerpts printed in your Nov. 2 issue from the report of Christian A. Herter and William L. Clayton urging that the United States link itself to the European Common Market is the sentence: "The immediate objective in this war is the control of the contested countries * * *."

THE wig will not again become the standard accessory for the woman of style that it was in the days when Marie Antoinette lost hers, but it is making a zestful comeback. In recent years, New York's leading custom wig makers have doubled their business annually.
An intensified freight rate war on a major Mediterranean trade route that may cost eighteen shipping lines millions of dollars in revenue appears certain.
A NEW type of epoxy plastic waterproof coating is now available. It can be used by homeowners to cure most leaky basements.

IT is rather a striking commentary on American conservation policies that a layman, Justice William O. Douglas, should have written one of the best, most appreciative surveys of our existing wilderness areas and the most vigorous of all recent arguments for their preservation.
The state's voters will act Tuesday on a plan to establish a unified and simplified statewide court system with central administrative control over all state and local courts.

ONE of Alec Woollcott's favorite stories had to do with a mysterious inscription over a doorway at Yale. The university authorities, deciding that two centuries of inscriptions were enough for anybody, had banned them on the Gothic buildings being erected at the time.

Leaseway Transportation Corporation, truck lessor and contract carrier in this country, and Premium Iron Ores, Ltd., Toronto, have set up a new Canadian company to lease trucks and other capital equipment to industry.
Bonnie Brae Farm for Boys in Millington, N.J., a haven for troubled boys from low-income families or broken homes, will receive assistance from two theatre benefits.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (UPI) -- Republican strategists plan to use President Kennedy's liberal policies as a weapon during the 1962 Congressional campaigns in the South.

ILLUSTRATED lectures by six leading photographers in several fields will be given Jan. 9 to March 20 in a series sponsored by the Institute of Modern Art and the American Society of Magazine Photographers.

Toys, Christmas decorations, gifts, antiques, gourmet foods, paintings, handmade articles and books will be on sale on Nov. 18, for early Yuletide shoppers at a Christmas Fair and Festival in the Fellowship Hall of the Unitarian Church of All Souls, Lexington Avenue and Eightieth Street.
LONDON, Nov. 4 The British Government has asked the Soviet Union to join it in an appeal to North Vietnam to end its subversive activities in South Vietnam.

The Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation will install what it says will be the fastest hot strip mill in the world, a $60,000,000 project at its Cleveland Works, Avery C. Adams, chairman of the Pittsburgh-based concern, announced for publication today.
The New York Board of Rabbis and the Presbytery of New York announced their opposition yesterday to the proposed Amendment 6 on the ballot Tuesday.
HOLLYWOOD-BY-THE-SEA, Fla. -- Evidence that many vacationists in Florida are desirous of returning home a bit healthier than when they left can be seen in this Gold Coast resort.

North American Aviation and the Aeronutronic Division of Ford Motor Company has jointly proposed to the Air Force that the B-52 and X-15 be used as a recoverable booster system for Blue Scout space probe and satellite launchings, according to a report in the Oct. 23 issue of Missiles and Rockets.

Louis I. Kaplan, the city Commissioner of Investigation, called on Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz yesterday to make public a report on the prosecution and disposition of monopoly cases by his office.

Wall Street's worst credit headache became splitting last week when the Securities and Exchange Commission moved to investigate the perhaps inadequate defenses that New York Stock Exchange firms have built against "free riders."

Letters Abroad, which next year celebrates its tenth anniversary as a clearing house for adult international correspondence, will benefit from "An Evening With Birgi Nilsson" on March 25 at Carnegie Hall.
The election of U Thant to fill the unexpired term of Dag Hammarskjold as Secretary General has brought to an end an interregnum that was beginning to have an unsettling effect.

DURHAM, N.C., Nov. 4 (UPI) -- The Duke University Library has acquired what has been called the largest and best collection of the writings of John and Charles Wesley in America and one of the most outstanding in the world.

JANACEK: Concertino for Piano and Chamber Orchestra (1925); Capriccio for Piano (Left Hand) and Chamber Orchestra (1926); Josef Palenicek, pianist, and chamber groups (Artia MK 1559). These are among the last compositions of the Czech composer, who died in 1928. They are genuine chamber-music works, in which the piano seldom plays a leading role.

ATLANTA, Nov. 4 -- Efforts to end segregation in interstate bus travel this week cleared the way for a conclusive showdown in the field between state and Federal authority. Unlike the school desegregation controversy, it appeared that this dispute would be confined to a relatively small area of the Deep South.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Freddie La Cour came off the bench in the closing minutes and led the St. Louis Hawks past the New York Knickerbockers, 112 -- 111, in a National Basketball Association game tonight.

Warm weather in many parts of the country has slowed retail sales, but buying of merchandise by stores is continuing at an active pace, according to reports last week from the resident buying offices here. Furtrimmed coats moved well in special selling events.

Upon reading Harold Schonberg's review of the Met's revival of Mozart's "Cosi fan tutte" I discovered that life is still excitingly adventurous even after a theatrical experience of more than half a century.

BATON ROUGE, La., Nov. 4 -- Jerry Stovall, a 193-pound halfback, ran 57 yards to set up a touchdown and Louisiana State smashed Mississippi's dreams of a national football championship with a 10-7 victory over the Rebels tonight.
MANHATTAN, Kan., Nov. 4 (AP) -- The Oklahoma Sooners scored a 17-6 victory over Kansas State today and ended a five-game losing streak.

AFTER her first year at a mainland school, Hawaiian-born Lani Latham is filled with joy thinking of summer at home. Lani's Polynesian mother has extended the islands' "hospitality-of-the-heart" to her niece, a New England girl deeply affected by her part in an automobile accident that killed her mother.

THIS new book by Ivan T. Sanderson, with its many photographs, is a magnificent example of fine craftsmanship on the part of engraver, printer and bookmaker. The 235 striking photographs, 109 of them in superb color, account for slightly more than half of the oversize (10 x 12-1/2-inch) pages.
The New York Times appointed operating executives yesterday for its forthcoming Western edition and named an assistant news editor to the new post of editor of regional editions.

Eddie Blanco of Brooklyn College won the individual honors in the seventh annual Municipal College cross-country championships yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park. The team title was retained by City College with 37 points.
THE selection of lilac varieties for a collection, whether for a private garden or a public display, should be assigned to someone who has observed many varieties over a period of years.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Nov. 4 (UPI) -- Roger Maris tonight got back the ball he hit for his sixty-first home run of last season, but he avoided a red-carpet welcome planned for him by a local business man.

GARDENERS who plan to attract winter birds to the home property should start preparing the feeding trays now. Throughout the autumn, birds that may remain as winter residents are constantly searching for food and congregating in places where it is certain and abundant.

WINDSOR, Ont., Nov. 4 (Canadian Press) -- A Norwegian freighter ripped mooring lines and smashed gangplanks and ramps along the Detroit waterfront today as she sped along at speeds estimated at more than twenty miles an hour.

ALBANY, Nov. 4 -- Civic groups must work closely with school officials to overcome the obstacles to excellence in education, according to the president of the New York State Citizens Committee for the Public Schools.

TUSCALOOSA, Ala. Nov. 4 (AP) -- Alabama's defense provided the openings today for a 24 -- 0 victory by the Crimson Tide over Mississippi State.

BERLIN, Nov. 3 -- Officials of RIAS, the United States-sponsored radio station in West Berlin, said today that broadcasts to Communist East Germany had been altered considerably since the Berlin border closing Aug. 13.

A senior committee has been appointed to assist with arrangements for the eighth annual Famous Designers and Artists Auction at the Parke-Bernet Galleries on Nov. 21. The event will benefit the Irvington House at Irvington, N.Y., a treatment and research center for children with rheumatic fever and rheumatic heart disease.
RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 4 -- Virginians will go to the polls Tuesday to elect a Governor. The expectation is that Albertis S. Harrison Jr., former Attorney General, will win. He is a Democrat.
The forty-sixth annual National Hotel Exposition opens tomorrow on what is expected to be a very optimistic note.
DENVER, Nov. 4 (AP) -- The Air Force Academy took advantage of a last-minute pass interference penalty today and beat Colorado State University, 14 -- 9.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Nov. 4 (UPI) -- A bevy of young Virginia backs ripped South Carolina's line apart today for a 28-20 upset and the Cavaliers' first victory in the Atlantic Coast Conference in nineteen games.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Official sources indicated today that the United States would press South Vietnam to undertake major economic, social and military reforms to provide a basis for increased United States support.
MIAMI BEACH -- One would be inclined to think that a resort as famous and well-established as Miami Beach would be content now to sit back and let the bottles of suntan lotion fall where they may.
MEDFORD, Mass., Nov. 4 -- Mark Hallam and Bill Julavits, substitutes, sparked undefeated Amherst to a 40-6 victory over Tufts today.

ONE of the most engaging minor characters of Elizabethan times is Sir John Harington. More notable courtiers strut in the full glare of history, but he peers out from behind the arras, while kingdoms hang in the balance, to whisper an unseemly jest to the ladies in waiting.
BELIZE, British Honduras, Nov. 4 (AP) -- British soldiers patrolled today with orders to shoat to kill to prevent the looting of food. The death toll from Hurricane Hattie climbed to 204.

S.J. PERELMAN, the writer of wild and wacky comedy, is working on the initial script for a proposed weekly half-hour television series entitled "Acres and Pains." With the Columbia Broadcasting System all set to finance a pilot film, the series would star Tom Poston as a New York writer living the life of a country squire in Bucks County, Pa.

Ed Dean of Chaminade won individual honors and led his school to the team laurels in the Catholic High School Athletic Association cross-country championship yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx.
PURCHASE, N.Y. Nov. 4 -- Ogden R. Reid, new chairman of the State Commission Against Discrimination, today urged young people to "get excited" and support social and economic equality.

PHILADELPHIA. "MARTY" made Paddy Chayefsky famous -- a neat slice of ordinary Bronx life, depicting the fumbling romance of a homely butcher and a plain old-maid schoolteacher, all so shrewdly observed and carefully detailed that Chayefsky was subsequently praised as "the master of the tape-recording school of dramatic writing."
Mrs. Mae Gurevich, vice chairman of the Democratic State Committee, strongly urged the re-election of Mayor Wagner yesterday.

ONE of the hardest kinds of stories to bring off well is that based on a minor event in regional history. Too often, historical detail overshadows the human element. In her modest but very agreeable story, "A Red Carpet for Lafayette," Martha Foster coaxe life and spirit into just such an incident.
LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 4 (AP) -- Timely passes by John Hadl sent Kansas to a 28-to-6 Big Eight triumph over Nebraska today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4 -- A large medical foundation supported by private funds but endorsed by the Government should be set up to make American medical knowledge "available to the people of all nations," says Brig. Gen. James H. Forsee.

The American Public Health Association said yesterday it would award its 1961 Sedgwick Memorial Medal for distinguished service in public health to Dr. Frank G. Boudreau, president and trustee of the Milbank Memorial Fund.

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 4 -- Mineola High's juggernaut was much too powerful for Carle Place today as the Mustangs romped to a 40-7 victory. The battle of unbeaten teams was watched by a crowd that packed the stands and also by a television audience.
CLEMSON, S.C., Nov. 4 (AP) -- Clemson ground out a 21-6 victory over Tulane today after a scoreless first quarter.

WE say "potato" and the Greeks say "patata." Whatever you call it the vegetable is a ranking favorite in the Western diet. This fall the American potato harvest, one of the most abundant in recent years, was estimated at nineteen billion pounds. Here are three unfamiliar recipes, suited to the season, that feature this familiar and versatile vegetable.

NEWS of pre-season training activities of the New York Football Giants was necessarily skimpy in the English-language papers in Europe last August. So an expatriate in Paris, a man who had been on terms of friendship with most of the Giant players, wrote an anxious letter home.

THAT corporate British team called Woodfall Productions but better known as those angry, dedicated young men, playwright John Osborne and director Tony Richardson, is ambitiously looking backward for film material.

In an informal but serious way the Administration served notice last week on Wall Street that it would seek to eliminate that small but investor-cherished partial exemption of taxes on dividend income. Present laws permit taxpayers to exclude the first $50 in dividend income and subtract from his tax bill 4 per cent of dividend income over $50.
Meals by machine have become the hottest item in the food service industry.
RED BANK, N.J., Nov. 1 -- The New Jersey Highway Authority announced today that the sixth in a series of public sales of Garden State Parkway land would be held Nov. 10.

HAMILTON, Bermuda -- This is the time of year when Bermuda starts to enjoy the equivalent of a cool, northern summer. Cooler waters will mean that visitors will take just a refreshing dip in the sea, instead of spending long periods in the surf and on the beaches.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 4 -- Although theoretically weakened by the absence of eight injured regulars, Army's football team proved too stout for the University of Detroit today. What the cadets lacked in numbers, they more than offset with superior "whomp" in their running, blocking and tackling-during a 34-7 romp at Michie Stadium.

CHARLOTTE AMALIE, St. Thomas, V.I. -- Tourism, the biggest industry in the Virgin Islands, is expected to get even bigger this season as a result of the recent Congressional legislation granting the islands a special duty-free allowance on articles tourists take back to the United States.

Net sales of the Chock Full o' Nuts Corporation were up 20 per cent in the quarter ended on Oct. 31, compared with the 1960 period, stockholders were told at the annual meeting last week. Sales in the 1960 period, the first quarter of the company's fiscal year, totaled $8,497,330.

PEARL PRIMUS arrived in New York from Liberia on Monday to start rehearsals for the forthcoming African Carnival 1961, to be held at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory, Lexington Avenue and Twenty-fifth Street. Nov. 24, 25 and 26.

My heartiest congratulations go to your letter-writer, Gretchen King, for her outspoken and well-taken views. She spoke for me, too. SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 4 -- Navy's relentless eleven outhit Notre Dame for fifty-nine minutes and one second today, but the last "hit" was the hardest of all for the fighting Irish and their fans.
A bomb hoax forced the evacuation of Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa's campaign headquarters at the Lexington Hotel last night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- The former Republican President and his Vice President are actively co-operating to develop more national figures in the Republican party, which could broaden and intensify the contest for the party's 1964 Presidential nomination. These are potential consequences of one of General Eisenhower's current political activities and of a statement made by Richard M. Nixon at a news conference in Syracuse.
TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 4 -- The Shah of Iran, Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, called today for a partnership of the United States and Iran to transform Iran into a showplace for the non-Communist world.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 4 -- The establishment of fifteen "cluster colleges" on the Oxford pattern is contemplated by the University of the Pacific at Stockton.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 4 -- The Army Corps of Engineers has awarded the last major contract for deepening the Delaware River channel to forty feet along the thirty-mile stretch from the Philadelphia Naval Base to Newbold Island, five miles south of Trenton.
City Controller Lawrence E Gerosa predicted yesterday that he would be elected Mayor by a margin of 250,000 votes. An aide said Mr. Gerosa would get 952,000 votes.

A TWO-YEAR program of bulb testing, which was completed last spring, has resulted in valuable planting information for gardeners who will plant tulips this fall. The tests were carried out by the Men's Garden Clubs of America in cooperation with the Associated Bulb Growers of Holland.
HELSINKI, Finland, Nov. 4 -- The bitterly fought Presidential campaign is continuing without a let-up as Finland awaits the mutual defense consultations requested by the Soviet Union.
WINTER PARK, Fla., Nov. 4 (AP) -- Dr. Edward Teller warned today that the Soviet Union would have the power to shape the world if it held its lead in the space race.

COCOA BEACH, Fla. -A great expansion of the area of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Missile Test Center, now concentrated at Cape Canaveral about eighteen miles north of this resort, is expected by next February and is bound to affect tourism here-abouts.

SAN ANTONIO, Nov. 4 -- Henry B. Gonzalez, a Democrat, beat John Goode Jr., a Republican, in a special Congressional election today that was fought on the issue of Kennedy Administration policies versus conservatism.
PORTSMOUTH, Ohio, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Cadet Paul M. Weaver 2d, missing from West Point since Aug. 30, returned to his home here today.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Nov. 4 (UPI) -- Several hundred persons attended a mass today honoring a teacher and a student who died in recent anti-Government demonstrations. An appeal by an Opposition party leader averted possible new trouble.

ALBANY Nov. 2 -- A 27-year-old Presbyterian minister who once sealed the Matterhorn has set himself an even more ambitious task in the state's capital city this fall.
ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 4 -- Paced by Tom Haggerty's three touchdowns, Columbia beat Cornell, 35 -- 7, today to retain its grip on second place in the Ivy League race.

LAUREL, Md., Nov. 4 (AP) -- King Ranch's Tamorona easily won the thirty-sixth running of the $58,490 Selima Stakes today. She scored by five lengths over Broadway in the mile-and-a-sixteenth race for 2-year-old fillies.

MOST of us find fascination in courtroom proceedings as depicted on the screen and in fiction. There is an attraction to the battle of wits between opposing counsel, the examination of witnesses and the relentless piling on of evidence that seldom fails to hold our attention in those imaginary media.

IN Martin Levin's column, A Reader's Report, for Oct. 8, there were three errors of fact in the first four lines. To wit: The name of the author of "Moment of No Return" is King-Hall, not King-Hill; the publisher is Ballantine Books, not Bantam; and the price is 50 cents, not 35 -- and well worth it, by the way.

VIENNA, Nov. 4 -- Five years ago today, Soviet tanks crushed the anti-Communist rebellion in Hungary and Jozsef Cardinal Mindszenty, Primate of Hungary, began his exile within the protective walls of the United States Legation.
The $300,000,000 antifreeze business is being chilled this year by a combination of discount pricing, do-it-yourself installation and new product confusion.

The Nobel Prize in chemistry was awarded last week to Dr. Melvin Calvin of the University of California for his major contributions in unravelling the highly complicated chemical steps in photosynthesis. This is the process in which the green pigment in plants (chlorophyll) harnesses the energy of sunlight to synthesize the food for man and animal out of carbon dioxide in the air and water in the soil.
PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 4 -- The 1962 political campaign is under way in Oregon. This state's Democrats seem in the mood to emulate California Republicans in providing a colorful gubernatorial primary.

WALLINGFORD, Conn., Nov. 4 -- Bruce Molloy, a former all-Connecticut quarterback, scored three times today to lead Choate School to an 18-7 upset victory over powerful Lawrenceville. It was Lawrenceville's first defeat in three years.

AMANDA BLAKE, a svelte redhead with sea-colored eyes who has quietly sizzled her way through six years of "Gunsmoke" as lady saloon keeper and tacit inamorata of the marshal, sat in a midtown hotel recently and talked about the evolution of Kitty.

WESTPORT, Conn., Nov. 4 -- School officials last night assured a group of Parent-Teachers Association members that the new Hillspoint Road elementary "school of the future," to open Monday, was safe for occupancy.

PARIS. "WE are the semblance of a Parliament confronting the shadow of a Government." This caustic verdict on the functioning of France's institutions in General Charles de Gaulle's Fifth Republic was delivered in the course of a recent debate in the National Assembly by veteran former Premier and Foreign Minister Georges Bidault.
A single approach to three of the nation's most pressing problems -- unemployment, automation and survival in an atomic war -- was proposed yesterday by a state labor official.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 4. (UPI) -- A 3-point scoring play by Ed Conlin as time ran out enabled the Philadelphia Warriors to gain a 135-132 victory over the Detroit Pistons in a National Basketball Association game tonight.
The annual luncheon and bridge party of the Advisory Board of the McMahon Memorial Temporary Shelter for Children will be given Thursday in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 29 -- Two young mariners spent the last four months on a 1,200-mile river voyage that began in northern Argentina near the Bolivian border. Buenos Aires was their destination.
ABOARD COAST GUARD CUTTER FREDERICK LEE, Nov. 1 -- The end of an era in the Coast Guard service began today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- In one of its illuminating yet unpredictable switchback turns, history repeated itself this week in a personal and fateful way in the Cabinet Room of the White House. Some eleven years ago in the White House, President Truman pondered the question of whether the United States should develop the hydrogen bomb.
No matter who wins on Election Day, the city will still have year-round watchdogs -- its active, vocal civic associations.

WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 4 -- Albert Gene, owned by the Black Shoe Stable of Garden City, L.I., unleashed a powerful stretch drive before 30,081 fans tonight at Roosevelt Raceway and registered a nose victory over Dick Byrd in the $3,500 Levittown Pace.
" Conflict of interest," a phrase that has passed the lips of more than one poltician, has paused to rest in the collective throats of leading life insurance executives of the nation.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- The protectionist opposition to the Administration's proposals for a more liberal trade policy lacks an established leader for the first time in the postwar era.
The Inter-American Press Association has appointed Jules Dubois of The Chicago Tribune chairman of its committee on freedom of the press for the twelfth consecutive year.
Mrs. George A. Rawler, chairman of the sponsoring committee, has announced the names of junior committee chairmen for the inter-preparatory school Holiday Hop.
The newly organized Federal Maritime Commission established last week a precedent that shipping executives hope will become routine procedure in the agency.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 4 -- Anyone who was on the scene then and still is around to talk about it would readily agree that 1888 was indeed a date to be remembered. For that was the year of the blizzard and it was the year that a Harvard football team overwhelmed Pennsylvania, 50 -- 0.
COVENTRY, England, Nov. 4 -- Twelve young Germans are rebuilding part of the ancient cathedral here that was destroyed by Nazi incendiaries twenty-one years ago.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 4 -- The Republicans are attempting to overturn a twenty-eight-year-old Democratic reign in the mayoralty race here, and are using the "bossism" issue in their effort.
ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 4 -- A general pattern of reluctant compliance with a Federal ban against segregation in interstate bus travel emerged today throughout much of the South.

NEWARK, Del., Nov. 4 (UPI) -- Delaware gained at least a tie for the Middle Atlantic Conference football championship today by trouncing Temple, 28 -- 0, before 6,200 fans. The triumph gave Delaware a won-lost record of 3 -- 0 in the conference.

Department store sales in the nation in the week ended Oct. 28 were up 2 per cent from the comparable 1960 level, the Federal Reserve Board reported. Sales in the preceding week were 4 per cent higher than a year earlier.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 3 (UPI) -- Darrel Cox and Howard Dunneback, sophomore backs, led Kentucky to a 20-0 victory over Florida State today. But the Wildcats, lost their ace passer, Jerry Woolum, probably for the rest of the season.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 3 (UPI) -- Darrel Cox and Howard Dunneback, sophomore backs, led Kentucky to a 20-0 victory over Florida State today. But the Wildcats, lost their ace passer, Jerry Woolum, probably for the rest of the season.

It seems that the eminent ornithologist Roger Tory Peterson has discovered a new species of songbird. In his article, "Why Birds Sing" (Oct. 22), he specifically mentions the "summer teenager," a kind one will vainly look for in Dr. Peterson's own reference books, excellent as they are.

FOR THIS WEEK: Mild weather has prolonged the planting season for little bulbs and the big three -- tulips, daffodils and hyacinths. Finish planting soon, however. . . . Continue mowing as long as the grass is growing. . . . It is natural for evergreens to drop some of their older leaves at this time of year.
ACCRA, Ghana, Nov. 4 -- Dynamite explosions laid to the Opposition damaged today the life-size statue of President Kwame Nkrumah that stands before Parliament House here.
LONDON, Nov. 4 -- Britain is giving "a very high priority" to reinforcement and re-equipment of the Army of the Rhine in view of the Berlin situation, the Minister of Defense announced today.
SAN SALVADOR, Nov. 2 -- Six parties have been granted permission to participate in the congressional elections Dec. 17 and political campaigning is moving into full swing.
EASTON, Pa., Nov. 4 -- Rutgers, one of the East's major football powers, rolled over a weak Lafayette eleven, 37 -- 6, before 6,500 fans at Fisher Field today.
HILTON HEAD ISLAND, S.C., Nov. 4 -- The armed forces will stage an assault on the beaches here Tuesday in a demonstration of modern tactics and in commemoration of a Civil War attack a century ago.

BONN. IT may well be that the Communist action of Aug. 13, when the "Chinese Wall" went up across the middle of Berlin, has for the first time since the war forced the Germans to begin a realistic reappraisal of their political situation.

ISTANBUL -- Every Saturday morning, a ship of the Turkish Maritime Lines sails from here through the Bosporus into the Black Sea. She proceeds along the Asiatic north coast of Turkey, carrying passengers and cargo to and from various ports as far as the Russian border.

THE business of political polling at times can be likened to Russian roulette. Our own organization has just pulled the trigger in the polls we are doing in the current New York mayoral election. Polling has become a built-in part of the mechanics of modern campaigns.

AN ethnic field recording on a major label is something of a novelty these days; a good one is something of an event. Capitol offers a novel event on A Visit to Borneo: Exotic Music of the Duson, Murut and Bajau Tribes (Capitol T 10271).
The Navy has begun an intensive study of anti-submarine warfare that may eventually result in the establishment of a global ocean surveillance system.

THE New York Times covered 119 art exhibitions during the month of October, not counting a few that were visited but, for humanitarian reasons, not mentioned. Count off a few as museum shows, and you still have at least 100 artists pleased, disappointed or reduced to a state of anguish by what was written about their work -- not to mention their friends, who take part in the act.

IN recent years America has not had to worry about its supply of native opera singers. Not only are there a number of fine music schools in this country, but also the singers themselves, often by selling their shirts and going to Europe, have had the enterprise to find their own training.

BERLIN, Nov. 5 -- Thirty East Germans attempted to break through the barbed wire to reach West Berlin today. The fire of an East German border guard disrupted the mass flight and only nine managed to reach the West.
When the election returns of Local 88 are tallied late next month, a major maritime union local will have completed an extensive transition.

The Motion Picture Association of America, Inc., and the Motion Picture Export Association, Inc., have leased a floor in the new twenty-fire-story office building at 522 Fifth Avenue, southwest corner of Forty-fourth Street.

TOKYO, Nov. 5 -- Three members of President Kennedy's Cabinet spent a busy Sunday far from home today, dealing in the name of international goodwill with a military junta, Left-wing labor leaders and windy mountain slopes.

Six of the eight scheduled sixth-round games and five fourth and fifth-round adjourned matches were decided yesterday in the women's world championship challengers chess tournament at Vrnjacka Banja, according to a report from Yugoslavia.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 5, (UPI) -- Bob Schnelker caught a 26-yard scoring pass in the waning moments today to give the Pittsburgh Steelers a 17-13 upset victory over the Cleveland Browns. The National Football League game drew a crowd of 62,723.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Nov. 5 -- Prince Chao Sopsaisana, Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs in the pro-western Government of Laos, said today that Soviet planes were dropping supplies in southern Laos at a place where Communist rebels in South Vietnam were believed to have a major staging base.
SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Nov. 5 -- Thomas M. Storke, 84-year-old editor and publisher of The Santa Barbara News-Press, was cited here tonight for his defense of civil liberties in 1961.
PARIS, Nov. 5 -- The European Common Market faces critical problems as it makes final preparations for the delicate bargaining to determine whether Britain will become its seventh member.

THE third performance of the season of "H.M.S. Pinafore" found the New York City Opera Company in better shape than had been the case when the work was first produced three weeks ago. It was vociferously greeted yesterday afternoon at City Center by an audience that included a large number of young people.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 5 -- Dr. Eugen Gerstenmaier said tonight he expected to receive the nomination of Chancellor Adenauer for another term as Chancellor tomorrow.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 5 -- Highly placed diplomats just arrived from Cairo said today that President Nasser was no longer running a one-man show in Cairo and was sharing the limelight with his Vice Presidents, Abdel Latif el-Boghdady and Zakariya Mohieddine.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Certain Connecticut politicians can breathe easier. Abraham A. Ribicoff, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, says he is not interested in running for the Senate.
DALLAS, Tex., Nov. 5 (AP) -- Mr. Gonzalez said tonight that former President Eisenhower's appearance in behalf of his opponent actually helped the Democratic cause.
Bank, utility and oil and gas stocks were the best performers last week in the over-the-counter market. Practically all of them rose in price on good demand.
Under a request from Mayor Wagner, negotiators were engaged in nonstop bargaining early today in an effort to settle the twelve-day-old milk strike.
The biggest clip joint in New York yesterday was a meeting room where more than 1,000 barbers got together for the fourth National Barber Show.
TEAKWOOD dispensers for paper towels and rosewood pencil holders are among the specialties of a young New Jersey designer.

On a balmy afternoon perfect for an outdoor program at, say, Piping Rock, Devon or Grosse Pointe, Argentina won the three-day low-score international jumping trophy at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden yesterday.

G. Mennen Williams said last night that the industrial nations of the West must contribute more to the development of the backward African nations "if Africa is to be counted a friend of the West in the future."

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Nov. 5 -- An intensive last-minute Democratic drive headed by Vice President Johnson was credited today for the victory of State Senator Henry B. Gonzalez in yesterday's Congressional election.

PEORIA, Ill., Nov. 5 (AP) -- The United Auto Workers and the Caterpillar Tractor Company said tonight that an agreement had been reached on a three-year contract for 13,000 workers at three plants in this area.
CHICAGO, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Buying support was scarce in grain futures last week and prices slowly backed down almost without interruption on the board of trade.

LONDON, Nov. 5 -- New concern for the safety of Queen Elizabeth II during her visit to Ghana, scheduled to begin Friday, was demonstrated tonight.

McMURDO SOUND, Antarctica, Nov. 4 -- A Navy P-2V Neptune airplane will take off here Monday on the first leg of the longest research flight ever attempted on this continent by the United States.
Profit sharing and pension plans are the latest investors to succumb to the spell of mutual funds.
The American Smelting and Refining Company (Asarco) reported declines in sales and earnings for the nine months ended Sept. 30 from the 1960 levels.

Mayor Wagner announced yesterday a general plan for an early start on a program of intensified social and health services for youths in Harlem.

AMSTERDAM, Nov. 5 -- The highlight of trading on the stock exchange here last week was a sharp rise in Unilever. Heavy American demand and expectations of a Wall Street listing spurred the demand.

Unseasonable warmth pushed the temperature up to 78 degrees at 12:45 P.M. yesterday, setting a record for a Nov. 5 here. On Saturday the high was 77, also a record.

A procession and holy communion in honor of all the saints of the church, known and unknown, was held yesterday at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine.

Approval of Amendment No. 6 on the ballot Nov. 7 would make possible construction of housing and academic buildings at both private and public colleges at lower cost than is now possible because the dormitory bonds to be issued would be guaranteed by the state.

DENVER, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Houston's Oiler's, looking once again like last year's champions, defeated the Denver Broncos, 55 -- 14, today for their third straight American Football League victory under their new coach, Wally Lemm.

PARIS, Nov. 5 -- While the opening rounds in next year's reciprocal trade law battle were being loudly fired in the United States last week, off-stage skirmishing that will greatly influence that fight was continuing quietly here in Europe.
MOSCOW, Nov. 5 -- The Soviet Union warned today that further nuclear testing by the United States and its allies might compel Moscow to extend its own program of testing.
PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 5 -- The American Social Health Association, Inc., is starting a nation-wide program to prevent narcotics addiction.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- In the wooded mountains of central Arizona, construction will begin shortly on what may be the world's largest, most sensitive seismic observatory for detecting underground nuclear explosions or earthquakes.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 5 -- There is much confused thinking by our public and muddled leadership by our politicians on the issue of fall-out shelters. Like the weather, everybody talks about it and nobody does anything, at least anything adequate and pondered.
The theft of automobile hub caps has become a relatively big business that is costing American motorists more than $5,000,000 a year.

Prices of cotton futures softened last week, with nearer months showing the largest losses. At the close Friday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were down 2 to 20 points for the week.

CAIRO, Nov. 5 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser is staking his regime on a fundamental reorganization of the Government based on "free elections" and "popular powers."

The Rev. Dr. G. Elson Ruff, editor of The Lutheran, weekly news magazine of the United Lutheran Church in America, will propose in Wednesday's issue that "the great American television strike" be called immediately.

Two singers will make their debuts during the Metropolitan Opera's fourth week, which begins next Monday. Both debuts will occur during the Friday night performance of "Lohengrin"; Randolph Symonette will sing the role of Telramund, and Ernst Wiemann will be heard as King Henry.

The new freer-trade policy of the Kennedy Administration must provide more than "adjustment assistance" to companies and workers adversely affected by increased imports, Senator Jacob K. Javits asserted yesterday.
DARLINGTON, England, Nov. 5 -- Guy Fawkes, the central figure in a plot in 1605 to blow up the houses of Parliament, is fast becoming the victim of a counterplot.

RABAT, Morocco, Nov. 5 -- Jewish groups in Morocco have taken a stand against French Right-wing extremists in Algeria and in favor of Jewish-Moslem cooperation in North Africa.

Antonina Kawecka, soprano from the Polish National Opera, made her American debut last night with the New York City Opera in the title role of "Aida." It was an impressive appearance.
An easier trend developed for the principal currencies in the foreign exchange market during the past week. Business turnover was heavy at times.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., Nov. 5 -- John J. Nagle, who retired a year and a half ago as president and chairman of the board of the Crown Cork and Seal Company., Inc., died last night from injuries suffered in an automobile accident an hour earlier.
Steel production declined slightly last week.

Pre-Election Day trading in commodity futures on the New York exchanges was quiet yesterday, with the exception of cocoa, which rose on reports of rioting in Ghana and of that country's trade agreement with the Soviet Union.
The forty-sixth annual National Hotel Exposition started off auspiciously yesterday at the New York Coliseum with the signing of the biggest single order in its history.
A railroad equipment industry spokesman appealed yesterday to the Government for urgent consideration for allowing accelerated depreciation for tax purposes of railroad-owned rolling stock.
LONDON, Nov. 6 -- Jomo Kenyatta, leader of Kenya's largest African political party, arrived in London today for talks with British colonial officials.
Yale University yesterday published a blueprint for complete revision of its engineering education.
ALBANY, Nov. 6 (UPI) -Straws in the winds for 1962 and 1964 will be looked for tomorrow when millions of upstate New Yorkers go to the polls to select municipal leaders.
SUPPLIES of crisp, fresh, pale green and white celery are increasing and now is the time to experiment with other uses for the vegetable besides placing the stalks on the relish tray.

MIAMI BEACH, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Two little Negro orphans of the storm that shattered Belize, British Honduras, are not really orphans at all, it was learned today. And the white man who announced plans to adopt them says his story "got out of hand."
CHAMONIX, France, Nov. 6 -- The world championships in Alpine skiing will open on Feb. 10 with qualification runs in slalom racing and will end with the men's downhill run on Feb. 18.

THE jinx that seems to have beset Danny Kaye's entertainment adventures in television refused to relax its hold last night during the comedian's annual video outing over Channel 2. For a moment here and there the personality that has captivated audiences at the Palace and Palladium asserted itself but most of the hour was the oft-told story of a comedian in need of far better material.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower came to Washington tonight for a get-together with colleagues active or formerly active in the Supreme Headquarters Allied Powers Europe.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 6 -The Free Democratic party said tonight it would not insist on a Ministry of Development Aid in the new West German Government if Economics Minister Ludwig Erhard persisted in his obligations to it.

NEW YORK stores are not going to be taken unawares by any blizzards this winter. Already, they are stocking devices to keep women protected from the cold. One of the zaniest is some spats that Bonwit Teller has in its hosiery department.

The Defense Department has ordered initial development work on a medium-range ballistic missile that could be deployed on trucks. It would be intended for use in Europe.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- The choice of their Mayor by the voters of New York City is always of great intrinsic importance. The municipal problems are the same as those which burden other American cities. Sanderson.

DETROIT, Nov. 6 -- More new cars were sold during Oct. 21 to 31 than ever before for that period, Ward's Automotive Reports said today. Joseph B. Greiner has formed the J.B. Greiner Company, industrial real estate concern. The offices of the company are at 5 Court Square, Long Island City. Mr. Greiner has been in the real estate field since 1955.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 6 -- U Thant thanked United Nations delegates today for having entrusted him "with the heavy responsibilities expected of the Acting Secretary General."

The picking of a jury began yesterday in the first-degree murder trial of Fred J. Thompson, a 59-year-old drifter accused of the rape-slaying of 4-year-old Edith Kiecorius last February in a Chelsea rooming house.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Charles C. Tillinghast Jr., president of Trans World Airlines, answered a Government official's demand for airline mergers today with a counter-proposal for partial monopolies.

NEW HYDE PARK, L.I., Nov. 6 (AP) -- A man the police call the "nitro bank robber" held up the Island Federal Savings and Loan Association today on a threat of blowing up the institution. He escaped with $8,000.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Dr. Donald R. Chadwick, new chief of the Public Health Service's Division of Radiological Health, said today that it seemed quite certain that fall-out from the current Soviet nuclear testing would result in damage to future generations.
The thirteen-day milk strike ended early today when union and management agreed to submit the single remaining issue to arbitration.

PALISADES, N.Y., Nov. 6 -- The cornerstone of the three-story $750,000 Oceanography Building was laid here today at the Columbia University Lamont Geological Observatory atop the northern tip of the Palisades.
For the fourth time in little more than a month, sales finance companies adjusted their rates yesterday on the commercial paper they sell directly to investors.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Nov. 6 -- A secret radio transmitter in the village of Helwa, Lebanon, was blown up by a Syrian Army commando unit on the night of Oct. 27, authoritative sources disclosed tonight. The transmitter was said to have been operated by forces supporting the policies of President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic.
JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 6 (UPI) -- A student group called "Patriotic American Youth" has been organized in Mississippi to fight communism.
MOSCOW, Nov. 6 -- The Soviet press printed today what was believed to be the first report from a Soviet uranium-producing center.

A laughing, Spanish-speaking Texan of Mexican descent campaigned yesterday for Mayor Wagner because, he said, "any time I get a chance to fight Republicans, I take it -- it's more relaxing than sleep."
ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 6 -The Orange Board of Education was called upon today to take "immediate steps to desegregate" the city's school system.

CHARLOTTSVILLE, Va., Nov. 6 (UPI) -- Eleven persons, including three University of Virginia students, were convicted, fined and sentenced up to sixty days in jail today on charges resulting from a tear gas-quelled campus riot.

THE cosmopolitan traditions of the Metropolitan Opera were upheld in last night's "Aida," which had a Russian soprano in the title role, an Italian as Amonasro, a Canadian as Radames and Americans most everywhere else.
IT would appear that someone is rocking the boat, particularly on the West Coast.
Philadelphia's largest commercial bank announced yesterday a stock split and an offering of rights to subscribe to shares.

The New York City Housing Authority is planning to borrow $29,545,000 on temporary loan notes on Nov. 14 to finance four city-sponsored projects subsidized by tax forgiveness. The notes will be dated Dee. 13 and will come due June 14.

The Hammermill Paper Company, Erie, Pa., has entered into agreements with two major stockholders of Strathmore Paper Company to acquire from them 42,528 shares of Strathmore in exchange for 63,793 common shares of Hammermill.

HOUSTON, Tex., Nov. 6 (UPI) -- A Missouri-Pacific passenger train hit a truck carrying a load of bricks at a crossing in northeast Houston late today, killing the truck driver and injuring about twenty-five passengers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Hubert H. Humphrey, the Senate's assistant majority leader, just back from a six-week tour of Europe, North Africa and the Middle East, said today that the threat of war over Berlin had been reduced but not eliminated.
PARIS, Nov. 6 -- President de Gaulle will begin a four-day visit to Corsica and Southern France tomorrow surrounded by exceptional security precautions to prevent a new assassination attempt.
ALGIERS, Nov. 6 -- A member of the French Government hinted strongly today that Paris was engaged in "pre-negotiation" with the Algerian Provisional Government in Tunis.

The campaigns have run their course and today the voter takes over. In New York City the election has more than normal importance. A new City Charter to strengthen the municipal government is presented in referendum for the first time in a quarter century.

ACCRA, Ghana, Nov. 6 -- Two explosions occurred in Accra tonight a few hours after Duncan Sandys, Britain's Secretary for Commonwealth Relations, arrived here to assess whether Queen Elizabeth's scheduled visit this week should be postponed for reasons of safety.
I cannot agree with Eugene Schnell's letter published Oct. 17 entitled "Phone Service Criticized."
The Minnesota Mining Manufacturing (3-M) Company reported yesterday increased sales and earning in both the quarter and nine months ended on Sept. 30.

The Western Union Telegraph Company reported yesterday that gross operating revenues were "moderately higher" in the first nine months of this year than last. Net income also increased but the gain was traced primarily to a profit of $4,414,963 from the sale of capital stock of two nonaffiliated companies.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Nov. 6 -- At least fifteen white women were raped by Congolese soldiers Thursday in Luluabourg, capital of Kasai Province, according to reports reaching here yesterday. The situation in Kasai was said to be tense.
This little by-play, the so-called "milk strike," has been performed before in New York City and will be again unless the consumer decides to do something about it.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Teodoro Moscoso of Puerto Rico will become Latin-American area administrator of the Agency for International Development, the White House announced tonight. He is now United States Ambassador to Venezuela.
ROME, Nov. 6 -- John D. Rockefeller 3d told the Food and Agriculture Organization today that "some effective and acceptable means of population stabilization" was one of man's most pressing needs.
LONDON, Nov. 6 -- After a firm start industrial share prices drifted lower in the stock market here today. By the close of trading losses outnumbered gains in most groups.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 6 -- The Foreign Ministry said tonight it was trying to arrange the immediate release of Lazo Vracaric, a Milwaukee-born former Yugoslav partisan, who is held in Munich for the wartime "murder" of two German soldiers.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -Helium, a glamour gas in the age of the big dirigibles, is being hoarded like gold for new, critical uses in the defense program.
John (Bing) Miller, who in his glory days at New York University kicked nothing but an egg-shaped ball, today will be coaching a group of athletes kicking a mere sphere.

The Soviet Union marks today the forty-fourth anniversary of the beginning of the Bolshevik Revolution. Thus -- hard as it may be to realize -- the overwhelming majority of Soviet citizens today were born since Lenin seized power, or were only children when he triumphed. During a period in which two generations have come to maturity, the Soviet people have been thoroughly and consistently indoctrinated to believe that their rulers' policy was always right.

Sales and earnings of the Boeing Company, maker of commercial and military aircraft and missiles, climbed for both the third quarter and first nine months of this year, it was announced yesterday. The company also announced a 25 per cent increase in its quarterly dividend.
MOSCOW, Nov. 7 -- The Soviet Union marked the forty-fourth anniversary of the Bolshevik Revolution by parading its rocket might today and reiterating its intention to build a Communist society.

The days of indiscriminate multi-million-dollar spending by the major leagues for untried baseball players -- known as "bonus babies" -- seem to be numbered. The end may come the last week of this month, when the major and minor leaguers hold their annual winter meetings in Tampa and Miami Beach.
The French liner Liberte, fifth largest in the world, is about to embark on a new and stationary career.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- The Supreme Court took under advisement today the prickly question of when a Government official may copyright his public speeches.

AT Mr. Barny's command, timepieces harness cuckoos and quails, sand and water to announce the hour. At work at 218 East Fifty-ninth Street, in a second-floor store that is both museum and repair shop, the New York clockmaker can make anything tick that he has the raw materials to fix or invent.
LAUREL, Md., Nov. 7 (AP) -- Soviet and French horses worked out at Laurel Race Course today in preparation for the $100,000 Washington D.C. International.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7 (AP) -- An experimental nuclear reactor will be allowed to run wild until it partly destroys itself so that scientists can study the results in the interest of safety, an Atomic Energy Commission spokesman said today.
Religious leaders of many denominations joined prominent laymen last night at a dinner honoring the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman.

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 7 -- Eugene H. Nickerson upset the Republicans in Nassau County on his second bid for elective office here. Defeated for County Surrogate two years ago he came back today as the candidate for County Executive and won, something many believed was "impossible" for a Democrat.

Rumors that Ray Bolger would be starred in "All American" were verified yesterday by Edward Padula, co-sponsor with L. Slade Brown, and Gwen Rickand, Mrs. Bolger. The confirmation puts an end to reports that the part would go to Ron Moody, who scored as Fagan in the London musical hit, "Oliver."

One result to cheer about in yesterday's election in New York was the vote of approval given to a new City Charter. This represents the first over-all Charter revision in twenty-five years, and of itself should bring some improvement in city government in the years to come regardless of who is Mayor.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) The Atomic Energy Commission announced today selection of the Fluor Corporation, Ltd., of Los Angeles to build what it called the world's largest nuclear test reactor.
HELSINKI, Finland, Nov. 7 -- Finland decided today to send Foreign Minister Ahti K. Karjalainen to Moscow to ask what the Russians really had in mind in requesting defense consultations.
Abraham J. Gellinoff and Nathaniel T. Helman, organization Democrats, were elected justices of the State Supreme Court yesterday in the First Judicial District (Manhattan and Bronx).

WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 7 -- The control of Westchester County's government was retained by the Republicans today, but with pluralities lower than party leaders had expected. It will be fifty-third consecutive year of Republican control.

LOS ALAMOS, N.M., Nov. 7 (AP) -- A full-power test of the Kiwi B-1A reactor was postponed today following a hydrogen gas explosion that wrecked the portable metal shed used to protect the reactor at Jackass Flats, Nev. Five men were injured.

GEORGE STAVROPOULOS, a Greek custom designer whose salon was the talk of Athens' chic and famous Constitution Square, has been in America only seven months and already he and his clothes are making fashion news.
The City Aquarium's hunt for sharks to place on exhibition has finally ended.
Contrary to the headline on your story (Oct. 18), the American Medical Association does not "decry" President Kennedy's appeal to help the mentally retarded.

The New York Public Library has sold the twelve-story store and loft building at 137 West Twenty-fifth Street, between Sixth and Seventh Avenues. The building was bought for cash by clients of Walter Scott Co., who plan to remodel it.
A procedure that would spare school personnel the stigma of being publicly charged with unfounded improprieties is being considered by the Board of Education.

The first major state-wide court reform in 115 years was approved yesterday. At the same time New York voters appeared to have rejected the controversial proposal to use $500,000,000 of the state's credit to guarantee loans to private and public colleges.

The Brookfield Farms' excellent sprinter, Intentionally, gave a courageous performance yesterday in winning the $23,900 Sport Page Handicap at Aqueduct. Competing against eleven rivals and carrying the top weight of 129 pounds, the 5-year-old son of Intent rallied in the stretch before crossing the finish line in front.
ROME, Nov. 7 -Pope John XXIII renewed his appeal today to rulers of both East and West to negotiate a settlement of problems that threaten the peace of the world.
The United States squad planning to compete in next February's world skiing championships at Chamonix, France, and Zakopane, Poland, is $25,000 short of the money it needs to make the trip to Europe.

VANDENBERG AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Nov. 7 (UPI) -- Trouble in the twenty-five-foot-long Discoverer XXXIV satellite has doomed efforts to recover an instrument capsule from it, the Air Force said today.

Rally experts of the Sports Car Club of America have just concluded a meeting in Washington during which the whole structure of the national program was assessed. We have an idea that the general report could be summed up in one word: shaky.

LONDON, Nov. 7 (Reuters) -- The Old Vic Theatre tonight introduced a theatrical experiment with the performance of the first of two consecutive works separated by 1,200 years but linked by the same theme.
MEMPHIS, Nov. 7 (UPI) -- Frank R. Ahlgren, editor of The Commercial Appeal for a quarter of a century, was honored here tonight for his twenty-five years of journalistic leadership.
ALBANY, Nov. 7 -- The work of the Joint Legislative Committee on Reapportionment was defended today by its chairman, State Senator Robert C. McEwen.

WOODCLIFFE, N.J., Nov. 7 -- Mayor Fred J. Homann, Republican incumbent, and Eugene J. Santoli, his Democratic opponent, wound up in a tie today at 497 votes each. There are 1.424 registered voters in the borough.

THE best shortstop in the major leagues last season was Tony Kubek of the Yankees. The experts, who rarely agree on anything, were unanimously agreed on that. Next season, however, Kubek will be the best nonplaying shortstop in the United States Army. UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 7 -- The discussion of a means of achieving an early end to colonialism began today in the General Assembly. The debate was marked by a Soviet attack on the Western powers and considerable division among African and Asian nations on how strong a position to take.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7 (AP) -- A light but steady commission house demand for grain futures primed a surge of speculative buying today that raised all commodities rather substantially in spots on the Board of Trade.

NEW CITY, N.Y., Nov. 7 -- All five incumbents on the Rockland County Board of Supervisors were re-elected today, and the board remains 4-to-1 Democratic.

LONDON, Nov. 7 -- With buyers holding off and business volume small, prices generally drifted lower on the stock market here today.

Pan American World Airways pilots have set a Friday night strike deadline.

The voters approved a new city Charter overwhelmingly yesterday. Effective Jan. 1, 1963, it provides the first over-all change in the basic framework of the city govern ment in twenty-five years. The proposal won by a wide margin in every borough and provided an added fillip to the resounding victory Mayor Wagner won in his bid for a third term.

The strike settlement enabled him to glow on Election Day as the savior whose readiness to put aside sleep and politicking in the campaign's final hours restored milk to the millions. But it has long been clear that, as usual, all has been chaos in the milk negotiations.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Nov. 7 -- This city's voters endorsed City Manager Joseph McD. Mitchell's drastic welfare reform program today by returning two incumbent Republican councilmen, William E. Doulin and William McIntyre, to office for two-year terms.

The Democrats retained control of the New Jersey Assembly in balloting yesterday and appeared at an early hour today to have an even chance of controlling next year's State Senate for the first time since 1914.

ACCRA, Ghana, Nov. 7 -- Duncan Sandys, Britain's Commonwealth Relations Secretary, left Accra today for London to advise the Cabinet to allow Queen Elizabeth's visit to Ghana to take place as planned.
Mayor Wagner's election to a third term yesterday brought varying opinions from Democrats and Republicans with regard to future political trends.
Four new directors have been elected by the board of the General Cigar Company, Inc., to replace four who have resigned, it was announced by Julius Strauss, president.

Jim Brown, a 21-year-old New York University senior, yesterday won a title that had eluded him twice in former years. He captured the Metropolitan Intercollegiate Track and Field Association cross-country championship at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 7 -- A three-day general strike called by the General Confederation of Labor began last midnight and brought almost a holiday atmosphere to Buenos Aires. But for union leaders it was a bitter day of defeat.
WASHINGTON, Nov 7 -- The crisis in Ecuador appears to illustrate the political dangers of the efforts by Latin American Governments to bolster their economies through tough "self-help" measures.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7 (AP) -- General Motors was the pacemaker today as auto shares moved up with prices generally higher on the Midwest Stock Exchange.

Mayor Wagner won re-election for a third term yesterday.

Robert Rossen, whose hard-hitting poolroom expose, "The Hustler," brought him his first substantial critical success since the Academy Award-winning "All the King's Men" twelve years ago, has scheduled another unglamorized movie examination of contemporary American mores for production this spring.

The first of four volumes of a popular edition of the late Rex Brasher's "Birds and Trees of North America" will be published Nov. 24 by the new book concern, Rowman Littlefield. The three other volumes are planned for publication in February, July and October of next year.
