One of the watchers at a polling place yesterday was an observer from a country where Mayors are appointed, not elected. He is Dr. Daubeny B. Cooper, chairman of the three-man Elections Commission of Liberia.

The four-story building at 4601 Eleventh Avenue, Brooklyn, has been sold by L. Kadish to an investing client of M. Gross, lawyer. The house contains thirty-eight apartments and occupies a plot 100 by 116 feet.

United Air Lines reported yesterday combined earnings and gain from sale of aircraft for the first nine months of this year of $6,356,000 or $1.37 a share. This compared with $9,711,000 and $2.43 for the comparable 1960 period, when fewer shares were outstanding.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 7 -- Samuel J. Tedesco, a Democrat, won re-election today to his third term as Mayor of this Fairfield County community.
The seventy-fourth National Horse Show, which opened eight days ago in Madison Square Garden to the music of the First Army Band, closed on the same note last night.
The New York Titans practiced two hours at the Polo Grounds yesterday, beginning preparations for Saturday night's American Football League game here with the Oakland Raiders.
MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 7 -- Nassau County Democrats scored a major upset today by electing their first County Executive in history.
WARSAW, Nov. 5 -- Newspapers gave its readers a rare peek this week-end into the mailbox of a Communist dictator.
President Kennedy paid tribute yesterday to the Theatre Guild American Repertory Company, which completed a tour of Europe, the Near East and Latin America on Monday night.
RUSSELL, Kan., Nov. 7 (AP) -- Two teen-age soldiers accused of having killed seven persons were convicted and sentenced to hang today.
Milk, a scarce commodity for two weeks, began to flow into homes and stores in New York City and Long Island yesterday at a steadily accelerating rate.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 7 -- U Thant, Acting Secretary General, declared today that the "administrative and financial integrity" of the United Nations must be "zealously maintained."

PHILADELPHIA, Wednesday, Nov. 8 -- The failure of the Philadelphia Democratic political machine to live up to pre-election claims may have cost the party a seat on the State Supreme Court in yesterday's election.

A WONDERFUL orange-gold and a bright pinkish-red have recently been added to fruit stands -- in the form of persimmons and pomegranates. Both these fruits arrive here in fairly limited quantities but, such as it is, this is the peak of their season.

Mme. Nonna Gabrindasvili of the Soviet Union, the leader in the women's world chess championship challengers tournament at Vrnjacka Banja, and Lisa Lane of Philadelphia adjourned yesterday after forty moves, according to a report from Yugoslavia.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- President Kennedy and Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru agreed today that the West's right of access to West Berlin must be guaranteed in any settlement with the Soviet Union.
RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 7 -- Albertis S. Harrison Jr., candidate of the Byrd Democratic organization, was elected Governor of Virginia today.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 7 -- Representative Marguerite Stitt Church said here today that if other countries put as much effort into improving race relations as the United States does, "the whole world would rejoice."

A department store executive told a gathering of discount store officials yesterday that they were going to face a "newly awakened, aroused, competitive, fighting spirit" in the department store field.
MOSCOW, Nov. 7 -- Marshal Kliment Y. Voroshilov, the former Soviet head of state, learned today that he was no longer expected to associate publicly with the Kremlin leadership.

WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 7 -- Edwin Gilbert Michaelian, whose surname rhymes with Pennsylvanian, was first elected County Executive of Westchester in 1957 after years of steady advancement in local politics. He formerly operated a home and office furnishings business here, which Mrs. Michaelian now heads.
QUITO, Ecuador, Nov. 7 (AP) -- An Army regiment rebelled and left its barracks to take up positions on the southern flank of this capital shortly after Vice President Arosemena was arrested today.
Changes in the responsibilities and organization of the Joint Chiefs of Staff are once again under discussion and study in the Pentagon.

Tom Haggerty, a senior halfback for Columbia from Worcester, Mass., yesterday was named Ivy League back of the week for his performance against Cornell last Saturday. It was the third time this season a Lion back had gained the honor.
Following is the text of Mayor Wagner's victory statement last night before campaign workers at the Astor Hotel:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Dr. Vannevar Bush, scientist and author, advised the medical profession today to clear away abuses as a means of resisting what he called an intensified trend toward socialism in the United States.
NEW HAVEN, Nov. 7 -- Mayor Richard C. Lee was reelected to his fifth consecutive two-year term today.
WHEN an instrument is as fragile in tone as the guitar, two can sound better than one. When the artists playing them are as good as Ida Presti and Alexandre Lagoya, they do sound better than one.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 7 -- A complete ban on nuclear weapons will be debated tomorrow in the General Assembly's Political Committee. The ban has been called for by a resolution offered by a group of African and Asian nations.

Many New Yorkers display a marked weakness for superlatives when talking about their city. They are fond of larding their descriptions with such remarks as: "There are more people of Irish descent living in New York than there are in Dublin; there are more Italians than there are in Rome, more Jewish people than in Tel Aviv."
Chicago, Nov. 7 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
MOSCOW, Nov. 7 -- Premier Khrushchev indicated today that the Soviet Union was ready for a respite in the Berlin dispute and in nuclear testing.

"THE Microscope," an exhibition of microphotographs, may be seen at the Brooklyn Children's Museum, Brooklyn Avenue and Park Place. The photographs show the vital cells of the body magnified hundreds of thousands of times.

AN intriguing new form of the running-deer target is in operation on week-ends at the Blue Trail range in East Wallingford, Conn. It is the most devastating device to confront hawk-eyed marksmen in a long time.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Nov. 7 -- South Vietnamese officials have reported that they have conclusive evidence that Communist forces attacking South Vietnam are enlarging a complex of military bases along the Cambodian frontier and partly in Cambodian territory.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 7 (UPI) -- An agent of the Civil Rights Division said yesterday that the Justice Department had investigated the arrest of a bus terminal manager for serving Negroes in the station's all-white cafeteria.

Robert F. Wagner has done the expected and been re-elected Mayor of New York City. If he completes his third four-year term he will have equaled Fiorello La Guardia's tenure in office, exceeding by two years the previous record among nearly a hundred Mayors going back to 1665. The Wagner victory was by a far greater margin than had been predicted, a convincing evidence of his popularity.
DETROIT, Nov. 7 -- Jerome P. Cavanagh, 33-year-old lawyer making a first run for public office, scored a stunning upset tonight to win election as Mayor of Detroit.
LONDON, Nov. 7 -- The Labor party accused the Government today of having failed to take practical steps to achieve a sustained expansion of industrial production without inflation.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Nov. 7 (UPI) -- President Kennedy's proposal for health insurance for the aged under the social priority at the next session of security system will get top Congress, Abraham A. Ribicoff, Secretary of Health. Education and Welfare, said tonight.
A detective who had arrested an unemployed Brooklyn salesman as the man allegedly tried to bribe him was promoted to first-grade detective yesterday by Police Commissioner Michael J. Murphy.
BOSTON, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Two of the best-known Massachusetts Mayors were beaten today as voters in thirty-eight of thirty-nine cities elected new municipal governments.
THE Viennese are waltzing to a new tune -- the sound of schillings clinking in the slots of vending machines.

Eastern Air Lines filed objections with the Civil Aeronautics Board yesterday to Continental Airlines' plan to offer three classes of service on its jets starting Dec. 1. The proposal includes a lower-fare "jet economy" service.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Nov. 7 (AP) -- Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower, looking hale and hearty after a physical check-up in Washington, voted here.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Nov. 7 -- The six nations of the European Economic Community, or Common Market, agreed tonight on their position for the negotiations, beginning tomorrow, for Britain's projected entry.
LISBON, Portugal, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar won by default today an extension of his thirty-two-year rule.
Said Bob Zuppke, before "The Dutchman" sent his Illinois team but to do battle with a mighty Minnesota juggernaut and gain one of the football victories of the ages:
NEWBURGH, N.Y., Nov. 8 -- A street brawl involving some of this city's chief officials broke out on Broadway last night in front of Democratic headquarters.

THE new element added to the Orchestra of America series is the inclusion of Latin-American composers. Up to now Richard Korn, the group's conductor, has interested himself only in music of the United States.
TOULON, France, Nov. 8 -President de Gaulle called today on his Right-wing terrorist opposition to abandon its "unhealthy dreams" and rejoin the country behind him.

Today's new film is "Flower Drum Song," a Universal-International adaptation of the Broadway musical comedy by Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d, at the Radio City Music Hall. Nancy Kwan, James Shigeta, Miyoshi Umeki and Juanita Hall have the leading roles in the color offering, produced by Ross Hunter and directed by Henry Koster.

Events tonight: "La Boheme," Metropolitan Opera, 8; "Oedipus Rex" and "Carmina Burana," New York City Opera Company, City Center, 8:15; New York Philharmonic preview concert, Paul Paray, conductor, Carnegie Hall 8:30; Guiomar Novaes, pianist, Rogers Auditorium, Metropolitan Museum of Art, 8:30.
Set in motion by the General Motors extra dividend on Monday and -- according to some brokers -- the Democratic victories on Tuesday, the stock market had one of its best days yesterday.

The directors of United States Gypsum Company voted yesterday to increase the quarterly dividend on the common stock to 65 cents a share from 60 cents. They also approved an extra dividend of 25 cents a share.
It was tulip time at the Waldorf-Astoria last evening, where the Festival of Holland Ball was held in behalf of the International Cultural Center for Youth in Jerusalem.

WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 8 -Adios Butler, the world champion pacer, today was made the 1-4 choice to win the $50,000 National Pacing Derby, the final race of his career, on Saturday night at Roosevelt Raceway.
LONDON, Thursday, Nov. 9 -- Queen Elizabeth and the Duke of Edinburgh will leave by air early today for Accra, capital of Ghana, to begin a tour of West Africa.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Four national education organizations declared today that adult education "is an integral and necessary service of the public school system."

The discount house, once the pariah of American retailing, has now carved out an accepted position in the field. Traditional merchants who formerly scorned the discount operator now concede he is here to stay and many have themselves climbed aboard the discount bandwagon, which is steadily picking up momentum. Symbolic of the movement to discounting, which its practitioners like to call a retailing "explosion" or "revolution," was the seminar on discount operatons held this week.

BOMBAY, India, Nov. 8 (Reuters) -- Bombay, India's national cricket champion, lost eight wickets for 210 runs today and still needed 76 runs by the close of play to match the 286 for five declared by the Marylebone C.C. of England.

Lucille Ball will have a starring role in "The Good Years," the Leland Hayward production to be televised by the Columbia Broadcasting System on Jan. 12. Other cast members announced earlier were Mort Sahl and Henry Fonda, who will be the host and narrator.

An account of the British "Naval Secrets Case," the trial of five Communist agents, including two Americans, will be published Nov. 27 by Coward-McCann under the title "Soviet Spy Ring." The author is Arthur Tietjen, a reporter for The London Daily Mail, who covered the case throughout for newspapers in England and America.
While pacing the New York Giants' rushing attack this season, Alex Webster has moved into third place on the club's list of leading ball-carriers on career totals.

Mayor Wagner's election to a third term is making him the state's most influential Democrat. As such he will have to shoulder the primary responsibility for reorganizing his party in the city and in the state, for helping it find and develop suitable candidates for Governor and United States Senator next year and for formulating issues Democrats can exploit in the 1962 state elections.
ALBANY, Nov. 8 -- Governor Rockefeller proposed today that the Legislature set aside $100,000,000 in state funds for a major fall-out shelter program.

BERLIN, Nov. 8 -- Forty French gendarmes chased a group of fifteen East German policemen out of West Berlin today. The East Germans had been clearing bushes around a railroad water tower in the French sector.
CHICAGO, Nov. 8 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

With a bruise on the middle finger of his throwing hand healed, Johnny Unitas tossed four touchdown passes for the seventh time in his six-year National Football League career, completed tweny-two of thirty-five tosses, had only one interception and led the Baltimore Colts to a 45-21 triumph over the Western Conference leading Green Bay Packers Sunday.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 8 -Polly Bergen's petition for an injunction to prevent theatrical release of a film in which she played the leading role was denied today by Superior Court Judge Gordon L. Files.
CHICAGO, Nov. 8 -- Dr. Robert C. Weaver, administrator of the Housing and Home Finance Agency, suggested today that the Federal Government might subsidize a cut in commuter fares as an experiment.

More than $30,000,000 in added interest is expected to be paid in 1962 to some 4,000,000 savings bank depositors as a result of a rise in interest rates authorized yesterday by the New York State Banking Board.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (UPI) -- Postmaster General J. Edward Day took the hint from President Kennedy today and toned down a sharply critical statement about a Negro postman he had reluctantly restored to duty.
The Brotherhood party conceded yesterday that it had got more experience than votes out of Tuesday's election. Nonetheless the party's leaders said confidently: "Wait till next time."
The United States must revolutionize its reciprocal trade laws to compete and prosper in the trading world of tomorrow, Secretary of the Treasury Douglas Dillon asserted here last night.
The student government at Hunter College in the Bronx has asked 3,600 day students to cut classes all day today in support of a "strike for academic freedom."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 8 -- The United States moved today to put off further debate on the composition of the United Nations staff until next fall to give U Thant, the acting Secretary General, time to work out the problem.
MEXICO CITY, Nov. 8 -- Mexico, which has charted a non-aligned course in the East-West "cold war," is giving evidence of moving toward the West, at lease on the issue of nuclear testing.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 8 -- The head of the Religious Zionists of America today termed the Arab refugee problem in the Middle East the "foremost barrier" to a permanent peace between Israel and the Arab states.
Following is a transcript of President Kennedy's news conference yesterday in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times:

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 8 -- The Syrian Government has protested to Lebanon against permitting President Gamal Abdel Nasser's Cairo Government to use Lebanese territory for subversive operations against Syria.

Eastern, National and Mohawk Airlines have withdrawn "for the present" their offer to merge Mohawk with Northeast Airlines and for Eastern and National to assume Northeast's Boston-New York-Florida routes, it was announced yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 8 -- The Security Council will meet Monday to discuss the eruption of new violence in the Congo.
PARIS, Nov. 8 -- The butchers of Paris knuckled under tonight before a determined Government drive to reduce the inordinately high prices of the best cuts of beef.

The six-story apartment building with self-service elevator at 2710 Webb Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by the 2710 Webb Corporation to an investing client of N. Kliegman, lawyer. The building occupies a plot 86 by 141 feet and contains fifty-four apartments.
The refunding of $6,963,000,000 of Government debt that is now going on caused further churning of Treasury securities yesterday.
CAMDEN, N.J., Nov. 8 (AP) -- Eric Guerin was suspended today for ten days by the Garden State Park stewards for a foul in last Saturday's running of the Garden State Stakes, the world's richest race.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 8 -- The forty-third season of the Los Angeles Philharmonic Orchestra will open here tomorrow night at the Philharmonic Auditorium.

About 2,000 women carrying yellow balloons marked "Women Want Peace" held a mass demonstration yesterday on First Avenue near United Nations headquarters. Their protest was aimed mainly at the effects of nuclear fall-out.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 8 (AP) -- A jolly, bearded real estate man from Santa Barbara, Calif., completed a trip around the world today with his wife and eight children. Most of it was in their own bus.
Like many appliances, the home washing machine is a versatile creature. In addition to routine washing, it can also starch clothing.

Despite a won-lost record of 4 -- 4, the New York Titans still hope to capture the Eastern Division title in the American Football League. They believe they can do so by taking four of their remaining five games.
HOUSTON, Tex., Nov. 8 (AP) -- At least three persons were killed last night when a freighter and a tanker collided in the Houston Ship Channel.

Thomas E. Stakem, chairman of the Federal Maritime Commission, disclosed yesterday that one of the agency's major headaches had been solved by a retreat agreed upon by the Japan Atlantic and Gulf Freight Conference.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The three major television networks carried only three-quarters of President Kennedy's news conference today in taped rebroadcasts. They broadcast thirteen of the nineteen questions put to the President.

The installation of one of the most elaborate exhibitions ever arranged by the Museum of Modern Art, twelve great stained glass windows designed and largely executed by Marc Chagall, is nearing completion.
A strike of Pan American World Airways pilots scheduled to begin tomorrow night will be deferred, the National Mediation Board said yesterday.

One of the most engaging visitors the United States has had in a long time was President Leopold S. Senghor of Senegal. His grace as poet and philosopher charmed academic audiences at Harvard and Fordham; his resoluteness in reminding his fellow leaders among the uncommitted countries of the obligations of genuine neutrality stirred equal admiration at the United Nations.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 8 (UPI) -- The Tennessee Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that a jury might not retract its verdict in a criminal case once the presiding judge had accepted the verdict.

The International Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots, largest deck officers' union in the nation, will mark today the sixth anniversary of a pension plan that has paid $24,037,962 to members and dependents.

An heroic dog that probably saved the lives of six members of a family living at 643 West 171st Street has received the Medal of Honor of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.

Production of electric power in the country rose to 15,396,000,000 kilowatt-hours in the week ended last Saturday from 15,263,000,000 kilowatt-hours in the preceding week, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. In the same 1960 week 14,373,000,000 kilowatt-hours were produced.
CHICAGO, Nov. 8 (AP) -Most grain futures contracts added to their broad gains of Tuesday in fairly active dealings today on the Board of Trade. Wheat, the major exception, eased on all deliveries.

A syndicate of South American investors represented by Robert P. Sheldon, Inc., broker, has bought five six-story apartment buildings at 68-12 to 6844 Burns Street, Forest Hills, Queens. Enkells-Rakoff Co. were the sellers.

A substantial margin of negative votes upstate on Tuesday defeated the amendment that would have provided state aid to building programs of public and private colleges, religious as well as nonsectarian.
MOSCOW, Nov. 8 -- The citizens of Stalingrad were reported today to be calling for a change in the name of their city.
A strike in 120 of the city's largest restaurants was averted yesterday when the Consolidated Dining Room Employes Union, Local 1, agreed to a new two-year contract.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- One reason for the infrequency of his news conferences, President Kennedy indicated today, is the sensitivity of foreign policy questions now taking most of his time.
LITTLE ROCK, Nov. 8 (AP) -- A $48,746 tax suit against Winthrop Rockefeller has been settled, his attorney said today.
A 26-year-old Queens mother and a woman neighbor were arraigned yesterday on homicide charges in the fatal beating of the former's 7-year-old daughter.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- An industry proposal for organizing a commercial communications satellite system encountered reservations today from Administration spokesmen and outright opposition from the chairman of a Senate subcommittee.

The State Department has now confirmed the fact that Soviet planes are dropping supplies into Tchepone, a mountain hamlet in Laos just over the border from the highlands of South Vietnam. Tchepone is in the hands of the Communist-led forces in Laos, and has been used as a supply and transit base for Communist North Vietnamese guerrillas operating in the northern sector of South Vietnam.
RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 8 -A chartered airliner carrying Army recruits to a training camp crashed and burned ten miles southeast of here tonight. At least seventy-seven persons were killed.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -President Kennedy warmly defended Chancellor Adenauer today against the "wholly wrong" Soviet charges about German militarism and revenge-seeking.
The Soviet moves on Berlin and Germany are cause of much irritation, injustice and terror. But is this all there is to the Berlin issue?
The Remington Rand division of Sperry Rand Corporation announced yesterday the purchase of the National Data Processing Corporation of Dallas, Tex., for an undisclosed amount.
Tennessee Gas Transmission Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday higher operating revenues and net income for the twelve and three months ended on Sept. 30 than in the like 1960 periods.

The split in the world Communist movement publicized by Premier Khrushchev last month is becoming wider, and therefore more explosive in its possibilities. Communist China has now made its support of the Hoxha leadership in Albania clearer than ever with its message praising Hoxha on the occasion of the Albanian Workers (Communist) party's twentieth anniversary.

Whitey Ford, the bellwether of the Yankee pitching staff for more than ten years, received a tribute yesterday that brought his finest year to a grand climax. The compact little lefthander who reached his thirtythird birthday last month gained the Cy Young award as the outstanding pitcher for 1961 in the major leagues.

JOHN B. KEANE has a taste -- and a memory -- for the grotesqueries familiar in a certain branch of Irish playwriting. In "Sharon's Grave," which the Irish Players brought last night to the Maidman Playhouse, he has assembled a few, set them to wild, lilting notes -- many old and a few fresh -- and offered them as a play.

Football coaches and officials were warned yesterday to be on the alert for playing equipment that might cause serious injuries and to crack down on rules violations that also constituted serious danger.
THE newly elected County Executive of Nassau County -- the first Democrat ever to win the post -- is a man accustomed to winning against odds.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- The Federal Aviation Agency proposed today a new pilot category to fit an old but revived type of air vehicle, the autogiro.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -President Kennedy said today that the United States should start now to reshape its foreign trade policy to meet the challenges and obligations that it faces around the world.

The Phoenix Theatre, Second Avenue at Twelfth Street, until recently the home of the producing organization bearing that name, has been leased for a year with an option for a second year. The new lessees, who will take immediate possession, are Michael Iannucci and Milton Warner.
DETROIT, Nov. 8 (UPI) -Richie Guerin pumped in 33 points and Johnnie Green 30 as the New York Knicks posted a 130-108 victory over the Chicago Packers in a National Basketball League game tonight.

Seventy-five aroused homeowners in Riverdale, the Bronx, were told yesterday they did not know a good thing when they saw it -- a ten-story apartment house set in a neighborhood restricted to one-family houses.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Scientists from twenty-two nations agreed today measles could be controlled by new vaccines, but they said work still must be done to eliminate unpleasant side effects.
Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz said yesterday he would press Governor Rockefeller and the Legislature to transfer the administration of residential rent control to the city government.

NEW YORK, more than most communities, offers its inhabitants an astonishing variety of vegetables. Some of them are unfamiliar to the public at large but a lot of them have merit. There are mustard greens, collard greens, fennel, kale and kohlrabi.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (UPI) -- Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg predicted today that rebellions agains James R. Hoffa of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters would spread and threaten his control over the 1,500,000-member truck union.

The appointment of Dr. Marvin E. Perkins by Mayor Robert F. Wagner as our first city Commissioner of Mental Health has special significance not just for the city, but possibly for the entire country. It means that for the first time the job of running the city's psychiatric services has been given individual rank, along with hospital, welfare, health and correction services.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- President Kennedy expressed the hope today that the Defense Department would have an up-to-date booklet on fall-out shelters for distribution to every American family by the end of the month.

LONDON, Nov. 8 -- Prime Minister Macmillan declared today that Britain would make a great advance toward the stability she needs for full economic development if she could get a nationally accepted wage policy.

Philip H. Gilsten, former deputy city treasurer and a Bronx Democratic leader, was ordered in Supreme Court yesterday to submit to questioning about "scurrilous" literature circulated during the September primary campaign.
Some slight progress has been made in reducing the one-party monopoly with which the Democrats have held the Board of Estimate and the City Council for many years.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Favorable growing weather helped increase this year's estimated cotton crop by 204,000 bales in October to 14,538,000 bales as of Nov. 1, the Department of Agriculture reported today in issuing its latest production forecast.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 8 -- When Joseph E. Levine leaves here for New York in a couple of days, many will sigh with nostalgia -- and just as many with relief.
Discount merchants were warned yesterday that they would be unable to meet the growing competition in their own field if they did not overcome an undue emphasis on price over value.
Mayor Wagner, buoyed by his re-election, vowed yesterday to seek the "revitalization of the entire Democratic leadership" at the state as well as the city level.
OSTERVILLE, Mass., Oct. 30 -- Since mid-October the hue of the cranberry bogs has been fading from magenta to burnt umber.

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 8 -Jubilant Nassau County Democrats and unhappy Republicans differed today on the reasons for the Democratic achievement yesterday in electing their first County Executive in history.

' TIS the season to prepare to be jolly. The December holiday starts with Christmas cards and well-organized women are ordering theirs now. (The woman who was really hyper-metropic placed her order in May when the new card collections were first published.)

WE have two books before us today. Together they illuminate national and international politics. One is "The Backside of Washington,"* an entertaining spoofing by a capital columnist, Dick West. The other is "What's Got Your Back Up?", a magnificent sheaf of devastating cartoons by Bill Mauldin.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Nov. 8 -Suffolk County Executive H. Lee Dennison, a Democrat who is confronted with a Republicancontrolled Board of Supervisors as a result of yesterday's elections, was outwardly optimistic today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The Administration watched the crisis in Ecuador with concern tonight, but the first assessments in the fast-changing situation were that the apparent victory of Vice President Arosemena did not necessarily imply a takeover by extreme Leftists.
WHILE shopping in a New York department store last week, a woman paused to admire a dinner plat. She asked the saleslady whether the plate was earthenware or stoneware.

The audience rose as the master of ceremonies raised his glass and offered a toast to "her grand and glorious majesty -Queen Victoria, and to the President of the United States -- William McKinley." The nineteenth century?
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Senator Jacob K. Javits said today Tuesday's elections proved ultra-conservatism was as outmoded as isolationism in American political life.

Paperboard production in the nation totaled 352,866 tons in the week ended Saturday. This figure compared with 356,111 tons in the preceding week and 308,733 tons in the same week last year, the National Paperboard Association reported yesterday.

WAITING for the return of the figure, or recognizable image, is a favorite occupation of some of those who keep an eye on abstract expressionism. Judging from a number of shows I have seen in the last few days, the emerging figure is going to have a difficult birth.

MUNICH, Germany, Nov. 8 (Reuters) -- The European premiere of "The Wall," Millard Lampell's adaptation of John Hersey's novel about the World War II Warsaw ghetto, made a deep impression on both audience and critics.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange dropped 20 cents to $1.80 a bale yesterday.

MUSICIANS are often called upon to transcend difficulties not of their making -- pianos that squeak, violin strings that break, fire engines on near-by streets. Last night at Judson Hall a young pianist named Sally MacArthur countered with complete equanimity an evil greater than all of these.
Six adjourned games from the seventh and eighth rounds were played off yesterday in the women's championship challengers chess tournament, according to a report from Yugoslavia.

GENEVA, Nov. 8 -- The development of mass markets in Western Europe as a result of economic integration may increase competition for United States producers at home, experts of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) said today.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 8 (AP) -- Artistic and scholastic temperaments clashed today over three drawings of nude women banned from display at St. Mary's College.
CHICAGO, Nov. 8 (UPI) -- President Kennedy said today the United States led the world "in the peaceful uses of Atomic energy."

The New York Stock Exchange and American Stock Exchange reported yesterday, pursuant to the Securities and Exchange Act of 1934, the following changes in the holdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed companies:
HONG KONG, Nov. 8 -- Albania's quarrel with the Soviet Union was aired again in Peiping tonight when the Albanian Ambassador publicly defended his country against Soviet criticism.
The New York Stock Exchange believes that it has found a way to unlock billions of dollars of capital for reinvestment, if the Government would let it use the key.

A new issue of $155,000,000 of Florida State Turnpike Authority revenue bonds will be offered for public subscription during the week of Dec. 4, according to plans of the syndicate managers. The marketing will be directed by Dillon, Read Co. Inc.; Glore, Forgan Co.; White Weld Co.; Wertheim Co.; Tripp Co.; Leedy, Wheeler Alleman, Inc.; Childress Co.; and Pierce, Carrison, Wulbern, Inc.
Don McKenney of the Boston Bruins ruined the night for the New York Rangers with eighteen seconds remaining in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- President Kennedy named Gov. J. Howard Edmondson of Oklahoma, a Democrat, today to a mission that will study Tunisia's economic development plans.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 8 -- The General Assembly, by an overwhelming vote, asked the United States, Britain and the Soviet Union tonight to resume negotiations at once on a treaty prohibiting nuclear tests.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Firemen battled to keep control of two big brush fires today. The toll of homes destroyed, some of the city's finest, had reached 456.
Never worse than second, Fred W. Hooper's 3-year-old filly, Bright Holly, scored a three-and-three-quarter-length victory at Aqueduct yesterday in the $10,000 Fair Star Handicap at six furlongs.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- President Kennedy said today that the Soviet Union, with its latest intensive test series, had acquired the "dubious" distinction of having created more atomic fall-out than the other three nuclear powers combined.
Michael J. Quill demanded multi-million-dollar settlement packages yesterday as he opened negotiations with the Transit Authority and the Fifth Avenue Coach Lines.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Democratic and Republican candidates for state and local offices shared the bag of victories in yesterday's elections, but the Democrats got the big ones. Conventionally, therefore, Republican National Chairman Miller's post-mortem stressed the first of these election results, and Democratic National Chairman Bailey's stressed the second.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -Mrs. John F. Kennedy has postponed a private visit to India and Pakistan until January, the White House said today.
The Borden Company announced yesterday that sales and earnings in both the third quarter and first nine months of this year were at record highs.
RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 8 (AP) -- Rescuers at the scene of the crash of the chartered Constellation tonight said they had seen no bodies outside the plane.
Nearly half of the restaurant owners along Maryland's Route 40 have agreed to desegregate, thereby averting a massive Freedom Ride set for Saturday.

THE grand slam force, which was scoffed at by nearly all experts when the late Ely Culbertson first proposed it in 1936, has now come to be used by nearly all experts. It is a free bid of five no-trump in the course of slam bidding.
LONDON, Nov. 8 -- Prices advanced in most sections of the stock market here today on a modest increase in demand in a market short of stock. Business activity remained relatively low.
BELIZE, British Honduras, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Ten United States Navy helicopters made food drops in British Honduras today to persons still marooned as a result of Hurricane Hattie.
A twenty-four-page handbook in Spanish and English has been published for parents of non-English-speaking pupils in the city schools.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 --- The bouffant hair style -subject of many an American headline in the last year -has acquired a champion in India.

Milk was distributed yesterday in normal quantities in the city and on Long Island as the full effect of last Monday's settlement of the two-week strike of teamsters reached the consumer level.

The Liberal party plans to reappraise its position in light of Tuesday's victory by Mayor Wagner, which it contends "broke the back of Tammany Hall in New York City."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -President Kennedy sought to explain to Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru today the Government's position on several questions that have caused misunderstanding and resentment between the United States and India.

Sam Snead, who recommends a free golf swing, also believes in free enterprise. Yesterday he became president of a new corporation.

The French liner Liberte slipped quietly into port yesterday morning for her final twoday stay here as the French Line's trans-Atlantic flagship.

Nobody with a sound knowledge of dogs and a license from the American Kennel Club ever has to wonder what he'll do during the years of retirement. He can be a judge at shows from one edge of the continent to the other. Between traveling, judging and social activities he will hardly have a dull day.

Nelson Rockefeller's advice that we resume atmospheric nuclear testing could not have been more badly timed, coming as it does in the midst of a world-wide anxiety about the adverse effects of the current U.S.S.R. explosions. I do not believe the Govenor realizes the extent of the horror, revulsion and fear which the Russian blasts have produced in hundreds of millions of people everywhere.

If they blink from the unaccustomed brightness, it's because they've been drowsing in semi-darkness. For the first time they can look ahead and see a possible Ivy League championship before them, a vision that had not previously come into their ken.

President Kennedy's recent remarks on foreign economic policy indicate that he is about to make a major decision. The long-awaited world premiere of Eugene O'Neill's "More Stately Mansions" will take place on Jan. 19 at the Royal Dramatic Theatre in Stockholm, Sweden, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Karl Ragnar Gierow, director of the theatre.
