WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that crop prospects continued to improve during October because of favorable weather.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 9 -- Informed sources described the terms of a reported Soviet proposal for a Berlin settlement tonight as "very much like a rehash" of remarks by Foreign Minister Gromyko during his recent "exploratory" talks with Secretary of State Rusk in New York.

BEAUMONT, Tex., Nov. 9 (AP) -- Don Fairfield, an unerring putter from Casey, Ill., used only twenty-six strokes on the greens today to register a five-under-par 66 and take a two-stroke lead in the opening round of the $20,000 Beaumont invitation golf tournament.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Nov. 9 -- Residents of Westchester will pay tribute to the memory of Dag Hammarskjold, Secretary General of the United Nations, and Heinrich Wieschhoff of Bronxville. United Nations director of Political and Security Council Affairs, at a fund-raising benefit Saturday night.
The directors of the Universal Match Corporation voted yesterday a 2 per cent stock dividend on the common stock in lieu of cash. It is payable Dec. 15 to holders of record of Nov. 24.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Department store sales in the nation for the week ended Nov. 4 were 3 per cent above the 1960 level. This was reported today by the Federal Reserve Board, which listed the following percentage changes in sales from like periods of 1960:
MANILA, Nov. 9 -- Philippine authorities began emergency measures today to cope with violence as the bitter Presidential race entered its final stages.
The Society of the Silurians, composed of men who worked on New York City newspapers twenty-five or more years ago, announced its annual awards yesterday.
Former President Herbert Hoover said yesterday the United States had fallen behind the Communists in the production of scientists and engineers.

The Mayor's praiseworthy request to the Planning Commission to draft a program for setting aside land for much needed additional recreational areas in this city comes at a curious time when one considers a recent action by the Board of Estimate at a midsummer meeting held last July on short notice.

I am writing you apropos the current investigation as to whether or not to continue maintenance and operation of the Brooklyn Army Terminal. This problem in the main involves the choice of ports and has been solved repeatedly by trial and error, by actual practice.
CHICAGO, Nov. 9 -- An increase in the number of physicians in the United States is foreseen in a report released today by the American Medical Association.
A PLAY West made in the deal shown today, futile though it proved to be this time, is worth the scrutiny of many fine players who do nearly everything else right.
A consolidation of the sales activities of the Anglo-Newfoundland Development Company, Ltd., and Price Brothers Co., Ltd., two large Canadian newsprint manufacturers, has been announced.
CHICAGO, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Sears, Roebuck Co. has announced record sales for October and the first nine months of its fiscal year.

BERLIN, Nov. 9 -- The United States Army announced today that a motorized infantry company would drive up the autobahn from West Germany to West Berlin tomorrow in the first of a series of convoy exercises through Communist East Germany.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission, which faces some of the toughest problems in its twenty-seven-year history, has a full panel of five active commissioners for the first time in more than a year.
The sale of the liner Liberte for use as a floating hotel at the Seattle World's Fair has uncovered a gap in Federal regulations.

The Treasury's $6,963,000,000 refunding of 2 1/2 per cent bonds passed the subscription deadline yesterday with the bond market staging a trading session marked by morning liveliness and afternoon slack.
SAVANNAH, Ga., Nov. 9 -- A small, wiry man shouldered a mail bag today and trudged off on his appointed rounds through the southwestern corner of this historic old port city.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Colombia requested tonight that the foreign ministers of the Americas meet Jan. 10 to consider measures for the defense of the Western Hemisphere from any threat posed by "the intervention of extra-continental powers."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The start of a limited Administration program for retraining the long-term unemployed in depressed areas has been delayed by red tape.
Mayor Wagner picked up 5,000 votes yesterday, and the news gladdened the heart of Herbert A. Koehler, Democratic leader of Queens County.

LONDON, Nov. 9 -- A final tabulation today of the voting in Wales yesterday on whether Welsh pubs should be permitted to open Sundays showed that nine areas had voted to end the eighty-year-old ban and eight had decided to remain dry.

ALGIERS, Nov. 9 -- The apartments of about 250 Europeans here were searched in a large-scale police action against Right-Wing extremists that ended early this morning. Two thousand policemen and gendarmes took part.

The double-bill of Stravinsky's "Oedipus Rex" and Orff's "Carmina Burana" was given its second and last performance of the season by the New York City Opera Company last night at City Center. A nearly sold-out house indicated that the company was probably ill-advised in planning so few performances of this wholly enterprising evening's entertainment.
Bank clearings in the twenty-six leading cities of the nation totaled $26,263,323,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the lowest since the Labor Day week, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday.

I was surprised by the article published Oct. 28 concerning the false accusations of the American Jewish Committee against the Libyan Government of pursuing an official policy of harsh religious, cultural and economic oppression against Jewish citizens in Libya. This so-called Libyan official policy is reported, according to the American Jewish Committee, on the basis of information from Libya.

The five-story building containing forty-eight apartments and occupying a plot 95 by 95 feet at 1664 Weeks Avenue, the Bronx, has been bought by H. Nugiel for cash over mortgages amounting to $245,000. The sale was negotiated by the William K. Langfan Company, broker, for a client of B. Levine, lawyer.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Great events often have modest beginnings. The United Nations started with the appointment of an obscure committee in the State Department in 1943. The Marshall Plan started with a speech by Dean Acheson in Cleveland, Mississippi, and, in a few remarks at his press conference yesterday, President Kennedy gave the signal for what may prove to be the most significant event of his Administration.

ROME, Nov. 9 -- A flag-raising ceremony following balloting marked the admission today of sixteen nations and territories to the Food and Agriculture Organization, holding its biennial conference here.
ALBANY, Nov. 9 -- Governor Rockefeller won legislative approval today for a major fallout shelter program.
CHICAGO, Nov. 9 (UPI) -- The subject of Federal control generated debate today when officials of forty-five states, including eighteen Governors, held a conference on mental health.
QUITO, Ecuador, Nov. 9 -- Dr. Carlos Julio Arosemena Monroy became today President of Ecuador, as were his father and his grandfather before him.

IT IS somewhat difficult to recall what Bergdorf Goodhan has in its "Winter Wonderland" collection of fashions for boys and girls, because the setting and the cast at yesterday's preview completely stole the show.
NEWBURGH, N.Y., Nov. 9 (UPI) -- William S. Ryan, son of Newburgh's Mayor, will be dropped from the city payroll in the next two weeks, City Manager Joseph McD Mitchell said today.

As if to signal the upswing in business, corporate dividends for the first nine months of 1961 have showed a healthy increase. The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that its companies paid a record of $7,440,907,000 to stockholders, or 2.6 per cent more than the payments by the same companies in the 1960 nine months.

MOSCOW, Nov. 9 (UPI) -- The Supreme Soviet, the Soviet Unions Parliament, was summoned today to meet here Dec. 6. The Soviet Presidium, the chief legislative and executive organ between sessions, issued the call.
Details of the proposed bonus rule that Commissioner Ford Frick believes may help end six-figure pay-offs to promising young players were disclosed yesterday.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 9 -- The Government said tonight that Lazo Vracaric, a former Yugoslav partisan, would be compensated for his five-day arrest in West Germany.
Mayor Wagner called on Governor Rockefeller and the Republican-dominated Legislature yesterday to pass a proper new rent-control law without any "further study."
John F. Lee, president of the State University's Long Island Center at Oyster Bay, was removed from office yesterday.
What happens when an irresistible force meets an immovable object? The football answer to this scientific poser may be supplied tomorrow at Cambridge, Mass., and at Baker Field here.
Nassau County, N.Y., borrowed $13,797,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance sewerage and other public improvements.
ATLANTA, Nov. 9 -- President Kennedy's associates have sought quietly but without reported success to open the way for Negroes to attend a speech here by Secretary of Defense, Robert S. McNamara.

The loss of recording income was a prime factor in the recent dispute between the Metropolitan Opera Company and its orchestral musicians, according to Herman Krawitz, the company's business administrator.

Mayor Wagner urged Governor Rockefeller yesterday to block immediate action on reapportionment of the state's Congressional districts by recessing the current special session of the Legislature until Dec. 4.

Business plans to spend $35,840,000,000 for new plants and equipment in 1962, or 4 per cent more than the estimated total of $34,460,000,000 in such expenditures this year. That is the chief finding of a preliminary survey of business spending plans by the economics department of the McGraw-Hill Publishing Company.
Mrs. James Dorment of Montclair was re-elected president of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association yesterday at the group's annual meeting at the Savoy Hilton.

TORONTO, Nov. 9 (UPI) -- The world heavyweight champion, Floyd Patterson, arrived today glowing with confidence and in a hurry to continue preparations for his Dec. 4 title fight with young Tom McNeeley of Arlington, Mass.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The Government borrowed about $800,000,000 of very-short-term cash today at discounts averaging 2.277 per cent.
Members of Local 584 of the Teamsters Union, the key group in the recent milk strike, will vote today on the settlement terms that ended the thirteen-day walkout.
SWEET are the uses of diversity, according to Jane Jacobs. People enjoy cities, she thinks, because they enjoy the spectacle of other people going about diverse affairs.

Henry Street Settlement, the lower East Side neighborhood house, yesterday received a half-million-dollar gift from Mr. and Mrs. Charles Guttman of New York. The gift was accepted for the settlement by former Senator Herbert H. Lehman, at Pete's House, one of the center's buildings.
The Transit Authority yesterday called a union proposal that it seek funds from two autonomous agencies to provide raises for its own employes "crazy and ridiculous."

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 9 -- Spokesmen for the Kennedy Administration and the medical profession disputed the Administration's plan of care for the aged at a White House regional conference here today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- A national organization endorsed today a proposal for Federal aid to adult education.

Supporters of the Bagby Music Lovers Foundation filled the Metropolitan Opera House last evening to hear "La Boheme" presented as a tribute to Lucrezia Bori. The Spanish-born soprano had sung at the Met for many years.
TRENTON, Nov. 9 -- Webster B. Todd, the Republican State Chairman, called today for a change of party leadership in Essex, the state's most populous county.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The Army called attention today to a Defense Department policy of chartering commercial airlines to carry military personnel.
ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 9 -- A leading educator said tonight the United States must "liberate" the talents of all its children to meet the total Soviet threat.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported the following spot primary market prices for the dates shown:
PARIS, Nov. 9 -- Former Premier Paul Reynaud charged today that Western Europe was failing to make the military effort necessary to "defend its life, its riches and its honor."
The gold telephone probably rang in the White House yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (UPI) -- President Kennedy asked his Commission on Campaign Costs today to report to him as early next spring as possible, not later than April 30, on ways of financing Presidential campaigns.

FORT WORTH, Tex., Nov. 9 (UPI) -- United States District Judge Leo Brewster today ordered racial integration to start next fall in Fort Worth schools, the largest remaining segregated system in Texas.
QUITO, Ecuador, Nov. 9 -- The new President of Ecuador, Dr. Carlos Julio Arosemena Monroy, is an "aginer."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP) Senator Barry Goldwater denied today that he was "even thinking" about the Republican Presidential nomination in 1964.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 9 (UPI) -- Vice President Lyndon B. Johnson was among those evacuated tonight when a two-alarm fire broke out in the Muehlebach Hotel in downtown Kansas City.
RABAT, Morocco, Nov. 9 -- Prince Abdallah, the 26-year-old brother of King Hassan II, was married today to Lamia Solh, 26, daughter of the late Riad Solh, former Premier of Lebanon.

After pushing forward for seven successive days, the market on the New York Stock Exchange paused for a breather yesterday. More stocks rose than fell, but all the leading market averages declined slightly.

Events today: "La Fanciulla del West," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P.M.; "Madama Butterfly," presented by New York City Opera, City Center, 8:15; New York Philharmonic, Paul Paray, conductor, Carnegie Hall, 2:15; Artur Rubenstein, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 8:40.

DETROIT, Nov. 9 (UPI) -- Norm Ullman's goal with fifty-four seconds left in the game tonight enabled the Detroit Red Wings to score a 2-1 victory over the last-place Boston Bruins in a National Hockey League contest.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange dropped 35 cents to $1.45 a bale yesterday. It was the third day of decline.
SURVIVAL in the event of nuclear attack was the theme of a thought-compelling telecast over the Columbia Broadcasting System last night.

Michael J. Quill, who was among Mayor Wagner's most raucous campaign supporters, waited less than half a day to present the Mayor with his first post-election headache. The blustery president of the Transport Workers Union wants his members on the municipal subways and buses to get wage increases, shorter hours and other contract improvements that would force a doubling of the present 15-cent fare.

It is regrettable that the editorial writers of The New York Times did not pay more attention to the news columns of The New York Times before charging, in the editorial of Nov. 8, that the milk industry acted irresponsibly during the recent milk strike.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Nov. 9 (AP) -- The Illinois Senate refused today to confirm Gov. Otto Kerner's selection of Ralph L. Helstein of Chicago as a member of the newly created Fair Employment Practices Commission.
The American Electric Power Company yesterday cleared up speculation over who would succeed Philip Sporn as president and chief executive of the giant utility holding company.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 9 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Press, a Scripps-Howard newspaper, and The Post-Gazette, owned and published by William Block and Paul Block Jr. announced today that, beginning Monday, The Post-Gazette would be printed at the Press building.
The bright spot that moved across the southern sky between 2:30 and 5:30 o'clock this morning was not a rocket but a comet called Seki, the sixth one discovered this year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The criterion of whatever impression was made on Prime Minister Nehru by the resentment he found here against positions taken in the United Nations by V.K. Krishna Menon, his chief representative, will be Krishna Menon's behavior when he returns to his post.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 9 -- The United States announced today that it would vote against an African draft resolution under which the General Assembly would call upon members of the United Nations to refrain from any form of nuclear tests in Africa.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 9 -- Thirty-one nations proposed today that a committee be set up to gather information on Portuguese colonies.
ACCRA, Ghana, Nov. 9 -- Queen Elizabeth II received an enthusiastic welcome from many thousands of Ghanaians here today at the start of her eleven-day state visit.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (UPI) -- A former Navy Department employe and a manufacturer's procurement representative were indicted and arrested today on chages involving alleged misuse of classified information about Navy equipment purchases.
The election of Mrs. Richard Kaye Korn as president of the board of directors of the Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association was announced yesterday. She succeeds Harcourt Amory, president since 1958.

Unless the major United States-flag lines operating in the Puerto Rican service meet union demands there by next Wednesday, 6,000 longshoremen in San Juan and other island ports will strike, according to Capt. William V. Bradley, president of the International Longshoremen's Association.
MOSCOW, Nov. 9 -- The Soviet Union has proposed informally to the Western powers a new compromise solution of the Berlin dispute.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Senator Russell B. Long, Democrat of Louisiana, criticized today the Federal Communications Commission's handling of the space satellite communications project.
Saverio Saridis will be the only policeman who has moonlighted at the Persian Room of the Plaza Hotel. But he will not be violating any Police Department rule.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (UPI) -- The Navy reported tonight that a University of Minnesota Scientist and four Navy crewmen were killed in the crash of a twin-engined Neptune plane early today in the Antarctic.

Senator Kenneth B. Keating said last night that "in our deep and justified concern over what Khrushchev is doing to terrorize humanity, let us not forget to be concerned over what we are doing to preserve humanity, in the sense of preserving justice, equality and the rights of man."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- President Kennedy and Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru issued a joint communique today asserting the West's "legitimate and necessary right of access to Berlin."
The wholesale commodity price index moved upward to 82.9 on Wednesday from a revised figure of 82.7 on Monday. No data was collected Tuesday because of the Election Day holiday.
Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System increased by $17,000,000 to $91,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
About 1,400 students went on strike at Hunter College in the Bronx yesterday for the right to invite anyone, including known Communists, to speak to student groups at municipal colleges.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The United States Court of Appeals late today blocked the sale of WNTA-TV. Channel 13, in Newark to a New York educational group.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The Kennedy Administration plans to appoint a top-level tripartite committee to study possible revision of the Labor Department's monthly analyses of the nation's unemployed.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox erased any possible racial segregation problem in housing in spring training today by purchasing the 117-room Sarasota Terrace Hotel at their Florida training base.
Directors of the Valley National Bank of Long Island and the National Bank of Kings Park, L.I., approved yesterday a proposal to merge the two banks.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10 (UPI) -A special Governors' conference on mental health decided today to ask the Federal Government to consider including public assistance for the mentally ill and tubercular under the Social Security Act.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The Food and Drug Administration moved today to require that the bad as well as the good effects of prescription drugs be printed in readable form on labeling materials sent to druggists and physicians.
Mrs. Frank E. Karelsen has announced plans for two theatre parties through which the Child Study Association of America will receive funds.

Rutgers and Columbia, enjoying their most successful football seasons in years, probably will have some more bright days ahead in the next three years. A game between the universities' freshman teams at Baker Field yesterday indicated that the Scarlet and Lions would gain talented varsity material next season, particularly at quarterback.
Franco Zeffirelli, the Italian director, is planning a Broadway production next fall of "Camille," the Alexandre Dumas, fils, tragedy.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 10 (AP) -- After a seesaw first half, the Cincinnati Royals settled down and beat the new Chicago Packers, 122 -- 117, tonight in the first meeting of the National Basketball Association teams.
QUITO, Ecuador, Nov. 10 -Ecuador will trade with and would accept aid from anyone with money, President Carlos Julio Arosemena Monroy said today.
Charles Edison, former Governor of New Jersey, has resigned as a director of the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation in Pittsburgh.
Major custom smelters yesterday trimmed 1/4 cent a pound from the price they would pay for scrap copper.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The principal legal officers of about thirty-five states will meet here Monday and Tuesday to discuss problems concerning bid-rigging, food and drugs, securities trading and fraud.
A six-foot-three Jesuit missionary has built "an empire" where none existed before -- on Panope Island in the South Pacific.
VIENNA, Nov. 10 -- Vyacheslav M. Molotov and his wife departed from Vienna tonight, presumably for Moscow.
The United Church of Christ accepted yesterday an invitation to take part in discussions toward union with the United Presbyterian, Protestant Episcopal and Methodist denominations.

Whatever the record is for bouncing basketballs off the rim of the hoop, the New York Knickerbockers probably surpassed it last night at the Garden. They also approached new heights in the commission of personal fouls, and this, too, contributed to their 124-118 setback by the Detroit Pistons.

Bowl of Flowers, Mrs. Dodge Sloane's flop-eared filly, is rated the 3-1 third choice in her first stakes meeting with colts in today's $56,200 Roamer Handicap at Aqueduct. With nine 3-year-olds starting, the winner will earn $36,530.

Mme. Nonna Gaprindasvili of the Soviet Union beat Mme. Alexandra Nickolau of Rumania in thirty-one moves yesterday and strengthened her hold on first place in the women's challenge chess tournament at Vrnjacka Banju, according to a report from Yugoslavia.

TODAY, Monday and Tuesday will offer the last chances for New Yorkers to see in toto the famed Erickson collection of old masters at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue. The paintings will be sold there on Wednesday evening.
I.D. Robbins, president of the City Club, said here yesterday it was "improper and unfair" for the Legislature to reapportion Congressional districts without allowing for public discussion.
ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 10 -A renowned Talmudic scholar who is a world leader of Orthodox Judaism today called on American Orthodox rabbis to enroll in the Religious Zionists' movement.

A short-lived air travel ban that followed Wednesday night's plane crash near Richmond, Va., was ordered dropped last night by the Army. Seventy-four recruits and three crew members died in the accident.
DETROIT, Saturday, Nov. 11 (AP) -- The United Automobile Workers and the Bendix Corporation reached agreement on a new national contract early today, a half hour after a midnight strike deadline.

Prices in the market for United States Government securities sagged in an inactive trading session yesterday as the bond community pondered the consequences of the Treasury's $6,963,000,000 refunding in a tight money market.
United States ownership of the Manila Electric Company is ending after fifty-four years.

The special session of the New York Legislature has met, done the bidding of the Republican leadership, and closed up shop in time for the members to get home for the week-end. Some of them did not have time to read the bills, of course. Committee meetings were not allowed to stand in the way of swift completion of appointed rounds.

One of the most unusual successes in New York night life is a self-taught pianist named Harold Quinn, who plays with the fingers and thumbs of both hands encased in bandages. He is appearing with his trio at the Embers.

Events today: Metropolitan Opera, "Lohengrin" at 2 P.M. and "The Tales of Hoffmann" at 8; New York City Opera Company, City Center, "H.M. S. Pinafore" at 2:30 and "La Boheme" at 8:15; New York Philharmonic young people's concert, Leonard Bernstein, conductor, Carnegie Hall, 12 noon; New York Philharmonic, Paul Paray, conductor, Carnegie Hall, 8:30.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Nov. 10 (AP) -- An American missionary, his British colleague and an American woman mission worker were assaulted by Congolese soldiers in Kasai Province last week, the United States Embassy said today.
The last of the three Teamsters Union locals involved in the recent milk strike voted last night, by 983 to 147, to ratify the terms of agreement reached Monday for a two-year contract.
NEW FAIRFIELD, Conn., Nov. 10 -- Twenty fifth grade pupils at the New Fairfield Consolidated School have written to Premier Khrushchev urging him to end nuclear testing.
The congregational organizations of Reform and Conservative Judaism will hold national conventions this coming week.
Any business man who warmly remembers Alexander Botts, that imaginative (although fictional) tractor salesman, should be stimulated to large and expansive thinking at hearing the word "Africa."

Twenty-six boys in typical Western attire, with white cowboy hats, neckerchiefs and high, stitched boots, added a picturesque note to the New York scene yesterday. They are members of the Texas Boys Choir, here for a concert at Town Hall on Wednesday.

The Great Northern Railway cleared $2,524,276 last month, or slightly more than in October, 1960, when it had a net income of $2,387,889. A spokesman for the carrier termed the showing a "satisfactory month, which was about in line with the experience of a disappointing year."
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 10 -- The United States said today that the threat of aggression made it "suicidal" for nations to give a blanket pledge not to use nuclear weapons.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 10 -- It may not have been planned that way, but a drive by the Harry Bridges union to expand into industrial plants on the Los Angeles-Long Beach waterfronts is having secondary effects in area labor union circles.

RYE, N.Y., Nov. 10 -- Dr. and Mrs. Webster Stover will be back in City Court next Tuesday, accused of continuing to fly old rags from a clothesline in the front yard of their home at 365 Rye Beach Avenue.
Frank I. Bertsch, a court-appointed fiscal agent for Doeskin Products. Inc., yesterday urged Federal Judge Edmund L. Palmieri to reject competing offers to buy the company.
On Oct. 14, 1947, Maj. Charles E. Yeager of the Air Force broke the sound barrier. His experimental XS-1 jet exceeded 760 miles an hour and thus became the first vehicle to fly faster than sound.

With the freshly starched khakis, the close-cropped hair, and the impenetrable confidence of any 19-year-old, the soldier walks down the avenue. He will inevitably meet the smile of a passerby who, after noticing the colored patch on the youth's left shoulder, says, "That's the Seventh Division, isn't it? Say, I was with them back in '43 and '44."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -President Kennedy has chosen Cambridge, Mass., as the site of a library and museum to house his papers and other materials of his Administration.
The Board of Education announced yesterday that it would hold a hearing Nov. 21 on the recommendations of Theodore Kiendl, trial examiner for Joseph Weiss, suspended Deputy Superintendent of Schools.

Steve Machooka, a lean, long-striding Cornell exchange student from the British colony of Kenya in East Africa, swept to victory in the twenty-third annual Heptagonal Games Association cross-country championships yesterday.
HAMBURG, Germany, Nov. 10 -- The United States served a mixture of political oratory and tasty food today to demonstrate that it is determined to sell more agricultural products in West Germany.
DUBLIN, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The United States amateur boxing team scored a 6 -- 2 triumph over Ireland tonight for its first victory on its tour.

THE homemaker who wants to decorate the house for Christmas but feels that once-a-year ornaments are an extravagance might take a look at the festive, yet inexpensive decorations in the basement of F.W. Woolworth, Fifth Avenue at Thirty-ninth Street.

LISBON, Portugal, Nov. 10 -- Six political foes of the Portuguese Government seized a Portuguese airliner in the air today and forced its crew to circle over Lisbon while they dropped pamphlets urging the nation to revolt.
SAN FRANCISCO Nov. 10 (UPI) -- The State of California today formally urged the Interstate Commerce Commission to keep the Western Pacific Railroad independent.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- President Kennedy named a panel of six statistical experts today to see if the Government's employment figures could be made more useful and reliable in combating joblessness.
Mayor Wagner moved yesterday to prepare for a court challenge of the Congressional reapportionment voted by the Legislature.
Today is the day for traditional encounters in the prep school football circuit. Many more eyes, however, will be focused on a battle between undefeated elevens in Brooklyn.

HANOVER, N.H., Nov. 10 (UPI) -- The manager of the Dartmouth College Book Store said today that professors at the college and clergymen had given him their support in his refusal to ban sales of "Tropic of Cancer."

A 24-year-old divorcee who, with her parents, allegedly bilked department stores of $200,000 in merchandise in the last two years was held in $3,500 bail in Felony Court yesterday. She was charged with criminally receiving stolen goods.
PARIS, Nov. 10 -- The new French plan for a political union of European states ran into an impasse today over the issue of British participation in discussions of the proposal.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Dismissal of antitrust charges against some of the country's biggest drug companies was recommended today by a Federal Trade Commission examiner.
Diners' Club, Inc., is negotiating once again to acquire the credit card operations of the American Express Company, it was learned yesterday.
Tricks that time can play on physicians, negotiators at international meetings, airline pilots, globe-trotting tourists and astronauts were discussed at a scientific meeting here yesterday.
ALBANY, Nov. 10 -- Democratic pressure is building up a strong sentiment in the Legislature for transfer of rent control administration in New York City to Mayor Wagner.

GENEVA, Nov. 10 -- The International Control Commission policing the precarious ceasefire in Laos has warned that continued wrangling among the rival Laotian political factions could lead to open warfare in the "near future."

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Nov. 10 -- An Atlas rocket carrying a monkey was deliberately destroyed today, less than one minute after its launching on a planned flight of 5,000 miles. In the nose cone with the monkey were fruit flies, bread mold, insect eggs and viruses.

ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 10 -- President Cemal Gursel today appointed Gen. Ismet Inonu, veteran leader of the People's Republican party and a former President of Turkey, to form the new Turkish Government.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 10 -- Harvard and Princeton will renew their Big Three football rivalry at Soldiers Field tomorrow. A capacity crowd of 35,000 is expected to see the game.
Three undefeated performers will be seen in action at Madison Square Garden tonight in the first heavyweight tripleheader there in eighteen months.

LONDON, Nov. 10 -- During consultations over the question of Queen Elizabeth's visit to Ghana, the Queen let her ministers know that she felt strongly that it was her duty to go, that if she remained at home she would be failing in her responsibility as a symbol of unity for the Commonwealth.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 10 (UPI) -- Bobby Smith's 63-yard touchdown pass play tonight started the University of California at Los Angeles toward a 28-7 football victory over Texas Christian University.
LAUREL, Md., Nov. 10 -Kelso, this country's horse of the year, has an excellent chance of becoming the horse of the world tomorrow.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Nov. 10 -- The Atomic Energy Commissioner's director of weapons development said today that "significant advances" in the design of both strategic and tactical weapons could be achieved with further testing.

MARSEILLES, France, Nov. 10 -- President de Gaulle's voice was drowned out by shouts from Right-wing opponents of his Algerian policy for a few minutes here today. He was addressing an open-air meeting.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 10 -- U Thant, Acting Secretary General, asked for salary increases today for the professional and executive staffs of the United Nations and its affiliated agencies.

MOSCOW, Nov. 10 -- Ambassadors Llewellyn E. Thompson Jr. of the United States, Sir Frank Roberts of Britain and Maurice Dejean of France met today with Dr. Hans Kroll, the West German envoy, to hear details of his hour-and-forty-five-minute conversation yesterday with Premier Khrushchev.
Charles Rosen is the kind of pianist you either dig or you don't. But his recitals, such as the one he gave at Town Hall last night, are always stimulating, personal and brilliant.
On Thursday night Stefan Bauer-Mengelberg directed a succesful symphonic concert in St. Louis.
President Kennedy set up an emergency board yesterday, heading off a strike of Pan American World Airways pilots that had been scheduled to begin last night.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Nov. 10 -- John F. Lee said today he would document his charges of "incompetence, corruption and cynical politics" at the State University's Long Island Center at a press conference in New York tomorrow.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 10 -- The recent history of relations between the United States and Mexico may conveniently be divided into two eras, B.C. and A.D.B.C. refers to the period before Castro and A.D. signifies after the debacle, the debacle in the Bay of Pigs.
The American Jewish Congress voiced "deep regret and increasing apprehension" yesterday over a report that six Jews had been imprisoned in the Soviet Union on treason charges.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Nov. 10 (AP) -- The leader of a group dedicated to guerrilla warfare survival was jailed for questioning today.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 10 -- Navy took the lead in the Eastern Intercollegiate 150-pound Football League today by scoring two touchdowns in the last period for a 15-7 victory over Army.
BERLIN, Nov. 10 -- West Berlin policemen posted along the East Berlin border barriers have received instructions to "cultivate contacts" with the East German border guards.
NEW HAVEN, Nov. 10 -- The Planned Parenthood Center, opened here Nov. 1, was closed today after its two top officials were arrested in a test of Connecticut's birth-control laws.

MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 10 (UPI) -- The new Federal community facilities loan program is a shocking Government invasion of private business, Gordon L. Calvert of the Investment Bankers Association said today.

The pomp and pageantry usually reserved to incoming ship royalty was accorded the Liberte, the retiring queen of the French merchant marine, as the graceful old liner headed out of port for the last time yesterday afternoon.
The new capital market is headed for one of the most active weeks in years, with fixed-interest securities valued at more than $400,000,000 slated for marketing.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Nov. 10 -- Mayor Willy Brandt of West Berlin arrived in Brussels tonight to see Foreign Minister Paul-Henri Spaak. There were signs that Herr Brandt, a Socialist leader of West Germany, felt concerned about the intervention of M. Spaak, a Belgian Socialist leader, in East-West diplomacy.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The Ohio Chamber of Commerce announced today that it would conduct a clinic-forum Tuesday afternoon and evening in Cleveland to "counter-balance the White House regional conference."

BONN, Germany, Nov. 10 -- A young dentist with a crusader's zeal has Bonn's politicians in a dither. He has sued one of them for "breach of trust" for failure to keep an election campaign promise. Not only has this never been done before, which makes it bad enough in custom-conscious Germany, but the remote possibility that he might win in the Constitutional or Supreme Court gives the politicians nightmares.
The daring exploit of the Danish people who helped Denmark's 8,000 Jews escape the Nazis will be televised in a two-part documentary, "Act of Faith," on Columbia Broadcasting System TV.

THE thirty-eighth, Annual Women's International Exposition continues today and tomorrow at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Park Avenue at Thirty-fourth Street. The exposition includes a wide variety of imported home furnishings, art objects, handcrafts and Christmas gift suggestions.

Electric Bond and Share Company reported yesterday that net assets on Sept. 30 amounted to $182,664,982, equal to $34.79 a share. The net asset value ran 7 per cent higher than at the end of 1960 and 15 per cent higher than a year ago.
The charges and countercharges surrounding the dismissal of John F. Lee from the presidency of the State University's Long Island Center are vague and inconclusive.
PARIS, Nov. 10 (Reuters) -French press reports said today that the Government of Albania had proclaimed a state of emergency, apparently in anticipation of a Soviet-backed attempt to stage a coup.
Mayor Wagner will visit President Kennedy in Washington on Monday, and they are expected to talk about Federal appointments and reorganizing the Democratic party in New York State.

THE way Robert Cameron McEwen sees it, there must have been one main reason why he was named chairman of the joint legislative committee that produced the new plan for reapportioning New York State's Congressional districts.

Stocks pushed ahead yesterday in a relatively quiet market in which every major group except nonferrous metals, building supplies and business equipments joined with some enthusiasm. Steels, electronics, drugs and motion pictures were strongest.

Two five-story office buildings at 3 and 5 East Fortieth Street, adjoining the Lane Bryant store at the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Fortieth have been sold by Eugene Hegy Jr. The structures occupy a plot 52 by 94 feet. They were bought by an investing client of I.J. Ginsberg, lawyer.

THIS is the time of the emperor grape -- albeit a little late this season. The deep red grape is now finally coming to market, delayed by a late harvest that was 11 per cent below average. According to advance reports, however, the crop gained in flavor what it forfeited in quantity.
Nine American universities have joined forces, with United States Government aid to form a technological institute in India.
Cotton futures moved 5 cent a bale up on the near December contract to 45 cents to $1.7 off on the others yesterday of the New York Cotton Exchange.
A Supreme Court suit yesterday challenged Governor Rockefeller's recent order halting rent increases based on the equalization provision of the 1961 Rent Control Law.
SEOUL, Korea, Nov. 10 -The South Korean military Government pardoned former Premier John M. Chang and most of his Cabinet members tonight.
LONDON, Nov. 10 -- Jomo Kenyatta, leader of the Kenya African National Union, said today that he was satisfied with the results of his talks here with British colonial officials.
RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 10 (AP) -- The impact of Wednesday night's Constellation crash "didn't seem like hardly anything," the pilot said today.
New York City is planning the sale of bond issues totaling $53,100,000 or more. Bids will be opened by the office of Controller Lawrence Goresa on Dec. 12.
ATLANTA, Nov. 10 -- A biracial organization protested tonight to President Kennedy against plans for a speech here tomorrow by Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara before a segregated audience.

The Federal National Mortgage Association (Fanny May) reported yesterday that its purchases of mortgages during the third quarter more than doubled purchases in the preceding quarter. J. Stanley Baughman, president of the multibillion-dollar secondary distributor of Government-insured mortgages, said third-quarter purchases totaled 10,753, valued at $137,500,000 compared with 5,315, valued at $68,400,000, added to the agency's portfolio in the second quarter.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Violence flared again today on the picket line in front of the Yale Towne Manufacturing Company plant in northeast Philadelphia. Two men were arrested on disorderly conduct charges.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 10 -- The West German Government and political parties took a cautious stand today toward the suggestions made in Moscow for a settlement of the Berlin crisis.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- If the railroads want it, the Curtiss-Wright Corporation will be happy to supply a passenger train propelled by an aircraft engine at each end. A patent for this application of aerodynamics to rolling stock was granted this week.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (UPI) -- The lawyer for station WNTA-TV in Newark said today there was a "reasonable likelihood" that a court ruling yesterday killed present plans to sell the station to an educational group.
SCARSDALE, N.Y., Nov. 10 -- A suburban housewife has been chosen by the Navy to visit its bases around the world to portray in water-colors the activities of women in the Navy.
PHILADELPHIA, Pa., Nov. 10 -- Penn Charter School routed Germantown Academy, 32 -- 0, in the Interacademic League today in a diamond pubilee football game before 4,000 fans.
Three new store buildings have been completed as part of an expansion program at the Preakness Shopping Center on the Paterson-Hamburg Turnpike in Wayne, N.J.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (UPI) -- George Meany has ordered a hearing to determine whether William Finegan should be ousted now as executive secretary of Cleveland's merged labor body.
BERWICK, Pa., Nov. 10 (AP) -- An uneasy feeling hangs over this northeastern Pennsylvania community.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Reports from Moscow that the Soviet Government had put forward compromise suggestions for a Berlin settlement were received here today with considerable skepticism.
MOSCOW, Saturday, Nov. 11 (Reuters) -- The "Hero City" of Stalingrad has been renamed Volgograd, the Soviet Communist party newspaper Pravda reported today.

One young narcotics user shot another yesterday near Public School 44, at Columbus Avenue and Seventy-sixth Street, just as school was letting out, and a student was grazed by one of five bullets fired.

Armistice Day as it used to be, Veterans Day as it is now, is a time to remember the soldiers who died in all our wars. It is for them that the custom of observing two minutes of silence at 11 o'clock on November 11 was established. But while we remember those who fell in battle, we now have to remember those who were not soldiers but who, nevertheless, died in war.

BRUCE GELLER, and Jacques Urbont dug into a classic and have struck it rich. They have transformed Richard Brinsley Sheridan's "The Rivals" into "All in Love," a delightful musical comedy that arrived last night at the Martinique Theatre.
LONDON, Nov. 10 -- Britain's Foreign Secretary emphasized tonight the Government's reliance on negotiation as a means of settling disputes over Berlin and other questions with the Soviet Union.
ALL authorities on the prevailing point-count system of valuation, the 4-3-2-1 count, agree that twenty-six points should produce a game at no-trump.

Details of forthcoming films involving Director Vittorio De Sica and Sophia Loren, the actress, were disclosed yesterday at a press luncheon at the Hemisphere Club, Avenue of the Americas and Fiftieth Street. The third guest of honor was Carlo Ponti, the actress' husband, who is a producer.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- President Kennedy will take to the road in the 1962 Congressional campaign to the limit that international problems permit.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 10 (UPI) -- Three young gunmen, one disguised as a woman, took $62,693 from a San Francisco bank today after holding families of two bank officials captive all night in their suburban homes.

LONDON, Nov. 10 -- Industrial shares recorded more gains than falls in the stock market here today. The rises among the leaders were smaller than yesterday's, but the advance extended to the smaller companies.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- For the last two weeks the Strategic Air Command has quietly expanded its air alert tests into north polar regions and across the Atlantic.
BOSTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- A fire safety engineer, flown from Boston to the scene of major fires in the Los Angeles area, reported today that wood shingles had been a factor in the destruction.
A Brooklyn physician and a pharmacist were accused yesterday in the Brooklyn Felony Court of illegally writing and filling more than 1,500 prescriptions for narcotics in a nineteen-month period.

DETROIT, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Ward's Automotive Reports said today that twenty-two of the nation's forty-seven automobile assembly plants would work overtime tomorrow. The reports estimated the week's total production at 151,382 cars.

Eastern Air Lines, Inc., reported yesterday that it had a net loss from operations of $10,374,000 for the nine months ended on Sept. 30. In the 1960 period, it had a $4,679,000 net loss from operations.

TORONTO, Nov. 10 (Canadian Press) -- The Unit States took first place tonight in the international equestrian team competition at the opening of Canada's Royal Agricultural Winter Fair. Mexico was second and Canada third.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (UPI) -- The National Postal Union assailed today an experiment with closed-circuit television in the Detroit Post Office. It said the plan would lead to "constant and invisible surveillance."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -President Kennedy said today he expected to appoint John A Vaccaro of Yonkers surveyor of Customs Collection District 10, with headquarters in New York. Mr. Vaccaro will succeed Harry Edwards in the $13,700-a-year post.
WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 10 -Adios Butler goes to the post for the last time in his comparatively short but extremely distinguished career tomorrow light at Roosevelt Raceway.
ALBANY, Nov. 10 -- The Legislature approved today a Republican-drafted realignment of the state's Congressional districts.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 10 -- Policies of the Kennedy Administration came under sharp attack today at the White House regional conference held here.
Five newspaper women received awards last night at the annual Front Page Dinner dance of the New York Newspaper Women's Club in the Astor Hotel.

PARIS, Nov. 10 -- Secret contacts between the French Government and the Algerian nationalist Provisional Government were authoritatively reported today to have been make and "preliminary" peace talks are in progress.

The humor, malice, horse sense and purple oratory delivered by Congress members from 1789 to the present has been culled from legislative records by Edward Boykin to form "The Wit and Wisdom of Congress." The book, which Funk Wagnalls will publish Monday, is Mr. Boykin's seventh, including three on the Civil War.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 10 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru made an impassioned plea to the United Nations General Assembly today to take quick action for a nuclear test ban and general disarmament as the only alternative to world destruction.
The note in your issue of Oct. 17 dealing with Dr. Hans Hirschfeld's role in the Soblen case was headlined: "Hirschfeld Spurns Soblen Case Role."

McMURDO SOUND, Antarctica, Nov. 10 -- Rear Admiral David M. Tyree, commander of the naval support force in Antarctica, said today that four Navy men injured in a plane crash yesterday would be returned here.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The Council of Chief State School Officers today called for a "substantial infusion" of Federal funds at all levels of education, but declined to approve any particular approach or legislation.

WHEN a pink uniformed woman pushes a pink cart topped by spaceman-like headgear through hospital halls it does not mean that a patient is about to be shot to the moon. It is simply the Hospital Beauty Service Systems, Inc., bringing its portable beauty salon to women who like to look well even though they do not feel it.
WARSAW, Nov. 10 -- Premier Khrushchev is likely to attend a meeting of the Warsaw Pact powers here this month, diplomatic sources said today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Representatives of 43,000 United States and Canadian airline mechanics called today for radioactivity checks on all high-flying jet planes after all flights.
An automated tobacco-leaf processing and storage plant was dedicated by P. Lorillard Company on Thursday at Danville, Va. It was described as the most modern in the industry.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 10 (UPI) -- Edward V. Rickenbacker, World War I flier, said today the United States should quit the United Nations and sever relations with the Soviet Union and "so-called neutrals."
BELLEVILLE, Ill., Nov. 10 (AP) -- A magistrate dismissed charges of illegal possession of weapons today against Richard Lauchli, regional director of the Minutemen.

The Capitol Building, a twostory office, theatre and store building at Bergenline Avenue and Forty-seventh Street in Union City, N.J., has been purchased by Abraham Slifka, a New York realty investor. The Capitol Holding Corporation of New York was the seller of the property.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission has signed a contract with Homestake-Sapin Partners of Grants, N.M., for the purchase of uranium concentrates valued at $135,000,000. The contract will run through 1966.

Kouni Zilliacus is a cantankerous Left-Wing Labor Member of the British Parliament. A month ago he applied at the American Embassy in London for a visa so that he could attend a dinner in New York Nov. 10. State Department officials in London and Washington "studied" the application until the day of the dinner approached, when they cabled Mr. Zilliacus that despite "urgent" efforts they could not complete their study on time.

In a letter printed in The Times on Oct. 23, 1960, Prof. George H.T. Kimble urged that Belgium be given a temporary trusteeship over the Congo by the United Nations. In weighing alternative solutions to the Congo's problems, he asked:

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 10 -- Former Presidents Harry S. Truman and Dwight D. Eisenhower broke a long period of coolness today when they chatted amiably for half an hour at the Truman Library in near-by Independence.

Maine potato futures prices dropped to new lows for the life of the contract yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Closing prices were down 5 to 7 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on the sale of 1,519 cars of 50,000 pounds each.
ACCRA, Ghana, Nov. 10 -- Ghana staged two brilliant parades today for Queen Elizabeth II.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Educators of adults were challenged today to mobilize national support for their program of teaching America's undereducated adults.
It is D-day for Columbia.
COLUMBIA, S.C., Nov. 10 (AP) -- The use of trespass ordinances against lunch counter sit-in demonstrators was upheld unanimously today by the South Carolina Supreme Court.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 10 -- A musical argument that ranged from confusion to bitterness has ended with the selection of Zubin Mehta as permanent conductor of the Los Angeles Philharmonic Orchestra.
" Well, we put it to bed today and now we'll see what happens."

Although sales of the General Dynamics Corporation rose in the first nine months of this year, the company reported yesterday that it operated at a greater loss in the period than in the initial three quarters of 1960.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and subsidiaries has reported gains in total sales and revenues and net income for the September quarter and for the first nine months of 1961. Orders on hand were $715,000,000 on Sept. 30.
CHICAGO, Nov. 10 (AP) -The grain futures market showed a rallying tendency in late dealings today and finished with some small to moderate gains on the Board of Trade.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10 -- A. Philip Randolph, the nation's leading Negro labor official, has decided that only the Federal Government, and not the labor federation, can effectively fight racism in trade unions.
Dorothy Kirsten sang all of the role of Minnie in "LA Fanciulla del West" at the Metropolitan Opera last night.

The directors of Walt Disney Productions voted yesterday the regular quarterly dividend of 10 cents a share plus a 3 per cent stock dividend. Both are payable on Jan. 20 to holders of record of Dec. 22.
DETROIT, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Detroit, with Ron Bishop, a substitute, throwing two second-half touchdown passes, put a crimp in Villanova's football bowl hopes tonight with a 20-6 victory.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 10 -- The Gabon Republic, a West African country hitherto associated primarily with the hospital founded by Dr. Albert Schweitzer, or with the Babingas, a tribe or pygmies, is facing rapid transition.
" BREAK OF DAY,"* by Colette, is the portrait of a lady who considers herself past her prime and is parting from a younger man who has no particular distinction outside her ruthless radiance.
Negotiations for merger of the New York Central and the Pennsylvania Railroads have been resumed upon the motion of Alfred E. Perlman, the Central's president.
BUFFALO, Nov. 10 (UPI) --- Gov. John A. Volpe of Massachusetts has encouraged Roman Catholic youth to enrich public life by entering politics and insuring good government.
Columbia and Dartmouth will meet today at Baker Field in one of the most important Ivy League football games of the season. The kick-off is scheduled for 1:30 P.M.
ALBANY, Nov. 10 -- The State Senate has started making a film designed to improve its public image.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 10 -- A mother and her 10-year-old son died early today in a fire that swept their new split-level home at 256 Breadfield Road.

At 9:20 A.M. at the Polo Grounds yesterday, Samuel Adrian Baugh, a cattle rancher from Rotan, Tex., gave two blasts on a little silver whistle. Thirty head of padded prime beef, otherwise known as the New York Titans, thundered toward him.

MIAMI, Nov. 10 (UPI) -- The Federal Government dismissed yesterday its indictment against a former Cuban Senator, Rolando Masferrer, who had been accused of violating United States neutrality laws by financing a twenty-seven-man invasion of Cuba Oct. 4, 1960.

NOW that Leonard Bernstein has concluded the first semester of his Seminar in Approaches, the pattern for the Philharmonic seems to be to settle down somewhat and concentrate on a "meat and potatoes" approach with its series of guest conductors.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- A thorough investigation of the Government's program for mandatory control of oil imports is about to get under way.

The Boeing Company has been awarded a $50,000,000 contract for production of KC135 jettankers and transports the Air Force announced yesterday. Another contract $35,751,240 was given to company for the production missiles operational and training equipment for the Minute-man intercontinental ballistic missile weapons system.

A group of 154 students from New York City public high schools attended a concert by the Juilliard Orchestra at the Juilliard School of Music last night to open a special program sponsored by the school and the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts.

Reiterating his stand in favor of the return of the spitball, ruled out of baseball by the major leagues forty-one years ago, Joe Cronin, president of the American League, made some pertinent observations yesterday.
A shakeup in top management is under way at the Security National Bank of Long Island, Huntington, third largest institution on the island.

ARLINGTON, Va., Nov. 11 -- President Kennedy made a Veterans Day plea today for patience in the search for peace. But he assured the world that this country was prepared "in the final extreme" to fight again for freedom.
CEDAR GROVE, N.J., Nov. 11 -- Essex County's Overbrook Hospital has won national support for its application of the remotivation technique in the treatment of mental patients.
The titanium industry is being tempted by a tantalizing goal: 1961 shipments exceeding the record 11,315,820 pounds shipped in 1957.

The nation's railroads had a net income of $41,000,000 in September, the Association of American Railroads has announced.

OLIVIA COOLIDGE, the author of such books as "Greek Myths" and "Roman People," knows how to write a first-rate story. She is also well-grounded in history and archaeology, and has the great good sense to realize that antiquity does not have to be tortured out of all recognition to be "interesting.'' She calls her new book, "Caesar's Gallic War," a companion to Julius Caesar's famous "Commentaries."

Nathan Goldstein, a young American violinist who has been a valued participant in chamber concerts and recitals for more than a decade, gave a commendable concert in Town Hall late yesterday afternoon.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 11 -- A new ordinance requires that when public or private schools are established they must have an automobile parking plan that is approved by the City Council.

IN this remarkable book Paul Oliver deals with the content and poetry of the blues, illustrating his comments with 350 excerpts drawn chiefly from country and city folk blues. In a later volume he promises to deal with the "form and history" of the blues.

EASTON, Pa., Nov. 1I -- Lafayette scored its first home football victory of the season today at Fisher Field, beating Tufts, 27 -- 17. The triumph was the Leopards' second as against five losses and a tie.

THE long and eventful life of the greatest artist of the Renaissance, Michelangelo, has been a subject for study, commentary and interpretation for more than four hundred years. Most of the important dates and events are known, and the surviving works have been analyzed exhaustively by critics, artists and psychiatrists.
The Pierre will be the setting on Feb. 1 for the twenty-third annual White Elephant party in behalf of the Child Adoption Service of the State Charities Aid Association.
BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Nov. 11 -- The annual Christmas Bazaar and tea of the Bronxville Woman's Exchange will be held at the Reformed Church here on Tuesday.

If there was any doubt about the basic trend of the stock market early last week, it was dispelled quickly on Wednesday morning at the opening. Traders gave forth with a resounding "hurrah" as both prices and volume soared. In all, 6,090,000 shares changed hands, the heaviest turnover since April 3. A record number of issues was traded.

DANIEL BAR JAMIN at 18 is an orphan and a bitter rebel against the Roman conquerors of his native Israel, who are responsible for his parents' deaths. Daniel has joined a band of outlaws whose rough leader, Rosh, boasts that he will someday drive the Romans into the sea.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 11 (AP) -- The St. Louis Hawks made 58 per cent of their shots from the field in the first half and went on to defeat the Detroit Pistons, 132 -- 119, tonight in a National Basketball Association game.

This week the Security Council will reluctantly take up the Congo question, surely one of the most frustrating problems that has ever confronted the United Nations. The prevailing pessimism results from the fact that while the military force at the United Nations' disposal is too weak to impose the political settlement envisaged by the Security Council, it is impossible to get a majority for more attainable goals.

A GROUP of 410 Swiss tourists, the first major complement of foreigners to visit this country under the wing of the recently created United States Travel Service, has come and gone, and the consensus is that their trip was a resounding success.

ONE impression the American ear gets from current English verse is of an articulateness so fluid it seems glib. English poetry blends into English literary-political journalism with its terribly knowledgeable chatter.

Additional committee members for the seventh annual Imperial Ball have been announced by Mrs. Walter S. Gubelmann and Mrs. Stanley C. Hope. The dinner dance will be held Dec. 7 in the Plaza. It will aid the Hospitalized Veterans Service of the Musicians Emergency Fund, whose president, Mrs. Lytle Hull, is honorary ball chairman.
CLINTON, N.Y., Nov. 11 -- Frank Melos, a halfback, scored four touchdowns and ran for 2 extra points as Wagner defeated Hamilton, 48 -- 20, today.
The Family Service Association of America, which will begin the observance of its fiftieth year this week, said yesterday that family breakdown was now "America's No. 1 social problem."

Monetary policy, once looked on hopefully as medicine to be taken internally to reverse economic depression and hold undue business booms in check, is being used increasingly these days for a different purpose -- to minimize the imbalance in a nation's international payments.
ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 11 (AP) -- Cornell gained its first Ivy League victory of the season today, defeating Brown, 25 -- 0, before a crowd of 8,000. Brown suffered its sixth straight league loss.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Nov. 8 -- The Ceylohese Government has decided to discourage the planting of new rubber land because it thinks the future for rubber is "not encouraging."

Polish dances such as the polonaise, the polka and the kujawiak will be performed by committee members in a setting of Poland's colors, red and while, at the Polonaise Ball in the Ballroom of the Sheraton-East next Saturday.

Hopeful listeners began lining up an hour ahead of time, and after the doors had been closed on a capacity house, better than a thousand poetry lovers -- or maybe lovers of true character -- were turned away.

ABOUT the time that Glenway Wescott was writing "Good-bye Wisconsin," August Derleth decided to return to his native Wisconsin town of Sac Prairie. That place, he hoped, would serve as his Walden, a microcosm in which he could observe "what went on in the woods as well as in the houses along the streets of Sac Prairie in the human heart" Since then he has written twenty-five books about his village.

IT is now five years since the world, both East and West, was shaken by the simultaneous eruption of the Polish "October," the revolt in Hungary and the Suez conflict. Distinct and yet interrelated, these events marked a major turning point in the recent course of international affairs.

WARSAW, Nov. 9 -- Wladyslaw Gomulka, chief of the Polish Communist party, was reported today to have advised his Central Committee that no purge or expose of Stalinists would take place in this country.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- The partial lifting of economic sanctions against the Dominican Republic is likely to be recommended Tuesday by a special committee of the Organization of American States.

During the past season, there was a serious bottleneck in pleasure boating. More than one and a quarter million boats lacked marina space. Mercury outboard people in some postseason researching have found that owners of a half million boats are still on waiting lists for berthing space next year.

IN dim, small stalls, South Korean craftsmen hammer out little copper disks for sale to foreign tourists. The designs on the disks are the symbols for "good fortune" or "happy life." Somehow, for Korea, they are souvenirs of a wrenching poignancy.

Margaret Hyde approaches the problem obliquely, but effectively, by surveying a vast range of scientific research aimed at providing more food and energy for the world.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 11 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru's talks with President Kennedy have been widely lauded here as a victory for the quiet diplomacy of the Indian leader and his policy of nonalignment.

THE award of the 1961 Nobel Prize for Literature to Ivo Andric (pronounced Andrich), the Yugoslav poet, novelist and ex-diplomat, was not entirely unexpected to those familiar with recent candidacies. Two of his books -- pivotal novels in an output that runs to nine volumes in all -- have been available here for some time.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Sponsors of the twelfth annual Debutante Cotillion and Thanksgiving Ball have been announced by Mrs. Robert Charles Diefenbach, general chairman and founder of the event, to be held here Nov. 23 at the Sheraton-Park Hotel.

IN the days of Queen Elizabeth I there lived in western Ireland another queen, the exact opposite of Elizabeth in background and way of life, but much like her in character and ability. When Gronia O'Malley's father died, she succeeded him to the chieftainship, and through boldness and courage led her clan to greater strength and prosperity.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla. -- Despite repeated assertions by members of the Florida tourist industry that facilities are being overbuilt for the volume of business, the construction boom continues. Recent statistical reports show that, in the first half of this year, building permits were issued by the Florida Hotel and Restaurant Commission for $72,622,922 in contracts, compared with the $94,331,966 in permits issued for all of last year.

With charts, timetables, suggestions for making food preparation quicker and easier, with glossaries of culinary terms and lists of herbs and spices and with hundreds of recipes, they accomplish their purpose in a very happy fashion.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board disclosed today that it had started an investigation of Imperial Airlines a few hours before one of the concern's planes crashed near Richmond, Va., killing seventy-seven persons.

STUART, Fla. -- The Elliott Museum, a $500,000 gift to the Martin County Historical Society, will be formally dedicated next Friday and Saturday. The museum, devoted to the evolution of the wheel, is being donated by Harmon P. Elliott, office equipment manufacturer, in honor of his father, Sterling Elliott.
SAN SALVADOR, Nov. 6 -- The Organization of Central American States may be locked in an impasse between Guatemala and El Salvador over plans for forming a federation of the five members.

Joseph Wechsberg's article "Grand Price of Grand Opera" (Oct. 22) is typical of the twisted reasoning of today's "culture-chasing cult." The small percentage of people who enjoy opera does not qualify it for public financial support.

TORONTO, Nov. 11 (UPI) -- The Maple Leafs spotted the Detroit Red Wings a goal and then stormed back for a 5-1 victory in a National Hockey League game before 14,011 tonight. The triumph moved Toronto past the idle New York Rangers into second place.
The catastrophic decline in the caribou of the Arctic barrens appears to have halted, at least temporarily.

LAFAYETTE, Ind. -- The past week has seen the 150th anniversary of the Battle of Tippecanoe, a bloody encounter in American frontier warfare, which took place at a spot only a short distance north of here.

THE old men sat in their boats in the slowly graying darkness of early morning, waiting to ferry the first group of fully-bearded, still sleepy-eyed Argonauts from a pebbled beach of this tiny fishing village to the strange vessel anchored in a quiet cove.

THE public image of Herbert von Karajan is that of a glamorous continental type who races from opera house to sports car to symphony orchestra to ski slope to music festival, from Salzburg to Milan to Vienna to Berlin with perhaps a pause to climb a mountain in between.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- The idol of the people crashed down from his Presidential pedestal in the small Republic of Ecuador this week, snapping abruptly into focus the unleashed anger and impatience of Latin America's restless students and destitute peasants and slurs dwellers.

A former amphibious naval ship has been converted to a cargo vessel for use in South American waters. The 203-footlong ship was purchased for $175,000 from the Navy by J. Manuel Cordova of Santiago, Chile, and converted at the Dade Drydock Corporation's yards in Miami.
ISFAHAN, Iran, Nov. 2 -- Within the walled orchard the scent of ripening quinces -- big and yellow as grapefruit -- sweetens the air.

In the article, "Today It's Saint-Tropez -- Tomorrow? " (Aug. 20), by P.E. Schneider, it was reported that "the oldest practicing abstract painter in town is the brother of the late Colonel McCormick of Chicago."

Mrs. Charles W. Engelhard and Mrs. Edward M.M. Warburg, co-chairmen, have announced that the Diamond Ball, third Global Gala for the benefit of the Institute of International Education, will he held at the Plaza Jan. 31.

ONE of my earliest memories is that of a small boy sitting in our village street surrounded by a group of grey-whiskered old men. Bored and fidgety, his mind clearly elsewhere, he is reading aloud in fluent sing-song the war news from a tattered newspaper.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- The twenty nations of the Atlantic community plan to announce next week their resolve to achieve by 1970 a 50 per cent increase in their combined economic output.

TO avoid -- permanently -- the need to shovel snow or chop ice on driveways and sidewalks, homeowners can now install an electric snow-melting system. Consisting of a series of heating cables or heating mats below the paying material, these systems are usually designed to melt the snow automatically before it can accumulate.

WHO were the two men looking around Winnesquam? And why? What did they mean when they said that Clam Cove was "a perfect place?" Teddy Tibbetts and his Saturday Gang don't much care as long as it is exciting.

EDWARD R. Murrow came to Hollywood last week preceded by an aura of suspicion and left a cloud of bewilderment. He produced this effect with one speech arranged through the Motion Picture Academy of Arts and Sciences.

AS the two K's of this season's musicals, "Kwamina" and "Kean" live up to the implications of their initials: they aim for size. "Kwamina" has the temerity to tackle no less a subject than the flaming tensions of Africa in transition.
BRASILIA, Nov. 4 -- Brasilia is a capital of the latest modern design but it is still looking for a Government that will stay put.
HACKENSACK, N.J., Nov. 11 -- Better understanding and greater cooperation between the medical and legal professions will be sought at a dinner here Tuesday.
FREDERICK BRISSON is ahead of a lot of us. He not only knows what he will be doing next year, he also knows what he's getting for Christmas.

WHENEVER Kyle Rote offers a suggestion in a Giant huddle, the quarterback pays respectful attention. Kyle offers few suggestions and what few he makes are solidly grounded on the evidence his own measured judgment and probing tactics have produced for him.

There probably was a ting-a-ling on a "gold" telephone last week in the White House. The telephone -- not gold at all -- was one the President had installed early this year during the worrisome days when the nation's monetary gold supply was shrinking too fast for comfort.

IN these days of nuclear tests and rocket-rattling, the horror that was Hiroshima bears another retelling. Robert Jungk's "Children of the Ashes: The Story of a Rebirth" describes the aftereffects on the victims of the first atomic bomb dropped on mankind, and tells the story of the resurrection of the stricken city.
HARTFORD, Nov, 11 -- Edwin H. May Jr., Republican State Chairman since December, 1958, resigned today to seek his party's nomination for Governor in 1962.
The depressed steamship industry was given a challenge and a ray of statistical hope last night by Thomas E. Stakem, chairman of the Federal Maritime Commission.
A $10,000,000 program to expand San Juan International Airport has been announced by the Puerto Rico Ports Authority.
The committee for the Dec. 5 performance of "The Complaisant Lover" at the Barrymore Theatre that will aid the Menninger Foundation has released a list of patrons of the event.

Next year will be a big political year in the U.S., with elections of thirty-six Senators, the entire House and thirty-six Governors. The votes will be in effect a midterm referendum on the Kennedy Administration.

BRIGHTON, Utah -- The ski season in the Wasatch Mountains got off to one of the earliest, most unusual starts in Utah history this year when a three-foot snowfall blanketed the 11,000-foot-high peaks hereabouts in late October.
KANSAS CITY, Nov. 11 (AP) -- Universal understanding will bring greater freedom throughout the world, Gen-Dwight D. Eisenhower said today.
TWO men were shot dead and a third was wounded in a crowded Brooklyn nightclub early yesterday.

SLIDES are "floated" magnetically into viewing position in a new projector announced last week. They are returned to the original slide tray location in the same way. The principle is the main feature of the Honeywell Model 650 slide projector announced last week by Minneapolis-Honeywell's Heiland division, 5200 East Evans Avenue, Denver 22, Colo.

THE third of a Hy Ruchlis series on physics for young people, "The Wonder of Heat Energy" is characterized by clear, simple exposition, effectively tied to fine photographs and diagrams. The author is very adept at clarifying ideas and stimulating the imagination.

EVEN as representatives of the airline industry met in Hartford, Conn., recently for a two-day symposium devoted to ways and means of promoting air transportation, the major domestic trunk lines were queued up before the Civil Aeronautics Board to beg out of a scheme revised to promote air transportation.

A meeting between the Philadelphia Eagles and the New York Giants heads today's National Football League slate of seven games. A capacity crowd of more 60,000 is expected at this contest in Yankee Stadium. The kick-off time is 2:05 P.M.

The children's zoo in Central Park, donated by Senator Lehman, is a charming idea, sad though it is that there should be so many children who have never seen a duck, a rabbit or other barnyard animals ("Noah's Ark for City Kids," Oct. 8).
