The business community is more hopeful than in years that the Government will move decisively to facilitate the renewal of the country's aging industrial plant through tax concessions.

SYRACUSE, Nov. 11 -- There were some regrets here today as Syracuse beat Colgate, 51 to 8, and an old football rivalry ended. Following the sixty-second contest between the colleges, many Orange alumni expressed the hope that gridiron relations would soon be resumed.

BECKY'S ISLAND was an ugly blot on an otherwise serene Maine landscape. Barren of trees, its land eroded and waterless, it gave little to its poverty stricken few inhabitants, who had a very unsavory reputation among the villagers on the mainland.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -The Cooperative League asked President Kennedy today to reconsider recent cuts in the Food and Drug Administration funds.

SOMETIMES people forget why we have stamps -- most particularly why we issue commemorative stamps. In a commendable enthusiasm for stamps as collectors' items, philatelists occasionally think of them as an end in themselves.

TO get into the heart of things as quickly as possible, this is a superb adventure story -- interestingly written, excellently plotted, and perceptively cast with well-defined characters. The core of the book is, of course, its tale of a 14-year-old American boy and the adventures he encounters as an inadvertent stowaway on an early nineteenth-century ship.
IT all started when we were in Holland on a "limited budget" vacation and a newfound Dutch friend made the point that his countrymen were among the greatest bargain hunters in the world.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Nov. 11 -- Hofstra College's football team posted its fifth victory in seven games by halting Rhode Island today, 12 -- 0. The victory assured Hofstra of a winning season for the sixth straight year.

CAMDEN, N.J., Nov. 11 -- The Meadowbrook Stables' Frimanaha scored a stunning upset in today's nineteenth running of the Vineland Handicap with a nose decision over the 4-5 favorite, the Brae Burn Farm's Shirley Jones.
WE have now a great opportunity to give form and substance to Western unity -- to provide for our children an invaluable heritage. The opportunity must be now; the world will not wait for us.

ST. MAWES, Cornwall, England -- Flowers bloom all the year here in Cornwall, at the southwest tip of England, which is reached in only six and one-half hours from London by the "Cornish Riviera Express." The climate is incomparable in this kingdom.

THE twenty-second Soviet Communist party congress in Moscow marked the end of a major chapter in the history both of the Soviet state and of the world Communist movement and the beginning of a new chapter whose outcome is unpredictable.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., Nov. 11 -- Thirty years ago, during the depression, a number of women formed the New Canaan Sewing Group to help, through the sale of their handicraft, an overburdened welfare agency cope with emergency problems.

THE new miniature orchids, in an exciting array of colors and flower forms, are becoming more and more popular as house plants. Dozens of these tiny plants can be accommodated in a small space -- on a window sill, in a Wardian case or under lights -- and most are easy to grow.

OGDENSBURG, N.Y., Nov. 11. -- Edward J. Keenan, independent, was elected Mayor by a write-in vote Tuesday, according to the unofficial returns, but John M. Langford, the Republican candidate, may ask for a recount.

OXFORD, Miss., Nov. 11 (UPI) -- Mississippi, one of the nation's best passing teams, was forced to stay on the ground because of rain today, but the nationally-ranked Rebels still racked up a 54 -- 0 rout of Chattanooga.

THERE was a time when man's only source of power was his own strong back. Being, however, a resourceful and somewhat lazy animal, he quickly remedied this uncomfortable situation by capitalizing on the potential workhorses around him -- wind and water, heat and electricity and, finally, the atom.

WASHINGTON, Nov 11 (AP) -- The general assembly of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations was told tonight that the Reform branch of Judaism grew faster in the last two years than at any time in its eighty-eight-year history.

J.G. CROWTHER brings considerable experience, as one of Britain's pioneering science writers, to the task of making highly technical subjects clear, understandable and exciting to young readers. His subject is new -- radioastronomy was founded less than thirty years ago, by a 26-year-old American, Karl Jansky -- and as always, his tale is fascinating.

BEAUMONT, Tex., Nov. 11 (AP) -- Jay Hebert shot a three-under-par 68 today for a 54-hole total of 206 and a two-stroke lead in the $20,000 Beaumont open golf tournament. Hebert, a pro who comes from Lafayette, La., posted a 32 on the incoming nine to pass Don Fairfield of Casey, Ill., who had led for two days.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 11 -- Southern California's most disastrous fire left 460 charred homes, $25,000,000 damage, sad afterthoughts and hot recriminations this week.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) -- An assertion by Senator Clinton P. Anderson, Democrat of New Mexico, that Russian agents had stolen atomic secrets supplied to the British appeared today in testimony released by a Senate sub-committee.

MOSCOW, Nov. 11 (Reuters) -- An American tourist has given Soviet officials two United States documents telling tourists to the Soviet Union how to recruit agents. The Government newspaper Izvestia said tonight.

WITH something of Mika Waltari's ability to reconstruct a long-vanished world -- but not the Finnish author's controlled, if usually cynical, worldliness -- and with an elan and eloquence all his own, Dan Levin has written a book which should soon have a large audience.

MADRID -- This romantic and ancient city, this year celebrating its 400th anniversary as the capital of Spain, is made for the foot-wanderer. Motor transport is, of course, available, but the local taxis, while plentiful and cheap, seem possessed by demons as they hurtle, swerve, dodge, shuttle and career though traffic.

LISBON, Portugal, Nov. 11 -- Portugal's parliamentary elections tomorrow will test the nation's mood against a background of rising costs and belt-tightening at home and improving conditions in the rebellion-torn province of Angola.

MANHATTAN, Kan. -- So swiftly does Progress, with a capital P and no sentimental nonsense about it, spread its superhighways, powerlines and urban development across land that almost no trace remains of what used to be a highly dramatic national region, the midwestern prairies, as they were when the pioneers crossed them.

Coining an aphorism -- "A Woman's Best Accessory is a Well-Dressed Man" -- the New York Committee for Boys and Girls Towns of Italy is planning a luncheon and a fashion show to prove its point. The benefit will be given in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza on Nov. 30
CARMEL, N.Y., Nov. 11 -- Political honors were divided between the two major parties in the elections held Tuesday in Putnam County.
A party will be given this month for two Brooklyn "residents" who are about to check in with their parole officers.

ONE of the few old-fashioned hobbies surviving from grandmother's day is that of collecting house plants. A lush display of foliage or flowering kinds adds a decorative touch in even the most modem homes.

AT one point in its furious course, the Tsangbo River in eastern Tibet plummets 7,000 feet down the side of Namche Barwa peak in the Himalayas. If dams, tunnels and turbines were built there, forty million horsepower could be produced -- almost matching today's entire world output of hydroelectric power.
Carlos E. Guimard of Argentina and Paul Keller of Switzerland tied for first place with scores of 5 -- 2 in a recent chess tournament at Enschede, the Netherlands. Each won three games and drew four.

The scholarship fund of the Vassar Club of New York will be aided by the club's thirty-ninth annual opera benefit. It will be at the Jan. 6 evening performance of Verdi's "La Traviata" at the Metropolitan Opera House.

A GROUP of small rooms in the basement of the Library of Congress here bears little resemblance to a bank vault. But to an increasing number of persons, the Archive of Folk Song is a Fort Knox of melody.

THE City Center is going to be devoted exclusively to dancing from Wednesday evening, when the Polish company called Mazowsze opens there, until Feb. 4 when the New York City Ballet gives the final performance of its coming nine-week season.

MOST people in these days of unwonted stress know something, or at least feel they do, about psychosomatic medicine, that branch of the physician's art which concerns itself in part with the effect of emotion on the body. It is, however, a new specialty, barely fifty years old, and some of its contributions have been widely misunderstood, others only partially grasped by the public at large.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Government surplus food stocks will be used instead of foreign aid dollars as far as possible in the Administration's program of helping under-developed areas of the world toward economic self-reliance.

The National Council of Jewish Women will hold a two-day program on the United Nations starting tomorrow. More than 200 leaders of the educational and service organization will at-I tend the sessions at the Carnegie Endowment Center, 345 East Forty-sixth Street.

THANKSGIVING, in the era documented in the prints of Currier Ives, was symbolized by the arrival of the family sleigh at grandmother's house -- somewhere over the river and through the woods -- where a festive meal awaited.

MOST books advertised for "readers of all ages" fail to keep their promise. But Norton Juster's amazing fantasy has something wonderful for anybody old enough to relish the allegorical wisdom of "Alice in Wonderland" and the pointed whimsy of "The Wizard of Oz."

The Infants Home of Brooklyn, a child-care agency at 1358 Fifty-sixth Street, will be the beneficiary of its forty-second anniversary dinner dance to be held at the Waldorf-Astoria next Sunday.

PARIS, Nov. 11 -- The tip of the replacement cable for the world's highest aerial cableway has just reached Aiguille du Midi Peak, 12,700 feet up in the French Alps above Chamonix. This is the cableway that was cut by an errant French Air Force jet last Aug. 29.
COLUMBIA, Mo., Nov. 11 (AP) -- Oklahoma's Sooners scored through the air for a 7-0 upset victory over Missouri's Tigers today.
The annual theatre party in, behalf of the Austen Riggs Center of Stockbridge, Mass., will be held at the Jan. 4 performance of "First Love" at the Morosco Theatre.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 11 -- The offering of two amendments to a resolution on apartheid has created a problem for the United States and other Western delegations here.
ST LOUIS, Nov. 11 -- The St. Louis Board of Education has begun a review of the extent and effectiveness of racial integration here since the Supreme Court desegregation decision seven years ago.
RECIFE, Brazil, Nov. 11 -- A billion-dollar program for developing Brazil's northeast, an impoverished area as big as Alaska, is caught up in a bitter fight.

AMHERST, Mass. -- Many of the interesting country inns of New England remain open during the interim period between the departure of the foliage viewers and the invasion of the ski slope worshipers.

ACCRA, Ghana, Nov. 11 -- The Government-controlled Evening News gave lavish praise to Queen Elizabeth II today and hailed her visit to Ghana as a turning point in Commonwealth relations. The Queen and the Duke of Edinburgh began an eleven-day state visit to Ghana Thursday.
Not since the days the American Labor party came to the aid of Fiorello H. LaGuardia has a third party helped tilt the balance in a city election in quite the way the Liberal party did this year.
About 2,000 leaders in the vast food industry will gather here tomorrow for the fifty-third annual meeting of the Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

RECORD collectors are, in the main, a strange, discontented breed. No matter how rich and varied may be the resources readily at hand, they seem driven to seek the broadest possible horizons in the acquisition of new material.

The General Motors Defense Systems Division at Santa Barbara, Calif., is making a detailed study of the basic vehicle types that can be used to explore the moon and planets. The three basic types of land-vehicle locomotion -- wheels, tracks and screws -- have been evaluated as to suitability for the moon's surface and experts in the Land Mobility Laboratory have designed three laboratory models which are being tested.

The "silver question," which has defied solution for almost a century, is thrusting itself to the forefront again in Washington and Wall Street.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) -- A growing number of public schools are changing the way they teach children to read.
Plans to extend the Police Department's downtown traffic-relief program north to Sixty-fifth Street were announced yesterday by Police Commissioner Michael J. Murphy.
DETROIT, Nov. 11 -- The surprise election of 33-year-old Jerome P. Cavanagh as Mayor of Detroit added another young man to the already youthful top ranks of Michigan Democrats.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Nov. 11 (UPI) -- Dave Raimey took Illinois' first punt of the game, ran 54 yards to score and started Michigan to a 38-6 victory over Illinois today. The rout doomed the Illini to their first football season without a home, victory since 1906.
Increasing concern with "illegal" trucking is expected to intensify demands soon for tighter Federal and state regulation of the trucking industry.

BERLIN, Nov. 11 -- Three leading East German newspapers carried articles and letters yesterday and today supporting Walter Ulbricht, chief of the Communist Government, in what appeared to be an atmosphere of mounting criticism against the 68-year-old leader.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Nov. 11 (UPI) -- A reserve quarterback, Tom Batten, playing with an injured hand, connected on three touchdown passes today to lead the Florida Gators to a 21-14 victory over the Georgia Bulldogs.

IF your correspondent, Dr. Paul Clapp, had been less busy one-upping the critic and paid more attention to Harold Pinter's "The Caretaker,'' he would have had no trouble finding meanings in that play.

THE first week of autumn, traditionally the best season for the opening of new artistic works in Paris, held up its reputation as critics and moviegoers cheered Alain Resnais' second feature film, "Last Year at Marienbad," as "the most important motion picture in twenty years."

FORT MYERS, Fla. -- Tourists who have been to this lower Gulf Coast city before and are returning this winter by motor will notice a structural change taking place between the banks of the mile-wide Caloosahatchee River here.

RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 11 -- While most of New Jersey's public schools were closed the last two days for teachers' conventions in Atlantic City, many high school seniors and their parents took to the road on college inspection trips.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Nov. 11 -- Military intelligence sources here estimate that 6,000 Communist troops occupy a number of bases in Cambodia. They said most of these bases were near the border of South Vietnam.

THE writers of this readable, profusely illustrated book point out in many places that a forest is much more titan trees, though they are its chief conditioning agents. It is a vast, intricate "web of interdependence." It is "a community of living things whose lives are inextricably intertwined with one another and bound to their physical environment."

A NAME memorable in the early days of Egyptology, before the decipherments of Jean Champollion and others had lent perspective to the search for Pharaonic antiquities, is that of Giovanni Battista Belzoni (1778-1823), originally of Padua but English by adaption.
